THE MAGNET ATTRACTING: A WAIF AMID FORCES\r\n\r\nWhen Caroline Meeber boarded the afternoon train for Chicago, her total\r\noutfit consisted of a small trunk, a cheap imitation alligator-skin\r\nsatchel, a small lunch in a paper box, and a yellow leather snap purse,\r\ncontaining her ticket, a scrap of paper with her sister\xe2\x80\x99s address in\r\nVan Buren Street, and four dollars in money. It was in August, 1889.\r\nShe was eighteen years of age, bright, timid, and full of the illusions\r\nof ignorance and youth. Whatever touch of regret at parting\r\ncharacterised her thoughts, it was certainly not for advantages now\r\nbeing given up. A gush of tears at her mother\xe2\x80\x99s farewell kiss, a touch\r\nin her throat when the cars clacked by the flour mill where her father\r\nworked by the day, a pathetic sigh as the familiar green environs of\r\nthe village passed in review, and the threads which bound her so\r\nlightly to girlhood and home were irretrievably broken.\r\n\r\nTo be sure there was always the next station, where one might descend\r\nand return. There was the great city, bound more closely by these very\r\ntrains which came up daily. Columbia City was not so very far away,\r\neven once she was in Chicago. What, pray, is a few hours\xe2\x80\x94a few hundred\r\nmiles? She looked at the little slip bearing her sister\xe2\x80\x99s address and\r\nwondered. She gazed at the green landscape, now passing in swift\r\nreview, until her swifter thoughts replaced its impression with vague\r\nconjectures of what Chicago might be.\r\n\r\nWhen a girl leaves her home at eighteen, she does one of two things.\r\nEither she falls into saving hands and becomes better, or she rapidly\r\nassumes the cosmopolitan standard of virtue and becomes worse. Of an\r\nintermediate balance, under the circumstances, there is no possibility.\r\nThe city has its cunning wiles, no less than the infinitely smaller and\r\nmore human tempter. There are large forces which allure with all the\r\nsoulfulness of expression possible in the most cultured human. The\r\ngleam of a thousand lights is often as effective as the persuasive\r\nlight in a wooing and fascinating eye. Half the undoing of the\r\nunsophisticated and natural mind is accomplished by forces wholly\r\nsuperhuman. A blare of sound, a roar of life, a vast array of human\r\nhives, appeal to the astonished senses in equivocal terms. Without a\r\ncounsellor at hand to whisper cautious interpretations, what falsehoods\r\nmay not these things breathe into the unguarded ear! Unrecognised for\r\nwhat they are, their beauty, like music, too often relaxes, then\r\nweakens, then perverts the simpler human perceptions.\r\n\r\nCaroline, or Sister Carrie, as she had been half affectionately termed\r\nby the family, was possessed of a mind rudimentary in its power of\r\nobservation and analysis. Self-interest with her was high, but not\r\nstrong. It was, nevertheless, her guiding characteristic. Warm with the\r\nfancies of youth, pretty with the insipid prettiness of the formative\r\nperiod, possessed of a figure promising eventual shapeliness and an eye\r\nalight with certain native intelligence, she was a fair example of the\r\nmiddle American class\xe2\x80\x94two generations removed from the emigrant. Books\r\nwere beyond her interest\xe2\x80\x94knowledge a sealed book. In the intuitive\r\ngraces she was still crude. She could scarcely toss her head\r\ngracefully. Her hands were almost ineffectual. The feet, though small,\r\nwere set flatly. And yet she was interested in her charms, quick to\r\nunderstand the keener pleasures of life, ambitious to gain in material\r\nthings. A half-equipped little knight she was, venturing to reconnoitre\r\nthe mysterious city and dreaming wild dreams of some vague, far-off\r\nsupremacy, which should make it prey and subject\xe2\x80\x94the proper penitent,\r\ngrovelling at a woman\xe2\x80\x99s slipper.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat,\xe2\x80\x9d said a voice in her ear, \xe2\x80\x9cis one of the prettiest little\r\nresorts in Wisconsin.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it?\xe2\x80\x9d she answered nervously.\r\n\r\nThe train was just pulling out of Waukesha. For some time she had been\r\nconscious of a man behind. She felt him observing her mass of hair. He\r\nhad been fidgetting, and with natural intuition she felt a certain\r\ninterest growing in that quarter. Her maidenly reserve, and a certain\r\nsense of what was conventional under the circumstances, called her to\r\nforestall and deny this familiarity, but the daring and magnetism of\r\nthe individual, born of past experiences and triumphs, prevailed. She\r\nanswered.\r\n\r\nHe leaned forward to put his elbows upon the back of her seat and\r\nproceeded to make himself volubly agreeable.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, that is a great resort for Chicago people. The hotels are swell.\r\nYou are not familiar with this part of the country, are you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes, I am,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Carrie. \xe2\x80\x9cThat is, I live at Columbia City. I\r\nhave never been through here, though.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd so this is your first visit to Chicago,\xe2\x80\x9d he observed.\r\n\r\nAll the time she was conscious of certain features out of the side of\r\nher eye. Flush, colourful cheeks, a light moustache, a grey fedora hat.\r\nShe now turned and looked upon him in full, the instincts of\r\nself-protection and coquetry mingling confusedly in her brain.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI didn\xe2\x80\x99t say that,\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered, in a very pleasing way and with an assumed air of\r\nmistake, \xe2\x80\x9cI thought you did.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHere was a type of the travelling canvasser for a manufacturing house\xe2\x80\x94a\r\nclass which at that time was first being dubbed by the slang of the day\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cdrummers.\xe2\x80\x9d He came within the meaning of a still newer term, which had\r\nsprung into general use among Americans in 1880, and which concisely\r\nexpressed the thought of one whose dress or manners are calculated to\r\nelicit the admiration of susceptible young women\xe2\x80\x94a \xe2\x80\x9cmasher.\xe2\x80\x9d His suit\r\nwas of a striped and crossed pattern of brown wool, new at that time,\r\nbut since become familiar as a business suit. The low crotch of the\r\nvest revealed a stiff shirt bosom of white and pink stripes. From his\r\ncoat sleeves protruded a pair of linen cuffs of the same pattern,\r\nfastened with large, gold plate buttons, set with the common yellow\r\nagates known as \xe2\x80\x9ccat\xe2\x80\x99s-eyes.\xe2\x80\x9d His fingers bore several rings\xe2\x80\x94one, the\r\never-enduring heavy seal\xe2\x80\x94and from his vest dangled a neat gold watch\r\nchain, from which was suspended the secret insignia of the Order of\r\nElks. The whole suit was rather tight-fitting, and was finished off\r\nwith heavy-soled tan shoes, highly polished, and the grey fedora hat.\r\nHe was, for the order of intellect represented, attractive, and\r\nwhatever he had to recommend him, you may be sure was not lost upon\r\nCarrie, in this, her first glance.\r\n\r\nLest this order of individual should permanently pass, let me put down\r\nsome of the most striking characteristics of his most successful manner\r\nand method. Good clothes, of course, were the first essential, the\r\nthings without which he was nothing. A strong physical nature, actuated\r\nby a keen desire for the feminine, was the next. A mind free of any\r\nconsideration of the problems or forces of the world and actuated not\r\nby greed, but an insatiable love of variable pleasure. His method was\r\nalways simple. Its principal element was daring, backed, of course, by\r\nan intense desire and admiration for the sex. Let him meet with a young\r\nwoman once and he would approach her with an air of kindly familiarity,\r\nnot unmixed with pleading, which would result in most cases in a\r\ntolerant acceptance. If she showed any tendency to coquetry he would be\r\napt to straighten her tie, or if she \xe2\x80\x9ctook up\xe2\x80\x9d with him at all, to call\r\nher by her first name. If he visited a department store it was to\r\nlounge familiarly over the counter and ask some leading questions. In\r\nmore exclusive circles, on the train or in waiting stations, he went\r\nslower. If some seemingly vulnerable object appeared he was all\r\nattention\xe2\x80\x94to pass the compliments of the day, to lead the way to the\r\nparlor car, carrying her grip, or, failing that, to take a seat next\r\nher with the hope of being able to court her to her destination.\r\nPillows, books, a footstool, the shade lowered; all these figured in\r\nthe things which he could do. If, when she reached her destination he\r\ndid not alight and attend her baggage for her, it was because, in his\r\nown estimation, he had signally failed.\r\n\r\nA woman should some day write the complete philosophy of clothes. No\r\nmatter how young, it is one of the things she wholly comprehends. There\r\nis an indescribably faint line in the matter of man\xe2\x80\x99s apparel which\r\nsomehow divides for her those who are worth glancing at and those who\r\nare not. Once an individual has passed this faint line on the way\r\ndownward he will get no glance from her. There is another line at which\r\nthe dress of a man will cause her to study her own. This line the\r\nindividual at her elbow now marked for Carrie. She became conscious of\r\nan inequality. Her own plain blue dress, with its black cotton tape\r\ntrimmings, now seemed to her shabby. She felt the worn state of her\r\nshoes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet\xe2\x80\x99s see,\xe2\x80\x9d he went on, \xe2\x80\x9cI know quite a number of people in your town.\r\nMorgenroth the clothier and Gibson the dry goods man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, do you?\xe2\x80\x9d she interrupted, aroused by memories of longings their\r\nshow windows had cost her.\r\n\r\nAt last he had a clew to her interest, and followed it deftly. In a few\r\nminutes he had come about into her seat. He talked of sales of\r\nclothing, his travels, Chicago, and the amusements of that city.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you are going there, you will enjoy it immensely. Have you\r\nrelatives?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am going to visit my sister,\xe2\x80\x9d she explained.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou want to see Lincoln Park,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cand Michigan Boulevard. They\r\nare putting up great buildings there. It\xe2\x80\x99s a second New York\xe2\x80\x94great. So\r\nmuch to see\xe2\x80\x94theatres, crowds, fine houses\xe2\x80\x94oh, you\xe2\x80\x99ll like that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was a little ache in her fancy of all he described. Her\r\ninsignificance in the presence of so much magnificence faintly affected\r\nher. She realised that hers was not to be a round of pleasure, and yet\r\nthere was something promising in all the material prospect he set\r\nforth. There was something satisfactory in the attention of this\r\nindividual with his good clothes. She could not help smiling as he told\r\nher of some popular actress of whom she reminded him. She was not\r\nsilly, and yet attention of this sort had its weight.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will be in Chicago some little time, won\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x9d he observed at\r\none turn of the now easy conversation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie vaguely\xe2\x80\x94a flash vision of the possibility\r\nof her not securing employment rising in her mind.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSeveral weeks, anyhow,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, looking steadily into her eyes.\r\n\r\nThere was much more passing now than the mere words indicated. He\r\nrecognised the indescribable thing that made up for fascination and\r\nbeauty in her. She realised that she was of interest to him from the\r\none standpoint which a woman both delights in and fears. Her manner was\r\nsimple, though for the very reason that she had not yet learned the\r\nmany little affectations with which women conceal their true feelings.\r\nSome things she did appeared bold. A clever companion\xe2\x80\x94had she ever had\r\none\xe2\x80\x94would have warned her never to look a man in the eyes so steadily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy do you ask?\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I\xe2\x80\x99m going to be there several weeks. I\xe2\x80\x99m going to study stock at\r\nour place and get new samples. I might show you \xe2\x80\x99round.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know whether you can or not. I mean I don\xe2\x80\x99t know whether I\r\ncan. I shall be living with my sister, and\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, if she minds, we\xe2\x80\x99ll fix that.\xe2\x80\x9d He took out his pencil and a\r\nlittle pocket note-book as if it were all settled. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat is your\r\naddress there?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe fumbled her purse which contained the address slip.\r\n\r\nHe reached down in his hip pocket and took out a fat purse. It was\r\nfilled with slips of paper, some mileage books, a roll of greenbacks.\r\nIt impressed her deeply. Such a purse had never been carried by any one\r\nattentive to her. Indeed, an experienced traveller, a brisk man of the\r\nworld, had never come within such close range before. The purse, the\r\nshiny tan shoes, the smart new suit, and the air with which he did\r\nthings, built up for her a dim world of fortune, of which he was the\r\ncentre. It disposed her pleasantly toward all he might do.\r\n\r\nHe took out a neat business card, on which was engraved Bartlett,\r\nCaryoe & Company, and down in the left-hand corner, Chas. H. Drouet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s me,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, putting the card in her hand and touching his\r\nname. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s pronounced Drew-eh. Our family was French, on my father\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nside.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe looked at it while he put up his purse. Then he got out a letter\r\nfrom a bunch in his coat pocket. \xe2\x80\x9cThis is the house I travel for,\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nwent on, pointing to a picture on it, \xe2\x80\x9ccorner of State and Lake.\xe2\x80\x9d There\r\nwas pride in his voice. He felt that it was something to be connected\r\nwith such a place, and he made her feel that way.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is your address?\xe2\x80\x9d he began again, fixing his pencil to write.\r\n\r\nShe looked at his hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCarrie Meeber,\xe2\x80\x9d she said slowly. \xe2\x80\x9cThree hundred and fifty-four West\r\nVan Buren Street, care S. C. Hanson.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe wrote it carefully down and got out the purse again. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ll be at\r\nhome if I come around Monday night?\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think so,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered.\r\n\r\nHow true it is that words are but the vague shadows of the volumes we\r\nmean. Little audible links, they are, chaining together great inaudible\r\nfeelings and purposes. Here were these two, bandying little phrases,\r\ndrawing purses, looking at cards, and both unconscious of how\r\ninarticulate all their real feelings were. Neither was wise enough to\r\nbe sure of the working of the mind of the other. He could not tell how\r\nhis luring succeeded. She could not realise that she was drifting,\r\nuntil he secured her address. Now she felt that she had yielded\r\nsomething\xe2\x80\x94he, that he had gained a victory. Already they felt that they\r\nwere somehow associated. Already he took control in directing the\r\nconversation. His words were easy. Her manner was relaxed.\r\n\r\nThey were nearing Chicago. Signs were everywhere numerous. Trains\r\nflashed by them. Across wide stretches of flat, open prairie they could\r\nsee lines of telegraph poles stalking across the fields toward the\r\ngreat city. Far away were indications of suburban towns, some big\r\nsmokestacks towering high in the air.\r\n\r\nFrequently there were two-story frame houses standing out in the open\r\nfields, without fence or trees, lone outposts of the approaching army\r\nof homes.\r\n\r\nTo the child, the genius with imagination, or the wholly untravelled,\r\nthe approach to a great city for the first time is a wonderful thing.\r\nParticularly if it be evening\xe2\x80\x94that mystic period between the glare and\r\ngloom of the world when life is changing from one sphere or condition\r\nto another. Ah, the promise of the night. What does it not hold for the\r\nweary! What old illusion of hope is not here forever repeated! Says the\r\nsoul of the toiler to itself, \xe2\x80\x9cI shall soon be free. I shall be in the\r\nways and the hosts of the merry. The streets, the lamps, the lighted\r\nchamber set for dining, are for me. The theatre, the halls, the\r\nparties, the ways of rest and the paths of song\xe2\x80\x94these are mine in the\r\nnight.\xe2\x80\x9d Though all humanity be still enclosed in the shops, the thrill\r\nruns abroad. It is in the air. The dullest feel something which they\r\nmay not always express or describe. It is the lifting of the burden of\r\ntoil.\r\n\r\nSister Carrie gazed out of the window. Her companion, affected by her\r\nwonder, so contagious are all things, felt anew some interest in the\r\ncity and pointed out its marvels.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is Northwest Chicago,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet. \xe2\x80\x9cThis is the Chicago River,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nand he pointed to a little muddy creek, crowded with the huge masted\r\nwanderers from far-off waters nosing the black-posted banks. With a\r\npuff, a clang, and a clatter of rails it was gone. \xe2\x80\x9cChicago is getting\r\nto be a great town,\xe2\x80\x9d he went on. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a wonder. You\xe2\x80\x99ll find lots to\r\nsee here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe did not hear this very well. Her heart was troubled by a kind of\r\nterror. The fact that she was alone, away from home, rushing into a\r\ngreat sea of life and endeavour, began to tell. She could not help but\r\nfeel a little choked for breath\xe2\x80\x94a little sick as her heart beat so\r\nfast. She half closed her eyes and tried to think it was nothing, that\r\nColumbia City was only a little way off.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cChicago! Chicago!\xe2\x80\x9d called the brakeman, slamming open the door. They\r\nwere rushing into a more crowded yard, alive with the clatter and clang\r\nof life. She began to gather up her poor little grip and closed her\r\nhand firmly upon her purse. Drouet arose, kicked his legs to straighten\r\nhis trousers, and seized his clean yellow grip.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI suppose your people will be here to meet you?\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cLet me\r\ncarry your grip.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d rather you wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t. I\xe2\x80\x99d rather you wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nbe with me when I meet my sister.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right,\xe2\x80\x9d he said in all kindness. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll be near, though, in case\r\nshe isn\xe2\x80\x99t here, and take you out there safely.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re so kind,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, feeling the goodness of such attention\r\nin her strange situation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cChicago!\xe2\x80\x9d called the brakeman, drawing the word out long. They were\r\nunder a great shadowy train shed, where the lamps were already\r\nbeginning to shine out, with passenger cars all about and the train\r\nmoving at a snail\xe2\x80\x99s pace. The people in the car were all up and\r\ncrowding about the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, here we are,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet, leading the way to the door.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood-bye, till I see you Monday.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood-bye,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered, taking his proffered hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRemember, I\xe2\x80\x99ll be looking till you find your sister.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe smiled into his eyes.\r\n\r\nThey filed out, and he affected to take no notice of her. A lean-faced,\r\nrather commonplace woman recognised Carrie on the platform and hurried\r\nforward.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, Sister Carrie!\xe2\x80\x9d she began, and there was embrace of welcome.\r\n\r\nCarrie realised the change of affectional atmosphere at once. Amid all\r\nthe maze, uproar, and novelty she felt cold reality taking her by the\r\nhand. No world of light and merriment. No round of amusement. Her\r\nsister carried with her most of the grimness of shift and toil.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, how are all the folks at home?\xe2\x80\x9d she began; \xe2\x80\x9chow is father, and\r\nmother?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie answered, but was looking away. Down the aisle, toward the gate\r\nleading into the waiting-room and the street, stood Drouet. He was\r\nlooking back. When he saw that she saw him and was safe with her sister\r\nhe turned to go, sending back the shadow of a smile. Only Carrie saw\r\nit. She felt something lost to her when he moved away. When he\r\ndisappeared she felt his absence thoroughly. With her sister she was\r\nmuch alone, a lone figure in a tossing, thoughtless sea.\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter II. WHAT POVERTY THREATENED: OF GRANITE AND BRASS\r\n\r\nMinnie\xe2\x80\x99s flat, as the one-floor resident apartments were then being\r\ncalled, was in a part of West Van Buren Street inhabited by families of\r\nlabourers and clerks, men who had come, and were still coming, with the\r\nrush of population pouring in at the rate of 50,000 a year. It was on\r\nthe third floor, the front windows looking down into the street, where,\r\nat night, the lights of grocery stores were shining and children were\r\nplaying. To Carrie, the sound of the little bells upon the horse-cars,\r\nas they tinkled in and out of hearing, was as pleasing as it was novel.\r\nShe gazed into the lighted street when Minnie brought her into the\r\nfront room, and wondered at the sounds, the movement, the murmur of the\r\nvast city which stretched for miles and miles in every direction.\r\n\r\nMrs. Hanson, after the first greetings were over, gave Carrie the baby\r\nand proceeded to get supper. Her husband asked a few questions and sat\r\ndown to read the evening paper. He was a silent man, American born, of\r\na Swede father, and now employed as a cleaner of refrigerator cars at\r\nthe stock-yards. To him the presence or absence of his wife\xe2\x80\x99s sister\r\nwas a matter of indifference. Her personal appearance did not affect\r\nhim one way or the other. His one observation to the point was\r\nconcerning the chances of work in Chicago.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a big place,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cYou can get in somewhere in a few days.\r\nEverybody does.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt had been tacitly understood beforehand that she was to get work and\r\npay her board. He was of a clean, saving disposition, and had already\r\npaid a number of monthly instalments on two lots far out on the West\r\nSide. His ambition was some day to build a house on them.\r\n\r\nIn the interval which marked the preparation of the meal Carrie found\r\ntime to study the flat. She had some slight gift of observation and\r\nthat sense, so rich in every woman\xe2\x80\x94intuition.\r\n\r\nShe felt the drag of a lean and narrow life. The walls of the rooms\r\nwere discordantly papered. The floors were covered with matting and the\r\nhall laid with a thin rag carpet. One could see that the furniture was\r\nof that poor, hurriedly patched together quality sold by the instalment\r\nhouses.\r\n\r\nShe sat with Minnie, in the kitchen, holding the baby until it began to\r\ncry. Then she walked and sang to it, until Hanson, disturbed in his\r\nreading, came and took it. A pleasant side to his nature came out here.\r\nHe was patient. One could see that he was very much wrapped up in his\r\noffspring.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, now,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, walking. \xe2\x80\x9cThere, there,\xe2\x80\x9d and there was a certain\r\nSwedish accent noticeable in his voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ll want to see the city first, won\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x9d said Minnie, when they\r\nwere eating. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, we\xe2\x80\x99ll go out Sunday and see Lincoln Park.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie noticed that Hanson had said nothing to this. He seemed to be\r\nthinking of something else.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cI think I\xe2\x80\x99ll look around to-morrow. I\xe2\x80\x99ve got Friday\r\nand Saturday, and it won\xe2\x80\x99t be any trouble. Which way is the business\r\npart?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMinnie began to explain, but her husband took this part of the\r\nconversation to himself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s that way,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, pointing east. \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s east.\xe2\x80\x9d Then he went\r\noff into the longest speech he had yet indulged in, concerning the lay\r\nof Chicago. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99d better look in those big manufacturing houses along\r\nFranklin Street and just the other side of the river,\xe2\x80\x9d he concluded.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLots of girls work there. You could get home easy, too. It isn\xe2\x80\x99t very\r\nfar.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie nodded and asked her sister about the neighbourhood. The latter\r\ntalked in a subdued tone, telling the little she knew about it, while\r\nHanson concerned himself with the baby. Finally he jumped up and handed\r\nthe child to his wife.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve got to get up early in the morning, so I\xe2\x80\x99ll go to bed,\xe2\x80\x9d and off\r\nhe went, disappearing into the dark little bedroom off the hall, for\r\nthe night.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe works way down at the stock-yards,\xe2\x80\x9d explained Minnie, \xe2\x80\x9cso he\xe2\x80\x99s got\r\nto get up at half-past five.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat time do you get up to get breakfast?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt about twenty minutes of five.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTogether they finished the labour of the day, Carrie washing the dishes\r\nwhile Minnie undressed the baby and put it to bed. Minnie\xe2\x80\x99s manner was\r\none of trained industry, and Carrie could see that it was a steady\r\nround of toil with her.\r\n\r\nShe began to see that her relations with Drouet would have to be\r\nabandoned. He could not come here. She read from the manner of Hanson,\r\nin the subdued air of Minnie, and, indeed, the whole atmosphere of the\r\nflat, a settled opposition to anything save a conservative round of\r\ntoil. If Hanson sat every evening in the front room and read his paper,\r\nif he went to bed at nine, and Minnie a little later, what would they\r\nexpect of her? She saw that she would first need to get work and\r\nestablish herself on a paying basis before she could think of having\r\ncompany of any sort. Her little flirtation with Drouet seemed now an\r\nextraordinary thing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d she said to herself, \xe2\x80\x9che can\xe2\x80\x99t come here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe asked Minnie for ink and paper, which were upon the mantel in the\r\ndining-room, and when the latter had gone to bed at ten, got out\r\nDrouet\xe2\x80\x99s card and wrote him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI cannot have you call on me here. You will have to wait until you\r\nhear from me again. My sister\xe2\x80\x99s place is so small.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe troubled herself over what else to put in the letter. She wanted to\r\nmake some reference to their relations upon the train, but was too\r\ntimid. She concluded by thanking him for his kindness in a crude way,\r\nthen puzzled over the formality of signing her name, and finally\r\ndecided upon the severe, winding up with a \xe2\x80\x9cVery truly,\xe2\x80\x9d which she\r\nsubsequently changed to \xe2\x80\x9cSincerely.\xe2\x80\x9d She scaled and addressed the\r\nletter, and going in the front room, the alcove of which contained her\r\nbed, drew the one small rocking-chair up to the open window, and sat\r\nlooking out upon the night and streets in silent wonder. Finally,\r\nwearied by her own reflections, she began to grow dull in her chair,\r\nand feeling the need of sleep, arranged her clothing for the night and\r\nwent to bed.\r\n\r\nWhen she awoke at eight the next morning, Hanson had gone. Her sister\r\nwas busy in the dining-room, which was also the sitting-room, sewing.\r\nShe worked, after dressing, to arrange a little breakfast for herself,\r\nand then advised with Minnie as to which way to look. The latter had\r\nchanged considerably since Carrie had seen her. She was now a thin,\r\nthough rugged, woman of twenty-seven, with ideas of life coloured by\r\nher husband\xe2\x80\x99s, and fast hardening into narrower conceptions of pleasure\r\nand duty than had ever been hers in a thoroughly circumscribed youth.\r\nShe had invited Carrie, not because she longed for her presence, but\r\nbecause the latter was dissatisfied at home, and could probably get\r\nwork and pay her board here. She was pleased to see her in a way but\r\nreflected her husband\xe2\x80\x99s point of view in the matter of work. Anything\r\nwas good enough so long as it paid\xe2\x80\x94say, five dollars a week to begin\r\nwith. A shop girl was the destiny prefigured for the newcomer. She\r\nwould get in one of the great shops and do well enough until\xe2\x80\x94well,\r\nuntil something happened. Neither of them knew exactly what. They did\r\nnot figure on promotion. They did not exactly count on marriage. Things\r\nwould go on, though, in a dim kind of way until the better thing would\r\neventuate, and Carrie would be rewarded for coming and toiling in the\r\ncity. It was under such auspicious circumstances that she started out\r\nthis morning to look for work.\r\n\r\nBefore following her in her round of seeking, let us look at the sphere\r\nin which her future was to lie. In 1889 Chicago had the peculiar\r\nqualifications of growth which made such adventuresome pilgrimages even\r\non the part of young girls plausible. Its many and growing commercial\r\nopportunities gave it widespread fame, which made of it a giant magnet,\r\ndrawing to itself, from all quarters, the hopeful and the\r\nhopeless\xe2\x80\x94those who had their fortune yet to make and those whose\r\nfortunes and affairs had reached a disastrous climax elsewhere. It was\r\na city of over 500,000, with the ambition, the daring, the activity of\r\na metropolis of a million. Its streets and houses were already\r\nscattered over an area of seventy-five square miles. Its population was\r\nnot so much thriving upon established commerce as upon the industries\r\nwhich prepared for the arrival of others. The sound of the hammer\r\nengaged upon the erection of new structures was everywhere heard. Great\r\nindustries were moving in. The huge railroad corporations which had\r\nlong before recognised the prospects of the place had seized upon vast\r\ntracts of land for transfer and shipping purposes. Street-car lines had\r\nbeen extended far out into the open country in anticipation of rapid\r\ngrowth. The city had laid miles and miles of streets and sewers through\r\nregions where, perhaps, one solitary house stood out alone\xe2\x80\x94a pioneer of\r\nthe populous ways to be. There were regions open to the sweeping winds\r\nand rain, which were yet lighted throughout the night with long,\r\nblinking lines of gas-lamps, fluttering in the wind. Narrow board walks\r\nextended out, passing here a house, and there a store, at far\r\nintervals, eventually ending on the open prairie.\r\n\r\nIn the central portion was the vast wholesale and shopping district, to\r\nwhich the uninformed seeker for work usually drifted. It was a\r\ncharacteristic of Chicago then, and one not generally shared by other\r\ncities, that individual firms of any pretension occupied individual\r\nbuildings. The presence of ample ground made this possible. It gave an\r\nimposing appearance to most of the wholesale houses, whose offices were\r\nupon the ground floor and in plain view of the street. The large plates\r\nof window glass, now so common, were then rapidly coming into use, and\r\ngave to the ground floor offices a distinguished and prosperous look.\r\nThe casual wanderer could see as he passed a polished array of office\r\nfixtures, much frosted glass, clerks hard at work, and genteel\r\nbusinessmen in \xe2\x80\x9cnobby\xe2\x80\x9d suits and clean linen lounging about or sitting\r\nin groups. Polished brass or nickel signs at the square stone entrances\r\nannounced the firm and the nature of the business in rather neat and\r\nreserved terms. The entire metropolitan centre possessed a high and\r\nmighty air calculated to overawe and abash the common applicant, and to\r\nmake the gulf between poverty and success seem both wide and deep.\r\n\r\nInto this important commercial region the timid Carrie went. She walked\r\neast along Van Buren Street through a region of lessening importance,\r\nuntil it deteriorated into a mass of shanties and coal-yards, and\r\nfinally verged upon the river. She walked bravely forward, led by an\r\nhonest desire to find employment and delayed at every step by the\r\ninterest of the unfolding scene, and a sense of helplessness amid so\r\nmuch evidence of power and force which she did not understand. These\r\nvast buildings, what were they? These strange energies and huge\r\ninterests, for what purposes were they there? She could have understood\r\nthe meaning of a little stone-cutter\xe2\x80\x99s yard at Columbia City, carving\r\nlittle pieces of marble for individual use, but when the yards of some\r\nhuge stone corporation came into view, filled with spur tracks and flat\r\ncars, transpierced by docks from the river and traversed overhead by\r\nimmense trundling cranes of wood and steel, it lost all significance in\r\nher little world.\r\n\r\nIt was so with the vast railroad yards, with the crowded array of\r\nvessels she saw at the river, and the huge factories over the way,\r\nlining the water\xe2\x80\x99s edge. Through the open windows she could see the\r\nfigures of men and women in working aprons, moving busily about. The\r\ngreat streets were wall-lined mysteries to her; the vast offices,\r\nstrange mazes which concerned far-off individuals of importance. She\r\ncould only think of people connected with them as counting money,\r\ndressing magnificently, and riding in carriages. What they dealt in,\r\nhow they laboured, to what end it all came, she had only the vaguest\r\nconception. It was all wonderful, all vast, all far removed, and she\r\nsank in spirit inwardly and fluttered feebly at the heart as she\r\nthought of entering any one of these mighty concerns and asking for\r\nsomething to do\xe2\x80\x94something that she could do\xe2\x80\x94anything.\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter III. WEE QUESTION OF FORTUNE: FOUR-FIFTY A WEEK\r\n\r\nOnce across the river and into the wholesale district, she glanced\r\nabout her for some likely door at which to apply. As she contemplated\r\nthe wide windows and imposing signs, she became conscious of being\r\ngazed upon and understood for what she was\xe2\x80\x94a wage-seeker. She had never\r\ndone this thing before, and lacked courage. To avoid a certain\r\nindefinable shame she felt at being caught spying about for a position,\r\nshe quickened her steps and assumed an air of indifference supposedly\r\ncommon to one upon an errand. In this way she passed many manufacturing\r\nand wholesale houses without once glancing in. At last, after several\r\nblocks of walking, she felt that this would not do, and began to look\r\nabout again, though without relaxing her pace. A little way on she saw\r\na great door which, for some reason, attracted her attention. It was\r\nornamented by a small brass sign, and seemed to be the entrance to a\r\nvast hive of six or seven floors. \xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps,\xe2\x80\x9d she thought, \xe2\x80\x9cthey may\r\nwant some one,\xe2\x80\x9d and crossed over to enter. When she came within a score\r\nof feet of the desired goal, she saw through the window a young man in\r\na grey checked suit. That he had anything to do with the concern, she\r\ncould not tell, but because he happened to be looking in her direction\r\nher weakening heart misgave her and she hurried by, too overcome with\r\nshame to enter. Over the way stood a great six-story structure,\r\nlabelled Storm and King, which she viewed with rising hope. It was a\r\nwholesale dry goods concern and employed women. She could see them\r\nmoving about now and then upon the upper floors. This place she decided\r\nto enter, no matter what. She crossed over and walked directly toward\r\nthe entrance. As she did so, two men came out and paused in the door. A\r\ntelegraph messenger in blue dashed past her and up the few steps that\r\nled to the entrance and disappeared. Several pedestrians out of the\r\nhurrying throng which filled the sidewalks passed about her as she\r\npaused, hesitating. She looked helplessly around, and then, seeing\r\nherself observed, retreated. It was too difficult a task. She could not\r\ngo past them.\r\n\r\nSo severe a defeat told sadly upon her nerves. Her feet carried her\r\nmechanically forward, every foot of her progress being a satisfactory\r\nportion of a flight which she gladly made. Block after block passed by.\r\nUpon streetlamps at the various corners she read names such as Madison,\r\nMonroe, La Salle, Clark, Dearborn, State, and still she went, her feet\r\nbeginning to tire upon the broad stone flagging. She was pleased in\r\npart that the streets were bright and clean. The morning sun, shining\r\ndown with steadily increasing warmth, made the shady side of the\r\nstreets pleasantly cool. She looked at the blue sky overhead with more\r\nrealisation of its charm than had ever come to her before.\r\n\r\nHer cowardice began to trouble her in a way. She turned back, resolving\r\nto hunt up Storm and King and enter. On the way, she encountered a\r\ngreat wholesale shoe company, through the broad plate windows of which\r\nshe saw an enclosed executive department, hidden by frosted glass.\r\nWithout this enclosure, but just within the street entrance, sat a\r\ngrey-haired gentleman at a small table, with a large open ledger before\r\nhim. She walked by this institution several times hesitating, but,\r\nfinding herself unobserved, faltered past the screen door and stood\r\nhumbly waiting.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, young lady,\xe2\x80\x9d observed the old gentleman, looking at her somewhat\r\nkindly, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat is it you wish?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am, that is, do you\xe2\x80\x94I mean, do you need any help?\xe2\x80\x9d she stammered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot just at present,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered smiling. \xe2\x80\x9cNot just at present. Come\r\nin some time next week. Occasionally we need some one.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe received the answer in silence and backed awkwardly out. The\r\npleasant nature of her reception rather astonished her. She had\r\nexpected that it would be more difficult, that something cold and harsh\r\nwould be said\xe2\x80\x94she knew not what. That she had not been put to shame and\r\nmade to feel her unfortunate position, seemed remarkable.\r\n\r\nSomewhat encouraged, she ventured into another large structure. It was\r\na clothing company, and more people were in evidence\xe2\x80\x94well-dressed men\r\nof forty and more, surrounded by brass railings.\r\n\r\nAn office boy approached her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho is it you wish to see?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI want to see the manager,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. He ran away and spoke to one of\r\na group of three men who were conferring together. One of these came\r\ntowards her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d he said coldly. The greeting drove all courage from her at\r\nonce.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you need any help?\xe2\x80\x9d she stammered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d he replied abruptly, and turned upon his heel.\r\n\r\nShe went foolishly out, the office boy deferentially swinging the door\r\nfor her, and gladly sank into the obscuring crowd. It was a severe\r\nsetback to her recently pleased mental state.\r\n\r\nNow she walked quite aimlessly for a time, turning here and there,\r\nseeing one great company after another, but finding no courage to\r\nprosecute her single inquiry. High noon came, and with it hunger. She\r\nhunted out an unassuming restaurant and entered, but was disturbed to\r\nfind that the prices were exorbitant for the size of her purse. A bowl\r\nof soup was all that she could afford, and, with this quickly eaten,\r\nshe went out again. It restored her strength somewhat and made her\r\nmoderately bold to pursue the search.\r\n\r\nIn walking a few blocks to fix upon some probable place, she again\r\nencountered the firm of Storm and King, and this time managed to get\r\nin. Some gentlemen were conferring close at hand, but took no notice of\r\nher. She was left standing, gazing nervously upon the floor. When the\r\nlimit of her distress had been nearly reached, she was beckoned to by a\r\nman at one of the many desks within the near-by railing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho is it you wish to see?\xe2\x80\x9d he required.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, any one, if you please,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered. \xe2\x80\x9cI am looking for\r\nsomething to do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, you want to see Mr. McManus,\xe2\x80\x9d he returned. \xe2\x80\x9cSit down,\xe2\x80\x9d and he\r\npointed to a chair against the neighbouring wall. He went on leisurely\r\nwriting, until after a time a short, stout gentleman came in from the\r\nstreet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. McManus,\xe2\x80\x9d called the man at the desk, \xe2\x80\x9cthis young woman wants to\r\nsee you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe short gentleman turned about towards Carrie, and she arose and came\r\nforward.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat can I do for you, miss?\xe2\x80\x9d he inquired, surveying her curiously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI want to know if I can get a position,\xe2\x80\x9d she inquired.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs what?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot as anything in particular,\xe2\x80\x9d she faltered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you ever had any experience in the wholesale dry goods business?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nhe questioned.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d she replied.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you a stenographer or typewriter?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, we haven\xe2\x80\x99t anything here,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cWe employ only experienced\r\nhelp.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe began to step backward toward the door, when something about her\r\nplaintive face attracted him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you ever worked at anything before?\xe2\x80\x9d he inquired.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, now, it\xe2\x80\x99s hardly possible that you would get anything to do in a\r\nwholesale house of this kind. Have you tried the department stores?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe acknowledged that she had not.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, if I were you,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, looking at her rather genially, \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nwould try the department stores. They often need young women as\r\nclerks.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, her whole nature relieved by this spark of\r\nfriendly interest.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, as she moved toward the door, \xe2\x80\x9cyou try the department\r\nstores,\xe2\x80\x9d and off he went.\r\n\r\nAt that time the department store was in its earliest form of\r\nsuccessful operation, and there were not many. The first three in the\r\nUnited States, established about 1884, were in Chicago. Carrie was\r\nfamiliar with the names of several through the advertisements in the\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDaily News,\xe2\x80\x9d and now proceeded to seek them. The words of Mr. McManus\r\nhad somehow managed to restore her courage, which had fallen low, and\r\nshe dared to hope that this new line would offer her something. Some\r\ntime she spent in wandering up and down, thinking to encounter the\r\nbuildings by chance, so readily is the mind, bent upon prosecuting a\r\nhard but needful errand, eased by that self-deception which the\r\nsemblance of search, without the reality, gives. At last she inquired\r\nof a police officer, and was directed to proceed \xe2\x80\x9ctwo blocks up,\xe2\x80\x9d where\r\nshe would find \xe2\x80\x9cThe Fair.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe nature of these vast retail combinations, should they ever\r\npermanently disappear, will form an interesting chapter in the\r\ncommercial history of our nation. Such a flowering out of a modest\r\ntrade principle the world had never witnessed up to that time. They\r\nwere along the line of the most effective retail organisation, with\r\nhundreds of stores coordinated into one and laid out upon the most\r\nimposing and economic basis. They were handsome, bustling, successful\r\naffairs, with a host of clerks and a swarm of patrons. Carrie passed\r\nalong the busy aisles, much affected by the remarkable displays of\r\ntrinkets, dress goods, stationery, and jewelry. Each separate counter\r\nwas a show place of dazzling interest and attraction. She could not\r\nhelp feeling the claim of each trinket and valuable upon her\r\npersonally, and yet she did not stop. There was nothing there which she\r\ncould not have used\xe2\x80\x94nothing which she did not long to own. The dainty\r\nslippers and stockings, the delicately frilled skirts and petticoats,\r\nthe laces, ribbons, hair-combs, purses, all touched her with individual\r\ndesire, and she felt keenly the fact that not any of these things were\r\nin the range of her purchase. She was a work-seeker, an outcast without\r\nemployment, one whom the average employee could tell at a glance was\r\npoor and in need of a situation.\r\n\r\nIt must not be thought that any one could have mistaken her for a\r\nnervous, sensitive, high-strung nature, cast unduly upon a cold,\r\ncalculating, and unpoetic world. Such certainly she was not. But women\r\nare peculiarly sensitive to their adornment.\r\n\r\nNot only did Carrie feel the drag of desire for all which was new and\r\npleasing in apparel for women, but she noticed too, with a touch at the\r\nheart, the fine ladies who elbowed and ignored her, brushing past in\r\nutter disregard of her presence, themselves eagerly enlisted in the\r\nmaterials which the store contained. Carrie was not familiar with the\r\nappearance of her more fortunate sisters of the city. Neither had she\r\nbefore known the nature and appearance of the shop girls with whom she\r\nnow compared poorly. They were pretty in the main, some even handsome,\r\nwith an air of independence and indifference which added, in the case\r\nof the more favoured, a certain piquancy. Their clothes were neat, in\r\nmany instances fine, and wherever she encountered the eye of one it was\r\nonly to recognise in it a keen analysis of her own position\xe2\x80\x94her\r\nindividual shortcomings of dress and that shadow of _manner_ which she\r\nthought must hang about her and make clear to all who and what she was.\r\nA flame of envy lighted in her heart. She realised in a dim way how\r\nmuch the city held\xe2\x80\x94wealth, fashion, ease\xe2\x80\x94every adornment for women, and\r\nshe longed for dress and beauty with a whole heart.\r\n\r\nOn the second floor were the managerial offices, to which, after some\r\ninquiry, she was now directed. There she found other girls ahead of\r\nher, applicants like herself, but with more of that self-satisfied and\r\nindependent air which experience of the city lends; girls who\r\nscrutinised her in a painful manner. After a wait of perhaps\r\nthree-quarters of an hour, she was called in turn.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow,\xe2\x80\x9d said a sharp, quick-mannered Jew, who was sitting at a roll-top\r\ndesk near the window, \xe2\x80\x9chave you ever worked in any other store?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, you haven\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, eyeing her keenly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d she replied.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, we prefer young women just now with some experience. I guess we\r\ncan\xe2\x80\x99t use you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie stood waiting a moment, hardly certain whether the interview had\r\nterminated.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t wait!\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed. \xe2\x80\x9cRemember we are very busy here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie began to move quickly to the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHold on,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, calling her back. \xe2\x80\x9cGive me your name and address.\r\nWe want girls occasionally.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhen she had gotten safely into the street, she could scarcely restrain\r\nthe tears. It was not so much the particular rebuff which she had just\r\nexperienced, but the whole abashing trend of the day. She was tired and\r\nnervous. She abandoned the thought of appealing to the other department\r\nstores and now wandered on, feeling a certain safety and relief in\r\nmingling with the crowd.\r\n\r\nIn her indifferent wandering she turned into Jackson Street, not far\r\nfrom the river, and was keeping her way along the south side of that\r\nimposing thoroughfare, when a piece of wrapping paper, written on with\r\nmarking ink and tacked up on the door, attracted her attention. It\r\nread, \xe2\x80\x9cGirls wanted\xe2\x80\x94wrappers & stitchers.\xe2\x80\x9d She hesitated a moment, then\r\nentered.\r\n\r\nThe firm of Speigelheim & Co., makers of boys\xe2\x80\x99 caps, occupied one floor\r\nof the building, fifty feet in width and some eighty feet in depth. It\r\nwas a place rather dingily lighted, the darkest portions having\r\nincandescent lights, filled with machines and work benches. At the\r\nlatter laboured quite a company of girls and some men. The former were\r\ndrabby-looking creatures, stained in face with oil and dust, clad in\r\nthin, shapeless, cotton dresses and shod with more or less worn shoes.\r\nMany of them had their sleeves rolled up, revealing bare arms, and in\r\nsome cases, owing to the heat, their dresses were open at the neck.\r\nThey were a fair type of nearly the lowest order of\r\nshop-girls\xe2\x80\x94careless, slouchy, and more or less pale from confinement.\r\nThey were not timid, however; were rich in curiosity, and strong in\r\ndaring and slang.\r\n\r\nCarrie looked about her, very much disturbed and quite sure that she\r\ndid not want to work here. Aside from making her uncomfortable by\r\nsidelong glances, no one paid her the least attention. She waited until\r\nthe whole department was aware of her presence. Then some word was sent\r\naround, and a foreman, in an apron and shirt sleeves, the latter rolled\r\nup to his shoulders, approached.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you want to see me?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you need any help?\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, already learning directness of\r\naddress.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know how to stitch caps?\xe2\x80\x9d he returned.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d she replied.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you ever had any experience at this kind of work?\xe2\x80\x9d he inquired.\r\n\r\nShe answered that she had not.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said the foreman, scratching his ear meditatively, \xe2\x80\x9cwe do need\r\na stitcher. We like experienced help, though. We\xe2\x80\x99ve hardly got time to\r\nbreak people in.\xe2\x80\x9d He paused and looked away out of the window. \xe2\x80\x9cWe\r\nmight, though, put you at finishing,\xe2\x80\x9d he concluded reflectively.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow much do you pay a week?\xe2\x80\x9d ventured Carrie, emboldened by a certain\r\nsoftness in the man\xe2\x80\x99s manner and his simplicity of address.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThree and a half,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh,\xe2\x80\x9d she was about to exclaim, but checked herself and allowed her\r\nthoughts to die without expression.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re not exactly in need of anybody,\xe2\x80\x9d he went on vaguely, looking her\r\nover as one would a package. \xe2\x80\x9cYou can come on Monday morning, though,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nhe added, \xe2\x80\x9cand I\xe2\x80\x99ll put you to work.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie weakly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you come, bring an apron,\xe2\x80\x9d he added.\r\n\r\nHe walked away and left her standing by the elevator, never so much as\r\ninquiring her name.\r\n\r\nWhile the appearance of the shop and the announcement of the price paid\r\nper week operated very much as a blow to Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s fancy, the fact that\r\nwork of any kind was offered after so rude a round of experience was\r\ngratifying. She could not begin to believe that she would take the\r\nplace, modest as her aspirations were. She had been used to better than\r\nthat. Her mere experience and the free out-of-door life of the country\r\ncaused her nature to revolt at such confinement. Dirt had never been\r\nher share. Her sister\xe2\x80\x99s flat was clean. This place was grimy and low,\r\nthe girls were careless and hardened. They must be bad-minded and\r\nhearted, she imagined. Still, a place had been offered her. Surely\r\nChicago was not so bad if she could find one place in one day. She\r\nmight find another and better later.\r\n\r\nHer subsequent experiences were not of a reassuring nature, however.\r\nFrom all the more pleasing or imposing places she was turned away\r\nabruptly with the most chilling formality. In others where she applied\r\nonly the experienced were required. She met with painful rebuffs, the\r\nmost trying of which had been in a manufacturing cloak house, where she\r\nhad gone to the fourth floor to inquire.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no,\xe2\x80\x9d said the foreman, a rough, heavily built individual, who\r\nlooked after a miserably lighted workshop, \xe2\x80\x9cwe don\xe2\x80\x99t want any one.\r\nDon\xe2\x80\x99t come here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith the wane of the afternoon went her hopes, her courage, and her\r\nstrength. She had been astonishingly persistent. So earnest an effort\r\nwas well deserving of a better reward. On every hand, to her fatigued\r\nsenses, the great business portion grew larger, harder, more stolid in\r\nits indifference. It seemed as if it was all closed to her, that the\r\nstruggle was too fierce for her to hope to do anything at all. Men and\r\nwomen hurried by in long, shifting lines. She felt the flow of the tide\r\nof effort and interest\xe2\x80\x94felt her own helplessness without quite\r\nrealising the wisp on the tide that she was. She cast about vainly for\r\nsome possible place to apply, but found no door which she had the\r\ncourage to enter. It would be the same thing all over. The old\r\nhumiliation of her plea, rewarded by curt denial. Sick at heart and in\r\nbody, she turned to the west, the direction of Minnie\xe2\x80\x99s flat, which she\r\nhad now fixed in mind, and began that wearisome, baffled retreat which\r\nthe seeker for employment at nightfall too often makes. In passing\r\nthrough Fifth Avenue, south towards Van Buren Street, where she\r\nintended to take a car, she passed the door of a large wholesale shoe\r\nhouse, through the plate-glass windows of which she could see a\r\nmiddle-aged gentleman sitting at a small desk. One of those forlorn\r\nimpulses which often grow out of a fixed sense of defeat, the last\r\nsprouting of a baffled and uprooted growth of ideas, seized upon her.\r\nShe walked deliberately through the door and up to the gentleman, who\r\nlooked at her weary face with partially awakened interest.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it?\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan you give me something to do?\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, I really don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d he said kindly. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat kind of work is it\r\nyou want\xe2\x80\x94you\xe2\x80\x99re not a typewriter, are you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, we only employ book-keepers and typewriters here. You might go\r\naround to the side and inquire upstairs. They did want some help\r\nupstairs a few days ago. Ask for Mr. Brown.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe hastened around to the side entrance and was taken up by the\r\nelevator to the fourth floor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCall Mr. Brown, Willie,\xe2\x80\x9d said the elevator man to a boy near by.\r\n\r\nWillie went off and presently returned with the information that Mr.\r\nBrown said she should sit down and that he would be around in a little\r\nwhile.\r\n\r\nIt was a portion of the stock room which gave no idea of the general\r\ncharacter of the place, and Carrie could form no opinion of the nature\r\nof the work.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo you want something to do,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Brown, after he inquired\r\nconcerning the nature of her errand. \xe2\x80\x9cHave you ever been employed in a\r\nshoe factory before?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is your name?\xe2\x80\x9d he inquired, and being informed, \xe2\x80\x9cWell, I don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nknow as I have anything for you. Would you work for four and a half a\r\nweek?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie was too worn by defeat not to feel that it was considerable. She\r\nhad not expected that he would offer her less than six. She acquiesced,\r\nhowever, and he took her name and address.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, finally, \xe2\x80\x9cyou report here at eight o\xe2\x80\x99clock Monday\r\nmorning. I think I can find something for you to do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe left her revived by the possibilities, sure that she had found\r\nsomething at last. Instantly the blood crept warmly over her body. Her\r\nnervous tension relaxed. She walked out into the busy street and\r\ndiscovered a new atmosphere. Behold, the throng was moving with a\r\nlightsome step. She noticed that men and women were smiling. Scraps of\r\nconversation and notes of laughter floated to her. The air was light.\r\nPeople were already pouring out of the buildings, their labour ended\r\nfor the day. She noticed that they were pleased, and thoughts of her\r\nsister\xe2\x80\x99s home and the meal that would be awaiting her quickened her\r\nsteps. She hurried on, tired perhaps, but no longer weary of foot. What\r\nwould not Minnie say! Ah, the long winter in Chicago\xe2\x80\x94the lights, the\r\ncrowd, the amusement! This was a great, pleasing metropolis after all.\r\nHer new firm was a goodly institution. Its windows were of huge plate\r\nglass. She could probably do well there. Thoughts of Drouet returned\xe2\x80\x94of\r\nthe things he had told her. She now felt that life was better, that it\r\nwas livelier, sprightlier. She boarded a car in the best of spirits,\r\nfeeling her blood still flowing pleasantly. She would live in Chicago,\r\nher mind kept saying to itself. She would have a better time than she\r\nhad ever had before\xe2\x80\x94she would be happy.\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter IV. THE SPENDINGS OF FANCY: FACTS ANSWER WITH SNEERS\r\n\r\nFor the next two days Carrie indulged in the most high-flown\r\nspeculations.\r\n\r\nHer fancy plunged recklessly into privileges and amusements which would\r\nhave been much more becoming had she been cradled a child of fortune.\r\nWith ready will and quick mental selection she scattered her meagre\r\nfour-fifty per week with a swift and graceful hand. Indeed, as she sat\r\nin her rocking-chair these several evenings before going to bed and\r\nlooked out upon the pleasantly lighted street, this money cleared for\r\nits prospective possessor the way to every joy and every bauble which\r\nthe heart of woman may desire. \xe2\x80\x9cI will have a fine time,\xe2\x80\x9d she thought.\r\n\r\nHer sister Minnie knew nothing of these rather wild cerebrations,\r\nthough they exhausted the markets of delight. She was too busy\r\nscrubbing the kitchen woodwork and calculating the purchasing power of\r\neighty cents for Sunday\xe2\x80\x99s dinner. When Carrie had returned home,\r\nflushed with her first success and ready, for all her weariness, to\r\ndiscuss the now interesting events which led up to her achievement, the\r\nformer had merely smiled approvingly and inquired whether she would\r\nhave to spend any of it for car fare. This consideration had not\r\nentered in before, and it did not now for long affect the glow of\r\nCarrie\xe2\x80\x99s enthusiasm. Disposed as she then was to calculate upon that\r\nvague basis which allows the subtraction of one sum from another\r\nwithout any perceptible diminution, she was happy.\r\n\r\nWhen Hanson came home at seven o\xe2\x80\x99clock, he was inclined to be a little\r\ncrusty\xe2\x80\x94his usual demeanour before supper. This never showed so much in\r\nanything he said as in a certain solemnity of countenance and the\r\nsilent manner in which he slopped about. He had a pair of yellow carpet\r\nslippers which he enjoyed wearing, and these he would immediately\r\nsubstitute for his solid pair of shoes. This, and washing his face with\r\nthe aid of common washing soap until it glowed a shiny red, constituted\r\nhis only preparation for his evening meal. He would then get his\r\nevening paper and read in silence.\r\n\r\nFor a young man, this was rather a morbid turn of character, and so\r\naffected Carrie. Indeed, it affected the entire atmosphere of the flat,\r\nas such things are inclined to do, and gave to his wife\xe2\x80\x99s mind its\r\nsubdued and tactful turn, anxious to avoid taciturn replies. Under the\r\ninfluence of Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s announcement he brightened up somewhat.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou didn\xe2\x80\x99t lose any time, did you?\xe2\x80\x9d he remarked, smiling a little.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Carrie with a touch of pride.\r\n\r\nHe asked her one or two more questions and then turned to play with the\r\nbaby, leaving the subject until it was brought up again by Minnie at\r\nthe table.\r\n\r\nCarrie, however, was not to be reduced to the common level of\r\nobservation which prevailed in the flat.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt seems to be such a large company,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, at one place.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGreat big plate-glass windows and lots of clerks. The man I saw said\r\nthey hired ever so many people.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s not very hard to get work now,\xe2\x80\x9d put in Hanson, \xe2\x80\x9cif you look\r\nright.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMinnie, under the warming influence of Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s good spirits and her\r\nhusband\xe2\x80\x99s somewhat conversational mood, began to tell Carrie of some of\r\nthe well-known things to see\xe2\x80\x94things the enjoyment of which cost\r\nnothing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99d like to see Michigan Avenue. There are such fine houses. It is\r\nsuch a fine street.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere is H. R. Jacob\xe2\x80\x99s?\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted Carrie, mentioning one of the\r\ntheatres devoted to melodrama which went by that name at the time.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, it\xe2\x80\x99s not very far from here,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Minnie. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s in Halstead\r\nStreet, right up here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow I\xe2\x80\x99d like to go there. I crossed Halstead Street to-day, didn\xe2\x80\x99t I?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this there was a slight halt in the natural reply. Thoughts are a\r\nstrangely permeating factor. At her suggestion of going to the theatre,\r\nthe unspoken shade of disapproval to the doing of those things which\r\ninvolved the expenditure of money\xe2\x80\x94shades of feeling which arose in the\r\nmind of Hanson and then in Minnie\xe2\x80\x94slightly affected the atmosphere of\r\nthe table. Minnie answered \xe2\x80\x9cyes,\xe2\x80\x9d but Carrie could feel that going to\r\nthe theatre was poorly advocated here. The subject was put off for a\r\nlittle while until Hanson, through with his meal, took his paper and\r\nwent into the front room.\r\n\r\nWhen they were alone, the two sisters began a somewhat freer\r\nconversation, Carrie interrupting it to hum a little, as they worked at\r\nthe dishes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI should like to walk up and see Halstead Street, if it isn\xe2\x80\x99t too\r\nfar,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, after a time. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy don\xe2\x80\x99t we go to the theatre\r\nto-night?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I don\xe2\x80\x99t think Sven would want to go to-night,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Minnie.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe has to get up so early.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t mind\xe2\x80\x94he\xe2\x80\x99d enjoy it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, he doesn\xe2\x80\x99t go very often,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Minnie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I\xe2\x80\x99d like to go,\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined Carrie. \xe2\x80\x9cLet\xe2\x80\x99s you and me go.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMinnie pondered a while, not upon whether she could or would go\xe2\x80\x94for\r\nthat point was already negatively settled with her\xe2\x80\x94but upon some means\r\nof diverting the thoughts of her sister to some other topic.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ll go some other time,\xe2\x80\x9d she said at last, finding no ready means of\r\nescape.\r\n\r\nCarrie sensed the root of the opposition at once.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have some money,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cYou go with me.\xe2\x80\x9d Minnie shook her head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe could go along,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Minnie softly, and rattling the dishes to drown the\r\nconversation. \xe2\x80\x9cHe wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt had been several years since Minnie had seen Carrie, and in that\r\ntime the latter\xe2\x80\x99s character had developed a few shades. Naturally timid\r\nin all things that related to her own advancement, and especially so\r\nwhen without power or resource, her craving for pleasure was so strong\r\nthat it was the one stay of her nature. She would speak for that when\r\nsilent on all else.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAsk him,\xe2\x80\x9d she pleaded softly.\r\n\r\nMinnie was thinking of the resource which Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s board would add. It\r\nwould pay the rent and would make the subject of expenditure a little\r\nless difficult to talk about with her husband. But if Carrie was going\r\nto think of running around in the beginning there would be a hitch\r\nsomewhere. Unless Carrie submitted to a solemn round of industry and\r\nsaw the need of hard work without longing for play, how was her coming\r\nto the city to profit them? These thoughts were not those of a cold,\r\nhard nature at all. They were the serious reflections of a mind which\r\ninvariably adjusted itself, without much complaining, to such\r\nsurroundings as its industry could make for it.\r\n\r\nAt last she yielded enough to ask Hanson. It was a half-hearted\r\nprocedure without a shade of desire on her part.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCarrie wants us to go to the theatre,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, looking in upon her\r\nhusband. Hanson looked up from his paper, and they exchanged a mild\r\nlook, which said as plainly as anything: \xe2\x80\x9cThis isn\xe2\x80\x99t what we expected.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t care to go,\xe2\x80\x9d he returned. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat does she want to see?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cH. R. Jacob\xe2\x80\x99s,\xe2\x80\x9d said Minnie.\r\n\r\nHe looked down at his paper and shook his head negatively.\r\n\r\nWhen Carrie saw how they looked upon her proposition, she gained a\r\nstill clearer feeling of their way of life. It weighed on her, but took\r\nno definite form of opposition.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think I\xe2\x80\x99ll go down and stand at the foot of the stairs,\xe2\x80\x9d she said,\r\nafter a time.\r\n\r\nMinnie made no objection to this, and Carrie put on her hat and went\r\nbelow.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere has Carrie gone?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Hanson, coming back into the dining-room\r\nwhen he heard the door close.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe said she was going down to the foot of the stairs,\xe2\x80\x9d answered\r\nMinnie. \xe2\x80\x9cI guess she just wants to look out a while.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe oughtn\xe2\x80\x99t to be thinking about spending her money on theatres\r\nalready, do you think?\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe just feels a little curious, I guess,\xe2\x80\x9d ventured Minnie.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEverything is so new.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hanson, and went over to the baby, his forehead\r\nslightly wrinkled.\r\n\r\nHe was thinking of a full career of vanity and wastefulness which a\r\nyoung girl might indulge in, and wondering how Carrie could contemplate\r\nsuch a course when she had so little, as yet, with which to do.\r\n\r\nOn Saturday Carrie went out by herself\xe2\x80\x94first toward the river, which\r\ninterested her, and then back along Jackson Street, which was then\r\nlined by the pretty houses and fine lawns which subsequently caused it\r\nto be made into a boulevard. She was struck with the evidences of\r\nwealth, although there was, perhaps, not a person on the street worth\r\nmore than a hundred thousand dollars. She was glad to be out of the\r\nflat, because already she felt that it was a narrow, humdrum place, and\r\nthat interest and joy lay elsewhere. Her thoughts now were of a more\r\nliberal character, and she punctuated them with speculations as to the\r\nwhereabouts of Drouet. She was not sure but that he might call anyhow\r\nMonday night, and, while she felt a little disturbed at the\r\npossibility, there was, nevertheless, just the shade of a wish that he\r\nwould.\r\n\r\nOn Monday she arose early and prepared to go to work. She dressed\r\nherself in a worn shirt-waist of dotted blue percale, a skirt of\r\nlight-brown serge rather faded, and a small straw hat which she had\r\nworn all summer at Columbia City. Her shoes were old, and her necktie\r\nwas in that crumpled, flattened state which time and much wearing\r\nimpart. She made a very average looking shop-girl with the exception of\r\nher features. These were slightly more even than common, and gave her a\r\nsweet, reserved, and pleasing appearance.\r\n\r\nIt is no easy thing to get up early in the morning when one is used to\r\nsleeping until seven and eight, as Carrie had been at home. She gained\r\nsome inkling of the character of Hanson\xe2\x80\x99s life when, half asleep, she\r\nlooked out into the dining-room at six o\xe2\x80\x99clock and saw him silently\r\nfinishing his breakfast. By the time she was dressed he was gone, and\r\nshe, Minnie, and the baby ate together, the latter being just old\r\nenough to sit in a high chair and disturb the dishes with a spoon. Her\r\nspirits were greatly subdued now when the fact of entering upon strange\r\nand untried duties confronted her. Only the ashes of all her fine\r\nfancies were remaining\xe2\x80\x94ashes still concealing, nevertheless, a few red\r\nembers of hope. So subdued was she by her weakening nerves, that she\r\nate quite in silence going over imaginary conceptions of the character\r\nof the shoe company, the nature of the work, her employer\xe2\x80\x99s attitude.\r\nShe was vaguely feeling that she would come in contact with the great\r\nowners, that her work would be where grave, stylishly dressed men\r\noccasionally look on.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, good luck,\xe2\x80\x9d said Minnie, when she was ready to go. They had\r\nagreed it was best to walk, that morning at least, to see if she could\r\ndo it every day\xe2\x80\x94sixty cents a week for car fare being quite an item\r\nunder the circumstances.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you how it goes to-night,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\nOnce in the sunlit street, with labourers tramping by in either\r\ndirection, the horse-cars passing crowded to the rails with the small\r\nclerks and floor help in the great wholesale houses, and men and women\r\ngenerally coming out of doors and passing about the neighbourhood,\r\nCarrie felt slightly reassured. In the sunshine of the morning, beneath\r\nthe wide, blue heavens, with a fresh wind astir, what fears, except the\r\nmost desperate, can find a harbourage? In the night, or the gloomy\r\nchambers of the day, fears and misgivings wax strong, but out in the\r\nsunlight there is, for a time, cessation even of the terror of death.\r\n\r\nCarrie went straight forward until she crossed the river, and then\r\nturned into Fifth Avenue. The thoroughfare, in this part, was like a\r\nwalled canon of brown stone and dark red brick. The big windows looked\r\nshiny and clean. Trucks were rumbling in increasing numbers; men and\r\nwomen, girls and boys were moving onward in all directions. She met\r\ngirls of her own age, who looked at her as if with contempt for her\r\ndiffidence. She wondered at the magnitude of this life and at the\r\nimportance of knowing much in order to do anything in it at all. Dread\r\nat her own inefficiency crept upon her. She would not know how, she\r\nwould not be quick enough. Had not all the other places refused her\r\nbecause she did not know something or other? She would be scolded,\r\nabused, ignominiously discharged.\r\n\r\nIt was with weak knees and a slight catch in her breathing that she\r\ncame up to the great shoe company at Adams and Fifth Avenue and entered\r\nthe elevator. When she stepped out on the fourth floor there was no one\r\nat hand, only great aisles of boxes piled to the ceiling. She stood,\r\nvery much frightened, awaiting some one.\r\n\r\nPresently Mr. Brown came up. He did not seem to recognise her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it you want?\xe2\x80\x9d he inquired.\r\n\r\nCarrie\xe2\x80\x99s heart sank.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou said I should come this morning to see about work\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh,\xe2\x80\x9d he interrupted. \xe2\x80\x9cUm\xe2\x80\x94yes. What is your name?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCarrie Meeber.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cYou come with me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe led the way through dark, box-lined aisles which had the smell of\r\nnew shoes, until they came to an iron door which opened into the\r\nfactory proper. There was a large, low-ceiled room, with clacking,\r\nrattling machines at which men in white shirt sleeves and blue gingham\r\naprons were working. She followed him diffidently through the\r\nclattering automatons, keeping her eyes straight before her, and\r\nflushing slightly. They crossed to a far corner and took an elevator to\r\nthe sixth floor. Out of the array of machines and benches, Mr. Brown\r\nsignalled a foreman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is the girl,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, and turning to Carrie, \xe2\x80\x9cYou go with him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nHe then returned, and Carrie followed her new superior to a little desk\r\nin a corner, which he used as a kind of official centre.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ve never worked at anything like this before, have you?\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nquestioned, rather sternly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered.\r\n\r\nHe seemed rather annoyed at having to bother with such help, but put\r\ndown her name and then led her across to where a line of girls occupied\r\nstools in front of clacking machines. On the shoulder of one of the\r\ngirls who was punching eye-holes in one piece of the upper, by the aid\r\nof the machine, he put his hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cshow this girl how to do what you\xe2\x80\x99re doing. When you\r\nget through, come to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe girl so addressed rose promptly and gave Carrie her place.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt isn\xe2\x80\x99t hard to do,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, bending over. \xe2\x80\x9cYou just take this so,\r\nfasten it with this clamp, and start the machine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe suited action to word, fastened the piece of leather, which was\r\neventually to form the right half of the upper of a man\xe2\x80\x99s shoe, by\r\nlittle adjustable clamps, and pushed a small steel rod at the side of\r\nthe machine. The latter jumped to the task of punching, with sharp,\r\nsnapping clicks, cutting circular bits of leather out of the side of\r\nthe upper, leaving the holes which were to hold the laces. After\r\nobserving a few times, the girl let her work at it alone. Seeing that\r\nit was fairly well done, she went away.\r\n\r\nThe pieces of leather came from the girl at the machine to her right,\r\nand were passed on to the girl at her left. Carrie saw at once that an\r\naverage speed was necessary or the work would pile up on her and all\r\nthose below would be delayed. She had no time to look about, and bent\r\nanxiously to her task. The girls at her left and right realised her\r\npredicament and feelings, and, in a way, tried to aid her, as much as\r\nthey dared, by working slower.\r\n\r\nAt this task she laboured incessantly for some time, finding relief\r\nfrom her own nervous fears and imaginings in the humdrum, mechanical\r\nmovement of the machine. She felt, as the minutes passed, that the room\r\nwas not very light. It had a thick odour of fresh leather, but that did\r\nnot worry her. She felt the eyes of the other help upon her, and\r\ntroubled lest she was not working fast enough.\r\n\r\nOnce, when she was fumbling at the little clamp, having made a slight\r\nerror in setting in the leather, a great hand appeared before her eyes\r\nand fastened the clamp for her. It was the foreman. Her heart thumped\r\nso that she could scarcely see to go on.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStart your machine,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cstart your machine. Don\xe2\x80\x99t keep the line\r\nwaiting.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis recovered her sufficiently and she went excitedly on, hardly\r\nbreathing until the shadow moved away from behind her. Then she heaved\r\na great breath.\r\n\r\nAs the morning wore on the room became hotter. She felt the need of a\r\nbreath of fresh air and a drink of water, but did not venture to stir.\r\nThe stool she sat on was without a back or foot-rest, and she began to\r\nfeel uncomfortable. She found, after a time, that her back was\r\nbeginning to ache. She twisted and turned from one position to another\r\nslightly different, but it did not ease her for long. She was beginning\r\nto weary.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStand up, why don\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x9d said the girl at her right, without any form\r\nof introduction. \xe2\x80\x9cThey won\xe2\x80\x99t care.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie looked at her gratefully. \xe2\x80\x9cI guess I will,\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\r\n\r\nShe stood up from her stool and worked that way for a while, but it was\r\na more difficult position. Her neck and shoulders ached in bending\r\nover.\r\n\r\nThe spirit of the place impressed itself on her in a rough way. She did\r\nnot venture to look around, but above the clack of the machine she\r\ncould hear an occasional remark. She could also note a thing or two out\r\nof the side of her eye.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you see Harry last night?\xe2\x80\x9d said the girl at her left, addressing\r\nher neighbour.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou ought to have seen the tie he had on. Gee, but he was a mark.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cS-s-t,\xe2\x80\x9d said the other girl, bending over her work. The first,\r\nsilenced, instantly assumed a solemn face. The foreman passed slowly\r\nalong, eyeing each worker distinctly.
