The moment he was gone, the\r\nconversation was resumed again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSay,\xe2\x80\x9d began the girl at her left, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat jeh think he said?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe said he saw us with Eddie Harris at Martin\xe2\x80\x99s last night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo!\xe2\x80\x9d They both giggled.\r\n\r\nA youth with tan-coloured hair, that needed clipping very badly, came\r\nshuffling along between the machines, bearing a basket of leather\r\nfindings under his left arm, and pressed against his stomach. When near\r\nCarrie, he stretched out his right hand and gripped one girl under the\r\narm.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAw, let me go,\xe2\x80\x9d she exclaimed angrily. \xe2\x80\x9cDuffer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe only grinned broadly in return.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRubber!\xe2\x80\x9d he called back as she looked after him. There was nothing of\r\nthe gallant in him.\r\n\r\nCarrie at last could scarcely sit still. Her legs began to tire and she\r\nwanted to get up and stretch. Would noon never come? It seemed as if\r\nshe had worked an entire day. She was not hungry at all, but weak, and\r\nher eyes were tired, straining at the one point where the eye-punch\r\ncame down. The girl at the right noticed her squirmings and felt sorry\r\nfor her. She was concentrating herself too thoroughly\xe2\x80\x94what she did\r\nreally required less mental and physical strain. There was nothing to\r\nbe done, however. The halves of the uppers came piling steadily down.\r\nHer hands began to ache at the wrists and then in the fingers, and\r\ntowards the last she seemed one mass of dull, complaining muscles,\r\nfixed in an eternal position and performing a single mechanical\r\nmovement which became more and more distasteful, until as last it was\r\nabsolutely nauseating. When she was wondering whether the strain would\r\never cease, a dull-sounding bell clanged somewhere down an elevator\r\nshaft, and the end came. In an instant there was a buzz of action and\r\nconversation. All the girls instantly left their stools and hurried\r\naway in an adjoining room, men passed through, coming from some\r\ndepartment which opened on the right. The whirling wheels began to sing\r\nin a steadily modifying key, until at last they died away in a low\r\nbuzz. There was an audible stillness, in which the common voice sounded\r\nstrange.\r\n\r\nCarrie got up and sought her lunch box. She was stiff, a little dizzy,\r\nand very thirsty. On the way to the small space portioned off by wood,\r\nwhere all the wraps and lunches were kept, she encountered the foreman,\r\nwho stared at her hard.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cdid you get along all right?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think so,\xe2\x80\x9d she replied, very respectfully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUm,\xe2\x80\x9d he replied, for want of something better, and walked on.\r\n\r\nUnder better material conditions, this kind of work would not have been\r\nso bad, but the new socialism which involves pleasant working\r\nconditions for employees had not then taken hold upon manufacturing\r\ncompanies.\r\n\r\nThe place smelled of the oil of the machines and the new leather\xe2\x80\x94a\r\ncombination which, added to the stale odours of the building, was not\r\npleasant even in cold weather. The floor, though regularly swept every\r\nevening, presented a littered surface. Not the slightest provision had\r\nbeen made for the comfort of the employees, the idea being that\r\nsomething was gained by giving them as little and making the work as\r\nhard and unremunerative as possible. What we know of foot-rests,\r\nswivel-back chairs, dining-rooms for the girls, clean aprons and\r\ncurling irons supplied free, and a decent cloak room, were unthought\r\nof. The washrooms were disagreeable, crude, if not foul places, and the\r\nwhole atmosphere was sordid.\r\n\r\nCarrie looked about her, after she had drunk a tinful of water from a\r\nbucket in one corner, for a place to sit and eat. The other girls had\r\nranged themselves about the windows or the work-benches of those of the\r\nmen who had gone out. She saw no place which did not hold a couple or a\r\ngroup of girls, and being too timid to think of intruding herself, she\r\nsought out her machine and, seated upon her stool, opened her lunch on\r\nher lap. There she sat listening to the chatter and comment about her.\r\nIt was, for the most part, silly and graced by the current slang.\r\nSeveral of the men in the room exchanged compliments with the girls at\r\nlong range.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSay, Kitty,\xe2\x80\x9d called one to a girl who was doing a waltz step in a few\r\nfeet of space near one of the windows, \xe2\x80\x9care you going to the ball with\r\nme?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLook out, Kitty,\xe2\x80\x9d called another, \xe2\x80\x9cyou\xe2\x80\x99ll jar your back hair.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo on, Rubber,\xe2\x80\x9d was her only comment.\r\n\r\nAs Carrie listened to this and much more of similar familiar badinage\r\namong the men and girls, she instinctively withdrew into herself. She\r\nwas not used to this type, and felt that there was something hard and\r\nlow about it all. She feared that the young boys about would address\r\nsuch remarks to her\xe2\x80\x94boys who, beside Drouet, seemed uncouth and\r\nridiculous. She made the average feminine distinction between clothes,\r\nputting worth, goodness, and distinction in a dress suit, and leaving\r\nall the unlovely qualities and those beneath notice in overalls and\r\njumper.\r\n\r\nShe was glad when the short half hour was over and the wheels began to\r\nwhirr again. Though wearied, she would be inconspicuous. This illusion\r\nended when another young man passed along the aisle and poked her\r\nindifferently in the ribs with his thumb. She turned about, indignation\r\nleaping to her eyes, but he had gone on and only once turned to grin.\r\nShe found it difficult to conquer an inclination to cry.\r\n\r\nThe girl next her noticed her state of mind. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t you mind,\xe2\x80\x9d she\r\nsaid. \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s too fresh.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie said nothing, but bent over her work. She felt as though she\r\ncould hardly endure such a life. Her idea of work had been so entirely\r\ndifferent. All during the long afternoon she thought of the city\r\noutside and its imposing show, crowds, and fine buildings. Columbia\r\nCity and the better side of her home life came back. By three o\xe2\x80\x99clock\r\nshe was sure it must be six, and by four it seemed as if they had\r\nforgotten to note the hour and were letting all work overtime. The\r\nforeman became a true ogre, prowling constantly about, keeping her tied\r\ndown to her miserable task. What she heard of the conversation about\r\nher only made her feel sure that she did not want to make friends with\r\nany of these. When six o\xe2\x80\x99clock came she hurried eagerly away, her arms\r\naching and her limbs stiff from sitting in one position.\r\n\r\nAs she passed out along the hall after getting her hat, a young machine\r\nhand, attracted by her looks, made bold to jest with her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSay, Maggie,\xe2\x80\x9d he called, \xe2\x80\x9cif you wait, I\xe2\x80\x99ll walk with you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was thrown so straight in her direction that she knew who was meant,\r\nbut never turned to look.\r\n\r\nIn the crowded elevator, another dusty, toil-stained youth tried to\r\nmake an impression on her by leering in her face.\r\n\r\nOne young man, waiting on the walk outside for the appearance of\r\nanother, grinned at her as she passed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAin\xe2\x80\x99t going my way, are you?\xe2\x80\x9d he called jocosely.\r\n\r\nCarrie turned her face to the west with a subdued heart. As she turned\r\nthe corner, she saw through the great shiny window the small desk at\r\nwhich she had applied. There were the crowds, hurrying with the same\r\nbuzz and energy-yielding enthusiasm. She felt a slight relief, but it\r\nwas only at her escape. She felt ashamed in the face of better dressed\r\ngirls who went by. She felt as though she should be better served, and\r\nher heart revolted.\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter V. A GLITTERING NIGHT FLOWER: THE USE OF A NAME\r\n\r\nDrouet did not call that evening. After receiving the letter, he had\r\nlaid aside all thought of Carrie for the time being and was floating\r\naround having what he considered a gay time. On this particular evening\r\nhe dined at \xe2\x80\x9cRector\xe2\x80\x99s,\xe2\x80\x9d a restaurant of some local fame, which occupied\r\na basement at Clark and Monroe Streets. There\xe2\x80\x94after he visited the\r\nresort of Fitzgerald and Moy\xe2\x80\x99s in Adams Street, opposite the imposing\r\nFederal Building. There he leaned over the splendid bar and swallowed a\r\nglass of plain whiskey and purchased a couple of cigars, one of which\r\nhe lighted. This to him represented in part high life\xe2\x80\x94a fair sample of\r\nwhat the whole must be. Drouet was not a drinker in excess. He was not\r\na moneyed man. He only craved the best, as his mind conceived it, and\r\nsuch doings seemed to him a part of the best. Rector\xe2\x80\x99s, with its\r\npolished marble walls and floor, its profusion of lights, its show of\r\nchina and silverware, and, above all, its reputation as a resort for\r\nactors and professional men, seemed to him the proper place for a\r\nsuccessful man to go. He loved fine clothes, good eating, and\r\nparticularly the company and acquaintanceship of successful men. When\r\ndining, it was a source of keen satisfaction to him to know that Joseph\r\nJefferson was wont to come to this same place, or that Henry E. Dixie,\r\na well-known performer of the day, was then only a few tables off. At\r\nRector\xe2\x80\x99s he could always obtain this satisfaction, for there one could\r\nencounter politicians, brokers, actors, some rich young \xe2\x80\x9crounders\xe2\x80\x9d of\r\nthe town, all eating and drinking amid a buzz of popular commonplace\r\nconversation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s So-and-so over there,\xe2\x80\x9d was a common remark of these gentlemen\r\namong themselves, particularly among those who had not yet reached, but\r\nhoped to do so, the dazzling height which money to dine here lavishly\r\nrepresented.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t say so,\xe2\x80\x9d would be the reply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, yes, didn\xe2\x80\x99t you know that? Why, he\xe2\x80\x99s manager of the Grand Opera\r\nHouse.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhen these things would fall upon Drouet\xe2\x80\x99s ears, he would straighten\r\nhimself a little more stiffly and eat with solid comfort. If he had any\r\nvanity, this augmented it, and if he had any ambition, this stirred it.\r\nHe would be able to flash a roll of greenbacks too some day. As it was,\r\nhe could eat where _they_ did.\r\n\r\nHis preference for Fitzgerald and Moy\xe2\x80\x99s Adams Street place was another\r\nyard off the same cloth. This was really a gorgeous saloon from a\r\nChicago standpoint. Like Rector\xe2\x80\x99s, it was also ornamented with a blaze\r\nof incandescent lights, held in handsome chandeliers. The floors were\r\nof brightly coloured tiles, the walls a composition of rich, dark,\r\npolished wood, which reflected the light, and coloured stucco-work,\r\nwhich gave the place a very sumptuous appearance. The long bar was a\r\nblaze of lights, polished woodwork, coloured and cut glassware, and\r\nmany fancy bottles. It was a truly swell saloon, with rich screens,\r\nfancy wines, and a line of bar goods unsurpassed in the country.\r\n\r\nAt Rector\xe2\x80\x99s, Drouet had met Mr. G. W. Hurstwood, manager of Fitzgerald\r\nand Moy\xe2\x80\x99s. He had been pointed out as a very successful and well-known\r\nman about town. Hurstwood looked the part, for, besides being slightly\r\nunder forty, he had a good, stout constitution, an active manner, and a\r\nsolid, substantial air, which was composed in part of his fine clothes,\r\nhis clean linen, his jewels, and, above all, his own sense of his\r\nimportance. Drouet immediately conceived a notion of him as being some\r\none worth knowing, and was glad not only to meet him, but to visit the\r\nAdams Street bar thereafter whenever he wanted a drink or a cigar.\r\n\r\nHurstwood was an interesting character after his kind. He was shrewd\r\nand clever in many little things, and capable of creating a good\r\nimpression. His managerial position was fairly important\xe2\x80\x94a kind of\r\nstewardship which was imposing, but lacked financial control. He had\r\nrisen by perseverance and industry, through long years of service, from\r\nthe position of barkeeper in a commonplace saloon to his present\r\naltitude. He had a little office in the place, set off in polished\r\ncherry and grill-work, where he kept, in a roll-top desk, the rather\r\nsimple accounts of the place\xe2\x80\x94supplies ordered and needed. The chief\r\nexecutive and financial functions devolved upon the owners\xe2\x80\x94Messrs.\r\nFitzgerald and Moy\xe2\x80\x94and upon a cashier who looked after the money taken\r\nin.\r\n\r\nFor the most part he lounged about, dressed in excellent tailored suits\r\nof imported goods, a solitaire ring, a fine blue diamond in his tie, a\r\nstriking vest of some new pattern, and a watch-chain of solid gold,\r\nwhich held a charm of rich design, and a watch of the latest make and\r\nengraving. He knew by name, and could greet personally with a \xe2\x80\x9cWell,\r\nold fellow,\xe2\x80\x9d hundreds of actors, merchants, politicians, and the\r\ngeneral run of successful characters about town, and it was part of his\r\nsuccess to do so. He had a finely graduated scale of informality and\r\nfriendship, which improved from the \xe2\x80\x9cHow do you do?\xe2\x80\x9d addressed to the\r\nfifteen-dollar-a-week clerks and office attaches, who, by long\r\nfrequenting of the place, became aware of his position, to the \xe2\x80\x9cWhy,\r\nold man, how are you?\xe2\x80\x9d which he addressed to those noted or rich\r\nindividuals who knew him and were inclined to be friendly. There was a\r\nclass, however, too rich, too famous, or too successful, with whom he\r\ncould not attempt any familiarity of address, and with these he was\r\nprofessionally tactful, assuming a grave and dignified attitude, paying\r\nthem the deference which would win their good feeling without in the\r\nleast compromising his own bearing and opinions. There were, in the\r\nlast place, a few good followers, neither rich nor poor, famous, nor\r\nyet remarkably successful, with whom he was friendly on the score of\r\ngood-fellowship. These were the kind of men with whom he would converse\r\nlongest and most seriously. He loved to go out and have a good time\r\nonce in a while\xe2\x80\x94to go to the races, the theatres, the sporting\r\nentertainments at some of the clubs. He kept a horse and neat trap, had\r\nhis wife and two children, who were well established in a neat house on\r\nthe North Side near Lincoln Park, and was altogether a very acceptable\r\nindividual of our great American upper class\xe2\x80\x94the first grade below the\r\nluxuriously rich.\r\n\r\nHurstwood liked Drouet. The latter\xe2\x80\x99s genial nature and dressy\r\nappearance pleased him. He knew that Drouet was only a travelling\r\nsalesman\xe2\x80\x94and not one of many years at that\xe2\x80\x94but the firm of Bartlett,\r\nCaryoe & Company was a large and prosperous house, and Drouet stood\r\nwell. Hurstwood knew Caryoe quite well, having drunk a glass now and\r\nthen with him, in company with several others, when the conversation\r\nwas general. Drouet had what was a help in his business, a moderate\r\nsense of humour, and could tell a good story when the occasion\r\nrequired. He could talk races with Hurstwood, tell interesting\r\nincidents concerning himself and his experiences with women, and report\r\nthe state of trade in the cities which he visited, and so managed to\r\nmake himself almost invariably agreeable. To-night he was particularly\r\nso, since his report to the company had been favourably commented upon,\r\nhis new samples had been satisfactorily selected, and his trip marked\r\nout for the next six weeks.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, hello, Charlie, old man,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood, as Drouet came in that\r\nevening about eight o\xe2\x80\x99clock. \xe2\x80\x9cHow goes it?\xe2\x80\x9d The room was crowded.\r\n\r\nDrouet shook hands, beaming good nature, and they strolled towards the\r\nbar.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, all right.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI haven\xe2\x80\x99t seen you in six weeks. When did you get in?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFriday,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet. \xe2\x80\x9cHad a fine trip.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGlad of it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood, his black eyes lit with a warmth which\r\nhalf displaced the cold make-believe that usually dwelt in them. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat\r\nare you going to take?\xe2\x80\x9d he added, as the barkeeper, in snowy jacket and\r\ntie, leaned toward them from behind the bar.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOld Pepper,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA little of the same for me,\xe2\x80\x9d put in Hurstwood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow long are you in town this time?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Hurstwood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnly until Wednesday. I\xe2\x80\x99m going up to St. Paul.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGeorge Evans was in here Saturday and said he saw you in Milwaukee\r\nlast week.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I saw George,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Drouet. \xe2\x80\x9cGreat old boy, isn\xe2\x80\x99t he? We had\r\nquite a time there together.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe barkeeper was setting out the glasses and bottle before them, and\r\nthey now poured out the draught as they talked, Drouet filling his to\r\nwithin a third of full, as was considered proper, and Hurstwood taking\r\nthe barest suggestion of whiskey and modifying it with seltzer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s become of Caryoe?\xe2\x80\x9d remarked Hurstwood. \xe2\x80\x9cI haven\xe2\x80\x99t seen him\r\naround here in two weeks.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLaid up, they say,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Drouet. \xe2\x80\x9cSay, he\xe2\x80\x99s a gouty old boy!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMade a lot of money in his time, though, hasn\xe2\x80\x99t he?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, wads of it,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Drouet. \xe2\x80\x9cHe won\xe2\x80\x99t live much longer. Barely\r\ncomes down to the office now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJust one boy, hasn\xe2\x80\x99t he?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Hurstwood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, and a swift-pacer,\xe2\x80\x9d laughed Drouet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI guess he can\xe2\x80\x99t hurt the business very much, though, with the other\r\nmembers all there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, he can\xe2\x80\x99t injure that any, I guess.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHurstwood was standing, his coat open, his thumbs in his pockets, the\r\nlight on his jewels and rings relieving them with agreeable\r\ndistinctness. He was the picture of fastidious comfort.\r\n\r\nTo one not inclined to drink, and gifted with a more serious turn of\r\nmind, such a bubbling, chattering, glittering chamber must ever seem an\r\nanomaly, a strange commentary on nature and life. Here come the moths,\r\nin endless procession, to bask in the light of the flame. Such\r\nconversation as one may hear would not warrant a commendation of the\r\nscene upon intellectual grounds. It seems plain that schemers would\r\nchoose more sequestered quarters to arrange their plans, that\r\npoliticians would not gather here in company to discuss anything save\r\nformalities, where the sharp-eared may hear, and it would scarcely be\r\njustified on the score of thirst, for the majority of those who\r\nfrequent these more gorgeous places have no craving for liquor.\r\nNevertheless, the fact that here men gather, here chatter, here love to\r\npass and rub elbows, must be explained upon some grounds. It must be\r\nthat a strange bundle of passions and vague desires give rise to such a\r\ncurious social institution or it would not be.\r\n\r\nDrouet, for one, was lured as much by his longing for pleasure as by\r\nhis desire to shine among his betters. The many friends he met here\r\ndropped in because they craved, without, perhaps, consciously analysing\r\nit, the company, the glow, the atmosphere which they found. One might\r\ntake it, after all, as an augur of the better social order, for the\r\nthings which they satisfied here, though sensory, were not evil. No\r\nevil could come out of the contemplation of an expensively decorated\r\nchamber. The worst effect of such a thing would be, perhaps, to stir up\r\nin the material-minded an ambition to arrange their lives upon a\r\nsimilarly splendid basis. In the last analysis, that would scarcely be\r\ncalled the fault of the decorations, but rather of the innate trend of\r\nthe mind. That such a scene might stir the less expensively dressed to\r\nemulate the more expensively dressed could scarcely be laid at the door\r\nof anything save the false ambition of the minds of those so affected.\r\nRemove the element so thoroughly and solely complained of\xe2\x80\x94liquor\xe2\x80\x94and\r\nthere would not be one to gainsay the qualities of beauty and\r\nenthusiasm which would remain. The pleased eye with which our modern\r\nrestaurants of fashion are looked upon is proof of this assertion.\r\n\r\nYet, here is the fact of the lighted chamber, the dressy, greedy\r\ncompany, the small, self-interested palaver, the disorganized, aimless,\r\nwandering mental action which it represents\xe2\x80\x94the love of light and show\r\nand finery which, to one outside, under the serene light of the eternal\r\nstars, must seem a strange and shiny thing. Under the stars and\r\nsweeping night winds, what a lamp-flower it must bloom; a strange,\r\nglittering night-flower, odour-yielding, insect-drawing,\r\ninsect-infested rose of pleasure.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSee that fellow coming in there?\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood, glancing at a\r\ngentleman just entering, arrayed in a high hat and Prince Albert coat,\r\nhis fat cheeks puffed and red as with good eating.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, where?\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood, indicating the direction by a cast of his eye,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthe man with the silk hat.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet, now affecting not to see. \xe2\x80\x9cWho is he?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s Jules Wallace, the spiritualist.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDrouet followed him with his eyes, much interested.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoesn\xe2\x80\x99t look much like a man who sees spirits, does he?\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Hurstwood. \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s got the money, all\r\nright,\xe2\x80\x9d and a little twinkle passed over his eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t go much on those things, do you?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Drouet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you never can tell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood. \xe2\x80\x9cThere may be something to\r\nit. I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t bother about it myself, though. By the way,\xe2\x80\x9d he added,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9care you going anywhere to-night?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98The Hole in the Ground,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet, mentioning the popular farce\r\nof the time.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you\xe2\x80\x99d better be going. It\xe2\x80\x99s half after eight already,\xe2\x80\x9d and he\r\ndrew out his watch.\r\n\r\nThe crowd was already thinning out considerably\xe2\x80\x94some bound for the\r\ntheatres, some to their clubs, and some to that most fascinating of all\r\nthe pleasures\xe2\x80\x94for the type of man there represented, at least\xe2\x80\x94the\r\nladies.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I will,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome around after the show. I have something I want to show you,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nHurstwood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSure,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet, elated.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou haven\xe2\x80\x99t anything on hand for the night, have you?\xe2\x80\x9d added\r\nHurstwood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot a thing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, come round, then.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI struck a little peach coming in on the train Friday,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked\r\nDrouet, by way of parting. \xe2\x80\x9cBy George, that\xe2\x80\x99s so, I must go and call on\r\nher before I go away.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, never mind her,\xe2\x80\x9d Hurstwood remarked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSay, she was a little dandy, I tell you,\xe2\x80\x9d went on Drouet\r\nconfidentially, and trying to impress his friend.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTwelve o\xe2\x80\x99clock,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s right,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet, going out.\r\n\r\nThus was Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s name bandied about in the most frivolous and gay of\r\nplaces, and that also when the little toiler was bemoaning her narrow\r\nlot, which was almost inseparable from the early stages of this, her\r\nunfolding fate.\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter VI. THE MACHINE AND THE MAIDEN: A KNIGHT OF TO-DAY\r\n\r\nAt the flat that evening Carrie felt a new phase of its atmosphere. The\r\nfact that it was unchanged, while her feelings were different,\r\nincreased her knowledge of its character. Minnie, after the good\r\nspirits Carrie manifested at first, expected a fair report. Hanson\r\nsupposed that Carrie would be satisfied.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, as he came in from the hall in his working clothes,\r\nand looked at Carrie through the dining-room door, \xe2\x80\x9chow did you make\r\nout?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, \xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99s pretty hard. I don\xe2\x80\x99t like it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was an air about her which showed plainer than any words that she\r\nwas both weary and disappointed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat sort of work is it?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, lingering a moment as he turned\r\nupon his heel to go into the bathroom.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRunning a machine,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Carrie.\r\n\r\nIt was very evident that it did not concern him much, save from the\r\nside of the flat\xe2\x80\x99s success. He was irritated a shade because it could\r\nnot have come about in the throw of fortune for Carrie to be pleased.\r\n\r\nMinnie worked with less elation than she had just before Carrie\r\narrived. The sizzle of the meat frying did not sound quite so pleasing\r\nnow that Carrie had reported her discontent. To Carrie, the one relief\r\nof the whole day would have been a jolly home, a sympathetic reception,\r\na bright supper table, and some one to say: \xe2\x80\x9cOh, well, stand it a\r\nlittle while. You will get something better,\xe2\x80\x9d but now this was ashes.\r\nShe began to see that they looked upon her complaint as unwarranted,\r\nand that she was supposed to work on and say nothing. She knew that she\r\nwas to pay four dollars for her board and room, and now she felt that\r\nit would be an exceedingly gloomy round, living with these people.\r\n\r\nMinnie was no companion for her sister\xe2\x80\x94she was too old. Her thoughts\r\nwere staid and solemnly adapted to a condition. If Hanson had any\r\npleasant thoughts or happy feelings he concealed them. He seemed to do\r\nall his mental operations without the aid of physical expression. He\r\nwas as still as a deserted chamber. Carrie, on the other hand, had the\r\nblood of youth and some imagination. Her day of love and the mysteries\r\nof courtship were still ahead. She could think of things she would like\r\nto do, of clothes she would like to wear, and of places she would like\r\nto visit. These were the things upon which her mind ran, and it was\r\nlike meeting with opposition at every turn to find no one here to call\r\nforth or respond to her feelings.\r\n\r\nShe had forgotten, in considering and explaining the result of her day,\r\nthat Drouet might come. Now, when she saw how unreceptive these two\r\npeople were, she hoped he would not. She did not know exactly what she\r\nwould do or how she would explain to Drouet, if he came. After supper\r\nshe changed her clothes. When she was trimly dressed she was rather a\r\nsweet little being, with large eyes and a sad mouth. Her face expressed\r\nthe mingled expectancy, dissatisfaction, and depression she felt. She\r\nwandered about after the dishes were put away, talked a little with\r\nMinnie, and then decided to go down and stand in the door at the foot\r\nof the stairs. If Drouet came, she could meet him there. Her face took\r\non the semblance of a look of happiness as she put on her hat to go\r\nbelow.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCarrie doesn\xe2\x80\x99t seem to like her place very well,\xe2\x80\x9d said Minnie to her\r\nhusband when the latter came out, paper in hand, to sit in the\r\ndining-room a few minutes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe ought to keep it for a time, anyhow,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hanson. \xe2\x80\x9cHas she gone\r\ndownstairs?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Minnie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d tell her to keep it if I were you. She might be here weeks without\r\ngetting another one.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMinnie said she would, and Hanson read his paper.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I were you,\xe2\x80\x9d he said a little later, \xe2\x80\x9cI wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t let her stand in\r\nthe door down there. It don\xe2\x80\x99t look good.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll tell her,\xe2\x80\x9d said Minnie.\r\n\r\nThe life of the streets continued for a long time to interest Carrie.\r\nShe never wearied of wondering where the people in the cars were going\r\nor what their enjoyments were. Her imagination trod a very narrow\r\nround, always winding up at points which concerned money, looks,\r\nclothes, or enjoyment. She would have a far-off thought of Columbia\r\nCity now and then, or an irritating rush of feeling concerning her\r\nexperiences of the present day, but, on the whole, the little world\r\nabout her enlisted her whole attention.\r\n\r\nThe first floor of the building, of which Hanson\xe2\x80\x99s flat was the third,\r\nwas occupied by a bakery, and to this, while she was standing there,\r\nHanson came down to buy a loaf of bread. She was not aware of his\r\npresence until he was quite near her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m after bread,\xe2\x80\x9d was all he said as he passed.\r\n\r\nThe contagion of thought here demonstrated itself. While Hanson really\r\ncame for bread, the thought dwelt with him that now he would see what\r\nCarrie was doing. No sooner did he draw near her with that in mind than\r\nshe felt it. Of course, she had no understanding of what put it into\r\nher head, but, nevertheless, it aroused in her the first shade of real\r\nantipathy to him. She knew now that she did not like him. He was\r\nsuspicious.\r\n\r\nA thought will colour a world for us. The flow of Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s meditations\r\nhad been disturbed, and Hanson had not long gone upstairs before she\r\nfollowed. She had realised with the lapse of the quarter hours that\r\nDrouet was not coming, and somehow she felt a little resentful, a\r\nlittle as if she had been forsaken\xe2\x80\x94was not good enough. She went\r\nupstairs, where everything was silent. Minnie was sewing by a lamp at\r\nthe table. Hanson had already turned in for the night. In her weariness\r\nand disappointment Carrie did no more than announce that she was going\r\nto bed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, you\xe2\x80\x99d better,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Minnie. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ve got to get up early, you\r\nknow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe morning was no better. Hanson was just going out the door as Carrie\r\ncame from her room. Minnie tried to talk with her during breakfast, but\r\nthere was not much of interest which they could mutually discuss. As on\r\nthe previous morning, Carrie walked down town, for she began to realise\r\nnow that her four-fifty would not even allow her car fare after she\r\npaid her board. This seemed a miserable arrangement. But the morning\r\nlight swept away the first misgivings of the day, as morning light is\r\never wont to do.\r\n\r\nAt the shoe factory she put in a long day, scarcely so wearisome as the\r\npreceding, but considerably less novel. The head foreman, on his round,\r\nstopped by her machine.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere did you come from?\xe2\x80\x9d he inquired.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Brown hired me,\xe2\x80\x9d she replied.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, he did, eh!\xe2\x80\x9d and then, \xe2\x80\x9cSee that you keep things going.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe machine girls impressed her even less favourably. They seemed\r\nsatisfied with their lot, and were in a sense \xe2\x80\x9ccommon.\xe2\x80\x9d Carrie had more\r\nimagination than they. She was not used to slang. Her instinct in the\r\nmatter of dress was naturally better. She disliked to listen to the\r\ngirl next to her, who was rather hardened by experience.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m going to quit this,\xe2\x80\x9d she heard her remark to her neighbour. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat\r\nwith the stipend and being up late, it\xe2\x80\x99s too much for me health.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey were free with the fellows, young and old, about the place, and\r\nexchanged banter in rude phrases, which at first shocked her. She saw\r\nthat she was taken to be of the same sort and addressed accordingly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHello,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked one of the stout-wristed sole-workers to her at noon.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re a daisy.\xe2\x80\x9d He really expected to hear the common \xe2\x80\x9cAw! go chase\r\nyourself!\xe2\x80\x9d in return, and was sufficiently abashed, by Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nsilently moving away, to retreat, awkwardly grinning.\r\n\r\nThat night at the flat she was even more lonely\xe2\x80\x94the dull situation was\r\nbecoming harder to endure. She could see that the Hansons seldom or\r\nnever had any company. Standing at the street door looking out, she\r\nventured to walk out a little way. Her easy gait and idle manner\r\nattracted attention of an offensive but common sort. She was slightly\r\ntaken back at the overtures of a well-dressed man of thirty, who in\r\npassing looked at her, reduced his pace, turned back, and said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOut for a little stroll, are you, this evening?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie looked at him in amazement, and then summoned sufficient thought\r\nto reply: \xe2\x80\x9cWhy, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know you,\xe2\x80\x9d backing away as she did so.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, that don\xe2\x80\x99t matter,\xe2\x80\x9d said the other affably.\r\n\r\nShe bandied no more words with him, but hurried away, reaching her own\r\ndoor quite out of breath. There was something in the man\xe2\x80\x99s look which\r\nfrightened her.\r\n\r\nDuring the remainder of the week it was very much the same. One or two\r\nnights she found herself too tired to walk home, and expended car fare.\r\nShe was not very strong, and sitting all day affected her back. She\r\nwent to bed one night before Hanson.\r\n\r\nTransplantation is not always successful in the matter of flowers or\r\nmaidens. It requires sometimes a richer soil, a better atmosphere to\r\ncontinue even a natural growth. It would have been better if her\r\nacclimatization had been more gradual\xe2\x80\x94less rigid. She would have done\r\nbetter if she had not secured a position so quickly, and had seen more\r\nof the city which she constantly troubled to know about.\r\n\r\nOn the first morning it rained she found that she had no umbrella.\r\nMinnie loaned her one of hers, which was worn and faded. There was the\r\nkind of vanity in Carrie that troubled at this. She went to one of the\r\ngreat department stores and bought herself one, using a dollar and a\r\nquarter of her small store to pay for it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat did you do that for, Carrie?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Minnie when she saw it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I need one,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou foolish girl.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie resented this, though she did not reply. She was not going to be\r\na common shop-girl, she thought; they need not think it, either.\r\n\r\nOn the first Saturday night Carrie paid her board, four dollars. Minnie\r\nhad a quaver of conscience as she took it, but did not know how to\r\nexplain to Hanson if she took less. That worthy gave up just four\r\ndollars less toward the household expenses with a smile of\r\nsatisfaction. He contemplated increasing his Building and Loan\r\npayments. As for Carrie, she studied over the problem of finding\r\nclothes and amusement on fifty cents a week. She brooded over this\r\nuntil she was in a state of mental rebellion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m going up the street for a walk,\xe2\x80\x9d she said after supper.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot alone, are you?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Hanson.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d said Minnie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI want to see _something_,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, and by the tone she put into\r\nthe last word they realised for the first time she was not pleased with\r\nthem.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the matter with her?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Hanson, when she went into the\r\nfront room to get her hat.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d said Minnie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, she ought to know better than to want to go out alone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie did not go very far, after all. She returned and stood in the\r\ndoor. The next day they went out to Garfield Park, but it did not\r\nplease her. She did not look well enough. In the shop next day she\r\nheard the highly coloured reports which girls give of their trivial\r\namusements. They had been happy. On several days it rained and she used\r\nup car fare. One night she got thoroughly soaked, going to catch the\r\ncar at Van Buren Street. All that evening she sat alone in the front\r\nroom looking out upon the street, where the lights were reflected on\r\nthe wet pavements, thinking. She had imagination enough to be moody.\r\n\r\nOn Saturday she paid another four dollars and pocketed her fifty cents\r\nin despair. The speaking acquaintanceship which she formed with some of\r\nthe girls at the shop discovered to her the fact that they had more of\r\ntheir earnings to use for themselves than she did. They had young men\r\nof the kind whom she, since her experience with Drouet, felt above, who\r\ntook them about. She came to thoroughly dislike the light-headed young\r\nfellows of the shop. Not one of them had a show of refinement. She saw\r\nonly their workday side.\r\n\r\nThere came a day when the first premonitory blast of winter swept over\r\nthe city. It scudded the fleecy clouds in the heavens, trailed long,\r\nthin streamers of smoke from the tall stacks, and raced about the\r\nstreets and corners in sharp and sudden puffs. Carrie now felt the\r\nproblem of winter clothes. What was she to do? She had no winter\r\njacket, no hat, no shoes. It was difficult to speak to Minnie about\r\nthis, but at last she summoned the courage.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know what I\xe2\x80\x99m going to do about clothes,\xe2\x80\x9d she said one evening\r\nwhen they were together. \xe2\x80\x9cI need a hat.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMinnie looked serious.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy don\xe2\x80\x99t you keep part of your money and buy yourself one?\xe2\x80\x9d she\r\nsuggested, worried over the situation which the withholding of Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nmoney would create.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d like to for a week or so, if you don\xe2\x80\x99t mind,\xe2\x80\x9d ventured Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCould you pay two dollars?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Minnie.\r\n\r\nCarrie readily acquiesced, glad to escape the trying situation, and\r\nliberal now that she saw a way out. She was elated and began figuring\r\nat once. She needed a hat first of all. How Minnie explained to Hanson\r\nshe never knew. He said nothing at all, but there were thoughts in the\r\nair which left disagreeable impressions.\r\n\r\nThe new arrangement might have worked if sickness had not intervened.\r\nIt blew up cold after a rain one afternoon when Carrie was still\r\nwithout a jacket. She came out of the warm shop at six and shivered as\r\nthe wind struck her. In the morning she was sneezing, and going down\r\ntown made it worse. That day her bones ached and she felt light-headed.\r\nTowards evening she felt very ill, and when she reached home was not\r\nhungry. Minnie noticed her drooping actions and asked her about\r\nherself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie. \xe2\x80\x9cI feel real bad.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe hung about the stove, suffered a chattering chill, and went to bed\r\nsick. The next morning she was thoroughly feverish.\r\n\r\nMinnie was truly distressed at this, but maintained a kindly demeanour.\r\nHanson said perhaps she had better go back home for a while. When she\r\ngot up after three days, it was taken for granted that her position was\r\nlost. The winter was near at hand, she had no clothes, and now she was\r\nout of work.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie; \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll go down Monday and see if I can\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nget something.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIf anything, her efforts were more poorly rewarded on this trial than\r\nthe last. Her clothes were nothing suitable for fall wearing. Her last\r\nmoney she had spent for a hat. For three days she wandered about,\r\nutterly dispirited. The attitude of the flat was fast becoming\r\nunbearable. She hated to think of going back there each evening. Hanson\r\nwas so cold. She knew it could not last much longer. Shortly she would\r\nhave to give up and go home.\r\n\r\nOn the fourth day she was down town all day, having borrowed ten cents\r\nfor lunch from Minnie. She had applied in the cheapest kind of places\r\nwithout success. She even answered for a waitress in a small restaurant\r\nwhere she saw a card in the window, but they wanted an experienced\r\ngirl. She moved through the thick throng of strangers, utterly subdued\r\nin spirit. Suddenly a hand pulled her arm and turned her about.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, well!\xe2\x80\x9d said a voice. In the first glance she beheld Drouet. He\r\nwas not only rosy-cheeked, but radiant. He was the essence of sunshine\r\nand good-humour. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy, how are you, Carrie?\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re a daisy.\r\nWhere have you been?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie smiled under his irresistible flood of geniality.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve been out home,\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cI saw you across the street there. I thought it was\r\nyou. I was just coming out to your place. How are you, anyhow?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m all right,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, smiling.\r\n\r\nDrouet looked her over and saw something different.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cI want to talk to you. You\xe2\x80\x99re not going anywhere in\r\nparticular, are you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot just now,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet\xe2\x80\x99s go up here and have something to eat. George! but I\xe2\x80\x99m glad to\r\nsee you again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe felt so relieved in his radiant presence, so much looked after and\r\ncared for, that she assented gladly, though with the slightest air of\r\nholding back.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, as he took her arm\xe2\x80\x94and there was an exuberance of\r\ngood-fellowship in the word which fairly warmed the cockles of her\r\nheart.\r\n\r\nThey went through Monroe Street to the old Windsor dining-room, which\r\nwas then a large, comfortable place, with an excellent cuisine and\r\nsubstantial service. Drouet selected a table close by the window, where\r\nthe busy rout of the street could be seen. He loved the changing\r\npanorama of the street\xe2\x80\x94to see and be seen as he dined.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, getting Carrie and himself comfortably settled, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat\r\nwill you have?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie looked over the large bill of fare which the waiter handed her\r\nwithout really considering it. She was very hungry, and the things she\r\nsaw there awakened her desires, but the high prices held her attention.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHalf broiled spring chicken\xe2\x80\x94seventy-five. Sirloin steak with\r\nmushrooms\xe2\x80\x94one twenty-five.\xe2\x80\x9d She had dimly heard of these things, but it\r\nseemed strange to be called to order from the list.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll fix this,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Drouet. \xe2\x80\x9cSst! waiter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThat officer of the board, a full-chested, round-faced negro,\r\napproached, and inclined his ear.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSirloin with mushrooms,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet. \xe2\x80\x9cStuffed tomatoes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYassah,\xe2\x80\x9d assented the negro, nodding his head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHashed brown potatoes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYassah.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAsparagus.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYassah.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd a pot of coffee.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDrouet turned to Carrie. \xe2\x80\x9cI haven\xe2\x80\x99t had a thing since breakfast. Just\r\ngot in from Rock Island. I was going off to dine when I saw you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie smiled and smiled.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat have you been doing?\xe2\x80\x9d he went on. \xe2\x80\x9cTell me all about yourself.\r\nHow is your sister?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe\xe2\x80\x99s well,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Carrie, answering the last query.\r\n\r\nHe looked at her hard.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSay,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cyou haven\xe2\x80\x99t been sick, have you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie nodded.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, now, that\xe2\x80\x99s a blooming shame, isn\xe2\x80\x99t it? You don\xe2\x80\x99t look very\r\nwell. I thought you looked a little pale. What have you been doing?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWorking,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t say so! At what?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe told him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRhodes, Morgenthau and Scott\xe2\x80\x94why, I know that house over here on Fifth\r\nAvenue, isn\xe2\x80\x99t it? They\xe2\x80\x99re a close-fisted concern. What made you go\r\nthere?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI couldn\xe2\x80\x99t get anything else,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie frankly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, that\xe2\x80\x99s an outrage,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet. \xe2\x80\x9cYou oughtn\xe2\x80\x99t to be working for\r\nthose people. Have the factory right back of the store, don\xe2\x80\x99t they?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat isn\xe2\x80\x99t a good house,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet. \xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t want to work at\r\nanything like that, anyhow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe chatted on at a great rate, asking questions, explaining things\r\nabout himself, telling her what a good restaurant it was, until the\r\nwaiter returned with an immense tray, bearing the hot savoury dishes\r\nwhich had been ordered. Drouet fairly shone in the matter of serving.\r\nHe appeared to great advantage behind the white napery and silver\r\nplatters of the table and displaying his arms with a knife and fork. As\r\nhe cut the meat his rings almost spoke. His new suit creaked as he\r\nstretched to reach the plates, break the bread, and pour the coffee. He\r\nhelped Carrie to a rousing plateful and contributed the warmth of his\r\nspirit to her body until she was a new girl. He was a splendid fellow\r\nin the true popular understanding of the term, and captivated Carrie\r\ncompletely.\r\n\r\nThat little soldier of fortune took her good turn in an easy way. She\r\nfelt a little out of place, but the great room soothed her and the view\r\nof the well-dressed throng outside seemed a splendid thing. Ah, what\r\nwas it not to have money! What a thing it was to be able to come in\r\nhere and dine! Drouet must be fortunate. He rode on trains, dressed in\r\nsuch nice clothes, was so strong, and ate in these fine places. He\r\nseemed quite a figure of a man, and she wondered at his friendship and\r\nregard for her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo you lost your place because you got sick, eh?\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat are\r\nyou going to do now?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLook around,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, a thought of the need that hung outside this\r\nfine restaurant like a hungry dog at her heels passing into her eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet, \xe2\x80\x9cthat won\xe2\x80\x99t do. How long have you been looking?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFour days,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThink of that!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, addressing some problematical individual.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou oughtn\xe2\x80\x99t to be doing anything like that. These girls,\xe2\x80\x9d and he\r\nwaved an inclusion of all shop and factory girls, \xe2\x80\x9cdon\xe2\x80\x99t get anything.\r\nWhy, you can\xe2\x80\x99t live on it, can you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe was a brotherly sort of creature in his demeanour. When he had\r\nscouted the idea of that kind of toil, he took another tack. Carrie was\r\nreally very pretty. Even then, in her commonplace garb, her figure was\r\nevidently not bad, and her eyes were large and gentle. Drouet looked at\r\nher and his thoughts reached home. She felt his admiration. It was\r\npowerfully backed by his liberality and good-humour. She felt that she\r\nliked him\xe2\x80\x94that she could continue to like him ever so much. There was\r\nsomething even richer than that, running as a hidden strain, in her\r\nmind. Every little while her eyes would meet his, and by that means the\r\ninterchanging current of feeling would be fully connected.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy don\xe2\x80\x99t you stay down town and go to the theatre with me?\xe2\x80\x9d he said,\r\nhitching his chair closer. The table was not very wide.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I can\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat are you going to do to-night?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered, a little drearily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t like out there where you are, do you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat are you going to do if you don\xe2\x80\x99t get work?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo back home, I guess.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was the least quaver in her voice as she said this. Somehow, the\r\ninfluence he was exerting was powerful. They came to an understanding\r\nof each other without words\xe2\x80\x94he of her situation, she of the fact that\r\nhe realised it. \xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cyou can\xe2\x80\x99t make it!\xe2\x80\x9d genuine sympathy\r\nfilling his mind for the time. \xe2\x80\x9cLet me help you. You take some of my\r\nmoney.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no!\xe2\x80\x9d she said, leaning back.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat are you going to do?\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\nShe sat meditating, merely shaking her head.\r\n\r\nHe looked at her quite tenderly for his kind. There were some loose\r\nbills in his vest pocket\xe2\x80\x94greenbacks. They were soft and noiseless, and\r\nhe got his fingers about them and crumpled them up in his hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome on,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll see you through all right. Get yourself some\r\nclothes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was the first reference he had made to that subject, and now she\r\nrealised how bad off she was. In his crude way he had struck the\r\nkey-note. Her lips trembled a little.\r\n\r\nShe had her hand out on the table before her. They were quite alone in\r\ntheir corner, and he put his larger, warmer hand over it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAw, come, Carrie,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat can you do alone? Let me help you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe pressed her hand gently and she tried to withdraw it. At this he\r\nheld it fast, and she no longer protested. Then he slipped the\r\ngreenbacks he had into her palm, and when she began to protest, he\r\nwhispered:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll loan it to you\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s all right. I\xe2\x80\x99ll loan it to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe made her take it. She felt bound to him by a strange tie of\r\naffection now. They went out, and he walked with her far out south\r\ntoward Polk Street, talking.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t want to live with those people?\xe2\x80\x9d he said in one place,\r\nabstractedly. Carrie heard it, but it made only a slight impression.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome down and meet me to-morrow,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cand we\xe2\x80\x99ll go to the\r\nmatin\xc3\xa9e. Will you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie protested a while, but acquiesced.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re not doing anything. Get yourself a nice pair of shoes and a\r\njacket.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe scarcely gave a thought to the complication which would trouble her\r\nwhen he was gone. In his presence, she was of his own hopeful,\r\neasy-way-out mood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t you bother about those people out there,\xe2\x80\x9d he said at parting.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll help you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie left him, feeling as though a great arm had slipped out before\r\nher to draw off trouble. The money she had accepted was two soft,\r\ngreen, handsome ten-dollar bills.\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter VII. THE LURE OF THE MATERIAL: BEAUTY SPEAKS FOR ITSELF\r\n\r\nThe true meaning of money yet remains to be popularly explained and\r\ncomprehended. When each individual realises for himself that this thing\r\nprimarily stands for and should only be accepted as a moral due\xe2\x80\x94that it\r\nshould be paid out as honestly stored energy, and not as a usurped\r\nprivilege\xe2\x80\x94many of our social, religious, and political troubles will\r\nhave permanently passed. As for Carrie, her understanding of the moral\r\nsignificance of money was the popular understanding, nothing more. The\r\nold definition: \xe2\x80\x9cMoney: something everybody else has and I must get,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nwould have expressed her understanding of it thoroughly. Some of it she\r\nnow held in her hand\xe2\x80\x94two soft, green ten-dollar bills\xe2\x80\x94and she felt that\r\nshe was immensely better off for the having of them. It was something\r\nthat was power in itself. One of her order of mind would have been\r\ncontent to be cast away upon a desert island with a bundle of money,\r\nand only the long strain of starvation would have taught her that in\r\nsome cases it could have no value. Even then she would have had no\r\nconception of the relative value of the thing; her one thought would,\r\nundoubtedly, have concerned the pity of having so much power and the\r\ninability to use it.\r\n\r\nThe poor girl thrilled as she walked away from Drouet. She felt ashamed\r\nin part because she had been weak enough to take it, but her need was\r\nso dire, she was still glad. Now she would have a nice new jacket! Now\r\nshe would buy a nice pair of pretty button shoes. She would get\r\nstockings, too, and a skirt, and, and\xe2\x80\x94until already, as in the matter\r\nof her prospective salary, she had got beyond, in her desires, twice\r\nthe purchasing power of her bills.\r\n\r\nShe conceived a true estimate of Drouet. To her, and indeed to all the\r\nworld, he was a nice, good-hearted man. There was nothing evil in the\r\nfellow. He gave her the money out of a good heart\xe2\x80\x94out of a realisation\r\nof her want. He would not have given the same amount to a poor young\r\nman, but we must not forget that a poor young man could not, in the\r\nnature of things, have appealed to him like a poor young girl.\r\nFemininity affected his feelings. He was the creature of an inborn\r\ndesire. Yet no beggar could have caught his eye and said, \xe2\x80\x9cMy God,\r\nmister, I\xe2\x80\x99m starving,\xe2\x80\x9d but he would gladly have handed out what was\r\nconsidered the proper portion to give beggars and thought no more about\r\nit. There would have been no speculation, no philosophising. He had no\r\nmental process in him worthy the dignity of either of those terms. In\r\nhis good clothes and fine health, he was a merry, unthinking moth of\r\nthe lamp. Deprived of his position, and struck by a few of the involved\r\nand baffling forces which sometimes play upon man, he would have been\r\nas helpless as Carrie\xe2\x80\x94as helpless, as non-understanding, as pitiable,\r\nif you will, as she.\r\n\r\nNow, in regard to his pursuit of women, he meant them no harm, because\r\nhe did not conceive of the relation which he hoped to hold with them as\r\nbeing harmful. He loved to make advances to women, to have them succumb\r\nto his charms, not because he was a cold-blooded, dark, scheming\r\nvillain, but because his inborn desire urged him to that as a chief\r\ndelight. He was vain, he was boastful, he was as deluded by fine\r\nclothes as any silly-headed girl. A truly deep-dyed villain could have\r\nhornswaggled him as readily as he could have flattered a pretty\r\nshop-girl. His fine success as a salesman lay in his geniality and the\r\nthoroughly reputable standing of his house. He bobbed about among men,\r\na veritable bundle of enthusiasm\xe2\x80\x94no power worthy the name of intellect,\r\nno thoughts worthy the adjective noble, no feelings long continued in\r\none strain. A Madame Sappho would have called him a pig; a Shakespeare\r\nwould have said \xe2\x80\x9cmy merry child\xe2\x80\x9d; old, drinking Caryoe thought him a\r\nclever, successful businessman. In short, he was as good as his\r\nintellect conceived.\r\n\r\nThe best proof that there was something open and commendable about the\r\nman was the fact that Carrie took the money. No deep, sinister soul\r\nwith ulterior motives could have given her fifteen cents under the\r\nguise of friendship. The unintellectual are not so helpless. Nature has\r\ntaught the beasts of the field to fly when some unheralded danger\r\nthreatens. She has put into the small, unwise head of the chipmunk the\r\nuntutored fear of poisons. \xe2\x80\x9cHe keepeth His creatures whole,\xe2\x80\x9d was not\r\nwritten of beasts alone. Carrie was unwise, and, therefore, like the\r\nsheep in its unwisdom, strong in feeling. The instinct of\r\nself-protection, strong in all such natures, was roused but feebly, if\r\nat all, by the overtures of Drouet.\r\n\r\nWhen Carrie had gone, he felicitated himself upon her good opinion. By\r\nGeorge, it was a shame young girls had to be knocked around like that.\r\nCold weather coming on and no clothes. Tough. He would go around to\r\nFitzgerald and Moy\xe2\x80\x99s and get a cigar. It made him feel light of foot as\r\nhe thought about her.\r\n\r\nCarrie reached home in high good spirits, which she could scarcely\r\nconceal. The possession of the money involved a number of points which\r\nperplexed her seriously. How should she buy any clothes when Minnie\r\nknew that she had no money? She had no sooner entered the flat than\r\nthis point was settled for her. It could not be done. She could think\r\nof no way of explaining.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow did you come out?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Minnie, referring to the day.\r\n\r\nCarrie had none of the small deception which could feel one thing and\r\nsay something directly opposed. She would prevaricate, but it would be\r\nin the line of her feelings at least. So instead of complaining when\r\nshe felt so good, she said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have the promise of something.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt the Boston Store.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it sure promised?\xe2\x80\x9d questioned Minnie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I\xe2\x80\x99m to find out to-morrow,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Carrie disliking to draw\r\nout a lie any longer than was necessary.\r\n\r\nMinnie felt the atmosphere of good feeling which Carrie brought with\r\nher. She felt now was the time to express to Carrie the state of\r\nHanson\xe2\x80\x99s feeling about her entire Chicago venture.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t get it\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d she paused, troubled for an easy way.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I don\xe2\x80\x99t get something pretty soon, I think I\xe2\x80\x99ll go home.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMinnie saw her chance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSven thinks it might be best for the winter, anyhow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe situation flashed on Carrie at once. They were unwilling to keep\r\nher any longer, out of work. She did not blame Minnie, she did not\r\nblame Hanson very much. Now, as she sat there digesting the remark, she\r\nwas glad she had Drouet\xe2\x80\x99s money. \xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d she said after a few moments,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thought of doing that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe did not explain that the thought, however, had aroused all the\r\nantagonism of her nature. Columbia City, what was there for her? She\r\nknew its dull, little round by heart. Here was the great, mysterious\r\ncity which was still a magnet for her. What she had seen only suggested\r\nits possibilities. Now to turn back on it and live the little old life\r\nout there\xe2\x80\x94she almost exclaimed against the thought.\r\n\r\nShe had reached home early and went in the front room to think. What\r\ncould she do? She could not buy new shoes and wear them here. She would\r\nneed to save part of the twenty to pay her fare home. She did not want\r\nto borrow of Minnie for that. And yet, how could she explain where she\r\neven got that money? If she could only get enough to let her out easy.\r\n\r\nShe went over the tangle again and again. Here, in the morning, Drouet\r\nwould expect to see her in a new jacket, and that couldn\xe2\x80\x99t be. The\r\nHansons expected her to go home, and she wanted to get away, and yet\r\nshe did not want to go home. In the light of the way they would look on\r\nher getting money without work, the taking of it now seemed dreadful.\r\nShe began to be ashamed. The whole situation depressed her. It was all\r\nso clear when she was with Drouet. Now it was all so tangled, so\r\nhopeless\xe2\x80\x94much worse than it was before, because she had the semblance\r\nof aid in her hand which she could not use.\r\n\r\nHer spirits sank so that at supper Minnie felt that she must have had\r\nanother hard day. Carrie finally decided that she would give the money\r\nback. It was wrong to take it. She would go down in the morning and\r\nhunt for work. At noon she would meet Drouet as agreed and tell him. At\r\nthis decision her heart sank, until she was the old Carrie of distress.\r\n\r\nCuriously, she could not hold the money in her hand without feeling\r\nsome relief. Even after all her depressing conclusions, she could sweep\r\naway all thought about the matter and then the twenty dollars seemed a\r\nwonderful and delightful thing. Ah, money, money, money! What a thing\r\nit was to have. How plenty of it would clear away all these troubles.\r\n\r\nIn the morning she got up and started out a little early. Her decision\r\nto hunt for work was moderately strong, but the money in her pocket,\r\nafter all her troubling over it, made the work question the least shade\r\nless terrible. She walked into the wholesale district, but as the\r\nthought of applying came with each passing concern, her heart shrank.\r\nWhat a coward she was, she thought to herself. Yet she had applied so\r\noften. It would be the same old story. She walked on and on, and\r\nfinally did go into one place, with the old result. She came out\r\nfeeling that luck was against her. It was no use.\r\n\r\nWithout much thinking, she reached Dearborn Street. Here was the great\r\nFair store with its multitude of delivery wagons about its long window\r\ndisplay, its crowd of shoppers. It readily changed her thoughts, she\r\nwho was so weary of them. It was here that she had intended to come and\r\nget her new things. Now for relief from distress; she thought she would\r\ngo in and see. She would look at the jackets.\r\n\r\nThere is nothing in this world more delightful than that middle state\r\nin which we mentally balance at times, possessed of the means, lured by\r\ndesire, and yet deterred by conscience or want of decision. When Carrie\r\nbegan wandering around the store amid the fine displays she was in this\r\nmood. Her original experience in this same place had given her a high\r\nopinion of its merits. Now she paused at each individual bit of finery,\r\nwhere before she had hurried on. Her woman\xe2\x80\x99s heart was warm with desire\r\nfor them. How would she look in this, how charming that would make her!\r\nShe came upon the corset counter and paused in rich reverie as she\r\nnoted the dainty concoctions of colour and lace there displayed. If she\r\nwould only make up her mind, she could have one of those now. She\r\nlingered in the jewelry department. She saw the earrings, the\r\nbracelets, the pins, the chains. What would she not have given if she\r\ncould have had them all! She would look fine too, if only she had some\r\nof these things.\r\n\r\nThe jackets were the greatest attraction. When she entered the store,\r\nshe already had her heart fixed upon the peculiar little tan jacket\r\nwith large mother-of-pearl buttons which was all the rage that fall.\r\nStill she delighted to convince herself that there was nothing she\r\nwould like better. She went about among the glass cases and racks where\r\nthese things were displayed, and satisfied herself that the one she\r\nthought of was the proper one. All the time she wavered in mind, now\r\npersuading herself that she could buy it right away if she chose, now\r\nrecalling to herself the actual condition. At last the noon hour was\r\ndangerously near, and she had done nothing. She must go now and return\r\nthe money.\r\n\r\nDrouet was on the corner when she came up.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHello,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cwhere is the jacket and\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94looking down\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cthe shoes?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie had thought to lead up to her decision in some intelligent way,\r\nbut this swept the whole fore-schemed situation by the board.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI came to tell you that\xe2\x80\x94that I can\xe2\x80\x99t take the money.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, that\xe2\x80\x99s it, is it?\xe2\x80\x9d he returned. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, you come on with me. Let\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ngo over here to Partridge\xe2\x80\x99s.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie walked with him. Behold, the whole fabric of doubt and\r\nimpossibility had slipped from her mind. She could not get at the\r\npoints that were so serious, the things she was going to make plain to\r\nhim.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you had lunch yet? Of course you haven\xe2\x80\x99t. Let\xe2\x80\x99s go in here,\xe2\x80\x9d and\r\nDrouet turned into one of the very nicely furnished restaurants off\r\nState Street, in Monroe.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI mustn\xe2\x80\x99t take the money,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, after they were settled in a\r\ncosey corner, and Drouet had ordered the lunch. \xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t wear those\r\nthings out there. They\xe2\x80\x94they wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t know where I got them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you want to do,\xe2\x80\x9d he smiled, \xe2\x80\x9cgo without them?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think I\xe2\x80\x99ll go home,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, wearily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, come,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cyou\xe2\x80\x99ve been thinking it over too long. I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell\r\nyou what you do. You say you can\xe2\x80\x99t wear them out there. Why don\xe2\x80\x99t you\r\nrent a furnished room and leave them in that for a week?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie shook her head. Like all women, she was there to object and be\r\nconvinced. It was for him to brush the doubts away and clear the path\r\nif he could. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy are you going home?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I can\xe2\x80\x99t get anything here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey won\xe2\x80\x99t keep you?\xe2\x80\x9d he remarked, intuitively.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey can\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you what you do,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cYou come with me. I\xe2\x80\x99ll take care\r\nof you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie heard this passively. The peculiar state which she was in made\r\nit sound like the welcome breath of an open door. Drouet seemed of her\r\nown spirit and pleasing. He was clean, handsome, well-dressed, and\r\nsympathetic. His voice was the voice of a friend.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat can you do back at Columbia City?\xe2\x80\x9d he went on, rousing by the\r\nwords in Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s mind a picture of the dull world she had left. \xe2\x80\x9cThere\r\nisn\xe2\x80\x99t anything down there. Chicago\xe2\x80\x99s the place. You can get a nice room\r\nhere and some clothes, and then you can do something.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie looked out through the window into the busy street. There it\r\nwas, the admirable, great city, so fine when you are not poor. An\r\nelegant coach, with a prancing pair of bays, passed by, carrying in its\r\nupholstered depths a young lady.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat will you have if you go back?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Drouet. There was no subtle\r\nundercurrent to the question. He imagined that she would have nothing\r\nat all of the things he thought worth while.\r\n\r\nCarrie sat still, looking out. She was wondering what she could do.\r\nThey would be expecting her to go home this week.\r\n\r\nDrouet turned to the subject of the clothes she was going to buy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy not get yourself a nice little jacket? You\xe2\x80\x99ve got to have it. I\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nloan you the money. You needn\xe2\x80\x99t worry about taking it. You can get\r\nyourself a nice room by yourself. I won\xe2\x80\x99t hurt you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie saw the drift, but could not express her thoughts. She felt more\r\nthan ever the helplessness of her case.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I could only get something to do,\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMaybe you can,\xe2\x80\x9d went on Drouet, \xe2\x80\x9cif you stay here. You can\xe2\x80\x99t if you go\r\naway. They won\xe2\x80\x99t let you stay out there. Now, why not let me get you a\r\nnice room? I won\xe2\x80\x99t bother you\xe2\x80\x94you needn\xe2\x80\x99t be afraid. Then, when you get\r\nfixed up, maybe you could get something.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe looked at her pretty face and it vivified his mental resources. She\r\nwas a sweet little mortal to him\xe2\x80\x94there was no doubt of that. She seemed\r\nto have some power back of her actions. She was not like the common run\r\nof store-girls. She wasn\xe2\x80\x99t silly.\r\n\r\nIn reality, Carrie had more imagination than he\xe2\x80\x94more taste. It was a\r\nfiner mental strain in her that made possible her depression and\r\nloneliness. Her poor clothes were neat, and she held her head\r\nunconsciously in a dainty way.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you think I could get something?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSure,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, reaching over and filling her cup with tea. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll help\r\nyou.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe looked at him, and he laughed reassuringly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you what we\xe2\x80\x99ll do. We\xe2\x80\x99ll go over here to Partridge\xe2\x80\x99s and\r\nyou pick out what you want. Then we\xe2\x80\x99ll look around for a room for you.\r\nYou can leave the things there. Then we\xe2\x80\x99ll go to the show to-night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie shook her head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you can go out to the flat then, that\xe2\x80\x99s all right. You don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nneed to stay in the room. Just take it and leave your things there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe hung in doubt about this until the dinner was over.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet\xe2\x80\x99s go over and look at the jackets,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\nTogether they went. In the store they found that shine and rustle of\r\nnew things which immediately laid hold of Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s heart. Under the\r\ninfluence of a good dinner and Drouet\xe2\x80\x99s radiating presence, the scheme\r\nproposed seemed feasible. She looked about and picked a jacket like the\r\none which she had admired at The Fair. When she got it in her hand it\r\nseemed so much nicer. The saleswoman helped her on with it, and, by\r\naccident, it fitted perfectly. Drouet\xe2\x80\x99s face lightened as he saw the\r\nimprovement. She looked quite smart.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s the thing,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\nCarrie turned before the glass. She could not help feeling pleased as\r\nshe looked at herself. A warm glow crept into her cheeks.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s the thing,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet. \xe2\x80\x9cNow pay for it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s nine dollars,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s all right\xe2\x80\x94take it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet.\r\n\r\nShe reached in her purse and took out one of the bills. The woman asked\r\nif she would wear the coat and went off. In a few minutes she was back\r\nand the purchase was closed.\r\n\r\nFrom Partridge\xe2\x80\x99s they went to a shoe store, where Carrie was fitted for\r\nshoes. Drouet stood by, and when he saw how nice they looked, said,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWear them.\xe2\x80\x9d Carrie shook her head, however. She was thinking of\r\nreturning to the flat. He bought her a purse for one thing, and a pair\r\nof gloves for another, and let her buy the stockings.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo-morrow,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cyou come down here and buy yourself a skirt.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn all of Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s actions there was a touch of misgiving. The deeper\r\nshe sank into the entanglement, the more she imagined that the thing\r\nhung upon the few remaining things she had not done. Since she had not\r\ndone these, there was a way out.\r\n\r\nDrouet knew a place in Wabash Avenue where there were rooms. He showed\r\nCarrie the outside of these, and said: \xe2\x80\x9cNow, you\xe2\x80\x99re my sister.\xe2\x80\x9d He\r\ncarried the arrangement off with an easy hand when it came to the\r\nselection, looking around, criticising, opining. \xe2\x80\x9cHer trunk will be\r\nhere in a day or so,\xe2\x80\x9d he observed to the landlady, who was very\r\npleased.\r\n\r\nWhen they were alone, Drouet did not change in the least. He talked in\r\nthe same general way as if they were out in the street. Carrie left her\r\nthings.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet, \xe2\x80\x9cwhy don\xe2\x80\x99t you move to-night?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I can\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t want to leave them so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe took that up as they walked along the avenue. It was a warm\r\nafternoon. The sun had come out and the wind had died down. As he\r\ntalked with Carrie, he secured an accurate detail of the atmosphere of\r\nthe flat.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome out of it,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cthey won\xe2\x80\x99t care. I\xe2\x80\x99ll help you get along.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe listened until her misgivings vanished. He would show her about a\r\nlittle and then help her get something. He really imagined that he\r\nwould. He would be out on the road and she could be working.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you what you do,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cyou go out there and get\r\nwhatever you want and come away.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe thought a long time about this. Finally she agreed. He would come\r\nout as far as Peoria Street and wait for her. She was to meet him at\r\nhalf-past eight. At half-past five she reached home, and at six her\r\ndetermination was hardened.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo you didn\xe2\x80\x99t get it?\xe2\x80\x9d said Minnie, referring to Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s story of the\r\nBoston Store.\r\n\r\nCarrie looked at her out of the corner of her eye. \xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t think you\xe2\x80\x99d better try any more this fall,\xe2\x80\x9d said Minnie.\r\n\r\nCarrie said nothing.\r\n\r\nWhen Hanson came home he wore the same inscrutable demeanour. He washed\r\nin silence and went off to read his paper. At dinner Carrie felt a\r\nlittle nervous. The strain of her own plans were considerable, and the\r\nfeeling that she was not welcome here was strong.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDidn\xe2\x80\x99t find anything, eh?\xe2\x80\x9d said Hanson.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe turned to his eating again, the thought that it was a burden to have\r\nher here dwelling in his mind. She would have to go home, that was all.\r\nOnce she was away, there would be no more coming back in the spring.\r\n\r\nCarrie was afraid of what she was going to do, but she was relieved to\r\nknow that this condition was ending. They would not care. Hanson\r\nparticularly would be glad when she went. He would not care what became\r\nof her.\r\n\r\nAfter dinner she went into the bathroom, where they could not disturb\r\nher, and wrote a little note.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood-bye, Minnie,\xe2\x80\x9d it read. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m not going home. I\xe2\x80\x99m going to stay in\r\nChicago a little while and look for work. Don\xe2\x80\x99t worry. I\xe2\x80\x99ll be all\r\nright.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn the front room Hanson was reading his paper. As usual, she helped\r\nMinnie clear away the dishes and straighten up. Then she said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI guess I\xe2\x80\x99ll stand down at the door a little while.\xe2\x80\x9d She could\r\nscarcely prevent her voice from trembling.\r\n\r\nMinnie remembered Hanson\xe2\x80\x99s remonstrance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSven doesn\xe2\x80\x99t think it looks good to stand down there,\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoesn\xe2\x80\x99t he?\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie. \xe2\x80\x9cI won\xe2\x80\x99t do it any more after this.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe put on her hat and fidgeted around the table in the little bedroom,\r\nwondering where to slip the note. Finally she put it under Minnie\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhair-brush.\r\n\r\nWhen she had closed the hall-door, she paused a moment and wondered\r\nwhat they would think. Some thought of the queerness of her deed\r\naffected her. She went slowly down the stairs. She looked back up the\r\nlighted step, and then affected to stroll up the street. When she\r\nreached the corner she quickened her pace.\r\n\r\nAs she was hurrying away, Hanson came back to his wife.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs Carrie down at the door again?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Minnie; \xe2\x80\x9cshe said she wasn\xe2\x80\x99t going to do it any more.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe went over to the baby where it was playing on the floor and began to\r\npoke his finger at it.\r\n\r\nDrouet was on the corner waiting, in good spirits.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHello, Carrie,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, as a sprightly figure of a girl drew near\r\nhim. \xe2\x80\x9cGot here safe, did you? Well, we\xe2\x80\x99ll take a car.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter VIII.
