INTIMATIONS BY WINTER: AN AMBASSADOR SUMMONED\r\n\r\nAmong the forces which sweep and play throughout the universe,\r\nuntutored man is but a wisp in the wind. Our civilisation is still in a\r\nmiddle stage, scarcely beast, in that it is no longer wholly guided by\r\ninstinct; scarcely human, in that it is not yet wholly guided by\r\nreason. On the tiger no responsibility rests. We see him aligned by\r\nnature with the forces of life\xe2\x80\x94he is born into their keeping and\r\nwithout thought he is protected. We see man far removed from the lairs\r\nof the jungles, his innate instincts dulled by too near an approach to\r\nfree-will, his free-will not sufficiently developed to replace his\r\ninstincts and afford him perfect guidance.\r\n\r\nHe is becoming too wise to hearken always to instincts and desires; he\r\nis still too weak to always prevail against them. As a beast, the\r\nforces of life aligned him with them; as a man, he has not yet wholly\r\nlearned to align himself with the forces. In this intermediate stage he\r\nwavers\xe2\x80\x94neither drawn in harmony with nature by his instincts nor yet\r\nwisely putting himself into harmony by his own free-will. He is even as\r\na wisp in the wind, moved by every breath of passion, acting now by his\r\nwill and now by his instincts, erring with one, only to retrieve by the\r\nother, falling by one, only to rise by the other\xe2\x80\x94a creature of\r\nincalculable variability. We have the consolation of knowing that\r\nevolution is ever in action, that the ideal is a light that cannot\r\nfail. He will not forever balance thus between good and evil. When this\r\njangle of free-will instinct shall have been adjusted, when perfect\r\nunderstanding has given the former the power to replace the latter\r\nentirely, man will no longer vary. The needle of understanding will yet\r\npoint steadfast and unwavering to the distinct pole of truth.\r\n\r\nIn Carrie\xe2\x80\x94as in how many of our worldlings do they not?\xe2\x80\x94instinct and\r\nreason, desire and understanding, were at war for the mastery. She\r\nfollowed whither her craving led. She was as yet more drawn than she\r\ndrew.\r\n\r\nWhen Minnie found the note next morning, after a night of mingled\r\nwonder and anxiety, which was not exactly touched by yearning, sorrow,\r\nor love, she exclaimed: \xe2\x80\x9cWell, what do you think of that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat?\xe2\x80\x9d said Hanson.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSister Carrie has gone to live somewhere else.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHanson jumped out of bed with more celerity than he usually displayed\r\nand looked at the note. The only indication of his thoughts came in the\r\nform of a little clicking sound made by his tongue; the sound some\r\npeople make when they wish to urge on a horse.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere do you suppose she\xe2\x80\x99s gone to?\xe2\x80\x9d said Minnie, thoroughly aroused.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d a touch of cynicism lighting his eye. \xe2\x80\x9cNow she has gone\r\nand done it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMinnie moved her head in a puzzled way.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, oh,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cshe doesn\xe2\x80\x99t know what she has done.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hanson, after a while, sticking his hands out before him,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cwhat can you do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMinnie\xe2\x80\x99s womanly nature was higher than this. She figured the\r\npossibilities in such cases.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh,\xe2\x80\x9d she said at last, \xe2\x80\x9cpoor Sister Carrie!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt the time of this particular conversation, which occurred at 5 A.M.,\r\nthat little soldier of fortune was sleeping a rather troubled sleep in\r\nher new room, alone.\r\n\r\nCarrie\xe2\x80\x99s new state was remarkable in that she saw possibilities in it.\r\nShe was no sensualist, longing to drowse sleepily in the lap of luxury.\r\nShe turned about, troubled by her daring, glad of her release,\r\nwondering whether she would get something to do, wondering what Drouet\r\nwould do. That worthy had his future fixed for him beyond a\r\nperadventure. He could not help what he was going to do. He could not\r\nsee clearly enough to wish to do differently. He was drawn by his\r\ninnate desire to act the old pursuing part. He would need to delight\r\nhimself with Carrie as surely as he would need to eat his heavy\r\nbreakfast. He might suffer the least rudimentary twinge of conscience\r\nin whatever he did, and in just so far he was evil and sinning. But\r\nwhatever twinges of conscience he might have would be rudimentary, you\r\nmay be sure.\r\n\r\nThe next day he called upon Carrie, and she saw him in her chamber. He\r\nwas the same jolly, enlivening soul.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAw,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat are you looking so blue about? Come on out to\r\nbreakfast. You want to get your other clothes to-day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie looked at him with the hue of shifting thought in her large\r\neyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish I could get something to do,\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ll get that all right,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the use worrying\r\nright now? Get yourself fixed up. See the city. I won\xe2\x80\x99t hurt you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know you won\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d she remarked, half truthfully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGot on the new shoes, haven\xe2\x80\x99t you? Stick \xe2\x80\x99em out. George, they look\r\nfine. Put on your jacket.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie obeyed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSay, that fits like a T, don\xe2\x80\x99t it?\xe2\x80\x9d he remarked, feeling the set of it\r\nat the waist and eyeing it from a few paces with real pleasure. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat\r\nyou need now is a new skirt. Let\xe2\x80\x99s go to breakfast.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie put on her hat.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere are the gloves?\xe2\x80\x9d he inquired.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, taking them out of the bureau drawer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, come on,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\nThus the first hour of misgiving was swept away.\r\n\r\nIt went this way on every occasion. Drouet did not leave her much\r\nalone. She had time for some lone wanderings, but mostly he filled her\r\nhours with sight-seeing. At Carson, Pirie\xe2\x80\x99s he bought her a nice skirt\r\nand shirt waist. With his money she purchased the little necessaries of\r\ntoilet, until at last she looked quite another maiden. The mirror\r\nconvinced her of a few things which she had long believed. She was\r\npretty, yes, indeed! How nice her hat set, and weren\xe2\x80\x99t her eyes pretty.\r\nShe caught her little red lip with her teeth and felt her first thrill\r\nof power. Drouet was so good.\r\n\r\nThey went to see \xe2\x80\x9cThe Mikado\xe2\x80\x9d one evening, an opera which was\r\nhilariously popular at that time. Before going, they made off for the\r\nWindsor dining-room, which was in Dearborn Street, a considerable\r\ndistance from Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s room. It was blowing up cold, and out of her\r\nwindow Carrie could see the western sky, still pink with the fading\r\nlight, but steely blue at the top where it met the darkness. A long,\r\nthin cloud of pink hung in midair, shaped like some island in a far-off\r\nsea. Somehow the swaying of some dead branches of trees across the way\r\nbrought back the picture with which she was familiar when she looked\r\nfrom their front window in December days at home. She paused and wrung\r\nher little hands.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the matter?\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, her lip trembling.\r\n\r\nHe sensed something, and slipped his arm over her shoulder, patting her\r\narm.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome on,\xe2\x80\x9d he said gently, \xe2\x80\x9cyou\xe2\x80\x99re all right.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe turned to slip on her jacket.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBetter wear that boa about your throat to-night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey walked north on Wabash to Adams Street and then west. The lights\r\nin the stores were already shining out in gushes of golden hue. The arc\r\nlights were sputtering overhead, and high up were the lighted windows\r\nof the tall office buildings. The chill wind whipped in and out in\r\ngusty breaths. Homeward bound, the six o\xe2\x80\x99clock throng bumped and\r\njostled. Light overcoats were turned up about the ears, hats were\r\npulled down. Little shop-girls went fluttering by in pairs and fours,\r\nchattering, laughing. It was a spectacle of warm-blooded humanity.\r\n\r\nSuddenly a pair of eyes met Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s in recognition. They were looking\r\nout from a group of poorly dressed girls. Their clothes were faded and\r\nloose-hanging, their jackets old, their general make-up shabby.\r\n\r\nCarrie recognised the glance and the girl. She was one of those who\r\nworked at the machines in the shoe factory. The latter looked, not\r\nquite sure, and then turned her head and looked. Carrie felt as if some\r\ngreat tide had rolled between them. The old dress and the old machine\r\ncame back. She actually started. Drouet didn\xe2\x80\x99t notice until Carrie\r\nbumped into a pedestrian.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou must be thinking,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\nThey dined and went to the theatre. That spectacle pleased Carrie\r\nimmensely. The colour and grace of it caught her eye. She had vain\r\nimaginings about place and power, about far-off lands and magnificent\r\npeople. When it was over, the clatter of coaches and the throng of fine\r\nladies made her stare.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWait a minute,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet, holding her back in the showy foyer where\r\nladies and gentlemen were moving in a social crush, skirts rustling,\r\nlace-covered heads nodding, white teeth showing through parted lips.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet\xe2\x80\x99s see.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSixty-seven,\xe2\x80\x9d the coach-caller was saying, his voice lifted in a sort\r\nof euphonious cry. \xe2\x80\x9cSixty-seven.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIsn\xe2\x80\x99t it fine?\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGreat,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet. He was as much affected by this show of finery\r\nand gayety as she. He pressed her arm warmly. Once she looked up, her\r\neven teeth glistening through her smiling lips, her eyes alight. As\r\nthey were moving out he whispered down to her, \xe2\x80\x9cYou look lovely!\xe2\x80\x9d They\r\nwere right where the coach-caller was swinging open a coach-door and\r\nushering in two ladies.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou stick to me and we\xe2\x80\x99ll have a coach,\xe2\x80\x9d laughed Drouet.\r\n\r\nCarrie scarcely heard, her head was so full of the swirl of life. They\r\nstopped in at a restaurant for a little after-theatre lunch. Just a\r\nshade of a thought of the hour entered Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s head, but there was no\r\nhousehold law to govern her now. If any habits ever had time to fix\r\nupon her, they would have operated here. Habits are peculiar things.\r\nThey will drive the really non-religious mind out of bed to say prayers\r\nthat are only a custom and not a devotion. The victim of habit, when he\r\nhas neglected the thing which it was his custom to do, feels a little\r\nscratching in the brain, a little irritating something which comes of\r\nbeing out of the rut, and imagines it to be the prick of conscience,\r\nthe still, small voice that is urging him ever to righteousness. If the\r\ndigression is unusual enough, the drag of habit will be heavy enough to\r\ncause the unreasoning victim to return and perform the perfunctory\r\nthing. \xe2\x80\x9cNow, bless me,\xe2\x80\x9d says such a mind, \xe2\x80\x9cI have done my duty,\xe2\x80\x9d when,\r\nas a matter of fact, it has merely done its old, unbreakable trick once\r\nagain.\r\n\r\nCarrie had no excellent home principles fixed upon her. If she had, she\r\nwould have been more consciously distressed. Now the lunch went off\r\nwith considerable warmth. Under the influence of the varied\r\noccurrences, the fine, invisible passion which was emanating from\r\nDrouet, the food, the still unusual luxury, she relaxed and heard with\r\nopen ears. She was again the victim of the city\xe2\x80\x99s hypnotic influence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet at last, \xe2\x80\x9cwe had better be going.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey had been dawdling over the dishes, and their eyes had frequently\r\nmet. Carrie could not help but feel the vibration of force which\r\nfollowed, which, indeed, was his gaze. He had a way of touching her\r\nhand in explanation, as if to impress a fact upon her. He touched it\r\nnow as he spoke of going.\r\n\r\nThey arose and went out into the street. The downtown section was now\r\nbare, save for a few whistling strollers, a few _owl_ cars, a few open\r\nresorts whose windows were still bright. Out Wabash Avenue they\r\nstrolled, Drouet still pouring forth his volume of small information.\r\nHe had Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s arm in his, and held it closely as he explained. Once\r\nin a while, after some witticism, he would look down, and his eyes\r\nwould meet hers. At last they came to the steps, and Carrie stood up on\r\nthe first one, her head now coming even with his own. He took her hand\r\nand held it genially. He looked steadily at her as she glanced about,\r\nwarmly musing.\r\n\r\nAt about that hour, Minnie was soundly sleeping, after a long evening\r\nof troubled thought. She had her elbow in an awkward position under her\r\nside. The muscles so held irritated a few nerves, and now a vague scene\r\nfloated in on the drowsy mind. She fancied she and Carrie were\r\nsomewhere beside an old coal-mine. She could see the tall runway and\r\nthe heap of earth and coal cast out. There was a deep pit, into which\r\nthey were looking; they could see the curious wet stones far down where\r\nthe wall disappeared in vague shadows. An old basket, used for\r\ndescending, was hanging there, fastened by a worn rope.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet\xe2\x80\x99s get in,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no,\xe2\x80\x9d said Minnie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, come on,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\nShe began to pull the basket over, and now, in spite of all protest,\r\nshe had swung over and was going down.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCarrie,\xe2\x80\x9d she called, \xe2\x80\x9cCarrie, come back\xe2\x80\x9d; but Carrie was far down now\r\nand the shadow had swallowed her completely.\r\n\r\nShe moved her arm.\r\n\r\nNow the mystic scenery merged queerly and the place was by waters she\r\nhad never seen. They were upon some board or ground or something that\r\nreached far out, and at the end of this was Carrie. They looked about,\r\nand now the thing was sinking, and Minnie heard the low sip of the\r\nencroaching water.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome on, Carrie,\xe2\x80\x9d she called, but Carrie was reaching farther out. She\r\nseemed to recede, and now it was difficult to call to her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCarrie,\xe2\x80\x9d she called, \xe2\x80\x9cCarrie,\xe2\x80\x9d but her own voice sounded far away, and\r\nthe strange waters were blurring everything. She came away suffering as\r\nthough she had lost something. She was more inexpressibly sad than she\r\nhad ever been in life.\r\n\r\nIt was this way through many shifts of the tired brain, those curious\r\nphantoms of the spirit slipping in, blurring strange scenes, one with\r\nthe other. The last one made her cry out, for Carrie was slipping away\r\nsomewhere over a rock, and her fingers had let loose and she had seen\r\nher falling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMinnie! What\xe2\x80\x99s the matter? Here, wake up,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hanson, disturbed, and\r\nshaking her by the shoulder.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWha\xe2\x80\x94what\xe2\x80\x99s the matter?\xe2\x80\x9d said Minnie, drowsily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWake up,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cand turn over. You\xe2\x80\x99re talking in your sleep.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nA week or so later Drouet strolled into Fitzgerald and Moy\xe2\x80\x99s, spruce in\r\ndress and manner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHello, Charley,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood, looking out from his office door.\r\n\r\nDrouet strolled over and looked in upon the manager at his desk. \xe2\x80\x9cWhen\r\ndo you go out on the road again?\xe2\x80\x9d he inquired.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPretty soon,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHaven\xe2\x80\x99t seen much of you this trip,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I\xe2\x80\x99ve been busy,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet.\r\n\r\nThey talked some few minutes on general topics.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSay,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet, as if struck by a sudden idea, \xe2\x80\x9cI want you to come\r\nout some evening.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOut where?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Hurstwood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOut to my house, of course,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet, smiling.\r\n\r\nHurstwood looked up quizzically, the least suggestion of a smile\r\nhovering about his lips. He studied the face of Drouet in his wise way,\r\nand then with the demeanour of a gentleman, said: \xe2\x80\x9cCertainly; glad to.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ll have a nice game of euchre.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMay I bring a nice little bottle of Sec?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Hurstwood.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll introduce you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter IX. CONVENTION\xe2\x80\x99S OWN TINDER-BOX: THE EYE THAT IS GREEN\r\n\r\nHurstwood\xe2\x80\x99s residence on the North Side, near Lincoln Park, was a brick\r\nbuilding of a very popular type then, a three-story affair with the\r\nfirst floor sunk a very little below the level of the street. It had a\r\nlarge bay window bulging out from the second floor, and was graced in\r\nfront by a small grassy plot, twenty-five feet wide and ten feet deep.\r\nThere was also a small rear yard, walled in by the fences of the\r\nneighbours and holding a stable where he kept his horse and trap.\r\n\r\nThe ten rooms of the house were occupied by himself, his wife Julia,\r\nand his son and daughter, George, Jr., and Jessica. There were besides\r\nthese a maid-servant, represented from time to time by girls of various\r\nextraction, for Mrs. Hurstwood was not always easy to please.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGeorge, I let Mary go yesterday,\xe2\x80\x9d was not an unfrequent salutation at\r\nthe dinner table.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right,\xe2\x80\x9d was his only reply. He had long since wearied of\r\ndiscussing the rancorous subject.\r\n\r\nA lovely home atmosphere is one of the flowers of the world, than which\r\nthere is nothing more tender, nothing more delicate, nothing more\r\ncalculated to make strong and just the natures cradled and nourished\r\nwithin it. Those who have never experienced such a beneficent influence\r\nwill not understand wherefore the tear springs glistening to the\r\neyelids at some strange breath in lovely music. The mystic chords which\r\nbind and thrill the heart of the nation, they will never know.\r\n\r\nHurstwood\xe2\x80\x99s residence could scarcely be said to be infused with this\r\nhome spirit. It lacked that toleration and regard without which the\r\nhome is nothing. There was fine furniture, arranged as soothingly as\r\nthe artistic perception of the occupants warranted. There were soft\r\nrugs, rich, upholstered chairs and divans, a grand piano, a marble\r\ncarving of some unknown Venus by some unknown artist, and a number of\r\nsmall bronzes gathered from heaven knows where, but generally sold by\r\nthe large furniture houses along with everything else which goes to\r\nmake the \xe2\x80\x9cperfectly appointed house.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn the dining-room stood a sideboard laden with glistening decanters\r\nand other utilities and ornaments in glass, the arrangement of which\r\ncould not be questioned. Here was something Hurstwood knew about. He\r\nhad studied the subject for years in his business. He took no little\r\nsatisfaction in telling each Mary, shortly after she arrived, something\r\nof what the art of the thing required. He was not garrulous by any\r\nmeans. On the contrary, there was a fine reserve in his manner toward\r\nthe entire domestic economy of his life which was all that is\r\ncomprehended by the popular term, gentlemanly. He would not argue, he\r\nwould not talk freely. In his manner was something of the dogmatist.\r\nWhat he could not correct, he would ignore. There was a tendency in him\r\nto walk away from the impossible thing.\r\n\r\nThere was a time when he had been considerably enamoured of his\r\nJessica, especially when he was younger and more confined in his\r\nsuccess. Now, however, in her seventeenth year, Jessica had developed a\r\ncertain amount of reserve and independence which was not inviting to\r\nthe richest form of parental devotion. She was in the high school, and\r\nhad notions of life which were decidedly those of a patrician. She\r\nliked nice clothes and urged for them constantly. Thoughts of love and\r\nelegant individual establishments were running in her head. She met\r\ngirls at the high school whose parents were truly rich and whose\r\nfathers had standing locally as partners or owners of solid businesses.\r\nThese girls gave themselves the airs befitting the thriving domestic\r\nestablishments from whence they issued. They were the only ones of the\r\nschool about whom Jessica concerned herself.\r\n\r\nYoung Hurstwood, Jr., was in his twentieth year, and was already\r\nconnected in a promising capacity with a large real estate firm. He\r\ncontributed nothing for the domestic expenses of the family, but was\r\nthought to be saving his money to invest in real estate. He had some\r\nability, considerable vanity, and a love of pleasure that had not, as\r\nyet, infringed upon his duties, whatever they were. He came in and went\r\nout, pursuing his own plans and fancies, addressing a few words to his\r\nmother occasionally, relating some little incident to his father, but\r\nfor the most part confining himself to those generalities with which\r\nmost conversation concerns itself. He was not laying bare his desires\r\nfor any one to see. He did not find any one in the house who\r\nparticularly cared to see.\r\n\r\nMrs. Hurstwood was the type of woman who has ever endeavoured to shine\r\nand has been more or less chagrined at the evidences of superior\r\ncapability in this direction elsewhere. Her knowledge of life extended\r\nto that little conventional round of society of which she was not\xe2\x80\x94but\r\nlonged to be\xe2\x80\x94a member. She was not without realisation already that\r\nthis thing was impossible, so far as she was concerned. For her\r\ndaughter, she hoped better things. Through Jessica she might rise a\r\nlittle. Through George, Jr.\xe2\x80\x99s, possible success she might draw to\r\nherself the privilege of pointing proudly. Even Hurstwood was doing\r\nwell enough, and she was anxious that his small real estate adventures\r\nshould prosper. His property holdings, as yet, were rather small, but\r\nhis income was pleasing and his position with Fitzgerald and Moy was\r\nfixed. Both those gentlemen were on pleasant and rather informal terms\r\nwith him.\r\n\r\nThe atmosphere which such personalities would create must be apparent\r\nto all. It worked out in a thousand little conversations, all of which\r\nwere of the same calibre.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m going up to Fox Lake to-morrow,\xe2\x80\x9d announced George, Jr., at the\r\ndinner table one Friday evening.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s going on up there?\xe2\x80\x9d queried Mrs. Hurstwood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEddie Fahrway\xe2\x80\x99s got a new steam launch, and he wants me to come up and\r\nsee how it works.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow much did it cost him?\xe2\x80\x9d asked his mother.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, over two thousand dollars. He says it\xe2\x80\x99s a dandy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOld Fahrway must be making money,\xe2\x80\x9d put in Hurstwood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is, I guess. Jack told me they were shipping Vegacura to Australia\r\nnow\xe2\x80\x94said they sent a whole box to Cape Town last week.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJust think of that!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Hurstwood, \xe2\x80\x9cand only four years ago\r\nthey had that basement in Madison Street.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJack told me they were going to put up a six-story building next\r\nspring in Robey Street.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJust think of that!\xe2\x80\x9d said Jessica.\r\n\r\nOn this particular occasion Hurstwood wished to leave early.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI guess I\xe2\x80\x99ll be going down town,\xe2\x80\x9d he remarked, rising.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre we going to McVicker\xe2\x80\x99s Monday?\xe2\x80\x9d questioned Mrs. Hurstwood, without\r\nrising.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d he said indifferently.\r\n\r\nThey went on dining, while he went upstairs for his hat and coat.\r\nPresently the door clicked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI guess papa\xe2\x80\x99s gone,\xe2\x80\x9d said Jessica.\r\n\r\nThe latter\xe2\x80\x99s school news was of a particular stripe.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99re going to give a performance in the Lyceum, upstairs,\xe2\x80\x9d she\r\nreported one day, \xe2\x80\x9cand I\xe2\x80\x99m going to be in it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you?\xe2\x80\x9d said her mother.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll have to have a new dress. Some of the nicest girls in\r\nthe school are going to be in it. Miss Palmer is going to take the part\r\nof Portia.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs she?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Hurstwood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99ve got that Martha Griswold in it again. She thinks she can act.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHer family doesn\xe2\x80\x99t amount to anything, does it?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Hurstwood\r\nsympathetically. \xe2\x80\x9cThey haven\xe2\x80\x99t anything, have they?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Jessica, \xe2\x80\x9cthey\xe2\x80\x99re poor as church mice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe distinguished very carefully between the young boys of the school,\r\nmany of whom were attracted by her beauty.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you think?\xe2\x80\x9d she remarked to her mother one evening; \xe2\x80\x9cthat\r\nHerbert Crane tried to make friends with me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho is he, my dear?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Mrs. Hurstwood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no one,\xe2\x80\x9d said Jessica, pursing her pretty lips. \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s just a\r\nstudent there. He hasn\xe2\x80\x99t anything.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe other half of this picture came when young Blyford, son of Blyford,\r\nthe soap manufacturer, walked home with her. Mrs. Hurstwood was on the\r\nthird floor, sitting in a rocking-chair reading, and happened to look\r\nout at the time.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho was that with you, Jessica?\xe2\x80\x9d she inquired, as Jessica came\r\nupstairs.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s Mr. Blyford, mamma,\xe2\x80\x9d she replied.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Hurstwood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, and he wants me to stroll over into the park with him,\xe2\x80\x9d explained\r\nJessica, a little flushed with running up the stairs.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right, my dear,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Hurstwood. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t be gone long.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs the two went down the street, she glanced interestedly out of the\r\nwindow. It was a most satisfactory spectacle indeed, most satisfactory.\r\n\r\nIn this atmosphere Hurstwood had moved for a number of years, not\r\nthinking deeply concerning it. His was not the order of nature to\r\ntrouble for something better, unless the better was immediately and\r\nsharply contrasted. As it was, he received and gave, irritated\r\nsometimes by the little displays of selfish indifference, pleased at\r\ntimes by some show of finery which supposedly made for dignity and\r\nsocial distinction. The life of the resort which he managed was his\r\nlife. There he spent most of his time. When he went home evenings the\r\nhouse looked nice. With rare exceptions the meals were acceptable,\r\nbeing the kind that an ordinary servant can arrange. In part, he was\r\ninterested in the talk of his son and daughter, who always looked well.\r\nThe vanity of Mrs. Hurstwood caused her to keep her person rather\r\nshowily arrayed, but to Hurstwood this was much better than plainness.\r\nThere was no love lost between them. There was no great feeling of\r\ndissatisfaction. Her opinion on any subject was not startling. They did\r\nnot talk enough together to come to the argument of any one point. In\r\nthe accepted and popular phrase, she had her ideas and he had his. Once\r\nin a while he would meet a woman whose youth, sprightliness, and humour\r\nwould make his wife seem rather deficient by contrast, but the\r\ntemporary dissatisfaction which such an encounter might arouse would be\r\ncounterbalanced by his social position and a certain matter of policy.\r\nHe could not complicate his home life, because it might affect his\r\nrelations with his employers. They wanted no scandals. A man, to hold\r\nhis position, must have a dignified manner, a clean record, a\r\nrespectable home anchorage. Therefore he was circumspect in all he did,\r\nand whenever he appeared in the public ways in the afternoon, or on\r\nSunday, it was with his wife, and sometimes his children. He would\r\nvisit the local resorts, or those near by in Wisconsin, and spend a few\r\nstiff, polished days strolling about conventional places doing\r\nconventional things. He knew the need of it.\r\n\r\nWhen some one of the many middle-class individuals whom he knew, who\r\nhad money, would get into trouble, he would shake his head. It didn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ndo to talk about those things. If it came up for discussion among such\r\nfriends as with him passed for close, he would deprecate the folly of\r\nthe thing. \xe2\x80\x9cIt was all right to do it\xe2\x80\x94all men do those things\xe2\x80\x94but why\r\nwasn\xe2\x80\x99t he careful? A man can\xe2\x80\x99t be too careful.\xe2\x80\x9d He lost sympathy for\r\nthe man that made a mistake and was found out.\r\n\r\nOn this account he still devoted some time to showing his wife\r\nabout\xe2\x80\x94time which would have been wearisome indeed if it had not been\r\nfor the people he would meet and the little enjoyments which did not\r\ndepend upon her presence or absence. He watched her with considerable\r\ncuriosity at times, for she was still attractive in a way and men\r\nlooked at her. She was affable, vain, subject to flattery, and this\r\ncombination, he knew quite well, might produce a tragedy in a woman of\r\nher home position. Owing to his order of mind, his confidence in the\r\nsex was not great. His wife never possessed the virtues which would win\r\nthe confidence and admiration of a man of his nature. As long as she\r\nloved him vigorously he could see how confidence could be, but when\r\nthat was no longer the binding chain\xe2\x80\x94well, something might happen.\r\n\r\nDuring the last year or two the expenses of the family seemed a large\r\nthing. Jessica wanted fine clothes, and Mrs. Hurstwood, not to be\r\noutshone by her daughter, also frequently enlivened her apparel.\r\nHurstwood had said nothing in the past, but one day he murmured.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJessica must have a new dress this month,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Hurstwood one\r\nmorning.\r\n\r\nHurstwood was arraying himself in one of his perfection vests before\r\nthe glass at the time.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thought she just bought one,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat was just something for evening wear,\xe2\x80\x9d returned his wife\r\ncomplacently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt seems to me,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Hurstwood, \xe2\x80\x9cthat she\xe2\x80\x99s spending a good deal\r\nfor dresses of late.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, she\xe2\x80\x99s going out more,\xe2\x80\x9d concluded his wife, but the tone of his\r\nvoice impressed her as containing something she had not heard there\r\nbefore.\r\n\r\nHe was not a man who traveled much, but when he did, he had been\r\naccustomed to take her along. On one occasion recently a local\r\naldermanic junket had been arranged to visit Philadelphia\xe2\x80\x94a junket that\r\nwas to last ten days. Hurstwood had been invited.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNobody knows us down there,\xe2\x80\x9d said one, a gentleman whose face was a\r\nslight improvement over gross ignorance and sensuality. He always wore\r\na silk hat of most imposing proportions. \xe2\x80\x9cWe can have a good time.\xe2\x80\x9d His\r\nleft eye moved with just the semblance of a wink. \xe2\x80\x9cYou want to come\r\nalong, George.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe next day Hurstwood announced his intention to his wife.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m going away, Julia,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cfor a few days.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked, looking up.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo Philadelphia, on business.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe looked at him consciously, expecting something else.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll have to leave you behind this time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right,\xe2\x80\x9d she replied, but he could see that she was thinking that\r\nit was a curious thing. Before he went she asked him a few more\r\nquestions, and that irritated him. He began to feel that she was a\r\ndisagreeable attachment.\r\n\r\nOn this trip he enjoyed himself thoroughly, and when it was over he was\r\nsorry to get back. He was not willingly a prevaricator, and hated\r\nthoroughly to make explanations concerning it. The whole incident was\r\nglossed over with general remarks, but Mrs. Hurstwood gave the subject\r\nconsiderable thought. She drove out more, dressed better, and attended\r\ntheatres freely to make up for it.\r\n\r\nSuch an atmosphere could hardly come under the category of home life.\r\nIt ran along by force of habit, by force of conventional opinion. With\r\nthe lapse of time it must necessarily become dryer and dryer\xe2\x80\x94must\r\neventually be tinder, easily lighted and destroyed.\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter X. THE COUNSEL OF WINTER: FORTUNE\xe2\x80\x99S AMBASSADOR CALLS\r\n\r\nIn the light of the world\xe2\x80\x99s attitude toward woman and her duties, the\r\nnature of Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s mental state deserves consideration. Actions such as\r\nhers are measured by an arbitrary scale. Society possesses a\r\nconventional standard whereby it judges all things. All men should be\r\ngood, all women virtuous. Wherefore, villain, hast thou failed?\r\n\r\nFor all the liberal analysis of Spencer and our modern naturalistic\r\nphilosophers, we have but an infantile perception of morals. There is\r\nmore in the subject than mere conformity to a law of evolution. It is\r\nyet deeper than conformity to things of earth alone. It is more\r\ninvolved than we, as yet, perceive. Answer, first, why the heart\r\nthrills; explain wherefore some plaintive note goes wandering about the\r\nworld, undying; make clear the rose\xe2\x80\x99s subtle alchemy evolving its ruddy\r\nlamp in light and rain. In the essence of these facts lie the first\r\nprinciples of morals.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Drouet, \xe2\x80\x9chow delicious is my conquest.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Carrie, with mournful misgivings, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat is it I have\r\nlost?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBefore this world-old proposition we stand, serious, interested,\r\nconfused; endeavouring to evolve the true theory of morals\xe2\x80\x94the true\r\nanswer to what is right.\r\n\r\nIn the view of a certain stratum of society, Carrie was comfortably\r\nestablished\xe2\x80\x94in the eyes of the starveling, beaten by every wind and\r\ngusty sheet of rain, she was safe in a halcyon harbour. Drouet had\r\ntaken three rooms, furnished, in Ogden Place, facing Union Park, on the\r\nWest Side. That was a little, green-carpeted breathing spot, than\r\nwhich, to-day, there is nothing more beautiful in Chicago. It afforded\r\na vista pleasant to contemplate. The best room looked out upon the lawn\r\nof the park, now sear and brown, where a little lake lay sheltered.\r\nOver the bare limbs of the trees, which now swayed in the wintry wind,\r\nrose the steeple of the Union Park Congregational Church, and far off\r\nthe towers of several others.\r\n\r\nThe rooms were comfortably enough furnished. There was a good Brussels\r\ncarpet on the floor, rich in dull red and lemon shades, and\r\nrepresenting large jardini\xc3\xa8res filled with gorgeous, impossible\r\nflowers. There was a large pier-glass mirror between the two windows. A\r\nlarge, soft, green, plush-covered couch occupied one corner, and\r\nseveral rocking-chairs were set about. Some pictures, several rugs, a\r\nfew small pieces of bric-\xc3\xa0-brac, and the tale of contents is told.\r\n\r\nIn the bedroom, off the front room, was Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s trunk, bought by\r\nDrouet, and in the wardrobe built into the wall quite an array of\r\nclothing\xe2\x80\x94more than she had ever possessed before, and of very becoming\r\ndesigns. There was a third room for possible use as a kitchen, where\r\nDrouet had Carrie establish a little portable gas stove for the\r\npreparation of small lunches, oysters, Welsh rarebits, and the like, of\r\nwhich he was exceedingly fond; and, lastly, a bath. The whole place was\r\ncosey, in that it was lighted by gas and heated by furnace registers,\r\npossessing also a small grate, set with an asbestos back, a method of\r\ncheerful warming which was then first coming into use. By her industry\r\nand natural love of order, which now developed, the place maintained an\r\nair pleasing in the extreme.\r\n\r\nHere, then, was Carrie, established in a pleasant fashion, free of\r\ncertain difficulties which most ominously confronted her, laden with\r\nmany new ones which were of a mental order, and altogether so turned\r\nabout in all of her earthly relationships that she might well have been\r\na new and different individual. She looked into her glass and saw a\r\nprettier Carrie than she had seen before; she looked into her mind, a\r\nmirror prepared of her own and the world\xe2\x80\x99s opinions, and saw a worse.\r\nBetween these two images she wavered, hesitating which to believe.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy, but you\xe2\x80\x99re a little beauty,\xe2\x80\x9d Drouet was wont to exclaim to her.\r\n\r\nShe would look at him with large, pleased eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know it, don\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x9d he would continue.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d she would reply, feeling delight in the fact that\r\none should think so, hesitating to believe, though she really did, that\r\nshe was vain enough to think so much of herself.\r\n\r\nHer conscience, however, was not a Drouet, interested to praise. There\r\nshe heard a different voice, with which she argued, pleaded, excused.\r\nIt was no just and sapient counsellor, in its last analysis. It was\r\nonly an average little conscience, a thing which represented the world,\r\nher past environment, habit, convention, in a confused way. With it,\r\nthe voice of the people was truly the voice of God.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, thou failure!\xe2\x80\x9d said the voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy?\xe2\x80\x9d she questioned.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLook at those about,\xe2\x80\x9d came the whispered answer. \xe2\x80\x9cLook at those who\r\nare good. How would they scorn to do what you have done. Look at the\r\ngood girls; how will they draw away from such as you when they know you\r\nhave been weak. You had not tried before you failed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was when Carrie was alone, looking out across the park, that she\r\nwould be listening to this. It would come infrequently\xe2\x80\x94when something\r\nelse did not interfere, when the pleasant side was not too apparent,\r\nwhen Drouet was not there. It was somewhat clear in utterance at first,\r\nbut never wholly convincing. There was always an answer, always the\r\nDecember days threatened. She was alone; she was desireful; she was\r\nfearful of the whistling wind. The voice of want made answer for her.\r\n\r\nOnce the bright days of summer pass by, a city takes on that sombre\r\ngarb of grey, wrapt in which it goes about its labours during the long\r\nwinter. Its endless buildings look grey, its sky and its streets assume\r\na sombre hue; the scattered, leafless trees and wind-blown dust and\r\npaper but add to the general solemnity of colour. There seems to be\r\nsomething in the chill breezes which scurry through the long, narrow\r\nthoroughfares productive of rueful thoughts. Not poets alone, nor\r\nartists, nor that superior order of mind which arrogates to itself all\r\nrefinement, feel this, but dogs and all men. These feel as much as the\r\npoet, though they have not the same power of expression. The sparrow\r\nupon the wire, the cat in the doorway, the dray horse tugging his weary\r\nload, feel the long, keen breaths of winter. It strikes to the heart of\r\nall life, animate and inanimate. If it were not for the artificial\r\nfires of merriment, the rush of profit-seeking trade, and\r\npleasure-selling amusements; if the various merchants failed to make\r\nthe customary display within and without their establishments; if our\r\nstreets were not strung with signs of gorgeous hues and thronged with\r\nhurrying purchasers, we would quickly discover how firmly the chill\r\nhand of winter lays upon the heart; how dispiriting are the days during\r\nwhich the sun withholds a portion of our allowance of light and warmth.\r\nWe are more dependent upon these things than is often thought. We are\r\ninsects produced by heat, and pass without it.\r\n\r\nIn the drag of such a grey day the secret voice would reassert itself,\r\nfeebly and more feebly.\r\n\r\nSuch mental conflict was not always uppermost. Carrie was not by any\r\nmeans a gloomy soul. More, she had not the mind to get firm hold upon a\r\ndefinite truth. When she could not find her way out of the labyrinth of\r\nill-logic which thought upon the subject created, she would turn away\r\nentirely.\r\n\r\nDrouet, all the time, was conducting himself in a model way for one of\r\nhis sort. He took her about a great deal, spent money upon her, and\r\nwhen he travelled took her with him. There were times when she would be\r\nalone for two or three days, while he made the shorter circuits of his\r\nbusiness, but, as a rule, she saw a great deal of him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSay, Carrie,\xe2\x80\x9d he said one morning, shortly after they had so\r\nestablished themselves, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve invited my friend Hurstwood to come out\r\nsome day and spend the evening with us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho is he?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Carrie doubtfully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, he\xe2\x80\x99s a nice man. He\xe2\x80\x99s manager of Fitzgerald and Moy\xe2\x80\x99s.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s that?\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe finest resort in town. It\xe2\x80\x99s a way-up, swell place.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie puzzled a moment. She was wondering what Drouet had told him,\r\nwhat her attitude would be.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s all right,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet, feeling her thought. \xe2\x80\x9cHe doesn\xe2\x80\x99t know\r\nanything. You\xe2\x80\x99re Mrs. Drouet now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was something about this which struck Carrie as slightly\r\ninconsiderate. She could see that Drouet did not have the keenest\r\nsensibilities.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy don\xe2\x80\x99t we get married?\xe2\x80\x9d she inquired, thinking of the voluble\r\npromises he had made.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, we will,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cjust as soon as I get this little deal of\r\nmine closed up.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe was referring to some property which he said he had, and which\r\nrequired so much attention, adjustment, and what not, that somehow or\r\nother it interfered with his free moral, personal actions.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJust as soon as I get back from my Denver trip in January we\xe2\x80\x99ll do\r\nit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie accepted this as basis for hope\xe2\x80\x94it was a sort of salve to her\r\nconscience, a pleasant way out. Under the circumstances, things would\r\nbe righted. Her actions would be justified. She really was not\r\nenamoured of Drouet. She was more clever than he. In a dim way, she was\r\nbeginning to see where he lacked. If it had not been for this, if she\r\nhad not been able to measure and judge him in a way, she would have\r\nbeen worse off than she was. She would have adored him. She would have\r\nbeen utterly wretched in her fear of not gaining his affection, of\r\nlosing his interest, of being swept away and left without an anchorage.\r\nAs it was, she wavered a little, slightly anxious, at first, to gain\r\nhim completely, but later feeling at ease in waiting. She was not\r\nexactly sure what she thought of him\xe2\x80\x94what she wanted to do.\r\n\r\nWhen Hurstwood called, she met a man who was more clever than Drouet in\r\na hundred ways. He paid that peculiar deference to women which every\r\nmember of the sex appreciates. He was not overawed, he was not\r\noverbold. His great charm was attentiveness. Schooled in winning those\r\nbirds of fine feather among his own sex, the merchants and\r\nprofessionals who visited his resort, he could use even greater tact\r\nwhen endeavouring to prove agreeable to some one who charmed him. In a\r\npretty woman of any refinement of feeling whatsoever he found his\r\ngreatest incentive. He was mild, placid, assured, giving the impression\r\nthat he wished to be of service only\xe2\x80\x94to do something which would make\r\nthe lady more pleased.\r\n\r\nDrouet had ability in this line himself when the game was worth the\r\ncandle, but he was too much the egotist to reach the polish which\r\nHurstwood possessed. He was too buoyant, too full of ruddy life, too\r\nassured. He succeeded with many who were not quite schooled in the art\r\nof love. He failed dismally where the woman was slightly experienced\r\nand possessed innate refinement. In the case of Carrie he found a woman\r\nwho was all of the latter, but none of the former. He was lucky in the\r\nfact that opportunity tumbled into his lap, as it were. A few years\r\nlater, with a little more experience, the slightest tide of success,\r\nand he had not been able to approach Carrie at all.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou ought to have a piano here, Drouet,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood, smiling at\r\nCarrie, on the evening in question, \xe2\x80\x9cso that your wife could play.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDrouet had not thought of that.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo we ought,\xe2\x80\x9d he observed readily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I don\xe2\x80\x99t play,\xe2\x80\x9d ventured Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt isn\xe2\x80\x99t very difficult,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Hurstwood. \xe2\x80\x9cYou could do very well\r\nin a few weeks.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe was in the best form for entertaining this evening. His clothes were\r\nparticularly new and rich in appearance. The coat lapels stood out with\r\nthat medium stiffness which excellent cloth possesses. The vest was of\r\na rich Scotch plaid, set with a double row of round mother-of-pearl\r\nbuttons. His cravat was a shiny combination of silken threads, not\r\nloud, not inconspicuous. What he wore did not strike the eye so\r\nforcibly as that which Drouet had on, but Carrie could see the elegance\r\nof the material. Hurstwood\xe2\x80\x99s shoes were of soft, black calf, polished\r\nonly to a dull shine. Drouet wore patent leather but Carrie could not\r\nhelp feeling that there was a distinction in favour of the soft\r\nleather, where all else was so rich. She noticed these things almost\r\nunconsciously. They were things which would naturally flow from the\r\nsituation. She was used to Drouet\xe2\x80\x99s appearance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSuppose we have a little game of euchre?\xe2\x80\x9d suggested Hurstwood, after a\r\nlight round of conversation. He was rather dexterous in avoiding\r\neverything that would suggest that he knew anything of Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s past.\r\nHe kept away from personalities altogether, and confined himself to\r\nthose things which did not concern individuals at all. By his manner,\r\nhe put Carrie at her ease, and by his deference and pleasantries he\r\namused her. He pretended to be seriously interested in all she said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know how to play,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCharlie, you are neglecting a part of your duty,\xe2\x80\x9d he observed to\r\nDrouet most affably. \xe2\x80\x9cBetween us, though,\xe2\x80\x9d he went on, \xe2\x80\x9cwe can show\r\nyou.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBy his tact he made Drouet feel that he admired his choice. There was\r\nsomething in his manner that showed that he was pleased to be there.\r\nDrouet felt really closer to him than ever before. It gave him more\r\nrespect for Carrie. Her appearance came into a new light, under\r\nHurstwood\xe2\x80\x99s appreciation. The situation livened considerably.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, let me see,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood, looking over Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s shoulder very\r\ndeferentially. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat have you?\xe2\x80\x9d He studied for a moment. \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s rather\r\ngood,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re lucky. Now, I\xe2\x80\x99ll show you how to trounce your husband. You take\r\nmy advice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet, \xe2\x80\x9cif you two are going to scheme together, I won\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nstand a ghost of a show. Hurstwood\xe2\x80\x99s a regular sharp.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, it\xe2\x80\x99s your wife. She brings me luck. Why shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t she win?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie looked gratefully at Hurstwood, and smiled at Drouet. The former\r\ntook the air of a mere friend. He was simply there to enjoy himself.\r\nAnything that Carrie did was pleasing to him, nothing more.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, holding back one of his own good cards, and giving\r\nCarrie a chance to take a trick. \xe2\x80\x9cI count that clever playing for a\r\nbeginner.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe latter laughed gleefully as she saw the hand coming her way. It was\r\nas if she were invincible when Hurstwood helped her.\r\n\r\nHe did not look at her often. When he did, it was with a mild light in\r\nhis eye. Not a shade was there of anything save geniality and kindness.\r\nHe took back the shifty, clever gleam, and replaced it with one of\r\ninnocence. Carrie could not guess but that it was pleasure with him in\r\nthe immediate thing. She felt that he considered she was doing a great\r\ndeal.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s unfair to let such playing go without earning something,\xe2\x80\x9d he said\r\nafter a time, slipping his finger into the little coin pocket of his\r\ncoat. \xe2\x80\x9cLet\xe2\x80\x99s play for dimes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet, fishing for bills.\r\n\r\nHurstwood was quicker. His fingers were full of new ten-cent pieces.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere we are,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, supplying each one with a little stack.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, this is gambling,\xe2\x80\x9d smiled Carrie. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s bad.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet, \xe2\x80\x9conly fun. If you never play for more than that, you\r\nwill go to Heaven.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t you moralise,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood to Carrie gently, \xe2\x80\x9cuntil you see\r\nwhat becomes of the money.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDrouet smiled.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf your husband gets them, he\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you how bad it is.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDrouet laughed loud.\r\n\r\nThere was such an ingratiating tone about Hurstwood\xe2\x80\x99s voice, the\r\ninsinuation was so perceptible that even Carrie got the humour of it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen do you leave?\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood to Drouet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn Wednesday,\xe2\x80\x9d he replied.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s rather hard to have your husband running about like that, isn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nit?\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood, addressing Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe\xe2\x80\x99s going along with me this time,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou must both go with me to the theatre before you go.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet. \xe2\x80\x9cEh, Carrie?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d like it ever so much,\xe2\x80\x9d she replied.\r\n\r\nHurstwood did his best to see that Carrie won the money. He rejoiced in\r\nher success, kept counting her winnings, and finally gathered and put\r\nthem in her extended hand. They spread a little lunch, at which he\r\nserved the wine, and afterwards he used fine tact in going.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, addressing first Carrie and then Drouet with his eyes,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cyou must be ready at 7.30. I\xe2\x80\x99ll come and get you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey went with him to the door and there was his cab waiting, its red\r\nlamps gleaming cheerfully in the shadow.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow,\xe2\x80\x9d he observed to Drouet, with a tone of good-fellowship, \xe2\x80\x9cwhen you\r\nleave your wife alone, you must let me show her around a little. It\r\nwill break up her loneliness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSure,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet, quite pleased at the attention shown.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re so kind,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot at all,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood, \xe2\x80\x9cI would want your husband to do as much\r\nfor me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe smiled and went lightly away. Carrie was thoroughly impressed. She\r\nhad never come in contact with such grace. As for Drouet, he was\r\nequally pleased.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s a nice man,\xe2\x80\x9d he remarked to Carrie, as they returned to their\r\ncosey chamber. \xe2\x80\x9cA good friend of mine, too.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe seems to be,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XI. THE PERSUASION OF FASHION: FEELING GUARDS O\xe2\x80\x99ER ITS OWN\r\n\r\nCarrie was an apt student of fortune\xe2\x80\x99s ways\xe2\x80\x94of fortune\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nsuperficialities. Seeing a thing, she would immediately set to\r\ninquiring how she would look, properly related to it. Be it known that\r\nthis is not fine feeling, it is not wisdom. The greatest minds are not\r\nso afflicted; and on the contrary, the lowest order of mind is not so\r\ndisturbed. Fine clothes to her were a vast persuasion; they spoke\r\ntenderly and Jesuitically for themselves. When she came within earshot\r\nof their pleading, desire in her bent a willing ear. The voice of the\r\nso-called inanimate! Who shall translate for us the language of the\r\nstones?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear,\xe2\x80\x9d said the lace collar she secured from Partridge\xe2\x80\x99s, \xe2\x80\x9cI fit\r\nyou beautifully; don\xe2\x80\x99t give me up.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, such little feet,\xe2\x80\x9d said the leather of the soft new shoes; \xe2\x80\x9chow\r\neffectively I cover them. What a pity they should ever want my aid.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOnce these things were in her hand, on her person, she might dream of\r\ngiving them up; the method by which they came might intrude itself so\r\nforcibly that she would ache to be rid of the thought of it, but she\r\nwould not give them up. \xe2\x80\x9cPut on the old clothes\xe2\x80\x94that torn pair of\r\nshoes,\xe2\x80\x9d was called to her by her conscience in vain. She could possibly\r\nhave conquered the fear of hunger and gone back; the thought of hard\r\nwork and a narrow round of suffering would, under the last pressure of\r\nconscience, have yielded, but spoil her appearance?\xe2\x80\x94be old-clothed and\r\npoor-appearing?\xe2\x80\x94never!\r\n\r\nDrouet heightened her opinion on this and allied subjects in such a\r\nmanner as to weaken her power of resisting their influence. It is so\r\neasy to do this when the thing opined is in the line of what we desire.\r\nIn his hearty way, he insisted upon her good looks. He looked at her\r\nadmiringly, and she took it at its full value. Under the circumstances,\r\nshe did not need to carry herself as pretty women do. She picked that\r\nknowledge up fast enough for herself. Drouet had a habit,\r\ncharacteristic of his kind, of looking after stylishly dressed or\r\npretty women on the street and remarking upon them. He had just enough\r\nof the feminine love of dress to be a good judge\xe2\x80\x94not of intellect, but\r\nof clothes. He saw how they set their little feet, how they carried\r\ntheir chins, with what grace and sinuosity they swung their bodies. A\r\ndainty, self-conscious swaying of the hips by a woman was to him as\r\nalluring as the glint of rare wine to a toper. He would turn and follow\r\nthe disappearing vision with his eyes. He would thrill as a child with\r\nthe unhindered passion that was in him. He loved the thing that women\r\nlove in themselves, grace. At this, their own shrine, he knelt with\r\nthem, an ardent devotee.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you see that woman who went by just now?\xe2\x80\x9d he said to Carrie on the\r\nfirst day they took a walk together. \xe2\x80\x9cFine stepper, wasn\xe2\x80\x99t she?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie looked, and observed the grace commended.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, she is,\xe2\x80\x9d she returned, cheerfully, a little suggestion of\r\npossible defect in herself awakening in her mind. If that was so fine,\r\nshe must look at it more closely. Instinctively, she felt a desire to\r\nimitate it. Surely she could do that too.\r\n\r\nWhen one of her mind sees many things emphasized and re-emphasized and\r\nadmired, she gathers the logic of it and applies accordingly. Drouet\r\nwas not shrewd enough to see that this was not tactful. He could not\r\nsee that it would be better to make her feel that she was competing\r\nwith herself, not others better than herself. He would not have done it\r\nwith an older, wiser woman, but in Carrie he saw only the novice. Less\r\nclever than she, he was naturally unable to comprehend her sensibility.\r\nHe went on educating and wounding her, a thing rather foolish in one\r\nwhose admiration for his pupil and victim was apt to grow.\r\n\r\nCarrie took the instructions affably. She saw what Drouet liked; in a\r\nvague way she saw where he was weak. It lessens a woman\xe2\x80\x99s opinion of a\r\nman when she learns that his admiration is so pointedly and generously\r\ndistributed. She sees but one object of supreme compliment in this\r\nworld, and that is herself. If a man is to succeed with many women, he\r\nmust be all in all to each.\r\n\r\nIn her own apartments Carrie saw things which were lessons in the same\r\nschool.\r\n\r\nIn the same house with her lived an official of one of the theatres,\r\nMr. Frank A. Hale, manager of the Standard, and his wife, a\r\npleasing-looking brunette of thirty-five. They were people of a sort\r\nvery common in America to-day, who live respectably from hand to mouth.\r\nHale received a salary of forty-five dollars a week. His wife, quite\r\nattractive, affected the feeling of youth, and objected to that sort of\r\nhome life which means the care of a house and the raising of a family.\r\nLike Drouet and Carrie, they also occupied three rooms on the floor\r\nabove.\r\n\r\nNot long after she arrived Mrs. Hale established social relations with\r\nher, and together they went about. For a long time this was her only\r\ncompanionship, and the gossip of the manager\xe2\x80\x99s wife formed the medium\r\nthrough which she saw the world. Such trivialities, such praises of\r\nwealth, such conventional expression of morals as sifted through this\r\npassive creature\xe2\x80\x99s mind, fell upon Carrie and for the while confused\r\nher.\r\n\r\nOn the other hand, her own feelings were a corrective influence. The\r\nconstant drag to something better was not to be denied. By those things\r\nwhich address the heart was she steadily recalled. In the apartments\r\nacross the hall were a young girl and her mother. They were from\r\nEvansville, Indiana, the wife and daughter of a railroad treasurer. The\r\ndaughter was here to study music, the mother to keep her company.\r\n\r\nCarrie did not make their acquaintance, but she saw the daughter coming\r\nin and going out. A few times she had seen her at the piano in the\r\nparlour, and not infrequently had heard her play. This young woman was\r\nparticularly dressy for her station, and wore a jewelled ring or two\r\nwhich flashed upon her white fingers as she played.\r\n\r\nNow Carrie was affected by music. Her nervous composition responded to\r\ncertain strains, much as certain strings of a harp vibrate when a\r\ncorresponding key of a piano is struck. She was delicately moulded in\r\nsentiment, and answered with vague ruminations to certain wistful\r\nchords. They awoke longings for those things which she did not have.\r\nThey caused her to cling closer to things she possessed. One short song\r\nthe young lady played in a most soulful and tender mood. Carrie heard\r\nit through the open door from the parlour below. It was at that hour\r\nbetween afternoon and night when, for the idle, the wanderer, things\r\nare apt to take on a wistful aspect. The mind wanders forth on far\r\njourneys and returns with sheaves of withered and departed joys. Carrie\r\nsat at her window looking out. Drouet had been away since ten in the\r\nmorning. She had amused herself with a walk, a book by Bertha M. Clay\r\nwhich Drouet had left there, though she did not wholly enjoy the\r\nlatter, and by changing her dress for the evening. Now she sat looking\r\nout across the park as wistful and depressed as the nature which craves\r\nvariety and life can be under such circumstances. As she contemplated\r\nher new state, the strain from the parlour below stole upward. With it\r\nher thoughts became coloured and enmeshed. She reverted to the things\r\nwhich were best and saddest within the small limit of her experience.\r\nShe became for the moment a repentant.\r\n\r\nWhile she was in this mood Drouet came in, bringing with him an\r\nentirely different atmosphere. It was dusk and Carrie had neglected to\r\nlight the lamp. The fire in the grate, too, had burned low.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere are you, Cad?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, using a pet name he had given her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered.\r\n\r\nThere was something delicate and lonely in her voice, but he could not\r\nhear it. He had not the poetry in him that would seek a woman out under\r\nsuch circumstances and console her for the tragedy of life. Instead, he\r\nstruck a match and lighted the gas.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHello,\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed, \xe2\x80\x9cyou\xe2\x80\x99ve been crying.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHer eyes were still wet with a few vague tears.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPshaw,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cyou don\xe2\x80\x99t want to do that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe took her hand, feeling in his good-natured egotism that it was\r\nprobably lack of his presence which had made her lonely.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome on, now,\xe2\x80\x9d he went on; \xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99s all right. Let\xe2\x80\x99s waltz a little to\r\nthat music.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe could not have introduced a more incongruous proposition. It made\r\nclear to Carrie that he could not sympathise with her. She could not\r\nhave framed thoughts which would have expressed his defect or made\r\nclear the difference between them, but she felt it. It was his first\r\ngreat mistake.\r\n\r\nWhat Drouet said about the girl\xe2\x80\x99s grace, as she tripped out evenings\r\naccompanied by her mother, caused Carrie to perceive the nature and\r\nvalue of those little modish ways which women adopt when they would\r\npresume to be something. She looked in the mirror and pursed up her\r\nlips, accompanying it with a little toss of the head, as she had seen\r\nthe railroad treasurer\xe2\x80\x99s daughter do. She caught up her skirts with an\r\neasy swing, for had not Drouet remarked that in her and several others,\r\nand Carrie was naturally imitative. She began to get the hang of those\r\nlittle things which the pretty woman who has vanity invariably adopts.\r\nIn short, her knowledge of grace doubled, and with it her appearance\r\nchanged. She became a girl of considerable taste.\r\n\r\nDrouet noticed this. He saw the new bow in her hair and the new way of\r\narranging her locks which she affected one morning.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou look fine that way, Cad,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo I?\xe2\x80\x9d she replied, sweetly. It made her try for other effects that\r\nselfsame day.\r\n\r\nShe used her feet less heavily, a thing that was brought about by her\r\nattempting to imitate the treasurer\xe2\x80\x99s daughter\xe2\x80\x99s graceful carriage. How\r\nmuch influence the presence of that young woman in the same house had\r\nupon her it would be difficult to say. But, because of all these\r\nthings, when Hurstwood called he had found a young woman who was much\r\nmore than the Carrie to whom Drouet had first spoken. The primary\r\ndefects of dress and manner had passed. She was pretty, graceful, rich\r\nin the timidity born of uncertainty, and with a something childlike in\r\nher large eyes which captured the fancy of this starched and\r\nconventional poser among men. It was the ancient attraction of the\r\nfresh for the stale. If there was a touch of appreciation left in him\r\nfor the bloom and unsophistication which is the charm of youth, it\r\nrekindled now. He looked into her pretty face and felt the subtle waves\r\nof young life radiating therefrom. In that large clear eye he could see\r\nnothing that his _blas\xc3\xa9_ nature could understand as guile. The little\r\nvanity, if he could have perceived it there, would have touched him as\r\na pleasant thing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wonder,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, as he rode away in his cab, \xe2\x80\x9chow Drouet came to\r\nwin her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe gave her credit for feelings superior to Drouet at the first glance.\r\n\r\nThe cab plopped along between the far-receding lines of gas lamps on\r\neither hand. He folded his gloved hands and saw only the lighted\r\nchamber and Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s face. He was pondering over the delight of\r\nyouthful beauty.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll have a bouquet for her,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought. \xe2\x80\x9cDrouet won\xe2\x80\x99t mind.\xe2\x80\x9d He\r\nnever for a moment concealed the fact of her attraction for himself. He\r\ntroubled himself not at all about Drouet\xe2\x80\x99s priority. He was merely\r\nfloating those gossamer threads of thought which, like the spider\xe2\x80\x99s, he\r\nhoped would lay hold somewhere. He did not know, he could not guess,\r\nwhat the result would be.\r\n\r\nA few weeks later Drouet, in his peregrinations, encountered one of his\r\nwell-dressed lady acquaintances in Chicago on his return from a short\r\ntrip to Omaha. He had intended to hurry out to Ogden Place and surprise\r\nCarrie, but now he fell into an interesting conversation and soon\r\nmodified his original intention.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet\xe2\x80\x99s go to dinner,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, little recking any chance meeting which\r\nmight trouble his way.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly,\xe2\x80\x9d said his companion.\r\n\r\nThey visited one of the better restaurants for a social chat. It was\r\nfive in the afternoon when they met; it was seven-thirty before the\r\nlast bone was picked.\r\n\r\nDrouet was just finishing a little incident he was relating, and his\r\nface was expanding into a smile, when Hurstwood\xe2\x80\x99s eye caught his own.\r\nThe latter had come in with several friends, and, seeing Drouet and\r\nsome woman, not Carrie, drew his own conclusion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, the rascal,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought, and then, with a touch of righteous\r\nsympathy, \xe2\x80\x9cthat\xe2\x80\x99s pretty hard on the little girl.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDrouet jumped from one easy thought to another as he caught Hurstwood\xe2\x80\x99s\r\neye. He felt but very little misgiving, until he saw that Hurstwood was\r\ncautiously pretending not to see. Then some of the latter\xe2\x80\x99s impression\r\nforced itself upon him. He thought of Carrie and their last meeting. By\r\nGeorge, he would have to explain this to Hurstwood. Such a chance\r\nhalf-hour with an old friend must not have anything more attached to it\r\nthan it really warranted.\r\n\r\nFor the first time he was troubled. Here was a moral complication of\r\nwhich he could not possibly get the ends. Hurstwood would laugh at him\r\nfor being a fickle boy. He would laugh with Hurstwood. Carrie would\r\nnever hear, his present companion at table would never know, and yet he\r\ncould not help feeling that he was getting the worst of it\xe2\x80\x94there was\r\nsome faint stigma attached, and he was not guilty. He broke up the\r\ndinner by becoming dull, and saw his companion on her car. Then he went\r\nhome.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe hasn\xe2\x80\x99t talked to me about any of these later flames,\xe2\x80\x9d thought\r\nHurstwood to himself. \xe2\x80\x9cHe thinks I think he cares for the girl out\r\nthere.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe ought not to think I\xe2\x80\x99m knocking around, since I have just\r\nintroduced him out there,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Drouet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI saw you,\xe2\x80\x9d Hurstwood said, genially, the next time Drouet drifted in\r\nto his polished resort, from which he could not stay away. He raised\r\nhis forefinger indicatively, as parents do to children.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAn old acquaintance of mine that I ran into just as I was coming up\r\nfrom the station,\xe2\x80\x9d explained Drouet. \xe2\x80\x9cShe used to be quite a beauty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStill attracts a little, eh?\xe2\x80\x9d returned the other, affecting to jest.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet, \xe2\x80\x9cjust couldn\xe2\x80\x99t escape her this time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow long are you here?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Hurstwood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnly a few days.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou must bring the girl down and take dinner with me,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m\r\nafraid you keep her cooped up out there. I\xe2\x80\x99ll get a box for Joe\r\nJefferson.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot me,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the drummer. \xe2\x80\x9cSure I\xe2\x80\x99ll come.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis pleased Hurstwood immensely. He gave Drouet no credit for any\r\nfeelings toward Carrie whatever. He envied him, and now, as he looked\r\nat the well-dressed jolly salesman, whom he so much liked, the gleam of\r\nthe rival glowed in his eye. He began to \xe2\x80\x9csize up\xe2\x80\x9d Drouet from the\r\nstandpoints of wit and fascination. He began to look to see where he\r\nwas weak. There was no disputing that, whatever he might think of him\r\nas a good fellow, he felt a certain amount of contempt for him as a\r\nlover. He could hoodwink him all right. Why, if he would just let\r\nCarrie see one such little incident as that of Thursday, it would\r\nsettle the matter. He ran on in thought, almost exulting, the while he\r\nlaughed and chatted, and Drouet felt nothing. He had no power of\r\nanalysing the glance and the atmosphere of a man like Hurstwood. He\r\nstood and smiled and accepted the invitation while his friend examined\r\nhim with the eye of a hawk.\r\n\r\nThe object of this peculiarly involved comedy was not thinking of\r\neither. She was busy adjusting her thoughts and feelings to newer\r\nconditions, and was not in danger of suffering disturbing pangs from\r\neither quarter. One evening Drouet found her dressing herself before\r\nthe glass.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCad,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, catching her, \xe2\x80\x9cI believe you\xe2\x80\x99re getting vain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing of the kind,\xe2\x80\x9d she returned, smiling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you\xe2\x80\x99re mighty pretty,\xe2\x80\x9d he went on, slipping his arm around her.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPut on that navy-blue dress of yours and I\xe2\x80\x99ll take you to the show.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I\xe2\x80\x99ve promised Mrs. Hale to go with her to the Exposition\r\nto-night,\xe2\x80\x9d she returned, apologetically.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou did, eh?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, studying the situation abstractedly. \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nwouldn\xe2\x80\x99t care to go to that myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Carrie, puzzling, but not offering to\r\nbreak her promise in his favour.\r\n\r\nJust then a knock came at their door and the maidservant handed a\r\nletter in.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe says there\xe2\x80\x99s an answer expected,\xe2\x80\x9d she explained.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s from Hurstwood,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet, noting the superscription as he\r\ntore it open.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are to come down and see Joe Jefferson with me to-night,\xe2\x80\x9d it ran\r\nin part. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s my turn, as we agreed the other day. All other bets are\r\noff.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, what do you say to this?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Drouet, innocently, while\r\nCarrie\xe2\x80\x99s mind bubbled with favourable replies.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou had better decide, Charlie,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, reservedly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI guess we had better go, if you can break that engagement upstairs,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid Drouet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I can,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Carrie without thinking.\r\n\r\nDrouet selected writing paper while Carrie went to change her dress.\r\nShe hardly explained to herself why this latest invitation appealed to\r\nher most.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall I wear my hair as I did yesterday?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked, as she came out\r\nwith several articles of apparel pending.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSure,\xe2\x80\x9d he returned, pleasantly.\r\n\r\nShe was relieved to see that he felt nothing. She did not credit her\r\nwillingness to go to any fascination Hurstwood held for her. It seemed\r\nthat the combination of Hurstwood, Drouet, and herself was more\r\nagreeable than anything else that had been suggested. She arrayed\r\nherself most carefully and they started off, extending excuses\r\nupstairs.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood, as they came up the theatre lobby, \xe2\x80\x9cwe are\r\nexceedingly charming this evening.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie fluttered under his approving glance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, then,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, leading the way up the foyer into the theatre.\r\n\r\nIf ever there was dressiness it was here. It was the personification of\r\nthe old term spick and span.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you ever see Jefferson?\xe2\x80\x9d he questioned, as he leaned toward Carrie\r\nin the box.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI never did,\xe2\x80\x9d she returned.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s delightful, delightful,\xe2\x80\x9d he went on, giving the commonplace\r\nrendition of approval which such men know. He sent Drouet after a\r\nprogramme, and then discoursed to Carrie concerning Jefferson as he had\r\nheard of him. The former was pleased beyond expression, and was really\r\nhypnotised by the environment, the trappings of the box, the elegance\r\nof her companion. Several times their eyes accidentally met, and then\r\nthere poured into hers such a flood of feeling as she had never before\r\nexperienced. She could not for the moment explain it, for in the next\r\nglance or the next move of the hand there was seeming indifference,\r\nmingled only with the kindest attention.\r\n\r\nDrouet shared in the conversation, but he was almost dull in\r\ncomparison. Hurstwood entertained them both, and now it was driven into\r\nCarrie\xe2\x80\x99s mind that here was the superior man. She instinctively felt\r\nthat he was stronger and higher, and yet withal so simple. By the end\r\nof the third act she was sure that Drouet was only a kindly soul, but\r\notherwise defective. He sank every moment in her estimation by the\r\nstrong comparison.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have had such a nice time,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, when it was all over and\r\nthey were coming out.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, indeed,\xe2\x80\x9d added Drouet, who was not in the least aware that a\r\nbattle had been fought and his defences weakened. He was like the\r\nEmperor of China, who sat glorying in himself, unaware that his fairest\r\nprovinces were being wrested from him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you have saved me a dreary evening,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Hurstwood.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood-night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe took Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s little hand, and a current of feeling swept from one\r\nto the other.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m so tired,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, leaning back in the car when Drouet began\r\nto talk.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you rest a little while I smoke,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, rising, and then he\r\nfoolishly went to the forward platform of the car and left the game as\r\nit stood.\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XII. OF THE LAMPS OF THE MANSIONS: THE AMBASSADOR PLEA\r\n\r\nMrs. Hurstwood was not aware of any of her husband\xe2\x80\x99s moral defections,\r\nthough she might readily have suspected his tendencies, which she well\r\nunderstood. She was a woman upon whose action under provocation you\r\ncould never count. Hurstwood, for one, had not the slightest idea of\r\nwhat she would do under certain circumstances. He had never seen her\r\nthoroughly aroused. In fact, she was not a woman who would fly into a\r\npassion. She had too little faith in mankind not to know that they were\r\nerring. She was too calculating to jeopardize any advantage she might\r\ngain in the way of information by fruitless clamour. Her wrath would\r\nnever wreak itself in one fell blow. She would wait and brood, studying\r\nthe details and adding to them until her power might be commensurate\r\nwith her desire for revenge. At the same time, she would not delay to\r\ninflict any injury, big or little, which would wound the object of her\r\nrevenge and still leave him uncertain as to the source of the evil. She\r\nwas a cold, self-centred woman, with many a thought of her own which\r\nnever found expression, not even by so much as the glint of an eye.\r\n\r\nHurstwood felt some of this in her nature, though he did not actually\r\nperceive it. He dwelt with her in peace and some satisfaction. He did\r\nnot fear her in the least\xe2\x80\x94there was no cause for it. She still took a\r\nfaint pride in him, which was augmented by her desire to have her\r\nsocial integrity maintained. She was secretly somewhat pleased by the\r\nfact that much of her husband\xe2\x80\x99s property was in her name, a precaution\r\nwhich Hurstwood had taken when his home interests were somewhat more\r\nalluring than at present. His wife had not the slightest reason to feel\r\nthat anything would ever go amiss with their household, and yet the\r\nshadows which run before gave her a thought of the good of it now and\r\nthen. She was in a position to become refractory with considerable\r\nadvantage, and Hurstwood conducted himself circumspectly because he\r\nfelt that he could not be sure of anything once she became\r\ndissatisfied.\r\n\r\nIt so happened that on the night when Hurstwood, Carrie, and Drouet\r\nwere in the box at McVickar\xe2\x80\x99s, George, Jr., was in the sixth row of the\r\nparquet with the daughter of H.
