B. Carmichael, the third partner of a\r\nwholesale dry-goods house of that city. Hurstwood did not see his son,\r\nfor he sat, as was his wont, as far back as possible, leaving himself\r\njust partially visible, when he bent forward, to those within the first\r\nsix rows in question. It was his wont to sit this way in every\r\ntheatre\xe2\x80\x94to make his personality as inconspicuous as possible where it\r\nwould be no advantage to him to have it otherwise.\r\n\r\nHe never moved but what, if there was any danger of his conduct being\r\nmisconstrued or ill-reported, he looked carefully about him and counted\r\nthe cost of every inch of conspicuity.\r\n\r\nThe next morning at breakfast his son said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI saw you, Governor, last night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWere you at McVickar\xe2\x80\x99s?\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood, with the best grace in the\r\nworld.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said young George.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho with?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMiss Carmichael.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Hurstwood directed an inquiring glance at her husband, but could\r\nnot judge from his appearance whether it was any more than a casual\r\nlook into the theatre which was referred to.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow was the play?\xe2\x80\x9d she inquired.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery good,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Hurstwood, \xe2\x80\x9conly it\xe2\x80\x99s the same old thing, \xe2\x80\x98Rip\r\nVan Winkle.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhom did you go with?\xe2\x80\x9d queried his wife, with assumed indifference.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCharlie Drouet and his wife. They are friends of Moy\xe2\x80\x99s, visiting\r\nhere.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOwing to the peculiar nature of his position, such a disclosure as this\r\nwould ordinarily create no difficulty. His wife took it for granted\r\nthat his situation called for certain social movements in which she\r\nmight not be included. But of late he had pleaded office duty on\r\nseveral occasions when his wife asked for his company to any evening\r\nentertainment. He had done so in regard to the very evening in question\r\nonly the morning before.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thought you were going to be busy,\xe2\x80\x9d she remarked, very carefully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo I was,\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed. \xe2\x80\x9cI couldn\xe2\x80\x99t help the interruption, but I made\r\nup for it afterward by working until two.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis settled the discussion for the time being, but there was a residue\r\nof opinion which was not satisfactory. There was no time at which the\r\nclaims of his wife could have been more unsatisfactorily pushed. For\r\nyears he had been steadily modifying his matrimonial devotion, and\r\nfound her company dull. Now that a new light shone upon the horizon,\r\nthis older luminary paled in the west. He was satisfied to turn his\r\nface away entirely, and any call to look back was irksome.\r\n\r\nShe, on the contrary, was not at all inclined to accept anything less\r\nthan a complete fulfilment of the letter of their relationship, though\r\nthe spirit might be wanting.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe are coming down town this afternoon,\xe2\x80\x9d she remarked, a few days\r\nlater. \xe2\x80\x9cI want you to come over to Kinsley\xe2\x80\x99s and meet Mr. Phillips and\r\nhis wife. They\xe2\x80\x99re stopping at the Tremont, and we\xe2\x80\x99re going to show them\r\naround a little.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAfter the occurrence of Wednesday, he could not refuse, though the\r\nPhillips were about as uninteresting as vanity and ignorance could make\r\nthem. He agreed, but it was with short grace. He was angry when he left\r\nthe house.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll put a stop to this,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m not going to be bothered\r\nfooling around with visitors when I have work to do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNot long after this Mrs. Hurstwood came with a similar proposition,\r\nonly it was to a matin\xc3\xa9e this time.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear,\xe2\x80\x9d he returned, \xe2\x80\x9cI haven\xe2\x80\x99t time. I\xe2\x80\x99m too busy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou find time to go with other people, though,\xe2\x80\x9d she replied, with\r\nconsiderable irritation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing of the kind,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered. \xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t avoid business relations,\r\nand that\xe2\x80\x99s all there is to it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, never mind,\xe2\x80\x9d she exclaimed. Her lips tightened. The feeling of\r\nmutual antagonism was increased.\r\n\r\nOn the other hand, his interest in Drouet\xe2\x80\x99s little shop-girl grew in an\r\nalmost evenly balanced proportion. That young lady, under the stress of\r\nher situation and the tutelage of her new friend, changed effectively.\r\nShe had the aptitude of the struggler who seeks emancipation. The glow\r\nof a more showy life was not lost upon her. She did not grow in\r\nknowledge so much as she awakened in the matter of desire. Mrs. Hale\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nextended harangues upon the subjects of wealth and position taught her\r\nto distinguish between degrees of wealth. Mrs. Hale loved to drive in\r\nthe afternoon in the sun when it was fine, and to satisfy her soul with\r\na sight of those mansions and lawns which she could not afford. On the\r\nNorth Side had been erected a number of elegant mansions along what is\r\nnow known as the North Shore Drive. The present lake wall of stone and\r\ngranitoid was not then in place, but the road had been well laid out,\r\nthe intermediate spaces of lawn were lovely to look upon, and the\r\nhouses were thoroughly new and imposing. When the winter season had\r\npassed and the first fine days of the early spring appeared, Mrs. Hale\r\nsecured a buggy for an afternoon and invited Carrie. They rode first\r\nthrough Lincoln Park and on far out towards Evanston, turning back at\r\nfour and arriving at the north end of the Shore Drive at about five\r\no\xe2\x80\x99clock. At this time of year the days are still comparatively short,\r\nand the shadows of the evening were beginning to settle down upon the\r\ngreat city. Lamps were beginning to burn with that mellow radiance\r\nwhich seems almost watery and translucent to the eye. There was a\r\nsoftness in the air which speaks with an infinite delicacy of feeling\r\nto the flesh as well as to the soul. Carrie felt that it was a lovely\r\nday. She was ripened by it in spirit for many suggestions. As they\r\ndrove along the smooth pavement an occasional carriage passed. She saw\r\none stop and the footman dismount, opening the door for a gentleman who\r\nseemed to be leisurely returning from some afternoon pleasure. Across\r\nthe broad lawns, now first freshening into green, she saw lamps faintly\r\nglowing upon rich interiors. Now it was but a chair, now a table, now\r\nan ornate corner, which met her eye, but it appealed to her as almost\r\nnothing else could. Such childish fancies as she had had of fairy\r\npalaces and kingly quarters now came back. She imagined that across\r\nthese richly carved entrance-ways, where the globed and crystalled\r\nlamps shone upon panelled doors set with stained and designed panes of\r\nglass, was neither care nor unsatisfied desire. She was perfectly\r\ncertain that here was happiness. If she could but stroll up yon broad\r\nwalk, cross that rich entrance-way, which to her was of the beauty of a\r\njewel, and sweep in grace and luxury to possession and command\xe2\x80\x94oh! how\r\nquickly would sadness flee; how, in an instant, would the heartache\r\nend. She gazed and gazed, wondering, delighting, longing, and all the\r\nwhile the siren voice of the unrestful was whispering in her ear.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf we could have such a home as that,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Hale sadly, \xe2\x80\x9chow\r\ndelightful it would be.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd yet they do say,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, \xe2\x80\x9cthat no one is ever happy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe had heard so much of the canting philosophy of the grapeless fox.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI notice,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Hale, \xe2\x80\x9cthat they all try mighty hard, though, to\r\ntake their misery in a mansion.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhen she came to her own rooms, Carrie saw their comparative\r\ninsignificance. She was not so dull but that she could perceive they\r\nwere but three small rooms in a moderately well-furnished\r\nboarding-house. She was not contrasting it now with what she had had,\r\nbut what she had so recently seen. The glow of the palatial doors was\r\nstill in her eye, the roll of cushioned carriages still in her ears.\r\nWhat, after all, was Drouet? What was she? At her window, she thought\r\nit over, rocking to and fro, and gazing out across the lamp-lit park\r\ntoward the lamp-lit houses on Warren and Ashland avenues. She was too\r\nwrought up to care to go down to eat, too pensive to do aught but rock\r\nand sing. Some old tunes crept to her lips, and, as she sang them, her\r\nheart sank. She longed and longed and longed. It was now for the old\r\ncottage room in Columbia City, now the mansion upon the Shore Drive,\r\nnow the fine dress of some lady, now the elegance of some scene. She\r\nwas sad beyond measure, and yet uncertain, wishing, fancying. Finally,\r\nit seemed as if all her state was one of loneliness and forsakenness,\r\nand she could scarce refrain from trembling at the lip. She hummed and\r\nhummed as the moments went by, sitting in the shadow by the window, and\r\nwas therein as happy, though she did not perceive it, as she ever would\r\nbe.\r\n\r\nWhile Carrie was still in this frame of mind, the house-servant brought\r\nup the intelligence that Mr. Hurstwood was in the parlour asking to see\r\nMr. and Mrs. Drouet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI guess he doesn\xe2\x80\x99t know that Charlie is out of town,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Carrie.\r\n\r\nShe had seen comparatively little of the manager during the winter, but\r\nhad been kept constantly in mind of him by one thing and another,\r\nprincipally by the strong impression he had made. She was quite\r\ndisturbed for the moment as to her appearance, but soon satisfied\r\nherself by the aid of the mirror, and went below.\r\n\r\nHurstwood was in his best form, as usual. He hadn\xe2\x80\x99t heard that Drouet\r\nwas out of town. He was but slightly affected by the intelligence, and\r\ndevoted himself to the more general topics which would interest Carrie.\r\nIt was surprising\xe2\x80\x94the ease with which he conducted a conversation. He\r\nwas like every man who has had the advantage of practice and knows he\r\nhas sympathy. He knew that Carrie listened to him pleasurably, and,\r\nwithout the least effort, he fell into a train of observation which\r\nabsorbed her fancy. He drew up his chair and modulated his voice to\r\nsuch a degree that what he said seemed wholly confidential. He confined\r\nhimself almost exclusively to his observation of men and pleasures. He\r\nhad been here and there, he had seen this and that. Somehow he made\r\nCarrie wish to see similar things, and all the while kept her aware of\r\nhimself. She could not shut out the consciousness of his individuality\r\nand presence for a moment. He would raise his eyes slowly in smiling\r\nemphasis of something, and she was fixed by their magnetism. He would\r\ndraw out, with the easiest grace, her approval. Once he touched her\r\nhand for emphasis and she only smiled. He seemed to radiate an\r\natmosphere which suffused her being. He was never dull for a minute,\r\nand seemed to make her clever. At least, she brightened under his\r\ninfluence until all her best side was exhibited. She felt that she was\r\nmore clever with him than with others. At least, he seemed to find so\r\nmuch in her to applaud. There was not the slightest touch of patronage.\r\nDrouet was full of it.\r\n\r\nThere had been something so personal, so subtle, in each meeting\r\nbetween them, both when Drouet was present and when he was absent, that\r\nCarrie could not speak of it without feeling a sense of difficulty. She\r\nwas no talker. She could never arrange her thoughts in fluent order. It\r\nwas always a matter of feeling with her, strong and deep. Each time\r\nthere had been no sentence of importance which she could relate, and as\r\nfor the glances and sensations, what woman would reveal them? Such\r\nthings had never been between her and Drouet. As a matter of fact, they\r\ncould never be. She had been dominated by distress and the enthusiastic\r\nforces of relief which Drouet represented at an opportune moment when\r\nshe yielded to him. Now she was persuaded by secret current feelings\r\nwhich Drouet had never understood. Hurstwood\xe2\x80\x99s glance was as effective\r\nas the spoken words of a lover, and more. They called for no immediate\r\ndecision, and could not be answered.\r\n\r\nPeople in general attach too much importance to words. They are under\r\nthe illusion that talking effects great results. As a matter of fact,\r\nwords are, as a rule, the shallowest portion of all the argument. They\r\nbut dimly represent the great surging feelings and desires which lie\r\nbehind. When the distraction of the tongue is removed, the heart\r\nlistens.\r\n\r\nIn this conversation she heard, instead of his words, the voices of the\r\nthings which he represented. How suave was the counsel of his\r\nappearance! How feelingly did his superior state speak for itself! The\r\ngrowing desire he felt for her lay upon her spirit as a gentle hand.\r\nShe did not need to tremble at all, because it was invisible; she did\r\nnot need to worry over what other people would say\xe2\x80\x94what she herself\r\nwould say\xe2\x80\x94because it had no tangibility. She was being pleaded with,\r\npersuaded, led into denying old rights and assuming new ones, and yet\r\nthere were no words to prove it. Such conversation as was indulged in\r\nheld the same relationship to the actual mental enactments of the twain\r\nthat the low music of the orchestra does to the dramatic incident which\r\nit is used to cover.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you ever seen the houses along the Lake Shore on the North Side?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nasked Hurstwood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, I was just over there this afternoon\xe2\x80\x94Mrs. Hale and I. Aren\xe2\x80\x99t they\r\nbeautiful?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99re very fine,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, pensively. \xe2\x80\x9cI wish I could live in such a\r\nplace.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re not happy,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood, slowly, after a slight pause.\r\n\r\nHe had raised his eyes solemnly and was looking into her own. He\r\nassumed that he had struck a deep chord. Now was a slight chance to say\r\na word in his own behalf. He leaned over quietly and continued his\r\nsteady gaze. He felt the critical character of the period. She\r\nendeavoured to stir, but it was useless. The whole strength of a man\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nnature was working. He had good cause to urge him on. He looked and\r\nlooked, and the longer the situation lasted the more difficult it\r\nbecame. The little shop-girl was getting into deep water. She was\r\nletting her few supports float away from her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh,\xe2\x80\x9d she said at last, \xe2\x80\x9cyou mustn\xe2\x80\x99t look at me like that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t help it,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered.\r\n\r\nShe relaxed a little and let the situation endure, giving him strength.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are not satisfied with life, are you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered, weakly.\r\n\r\nHe saw he was the master of the situation\xe2\x80\x94he felt it. He reached over\r\nand touched her hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou mustn\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d she exclaimed, jumping up.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI didn\xe2\x80\x99t intend to,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered, easily.\r\n\r\nShe did not run away, as she might have done. She did not terminate the\r\ninterview, but he drifted off into a pleasant field of thought with the\r\nreadiest grace. Not long after he rose to go, and she felt that he was\r\nin power. \xe2\x80\x9cYou mustn\xe2\x80\x99t feel bad,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, kindly; \xe2\x80\x9cthings will\r\nstraighten out in the course of time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe made no answer, because she could think of nothing to say.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe are good friends, aren\xe2\x80\x99t we?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, extending his hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot a word, then, until I see you again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe retained a hold on her hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t promise,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, doubtfully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou must be more generous than that,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, in such a simple way\r\nthat she was touched.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet\xe2\x80\x99s not talk about it any more,\xe2\x80\x9d she returned.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, brightening.\r\n\r\nHe went down the steps and into his cab. Carrie closed the door and\r\nascended into her room. She undid her broad lace collar before the\r\nmirror and unfastened her pretty alligator belt which she had recently\r\nbought.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m getting terrible,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, honestly affected by a feeling of\r\ntrouble and shame. \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t seem to do anything right.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe unloosed her hair after a time, and let it hang in loose brown\r\nwaves. Her mind was going over the events of the evening.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d she murmured at last, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat I can do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood as he rode away, \xe2\x80\x9cshe likes me all right; that I\r\nknow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe aroused manager whistled merrily for a good four miles to his\r\noffice an old melody that he had not recalled for fifteen years.\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XIII. HIS CREDENTIALS ACCEPTED: A BABEL OF TONGUES\r\n\r\nIt was not quite two days after the scene between Carrie and Hurstwood\r\nin the Ogden Place parlour before he again put in his appearance. He\r\nhad been thinking almost uninterruptedly of her. Her leniency had, in a\r\nway, inflamed his regard. He felt that he must succeed with her, and\r\nthat speedily.\r\n\r\nThe reason for his interest, not to say fascination, was deeper than\r\nmere desire. It was a flowering out of feelings which had been\r\nwithering in dry and almost barren soil for many years. It is probable\r\nthat Carrie represented a better order of woman than had ever attracted\r\nhim before. He had had no love affair since that which culminated in\r\nhis marriage, and since then time and the world had taught him how raw\r\nand erroneous was his original judgment. Whenever he thought of it, he\r\ntold himself that, if he had it to do over again, he would never marry\r\nsuch a woman. At the same time, his experience with women in general\r\nhad lessened his respect for the sex. He maintained a cynical attitude,\r\nwell grounded on numerous experiences. Such women as he had known were\r\nof nearly one type, selfish, ignorant, flashy. The wives of his friends\r\nwere not inspiring to look upon. His own wife had developed a cold,\r\ncommonplace nature which to him was anything but pleasing. What he knew\r\nof that under-world where grovel the beat-men of society (and he knew a\r\ngreat deal) had hardened his nature. He looked upon most women with\r\nsuspicion\xe2\x80\x94a single eye to the utility of beauty and dress. He followed\r\nthem with a keen, suggestive glance. At the same time, he was not so\r\ndull but that a good woman commanded his respect. Personally, he did\r\nnot attempt to analyse the marvel of a saintly woman. He would take off\r\nhis hat, and would silence the light-tongued and the vicious in her\r\npresence\xe2\x80\x94much as the Irish keeper of a Bowery hall will humble himself\r\nbefore a Sister of Mercy, and pay toll to charity with a willing and\r\nreverent hand. But he would not think much upon the question of why he\r\ndid so.\r\n\r\nA man in his situation who comes, after a long round of worthless or\r\nhardening experiences, upon a young, unsophisticated, innocent soul, is\r\napt either to hold aloof, out of a sense of his own remoteness, or to\r\ndraw near and become fascinated and elated by his discovery. It is only\r\nby a roundabout process that such men ever do draw near such a girl.\r\nThey have no method, no understanding of how to ingratiate themselves\r\nin youthful favour, save when they find virtue in the toils. If,\r\nunfortunately, the fly has got caught in the net, the spider can come\r\nforth and talk business upon its own terms. So when maidenhood has\r\nwandered into the moil of the city, when it is brought within the\r\ncircle of the \xe2\x80\x9crounder\xe2\x80\x9d and the rou\xc3\xa9, even though it be at the\r\noutermost rim, they can come forth and use their alluring arts.\r\n\r\nHurstwood had gone, at Drouet\xe2\x80\x99s invitation, to meet a new baggage of\r\nfine clothes and pretty features. He entered, expecting to indulge in\r\nan evening of lightsome frolic, and then lose track of the newcomer\r\nforever. Instead he found a woman whose youth and beauty attracted him.\r\nIn the mild light of Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s eye was nothing of the calculation of the\r\nmistress. In the diffident manner was nothing of the art of the\r\ncourtesan. He saw at once that a mistake had been made, that some\r\ndifficult conditions had pushed this troubled creature into his\r\npresence, and his interest was enlisted. Here sympathy sprang to the\r\nrescue, but it was not unmixed with selfishness. He wanted to win\r\nCarrie because he thought her fate mingled with his was better than if\r\nit were united with Drouet\xe2\x80\x99s. He envied the drummer his conquest as he\r\nhad never envied any man in all the course of his experience.\r\n\r\nCarrie was certainly better than this man, as she was superior,\r\nmentally, to Drouet. She came fresh from the air of the village, the\r\nlight of the country still in her eye. Here was neither guile nor\r\nrapacity. There were slight inherited traits of both in her, but they\r\nwere rudimentary. She was too full of wonder and desire to be greedy.\r\nShe still looked about her upon the great maze of the city without\r\nunderstanding. Hurstwood felt the bloom and the youth. He picked her as\r\nhe would the fresh fruit of a tree. He felt as fresh in her presence as\r\none who is taken out of the flash of summer to the first cool breath of\r\nspring.\r\n\r\nCarrie, left alone since the scene in question, and having no one with\r\nwhom to counsel, had at first wandered from one strange mental\r\nconclusion to another, until at last, tired out, she gave it up. She\r\nowed something to Drouet, she thought. It did not seem more than\r\nyesterday that he had aided her when she was worried and distressed.\r\nShe had the kindliest feelings for him in every way. She gave him\r\ncredit for his good looks, his generous feelings, and even, in fact,\r\nfailed to recollect his egotism when he was absent; but she could not\r\nfeel any binding influence keeping her for him as against all others.\r\nIn fact, such a thought had never had any grounding, even in Drouet\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndesires.\r\n\r\nThe truth is, that this goodly drummer carried the doom of all enduring\r\nrelationships in his own lightsome manner and unstable fancy. He went\r\nmerrily on, assured that he was alluring all, that affection followed\r\ntenderly in his wake, that things would endure unchangingly for his\r\npleasure. When he missed some old face, or found some door finally shut\r\nto him, it did not grieve him deeply. He was too young, too successful.\r\nHe would remain thus young in spirit until he was dead.\r\n\r\nAs for Hurstwood, he was alive with thoughts and feelings concerning\r\nCarrie. He had no definite plans regarding her, but he was determined\r\nto make her confess an affection for him. He thought he saw in her\r\ndrooping eye, her unstable glance, her wavering manner, the symptoms of\r\na budding passion. He wanted to stand near her and make her lay her\r\nhand in his\xe2\x80\x94he wanted to find out what her next step would be\xe2\x80\x94what the\r\nnext sign of feeling for him would be. Such anxiety and enthusiasm had\r\nnot affected him for years. He was a youth again in feeling\xe2\x80\x94a cavalier\r\nin action.\r\n\r\nIn his position opportunity for taking his evenings out was excellent.\r\nHe was a most faithful worker in general, and a man who commanded the\r\nconfidence of his employers in so far as the distribution of his time\r\nwas concerned. He could take such hours off as he chose, for it was\r\nwell known that he fulfilled his managerial duties successfully,\r\nwhatever time he might take. His grace, tact, and ornate appearance\r\ngave the place an air which was most essential, while at the same time\r\nhis long experience made him a most excellent judge of its stock\r\nnecessities. Bartenders and assistants might come and go, singly or in\r\ngroups, but, so long as he was present, the host of old-time customers\r\nwould barely notice the change. He gave the place the atmosphere to\r\nwhich they were used. Consequently, he arranged his hours very much to\r\nsuit himself, taking now an afternoon, now an evening, but invariably\r\nreturning between eleven and twelve to witness the last hour or two of\r\nthe day\xe2\x80\x99s business and look after the closing details.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see that things are safe and all the employees are out when you go\r\nhome, George,\xe2\x80\x9d Moy had once remarked to him, and he never once, in all\r\nthe period of his long service, neglected to do this. Neither of the\r\nowners had for years been in the resort after five in the afternoon,\r\nand yet their manager as faithfully fulfilled this request as if they\r\nhad been there regularly to observe.\r\n\r\nOn this Friday afternoon, scarcely two days after his previous visit,\r\nhe made up his mind to see Carrie. He could not stay away longer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEvans,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, addressing the head barkeeper, \xe2\x80\x9cif any one calls, I\r\nwill be back between four and five.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe hurried to Madison Street and boarded a horse-car, which carried him\r\nto Ogden Place in half an hour.\r\n\r\nCarrie had thought of going for a walk, and had put on a light grey\r\nwoollen dress with a jaunty double-breasted jacket. She had out her hat\r\nand gloves, and was fastening a white lace tie about her throat when\r\nthe housemaid brought up the information that Mr. Hurstwood wished to\r\nsee her.\r\n\r\nShe started slightly at the announcement, but told the girl to say that\r\nshe would come down in a moment, and proceeded to hasten her dressing.\r\n\r\nCarrie could not have told herself at this moment whether she was glad\r\nor sorry that the impressive manager was awaiting her presence. She was\r\nslightly flurried and tingling in the cheeks, but it was more\r\nnervousness than either fear or favour. She did not try to conjecture\r\nwhat the drift of the conversation would be. She only felt that she\r\nmust be careful, and that Hurstwood had an indefinable fascination for\r\nher. Then she gave her tie its last touch with her fingers and went\r\nbelow.\r\n\r\nThe deep-feeling manager was himself a little strained in the nerves by\r\nthe thorough consciousness of his mission. He felt that he must make a\r\nstrong play on this occasion, but now that the hour was come, and he\r\nheard Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s feet upon the stair, his nerve failed him. He sank a\r\nlittle in determination, for he was not so sure, after all, what her\r\nopinion might be.\r\n\r\nWhen she entered the room, however, her appearance gave him courage.\r\nShe looked simple and charming enough to strengthen the daring of any\r\nlover. Her apparent nervousness dispelled his own.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow are you?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, easily. \xe2\x80\x9cI could not resist the temptation to\r\ncome out this afternoon, it was so pleasant.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, halting before him, \xe2\x80\x9cI was just preparing to go for\r\na walk myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, were you?\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cSupposing, then, you get your hat and we both\r\ngo?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey crossed the park and went west along Washington Boulevard,\r\nbeautiful with its broad macadamised road, and large frame houses set\r\nback from the sidewalks. It was a street where many of the more\r\nprosperous residents of the West Side lived, and Hurstwood could not\r\nhelp feeling nervous over the publicity of it. They had gone but a few\r\nblocks when a livery stable sign in one of the side streets solved the\r\ndifficulty for him. He would take her to drive along the new Boulevard.\r\n\r\nThe Boulevard at that time was little more than a country road. The\r\npart he intended showing her was much farther out on this same West\r\nSide, where there was scarcely a house. It connected Douglas Park with\r\nWashington or South Park, and was nothing more than a neatly _made_\r\nroad, running due south for some five miles over an open, grassy\r\nprairie, and then due east over the same kind of prairie for the same\r\ndistance. There was not a house to be encountered anywhere along the\r\nlarger part of the route, and any conversation would be pleasantly free\r\nof interruption.\r\n\r\nAt the stable he picked a gentle horse, and they were soon out of range\r\nof either public observation or hearing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan you drive?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, after a time.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI never tried,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\nHe put the reins in her hand, and folded his arms.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see there\xe2\x80\x99s nothing to it much,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, smilingly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot when you have a gentle horse,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou can handle a horse as well as any one, after a little practice,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nhe added, encouragingly.\r\n\r\nHe had been looking for some time for a break in the conversation when\r\nhe could give it a serious turn. Once or twice he had held his peace,\r\nhoping that in silence her thoughts would take the colour of his own,\r\nbut she had lightly continued the subject. Presently, however, his\r\nsilence controlled the situation. The drift of his thoughts began to\r\ntell. He gazed fixedly at nothing in particular, as if he were thinking\r\nof something which concerned her not at all. His thoughts, however,\r\nspoke for themselves. She was very much aware that a climax was\r\npending.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cI have spent the happiest evenings in years\r\nsince I have known you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you?\xe2\x80\x9d she said, with assumed airiness, but still excited by the\r\nconviction which the tone of his voice carried.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was going to tell you the other evening,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, \xe2\x80\x9cbut somehow the\r\nopportunity slipped away.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie was listening without attempting to reply. She could think of\r\nnothing worth while to say. Despite all the ideas concerning right\r\nwhich had troubled her vaguely since she had last seen him, she was now\r\ninfluenced again strongly in his favour.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI came out here to-day,\xe2\x80\x9d he went on, solemnly, \xe2\x80\x9cto tell you just how I\r\nfeel\xe2\x80\x94to see if you wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t listen to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHurstwood was something of a romanticist after his kind. He was capable\r\nof strong feelings\xe2\x80\x94often poetic ones\xe2\x80\x94and under a stress of desire, such\r\nas the present, he waxed eloquent. That is, his feelings and his voice\r\nwere coloured with that seeming repression and pathos which is the\r\nessence of eloquence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, putting his hand on her arm, and keeping a strange\r\nsilence while he formulated words, \xe2\x80\x9cthat I love you?\xe2\x80\x9d Carrie did not\r\nstir at the words. She was bound up completely in the man\xe2\x80\x99s atmosphere.\r\nHe would have churchlike silence in order to express his feelings, and\r\nshe kept it. She did not move her eyes from the flat, open scene before\r\nher. Hurstwood waited for a few moments, and then repeated the words.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou must not say that,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, weakly.\r\n\r\nHer words were not convincing at all. They were the result of a feeble\r\nthought that something ought to be said. He paid no attention to them\r\nwhatever.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCarrie,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, using her first name with sympathetic familiarity,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI want you to love me. You don\xe2\x80\x99t know how much I need some one to\r\nwaste a little affection on me. I am practically alone. There is\r\nnothing in my life that is pleasant or delightful. It\xe2\x80\x99s all work and\r\nworry with people who are nothing to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs he said this, Hurstwood really imagined that his state was pitiful.\r\nHe had the ability to get off at a distance and view himself\r\nobjectively\xe2\x80\x94of seeing what he wanted to see in the things which made up\r\nhis existence. Now, as he spoke, his voice trembled with that peculiar\r\nvibration which is the result of tensity. It went ringing home to his\r\ncompanion\xe2\x80\x99s heart.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, I should think,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, turning upon him large eyes which were\r\nfull of sympathy and feeling, \xe2\x80\x9cthat you would be very happy. You know\r\nso much of the world.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is it,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, his voice dropping to a soft minor, \xe2\x80\x9cI know too\r\nmuch of the world.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was an important thing to her to hear one so well-positioned and\r\npowerful speaking in this manner. She could not help feeling the\r\nstrangeness of her situation. How was it that, in so little a while,\r\nthe narrow life of the country had fallen from her as a garment, and\r\nthe city, with all its mystery, taken its place? Here was this greatest\r\nmystery, the man of money and affairs sitting beside her, appealing to\r\nher. Behold, he had ease and comfort, his strength was great, his\r\nposition high, his clothing rich, and yet he was appealing to her. She\r\ncould formulate no thought which would be just and right. She troubled\r\nherself no more upon the matter. She only basked in the warmth of his\r\nfeeling, which was as a grateful blaze to one who is cold. Hurstwood\r\nglowed with his own intensity, and the heat of his passion was already\r\nmelting the wax of his companion\xe2\x80\x99s scruples.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou think,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cI am happy; that I ought not to complain? If you\r\nwere to meet all day with people who care absolutely nothing about you,\r\nif you went day after day to a place where there was nothing but show\r\nand indifference, if there was not one person in all those you knew to\r\nwhom you could appeal for sympathy or talk to with pleasure, perhaps\r\nyou would be unhappy too.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe was striking a chord now which found sympathetic response in her own\r\nsituation. She knew what it was to meet with people who were\r\nindifferent, to walk alone amid so many who cared absolutely nothing\r\nabout you. Had not she? Was not she at this very moment quite alone?\r\nWho was there among all whom she knew to whom she could appeal for\r\nsympathy? Not one. She was left to herself to brood and wonder.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI could be content,\xe2\x80\x9d went on Hurstwood, \xe2\x80\x9cif I had you to love me. If I\r\nhad you to go to; you for a companion. As it is, I simply move about\r\nfrom place to place without any satisfaction. Time hangs heavily on my\r\nhands. Before you came I did nothing but idle and drift into anything\r\nthat offered itself. Since you came\xe2\x80\x94well, I\xe2\x80\x99ve had you to think about.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe old illusion that here was some one who needed her aid began to\r\ngrow in Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s mind. She truly pitied this sad, lonely figure. To\r\nthink that all his fine state should be so barren for want of her; that\r\nhe needed to make such an appeal when she herself was lonely and\r\nwithout anchor. Surely, this was too bad.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am not very bad,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, apologetically, as if he owed it to her\r\nto explain on this score. \xe2\x80\x9cYou think, probably, that I roam around, and\r\nget into all sorts of evil? I have been rather reckless, but I could\r\neasily come out of that. I need you to draw me back, if my life ever\r\namounts to anything.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie looked at him with the tenderness which virtue ever feels in its\r\nhope of reclaiming vice. How could such a man need reclaiming? His\r\nerrors, what were they, that she could correct? Small they must be,\r\nwhere all was so fine. At worst, they were gilded affairs, and with\r\nwhat leniency are gilded errors viewed. He put himself in such a lonely\r\nlight that she was deeply moved.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it that way?\xe2\x80\x9d she mused.\r\n\r\nHe slipped his arm about her waist, and she could not find the heart to\r\ndraw away. With his free hand he seized upon her fingers. A breath of\r\nsoft spring wind went bounding over the road, rolling some brown twigs\r\nof the previous autumn before it. The horse paced leisurely on,\r\nunguided.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell me,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, softly, \xe2\x80\x9cthat you love me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHer eyes fell consciously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOwn to it, dear,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, feelingly; \xe2\x80\x9cyou do, don\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe made no answer, but he felt his victory.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell me,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, richly, drawing her so close that their lips were\r\nnear together. He pressed her hand warmly, and then released it to\r\ntouch her cheek.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou do?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, pressing his lips to her own.\r\n\r\nFor answer, her lips replied.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, joyously, his fine eyes ablaze, \xe2\x80\x9cyou\xe2\x80\x99re my own girl,\r\naren\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBy way of further conclusion, her head lay softly upon his shoulder.\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XIV. WITH EYES AND NOT SEEING: ONE INFLUENCE WANES\r\n\r\nCarrie in her rooms that evening was in a fine glow, physically and\r\nmentally. She was deeply rejoicing in her affection for Hurstwood and\r\nhis love, and looked forward with fine fancy to their next meeting\r\nSunday night. They had agreed, without any feeling of enforced secrecy,\r\nthat she should come down town and meet him, though, after all, the\r\nneed of it was the cause.\r\n\r\nMrs. Hale, from her upper window, saw her come in.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUm,\xe2\x80\x9d she thought to herself, \xe2\x80\x9cshe goes riding with another man when\r\nher husband is out of the city. He had better keep an eye on her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe truth is that Mrs. Hale was not the only one who had a thought on\r\nthis score. The housemaid who had welcomed Hurstwood had her opinion\r\nalso. She had no particular regard for Carrie, whom she took to be cold\r\nand disagreeable. At the same time, she had a fancy for the merry and\r\neasy-mannered Drouet, who threw her a pleasant remark now and then, and\r\nin other ways extended her the evidence of that regard which he had for\r\nall members of the sex. Hurstwood was more reserved and critical in his\r\nmanner. He did not appeal to this bodiced functionary in the same\r\npleasant way. She wondered that he came so frequently, that Mrs. Drouet\r\nshould go out with him this afternoon when Mr. Drouet was absent. She\r\ngave vent to her opinions in the kitchen where the cook was. As a\r\nresult, a hum of gossip was set going which moved about the house in\r\nthat secret manner common to gossip.\r\n\r\nCarrie, now that she had yielded sufficiently to Hurstwood to confess\r\nher affection, no longer troubled about her attitude towards him.\r\nTemporarily she gave little thought to Drouet, thinking only of the\r\ndignity and grace of her lover and of his consuming affection for her.\r\nOn the first evening, she did little but go over the details of the\r\nafternoon. It was the first time her sympathies had ever been\r\nthoroughly aroused, and they threw a new light on her character. She\r\nhad some power of initiative, latent before, which now began to exert\r\nitself. She looked more practically upon her state and began to see\r\nglimmerings of a way out. Hurstwood seemed a drag in the direction of\r\nhonour. Her feelings were exceedingly creditable, in that they\r\nconstructed out of these recent developments something which conquered\r\nfreedom from dishonour. She had no idea what Hurstwood\xe2\x80\x99s next word\r\nwould be. She only took his affection to be a fine thing, and appended\r\nbetter, more generous results accordingly.\r\n\r\nAs yet, Hurstwood had only a thought of pleasure without\r\nresponsibility. He did not feel that he was doing anything to\r\ncomplicate his life. His position was secure, his home-life, if not\r\nsatisfactory, was at least undisturbed, his personal liberty rather\r\nuntrammelled. Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s love represented only so much added pleasure. He\r\nwould enjoy this new gift over and above his ordinary allowance of\r\npleasure. He would be happy with her and his own affairs would go on as\r\nthey had, undisturbed.\r\n\r\nOn Sunday evening Carrie dined with him at a place he had selected in\r\nEast Adams Street, and thereafter they took a cab to what was then a\r\npleasant evening resort out on Cottage Grove Avenue near 39th Street.\r\nIn the process of his declaration he soon realised that Carrie took his\r\nlove upon a higher basis than he had anticipated. She kept him at a\r\ndistance in a rather earnest way, and submitted only to those tender\r\ntokens of affection which better become the inexperienced lover.\r\nHurstwood saw that she was not to be possessed for the asking, and\r\ndeferred pressing his suit too warmly.\r\n\r\nSince he feigned to believe in her married state he found that he had\r\nto carry out the part. His triumph, he saw, was still at a little\r\ndistance. How far he could not guess.\r\n\r\nThey were returning to Ogden Place in the cab, when he asked:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen will I see you again?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered, wondering herself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy not come down to The Fair,\xe2\x80\x9d he suggested, \xe2\x80\x9cnext Tuesday?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe shook her head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot so soon,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you what I\xe2\x80\x99ll do,\xe2\x80\x9d he added. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll write you, care of this\r\nWest Side Post-office. Could you call next Tuesday?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie assented.\r\n\r\nThe cab stopped one door out of the way according to his call.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood-night,\xe2\x80\x9d he whispered, as the cab rolled away.\r\n\r\nUnfortunately for the smooth progression of this affair, Drouet\r\nreturned. Hurstwood was sitting in his imposing little office the next\r\nafternoon when he saw Drouet enter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, hello, Charles,\xe2\x80\x9d he called affably; \xe2\x80\x9cback again?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d smiled Drouet, approaching and looking in at the door.\r\n\r\nHurstwood arose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, looking the drummer over, \xe2\x80\x9crosy as ever, eh?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey began talking of the people they knew and things that had\r\nhappened.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBeen home yet?\xe2\x80\x9d finally asked Hurstwood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I am going, though,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI remembered the little girl out there,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood, \xe2\x80\x9cand called\r\nonce. Thought you wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t want her left quite alone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRight you are,\xe2\x80\x9d agreed Drouet. \xe2\x80\x9cHow is she?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood. \xe2\x80\x9cRather anxious about you though. You\xe2\x80\x99d\r\nbetter go out now and cheer her up.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet, smilingly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLike to have you both come down and go to the show with me Wednesday,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nconcluded Hurstwood at parting.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThanks, old man,\xe2\x80\x9d said his friend, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll see what the girl says and\r\nlet you know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey separated in the most cordial manner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s a nice fellow,\xe2\x80\x9d Drouet thought to himself as he turned the\r\ncorner towards Madison.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDrouet is a good fellow,\xe2\x80\x9d Hurstwood thought to himself as he went back\r\ninto his office, \xe2\x80\x9cbut he\xe2\x80\x99s no man for Carrie.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe thought of the latter turned his mind into a most pleasant vein,\r\nand he wandered how he would get ahead of the drummer.\r\n\r\nWhen Drouet entered Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s presence, he caught her in his arms as\r\nusual, but she responded to his kiss with a tremour of opposition.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cI had a great trip.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you? How did you come out with that La Crosse man you were telling\r\nme about?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, fine; sold him a complete line. There was another fellow there,\r\nrepresenting Burnstein, a regular hook-nosed sheeny, but he wasn\xe2\x80\x99t in\r\nit. I made him look like nothing at all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs he undid his collar and unfastened his studs, preparatory to washing\r\nhis face and changing his clothes, he dilated upon his trip. Carrie\r\ncould not help listening with amusement to his animated descriptions.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI tell you,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cI surprised the people at the office. I\xe2\x80\x99ve sold\r\nmore goods this last quarter than any other man of our house on the\r\nroad. I sold three thousand dollars\xe2\x80\x99 worth in La Crosse.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe plunged his face in a basin of water, and puffed and blew as he\r\nrubbed his neck and ears with his hands, while Carrie gazed upon him\r\nwith mingled thoughts of recollection and present judgment. He was\r\nstill wiping his face, when he continued:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m going to strike for a raise in June. They can afford to pay it, as\r\nmuch business as I turn in. I\xe2\x80\x99ll get it too, don\xe2\x80\x99t you forget.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hope you do,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd then if that little real estate deal I\xe2\x80\x99ve got on goes through,\r\nwe\xe2\x80\x99ll get married,\xe2\x80\x9d he said with a great show of earnestness, the while\r\nhe took his place before the mirror and began brushing his hair.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t believe you ever intend to marry me, Charlie,\xe2\x80\x9d Carrie said\r\nruefully. The recent protestations of Hurstwood had given her courage\r\nto say this.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes I do\xe2\x80\x94course I do\xe2\x80\x94what put that into your head?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe had stopped his trifling before the mirror now and crossed over to\r\nher. For the first time Carrie felt as if she must move away from him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you\xe2\x80\x99ve been saying that so long,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, looking with her\r\npretty face upturned into his.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, and I mean it too, but it takes money to live as I want to. Now,\r\nwhen I get this increase, I can come pretty near fixing things all\r\nright, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll do it. Now, don\xe2\x80\x99t you worry, girlie.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe patted her reassuringly upon the shoulder, but Carrie felt how\r\nreally futile had been her hopes. She could clearly see that this\r\neasy-going soul intended no move in her behalf. He was simply letting\r\nthings drift because he preferred the free round of his present state\r\nto any legal trammellings.\r\n\r\nIn contrast, Hurstwood appeared strong and sincere. He had no easy\r\nmanner of putting her off. He sympathised with her and showed her what\r\nher true value was. He needed her, while Drouet did not care.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no,\xe2\x80\x9d she said remorsefully, her tone reflecting some of her own\r\nsuccess and more of her helplessness, \xe2\x80\x9cyou never will.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you wait a little while and see,\xe2\x80\x9d he concluded. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll marry you\r\nall right.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie looked at him and felt justified. She was looking for something\r\nwhich would calm her conscience, and here it was, a light, airy\r\ndisregard of her claims upon his justice. He had faithfully promised to\r\nmarry her, and this was the way he fulfilled his promise.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSay,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, after he had, as he thought, pleasantly disposed of the\r\nmarriage question, \xe2\x80\x9cI saw Hurstwood to-day, and he wants us to go to\r\nthe theatre with him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie started at the name, but recovered quickly enough to avoid\r\nnotice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked, with assumed indifference.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWednesday. We\xe2\x80\x99ll go, won\xe2\x80\x99t we?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you think so,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered, her manner being so enforcedly\r\nreserved as to almost excite suspicion. Drouet noticed something but he\r\nthought it was due to her feelings concerning their talk about\r\nmarriage. \xe2\x80\x9cHe called once, he said.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, \xe2\x80\x9che was out here Sunday evening.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWas he?\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet. \xe2\x80\x9cI thought from what he said that he had called\r\na week or so ago.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo he did,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Carrie, who was wholly unaware of what\r\nconversation her lovers might have held. She was all at sea mentally,\r\nand fearful of some entanglement which might ensue from what she would\r\nanswer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, then he called twice?\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet, the first shade of\r\nmisunderstanding showing in his face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie innocently, feeling now that Hurstwood must have\r\nmentioned but one call.\r\n\r\nDrouet imagined that he must have misunderstood his friend. He did not\r\nattach particular importance to the information, after all.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat did he have to say?\xe2\x80\x9d he queried, with slightly increased\r\ncuriosity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe said he came because he thought I might be lonely. You hadn\xe2\x80\x99t been\r\nin there so long he wondered what had become of you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGeorge is a fine fellow,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet, rather gratified by his\r\nconception of the manager\xe2\x80\x99s interest. \xe2\x80\x9cCome on and we\xe2\x80\x99ll go out to\r\ndinner.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhen Hurstwood saw that Drouet was back he wrote at once to Carrie,\r\nsaying:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI told him I called on you, dearest, when he was away. I did not say\r\nhow often, but he probably thought once. Let me know of anything you\r\nmay have said. Answer by special messenger when you get this, and,\r\ndarling, I must see you. Let me know if you can\xe2\x80\x99t meet me at Jackson\r\nand Throop Streets Wednesday afternoon at two o\xe2\x80\x99clock. I want to speak\r\nwith you before we meet at the theatre.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie received this Tuesday morning when she called at the West Side\r\nbranch of the post-office, and answered at once.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI said you called twice,\xe2\x80\x9d she wrote. \xe2\x80\x9cHe didn\xe2\x80\x99t seem to mind. I will\r\ntry and be at Throop Street if nothing interferes. I seem to be getting\r\nvery bad. It\xe2\x80\x99s wrong to act as I do, I know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHurstwood, when he met her as agreed, reassured her on this score.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou mustn\xe2\x80\x99t worry, sweetheart,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cJust as soon as he goes on\r\nthe road again we will arrange something. We\xe2\x80\x99ll fix it so that you\r\nwon\xe2\x80\x99t have to deceive any one.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie imagined that he would marry her at once, though he had not\r\ndirectly said so, and her spirits rose. She proposed to make the best\r\nof the situation until Drouet left again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t show any more interest in me than you ever have,\xe2\x80\x9d Hurstwood\r\ncounselled concerning the evening at the theatre.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou mustn\xe2\x80\x99t look at me steadily then,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered, mindful of the\r\npower of his eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI won\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, squeezing her hand at parting and giving the glance\r\nshe had just cautioned against.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere,\xe2\x80\x9d she said playfully, pointing a finger at him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe show hasn\xe2\x80\x99t begun yet,\xe2\x80\x9d he returned.\r\n\r\nHe watched her walk from him with tender solicitation. Such youth and\r\nprettiness reacted upon him more subtly than wine.\r\n\r\nAt the theatre things passed as they had in Hurstwood\xe2\x80\x99s favour. If he\r\nhad been pleasing to Carrie before, how much more so was he now. His\r\ngrace was more permeating because it found a readier medium. Carrie\r\nwatched his every movement with pleasure. She almost forgot poor\r\nDrouet, who babbled on as if he were the host.\r\n\r\nHurstwood was too clever to give the slightest indication of a change.\r\nHe paid, if anything, more attention to his old friend than usual, and\r\nyet in no way held him up to that subtle ridicule which a lover in\r\nfavour may so secretly practise before the mistress of his heart. If\r\nanything, he felt the injustice of the game as it stood, and was not\r\ncheap enough to add to it the slightest mental taunt.\r\n\r\nOnly the play produced an ironical situation, and this was due to\r\nDrouet alone.\r\n\r\nThe scene was one in \xe2\x80\x9cThe Covenant,\xe2\x80\x9d in which the wife listened to the\r\nseductive voice of a lover in the absence of her husband.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cServed him right,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet afterward, even in view of her keen\r\nexpiation of her error. \xe2\x80\x9cI haven\xe2\x80\x99t any pity for a man who would be such\r\na chump as that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you never can tell,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Hurstwood gently. \xe2\x80\x9cHe probably\r\nthought he was right.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, a man ought to be more attentive than that to his wife if he\r\nwants to keep her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey had come out of the lobby and made their way through the showy\r\ncrush about the entrance way.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSay, mister,\xe2\x80\x9d said a voice at Hurstwood\xe2\x80\x99s side, \xe2\x80\x9cwould you mind giving\r\nme the price of a bed?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHurstwood was interestedly remarking to Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHonest to God, mister, I\xe2\x80\x99m without a place to sleep.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe plea was that of a gaunt-faced man of about thirty, who looked the\r\npicture of privation and wretchedness. Drouet was the first to see. He\r\nhanded over a dime with an upwelling feeling of pity in his heart.\r\nHurstwood scarcely noticed the incident. Carrie quickly forgot.\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XV. THE IRK OF THE OLD TIES: THE MAGIC OF YOUTH\r\n\r\nThe complete ignoring by Hurstwood of his own home came with the growth\r\nof his affection for Carrie. His actions, in all that related to his\r\nfamily, were of the most perfunctory kind. He sat at breakfast with his\r\nwife and children, absorbed in his own fancies, which reached far\r\nwithout the realm of their interests. He read his paper, which was\r\nheightened in interest by the shallowness of the themes discussed by\r\nhis son and daughter. Between himself and his wife ran a river of\r\nindifference.\r\n\r\nNow that Carrie had come, he was in a fair way to be blissful again.\r\nThere was delight in going down town evenings. When he walked forth in\r\nthe short days, the street lamps had a merry twinkle. He began to\r\nexperience the almost forgotten feeling which hastens the lover\xe2\x80\x99s feet.\r\nWhen he looked at his fine clothes, he saw them with her eyes\xe2\x80\x94and her\r\neyes were young.\r\n\r\nWhen in the flush of such feelings he heard his wife\xe2\x80\x99s voice, when the\r\ninsistent demands of matrimony recalled him from dreams to a stale\r\npractice, how it grated. He then knew that this was a chain which bound\r\nhis feet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGeorge,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Hurstwood, in that tone of voice which had long\r\nsince come to be associated in his mind with demands, \xe2\x80\x9cwe want you to\r\nget us a season ticket to the races.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you want to go to all of them?\xe2\x80\x9d he said with a rising inflection.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered.\r\n\r\nThe races in question were soon to open at Washington Park, on the\r\nSouth Side, and were considered quite society affairs among those who\r\ndid not affect religious rectitude and conservatism. Mrs. Hurstwood had\r\nnever asked for a whole season ticket before, but this year certain\r\nconsiderations decided her to get a box. For one thing, one of her\r\nneighbours, a certain Mr. and Mrs. Ramsey, who were possessors of\r\nmoney, made out of the coal business, had done so. In the next place,\r\nher favourite physician, Dr. Beale, a gentleman inclined to horses and\r\nbetting, had talked with her concerning his intention to enter a\r\ntwo-year-old in the Derby. In the third place, she wished to exhibit\r\nJessica, who was gaining in maturity and beauty, and whom she hoped to\r\nmarry to a man of means. Her own desire to be about in such things and\r\nparade among her acquaintances and common throng was as much an\r\nincentive as anything.\r\n\r\nHurstwood thought over the proposition a few moments without answering.\r\nThey were in the sitting room on the second floor, waiting for supper.\r\nIt was the evening of his engagement with Carrie and Drouet to see \xe2\x80\x9cThe\r\nCovenant,\xe2\x80\x9d which had brought him home to make some alterations in his\r\ndress.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re sure separate tickets wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t do as well?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked,\r\nhesitating to say anything more rugged.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d she replied impatiently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, taking offence at her manner, \xe2\x80\x9cyou needn\xe2\x80\x99t get mad\r\nabout it. I\xe2\x80\x99m just asking you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m not mad,\xe2\x80\x9d she snapped. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m merely asking you for a season\r\nticket.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I\xe2\x80\x99m telling you,\xe2\x80\x9d he returned, fixing a clear, steady eye on her,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthat it\xe2\x80\x99s no easy thing to get. I\xe2\x80\x99m not sure whether the manager will\r\ngive it to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe had been thinking all the time of his \xe2\x80\x9cpull\xe2\x80\x9d with the race-track\r\nmagnates.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe can buy it then,\xe2\x80\x9d she exclaimed sharply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou talk easy,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cA season family ticket costs one hundred and\r\nfifty dollars.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll not argue with you,\xe2\x80\x9d she replied with determination. \xe2\x80\x9cI want the\r\nticket and that\xe2\x80\x99s all there is to it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe had risen, and now walked angrily out of the room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you get it then,\xe2\x80\x9d he said grimly, though in a modified tone of\r\nvoice.\r\n\r\nAs usual, the table was one short that evening.\r\n\r\nThe next morning he had cooled down considerably, and later the ticket\r\nwas duly secured, though it did not heal matters. He did not mind\r\ngiving his family a fair share of all that he earned, but he did not\r\nlike to be forced to provide against his will.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you know, mother,\xe2\x80\x9d said Jessica another day, \xe2\x80\x9cthe Spencers are\r\ngetting ready to go away?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo. Where, I wonder?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEurope,\xe2\x80\x9d said Jessica. \xe2\x80\x9cI met Georgine yesterday and she told me. She\r\njust put on more airs about it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid she say when?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonday, I think. They\xe2\x80\x99ll get a notice in the papers again\xe2\x80\x94they always\r\ndo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever mind,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Hurstwood consolingly, \xe2\x80\x9cwe\xe2\x80\x99ll go one of these\r\ndays.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHurstwood moved his eyes over the paper slowly, but said nothing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98We sail for Liverpool from New York,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d Jessica exclaimed, mocking her\r\nacquaintance. \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Expect to spend most of the \xe2\x80\x9csummah\xe2\x80\x9d in France,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94vain\r\nthing. As if it was anything to go to Europe.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt must be if you envy her so much,\xe2\x80\x9d put in Hurstwood.\r\n\r\nIt grated upon him to see the feeling his daughter displayed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t worry over them, my dear,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Hurstwood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid George get off?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Jessica of her mother another day, thus\r\nrevealing something that Hurstwood had heard nothing about.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere has he gone?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, looking up. He had never before been\r\nkept in ignorance concerning departures.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe was going to Wheaton,\xe2\x80\x9d said Jessica, not noticing the slight put\r\nupon her father.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s out there?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, secretly irritated and chagrined to think\r\nthat he should be made to pump for information in this manner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA tennis match,\xe2\x80\x9d said Jessica.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe didn\xe2\x80\x99t say anything to me,\xe2\x80\x9d Hurstwood concluded, finding it\r\ndifficult to refrain from a bitter tone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI guess he must have forgotten,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed his wife blandly. In the\r\npast he had always commanded a certain amount of respect, which was a\r\ncompound of appreciation and awe. The familiarity which in part still\r\nexisted between himself and his daughter he had courted. As it was, it\r\ndid not go beyond the light assumption of words. The _tone_ was always\r\nmodest. Whatever had been, however, had lacked affection, and now he\r\nsaw that he was losing track of their doings. His knowledge was no\r\nlonger intimate. He sometimes saw them at table, and sometimes did not.\r\nHe heard of their doings occasionally, more often not. Some days he\r\nfound that he was all at sea as to what they were talking about\xe2\x80\x94things\r\nthey had arranged to do or that they had done in his absence. More\r\naffecting was the feeling that there were little things going on of\r\nwhich he no longer heard. Jessica was beginning to feel that her\r\naffairs were her own. George, Jr., flourished about as if he were a man\r\nentirely and must needs have private matters. All this Hurstwood could\r\nsee, and it left a trace of feeling, for he was used to being\r\nconsidered\xe2\x80\x94in his official position, at least\xe2\x80\x94and felt that his\r\nimportance should not begin to wane here. To darken it all, he saw the\r\nsame indifference and independence growing in his wife, while he looked\r\non and paid the bills.\r\n\r\nHe consoled himself with the thought, however, that, after all, he was\r\nnot without affection. Things might go as they would at his house, but\r\nhe had Carrie outside of it. With his mind\xe2\x80\x99s eye he looked into her\r\ncomfortable room in Ogden Place, where he had spent several such\r\ndelightful evenings, and thought how charming it would be when Drouet\r\nwas disposed of entirely and she was waiting evenings in cosey little\r\nquarters for him. That no cause would come up whereby Drouet would be\r\nled to inform Carrie concerning his married state, he felt hopeful.\r\nThings were going so smoothly that he believed they would not change.\r\nShortly now he would persuade Carrie and all would be satisfactory.\r\n\r\nThe day after their theatre visit he began writing her regularly\xe2\x80\x94a\r\nletter every morning, and begging her to do as much for him. He was not\r\nliterary by any means, but experience of the world and his growing\r\naffection gave him somewhat of a style. This he exercised at his office\r\ndesk with perfect deliberation. He purchased a box of delicately\r\ncoloured and scented writing paper in monogram, which he kept locked in\r\none of the drawers. His friends now wondered at the cleric and very\r\nofficial-looking nature of his position. The five bartenders viewed\r\nwith respect the duties which could call a man to do so much desk-work\r\nand penmanship.\r\n\r\nHurstwood surprised himself with his fluency. By the natural law which\r\ngoverns all effort, what he wrote reacted upon him. He began to feel\r\nthose subtleties which he could find words to express. With every\r\nexpression came increased conception. Those inmost breathings which\r\nthere found words took hold upon him. He thought Carrie worthy of all\r\nthe affection he could there express.\r\n\r\nCarrie was indeed worth loving if ever youth and grace are to command\r\nthat token of acknowledgment from life in their bloom. Experience had\r\nnot yet taken away that freshness of the spirit which is the charm of\r\nthe body. Her soft eyes contained in their liquid lustre no suggestion\r\nof the knowledge of disappointment. She had been troubled in a way by\r\ndoubt and longing, but these had made no deeper impression than could\r\nbe traced in a certain open wistfulness of glance and speech. The mouth\r\nhad the expression at times, in talking and in repose, of one who might\r\nbe upon the verge of tears. It was not that grief was thus ever\r\npresent. The pronunciation of certain syllables gave to her lips this\r\npeculiarity of formation\xe2\x80\x94a formation as suggestive and moving as pathos\r\nitself.\r\n\r\nThere was nothing bold in her manner. Life had not taught her\r\ndomination\xe2\x80\x94superciliousness of grace, which is the lordly power of some\r\nwomen. Her longing for consideration was not sufficiently powerful to\r\nmove her to demand it. Even now she lacked self-assurance, but there\r\nwas that in what she had already experienced which left her a little\r\nless than timid. She wanted pleasure, she wanted position, and yet she\r\nwas confused as to what these things might be. Every hour the\r\nkaleidoscope of human affairs threw a new lustre upon something, and\r\ntherewith it became for her the desired\xe2\x80\x94the all. Another shift of the\r\nbox, and some other had become the beautiful, the perfect.\r\n\r\nOn her spiritual side, also, she was rich in feeling, as such a nature\r\nwell might be. Sorrow in her was aroused by many a spectacle\xe2\x80\x94an\r\nuncritical upwelling of grief for the weak and the helpless. She was\r\nconstantly pained by the sight of the white-faced, ragged men who\r\nslopped desperately by her in a sort of wretched mental stupor. The\r\npoorly clad girls who went blowing by her window evenings, hurrying\r\nhome from some of the shops of the West Side, she pitied from the\r\ndepths of her heart. She would stand and bite her lips as they passed,\r\nshaking her little head and wondering. They had so little, she thought.\r\nIt was so sad to be ragged and poor. The hang of faded clothes pained\r\nher eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd they have to work so hard!\xe2\x80\x9d was her only comment.\r\n\r\nOn the street sometimes she would see men working\xe2\x80\x94Irishmen with picks,\r\ncoal-heavers with great loads to shovel, Americans busy about some work\r\nwhich was a mere matter of strength\xe2\x80\x94and they touched her fancy. Toil,\r\nnow that she was free of it, seemed even a more desolate thing than\r\nwhen she was part of it. She saw it through a mist of fancy\xe2\x80\x94a pale,\r\nsombre half-light, which was the essence of poetic feeling. Her old\r\nfather, in his flour-dusted miller\xe2\x80\x99s suit, sometimes returned to her in\r\nmemory, revived by a face in a window. A shoemaker pegging at his last,\r\na blastman seen through a narrow window in some basement where iron was\r\nbeing melted, a bench-worker seen high aloft in some window, his coat\r\noff, his sleeves rolled up; these took her back in fancy to the details\r\nof the mill. She felt, though she seldom expressed them, sad thoughts\r\nupon this score. Her sympathies were ever with that under-world of toil\r\nfrom which she had so recently sprung, and which she best understood.\r\n\r\nThough Hurstwood did not know it, he was dealing with one whose\r\nfeelings were as tender and as delicate as this. He did not know, but\r\nit was this in her, after all, which attracted him. He never attempted\r\nto analyse the nature of his affection. It was sufficient that there\r\nwas tenderness in her eye, weakness in her manner, good nature and hope\r\nin her thoughts. He drew near this lily, which had sucked its waxen\r\nbeauty and perfume from below a depth of waters which he had never\r\npenetrated, and out of ooze and mould which he could not understand. He\r\ndrew near because it was waxen and fresh. It lightened his feelings for\r\nhim. It made the morning worth while.\r\n\r\nIn a material way, she was considerably improved. Her awkwardness had\r\nall but passed, leaving, if anything, a quaint residue which was as\r\npleasing as perfect grace. Her little shoes now fitted her smartly and\r\nhad high heels. She had learned much about laces and those little\r\nneckpieces which add so much to a woman\xe2\x80\x99s appearance. Her form had\r\nfilled out until it was admirably plump and well-rounded.\r\n\r\nHurstwood wrote her one morning, asking her to meet him in Jefferson\r\nPark, Monroe Street. He did not consider it policy to call any more,\r\neven when Drouet was at home.\r\n\r\nThe next afternoon he was in the pretty little park by one, and had\r\nfound a rustic bench beneath the green leaves of a lilac bush which\r\nbordered one of the paths. It was at that season of the year when the\r\nfulness of spring had not yet worn quite away. At a little pond near by\r\nsome cleanly dressed children were sailing white canvas boats. In the\r\nshade of a green pagoda a bebuttoned officer of the law was resting,\r\nhis arms folded, his club at rest in his belt. An old gardener was upon\r\nthe lawn, with a pair of pruning shears, looking after some bushes.\r\nHigh overhead was the clean blue sky of the new summer, and in the\r\nthickness of the shiny green leaves of the trees hopped and twittered\r\nthe busy sparrows.\r\n\r\nHurstwood had come out of his own home that morning feeling much of the\r\nsame old annoyance. At his store he had idled, there being no need to\r\nwrite. He had come away to this place with the lightness of heart which\r\ncharacterises those who put weariness behind. Now, in the shade of this\r\ncool, green bush, he looked about him with the fancy of the lover. He\r\nheard the carts go lumbering by upon the neighbouring streets, but they\r\nwere far off, and only buzzed upon his ear. The hum of the surrounding\r\ncity was faint, the clang of an occasional bell was as music. He looked\r\nand dreamed a new dream of pleasure which concerned his present fixed\r\ncondition not at all. He got back in fancy to the old Hurstwood, who\r\nwas neither married nor fixed in a solid position for life. He\r\nremembered the light spirit in which he once looked after the girls\xe2\x80\x94how\r\nhe had danced, escorted them home, hung over their gates. He almost\r\nwished he was back there again\xe2\x80\x94here in this pleasant scene he felt as\r\nif he were wholly free.\r\n\r\nAt two Carrie came tripping along the walk toward him, rosy and clean.\r\nShe had just recently donned a sailor hat for the season with a band of\r\npretty white-dotted blue silk. Her skirt was of a rich blue material,\r\nand her shirt waist matched it, with a thin-stripe of blue upon a\r\nsnow-white ground\xe2\x80\x94stripes that were as fine as hairs. Her brown shoes\r\npeeped occasionally from beneath her skirt. She carried her gloves in\r\nher hand.\r\n\r\nHurstwood looked up at her with delight.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou came, dearest,\xe2\x80\x9d he said eagerly, standing to meet her and taking\r\nher hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, smiling; \xe2\x80\x9cdid you think I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI didn\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d he replied.\r\n\r\nHe looked at her forehead, which was moist from her brisk walk. Then he\r\ntook out one of his own soft, scented silk handkerchiefs and touched\r\nher face here and there.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow,\xe2\x80\x9d he said affectionately, \xe2\x80\x9cyou\xe2\x80\x99re all right.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey were happy in being near one another\xe2\x80\x94in looking into each other\xe2\x80\x99s\r\neyes. Finally, when the long flush of delight had subsided, he said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen is Charlie going away again?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered. \xe2\x80\x9cHe says he has some things to do for the\r\nhouse here now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHurstwood grew serious, and he lapsed into quiet thought. He looked up\r\nafter a time to say:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome away and leave him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe turned his eyes to the boys with the boats, as if the request were\r\nof little importance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere would we go?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked in much the same manner, rolling her\r\ngloves, and looking into a neighbouring tree.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere do you want to go?\xe2\x80\x9d he enquired.\r\n\r\nThere was something in the tone in which he said this which made her\r\nfeel as if she must record her feelings against any local habitation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe can\xe2\x80\x99t stay in Chicago,\xe2\x80\x9d she replied.\r\n\r\nHe had no thought that this was in her mind\xe2\x80\x94that any removal would be\r\nsuggested.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy not?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked softly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, because,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cI wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t want to.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe listened to this with but dull perception of what it meant. It had\r\nno serious ring to it. The question was not up for immediate decision.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI would have to give up my position,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\nThe tone he used made it seem as if the matter deserved only slight\r\nconsideration. Carrie thought a little, the while enjoying the pretty\r\nscene.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t like to live in Chicago and him here,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, thinking\r\nof Drouet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a big town, dearest,\xe2\x80\x9d Hurstwood answered. \xe2\x80\x9cIt would be as good as\r\nmoving to another part of the country to move to the South Side.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe had fixed upon that region as an objective point.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnyhow,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, \xe2\x80\x9cI shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t want to get married as long as he\r\nis here. I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t want to run away.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe suggestion of marriage struck Hurstwood forcibly. He saw clearly\r\nthat this was her idea\xe2\x80\x94he felt that it was not to be gotten over\r\neasily. Bigamy lightened the horizon of his shadowy thoughts for a\r\nmoment. He wondered for the life of him how it would all come out. He\r\ncould not see that he was making any progress save in her regard. When\r\nhe looked at her now, he thought her beautiful. What a thing it was to\r\nhave her love him, even if it be entangling! She increased in value in\r\nhis eyes because of her objection. She was something to struggle for,\r\nand that was everything. How different from the women who yielded\r\nwillingly! He swept the thought of them from his mind.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you don\xe2\x80\x99t know when he\xe2\x80\x99ll go away?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Hurstwood, quietly.\r\n\r\nShe shook her head.\r\n\r\nHe sighed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re a determined little miss, aren\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, after a few\r\nmoments, looking up into her eyes.\r\n\r\nShe felt a wave of feeling sweep over her at this. It was pride at what\r\nseemed his admiration\xe2\x80\x94affection for the man who could feel this\r\nconcerning her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d she said coyly, \xe2\x80\x9cbut what can I do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAgain he folded his hands and looked away over the lawn into the\r\nstreet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish,\xe2\x80\x9d he said pathetically, \xe2\x80\x9cyou would come to me. I don\xe2\x80\x99t like to\r\nbe away from you this way. What good is there in waiting? You\xe2\x80\x99re not\r\nany happier, are you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHappier!\xe2\x80\x9d she exclaimed softly, \xe2\x80\x9cyou know better than that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere we are then,\xe2\x80\x9d he went on in the same tone, \xe2\x80\x9cwasting our days. If\r\nyou are not happy, do you think I am? I sit and write to you the\r\nbiggest part of the time. I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you what, Carrie,\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed,\r\nthrowing sudden force of expression into his voice and fixing her with\r\nhis eyes, \xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t live without you, and that\xe2\x80\x99s all there is to it.\r\nNow,\xe2\x80\x9d he concluded, showing the palm of one of his white hands in a\r\nsort of at-an-end, helpless expression, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat shall I do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis shifting of the burden to her appealed to Carrie. The semblance of\r\nthe load without the weight touched the woman\xe2\x80\x99s heart.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan\xe2\x80\x99t you wait a little while yet?\xe2\x80\x9d she said tenderly. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll try and\r\nfind out when he\xe2\x80\x99s going.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat good will it do?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, holding the same strain of feeling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, perhaps we can arrange to go somewhere.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe really did not see anything clearer than before, but she was\r\ngetting into that frame of mind where, out of sympathy, a woman yields.\r\n\r\nHurstwood did not understand. He was wondering how she was to be\r\npersuaded\xe2\x80\x94what appeal would move her to forsake Drouet. He began to\r\nwonder how far her affection for him would carry her. He was thinking\r\nof some question which would make her tell.\r\n\r\nFinally he hit upon one of those problematical propositions which often\r\ndisguise our own desires while leading us to an understanding of the\r\ndifficulties which others make for us, and so discover for us a way.
