It\r\nhad not the slightest connection with anything intended on his part,\r\nand was spoken at random before he had given it a moment\xe2\x80\x99s serious\r\nthought.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCarrie,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, looking into her face and assuming a serious look\r\nwhich he did not feel, \xe2\x80\x9csuppose I were to come to you next week, or\r\nthis week for that matter\xe2\x80\x94to-night say\xe2\x80\x94and tell you I had to go\r\naway\xe2\x80\x94that I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t stay another minute and wasn\xe2\x80\x99t coming back any\r\nmore\xe2\x80\x94would you come with me?\xe2\x80\x9d His sweetheart viewed him with the most\r\naffectionate glance, her answer ready before the words were out of his\r\nmouth.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t stop to argue or arrange?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot if you couldn\xe2\x80\x99t wait.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe smiled when he saw that she took him seriously, and he thought what\r\na chance it would afford for a possible junket of a week or two. He had\r\na notion to tell her that he was joking and so brush away her sweet\r\nseriousness, but the effect of it was too delightful. He let it stand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSuppose we didn\xe2\x80\x99t have time to get married here?\xe2\x80\x9d he added, an\r\nafterthought striking him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf we got married as soon as we got to the other end of the journey it\r\nwould be all right.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI meant that,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe morning seemed peculiarly bright to him now. He wondered whatever\r\ncould have put such a thought into his head. Impossible as it was, he\r\ncould not help smiling at its cleverness. It showed how she loved him.\r\nThere was no doubt in his mind now, and he would find a way to win her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, jokingly, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll come and get you one of these\r\nevenings,\xe2\x80\x9d and then he laughed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t stay with you, though, if you didn\xe2\x80\x99t marry me,\xe2\x80\x9d Carrie\r\nadded reflectively.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t want you to,\xe2\x80\x9d he said tenderly, taking her hand.\r\n\r\nShe was extremely happy now that she understood. She loved him the more\r\nfor thinking that he would rescue her so. As for him, the marriage\r\nclause did not dwell in his mind. He was thinking that with such\r\naffection there could be no bar to his eventual happiness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet\xe2\x80\x99s stroll about,\xe2\x80\x9d he said gayly, rising and surveying all the\r\nlovely park.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\nThey passed the young Irishman, who looked after them with envious\r\neyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x99Tis a foine couple,\xe2\x80\x9d he observed to himself. \xe2\x80\x9cThey must be rich.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XVI. A WITLESS ALADDIN: THE GATE TO THE WORLD\r\n\r\nIn the course of his present stay in Chicago, Drouet paid some slight\r\nattention to the secret order to which he belonged. During his last\r\ntrip he had received a new light on its importance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI tell you,\xe2\x80\x9d said another drummer to him, \xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99s a great thing. Look at\r\nHazenstab. He isn\xe2\x80\x99t so deuced clever. Of course he\xe2\x80\x99s got a good house\r\nbehind him, but that won\xe2\x80\x99t do alone. I tell you it\xe2\x80\x99s his degree. He\xe2\x80\x99s a\r\nway-up Mason, and that goes a long way. He\xe2\x80\x99s got a secret sign that\r\nstands for something.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDrouet resolved then and there that he would take more interest in such\r\nmatters. So when he got back to Chicago he repaired to his local lodge\r\nheadquarters.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say, Drouet,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Harry Quincel, an individual who was very\r\nprominent in this local branch of the Elks, \xe2\x80\x9cyou\xe2\x80\x99re the man that can\r\nhelp us out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was after the business meeting and things were going socially with a\r\nhum. Drouet was bobbing around chatting and joking with a score of\r\nindividuals whom he knew.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat are you up to?\xe2\x80\x9d he inquired genially, turning a smiling face upon\r\nhis secret brother.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re trying to get up some theatricals for two weeks from to-day, and\r\nwe want to know if you don\xe2\x80\x99t know some young lady who could take a\r\npart\xe2\x80\x94it\xe2\x80\x99s an easy part.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSure,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat is it?\xe2\x80\x9d He did not trouble to remember that\r\nhe knew no one to whom he could appeal on this score. His innate\r\ngood-nature, however, dictated a favourable reply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, now, I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you what we are trying to do,\xe2\x80\x9d went on Mr.\r\nQuincel. \xe2\x80\x9cWe are trying to get a new set of furniture for the lodge.\r\nThere isn\xe2\x80\x99t enough money in the treasury at the present time, and we\r\nthought we would raise it by a little entertainment.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSure,\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted Drouet, \xe2\x80\x9cthat\xe2\x80\x99s a good idea.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSeveral of the boys around here have got talent. There\xe2\x80\x99s Harry\r\nBurbeck, he does a fine black-face turn. Mac Lewis is all right at\r\nheavy dramatics. Did you ever hear him recite \xe2\x80\x98Over the Hills\xe2\x80\x99?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever did.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I tell you, he does it fine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you want me to get some woman to take a part?\xe2\x80\x9d questioned Drouet,\r\nanxious to terminate the subject and get on to something else. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat\r\nare you going to play?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Under the Gaslight,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Quincel, mentioning Augustin Daly\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nfamous production, which had worn from a great public success down to\r\nan amateur theatrical favourite, with many of the troublesome\r\naccessories cut out and the _dramatis person\xc3\xa6_ reduced to the smallest\r\npossible number.\r\n\r\nDrouet had seen this play some time in the past.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s it,\xe2\x80\x9d he said; \xe2\x80\x9cthat\xe2\x80\x99s a fine play. It will go all right. You\r\nought to make a lot of money out of that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe think we\xe2\x80\x99ll do very well,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Quincel replied. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t you forget\r\nnow,\xe2\x80\x9d he concluded, Drouet showing signs of restlessness; \xe2\x80\x9csome young\r\nwoman to take the part of Laura.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSure, I\xe2\x80\x99ll attend to it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe moved away, forgetting almost all about it the moment Mr. Quincel\r\nhad ceased talking. He had not even thought to ask the time or place.\r\n\r\nDrouet was reminded of his promise a day or two later by the receipt of\r\na letter announcing that the first rehearsal was set for the following\r\nFriday evening, and urging him to kindly forward the young lady\xe2\x80\x99s\r\naddress at once, in order that the part might be delivered to her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, who the deuce do I know?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the drummer reflectively,\r\nscratching his rosy ear. \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know any one that knows anything\r\nabout amateur theatricals.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe went over in memory the names of a number of women he knew, and\r\nfinally fixed on one, largely because of the convenient location of her\r\nhome on the West Side, and promised himself that as he came out that\r\nevening he would see her. When, however, he started west on the car he\r\nforgot, and was only reminded of his delinquency by an item in the\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEvening News\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94a small three-line affair under the head of Secret\r\nSociety Notes\xe2\x80\x94which stated the Custer Lodge of the Order of Elks would\r\ngive a theatrical performance in Avery Hall on the 16th, when \xe2\x80\x9cUnder\r\nthe Gaslight\xe2\x80\x9d would be produced.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGeorge!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Drouet, \xe2\x80\x9cI forgot that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Carrie.\r\n\r\nThey were at their little table in the room which might have been used\r\nfor a kitchen, where Carrie occasionally served a meal. To-night the\r\nfancy had caught her, and the little table was spread with a pleasing\r\nrepast.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, my lodge entertainment. They\xe2\x80\x99re going to give a play, and they\r\nwanted me to get them some young lady to take a part.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it they\xe2\x80\x99re going to play?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Under the Gaslight.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn the 16th.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, why don\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know any one,\xe2\x80\x9d he replied.\r\n\r\nSuddenly he looked up.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSay,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9chow would you like to take the part?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMe?\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie. \xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t act.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow do you know?\xe2\x80\x9d questioned Drouet reflectively.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Carrie, \xe2\x80\x9cI never did.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNevertheless, she was pleased to think he would ask. Her eyes\r\nbrightened, for if there was anything that enlisted her sympathies it\r\nwas the art of the stage. True to his nature, Drouet clung to this idea\r\nas an easy way out.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s nothing. You can act all you have to down there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I can\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie weakly, very much drawn toward the\r\nproposition and yet fearful.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, you can. Now, why don\xe2\x80\x99t you do it? They need some one, and it\r\nwill be lots of fun for you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no, it won\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie seriously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99d like that. I know you would. I\xe2\x80\x99ve seen you dancing around here\r\nand giving imitations and that\xe2\x80\x99s why I asked you. You\xe2\x80\x99re clever enough,\r\nall right.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I\xe2\x80\x99m not,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie shyly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you what you do. You go down and see about it. It\xe2\x80\x99ll be\r\nfun for you. The rest of the company isn\xe2\x80\x99t going to be any good. They\r\nhaven\xe2\x80\x99t any experience. What do they know about theatricals?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe frowned as he thought of their ignorance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHand me the coffee,\xe2\x80\x9d he added.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t believe I could act, Charlie,\xe2\x80\x9d Carrie went on pettishly. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t think I could, do you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSure. Out o\xe2\x80\x99 sight. I bet you make a hit. Now you want to go, I know\r\nyou do. I knew it when I came home. That\xe2\x80\x99s why I asked you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is the play, did you say?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Under the Gaslight.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat part would they want me to take?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, one of the heroines\xe2\x80\x94I don\xe2\x80\x99t know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat sort of a play is it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet, whose memory for such things was not the best,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99s about a girl who gets kidnapped by a couple of crooks\xe2\x80\x94a man and a\r\nwoman that live in the slums. She had some money or something and they\r\nwanted to get it. I don\xe2\x80\x99t know now how it did go exactly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t you know what part I would have to take?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I don\xe2\x80\x99t, to tell the truth.\xe2\x80\x9d He thought a moment. \xe2\x80\x9cYes, I do, too.\r\nLaura, that\xe2\x80\x99s the thing\xe2\x80\x94you\xe2\x80\x99re to be Laura.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you can\xe2\x80\x99t remember what the part is like?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo save me, Cad, I can\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered. \xe2\x80\x9cI ought to, too; I\xe2\x80\x99ve seen\r\nthe play enough. There\xe2\x80\x99s a girl in it that was stolen when she was an\r\ninfant\xe2\x80\x94was picked off the street or something\xe2\x80\x94and she\xe2\x80\x99s the one that\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhounded by the two old criminals I was telling you about.\xe2\x80\x9d He stopped\r\nwith a mouthful of pie poised on a fork before his face. \xe2\x80\x9cShe comes\r\nvery near getting drowned\xe2\x80\x94no, that\xe2\x80\x99s not it. I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you what I\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\ndo,\xe2\x80\x9d he concluded hopelessly, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll get you the book. I can\xe2\x80\x99t remember\r\nnow for the life of me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, when he had concluded, her interest\r\nand desire to shine dramatically struggling with her timidity for the\r\nmastery. \xe2\x80\x9cI might go if you thought I\xe2\x80\x99d do all right.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course, you\xe2\x80\x99ll do,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet, who, in his efforts to enthuse\r\nCarrie, had interested himself. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you think I\xe2\x80\x99d come home here and\r\nurge you to do something that I didn\xe2\x80\x99t think you would make a success\r\nof? You can act all right. It\xe2\x80\x99ll be good for you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen must I go?\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, reflectively.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe first rehearsal is Friday night. I\xe2\x80\x99ll get the part for you\r\nto-night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie resignedly, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll do it, but if I make a\r\nfailure now it\xe2\x80\x99s your fault.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou won\xe2\x80\x99t fail,\xe2\x80\x9d assured Drouet. \xe2\x80\x9cJust act as you do around here. Be\r\nnatural. You\xe2\x80\x99re all right. I\xe2\x80\x99ve often thought you\xe2\x80\x99d make a corking good\r\nactress.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you really?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s right,\xe2\x80\x9d said the drummer.\r\n\r\nHe little knew as he went out of the door that night what a secret\r\nflame he had kindled in the bosom of the girl he left behind. Carrie\r\nwas possessed of that sympathetic, impressionable nature which, ever in\r\nthe most developed form, has been the glory of the drama. She was\r\ncreated with that passivity of soul which is always the mirror of the\r\nactive world. She possessed an innate taste for imitation and no small\r\nability. Even without practice, she could sometimes restore dramatic\r\nsituations she had witnessed by re-creating, before her mirror, the\r\nexpressions of the various faces taking part in the scene. She loved to\r\nmodulate her voice after the conventional manner of the distressed\r\nheroine, and repeat such pathetic fragments as appealed most to her\r\nsympathies. Of late, seeing the airy grace of the _ingenue_ in several\r\nwell-constructed plays, she had been moved to secretly imitate it, and\r\nmany were the little movements and expressions of the body in which she\r\nindulged from time to time in the privacy of her chamber. On several\r\noccasions, when Drouet had caught her admiring herself, as he imagined,\r\nin the mirror, she was doing nothing more than recalling some little\r\ngrace of the mouth or the eyes which she had witnessed in another.\r\nUnder his airy accusation she mistook this for vanity and accepted the\r\nblame with a faint sense of error, though, as a matter of fact, it was\r\nnothing more than the first subtle outcroppings of an artistic nature,\r\nendeavouring to re-create the perfect likeness of some phase of beauty\r\nwhich appealed to her. In such feeble tendencies, be it known, such\r\noutworking of desire to reproduce life, lies the basis of all dramatic\r\nart.\r\n\r\nNow, when Carrie heard Drouet\xe2\x80\x99s laudatory opinion of her dramatic\r\nability, her body tingled with satisfaction. Like the flame which welds\r\nthe loosened particles into a solid mass, his words united those\r\nfloating wisps of feeling which she had felt, but never believed,\r\nconcerning her possible ability, and made them into a gaudy shred of\r\nhope. Like all human beings, she had a touch of vanity. She felt that\r\nshe could do things if she only had a chance. How often had she looked\r\nat the well-dressed actresses on the stage and wondered how she would\r\nlook, how delightful she would feel if only she were in their place.\r\nThe glamour, the tense situation, the fine clothes, the applause, these\r\nhad lured her until she felt that she, too, could act\xe2\x80\x94that she, too,\r\ncould compel acknowledgment of power. Now she was told that she really\r\ncould\xe2\x80\x94that little things she had done about the house had made even him\r\nfeel her power. It was a delightful sensation while it lasted.\r\n\r\nWhen Drouet was gone, she sat down in her rocking-chair by the window\r\nto think about it. As usual, imagination exaggerated the possibilities\r\nfor her. It was as if he had put fifty cents in her hand and she had\r\nexercised the thoughts of a thousand dollars. She saw herself in a\r\nscore of pathetic situations in which she assumed a tremulous voice and\r\nsuffering manner. Her mind delighted itself with scenes of luxury and\r\nrefinement, situations in which she was the cynosure of all eyes, the\r\narbiter of all fates. As she rocked to and fro she felt the tensity of\r\nwoe in abandonment, the magnificence of wrath after deception, the\r\nlanguour of sorrow after defeat. Thoughts of all the charming women she\r\nhad seen in plays\xe2\x80\x94every fancy, every illusion which she had concerning\r\nthe stage\xe2\x80\x94now came back as a returning tide after the ebb. She built up\r\nfeelings and a determination which the occasion did not warrant.\r\n\r\nDrouet dropped in at the lodge when he went down town, and swashed\r\naround with a great _air_, as Quincel met him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere is that young lady you were going to get for us?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the\r\nlatter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve got her,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you?\xe2\x80\x9d said Quincel, rather surprised by his promptness; \xe2\x80\x9cthat\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ngood. What\xe2\x80\x99s her address?\xe2\x80\x9d and he pulled out his notebook in order to\r\nbe able to send her part to her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou want to send her her part?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the drummer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I\xe2\x80\x99ll take it. I\xe2\x80\x99m going right by her house in the morning.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat did you say her address was? We only want it in case we have any\r\ninformation to send her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTwenty-nine Ogden Place.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd her name?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCarrie Madenda,\xe2\x80\x9d said the drummer, firing at random. The lodge members\r\nknew him to be single.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat sounds like somebody that can act, doesn\xe2\x80\x99t it?\xe2\x80\x9d said Quincel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, it does.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe took the part home to Carrie and handed it to her with the manner of\r\none who does a favour.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe says that\xe2\x80\x99s the best part. Do you think you can do it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know until I look it over. You know I\xe2\x80\x99m afraid, now that I\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\nsaid I would.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, go on. What have you got to be afraid of? It\xe2\x80\x99s a cheap company.\r\nThe rest of them aren\xe2\x80\x99t as good as you are.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I\xe2\x80\x99ll see,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, pleased to have the part, for all her\r\nmisgivings.\r\n\r\nHe sidled around, dressing and fidgeting before he arranged to make his\r\nnext remark.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey were getting ready to print the programmes,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cand I gave\r\nthem the name of Carrie Madenda. Was that all right?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I guess so,\xe2\x80\x9d said his companion, looking up at him. She was\r\nthinking it was slightly strange.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you didn\xe2\x80\x99t make a hit, you know,\xe2\x80\x9d he went on.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered, rather pleased now with his caution. It was\r\nclever for Drouet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI didn\xe2\x80\x99t want to introduce you as my wife, because you\xe2\x80\x99d feel worse\r\nthen if you didn\xe2\x80\x99t _go_. They all know me so well. But you\xe2\x80\x99ll _go_ all\r\nright. Anyhow, you\xe2\x80\x99ll probably never meet any of them again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I don\xe2\x80\x99t care,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie desperately. She was determined now to\r\nhave a try at the fascinating game.\r\n\r\nDrouet breathed a sigh of relief. He had been afraid that he was about\r\nto precipitate another conversation upon the marriage question.\r\n\r\nThe part of Laura, as Carrie found out when she began to examine it,\r\nwas one of suffering and tears. As delineated by Mr. Daly, it was true\r\nto the most sacred traditions of melodrama as he found it when he began\r\nhis career. The sorrowful demeanour, the tremolo music, the long,\r\nexplanatory, cumulative addresses, all were there.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor fellow,\xe2\x80\x9d read Carrie, consulting the text and drawing her voice\r\nout pathetically. \xe2\x80\x9cMartin, be sure and give him a glass of wine before\r\nhe goes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe was surprised at the briefness of the entire part, not knowing that\r\nshe must be on the stage while others were talking, and not only be\r\nthere, but also keep herself in harmony with the dramatic movement of\r\nthe scenes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think I can do that, though,\xe2\x80\x9d she concluded.\r\n\r\nWhen Drouet came the next night, she was very much satisfied with her\r\nday\xe2\x80\x99s study.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, how goes it, Caddie?\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right,\xe2\x80\x9d she laughed. \xe2\x80\x9cI think I have it memorised nearly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s good,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cLet\xe2\x80\x99s hear some of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know whether I can get up and say it off here,\xe2\x80\x9d she said\r\nbashfully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know why you shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t. It\xe2\x80\x99ll be easier here than it\r\nwill there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know about that,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered. Eventually she took off the\r\nballroom episode with considerable feeling, forgetting, as she got\r\ndeeper in the scene, all about Drouet, and letting herself rise to a\r\nfine state of feeling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet; \xe2\x80\x9cfine, out o\xe2\x80\x99 sight! You\xe2\x80\x99re all right Caddie, I\r\ntell you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe was really moved by her excellent representation and the general\r\nappearance of the pathetic little figure as it swayed and finally\r\nfainted to the floor. He had bounded up to catch her, and now held her\r\nlaughing in his arms.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAin\xe2\x80\x99t you afraid you\xe2\x80\x99ll hurt yourself?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot a bit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you\xe2\x80\x99re a wonder. Say, I never knew you could do anything like\r\nthat.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI never did, either,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie merrily, her face flushed with\r\ndelight.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you can bet that you\xe2\x80\x99re all right,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet. \xe2\x80\x9cYou can take\r\nmy word for that. You won\xe2\x80\x99t fail.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XVII. A GLIMPSE THROUGH THE GATEWAY: HOPE LIGHTENS THE EYE\r\n\r\nThe, to Carrie, very important theatrical performance was to take place\r\nat the Avery on conditions which were to make it more noteworthy than\r\nwas at first anticipated. The little dramatic student had written to\r\nHurstwood the very morning her part was brought her that she was going\r\nto take part in a play.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI really am,\xe2\x80\x9d she wrote, feeling that he might take it as a jest; \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nhave my part now, honest, truly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHurstwood smiled in an indulgent way as he read this.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wonder what it is going to be? I must see that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe answered at once, making a pleasant reference to her ability. \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nhaven\xe2\x80\x99t the slightest doubt you will make a success. You must come to\r\nthe park to-morrow morning and tell me all about it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie gladly complied, and revealed all the details of the undertaking\r\nas she understood it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cthat\xe2\x80\x99s fine. I\xe2\x80\x99m glad to hear it. Of course, you will\r\ndo well, you\xe2\x80\x99re so clever.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe had truly never seen so much spirit in the girl before. Her tendency\r\nto discover a touch of sadness had for the nonce disappeared. As she\r\nspoke her eyes were bright, her cheeks red. She radiated much of the\r\npleasure which her undertakings gave her. For all her misgivings\xe2\x80\x94and\r\nthey were as plentiful as the moments of the day\xe2\x80\x94she was still happy.\r\nShe could not repress her delight in doing this little thing which, to\r\nan ordinary observer, had no importance at all.\r\n\r\nHurstwood was charmed by the development of the fact that the girl had\r\ncapabilities. There is nothing so inspiring in life as the sight of a\r\nlegitimate ambition, no matter how incipient. It gives colour, force,\r\nand beauty to the possessor.\r\n\r\nCarrie was now lightened by a touch of this divine afflatus. She drew\r\nto herself commendation from her two admirers which she had not earned.\r\nTheir affection for her naturally heightened their perception of what\r\nshe was trying to do and their approval of what she did. Her\r\ninexperience conserved her own exuberant fancy, which ran riot with\r\nevery straw of opportunity, making of it a golden divining rod whereby\r\nthe treasure of life was to be discovered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet\xe2\x80\x99s see,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood, \xe2\x80\x9cI ought to know some of the boys in the\r\nlodge. I\xe2\x80\x99m an Elk myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, you mustn\xe2\x80\x99t let him know I told you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s so,\xe2\x80\x9d said the manager.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d like for you to be there, if you want to come, but I don\xe2\x80\x99t see how\r\nyou can unless he asks you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll be there,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood affectionately. \xe2\x80\x9cI can fix it so he\r\nwon\xe2\x80\x99t know you told me. You leave it to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis interest of the manager was a large thing in itself for the\r\nperformance, for his standing among the Elks was something worth\r\ntalking about. Already he was thinking of a box with some friends, and\r\nflowers for Carrie. He would make it a dress-suit affair and give the\r\nlittle girl a chance.\r\n\r\nWithin a day or two, Drouet dropped into the Adams Street resort, and\r\nhe was at once spied by Hurstwood. It was at five in the afternoon and\r\nthe place was crowded with merchants, actors, managers, politicians, a\r\ngoodly company of rotund, rosy figures, silk-hatted, starchy-bosomed,\r\nberinged and bescarfpinned to the queen\xe2\x80\x99s taste. John L. Sullivan, the\r\npugilist, was at one end of the glittering bar, surrounded by a company\r\nof loudly dressed sports, who were holding a most animated\r\nconversation. Drouet came across the floor with a festive stride, a new\r\npair of tan shoes squeaking audibly at his progress.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood, \xe2\x80\x9cI was wondering what had become of you. I\r\nthought you had gone out of town again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDrouet laughed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you don\xe2\x80\x99t report more regularly we\xe2\x80\x99ll have to cut you off the\r\nlist.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCouldn\xe2\x80\x99t help it,\xe2\x80\x9d said the drummer, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve been busy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey strolled over toward the bar amid the noisy, shifting company of\r\nnotables. The dressy manager was shaken by the hand three times in as\r\nmany minutes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hear your lodge is going to give a performance,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Hurstwood,\r\nin the most offhand manner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, who told you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo one,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood. \xe2\x80\x9cThey just sent me a couple of tickets, which\r\nI can have for two dollars. Is it going to be any good?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the drummer. \xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99ve been trying to get me to\r\nget some woman to take a part.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wasn\xe2\x80\x99t intending to go,\xe2\x80\x9d said the manager easily. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll subscribe,\r\nof course. How are things over there?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right. They\xe2\x80\x99re going to fit things up out of the proceeds.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said the manager, \xe2\x80\x9cI hope they make a success of it. Have\r\nanother?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe did not intend to say any more. Now, if he should appear on the\r\nscene with a few friends, he could say that he had been urged to come\r\nalong. Drouet had a desire to wipe out the possibility of confusion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think the girl is going to take a part in it,\xe2\x80\x9d he said abruptly,\r\nafter thinking it over.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t say so! How did that happen?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, they were short and wanted me to find them some one. I told\r\nCarrie, and she seems to want to try.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood for her,\xe2\x80\x9d said the manager. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99ll be a real nice affair. Do her\r\ngood, too. Has she ever had any experience?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot a bit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, well, it isn\xe2\x80\x99t anything very serious.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe\xe2\x80\x99s clever, though,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet, casting off any imputation against\r\nCarrie\xe2\x80\x99s ability. \xe2\x80\x9cShe picks up her part quick enough.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t say so!\xe2\x80\x9d said the manager.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir; she surprised me the other night. By George, if she didn\xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe must give her a nice little send-off,\xe2\x80\x9d said the manager. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll look\r\nafter the flowers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDrouet smiled at his good-nature.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAfter the show you must come with me and we\xe2\x80\x99ll have a little supper.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think she\xe2\x80\x99ll do all right,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI want to see her. She\xe2\x80\x99s got to do all right. We\xe2\x80\x99ll make her,\xe2\x80\x9d and the\r\nmanager gave one of his quick, steely half-smiles, which was a compound\r\nof good-nature and shrewdness.\r\n\r\nCarrie, meanwhile, attended the first rehearsal. At this performance\r\nMr. Quincel presided, aided by Mr. Millice, a young man who had some\r\nqualifications of past experience, which were not exactly understood by\r\nany one. He was so experienced and so business-like, however, that he\r\ncame very near being rude\xe2\x80\x94failing to remember, as he did, that the\r\nindividuals he was trying to instruct were volunteer players and not\r\nsalaried underlings.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, Miss Madenda,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, addressing Carrie, who stood in one part\r\nuncertain as to what move to make, \xe2\x80\x9cyou don\xe2\x80\x99t want to stand like that.\r\nPut expression in your face. Remember, you are troubled over the\r\nintrusion of the stranger. Walk so,\xe2\x80\x9d and he struck out across the Avery\r\nstage in almost drooping manner.\r\n\r\nCarrie did not exactly fancy the suggestion, but the novelty of the\r\nsituation, the presence of strangers, all more or less nervous, and the\r\ndesire to do anything rather than make a failure, made her timid. She\r\nwalked in imitation of her mentor as requested, inwardly feeling that\r\nthere was something strangely lacking.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, Mrs. Morgan,\xe2\x80\x9d said the director to one young married woman who\r\nwas to take the part of Pearl, \xe2\x80\x9cyou sit here. Now, Mr. Bamberger, you\r\nstand here, so. Now, what is it you say?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExplain,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Bamberger feebly. He had the part of Ray, Laura\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nlover, the society individual who was to waver in his thoughts of\r\nmarrying her, upon finding that she was a waif and a nobody by birth.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow is that\xe2\x80\x94what does your text say?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExplain,\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Mr. Bamberger, looking intently at his part.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, but it also says,\xe2\x80\x9d the director remarked, \xe2\x80\x9cthat you are to look\r\nshocked. Now, say it again, and see if you can\xe2\x80\x99t look shocked.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExplain!\xe2\x80\x9d demanded Mr. Bamberger vigorously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no, that won\xe2\x80\x99t do! Say it this way\xe2\x80\x94_explain_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExplain,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Bamberger, giving a modified imitation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s better. Now go on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne night,\xe2\x80\x9d resumed Mrs. Morgan, whose lines came next, \xe2\x80\x9cfather and\r\nmother were going to the opera. When they were crossing Broadway, the\r\nusual crowd of children accosted them for alms\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHold on,\xe2\x80\x9d said the director, rushing forward, his arm extended. \xe2\x80\x9cPut\r\nmore feeling into what you are saying.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Morgan looked at him as if she feared a personal assault. Her eye\r\nlightened with resentment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRemember, Mrs. Morgan,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, ignoring the gleam, but modifying\r\nhis manner, \xe2\x80\x9cthat you\xe2\x80\x99re detailing a pathetic story. You are now\r\nsupposed to be telling something that is a grief to you. It requires\r\nfeeling, repression, thus: \xe2\x80\x98The usual crowd of children accosted them\r\nfor alms.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Morgan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, go on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs mother felt in her pocket for some change, her fingers touched a\r\ncold and trembling hand which had clutched her purse.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery good,\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted the director, nodding his head significantly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA pickpocket! Well!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Mr. Bamberger, speaking the lines that\r\nhere fell to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no, Mr. Bamberger,\xe2\x80\x9d said the director, approaching, \xe2\x80\x9cnot that way.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A pickpocket\xe2\x80\x94well?\xe2\x80\x99 so. That\xe2\x80\x99s the idea.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t you think,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie weakly, noticing that it had not been\r\nproved yet whether the members of the company knew their lines, let\r\nalone the details of expression, \xe2\x80\x9cthat it would be better if we just\r\nwent through our lines once to see if we know them? We might pick up\r\nsome points.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA very good idea, Miss Madenda,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Quincel, who sat at the side\r\nof the stage, looking serenely on and volunteering opinions which the\r\ndirector did not heed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right,\xe2\x80\x9d said the latter, somewhat abashed, \xe2\x80\x9cit might be well to do\r\nit.\xe2\x80\x9d Then brightening, with a show of authority, \xe2\x80\x9cSuppose we run right\r\nthrough, putting in as much expression as we can.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Quincel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis hand,\xe2\x80\x9d resumed Mrs. Morgan, glancing up at Mr. Bamberger and down\r\nat her book, as the lines proceeded, \xe2\x80\x9cmy mother grasped in her own, and\r\nso tight that a small, feeble voice uttered an exclamation of pain.\r\nMother looked down, and there beside her was a little ragged girl.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery good,\xe2\x80\x9d observed the director, now hopelessly idle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe thief!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Mr. Bamberger.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLouder,\xe2\x80\x9d put in the director, finding it almost impossible to keep his\r\nhands off.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe thief!\xe2\x80\x9d roared poor Bamberger.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, but a thief hardly six years old, with a face like an angel\xe2\x80\x99s.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Stop,\xe2\x80\x99 said my mother. \xe2\x80\x98What are you doing?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Trying to steal,\xe2\x80\x99 said the child.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t you know that it is wicked to do so?\xe2\x80\x99 asked my father.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98No,\xe2\x80\x99 said the girl, \xe2\x80\x98but it is dreadful to be hungry.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Who told you to steal?\xe2\x80\x99 asked my mother.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98She\xe2\x80\x94there,\xe2\x80\x99 said the child, pointing to a squalid woman in a doorway\r\nopposite, who fled suddenly down the street. \xe2\x80\x98That is old Judas,\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nthe girl.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Morgan read this rather flatly, and the director was in despair.\r\nHe fidgeted around, and then went over to Mr. Quincel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you think of them?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I guess we\xe2\x80\x99ll be able to whip them into shape,\xe2\x80\x9d said the latter,\r\nwith an air of strength under difficulties.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d said the director. \xe2\x80\x9cThat fellow Bamberger strikes me as\r\nbeing a pretty poor shift for a lover.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s all we\xe2\x80\x99ve got,\xe2\x80\x9d said Quincel, rolling up his eyes. \xe2\x80\x9cHarrison went\r\nback on me at the last minute. Who else can we get?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d said the director. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m afraid he\xe2\x80\x99ll never pick up.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this moment Bamberger was exclaiming, \xe2\x80\x9cPearl, you are joking with\r\nme.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLook at that now,\xe2\x80\x9d said the director, whispering behind his hand. \xe2\x80\x9cMy\r\nLord! what can you do with a man who drawls out a sentence like that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo the best you can,\xe2\x80\x9d said Quincel consolingly.\r\n\r\nThe rendition ran on in this wise until it came to where Carrie, as\r\nLaura, comes into the room to explain to Ray, who, after hearing\r\nPearl\xe2\x80\x99s statement about her birth, had written the letter repudiating\r\nher, which, however, he did not deliver. Bamberger was just concluding\r\nthe words of Ray, \xe2\x80\x9cI must go before she returns. Her step! Too late,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nand was cramming the letter in his pocket, when she began sweetly with:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRay!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMiss\xe2\x80\x94Miss Courtland,\xe2\x80\x9d Bamberger faltered weakly.\r\n\r\nCarrie looked at him a moment and forgot all about the company present.\r\nShe began to feel the part, and summoned an indifferent smile to her\r\nlips, turning as the lines directed and going to a window, as if he\r\nwere not present. She did it with a grace which was fascinating to look\r\nupon.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho is that woman?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the director, watching Carrie in her little\r\nscene with Bamberger.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMiss Madenda,\xe2\x80\x9d said Quincel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know her name,\xe2\x80\x9d said the director, \xe2\x80\x9cbut what does she do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d said Quincel. \xe2\x80\x9cShe\xe2\x80\x99s a friend of one of our members.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, she\xe2\x80\x99s got more gumption than any one I\xe2\x80\x99ve seen here so far\xe2\x80\x94seems\r\nto take an interest in what she\xe2\x80\x99s doing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPretty, too, isn\xe2\x80\x99t she?\xe2\x80\x9d said Quincel.\r\n\r\nThe director strolled away without answering.\r\n\r\nIn the second scene, where she was supposed to face the company in the\r\nball-room, she did even better, winning the smile of the director, who\r\nvolunteered, because of her fascination for him, to come over and speak\r\nwith her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWere you ever on the stage?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked insinuatingly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou do so well, I thought you might have had some experience.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie only smiled consciously.\r\n\r\nHe walked away to listen to Bamberger, who was feebly spouting some\r\nardent line.\r\n\r\nMrs. Morgan saw the drift of things and gleamed at Carrie with envious\r\nand snapping black eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe\xe2\x80\x99s some cheap professional,\xe2\x80\x9d she gave herself the satisfaction of\r\nthinking, and scorned and hated her accordingly.\r\n\r\nThe rehearsal ended for one day, and Carrie went home feeling that she\r\nhad acquitted herself satisfactorily. The words of the director were\r\nringing in her ears, and she longed for an opportunity to tell\r\nHurstwood. She wanted him to know just how well she was doing. Drouet,\r\ntoo, was an object for her confidences. She could hardly wait until he\r\nshould ask her, and yet she did not have the vanity to bring it up. The\r\ndrummer, however, had another line of thought to-night, and her little\r\nexperience did not appeal to him as important. He let the conversation\r\ndrop, save for what she chose to recite without solicitation, and\r\nCarrie was not good at that. He took it for granted that she was doing\r\nvery well and he was relieved of further worry. Consequently he threw\r\nCarrie into repression, which was irritating. She felt his indifference\r\nkeenly and longed to see Hurstwood. It was as if he were now the only\r\nfriend she had on earth. The next morning Drouet was interested again,\r\nbut the damage had been done.\r\n\r\nShe got a pretty letter from the manager, saying that by the time she\r\ngot it he would be waiting for her in the park. When she came, he shone\r\nupon her as the morning sun.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, my dear,\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, \xe2\x80\x9chow did you come out?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell enough,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, still somewhat reduced after Drouet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, tell me just what you did. Was it pleasant?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie related the incidents of the rehearsal, warming up as she\r\nproceeded.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, that\xe2\x80\x99s delightful,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m so glad. I must get\r\nover there to see you. When is the next rehearsal?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTuesday,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, \xe2\x80\x9cbut they don\xe2\x80\x99t allow visitors.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI imagine I could get in,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood significantly.\r\n\r\nShe was completely restored and delighted by his consideration, but she\r\nmade him promise not to come around.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, you must do your best to please me,\xe2\x80\x9d he said encouragingly. \xe2\x80\x9cJust\r\nremember that I want you to succeed. We will make the performance worth\r\nwhile. You do that now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll try,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, brimming with affection and enthusiasm.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s the girl,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood fondly. \xe2\x80\x9cNow, remember,\xe2\x80\x9d shaking an\r\naffectionate finger at her, \xe2\x80\x9cyour best.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered, looking back.\r\n\r\nThe whole earth was brimming sunshine that morning. She tripped along,\r\nthe clear sky pouring liquid blue into her soul. Oh, blessed are the\r\nchildren of endeavour in this, that they try and are hopeful. And\r\nblessed also are they who, knowing, smile and approve.\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XVIII. JUST OVER THE BORDER: A HAIL AND FAREWELL\r\n\r\nBy the evening of the 16th the subtle hand of Hurstwood had made itself\r\napparent. He had given the word among his friends\xe2\x80\x94and they were many\r\nand influential\xe2\x80\x94that here was something which they ought to attend,\r\nand, as a consequence, the sale of tickets by Mr. Quincel, acting for\r\nthe lodge, had been large. Small four-line notes had appeared in all of\r\nthe daily newspapers. These he had arranged for by the aid of one of\r\nhis newspaper friends on the \xe2\x80\x9cTimes,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Harry McGarren, the managing\r\neditor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSay, Harry,\xe2\x80\x9d Hurstwood said to him one evening, as the latter stood at\r\nthe bar drinking before wending his belated way homeward, \xe2\x80\x9cyou can help\r\nthe boys out, I guess.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it?\xe2\x80\x9d said McGarren, pleased to be consulted by the opulent\r\nmanager.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Custer Lodge is getting up a little entertainment for their own\r\ngood, and they\xe2\x80\x99d like a little newspaper notice. You know what I mean\xe2\x80\x94a\r\nsquib or two saying that it\xe2\x80\x99s going to take place.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly,\xe2\x80\x9d said McGarren, \xe2\x80\x9cI can fix that for you, George.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt the same time Hurstwood kept himself wholly in the background. The\r\nmembers of Custer Lodge could scarcely understand why their little\r\naffair was taking so well. Mr. Harry Quincel was looked upon as quite a\r\nstar for this sort of work.\r\n\r\nBy the time the 16th had arrived Hurstwood\xe2\x80\x99s friends had rallied like\r\nRomans to a senator\xe2\x80\x99s call. A well-dressed, good-natured,\r\nflatteringly-inclined audience was assured from the moment he thought\r\nof assisting Carrie.\r\n\r\nThat little student had mastered her part to her own satisfaction, much\r\nas she trembled for her fate when she should once face the gathered\r\nthrong, behind the glare of the footlights. She tried to console\r\nherself with the thought that a score of other persons, men and women,\r\nwere equally tremulous concerning the outcome of their efforts, but she\r\ncould not disassociate the general danger from her own individual\r\nliability. She feared that she would forget her lines, that she might\r\nbe unable to master the feeling which she now felt concerning her own\r\nmovements in the play. At times she wished that she had never gone into\r\nthe affair; at others, she trembled lest she should be paralysed with\r\nfear and stand white and gasping, not knowing what to say and spoiling\r\nthe entire performance.\r\n\r\nIn the matter of the company, Mr. Bamberger had disappeared. That\r\nhopeless example had fallen under the lance of the director\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncriticism. Mrs. Morgan was still present, but envious and determined,\r\nif for nothing more than spite, to do as well as Carrie at least. A\r\nloafing professional had been called in to assume the role of Ray, and,\r\nwhile he was a poor stick of his kind, he was not troubled by any of\r\nthose qualms which attack the spirit of those who have never faced an\r\naudience. He swashed about (cautioned though he was to maintain silence\r\nconcerning his past theatrical relationships) in such a self-confident\r\nmanner that he was like to convince every one of his identity by mere\r\nmatter of circumstantial evidence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is so easy,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to Mrs. Morgan, in the usual affected stage\r\nvoice. \xe2\x80\x9cAn audience would be the last thing to trouble me. It\xe2\x80\x99s the\r\nspirit of the part, you know, that is difficult.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie disliked his appearance, but she was too much the actress not to\r\nswallow his qualities with complaisance, seeing that she must suffer\r\nhis fictitious love for the evening.\r\n\r\nAt six she was ready to go. Theatrical paraphernalia had been provided\r\nover and above her care. She had practised her make-up in the morning,\r\nhad rehearsed and arranged her material for the evening by one o\xe2\x80\x99clock,\r\nand had gone home to have a final look at her part, waiting for the\r\nevening to come.\r\n\r\nOn this occasion the lodge sent a carriage. Drouet rode with her as far\r\nas the door, and then went about the neighbouring stores, looking for\r\nsome good cigars. The little actress marched nervously into her\r\ndressing-room and began that painfully anticipated matter of make-up\r\nwhich was to transform her, a simple maiden, to Laura, The Belle of\r\nSociety.\r\n\r\nThe flare of the gas-jets, the open trunks, suggestive of travel and\r\ndisplay, the scattered contents of the make-up box\xe2\x80\x94rouge, pearl powder,\r\nwhiting, burnt cork, India ink, pencils for the eye-lids, wigs,\r\nscissors, looking-glasses, drapery\xe2\x80\x94in short, all the nameless\r\nparaphernalia of disguise, have a remarkable atmosphere of their own.\r\nSince her arrival in the city many things had influenced her, but\r\nalways in a far-removed manner. This new atmosphere was more friendly.\r\nIt was wholly unlike the great brilliant mansions which waved her\r\ncoldly away, permitting her only awe and distant wonder. This took her\r\nby the hand kindly, as one who says, \xe2\x80\x9cMy dear, come in.\xe2\x80\x9d It opened for\r\nher as if for its own. She had wondered at the greatness of the names\r\nupon the bill-boards, the marvel of the long notices in the papers, the\r\nbeauty of the dresses upon the stage, the atmosphere of carriages,\r\nflowers, refinement. Here was no illusion. Here was an open door to see\r\nall of that. She had come upon it as one who stumbles upon a secret\r\npassage and, behold, she was in the chamber of diamonds and delight!\r\n\r\nAs she dressed with a flutter, in her little stage room, hearing the\r\nvoices outside, seeing Mr. Quincel hurrying here and there, noting Mrs.\r\nMorgan and Mrs. Hoagland at their nervous work of preparation, seeing\r\nall the twenty members of the cast moving about and worrying over what\r\nthe result would be, she could not help thinking what a delight this\r\nwould be if it would endure; how perfect a state, if she could only do\r\nwell now, and then some time get a place as a real actress. The thought\r\nhad taken a mighty hold upon her. It hummed in her ears as the melody\r\nof an old song.\r\n\r\nOutside in the little lobby another scene was being enacted. Without\r\nthe interest of Hurstwood, the little hall would probably have been\r\ncomfortably filled, for the members of the lodge were moderately\r\ninterested in its welfare. Hurstwood\xe2\x80\x99s word, however, had gone the\r\nrounds. It was to be a full-dress affair. The four boxes had been\r\ntaken. Dr. Norman McNeill Hale and his wife were to occupy one. This\r\nwas quite a card. C. R. Walker, dry-goods merchant and possessor of at\r\nleast two hundred thousand dollars, had taken another; a well-known\r\ncoal merchant had been induced to take the third, and Hurstwood and his\r\nfriends the fourth. Among the latter was Drouet. The people who were\r\nnow pouring here were not celebrities, nor even local notabilities, in\r\na general sense. They were the lights of a certain circle\xe2\x80\x94the circle of\r\nsmall fortunes and secret order distinctions. These gentlemen Elks knew\r\nthe standing of one another. They had regard for the ability which\r\ncould amass a small fortune, own a nice home, keep a barouche or\r\ncarriage, perhaps, wear fine clothes, and maintain a good mercantile\r\nposition. Naturally, Hurstwood, who was a little above the order of\r\nmind which accepted this standard as perfect, who had shrewdness and\r\nmuch assumption of dignity, who held an imposing and authoritative\r\nposition, and commanded friendship by intuitive tact in handling\r\npeople, was quite a figure. He was more generally known than most\r\nothers in the same circle, and was looked upon as some one whose\r\nreserve covered a mine of influence and solid financial prosperity.\r\n\r\nTo-night he was in his element. He came with several friends directly\r\nfrom Rector\xe2\x80\x99s in a carriage. In the lobby he met Drouet, who was just\r\nreturning from a trip for more cigars. All five now joined in an\r\nanimated conversation concerning the company present and the general\r\ndrift of lodge affairs.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho\xe2\x80\x99s here?\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood, passing into the theatre proper, where\r\nthe lights were turned up and a company of gentlemen were laughing and\r\ntalking in the open space back of the seats.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, how do you do, Mr. Hurstwood?\xe2\x80\x9d came from the first individual\r\nrecognised.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGlad to see you,\xe2\x80\x9d said the latter, grasping his hand lightly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLooks quite an affair, doesn\xe2\x80\x99t it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, indeed,\xe2\x80\x9d said the manager.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCuster seems to have the backing of its members,\xe2\x80\x9d observed the friend.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo it should,\xe2\x80\x9d said the knowing manager. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m glad to see it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, George,\xe2\x80\x9d said another rotund citizen, whose avoirdupois made\r\nnecessary an almost alarming display of starched shirt bosom, \xe2\x80\x9chow goes\r\nit with you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExcellent,\xe2\x80\x9d said the manager.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat brings you over here? You\xe2\x80\x99re not a member of Custer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood-nature,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the manager. \xe2\x80\x9cLike to see the boys, you know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWife here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe couldn\xe2\x80\x99t come to-night. She\xe2\x80\x99s not well.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSorry to hear it\xe2\x80\x94nothing serious, I hope.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, just feeling a little ill.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI remember Mrs. Hurstwood when she was travelling once with you over\r\nto St. Joe\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d and here the newcomer launched off in a trivial\r\nrecollection, which was terminated by the arrival of more friends.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, George, how are you?\xe2\x80\x9d said another genial West Side politician\r\nand lodge member. \xe2\x80\x9cMy, but I\xe2\x80\x99m glad to see you again; how are things,\r\nanyhow?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well; I see you got that nomination for alderman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, we whipped them out over there without much trouble.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you suppose Hennessy will do now?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, he\xe2\x80\x99ll go back to his brick business. He has a brick-yard, you\r\nknow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI didn\xe2\x80\x99t know that,\xe2\x80\x9d said the manager. \xe2\x80\x9cFelt pretty sore, I suppose,\r\nover his defeat.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps,\xe2\x80\x9d said the other, winking shrewdly.\r\n\r\nSome of the more favoured of his friends whom he had invited began to\r\nroll up in carriages now. They came shuffling in with a great show of\r\nfinery and much evident feeling of content and importance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere we are,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood, turning to one from a group with whom he\r\nwas talking.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s right,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the newcomer, a gentleman of about forty-five.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd say,\xe2\x80\x9d he whispered, jovially, pulling Hurstwood over by the\r\nshoulder so that he might whisper in his ear, \xe2\x80\x9cif this isn\xe2\x80\x99t a good\r\nshow, I\xe2\x80\x99ll punch your head.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou ought to pay for seeing your old friends. Bother the show!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTo another who inquired, \xe2\x80\x9cIs it something really good?\xe2\x80\x9d the manager\r\nreplied:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know. I don\xe2\x80\x99t suppose so.\xe2\x80\x9d Then, lifting his hand graciously,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor the lodge.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLots of boys out, eh?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, look up Shanahan. He was just asking for you a moment ago.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was thus that the little theatre resounded to a babble of successful\r\nvoices, the creak of fine clothes, the commonplace of good-nature, and\r\nall largely because of this man\xe2\x80\x99s bidding. Look at him any time within\r\nthe half hour before the curtain was up, he was a member of an eminent\r\ngroup\xe2\x80\x94a rounded company of five or more whose stout figures, large\r\nwhite bosoms, and shining pins bespoke the character of their success.\r\nThe gentlemen who brought their wives called him out to shake hands.\r\nSeats clicked, ushers bowed while he looked blandly on. He was\r\nevidently a light among them, reflecting in his personality the\r\nambitions of those who greeted him. He was acknowledged, fawned upon,\r\nin a way lionised. Through it all one could see the standing of the\r\nman. It was greatness in a way, small as it was.\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XIX. AN HOUR IN ELFLAND: A CLAMOUR HALF HEARD\r\n\r\nAt last the curtain was ready to go up. All the details of the make-up\r\nhad been completed, and the company settled down as the leader of the\r\nsmall, hired orchestra tapped significantly upon his music rack with\r\nhis baton and began the soft curtain-raising strain. Hurstwood ceased\r\ntalking, and went with Drouet and his friend Sagar Morrison around to\r\nthe box.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, we\xe2\x80\x99ll see how the little girl does,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to Drouet, in a tone\r\nwhich no one else could hear.\r\n\r\nOn the stage, six of the characters had already appeared in the opening\r\nparlour scene. Drouet and Hurstwood saw at a glance that Carrie was not\r\namong them, and went on talking in a whisper. Mrs. Morgan, Mrs.\r\nHoagland, and the actor who had taken Bamberger\xe2\x80\x99s part were\r\nrepresenting the principal r\xc3\xb4les in this scene. The professional, whose\r\nname was Patton, had little to recommend him outside of his assurance,\r\nbut this at the present moment was most palpably needed. Mrs. Morgan,\r\nas Pearl, was stiff with fright. Mrs. Hoagland was husky in the throat.\r\nThe whole company was so weak-kneed that the lines were merely spoken,\r\nand nothing more. It took all the hope and uncritical good-nature of\r\nthe audience to keep from manifesting pity by that unrest which is the\r\nagony of failure.\r\n\r\nHurstwood was perfectly indifferent. He took it for granted that it\r\nwould be worthless. All he cared for was to have it endurable enough to\r\nallow for pretension and congratulation afterward.\r\n\r\nAfter the first rush of fright, however, the players got over the\r\ndanger of collapse. They rambled weakly forward, losing nearly all the\r\nexpression which was intended, and making the thing dull in the\r\nextreme, when Carrie came in.\r\n\r\nOne glance at her, and both Hurstwood and Drouet saw plainly that she\r\nalso was weak-kneed. She came faintly across the stage, saying:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you, sir; we have been looking for you since eight o\xe2\x80\x99clock,\xe2\x80\x9d but\r\nwith so little colour and in such a feeble voice that it was positively\r\npainful.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe\xe2\x80\x99s frightened,\xe2\x80\x9d whispered Drouet to Hurstwood.\r\n\r\nThe manager made no answer.\r\n\r\nShe had a line presently which was supposed to be funny.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, that\xe2\x80\x99s as much as to say that I\xe2\x80\x99m a sort of life pill.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt came out so flat, however, that it was a deathly thing. Drouet\r\nfidgeted. Hurstwood moved his toe the least bit.\r\n\r\nThere was another place in which Laura was to rise and, with a sense of\r\nimpending disaster, say, sadly:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish you hadn\xe2\x80\x99t said that, Pearl. You know the old proverb, \xe2\x80\x98Call a\r\nmaid by a married name.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe lack of feeling in the thing was ridiculous. Carrie did not get it\r\nat all. She seemed to be talking in her sleep. It looked as if she were\r\ncertain to be a wretched failure. She was more hopeless than Mrs.\r\nMorgan, who had recovered somewhat, and was now saying her lines\r\nclearly at least. Drouet looked away from the stage at the audience.\r\nThe latter held out silently, hoping for a general change, of course.\r\nHurstwood fixed his eye on Carrie, as if to hypnotise her into doing\r\nbetter. He was pouring determination of his own in her direction. He\r\nfelt sorry for her.\r\n\r\nIn a few more minutes it fell to her to read the letter sent in by the\r\nstrange villain. The audience had been slightly diverted by a\r\nconversation between the professional actor and a character called\r\nSnorky, impersonated by a short little American, who really developed\r\nsome humour as a half-crazed, one-armed soldier, turned messenger for a\r\nliving. He bawled his lines out with such defiance that, while they\r\nreally did not partake of the humour intended, they were funny. Now he\r\nwas off, however, and it was back to pathos, with Carrie as the chief\r\nfigure. She did not recover. She wandered through the whole scene\r\nbetween herself and the intruding villain, straining the patience of\r\nthe audience, and finally exiting, much to their relief.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe\xe2\x80\x99s too nervous,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet, feeling in the mildness of the remark\r\nthat he was lying for once.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBetter go back and say a word to her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDrouet was glad to do anything for relief. He fairly hustled around to\r\nthe side entrance, and was let in by the friendly door-keeper. Carrie\r\nwas standing in the wings, weakly waiting her next cue, all the snap\r\nand nerve gone out of her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSay, Cad,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, looking at her, \xe2\x80\x9cyou mustn\xe2\x80\x99t be nervous. Wake up.\r\nThose guys out there don\xe2\x80\x99t amount to anything. What are you afraid of?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie. \xe2\x80\x9cI just don\xe2\x80\x99t seem to be able to do it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe was grateful for the drummer\xe2\x80\x99s presence, though. She had found the\r\ncompany so nervous that her own strength had gone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome on,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet. \xe2\x80\x9cBrace up. What are you afraid of? Go on out\r\nthere now, and do the trick. What do you care?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie revived a little under the drummer\xe2\x80\x99s electrical, nervous\r\ncondition.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid I do so very bad?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot a bit. All you need is a little more ginger. Do it as you showed\r\nme. Get that toss of your head you had the other night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie remembered her triumph in the room. She tried to think she could\r\nto it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s next?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, looking at her part, which she had been\r\nstudying.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, the scene between Ray and me when I refuse him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, now you do that lively,\xe2\x80\x9d said the drummer. \xe2\x80\x9cPut in snap, that\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nthe thing. Act as if you didn\xe2\x80\x99t care.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour turn next, Miss Madenda,\xe2\x80\x9d said the prompter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, dear,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you\xe2\x80\x99re a chump for being afraid,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet. \xe2\x80\x9cCome on now,\r\nbrace up. I\xe2\x80\x99ll watch you from right here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill you?\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, now go on. Don\xe2\x80\x99t be afraid.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe prompter signalled her.\r\n\r\nShe started out, weak as ever, but suddenly her nerve partially\r\nreturned. She thought of Drouet looking.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRay,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, gently, using a tone of voice much more calm than when\r\nshe had last appeared. It was the scene which had pleased the director\r\nat the rehearsal.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe\xe2\x80\x99s easier,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Hurstwood to himself.\r\n\r\nShe did not do the part as she had at rehearsal, but she was better.\r\nThe audience was at least not irritated. The improvement of the work of\r\nthe entire company took away direct observation from her. They were\r\nmaking very fair progress, and now it looked as if the play would be\r\npassable, in the less trying parts at least.\r\n\r\nCarrie came off warm and nervous.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, looking at him, \xe2\x80\x9cwas it any better?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I should say so. That\xe2\x80\x99s the way. Put life into it. You did that\r\nabout a thousand per cent. better than you did the other scene. Now go\r\non and fire up. You can do it. Knock \xe2\x80\x99em.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWas it really better?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBetter, I should say so. What comes next?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat ballroom scene.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you can do that all right,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, woman,\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed, \xe2\x80\x9cyou did it for me! Now you go out there\r\nand do it. It\xe2\x80\x99ll be fun for you. Just do as you did in the room. If\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x99ll reel it off that way, I\xe2\x80\x99ll bet you make a hit. Now, what\xe2\x80\x99ll you\r\nbet? You do it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe drummer usually allowed his ardent good-nature to get the better of\r\nhis speech. He really did think that Carrie had acted this particular\r\nscene very well, and he wanted her to repeat it in public. His\r\nenthusiasm was due to the mere spirit of the occasion.\r\n\r\nWhen the time came, he buoyed Carrie up most effectually. He began to\r\nmake her feel as if she had done very well. The old melancholy of\r\ndesire began to come back as he talked at her, and by the time the\r\nsituation rolled around she was running high in feeling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think I can do this.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSure you can. Now you go ahead and see.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOn the stage, Mrs. Van Dam was making her cruel insinuation against\r\nLaura.\r\n\r\nCarrie listened, and caught the infection of something\xe2\x80\x94she did not know\r\nwhat. Her nostrils sniffed thinly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt means,\xe2\x80\x9d the professional actor began, speaking as Ray, \xe2\x80\x9cthat\r\nsociety is a terrible avenger of insult. Have you ever heard of the\r\nSiberian wolves? When one of the pack falls through weakness, the\r\nothers devour him. It is not an elegant comparison, but there is\r\nsomething wolfish in society. Laura has mocked it with a pretence, and\r\nsociety, which is made up of pretence, will bitterly resent the\r\nmockery.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt the sound of her stage name Carrie started. She began to feel the\r\nbitterness of the situation. The feelings of the outcast descended upon\r\nher. She hung at the wing\xe2\x80\x99s edge, wrapt in her own mounting thoughts.\r\nShe hardly heard anything more, save her own rumbling blood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, girls,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Van Dam, solemnly, \xe2\x80\x9clet us look after our\r\nthings. They are no longer safe when such an accomplished thief\r\nenters.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCue,\xe2\x80\x9d said the prompter, close to her side, but she did not hear.\r\nAlready she was moving forward with a steady grace, born of\r\ninspiration. She dawned upon the audience, handsome and proud,\r\nshifting, with the necessity of the situation, to a cold, white,\r\nhelpless object, as the social pack moved away from her scornfully.\r\n\r\nHurstwood blinked his eyes and caught the infection. The radiating\r\nwaves of feeling and sincerity were already breaking against the\r\nfarthest walls of the chamber. The magic of passion, which will yet\r\ndissolve the world, was here at work.\r\n\r\nThere was a drawing, too, of attention, a riveting of feeling,\r\nheretofore wandering.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRay! Ray! Why do you not come back to her?\xe2\x80\x9d was the cry of Pearl.\r\n\r\nEvery eye was fixed on Carrie, still proud and scornful. They moved as\r\nshe moved. Their eyes were with her eyes.\r\n\r\nMrs. Morgan, as Pearl, approached her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us go home,\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Carrie, her voice assuming for the first time a\r\npenetrating quality which it had never known. \xe2\x80\x9cStay with him!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe pointed an almost accusing hand toward her lover. Then, with a\r\npathos which struck home because of its utter simplicity, \xe2\x80\x9cHe shall not\r\nsuffer long.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHurstwood realised that he was seeing something extraordinarily good.\r\nIt was heightened for him by the applause of the audience as the\r\ncurtain descended and the fact that it was Carrie. He thought now that\r\nshe was beautiful. She had done something which was above his sphere.\r\nHe felt a keen delight in realising that she was his.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFine,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, and then, seized by a sudden impulse, arose and went\r\nabout to the stage door.\r\n\r\nWhen he came in upon Carrie she was still with Drouet. His feelings for\r\nher were most exuberant. He was almost swept away by the strength and\r\nfeeling she exhibited. His desire was to pour forth his praise with the\r\nunbounded feelings of a lover, but here was Drouet, whose affection was\r\nalso rapidly reviving. The latter was more fascinated, if anything,\r\nthan Hurstwood. At least, in the nature of things, it took a more ruddy\r\nform.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, well,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet, \xe2\x80\x9cyou did out of sight. That was simply\r\ngreat. I knew you could do it. Oh, but you\xe2\x80\x99re a little daisy!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie\xe2\x80\x99s eyes flamed with the light of achievement.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid I do all right?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you? Well, I guess. Didn\xe2\x80\x99t you hear the applause?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was some faint sound of clapping yet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thought I got it something like\xe2\x80\x94I felt it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nJust then Hurstwood came in. Instinctively he felt the change in\r\nDrouet. He saw that the drummer was near to Carrie, and jealousy leaped\r\nalight in his bosom. In a flash of thought, he reproached himself for\r\nhaving sent him back. Also, he hated him as an intruder. He could\r\nscarcely pull himself down to the level where he would have to\r\ncongratulate Carrie as a friend. Nevertheless, the man mastered\r\nhimself, and it was a triumph. He almost jerked the old subtle light to\r\nhis eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thought,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, looking at Carrie, \xe2\x80\x9cI would come around and tell\r\nyou how well you did, Mrs. Drouet. It was delightful.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie took the cue, and replied:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, thank you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was just telling her,\xe2\x80\x9d put in Drouet, now delighted with his\r\npossession, \xe2\x80\x9cthat I thought she did fine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed you did,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood, turning upon Carrie eyes in which she\r\nread more than the words.\r\n\r\nCarrie laughed luxuriantly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you do as well in the rest of the play, you will make us all think\r\nyou are a born actress.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie smiled again. She felt the acuteness of Hurstwood\xe2\x80\x99s position,\r\nand wished deeply that she could be alone with him, but she did not\r\nunderstand the change in Drouet. Hurstwood found that he could not\r\ntalk, repressed as he was, and grudging Drouet every moment of his\r\npresence, he bowed himself out with the elegance of a Faust. Outside he\r\nset his teeth with envy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDamn it!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cis he always going to be in the way?\xe2\x80\x9d He was moody\r\nwhen he got back to the box, and could not talk for thinking of his\r\nwretched situation.\r\n\r\nAs the curtain for the next act arose, Drouet came back. He was very\r\nmuch enlivened in temper and inclined to whisper, but Hurstwood\r\npretended interest. He fixed his eyes on the stage, although Carrie was\r\nnot there, a short bit of melodramatic comedy preceding her entrance.\r\nHe did not see what was going on, however. He was thinking his own\r\nthoughts, and they were wretched.\r\n\r\nThe progress of the play did not improve matters for him. Carrie, from\r\nnow on, was easily the centre of interest. The audience, which had been\r\ninclined to feel that nothing could be good after the first gloomy\r\nimpression, now went to the other extreme and saw power where it was\r\nnot. The general feeling reacted on Carrie. She presented her part with\r\nsome felicity, though nothing like the intensity which had aroused the\r\nfeeling at the end of the long first act.\r\n\r\nBoth Hurstwood and Drouet viewed her pretty figure with rising\r\nfeelings. The fact that such ability should reveal itself in her, that\r\nthey should see it set forth under such effective circumstances, framed\r\nalmost in massy gold and shone upon by the appropriate lights of\r\nsentiment and personality, heightened her charm for them. She was more\r\nthan the old Carrie to Drouet. He longed to be at home with her until\r\nhe could tell her. He awaited impatiently the end, when they should go\r\nhome alone.\r\n\r\nHurstwood, on the contrary, saw in the strength of her new\r\nattractiveness his miserable predicament. He could have cursed the man\r\nbeside him. By the Lord, he could not even applaud feelingly as he\r\nwould. For once he must simulate when it left a taste in his mouth.\r\n\r\nIt was in the last act that Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s fascination for her lovers assumed\r\nits most effective character.\r\n\r\nHurstwood listened to its progress, wondering when Carrie would come\r\non. He had not long to wait. The author had used the artifice of\r\nsending all the merry company for a drive, and now Carrie came in\r\nalone. It was the first time that Hurstwood had had a chance to see her\r\nfacing the audience quite alone, for nowhere else had she been without\r\na foil of some sort. He suddenly felt, as she entered, that her old\r\nstrength\xe2\x80\x94the power that had grasped him at the end of the first act\xe2\x80\x94had\r\ncome back. She seemed to be gaining feeling, now that the play was\r\ndrawing to a close and the opportunity for great action was passing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor Pearl,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, speaking with natural pathos. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is a sad\r\nthing to want for happiness, but it is a terrible thing to see another\r\ngroping about blindly for it, when it is almost within the grasp.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe was gazing now sadly out upon the open sea, her arm resting\r\nlistlessly upon the polished door-post.\r\n\r\nHurstwood began to feel a deep sympathy for her and for himself. He\r\ncould almost feel that she was talking to him. He was, by a combination\r\nof feelings and entanglements, almost deluded by that quality of voice\r\nand manner which, like a pathetic strain of music, seems ever a\r\npersonal and intimate thing. Pathos has this quality, that it seems\r\never addressed to one alone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd yet, she can be very happy with him,\xe2\x80\x9d went on the little actress.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHer sunny temper, her joyous face will brighten any home.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe turned slowly toward the audience without seeing. There was so much\r\nsimplicity in her movements that she seemed wholly alone. Then she\r\nfound a seat by a table, and turned over some books, devoting a thought\r\nto them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith no longings for what I may not have,\xe2\x80\x9d she breathed in\r\nconclusion\xe2\x80\x94and it was almost a sigh\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cmy existence hidden from all save\r\ntwo in the wide world, and making my joy out of the joy of that\r\ninnocent girl who will soon be his wife.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHurstwood was sorry when a character, known as Peach Blossom,\r\ninterrupted her. He stirred irritably, for he wished her to go on. He\r\nwas charmed by the pale face, the lissome figure, draped in pearl grey,\r\nwith a coiled string of pearls at the throat. Carrie had the air of one\r\nwho was weary and in need of protection, and, under the fascinating\r\nmake-believe of the moment, he rose in feeling until he was ready in\r\nspirit to go to her and ease her out of her misery by adding to his own\r\ndelight.\r\n\r\nIn a moment Carrie was alone again, and was saying, with animation:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI must return to the city, no matter what dangers may lurk here. I\r\nmust go, secretly if I can; openly, if I must.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was a sound of horses\xe2\x80\x99 hoofs outside, and then Ray\xe2\x80\x99s voice\r\nsaying: \xe2\x80\x9cNo, I shall not ride again. Put him up.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe entered, and then began a scene which had as much to do with the\r\ncreation of the tragedy of affection in Hurstwood as anything in his\r\npeculiar and involved career. For Carrie had resolved to make something\r\nof this scene, and, now that the cue had come, it began to take a\r\nfeeling hold upon her. Both Hurstwood and Drouet noted the rising\r\nsentiment as she proceeded.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thought you had gone with Pearl,\xe2\x80\x9d she said to her lover.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI did go part of the way, but I left the party a mile down the road.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou and Pearl had no disagreement?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo\xe2\x80\x94yes; that is, we always have. Our social barometers always stand at\r\n\xe2\x80\x98cloudy\xe2\x80\x99 and \xe2\x80\x98overcast.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd whose fault is that?\xe2\x80\x9d she said, easily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot mine,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered, pettishly. \xe2\x80\x9cI know I do all I can\xe2\x80\x94I say all I\r\ncan\xe2\x80\x94but she\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis was rather awkwardly put by Patton, but Carrie redeemed it with a\r\ngrace which was inspiring.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut she is your wife,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, fixing her whole attention upon the\r\nstilled actor, and softening the quality of her voice until it was\r\nagain low and musical. \xe2\x80\x9cRay, my friend, courtship is the text from\r\nwhich the whole sermon of married life takes its theme. Do not let\r\nyours be discontented and unhappy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe put her two little hands together and pressed them appealingly.\r\n\r\nHurstwood gazed with slightly parted lips.
