Drouet was fidgeting with\r\nsatisfaction.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo be my wife, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d went on the actor in a manner which was weak by\r\ncomparison, but which could not now spoil the tender atmosphere which\r\nCarrie had created and maintained. She did not seem to feel that he was\r\nwretched. She would have done nearly as well with a block of wood. The\r\naccessories she needed were within her own imagination. The acting of\r\nothers could not affect them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you repent already?\xe2\x80\x9d she said, slowly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI lost you,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, seizing her little hand, \xe2\x80\x9cand I was at the mercy\r\nof any flirt who chose to give me an inviting look. It was your\r\nfault\xe2\x80\x94you know it was\xe2\x80\x94why did you leave me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie turned slowly away, and seemed to be mastering some impulse in\r\nsilence. Then she turned back.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRay,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cthe greatest happiness I have ever felt has been the\r\nthought that all your affection was forever bestowed upon a virtuous\r\nwoman, your equal in family, fortune, and accomplishments. What a\r\nrevelation do you make to me now! What is it makes you continually war\r\nwith your happiness?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe last question was asked so simply that it came to the audience and\r\nthe lover as a personal thing.\r\n\r\nAt last it came to the part where the lover exclaimed, \xe2\x80\x9cBe to me as you\r\nused to be.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie answered, with affecting sweetness, \xe2\x80\x9cI cannot be that to you,\r\nbut I can speak in the spirit of the Laura who is dead to you forever.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe it as you will,\xe2\x80\x9d said Patton.\r\n\r\nHurstwood leaned forward. The whole audience was silent and intent.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet the woman you look upon be wise or vain,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, her eyes\r\nbent sadly upon the lover, who had sunk into a seat, \xe2\x80\x9cbeautiful or\r\nhomely, rich or poor, she has but one thing she can really give or\r\nrefuse\xe2\x80\x94her heart.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDrouet felt a scratch in his throat.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHer beauty, her wit, her accomplishments, she may sell to you; but her\r\nlove is the treasure without money and without price.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe manager suffered this as a personal appeal. It came to him as if\r\nthey were alone, and he could hardly restrain the tears for sorrow over\r\nthe hopeless, pathetic, and yet dainty and appealing woman whom he\r\nloved. Drouet also was beside himself. He was resolving that he would\r\nbe to Carrie what he had never been before. He would marry her, by\r\nGeorge! She was worth it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe asks only in return,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, scarcely hearing the small,\r\nscheduled reply of her lover, and putting herself even more in harmony\r\nwith the plaintive melody now issuing from the orchestra, \xe2\x80\x9cthat when\r\nyou look upon her your eyes shall speak devotion; that when you address\r\nher your voice shall be gentle, loving, and kind; that you shall not\r\ndespise her because she cannot understand all at once your vigorous\r\nthoughts and ambitious designs; for, when misfortune and evil have\r\ndefeated your greatest purposes, her love remains to console you. You\r\nlook to the trees,\xe2\x80\x9d she continued, while Hurstwood restrained his\r\nfeelings only by the grimmest repression, \xe2\x80\x9cfor strength and grandeur;\r\ndo not despise the flowers because their fragrance is all they have to\r\ngive. Remember,\xe2\x80\x9d she concluded, tenderly, \xe2\x80\x9clove is all a woman has to\r\ngive,\xe2\x80\x9d and she laid a strange, sweet accent on the all, \xe2\x80\x9cbut it is the\r\nonly thing which God permits us to carry beyond the grave.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe two men were in the most harrowed state of affection. They scarcely\r\nheard the few remaining words with which the scene concluded. They only\r\nsaw their idol, moving about with appealing grace, continuing a power\r\nwhich to them was a revelation.\r\n\r\nHurstwood resolved a thousands things, Drouet as well. They joined\r\nequally in the burst of applause which called Carrie out. Drouet\r\npounded his hands until they ached. Then he jumped up again and started\r\nout. As he went, Carrie came out, and, seeing an immense basket of\r\nflowers being hurried down the aisle toward her, she waited. They were\r\nHurstwood\xe2\x80\x99s. She looked toward the manager\xe2\x80\x99s box for a moment, caught\r\nhis eye, and smiled. He could have leaped out of the box to enfold her.\r\nHe forgot the need of circumspectness which his married state enforced.\r\nHe almost forgot that he had with him in the box those who knew him. By\r\nthe Lord, he would have that lovely girl if it took his all. He would\r\nact at once. This should be the end of Drouet, and don\xe2\x80\x99t you forget it.\r\nHe would not wait another day. The drummer should not have her.\r\n\r\nHe was so excited that he could not stay in the box. He went into the\r\nlobby, and then into the street, thinking. Drouet did not return. In a\r\nfew minutes the last act was over, and he was crazy to have Carrie\r\nalone. He cursed the luck that could keep him smiling, bowing,\r\nshamming, when he wanted to tell her that he loved her, when he wanted\r\nto whisper to her alone. He groaned as he saw that his hopes were\r\nfutile. He must even take her to supper, shamming. He finally went\r\nabout and asked how she was getting along. The actors were all\r\ndressing, talking, hurrying about. Drouet was palavering himself with\r\nthe looseness of excitement and passion. The manager mastered himself\r\nonly by a great effort.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe are going to supper, of course,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, with a voice that was a\r\nmockery of his heart.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, smiling.\r\n\r\nThe little actress was in fine feather. She was realising now what it\r\nwas to be petted. For once she was the admired, the sought-for. The\r\nindependence of success now made its first faint showing. With the\r\ntables turned, she was looking down, rather than up, to her lover. She\r\ndid not fully realise that this was so, but there was something in\r\ncondescension coming from her which was infinitely sweet. When she was\r\nready they climbed into the waiting coach and drove down town; once,\r\nonly, did she find an opportunity to express her feeling, and that was\r\nwhen the manager preceded Drouet in the coach and sat beside her.\r\nBefore Drouet was fully in she had squeezed Hurstwood\xe2\x80\x99s hand in a\r\ngentle, impulsive manner. The manager was beside himself with\r\naffection. He could have sold his soul to be with her alone. \xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nthought, \xe2\x80\x9cthe agony of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDrouet hung on, thinking he was all in all. The dinner was spoiled by\r\nhis enthusiasm. Hurstwood went home feeling as if he should die if he\r\ndid not find affectionate relief. He whispered \xe2\x80\x9cto-morrow\xe2\x80\x9d passionately\r\nto Carrie, and she understood. He walked away from the drummer and his\r\nprize at parting feeling as if he could slay him and not regret. Carrie\r\nalso felt the misery of it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood-night,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, simulating an easy friendliness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood-night,\xe2\x80\x9d said the little actress, tenderly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe fool!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, now hating Drouet. \xe2\x80\x9cThe idiot! I\xe2\x80\x99ll do him yet,\r\nand that quick! We\xe2\x80\x99ll see to-morrow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, if you aren\xe2\x80\x99t a wonder,\xe2\x80\x9d Drouet was saying, complacently,\r\nsqueezing Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s arm. \xe2\x80\x9cYou are the dandiest little girl on earth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XX. THE LURE OF THE SPIRIT: THE FLESH IN PURSUIT\r\n\r\nPassion in a man of Hurstwood\xe2\x80\x99s nature takes a vigorous form. It is no\r\nmusing, dreamy thing. There is none of the tendency to sing outside of\r\nmy lady\xe2\x80\x99s window\xe2\x80\x94to languish and repine in the face of difficulties. In\r\nthe night he was long getting to sleep because of too much thinking,\r\nand in the morning he was early awake, seizing with alacrity upon the\r\nsame dear subject and pursuing it with vigour. He was out of sorts\r\nphysically, as well as disordered mentally, for did he not delight in a\r\nnew manner in his Carrie, and was not Drouet in the way? Never was man\r\nmore harassed than he by the thoughts of his love being held by the\r\nelated, flush-mannered drummer. He would have given anything, it seemed\r\nto him, to have the complication ended\xe2\x80\x94to have Carrie acquiesce to an\r\narrangement which would dispose of Drouet effectually and forever.\r\n\r\nWhat to do. He dressed thinking. He moved about in the same chamber\r\nwith his wife, unmindful of her presence.\r\n\r\nAt breakfast he found himself without an appetite. The meat to which he\r\nhelped himself remained on his plate untouched. His coffee grew cold,\r\nwhile he scanned the paper indifferently. Here and there he read a\r\nlittle thing, but remembered nothing. Jessica had not yet come down.\r\nHis wife sat at one end of the table revolving thoughts of her own in\r\nsilence. A new servant had been recently installed and had forgot the\r\nnapkins. On this account the silence was irritably broken by a reproof.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve told you about this before, Maggie,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Hurstwood. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m\r\nnot going to tell you again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHurstwood took a glance at his wife. She was frowning. Just now her\r\nmanner irritated him excessively. Her next remark was addressed to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you made up your mind, George, when you will take your vacation?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was customary for them to discuss the regular summer outing at this\r\nseason of the year.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot yet,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m very busy just now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you\xe2\x80\x99ll want to make up your mind pretty soon, won\xe2\x80\x99t you, if\r\nwe\xe2\x80\x99re going?\xe2\x80\x9d she returned.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI guess we have a few days yet,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHmff,\xe2\x80\x9d she returned. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t wait until the season\xe2\x80\x99s over.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe stirred in aggravation as she said this.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere you go again,\xe2\x80\x9d he observed. \xe2\x80\x9cOne would think I never did\r\nanything, the way you begin.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I want to know about it,\xe2\x80\x9d she reiterated.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ve got a few days yet,\xe2\x80\x9d he insisted. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ll not want to start\r\nbefore the races are over.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe was irritated to think that this should come up when he wished to\r\nhave his thoughts for other purposes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, we may. Jessica doesn\xe2\x80\x99t want to stay until the end of the\r\nraces.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat did you want with a season ticket, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUh!\xe2\x80\x9d she said, using the sound as an exclamation of disgust, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll not\r\nargue with you,\xe2\x80\x9d and therewith arose to leave the table.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSay,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, rising, putting a note of determination in his voice\r\nwhich caused her to delay her departure, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat\xe2\x80\x99s the matter with you of\r\nlate? Can\xe2\x80\x99t I talk with you any more?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly, you can _talk_ with me,\xe2\x80\x9d she replied, laying emphasis on\r\nthe word.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t think so by the way you act. Now, you want to know\r\nwhen I\xe2\x80\x99ll be ready\xe2\x80\x94not for a month yet. Maybe not then.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ll go without you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will, eh?\xe2\x80\x9d he sneered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, we will.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe was astonished at the woman\xe2\x80\x99s determination, but it only irritated\r\nhim the more.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, we\xe2\x80\x99ll see about that. It seems to me you\xe2\x80\x99re trying to run things\r\nwith a pretty high hand of late. You talk as though you settled my\r\naffairs for me. Well, you don\xe2\x80\x99t. You don\xe2\x80\x99t regulate anything that\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nconnected with me. If you want to go, go, but you won\xe2\x80\x99t hurry me by any\r\nsuch talk as that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe was thoroughly aroused now. His dark eyes snapped, and he crunched\r\nhis paper as he laid it down. Mrs. Hurstwood said nothing more. He was\r\njust finishing when she turned on her heel and went out into the hall\r\nand upstairs. He paused for a moment, as if hesitating, then sat down\r\nand drank a little coffee, and thereafter arose and went for his hat\r\nand gloves upon the main floor.\r\n\r\nHis wife had really not anticipated a row of this character. She had\r\ncome down to the breakfast table feeling a little out of sorts with\r\nherself and revolving a scheme which she had in her mind. Jessica had\r\ncalled her attention to the fact that the races were not what they were\r\nsupposed to be. The social opportunities were not what they had thought\r\nthey would be this year. The beautiful girl found going every day a\r\ndull thing. There was an earlier exodus this year of people who were\r\nanybody to the watering places and Europe. In her own circle of\r\nacquaintances several young men in whom she was interested had gone to\r\nWaukesha. She began to feel that she would like to go too, and her\r\nmother agreed with her.\r\n\r\nAccordingly, Mrs. Hurstwood decided to broach the subject. She was\r\nthinking this over when she came down to the table, but for some reason\r\nthe atmosphere was wrong. She was not sure, after it was all over, just\r\nhow the trouble had begun. She was determined now, however, that her\r\nhusband was a brute, and that, under no circumstances, would she let\r\nthis go by unsettled. She would have more lady-like treatment or she\r\nwould know why.\r\n\r\nFor his part, the manager was loaded with the care of this new argument\r\nuntil he reached his office and started from there to meet Carrie. Then\r\nthe other complications of love, desire, and opposition possessed him.\r\nHis thoughts fled on before him upon eagles\xe2\x80\x99 wings. He could hardly\r\nwait until he should meet Carrie face to face. What was the night,\r\nafter all, without her\xe2\x80\x94what the day? She must and should be his.\r\n\r\nFor her part, Carrie had experienced a world of fancy and feeling since\r\nshe had left him, the night before. She had listened to Drouet\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nenthusiastic maunderings with much regard for that part which concerned\r\nherself, with very little for that which affected his own gain. She\r\nkept him at such lengths as she could, because her thoughts were with\r\nher own triumph. She felt Hurstwood\xe2\x80\x99s passion as a delightful\r\nbackground to her own achievement, and she wondered what he would have\r\nto say. She was sorry for him, too, with that peculiar sorrow which\r\nfinds something complimentary to itself in the misery of another. She\r\nwas now experiencing the first shades of feeling of that subtle change\r\nwhich removes one out of the ranks of the suppliants into the lines of\r\nthe dispensers of charity. She was, all in all, exceedingly happy.\r\n\r\nOn the morrow, however, there was nothing in the papers concerning the\r\nevent, and, in view of the flow of common, everyday things about, it\r\nnow lost a shade of the glow of the previous evening. Drouet himself\r\nwas not talking so much _of_ as _for_ her. He felt instinctively that,\r\nfor some reason or other, he needed reconstruction in her regard.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, as he spruced around their chambers the next\r\nmorning, preparatory to going down town, \xe2\x80\x9cthat I\xe2\x80\x99ll straighten out that\r\nlittle deal of mine this month and then we\xe2\x80\x99ll get married. I was\r\ntalking with Mosher about that yesterday.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, you won\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, who was coming to feel a certain faint\r\npower to jest with the drummer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I will,\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed, more feelingly than usual, adding, with\r\nthe tone of one who pleads, \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t you believe what I\xe2\x80\x99ve told you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie laughed a little.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course I do,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered.\r\n\r\nDrouet\xe2\x80\x99s assurance now misgave him. Shallow as was his mental\r\nobservation, there was that in the things which had happened which made\r\nhis little power of analysis useless. Carrie was still with him, but\r\nnot helpless and pleading. There was a lilt in her voice which was new.\r\nShe did not study him with eyes expressive of dependence. The drummer\r\nwas feeling the shadow of something which was coming. It coloured his\r\nfeelings and made him develop those little attentions and say those\r\nlittle words which were mere forefendations against danger.\r\n\r\nShortly afterward he departed, and Carrie prepared for her meeting with\r\nHurstwood. She hurried at her toilet, which was soon made, and hastened\r\ndown the stairs. At the corner she passed Drouet, but they did not see\r\neach other.\r\n\r\nThe drummer had forgotten some bills which he wished to turn into his\r\nhouse. He hastened up the stairs and burst into the room, but found\r\nonly the chambermaid, who was cleaning up.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHello,\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed, half to himself, \xe2\x80\x9chas Carrie gone?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour wife? Yes, she went out just a few minutes ago.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s strange,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Drouet. \xe2\x80\x9cShe didn\xe2\x80\x99t say a word to me. I\r\nwonder where she went?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe hastened about, rummaging in his valise for what he wanted, and\r\nfinally pocketing it. Then he turned his attention to his fair\r\nneighbour, who was good-looking and kindly disposed towards him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat are you up to?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, smiling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJust cleaning,\xe2\x80\x9d she replied, stopping and winding a dusting towel\r\nabout her hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTired of it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot so very.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet me show you something,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, affably, coming over and taking\r\nout of his pocket a little lithographed card which had been issued by a\r\nwholesale tobacco company. On this was printed a picture of a pretty\r\ngirl, holding a striped parasol, the colours of which could be changed\r\nby means of a revolving disk in the back, which showed red, yellow,\r\ngreen, and blue through little interstices made in the ground occupied\r\nby the umbrella top.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIsn\xe2\x80\x99t that clever?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, handing it to her and showing her how it\r\nworked. \xe2\x80\x9cYou never saw anything like that before.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIsn\xe2\x80\x99t it nice?\xe2\x80\x9d she answered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou can have it if you want it,\xe2\x80\x9d he remarked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s a pretty ring you have,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, touching a commonplace\r\nsetting which adorned the hand holding the card he had given her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you think so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s right,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered, making use of a pretence at examination to\r\nsecure her finger. \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s fine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe ice being thus broken, he launched into further observation\r\npretending to forget that her fingers were still retained by his. She\r\nsoon withdrew them, however, and retreated a few feet to rest against\r\nthe window-sill.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI didn\xe2\x80\x99t see you for a long time,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, coquettishly, repulsing\r\none of his exuberant approaches. \xe2\x80\x9cYou must have been away.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you travel far?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPretty far\xe2\x80\x94yes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you like it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, not very well. You get tired of it after a while.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish I could travel,\xe2\x80\x9d said the girl, gazing idly out of the window.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat has become of your friend, Mr. Hurstwood?\xe2\x80\x9d she suddenly asked,\r\nbethinking herself of the manager, who, from her own observation,\r\nseemed to contain promising material.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s here in town. What makes you ask about him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, nothing, only he hasn\xe2\x80\x99t been here since you got back.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow did you come to know him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDidn\xe2\x80\x99t I take up his name a dozen times in the last month?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGet out,\xe2\x80\x9d said the drummer, lightly. \xe2\x80\x9cHe hasn\xe2\x80\x99t called more than half\r\na dozen times since we\xe2\x80\x99ve been here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe hasn\xe2\x80\x99t, eh?\xe2\x80\x9d said the girl, smiling. \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s all you know about\r\nit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDrouet took on a slightly more serious tone. He was uncertain as to\r\nwhether she was joking or not.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTease,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat makes you smile that way?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, nothing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you seen him recently?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot since you came back,\xe2\x80\x9d she laughed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBefore?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow often?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, nearly every day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe was a mischievous newsmonger, and was keenly wondering what the\r\neffect of her words would be.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho did he come to see?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the drummer, incredulously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMrs. Drouet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe looked rather foolish at this answer, and then attempted to correct\r\nhimself so as not to appear a dupe.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat of it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the girl, her head cocked coquettishly on one side.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s an old friend,\xe2\x80\x9d he went on, getting deeper into the mire.\r\n\r\nHe would have gone on further with his little flirtation, but the taste\r\nfor it was temporarily removed. He was quite relieved when the girl\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nnamed was called from below.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve got to go,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, moving away from him airily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll see you later,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, with a pretence of disturbance at being\r\ninterrupted.\r\n\r\nWhen she was gone, he gave freer play to his feelings. His face, never\r\neasily controlled by him, expressed all the perplexity and disturbance\r\nwhich he felt. Could it be that Carrie had received so many visits and\r\nyet said nothing about them? Was Hurstwood lying? What did the\r\nchambermaid mean by it, anyway? He had thought there was something odd\r\nabout Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s manner at the time. Why did she look so disturbed when\r\nhe had asked her how many times Hurstwood had called? By George! He\r\nremembered now. There was something strange about the whole thing.\r\n\r\nHe sat down in a rocking-chair to think the better, drawing up one leg\r\non his knee and frowning mightily. His mind ran on at a great rate.\r\n\r\nAnd yet Carrie hadn\xe2\x80\x99t acted out of the ordinary. It couldn\xe2\x80\x99t be, by\r\nGeorge, that she was deceiving him. She hadn\xe2\x80\x99t acted that way. Why,\r\neven last night she had been as friendly toward him as could be, and\r\nHurstwood too. Look how they acted! He could hardly believe they would\r\ntry to deceive him.\r\n\r\nHis thoughts burst into words.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe did act sort of funny at times. Here she had dressed, and gone out\r\nthis morning and never said a word.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe scratched his head and prepared to go down town. He was still\r\nfrowning. As he came into the hall he encountered the girl, who was now\r\nlooking after another chamber. She had on a white dusting cap, beneath\r\nwhich her chubby face shone good-naturedly. Drouet almost forgot his\r\nworry in the fact that she was smiling on him. He put his hand\r\nfamiliarly on her shoulder, as if only to greet her in passing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGot over being mad?\xe2\x80\x9d she said, still mischievously inclined.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m not mad,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thought you were,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, smiling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cQuit your fooling about that,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, in an offhand way. \xe2\x80\x9cWere you\r\nserious?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered. Then, with an air of one who did not\r\nintentionally mean to create trouble, \xe2\x80\x9cHe came lots of times. I thought\r\nyou knew.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe game of deception was up with Drouet. He did not try to simulate\r\nindifference further.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid he spend the evenings here?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSometimes. Sometimes they went out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the evening?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. You mustn\xe2\x80\x99t look so mad, though.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m not,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cDid any one else see him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course,\xe2\x80\x9d said the girl, as if, after all, it were nothing in\r\nparticular.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow long ago was this?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJust before you came back.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe drummer pinched his lip nervously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t say anything, will you?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, giving the girl\xe2\x80\x99s arm a\r\ngentle squeeze.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly not,\xe2\x80\x9d she returned. \xe2\x80\x9cI wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t worry over it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, passing on, seriously brooding for once, and yet\r\nnot wholly unconscious of the fact that he was making a most excellent\r\nimpression upon the chambermaid.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll see her about that,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to himself, passionately, feeling\r\nthat he had been unduly wronged. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll find out, b\xe2\x80\x99George, whether\r\nshe\xe2\x80\x99ll act that way or not.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XXI. THE LURE OF THE SPIRIT: THE FLESH IN PURSUIT\r\n\r\nWhen Carrie came Hurstwood had been waiting many minutes. His blood was\r\nwarm; his nerves wrought up. He was anxious to see the woman who had\r\nstirred him so profoundly the night before.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere you are,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, repressedly, feeling a spring in his limbs and\r\nan elation which was tragic in itself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\nThey walked on as if bound for some objective point, while Hurstwood\r\ndrank in the radiance of her presence. The rustle of her pretty skirt\r\nwas like music to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you satisfied?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, thinking of how well she did the night\r\nbefore.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe tightened his fingers as he saw the smile she gave him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was wonderful.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie laughed ecstatically.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat was one of the best things I\xe2\x80\x99ve seen in a long time,\xe2\x80\x9d he added.\r\n\r\nHe was dwelling on her attractiveness as he had felt it the evening\r\nbefore, and mingling it with the feeling her presence inspired now.\r\n\r\nCarrie was dwelling in the atmosphere which this man created for her.\r\nAlready she was enlivened and suffused with a glow. She felt his\r\ndrawing toward her in every sound of his voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThose were such nice flowers you sent me,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, after a moment or\r\ntwo. \xe2\x80\x9cThey were beautiful.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGlad you liked them,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered, simply.\r\n\r\nHe was thinking all the time that the subject of his desire was being\r\ndelayed. He was anxious to turn the talk to his own feelings. All was\r\nripe for it. His Carrie was beside him. He wanted to plunge in and\r\nexpostulate with her, and yet he found himself fishing for words and\r\nfeeling for a way.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou got home all right,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, gloomily, of a sudden, his tune\r\nmodifying itself to one of self-commiseration.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, easily.\r\n\r\nHe looked at her steadily for a moment, slowing his pace and fixing her\r\nwith his eye.\r\n\r\nShe felt the flood of feeling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow about me?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\nThis confused Carrie considerably, for she realised the flood-gates\r\nwere open. She didn\xe2\x80\x99t know exactly what to answer. \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d she\r\nanswered.\r\n\r\nHe took his lower lip between his teeth for a moment, and then let it\r\ngo. He stopped by the walk side and kicked the grass with his toe. He\r\nsearched her face with a tender, appealing glance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWon\xe2\x80\x99t you come away from him?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, intensely.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Carrie, still illogically drifting and finding\r\nnothing at which to catch.\r\n\r\nAs a matter of fact, she was in a most hopeless quandary. Here was a\r\nman whom she thoroughly liked, who exercised an influence over her,\r\nsufficient almost to delude her into the belief that she was possessed\r\nof a lively passion for him. She was still the victim of his keen eyes,\r\nhis suave manners, his fine clothes. She looked and saw before her a\r\nman who was most gracious and sympathetic, who leaned toward her with a\r\nfeeling that was a delight to observe. She could not resist the glow of\r\nhis temperament, the light of his eye. She could hardly keep from\r\nfeeling what he felt.\r\n\r\nAnd yet she was not without thoughts which were disturbing. What did he\r\nknow? What had Drouet told him? Was she a wife in his eyes, or what?\r\nWould he marry her? Even while he talked, and she softened, and her\r\neyes were lighted with a tender glow, she was asking herself if Drouet\r\nhad told him they were not married. There was never anything at all\r\nconvincing about what Drouet said.\r\n\r\nAnd yet she was not grieved at Hurstwood\xe2\x80\x99s love. No strain of\r\nbitterness was in it for her, whatever he knew. He was evidently\r\nsincere. His passion was real and warm. There was power in what he\r\nsaid. What should she do? She went on thinking this, answering vaguely,\r\nlanguishing affectionately, and altogether drifting, until she was on a\r\nborderless sea of speculation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy don\xe2\x80\x99t you come away?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, tenderly. \xe2\x80\x9cI will arrange for you\r\nwhatever\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, don\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t what?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you mean?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was a look of confusion and pain in her face. She was wondering\r\nwhy that miserable thought must be brought in. She was struck as by a\r\nblade with the miserable provision which was outside the pale of\r\nmarriage.\r\n\r\nHe himself realized that it was a wretched thing to have dragged in. He\r\nwanted to weigh the effects of it, and yet he could not see. He went\r\nbeating on, flushed by her presence, clearly awakened, intensely\r\nenlisted in his plan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWon\xe2\x80\x99t you come?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, beginning over and with a more reverent\r\nfeeling. \xe2\x80\x9cYou know I can\xe2\x80\x99t do without you\xe2\x80\x94you know it\xe2\x80\x94it can\xe2\x80\x99t go on\r\nthis way\xe2\x80\x94can it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t ask if I\xe2\x80\x94I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t argue with you if I could help it. Look\r\nat me, Carrie. Put yourself in my place. You don\xe2\x80\x99t want to stay away\r\nfrom me, do you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe shook her head as if in deep thought. \xe2\x80\x9cThen why not settle the\r\nwhole thing, once and for all?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t know! Ah, Carrie, what makes you say that? Don\xe2\x80\x99t torment me. Be\r\nserious.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, softly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou can\xe2\x80\x99t be, dearest, and say that. Not when you know how I love you.\r\nLook at last night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHis manner as he said this was the most quiet imaginable. His face and\r\nbody retained utter composure. Only his eyes moved, and they flashed a\r\nsubtle, dissolving fire. In them the whole intensity of the man\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nnature was distilling itself.\r\n\r\nCarrie made no answer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow can you act this way, dearest?\xe2\x80\x9d he inquired, after a time. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\r\nlove me, don\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe turned on her such a storm of feeling that she was overwhelmed. For\r\nthe moment all doubts were cleared away.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered, frankly and tenderly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then you\xe2\x80\x99ll come, won\xe2\x80\x99t you\xe2\x80\x94come to-night?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie shook her head in spite of her distress.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t wait any longer,\xe2\x80\x9d urged Hurstwood. \xe2\x80\x9cIf that is too soon, come\r\nSaturday.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen will we be married?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked, diffidently, forgetting in her\r\ndifficult situation that she had hoped he took her to be Drouet\xe2\x80\x99s wife.\r\n\r\nThe manager started, hit as he was by a problem which was more\r\ndifficult than hers. He gave no sign of the thoughts that flashed like\r\nmessages to his mind.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAny time you say,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, with ease, refusing to discolour his\r\npresent delight with this miserable problem.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSaturday?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Carrie.\r\n\r\nHe nodded his head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, if you will marry me then,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll go.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe manager looked at his lovely prize, so beautiful, so winsome, so\r\ndifficult to be won, and made strange resolutions. His passion had\r\ngotten to that stage now where it was no longer coloured with reason.\r\nHe did not trouble over little barriers of this sort in the face of so\r\nmuch loveliness. He would accept the situation with all its\r\ndifficulties; he would not try to answer the objections which cold\r\ntruth thrust upon him. He would promise anything, everything, and trust\r\nto fortune to disentangle him. He would make a try for Paradise,\r\nwhatever might be the result. He would be happy, by the Lord, if it\r\ncost all honesty of statement, all abandonment of truth.\r\n\r\nCarrie looked at him tenderly. She could have laid her head upon his\r\nshoulder, so delightful did it all seem. \xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll try\r\nand get ready then.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHurstwood looked into her pretty face, crossed with little shadows of\r\nwonder and misgiving, and thought he had never seen anything more\r\nlovely.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll see you again to-morrow,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, joyously, \xe2\x80\x9cand we\xe2\x80\x99ll talk over\r\nthe plans.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe walked on with her, elated beyond words, so delightful had been the\r\nresult. He impressed a long story of joy and affection upon her, though\r\nthere was but here and there a word. After a half-hour he began to\r\nrealise that the meeting must come to an end, so exacting is the world.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo-morrow,\xe2\x80\x9d he said at parting, a gayety of manner adding wonderfully\r\nto his brave demeanour.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, tripping elatedly away.\r\n\r\nThere had been so much enthusiasm engendered that she was believing\r\nherself deeply in love. She sighed as she thought of her handsome\r\nadorer. Yes, she would get ready by Saturday. She would go, and they\r\nwould be happy.\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XXII. THE BLAZE OF THE TINDER: FLESH WARS WITH THE FLESH\r\n\r\nThe misfortune of the Hurstwood household was due to the fact that\r\njealousy, having been born of love, did not perish with it. Mrs.\r\nHurstwood retained this in such form that subsequent influences could\r\ntransform it into hate. Hurstwood was still worthy, in a physical\r\nsense, of the affection his wife had once bestowed upon him, but in a\r\nsocial sense he fell short. With his regard died his power to be\r\nattentive to her, and this, to a woman, is much greater than outright\r\ncrime toward another. Our self-love dictates our appreciation of the\r\ngood or evil in another. In Mrs. Hurstwood it discoloured the very hue\r\nof her husband\xe2\x80\x99s indifferent nature. She saw design in deeds and\r\nphrases which sprung only from a faded appreciation of her presence.\r\n\r\nAs a consequence, she was resentful and suspicious. The jealousy that\r\nprompted her to observe every falling away from the little amenities of\r\nthe married relation on his part served to give her notice of the airy\r\ngrace with which he still took the world. She could see from the\r\nscrupulous care which he exercised in the matter of his personal\r\nappearance that his interest in life had abated not a jot. Every\r\nmotion, every glance had something in it of the pleasure he felt in\r\nCarrie, of the zest this new pursuit of pleasure lent to his days. Mrs.\r\nHurstwood felt something, sniffing change, as animals do danger, afar\r\noff.\r\n\r\nThis feeling was strengthened by actions of a direct and more potent\r\nnature on the part of Hurstwood. We have seen with what irritation he\r\nshirked those little duties which no longer contained any amusement of\r\nsatisfaction for him, and the open snarls with which, more recently, he\r\nresented her irritating goads. These little rows were really\r\nprecipitated by an atmosphere which was surcharged with dissension.\r\nThat it would shower, with a sky so full of blackening thunderclouds,\r\nwould scarcely be thought worthy of comment. Thus, after leaving the\r\nbreakfast table this morning, raging inwardly at his blank declaration\r\nof indifference at her plans, Mrs. Hurstwood encountered Jessica in her\r\ndressing-room, very leisurely arranging her hair. Hurstwood had already\r\nleft the house.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish you wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be so late coming down to breakfast,\xe2\x80\x9d she said,\r\naddressing Jessica, while making for her crochet basket. \xe2\x80\x9cNow here the\r\nthings are quite cold, and you haven\xe2\x80\x99t eaten.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHer natural composure was sadly ruffled, and Jessica was doomed to feel\r\nthe fag end of the storm.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m not hungry,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen why don\xe2\x80\x99t you say so, and let the girl put away the things,\r\ninstead of keeping her waiting all morning?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe doesn\xe2\x80\x99t mind,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Jessica, coolly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I do, if she doesn\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the mother, \xe2\x80\x9cand, anyhow, I\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t like you to talk that way to me. You\xe2\x80\x99re too young to put on such\r\nan air with your mother.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, mamma, don\xe2\x80\x99t row,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Jessica. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the matter this\r\nmorning, anyway?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing\xe2\x80\x99s the matter, and I\xe2\x80\x99m not rowing. You mustn\xe2\x80\x99t think because I\r\nindulge you in some things that you can keep everybody waiting. I won\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nhave it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m not keeping anybody waiting,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Jessica, sharply, stirred\r\nout of a cynical indifference to a sharp defence. \xe2\x80\x9cI said I wasn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nhungry. I don\xe2\x80\x99t want any breakfast.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMind how you address me, missy. I\xe2\x80\x99ll not have it. Hear me now; I\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nnot have it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nJessica heard this last while walking out of the room, with a toss of\r\nher head and a flick of her pretty skirts indicative of the\r\nindependence and indifference she felt. She did not propose to be\r\nquarrelled with.\r\n\r\nSuch little arguments were all too frequent, the result of a growth of\r\nnatures which were largely independent and selfish. George, Jr.,\r\nmanifested even greater touchiness and exaggeration in the matter of\r\nhis individual rights, and attempted to make all feel that he was a man\r\nwith a man\xe2\x80\x99s privileges\xe2\x80\x94an assumption which, of all things, is most\r\ngroundless and pointless in a youth of nineteen.\r\n\r\nHurstwood was a man of authority and some fine feeling, and it\r\nirritated him excessively to find himself surrounded more and more by a\r\nworld upon which he had no hold, and of which he had a lessening\r\nunderstanding.\r\n\r\nNow, when such little things, such as the proposed earlier start to\r\nWaukesha, came up, they made clear to him his position. He was being\r\nmade to follow, was not leading. When, in addition, a sharp temper was\r\nmanifested, and to the process of shouldering him out of his authority\r\nwas added a rousing intellectual kick, such as a sneer or a cynical\r\nlaugh, he was unable to keep his temper. He flew into hardly repressed\r\npassion, and wished himself clear of the whole household. It seemed a\r\nmost irritating drag upon all his desires and opportunities.\r\n\r\nFor all this, he still retained the semblance of leadership and\r\ncontrol, even though his wife was straining to revolt. Her display of\r\ntemper and open assertion of opposition were based upon nothing more\r\nthan the feeling that she could do it. She had no special evidence\r\nwherewith to justify herself\xe2\x80\x94the knowledge of something which would\r\ngive her both authority and excuse. The latter was all that was\r\nlacking, however, to give a solid foundation to what, in a way, seemed\r\ngroundless discontent. The clear proof of one overt deed was the cold\r\nbreath needed to convert the lowering clouds of suspicion into a rain\r\nof wrath.\r\n\r\nAn inkling of untoward deeds on the part of Hurstwood had come. Doctor\r\nBeale, the handsome resident physician of the neighbourhood, met Mrs.\r\nHurstwood at her own doorstep some days after Hurstwood and Carrie had\r\ntaken the drive west on Washington Boulevard. Dr. Beale, coming east on\r\nthe same drive, had recognised Hurstwood, but not before he was quite\r\npast him. He was not so sure of Carrie\xe2\x80\x94did not know whether it was\r\nHurstwood\xe2\x80\x99s wife or daughter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t speak to your friends when you meet them out driving, do\r\nyou?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, jocosely, to Mrs. Hurstwood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I see them, I do. Where was I?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn Washington Boulevard.\xe2\x80\x9d he answered, expecting her eye to light with\r\nimmediate remembrance.\r\n\r\nShe shook her head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, out near Hoyne Avenue. You were with your husband.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI guess you\xe2\x80\x99re mistaken,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered. Then, remembering her\r\nhusband\xe2\x80\x99s part in the affair, she immediately fell a prey to a host of\r\nyoung suspicions, of which, however, she gave no sign.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know I saw your husband,\xe2\x80\x9d he went on. \xe2\x80\x9cI wasn\xe2\x80\x99t so sure about you.\r\nPerhaps it was your daughter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps it was,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Hurstwood, knowing full well that such was\r\nnot the case, as Jessica had been her companion for weeks. She had\r\nrecovered herself sufficiently to wish to know more of the details.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWas it in the afternoon?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked, artfully, assuming an air of\r\nacquaintanceship with the matter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, about two or three.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt must have been Jessica,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Hurstwood, not wishing to seem\r\nto attach any importance to the incident.\r\n\r\nThe physician had a thought or two of his own, but dismissed the matter\r\nas worthy of no further discussion on his part at least.\r\n\r\nMrs. Hurstwood gave this bit of information considerable thought during\r\nthe next few hours, and even days. She took it for granted that the\r\ndoctor had really seen her husband, and that he had been riding, most\r\nlikely, with some other woman, after announcing himself as _busy_ to\r\nher. As a consequence, she recalled, with rising feeling, how often he\r\nhad refused to go to places with her, to share in little visits, or,\r\nindeed, take part in any of the social amenities which furnished the\r\ndiversion of her existence. He had been seen at the theatre with people\r\nwhom he called Moy\xe2\x80\x99s friends; now he was seen driving, and, most\r\nlikely, would have an excuse for that. Perhaps there were others of\r\nwhom she did not hear, or why should he be so busy, so indifferent, of\r\nlate? In the last six weeks he had become strangely irritable\xe2\x80\x94strangely\r\nsatisfied to pick up and go out, whether things were right or wrong in\r\nthe house. Why?\r\n\r\nShe recalled, with more subtle emotions, that he did not look at her\r\nnow with any of the old light of satisfaction or approval in his eye.\r\nEvidently, along with other things, he was taking her to be getting old\r\nand uninteresting. He saw her wrinkles, perhaps. She was fading, while\r\nhe was still preening himself in his elegance and youth. He was still\r\nan interested factor in the merry-makings of the world, while she\xe2\x80\x94but\r\nshe did not pursue the thought. She only found the whole situation\r\nbitter, and hated him for it thoroughly.\r\n\r\nNothing came of this incident at the time, for the truth is it did not\r\nseem conclusive enough to warrant any discussion. Only the atmosphere\r\nof distrust and ill-feeling was strengthened, precipitating every now\r\nand then little sprinklings of irritable conversation, enlivened by\r\nflashes of wrath. The matter of the Waukesha outing was merely a\r\ncontinuation of other things of the same nature.\r\n\r\nThe day after Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s appearance on the Avery stage, Mrs. Hurstwood\r\nvisited the races with Jessica and a youth of her acquaintance, Mr.\r\nBart Taylor, the son of the owner of a local house-furnishing\r\nestablishment. They had driven out early, and, as it chanced,\r\nencountered several friends of Hurstwood, all Elks, and two of whom had\r\nattended the performance the evening before. A thousand chances the\r\nsubject of the performance had never been brought up had Jessica not\r\nbeen so engaged by the attentions of her young companion, who usurped\r\nas much time as possible. This left Mrs. Hurstwood in the mood to\r\nextend the perfunctory greetings of some who knew her into short\r\nconversations, and the short conversations of friends into long ones.\r\nIt was from one who meant but to greet her perfunctorily that this\r\ninteresting intelligence came.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI see,\xe2\x80\x9d said this individual, who wore sporting clothes of the most\r\nattractive pattern, and had a field-glass strung over his shoulder,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthat you did not get over to our little entertainment last evening.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Hurstwood, inquiringly, and wondering why he should be\r\nusing the tone he did in noting the fact that she had not been to\r\nsomething she knew nothing about. It was on her lips to say, \xe2\x80\x9cWhat was\r\nit?\xe2\x80\x9d when he added, \xe2\x80\x9cI saw your husband.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHer wonder was at once replaced by the more subtle quality of\r\nsuspicion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, cautiously, \xe2\x80\x9cwas it pleasant? He did not tell me much\r\nabout it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery. Really one of the best private theatricals I ever attended.\r\nThere was one actress who surprised us all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Hurstwood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s too bad you couldn\xe2\x80\x99t have been there, really. I was sorry to hear\r\nyou weren\xe2\x80\x99t feeling well.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFeeling well! Mrs. Hurstwood could have echoed the words after him\r\nopen-mouthed. As it was, she extricated herself from her mingled\r\nimpulse to deny and question, and said, almost raspingly:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, it is too bad.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLooks like there will be quite a crowd here to-day, doesn\xe2\x80\x99t it?\xe2\x80\x9d the\r\nacquaintance observed, drifting off upon another topic.\r\n\r\nThe manager\xe2\x80\x99s wife would have questioned farther, but she saw no\r\nopportunity. She was for the moment wholly at sea, anxious to think for\r\nherself, and wondering what new deception was this which caused him to\r\ngive out that she was ill when she was not. Another case of her company\r\nnot wanted, and excuses being made. She resolved to find out more.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWere you at the performance last evening?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked of the next of\r\nHurstwood\xe2\x80\x99s friends who greeted her as she sat in her box.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. You didn\xe2\x80\x99t get around.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered, \xe2\x80\x9cI was not feeling very well.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo your husband told me,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, it was really very\r\nenjoyable. Turned out much better than I expected.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWere there many there?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe house was full. It was quite an Elk night. I saw quite a number of\r\nyour friends\xe2\x80\x94Mrs. Harrison, Mrs. Barnes, Mrs. Collins.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cQuite a social gathering.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed it was. My wife enjoyed it very much.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Hurstwood bit her lip.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo,\xe2\x80\x9d she thought, \xe2\x80\x9cthat\xe2\x80\x99s the way he does. Tells my friends I am sick\r\nand cannot come.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe wondered what could induce him to go alone. There was something\r\nback of this. She rummaged her brain for a reason.\r\n\r\nBy evening, when Hurstwood reached home, she had brooded herself into a\r\nstate of sullen desire for explanation and revenge. She wanted to know\r\nwhat this peculiar action of his imported. She was certain there was\r\nmore behind it all than what she had heard, and evil curiosity mingled\r\nwell with distrust and the remnants of her wrath of the morning. She,\r\nimpending disaster itself, walked about with gathered shadow at the\r\neyes and the rudimentary muscles of savagery fixing the hard lines of\r\nher mouth.\r\n\r\nOn the other hand, as we may well believe, the manager came home in the\r\nsunniest mood. His conversation and agreement with Carrie had raised\r\nhis spirits until he was in the frame of mind of one who sings\r\njoyously. He was proud of himself, proud of his success, proud of\r\nCarrie. He could have been genial to all the world, and he bore no\r\ngrudge against his wife. He meant to be pleasant, to forget her\r\npresence, to live in the atmosphere of youth and pleasure which had\r\nbeen restored to him.\r\n\r\nSo now, the house, to his mind, had a most pleasing and comfortable\r\nappearance. In the hall he found an evening paper, laid there by the\r\nmaid and forgotten by Mrs. Hurstwood. In the dining-room the table was\r\nclean laid with linen and napery and shiny with glasses and decorated\r\nchina. Through an open door he saw into the kitchen, where the fire was\r\ncrackling in the stove and the evening meal already well under way. Out\r\nin the small back yard was George, Jr., frolicking with a young dog he\r\nhad recently purchased, and in the parlour Jessica was playing at the\r\npiano, the sounds of a merry waltz filling every nook and corner of the\r\ncomfortable home. Every one, like himself, seemed to have regained his\r\ngood spirits, to be in sympathy with youth and beauty, to be inclined\r\nto joy and merry-making. He felt as if he could say a good word all\r\naround himself, and took a most genial glance at the spread table and\r\npolished sideboard before going upstairs to read his paper in the\r\ncomfortable armchair of the sitting-room which looked through the open\r\nwindows into the street. When he entered there, however, he found his\r\nwife brushing her hair and musing to herself the while.\r\n\r\nHe came lightly in, thinking to smooth over any feeling that might\r\nstill exist by a kindly word and a ready promise, but Mrs. Hurstwood\r\nsaid nothing. He seated himself in the large chair, stirred lightly in\r\nmaking himself comfortable, opened his paper, and began to read. In a\r\nfew moments he was smiling merrily over a very comical account of a\r\nbaseball game which had taken place between the Chicago and Detroit\r\nteams.\r\n\r\nThe while he was doing this Mrs. Hurstwood was observing him casually\r\nthrough the medium of the mirror which was before her. She noticed his\r\npleasant and contented manner, his airy grace and smiling humour, and\r\nit merely aggravated her the more. She wondered how he could think to\r\ncarry himself so in her presence after the cynicism, indifference, and\r\nneglect he had heretofore manifested and would continue to manifest so\r\nlong as she would endure it. She thought how she should like to tell\r\nhim\xe2\x80\x94what stress and emphasis she would lend her assertions, how she\r\nshould drive over this whole affair until satisfaction should be\r\nrendered her. Indeed, the shining sword of her wrath was but weakly\r\nsuspended by a thread of thought.\r\n\r\nIn the meanwhile Hurstwood encountered a humorous item concerning a\r\nstranger who had arrived in the city and became entangled with a\r\nbunco-steerer. It amused him immensely, and at last he stirred and\r\nchuckled to himself. He wished that he might enlist his wife\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nattention and read it to her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHa, ha,\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed softly, as if to himself, \xe2\x80\x9cthat\xe2\x80\x99s funny.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Hurstwood kept on arranging her hair, not so much as deigning a\r\nglance.\r\n\r\nHe stirred again and went on to another subject. At last he felt as if\r\nhis good-humour must find some outlet. Julia was probably still out of\r\nhumour over that affair of this morning, but that could easily be\r\nstraightened. As a matter of fact, she was in the wrong, but he didn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ncare. She could go to Waukesha right away if she wanted to. The sooner\r\nthe better. He would tell her that as soon as he got a chance, and the\r\nwhole thing would blow over.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you notice,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, at last, breaking forth concerning another\r\nitem which he had found, \xe2\x80\x9cthat they have entered suit to compel the\r\nIllinois Central to get off the lake front, Julia?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\nShe could scarcely force herself to answer, but managed to say \xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsharply.\r\n\r\nHurstwood pricked up his ears. There was a note in her voice which\r\nvibrated keenly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt would be a good thing if they did,\xe2\x80\x9d he went on, half to himself,\r\nhalf to her, though he felt that something was amiss in that quarter.\r\nHe withdrew his attention to his paper very circumspectly, listening\r\nmentally for the little sounds which should show him what was on foot.\r\n\r\nAs a matter of fact, no man as clever as Hurstwood\xe2\x80\x94as observant and\r\nsensitive to atmospheres of many sorts, particularly upon his own plane\r\nof thought\xe2\x80\x94would have made the mistake which he did in regard to his\r\nwife, wrought up as she was, had he not been occupied mentally with a\r\nvery different train of thought. Had not the influence of Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nregard for him, the elation which her promise aroused in him, lasted\r\nover, he would not have seen the house in so pleasant a mood. It was\r\nnot extraordinarily bright and merry this evening. He was merely very\r\nmuch mistaken, and would have been much more fitted to cope with it had\r\nhe come home in his normal state.\r\n\r\nAfter he had studied his paper a few moments longer, he felt that he\r\nought to modify matters in some way or other. Evidently his wife was\r\nnot going to patch up peace at a word. So he said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere did George get the dog he has there in the yard?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d she snapped.\r\n\r\nHe put his paper down on his knees and gazed idly out of the window. He\r\ndid not propose to lose his temper, but merely to be persistent and\r\nagreeable, and by a few questions bring around a mild understanding of\r\nsome sort.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy do you feel so bad about that affair of this morning?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, at\r\nlast. \xe2\x80\x9cWe needn\xe2\x80\x99t quarrel about that. You know you can go to Waukesha\r\nif you want to.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo you can stay here and trifle around with some one else?\xe2\x80\x9d she\r\nexclaimed, turning to him a determined countenance upon which was drawn\r\na sharp and wrathful sneer.\r\n\r\nHe stopped as if slapped in the face. In an instant his persuasive,\r\nconciliatory manner fled. He was on the defensive at a wink and puzzled\r\nfor a word to reply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you mean?\xe2\x80\x9d he said at last, straightening himself and gazing\r\nat the cold, determined figure before him, who paid no attention, but\r\nwent on arranging herself before the mirror.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know what I mean,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, finally, as if there were a world of\r\ninformation which she held in reserve\xe2\x80\x94which she did not need to tell.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I don\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, stubbornly, yet nervous and alert for what\r\nshould come next. The finality of the woman\xe2\x80\x99s manner took away his\r\nfeeling of superiority in battle.\r\n\r\nShe made no answer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHmph!\xe2\x80\x9d he murmured, with a movement of his head to one side. It was\r\nthe weakest thing he had ever done. It was totally unassured.\r\n\r\nMrs. Hurstwood noticed the lack of colour in it. She turned upon him,\r\nanimal-like, able to strike an effectual second blow.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI want the Waukesha money to-morrow morning,\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\r\n\r\nHe looked at her in amazement. Never before had he seen such a cold,\r\nsteely determination in her eye\xe2\x80\x94such a cruel look of indifference. She\r\nseemed a thorough master of her mood\xe2\x80\x94thoroughly confident and\r\ndetermined to wrest all control from him. He felt that all his\r\nresources could not defend him. He must attack.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you mean?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, jumping up. \xe2\x80\x9cYou want! I\xe2\x80\x99d like to know\r\nwhat\xe2\x80\x99s got into you to-night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing\xe2\x80\x99s _got_ into me,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, flaming. \xe2\x80\x9cI want that money. You\r\ncan do your swaggering afterwards.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSwaggering, eh! What! You\xe2\x80\x99ll get nothing from me. What do you mean by\r\nyour insinuations, anyhow?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere were you last night?\xe2\x80\x9d she answered. The words were hot as they\r\ncame. \xe2\x80\x9cWho were you driving with on Washington Boulevard? Who were you\r\nwith at the theatre when George saw you? Do you think I\xe2\x80\x99m a fool to be\r\nduped by you? Do you think I\xe2\x80\x99ll sit at home here and take your \xe2\x80\x98too\r\nbusys\xe2\x80\x99 and \xe2\x80\x98can\xe2\x80\x99t come,\xe2\x80\x99 while you parade around and make out that I\xe2\x80\x99m\r\nunable to come? I want you to know that lordly airs have come to an end\r\nso far as I am concerned. You can\xe2\x80\x99t dictate to me nor my children. I\xe2\x80\x99m\r\nthrough with you entirely.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a lie,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, driven to a corner and knowing no other excuse.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLie, eh!\xe2\x80\x9d she said, fiercely, but with returning reserve; \xe2\x80\x9cyou may\r\ncall it a lie if you want to, but I know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a lie, I tell you,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, in a low, sharp voice. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ve been\r\nsearching around for some cheap accusation for months and now you think\r\nyou have it. You think you\xe2\x80\x99ll spring something and get the upper hand.\r\nWell, I tell you, you can\xe2\x80\x99t. As long as I\xe2\x80\x99m in this house I\xe2\x80\x99m master of\r\nit, and you or any one else won\xe2\x80\x99t dictate to me\xe2\x80\x94do you hear?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe crept toward her with a light in his eye that was ominous. Something\r\nin the woman\xe2\x80\x99s cool, cynical, upper-handish manner, as if she were\r\nalready master, caused him to feel for the moment as if he could\r\nstrangle her.\r\n\r\nShe gazed at him\xe2\x80\x94a pythoness in humour.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m not dictating to you,\xe2\x80\x9d she returned; \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m telling you what I\r\nwant.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe answer was so cool, so rich in bravado, that somehow it took the\r\nwind out of his sails. He could not attack her, he could not ask her\r\nfor proofs. Somehow he felt evidence, law, the remembrance of all his\r\nproperty which she held in her name, to be shining in her glance. He\r\nwas like a vessel, powerful and dangerous, but rolling and floundering\r\nwithout sail.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I\xe2\x80\x99m telling you,\xe2\x80\x9d he said in the end, slightly recovering himself,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cwhat you\xe2\x80\x99ll not get.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ll see about it,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll find out what my rights are.\r\nPerhaps you\xe2\x80\x99ll talk to a lawyer, if you won\xe2\x80\x99t to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was a magnificent play, and had its effect. Hurstwood fell back\r\nbeaten. He knew now that he had more than mere bluff to contend with.\r\nHe felt that he was face to face with a dull proposition. What to say\r\nhe hardly knew. All the merriment had gone out of the day. He was\r\ndisturbed, wretched, resentful. What should he do? \xe2\x80\x9cDo as you please,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nhe said, at last. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll have nothing more to do with you,\xe2\x80\x9d and out he\r\nstrode.\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XXIII. A SPIRIT IN TRAVAIL: ONE RUNG PUT BEHIND\r\n\r\nWhen Carrie reached her own room she had already fallen a prey to those\r\ndoubts and misgivings which are ever the result of a lack of decision.\r\nShe could not persuade herself as to the advisability of her promise,\r\nor that now, having given her word, she ought to keep it. She went over\r\nthe whole ground in Hurstwood\xe2\x80\x99s absence, and discovered little\r\nobjections that had not occurred to her in the warmth of the manager\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nargument. She saw where she had put herself in a peculiar light,\r\nnamely, that of agreeing to marry when she was already supposedly\r\nmarried. She remembered a few things Drouet had done, and now that it\r\ncame to walking away from him without a word, she felt as if she were\r\ndoing wrong. Now, she was comfortably situated, and to one who is more\r\nor less afraid of the world, this is an urgent matter, and one which\r\nputs up strange, uncanny arguments. \xe2\x80\x9cYou do not know what will come.\r\nThere are miserable things outside. People go a-begging. Women are\r\nwretched. You never can tell what will happen. Remember the time you\r\nwere hungry. Stick to what you have.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCuriously, for all her leaning towards Hurstwood, he had not taken a\r\nfirm hold on her understanding. She was listening, smiling, approving,\r\nand yet not finally agreeing. This was due to a lack of power on his\r\npart, a lack of that majesty of passion that sweeps the mind from its\r\nseat, fuses and melts all arguments and theories into a tangled mass,\r\nand destroys for the time being the reasoning power. This majesty of\r\npassion is possessed by nearly every man once in his life, but it is\r\nusually an attribute of youth and conduces to the first successful\r\nmating.\r\n\r\nHurstwood, being an older man, could scarcely be said to retain the\r\nfire of youth, though he did possess a passion warm and unreasoning. It\r\nwas strong enough to induce the leaning toward him which, on Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s\r\npart, we have seen. She might have been said to be imagining herself in\r\nlove, when she was not. Women frequently do this. It flows from the\r\nfact that in each exists a bias toward affection, a craving for the\r\npleasure of being loved. The longing to be shielded, bettered,\r\nsympathised with, is one of the attributes of the sex. This, coupled\r\nwith sentiment and a natural tendency to emotion, often makes refusing\r\ndifficult. It persuades them that they are in love.\r\n\r\nOnce at home, she changed her clothes and straightened the rooms for\r\nherself. In the matter of the arrangement of the furniture she never\r\ntook the housemaid\xe2\x80\x99s opinion. That young woman invariably put one of\r\nthe rocking-chairs in the corner, and Carrie as regularly moved it out.\r\nTo-day she hardly noticed that it was in the wrong place, so absorbed\r\nwas she in her own thoughts. She worked about the room until Drouet put\r\nin appearance at five o\xe2\x80\x99clock. The drummer was flushed and excited and\r\nfull of determination to know all about her relations with Hurstwood.\r\nNevertheless, after going over the subject in his mind the livelong\r\nday, he was rather weary of it and wished it over with. He did not\r\nforesee serious consequences of any sort, and yet he rather hesitated\r\nto begin. Carrie was sitting by the window when he came in, rocking and\r\nlooking out. \xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d she said innocently, weary of her own mental\r\ndiscussion and wondering at his haste and ill-concealed excitement,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cwhat makes you hurry so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDrouet hesitated, now that he was in her presence, uncertain as to what\r\ncourse to pursue. He was no diplomat. He could neither read nor see.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen did you get home?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked foolishly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, an hour or so ago. What makes you ask that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou weren\xe2\x80\x99t here,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cwhen I came back this morning, and I\r\nthought you had gone out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo I did,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie simply. \xe2\x80\x9cI went for a walk.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDrouet looked at her wonderingly. For all his lack of dignity in such\r\nmatters he did not know how to begin. He stared at her in the most\r\nflagrant manner until at last she said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat makes you stare at me so? What\xe2\x80\x99s the matter?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered. \xe2\x80\x9cI was just thinking.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJust thinking what?\xe2\x80\x9d she returned smilingly, puzzled by his attitude.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, nothing\xe2\x80\x94nothing much.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, what makes you look so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDrouet was standing by the dresser, gazing at her in a comic manner. He\r\nhad laid off his hat and gloves and was now fidgeting with the little\r\ntoilet pieces which were nearest him. He hesitated to believe that the\r\npretty woman before him was involved in anything so unsatisfactory to\r\nhimself. He was very much inclined to feel that it was all right, after\r\nall. Yet the knowledge imparted to him by the chambermaid was rankling\r\nin his mind. He wanted to plunge in with a straight remark of some\r\nsort, but he knew not what.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere did you go this morning?\xe2\x80\x9d he finally asked weakly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, I went for a walk,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSure you did?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, what makes you ask?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe was beginning to see now that he knew something. Instantly she drew\r\nherself into a more reserved position. Her cheeks blanched slightly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thought maybe you didn\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, beating about the bush in the\r\nmost useless manner.\r\n\r\nCarrie gazed at him, and as she did so her ebbing courage halted. She\r\nsaw that he himself was hesitating, and with a woman\xe2\x80\x99s intuition\r\nrealised that there was no occasion for great alarm.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat makes you talk like that?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked, wrinkling her pretty\r\nforehead. \xe2\x80\x9cYou act so funny to-night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI feel funny,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered. They looked at one another for a moment,\r\nand then Drouet plunged desperately into his subject.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s this about you and Hurstwood?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMe and Hurstwood\xe2\x80\x94what do you mean?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDidn\xe2\x80\x99t he come here a dozen times while I was away?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA dozen times,\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Carrie, guiltily. \xe2\x80\x9cNo, but what do you mean?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSomebody said that you went out riding with him and that he came here\r\nevery night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo such thing,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Carrie. \xe2\x80\x9cIt isn\xe2\x80\x99t true. Who told you that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe was flushing scarlet to the roots of her hair, but Drouet did not\r\ncatch the full hue of her face, owing to the modified light of the\r\nroom. He was regaining much confidence as Carrie defended herself with\r\ndenials.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, some one,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re sure you didn\xe2\x80\x99t?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie. \xe2\x80\x9cYou know how often he came.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDrouet paused for a moment and thought.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know what you told me,\xe2\x80\x9d he said finally.\r\n\r\nHe moved nervously about, while Carrie looked at him confusedly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I know that I didn\xe2\x80\x99t tell you any such thing as that,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nCarrie, recovering herself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I were you,\xe2\x80\x9d went on Drouet, ignoring her last remark, \xe2\x80\x9cI wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nhave anything to do with him. He\xe2\x80\x99s a married man, you know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho\xe2\x80\x94who is?\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, stumbling at the word.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, Hurstwood,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet, noting the effect and feeling that he\r\nwas delivering a telling blow.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHurstwood!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Carrie, rising. Her face had changed several\r\nshades since this announcement was made.
