She could hardly believe\r\nher senses\xe2\x80\x94so good-natured and tractable had he invariably been. It was\r\nnot for her to see the wellspring of human passion. A real flame of\r\nlove is a subtle thing. It burns as a will-o\xe2\x80\x99-the-wisp, dancing onward\r\nto fairylands of delight. It roars as a furnace. Too often jealousy is\r\nthe quality upon which it feeds.\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XXIV. ASHES OF TINDER: A FACE AT THE WINDOW\r\n\r\nThat night Hurstwood remained down town entirely, going to the Palmer\r\nHouse for a bed after his work was through. He was in a fevered state\r\nof mind, owing to the blight his wife\xe2\x80\x99s action threatened to cast upon\r\nhis entire future. While he was not sure how much significance might be\r\nattached to the threat she had made, he was sure that her attitude, if\r\nlong continued, would cause him no end of trouble. She was determined,\r\nand had worsted him in a very important contest. How would it be from\r\nnow on? He walked the floor of his little office, and later that of his\r\nroom, putting one thing and another together to no avail.\r\n\r\nMrs. Hurstwood, on the contrary, had decided not to lose her advantage\r\nby inaction. Now that she had practically cowed him, she would follow\r\nup her work with demands, the acknowledgment of which would make her\r\nword _law_ in the future. He would have to pay her the money which she\r\nwould now regularly demand or there would be trouble. It did not matter\r\nwhat he did. She really did not care whether he came home any more or\r\nnot. The household would move along much more pleasantly without him,\r\nand she could do as she wished without consulting any one. Now she\r\nproposed to consult a lawyer and hire a detective. She would find out\r\nat once just what advantages she could gain.\r\n\r\nHurstwood walked the floor, mentally arranging the chief points of his\r\nsituation. \xe2\x80\x9cShe has that property in her name,\xe2\x80\x9d he kept saying to\r\nhimself. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat a fool trick that was. Curse it! What a fool move that\r\nwas.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe also thought of his managerial position. \xe2\x80\x9cIf she raises a row now\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ll lose this thing. They won\xe2\x80\x99t have me around if my name gets in the\r\npapers. My friends, too!\xe2\x80\x9d He grew more angry as he thought of the talk\r\nany action on her part would create. How would the papers talk about\r\nit? Every man he knew would be wondering. He would have to explain and\r\ndeny and make a general mark of himself. Then Moy would come and confer\r\nwith him and there would be the devil to pay.\r\n\r\nMany little wrinkles gathered between his eyes as he contemplated this,\r\nand his brow moistened. He saw no solution of anything\xe2\x80\x94not a loophole\r\nleft.\r\n\r\nThrough all this thoughts of Carrie flashed upon him, and the\r\napproaching affair of Saturday. Tangled as all his matters were, he did\r\nnot worry over that. It was the one pleasing thing in this whole rout\r\nof trouble. He could arrange that satisfactorily, for Carrie would be\r\nglad to wait, if necessary. He would see how things turned out\r\nto-morrow, and then he would talk to her. They were going to meet as\r\nusual. He saw only her pretty face and neat figure and wondered why\r\nlife was not arranged so that such joy as he found with her could be\r\nsteadily maintained. How much more pleasant it would be. Then he would\r\ntake up his wife\xe2\x80\x99s threat again, and the wrinkles and moisture would\r\nreturn.\r\n\r\nIn the morning he came over from the hotel and opened his mail, but\r\nthere was nothing in it outside the ordinary run. For some reason he\r\nfelt as if something might come that way, and was relieved when all the\r\nenvelopes had been scanned and nothing suspicious noticed. He began to\r\nfeel the appetite that had been wanting before he had reached the\r\noffice, and decided before going out to the park to meet Carrie to drop\r\nin at the Grand Pacific and have a pot of coffee and some rolls. While\r\nthe danger had not lessened, it had not as yet materialised, and with\r\nhim no news was good news. If he could only get plenty of time to\r\nthink, perhaps something would turn up. Surely, surely, this thing\r\nwould not drift along to catastrophe and he not find a way out.\r\n\r\nHis spirits fell, however, when, upon reaching the park, he waited and\r\nwaited and Carrie did not come. He held his favourite post for an hour\r\nor more, then arose and began to walk about restlessly. Could something\r\nhave happened out there to keep her away? Could she have been reached\r\nby his wife? Surely not. So little did he consider Drouet that it never\r\nonce occurred to him to worry about his finding out. He grew restless\r\nas he ruminated, and then decided that perhaps it was nothing. She had\r\nnot been able to get away this morning. That was why no letter\r\nnotifying him had come. He would get one to-day. It would probably be\r\non his desk when he got back. He would look for it at once.\r\n\r\nAfter a time he gave up waiting and drearily headed for the Madison\r\ncar. To add to his distress, the bright blue sky became overcast with\r\nlittle fleecy clouds which shut out the sun. The wind veered to the\r\neast, and by the time he reached his office it was threatening to\r\ndrizzle all afternoon.\r\n\r\nHe went in and examined his letters, but there was nothing from Carrie.\r\nFortunately, there was nothing from his wife either. He thanked his\r\nstars that he did not have to confront that proposition just now when\r\nhe needed to think so much. He walked the floor again, pretending to be\r\nin an ordinary mood, but secretly troubled beyond the expression of\r\nwords.\r\n\r\nAt one-thirty he went to Rector\xe2\x80\x99s for lunch, and when he returned a\r\nmessenger was waiting for him. He looked at the little chap with a\r\nfeeling of doubt.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m to bring an answer,\xe2\x80\x9d said the boy.\r\n\r\nHurstwood recognised his wife\xe2\x80\x99s writing. He tore it open and read\r\nwithout a show of feeling. It began in the most formal manner and was\r\nsharply and coldly worded throughout.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI want you to send the money I asked for at once. I need it to carry\r\nout my plans. You can stay away if you want to. It doesn\xe2\x80\x99t matter in\r\nthe least. But I must have some money. So don\xe2\x80\x99t delay, but send it by\r\nthe boy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhen he had finished it, he stood holding it in his hands. The audacity\r\nof the thing took his breath. It roused his ire also\xe2\x80\x94the deepest\r\nelement of revolt in him. His first impulse was to write but four words\r\nin reply\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cGo to the devil!\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94but he compromised by telling the boy that\r\nthere would be no reply. Then he sat down in his chair and gazed\r\nwithout seeing, contemplating the result of his work. What would she do\r\nabout that? The confounded wretch! Was she going to try to bulldoze him\r\ninto submission? He would go up there and have it out with her, that\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nwhat he would do. She was carrying things with too high a hand. These\r\nwere his first thoughts.\r\n\r\nLater, however, his old discretion asserted itself. Something had to be\r\ndone. A climax was near and she would not sit idle. He knew her well\r\nenough to know that when she had decided upon a plan she would follow\r\nit up. Possibly matters would go into a lawyer\xe2\x80\x99s hands at once.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDamn her!\xe2\x80\x9d he said softly, with his teeth firmly set, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll make it\r\nhot for her if she causes me trouble. I\xe2\x80\x99ll make her change her tone if\r\nI have to use force to do it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe arose from his chair and went and looked out into the street. The\r\nlong drizzle had begun. Pedestrians had turned up collars, and trousers\r\nat the bottom. Hands were hidden in the pockets of the umbrellaless;\r\numbrellas were up. The street looked like a sea of round black cloth\r\nroofs, twisting, bobbing, moving. Trucks and vans were rattling in a\r\nnoisy line and everywhere men were shielding themselves as best they\r\ncould. He scarcely noticed the picture. He was forever confronting his\r\nwife, demanding of her to change her attitude toward him before he\r\nworked her bodily harm.\r\n\r\nAt four o\xe2\x80\x99clock another note came, which simply said that if the money\r\nwas not forthcoming that evening the matter would be laid before\r\nFitzgerald and Moy on the morrow, and other steps would be taken to get\r\nit.\r\n\r\nHurstwood almost exclaimed out loud at the insistency of this thing.\r\nYes, he would send her the money. He\xe2\x80\x99d take it to her\xe2\x80\x94he would go up\r\nthere and have a talk with her, and that at once.\r\n\r\nHe put on his hat and looked around for his umbrella. He would have\r\nsome arrangement of this thing.\r\n\r\nHe called a cab and was driven through the dreary rain to the North\r\nSide. On the way his temper cooled as he thought of the details of the\r\ncase. What did she know? What had she done? Maybe she\xe2\x80\x99d got hold of\r\nCarrie, who knows\xe2\x80\x94or\xe2\x80\x94or Drouet. Perhaps she really had evidence, and\r\nwas prepared to fell him as a man does another from secret ambush. She\r\nwas shrewd. Why should she taunt him this way unless she had good\r\ngrounds?\r\n\r\nHe began to wish that he had compromised in some way or other\xe2\x80\x94that he\r\nhad sent the money. Perhaps he could do it up here. He would go in and\r\nsee, anyhow. He would have no row. By the time he reached his own\r\nstreet he was keenly alive to the difficulties of his situation and\r\nwished over and over that some solution would offer itself, that he\r\ncould see his way out. He alighted and went up the steps to the front\r\ndoor, but it was with a nervous palpitation of the heart. He pulled out\r\nhis key and tried to insert it, but another key was on the inside. He\r\nshook at the knob, but the door was locked. Then he rang the bell. No\r\nanswer. He rang again\xe2\x80\x94this time harder. Still no answer. He jangled it\r\nfiercely several times in succession, but without avail. Then he went\r\nbelow.\r\n\r\nThere was a door which opened under the steps into the kitchen,\r\nprotected by an iron grating, intended as a safeguard against burglars.\r\nWhen he reached this he noticed that it also was bolted and that the\r\nkitchen windows were down. What could it mean? He rang the bell and\r\nthen waited. Finally, seeing that no one was coming, he turned and went\r\nback to his cab.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI guess they\xe2\x80\x99ve gone out,\xe2\x80\x9d he said apologetically to the individual\r\nwho was hiding his red face in a loose tarpaulin raincoat.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI saw a young girl up in that winder,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the cabby.\r\n\r\nHurstwood looked, but there was no face there now. He climbed moodily\r\ninto the cab, relieved and distressed.\r\n\r\nSo this was the game, was it? Shut him out and make him pay. Well, by\r\nthe Lord, that did beat all!\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XXV. ASHES OF TINDER: THE LOOSING OF STAYS\r\n\r\nWhen Hurstwood got back to his office again he was in a greater\r\nquandary than ever. Lord, Lord, he thought, what had he got into? How\r\ncould things have taken such a violent turn, and so quickly? He could\r\nhardly realise how it had all come about. It seemed a monstrous,\r\nunnatural, unwarranted condition which had suddenly descended upon him\r\nwithout his let or hindrance.\r\n\r\nMeanwhile he gave a thought now and then to Carrie. What could be the\r\ntrouble in that quarter? No letter had come, no word of any kind, and\r\nyet here it was late in the evening and she had agreed to meet him that\r\nmorning. To-morrow they were to have met and gone off\xe2\x80\x94where? He saw\r\nthat in the excitement of recent events he had not formulated a plan\r\nupon that score. He was desperately in love, and would have taken great\r\nchances to win her under ordinary circumstances, but now\xe2\x80\x94now what?\r\nSupposing she had found out something? Supposing she, too, wrote him\r\nand told him that she knew all\xe2\x80\x94that she would have nothing more to do\r\nwith him? It would be just like this to happen as things were going\r\nnow. Meanwhile he had not sent the money.\r\n\r\nHe strolled up and down the polished floor of the resort, his hands in\r\nhis pockets, his brow wrinkled, his mouth set. He was getting some\r\nvague comfort out of a good cigar, but it was no panacea for the ill\r\nwhich affected him. Every once in a while he would clinch his fingers\r\nand tap his foot\xe2\x80\x94signs of the stirring mental process he was\r\nundergoing. His whole nature was vigorously and powerfully shaken up,\r\nand he was finding what limits the mind has to endurance. He drank more\r\nbrandy and soda than he had any evening in months. He was altogether a\r\nfine example of great mental perturbation.\r\n\r\nFor all his study nothing came of the evening except this\xe2\x80\x94he sent the\r\nmoney. It was with great opposition, after two or three hours of the\r\nmost urgent mental affirmation and denial, that at last he got an\r\nenvelope, placed in it the requested amount, and slowly sealed it up.\r\n\r\nThen he called Harry, the boy of all work around the place.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou take this to this address,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, handing him the envelope,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cand give it to Mrs. Hurstwood.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said the boy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf she isn\xe2\x80\x99t there bring it back.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ve seen my wife?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked as a precautionary measure as the boy\r\nturned to go.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes, sir. I know her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right, now. Hurry right back.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAny answer?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI guess not.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe boy hastened away and the manager fell to his musings. Now he had\r\ndone it. There was no use speculating over that. He was beaten for\r\nto-night and he might just as well make the best of it. But, oh, the\r\nwretchedness of being forced this way! He could see her meeting the boy\r\nat the door and smiling sardonically. She would take the envelope and\r\nknow that she had triumphed. If he only had that letter back he\r\nwouldn\xe2\x80\x99t send it. He breathed heavily and wiped the moisture from his\r\nface.\r\n\r\nFor relief, he arose and joined in conversation with a few friends who\r\nwere drinking. He tried to get the interest of things about him, but it\r\nwas not to be. All the time his thoughts would run out to his home and\r\nsee the scene being therein enacted. All the time he was wondering what\r\nshe would say when the boy handed her the envelope.\r\n\r\nIn about an hour and three-quarters the boy returned. He had evidently\r\ndelivered the package, for, as he came up, he made no sign of taking\r\nanything out of his pocket.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI gave it to her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy wife?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAny answer?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe said it was high time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHurstwood scowled fiercely.\r\n\r\nThere was no more to be done upon that score that night. He went on\r\nbrooding over his situation until midnight, when he repaired again to\r\nthe Palmer House. He wondered what the morning would bring forth, and\r\nslept anything but soundly upon it. Next day he went again to the\r\noffice and opened his mail, suspicious and hopeful of its contents. No\r\nword from Carrie. Nothing from his wife, which was pleasant.\r\n\r\nThe fact that he had sent the money and that she had received it worked\r\nto the ease of his mind, for, as the thought that he had done it\r\nreceded, his chagrin at it grew less and his hope of peace more. He\r\nfancied, as he sat at his desk, that nothing would be done for a week\r\nor two. Meanwhile, he would have time to think.\r\n\r\nThis process of _thinking_ began by a reversion to Carrie and the\r\narrangement by which he was to get her away from Drouet. How about that\r\nnow? His pain at her failure to meet or write him rapidly increased as\r\nhe devoted himself to this subject. He decided to write her care of the\r\nWest Side Post-office and ask for an explanation, as well as to have\r\nher meet him. The thought that this letter would probably not reach her\r\nuntil Monday chafed him exceedingly. He must get some speedier\r\nmethod\xe2\x80\x94but how?\r\n\r\nHe thought upon it for a half-hour, not contemplating a messenger or a\r\ncab direct to the house, owing to the exposure of it, but finding that\r\ntime was slipping away to no purpose, he wrote the letter and then\r\nbegan to think again.\r\n\r\nThe hours slipped by, and with them the possibility of the union he had\r\ncontemplated. He had thought to be joyously aiding Carrie by now in the\r\ntask of joining her interests to his, and here it was afternoon and\r\nnothing done. Three o\xe2\x80\x99clock came, four, five, six, and no letter. The\r\nhelpless manager paced the floor and grimly endured the gloom of\r\ndefeat. He saw a busy Saturday ushered out, the Sabbath in, and nothing\r\ndone. All day, the bar being closed, he brooded alone, shut out from\r\nhome, from the excitement of his resort, from Carrie, and without the\r\nability to alter his condition one iota. It was the worst Sunday he had\r\nspent in his life.\r\n\r\nIn Monday\xe2\x80\x99s second mail he encountered a very legal-looking letter,\r\nwhich held his interest for some time. It bore the imprint of the law\r\noffices of McGregor, James and Hay, and with a very formal \xe2\x80\x9cDear Sir,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nand \xe2\x80\x9cWe beg to state,\xe2\x80\x9d went on to inform him briefly that they had been\r\nretained by Mrs. Julia Hurstwood to adjust certain matters which\r\nrelated to her sustenance and property rights, and would he kindly call\r\nand see them about the matter at once.\r\n\r\nHe read it through carefully several times, and then merely shook his\r\nhead. It seemed as if his family troubles were just beginning.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell!\xe2\x80\x9d he said after a time, quite audibly, \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen he folded it up and put it in his pocket.\r\n\r\nTo add to his misery there was no word from Carrie. He was quite\r\ncertain now that she knew he was married and was angered at his\r\nperfidy. His loss seemed all the more bitter now that he needed her\r\nmost. He thought he would go out and insist on seeing her if she did\r\nnot send him word of some sort soon. He was really affected most\r\nmiserably of all by this desertion. He had loved her earnestly enough,\r\nbut now that the possibility of losing her stared him in the face she\r\nseemed much more attractive. He really pined for a word, and looked out\r\nupon her with his mind\xe2\x80\x99s eye in the most wistful manner. He did not\r\npropose to lose her, whatever she might think. Come what might, he\r\nwould adjust this matter, and soon. He would go to her and tell her all\r\nhis family complications. He would explain to her just where he stood\r\nand how much he needed her. Surely she couldn\xe2\x80\x99t go back on him now? It\r\nwasn\xe2\x80\x99t possible. He would plead until her anger would melt\xe2\x80\x94until she\r\nwould forgive him.\r\n\r\nSuddenly he thought: \xe2\x80\x9cSupposing she isn\xe2\x80\x99t out there\xe2\x80\x94suppose she has\r\ngone?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe was forced to take his feet. It was too much to think of and sit\r\nstill.\r\n\r\nNevertheless, his rousing availed him nothing.\r\n\r\nOn Tuesday it was the same way. He did manage to bring himself into the\r\nmood to go out to Carrie, but when he got in Ogden Place he thought he\r\nsaw a man watching him and went away. He did not go within a block of\r\nthe house.\r\n\r\nOne of the galling incidents of this visit was that he came back on a\r\nRandolph Street car, and without noticing arrived almost opposite the\r\nbuilding of the concern with which his son was connected. This sent a\r\npang through his heart. He had called on his boy there several times.\r\nNow the lad had not sent him a word. His absence did not seem to be\r\nnoticed by either of his children. Well, well, fortune plays a man\r\nqueer tricks. He got back to his office and joined in a conversation\r\nwith friends. It was as if idle chatter deadened the sense of misery.\r\n\r\nThat night he dined at Rector\xe2\x80\x99s and returned at once to his office. In\r\nthe bustle and show of the latter was his only relief. He troubled over\r\nmany little details and talked perfunctorily to everybody. He stayed at\r\nhis desk long after all others had gone, and only quitted it when the\r\nnight watchman on his round pulled at the front door to see if it was\r\nsafely locked.\r\n\r\nOn Wednesday he received another polite note from McGregor, James and\r\nHay. It read:\r\n\r\n     \xe2\x80\x9c_Dear Sir:_ We beg to inform you that we are instructed to wait\r\n     until to-morrow (Thursday) at one o\xe2\x80\x99clock, before filing suit\r\n     against you, on behalf of Mrs. Julia Hurstwood, for divorce and\r\n     alimony. If we do not hear from you before that time we shall\r\n     consider that you do not wish to compromise the matter in any way\r\n     and act accordingly.\r\n\r\n     \xe2\x80\x9cVery truly yours, etc.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCompromise!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Hurstwood bitterly. \xe2\x80\x9cCompromise!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAgain he shook his head.\r\n\r\nSo here it was spread out clear before him, and now he knew what to\r\nexpect. If he didn\xe2\x80\x99t go and see them they would sue him promptly. If he\r\ndid, he would be offered terms that would make his blood boil. He\r\nfolded the letter and put it with the other one. Then he put on his hat\r\nand went for a turn about the block.\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XXVI. THE AMBASSADOR FALLEN: A SEARCH FOR THE GATE\r\n\r\nCarrie, left alone by Drouet, listened to his retreating steps,\r\nscarcely realising what had happened. She knew that he had stormed out.\r\nIt was some moments before she questioned whether he would return, not\r\nnow exactly, but ever. She looked around her upon the rooms, out of\r\nwhich the evening light was dying, and wondered why she did not feel\r\nquite the same towards them. She went over to the dresser and struck a\r\nmatch, lighting the gas. Then she went back to the rocker to think.\r\n\r\nIt was some time before she could collect her thoughts, but when she\r\ndid, this truth began to take on importance. She was quite alone.\r\nSuppose Drouet did not come back? Suppose she should never hear\r\nanything more of him? This fine arrangement of chambers would not last\r\nlong. She would have to quit them.\r\n\r\nTo her credit, be it said, she never once counted on Hurstwood. She\r\ncould only approach that subject with a pang of sorrow and regret. For\r\na truth, she was rather shocked and frightened by this evidence of\r\nhuman depravity. He would have tricked her without turning an eyelash.\r\nShe would have been led into a newer and worse situation. And yet she\r\ncould not keep out the pictures of his looks and manners. Only this one\r\ndeed seemed strange and miserable. It contrasted sharply with all she\r\nfelt and knew concerning the man.\r\n\r\nBut she was alone. That was the greater thought just at present. How\r\nabout that? Would she go out to work again? Would she begin to look\r\naround in the business district? The stage! Oh, yes. Drouet had spoken\r\nabout that. Was there any hope there? She moved to and fro, in deep and\r\nvaried thoughts, while the minutes slipped away and night fell\r\ncompletely. She had had nothing to eat, and yet there she sat, thinking\r\nit over.\r\n\r\nShe remembered that she was hungry and went to the little cupboard in\r\nthe rear room where were the remains of one of their breakfasts. She\r\nlooked at these things with certain misgivings. The contemplation of\r\nfood had more significance than usual.\r\n\r\nWhile she was eating she began to wonder how much money she had. It\r\nstruck her as exceedingly important, and without ado she went to look\r\nfor her purse. It was on the dresser, and in it were seven dollars in\r\nbills and some change. She quailed as she thought of the insignificance\r\nof the amount and rejoiced because the rent was paid until the end of\r\nthe month. She began also to think what she would have done if she had\r\ngone out into the street when she first started. By the side of that\r\nsituation, as she looked at it now, the present seemed agreeable. She\r\nhad a little time at least, and then, perhaps, everything would come\r\nout all right, after all.\r\n\r\nDrouet had gone, but what of it? He did not seem seriously angry. He\r\nonly acted as if he were huffy. He would come back\xe2\x80\x94of course he would.\r\nThere was his cane in the corner. Here was one of his collars. He had\r\nleft his light overcoat in the wardrobe. She looked about and tried to\r\nassure herself with the sight of a dozen such details, but, alas, the\r\nsecondary thought arrived. Supposing he did come back. Then what?\r\n\r\nHere was another proposition nearly, if not quite, as disturbing. She\r\nwould have to talk with and explain to him. He would want her to admit\r\nthat he was right. It would be impossible for her to live with him.\r\n\r\nOn Friday Carrie remembered her appointment with Hurstwood, and the\r\npassing of the hour when she should, by all right of promise, have been\r\nin his company served to keep the calamity which had befallen her\r\nexceedingly fresh and clear. In her nervousness and stress of mind she\r\nfelt it necessary to act, and consequently put on a brown street dress,\r\nand at eleven o\xe2\x80\x99clock started to visit the business portion once again.\r\nShe must look for work.\r\n\r\nThe rain, which threatened at twelve and began at one, served equally\r\nwell to cause her to retrace her steps and remain within doors as it\r\ndid to reduce Hurstwood\xe2\x80\x99s spirits and give him a wretched day.\r\n\r\nThe morrow was Saturday, a half-holiday in many business quarters, and\r\nbesides it was a balmy, radiant day, with the trees and grass shining\r\nexceedingly green after the rain of the night before. When she went out\r\nthe sparrows were twittering merrily in joyous choruses. She could not\r\nhelp feeling, as she looked across the lovely park, that life was a\r\njoyous thing for those who did not need to worry, and she wished over\r\nand over that something might interfere now to preserve for her the\r\ncomfortable state which she had occupied. She did not want Drouet or\r\nhis money when she thought of it, nor anything more to do with\r\nHurstwood, but only the content and ease of mind she had experienced,\r\nfor, after all, she had been happy\xe2\x80\x94happier, at least, than she was now\r\nwhen confronted by the necessity of making her way alone.\r\n\r\nWhen she arrived in the business part it was quite eleven o\xe2\x80\x99clock, and\r\nthe business had little longer to run. She did not realise this at\r\nfirst, being affected by some of the old distress which was a result of\r\nher earlier adventure into this strenuous and exacting quarter. She\r\nwandered about, assuring herself that she was making up her mind to\r\nlook for something, and at the same time feeling that perhaps it was\r\nnot necessary to be in such haste about it. The thing was difficult to\r\nencounter, and she had a few days. Besides, she was not sure that she\r\nwas really face to face again with the bitter problem of\r\nself-sustenance. Anyhow, there was one change for the better. She knew\r\nthat she had improved in appearance. Her manner had vastly changed. Her\r\nclothes were becoming, and men\xe2\x80\x94well-dressed men, some of the kind who\r\nbefore had gazed at her indifferently from behind their polished\r\nrailings and imposing office partitions\xe2\x80\x94now gazed into her face with a\r\nsoft light in their eyes. In a way, she felt the power and satisfaction\r\nof the thing, but it did not wholly reassure her. She looked for\r\nnothing save what might come legitimately and without the appearance of\r\nspecial favour. She wanted something, but no man should buy her by\r\nfalse protestations or favour. She proposed to earn her living\r\nhonestly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis store closes at one on Saturdays,\xe2\x80\x9d was a pleasing and\r\nsatisfactory legend to see upon doors which she felt she ought to enter\r\nand inquire for work. It gave her an excuse, and after encountering\r\nquite a number of them, and noting that the clock registered 12.15, she\r\ndecided that it would be no use to seek further to-day, so she got on a\r\ncar and went to Lincoln Park. There was always something to see\r\nthere\xe2\x80\x94the flowers, the animals, the lake\xe2\x80\x94and she flattered herself that\r\non Monday she would be up betimes and searching. Besides, many things\r\nmight happen between now and Monday.\r\n\r\nSunday passed with equal doubts, worries, assurances, and heaven knows\r\nwhat vagaries of mind and spirit. Every half-hour in the day the\r\nthought would come to her most sharply, like the tail of a swishing\r\nwhip, that action\xe2\x80\x94immediate action\xe2\x80\x94was imperative. At other times she\r\nwould look about her and assure herself that things were not so\r\nbad\xe2\x80\x94that certainly she would come out safe and sound. At such times she\r\nwould think of Drouet\xe2\x80\x99s advice about going on the stage, and saw some\r\nchance for herself in that quarter. She decided to take up that\r\nopportunity on the morrow.\r\n\r\nAccordingly, she arose early Monday morning and dressed herself\r\ncarefully. She did not know just how such applications were made, but\r\nshe took it to be a matter which related more directly to the theatre\r\nbuildings. All you had to do was to inquire of some one about the\r\ntheatre for the manager and ask for a position. If there was anything,\r\nyou might get it, or, at least, he could tell you how.\r\n\r\nShe had had no experience with this class of individuals whatsoever,\r\nand did not know the salacity and humour of the theatrical tribe. She\r\nonly knew of the position which Mr. Hale occupied, but, of all things,\r\nshe did not wish to encounter that personage, on account of her\r\nintimacy with his wife.\r\n\r\nThere was, however, at this time, one theatre, the Chicago Opera House,\r\nwhich was considerably in the public eye, and its manager, David A.\r\nHenderson, had a fair local reputation. Carrie had seen one or two\r\nelaborate performances there and had heard of several others. She knew\r\nnothing of Henderson nor of the methods of applying, but she\r\ninstinctively felt that this would be a likely place, and accordingly\r\nstrolled about in that neighbourhood. She came bravely enough to the\r\nshowy entrance way, with the polished and begilded lobby, set with\r\nframed pictures out of the current attraction, leading up to the quiet\r\nbox-office, but she could get no further. A noted comic opera comedian\r\nwas holding forth that week, and the air of distinction and prosperity\r\noverawed her. She could not imagine that there would be anything in\r\nsuch a lofty sphere for her. She almost trembled at the audacity which\r\nmight have carried her on to a terrible rebuff. She could find heart\r\nonly to look at the pictures which were showy and then walk out. It\r\nseemed to her as if she had made a splendid escape and that it would be\r\nfoolhardy to think of applying in that quarter again.\r\n\r\nThis little experience settled her hunting for one day. She looked\r\naround elsewhere, but it was from the outside. She got the location of\r\nseveral playhouses fixed in her mind\xe2\x80\x94notably the Grand Opera House and\r\nMcVickar\xe2\x80\x99s, both of which were leading in attractions\xe2\x80\x94and then came\r\naway. Her spirits were materially reduced, owing to the newly restored\r\nsense of magnitude of the great interests and the insignificance of her\r\nclaims upon society, such as she understood them to be.\r\n\r\nThat night she was visited by Mrs. Hale, whose chatter and protracted\r\nstay made it impossible to dwell upon her predicament or the fortune of\r\nthe day. Before retiring, however, she sat down to think, and gave\r\nherself up to the most gloomy forebodings. Drouet had not put in an\r\nappearance. She had had no word from any quarter, she had spent a\r\ndollar of her precious sum in procuring food and paying car fare. It\r\nwas evident that she would not endure long. Besides, she had discovered\r\nno resource.\r\n\r\nIn this situation her thoughts went out to her sister in Van Buren\r\nStreet, whom she had not seen since the night of her flight, and to her\r\nhome at Columbia City, which seemed now a part of something that could\r\nnot be again. She looked for no refuge in that direction. Nothing but\r\nsorrow was brought her by thoughts of Hurstwood, which would return.\r\nThat he could have chosen to dupe her in so ready a manner seemed a\r\ncruel thing.\r\n\r\nTuesday came, and with it appropriate indecision and speculation. She\r\nwas in no mood, after her failure of the day before, to hasten forth\r\nupon her work-seeking errand, and yet she rebuked herself for what she\r\nconsidered her weakness the day before. Accordingly she started out to\r\nrevisit the Chicago Opera House, but possessed scarcely enough courage\r\nto approach.\r\n\r\nShe did manage to inquire at the box-office, however.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cManager of the company or the house?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the smartly dressed\r\nindividual who took care of the tickets. He was favourably impressed by\r\nCarrie\xe2\x80\x99s looks.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, taken back by the question.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou couldn\xe2\x80\x99t see the manager of the house to-day, anyhow,\xe2\x80\x9d volunteered\r\nthe young man. \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s out of town.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe noted her puzzled look, and then added: \xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it you wish to see\r\nabout?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI want to see about getting a position,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99d better see the manager of the company,\xe2\x80\x9d he returned, \xe2\x80\x9cbut he\r\nisn\xe2\x80\x99t here now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen will he be in?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Carrie, somewhat relieved by this\r\ninformation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you might find him in between eleven and twelve. He\xe2\x80\x99s here after\r\ntwo o\xe2\x80\x99clock.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie thanked him and walked briskly out, while the young man gazed\r\nafter her through one of the side windows of his gilded coop.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood-looking,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to himself, and proceeded to visions of\r\ncondescensions on her part which were exceedingly flattering to\r\nhimself.\r\n\r\nOne of the principal comedy companies of the day was playing an\r\nengagement at the Grand Opera House. Here Carrie asked to see the\r\nmanager of the company. She little knew the trivial authority of this\r\nindividual, or that had there been a vacancy an actor would have been\r\nsent on from New York to fill it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHis office is upstairs,\xe2\x80\x9d said a man in the box-office.\r\n\r\nSeveral persons were in the manager\xe2\x80\x99s office, two lounging near a\r\nwindow, another talking to an individual sitting at a roll-top desk\xe2\x80\x94the\r\nmanager. Carrie glanced nervously about, and began to fear that she\r\nshould have to make her appeal before the assembled company, two of\r\nwhom\xe2\x80\x94the occupants of the window\xe2\x80\x94were already observing her carefully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t do it,\xe2\x80\x9d the manager was saying; \xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99s a rule of Mr. Frohman\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nnever to allow visitors back of the stage. No, no!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie timidly waited, standing. There were chairs, but no one motioned\r\nher to be seated. The individual to whom the manager had been talking\r\nwent away quite crestfallen. That luminary gazed earnestly at some\r\npapers before him, as if they were of the greatest concern.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you see that in the \xe2\x80\x98Herald\xe2\x80\x99 this morning about Nat Goodwin,\r\nHarris?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said the person addressed. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat was it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMade quite a curtain address at Hooley\xe2\x80\x99s last night. Better look it\r\nup.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHarris reached over to a table and began to look for the \xe2\x80\x9cHerald.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it?\xe2\x80\x9d said the manager to Carrie, apparently noticing her for\r\nthe first time. He thought he was going to be held up for free tickets.\r\n\r\nCarrie summoned up all her courage, which was little at best. She\r\nrealised that she was a novice, and felt as if a rebuff were certain.\r\nOf this she was so sure that she only wished now to pretend she had\r\ncalled for advice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan you tell me how to go about getting on the stage?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was the best way after all to have gone about the matter. She was\r\ninteresting, in a manner, to the occupant of the chair, and the\r\nsimplicity of her request and attitude took his fancy. He smiled, as\r\ndid the others in the room, who, however, made some slight effort to\r\nconceal their humour.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered, looking her brazenly over. \xe2\x80\x9cHave you ever\r\nhad any experience upon the stage?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA little,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Carrie. \xe2\x80\x9cI have taken part in amateur\r\nperformances.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe thought she had to make some sort of showing in order to retain his\r\ninterest.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever studied for the stage?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, putting on an air intended as\r\nmuch to impress his friends with his discretion as Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered, tipping lazily back in his chair\r\nwhile she stood before him. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat makes you want to get on the stage?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe felt abashed at the man\xe2\x80\x99s daring, but could only smile in answer to\r\nhis engaging smirk, and say:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI need to make a living.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered, rather taken by her trim appearance, and feeling as\r\nif he might scrape up an acquaintance with her. \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s a good reason,\r\nisn\xe2\x80\x99t it? Well, Chicago is not a good place for what you want to do.\r\nYou ought to be in New York. There\xe2\x80\x99s more chance there. You could\r\nhardly expect to get started out here.\xe2\x80\x9d Carrie smiled genially,\r\ngrateful that he should condescend to advise her even so much. He\r\nnoticed the smile, and put a slightly different construction on it. He\r\nthought he saw an easy chance for a little flirtation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSit down,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, pulling a chair forward from the side of his desk\r\nand dropping his voice so that the two men in the room should not hear.\r\nThose two gave each other the suggestion of a wink.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I\xe2\x80\x99ll be going, Barney,\xe2\x80\x9d said one, breaking away and so\r\naddressing the manager. \xe2\x80\x9cSee you this afternoon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right,\xe2\x80\x9d said the manager.\r\n\r\nThe remaining individual took up a paper as if to read.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you have any idea what sort of part you would like to get?\xe2\x80\x9d asked\r\nthe manager softly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie. \xe2\x80\x9cI would take anything to begin with.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI see,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you live here in the city?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe manager smiled most blandly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you ever tried to get in as a chorus girl?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, assuming a\r\nmore confidential air.\r\n\r\nCarrie began to feel that there was something exuberant and unnatural\r\nin his manner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s the way most girls begin,\xe2\x80\x9d he went on, \xe2\x80\x9cwho go on the stage.\r\nIt\xe2\x80\x99s a good way to get experience.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe was turning on her a glance of the companionable and persuasive\r\nmanner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI didn\xe2\x80\x99t know that,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a difficult thing,\xe2\x80\x9d he went on, \xe2\x80\x9cbut there\xe2\x80\x99s always a chance, you\r\nknow.\xe2\x80\x9d Then, as if he suddenly remembered, he pulled out his watch and\r\nconsulted it. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve an appointment at two,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cand I\xe2\x80\x99ve got to\r\ngo to lunch now. Would you care to come and dine with me? We can talk\r\nit over there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, the whole motive of the man flashing on her at\r\nonce. \xe2\x80\x9cI have an engagement myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s too bad,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, realising that he had been a little\r\nbeforehand in his offer and that Carrie was about to go away. \xe2\x80\x9cCome in\r\nlater. I may know of something.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered, with some trepidation and went out.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe was good-looking, wasn\xe2\x80\x99t she?\xe2\x80\x9d said the manager\xe2\x80\x99s companion, who\r\nhad not caught all the details of the game he had played.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, in a way,\xe2\x80\x9d said the other, sore to think the game had been lost.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe\xe2\x80\x99d never make an actress, though. Just another chorus girl\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nall.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis little experience nearly destroyed her ambition to call upon the\r\nmanager at the Chicago Opera House, but she decided to do so after a\r\ntime. He was of a more sedate turn of mind. He said at once that there\r\nwas no opening of any sort, and seemed to consider her search foolish.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cChicago is no place to get a start,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cYou ought to be in New\r\nYork.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nStill she persisted, and went to McVickar\xe2\x80\x99s, where she could not find\r\nany one. \xe2\x80\x9cThe Old Homestead\xe2\x80\x9d was running there, but the person to whom\r\nshe was referred was not to be found.\r\n\r\nThese little expeditions took up her time until quite four o\xe2\x80\x99clock,\r\nwhen she was weary enough to go home. She felt as if she ought to\r\ncontinue and inquire elsewhere, but the results so far were too\r\ndispiriting. She took the car and arrived at Ogden Place in\r\nthree-quarters of an hour, but decided to ride on to the West Side\r\nbranch of the Post-office, where she was accustomed to receive\r\nHurstwood\xe2\x80\x99s letters. There was one there now, written Saturday, which\r\nshe tore open and read with mingled feelings. There was so much warmth\r\nin it and such tense complaint at her having failed to meet him, and\r\nher subsequent silence, that she rather pitied the man. That he loved\r\nher was evident enough. That he had wished and dared to do so, married\r\nas he was, was the evil. She felt as if the thing deserved an answer,\r\nand consequently decided that she would write and let him know that she\r\nknew of his married state and was justly incensed at his deception. She\r\nwould tell him that it was all over between them.\r\n\r\nAt her room, the wording of this missive occupied her for some time,\r\nfor she fell to the task at once. It was most difficult.\r\n\r\n     \xe2\x80\x9cYou do not need to have me explain why I did not meet you,\xe2\x80\x9d she\r\n     wrote in part. \xe2\x80\x9cHow could you deceive me so? You cannot expect me\r\n     to have anything more to do with you. I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t under any\r\n     circumstances. Oh, how could you act so?\xe2\x80\x9d she added in a burst of\r\n     feeling. \xe2\x80\x9cYou have caused me more misery than you can think. I\r\n     hope you will get over your infatuation for me. We must not meet\r\n     any more. Good-bye.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nShe took the letter the next morning, and at the corner dropped it\r\nreluctantly into the letter-box, still uncertain as to whether she\r\nshould do so or not. Then she took the car and went down town.\r\n\r\nThis was the dull season with the department stores, but she was\r\nlistened to with more consideration than was usually accorded to young\r\nwomen applicants, owing to her neat and attractive appearance. She was\r\nasked the same old questions with which she was already familiar.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat can you do? Have you ever worked in a retail store before? Are\r\nyou experienced?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt The Fair, See and Company\xe2\x80\x99s, and all the great stores it was much\r\nthe same. It was the dull season, she might come in a little later,\r\npossibly they would like to have her.\r\n\r\nWhen she arrived at the house at the end of the day, weary and\r\ndisheartened, she discovered that Drouet had been there. His umbrella\r\nand light overcoat were gone. She thought she missed other things, but\r\ncould not be sure. Everything had not been taken.\r\n\r\nSo his going was crystallising into staying. What was she to do now?\r\nEvidently she would be facing the world in the same old way within a\r\nday or two. Her clothes would get poor. She put her two hands together\r\nin her customary expressive way and pressed her fingers. Large tears\r\ngathered in her eyes and broke hot across her cheeks. She was alone,\r\nvery much alone.\r\n\r\nDrouet really had called, but it was with a very different mind from\r\nthat which Carrie had imagined. He expected to find her, to justify his\r\nreturn by claiming that he came to get the remaining portion of his\r\nwardrobe, and before he got away again to patch up a peace.\r\n\r\nAccordingly, when he arrived, he was disappointed to find Carrie out.\r\nHe trifled about, hoping that she was somewhere in the neighbourhood\r\nand would soon return. He constantly listened, expecting to hear her\r\nfoot on the stair.\r\n\r\nWhen he did so, it was his intention to make believe that he had just\r\ncome in and was disturbed at being caught. Then he would explain his\r\nneed of his clothes and find out how things stood.\r\n\r\nWait as he did, however, Carrie did not come. From pottering around\r\namong the drawers, in momentary expectation of her arrival he changed\r\nto looking out of the window, and from that to resting himself in the\r\nrocking-chair. Still no Carrie. He began to grow restless and lit a\r\ncigar. After that he walked the floor. Then he looked out of the window\r\nand saw clouds gathering. He remembered an appointment at three. He\r\nbegan to think that it would be useless to wait, and got hold of his\r\numbrella and light coat, intending to take these things, any way. It\r\nwould scare her, he hoped. To-morrow he would come back for the others.\r\nHe would find out how things stood.\r\n\r\nAs he started to go he felt truly sorry that he had missed her. There\r\nwas a little picture of her on the wall, showing her arrayed in the\r\nlittle jacket he had first bought her\xe2\x80\x94her face a little more wistful\r\nthan he had seen it lately. He was really touched by it, and looked\r\ninto the eyes of it with a rather rare feeling for him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou didn\xe2\x80\x99t do me right, Cad,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, as if he were addressing her in\r\nthe flesh.\r\n\r\nThen he went to the door, took a good look around and went out.\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XXVII. WHEN WATERS ENGULF US WE REACH FOR A STAR\r\n\r\nIt was when he returned from his disturbed stroll about the streets,\r\nafter receiving the decisive note from McGregor, James and Hay, that\r\nHurstwood found the letter Carrie had written him that morning. He\r\nthrilled intensely as he noted the handwriting, and rapidly tore it\r\nopen.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought, \xe2\x80\x9cshe loves me or she would not have written to me\r\nat all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe was slightly depressed at the tenor of the note for the first few\r\nminutes, but soon recovered. \xe2\x80\x9cShe wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t write at all if she didn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ncare for me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis was his one resource against the depression which held him. He\r\ncould extract little from the wording of the letter, but the spirit he\r\nthought he knew.\r\n\r\nThere was really something exceedingly human\xe2\x80\x94if not pathetic\xe2\x80\x94in his\r\nbeing thus relieved by a clearly worded reproof. He who had for so long\r\nremained satisfied with himself now looked outside of himself for\r\ncomfort\xe2\x80\x94and to such a source. The mystic cords of affection! How they\r\nbind us all.\r\n\r\nThe colour came to his cheeks. For the moment he forgot the letter from\r\nMcGregor, James and Hay. If he could only have Carrie, perhaps he could\r\nget out of the whole entanglement\xe2\x80\x94perhaps it would not matter. He\r\nwouldn\xe2\x80\x99t care what his wife did with herself if only he might not lose\r\nCarrie. He stood up and walked about, dreaming his delightful dream of\r\na life continued with this lovely possessor of his heart.\r\n\r\nIt was not long, however, before the old worry was back for\r\nconsideration, and with it what weariness! He thought of the morrow and\r\nthe suit. He had done nothing, and here was the afternoon slipping\r\naway. It was now a quarter of four. At five the attorneys would have\r\ngone home. He still had the morrow until noon. Even as he thought, the\r\nlast fifteen minutes passed away and it was five. Then he abandoned the\r\nthought of seeing them any more that day and turned to Carrie.\r\n\r\nIt is to be observed that the man did not justify himself to himself.\r\nHe was not troubling about that. His whole thought was the possibility\r\nof persuading Carrie. Nothing was wrong in that. He loved her dearly.\r\nTheir mutual happiness depended upon it. Would that Drouet were only\r\naway!\r\n\r\nWhile he was thinking thus elatedly, he remembered that he wanted some\r\nclean linen in the morning.\r\n\r\nThis he purchased, together with a half-dozen ties, and went to the\r\nPalmer House. As he entered he thought he saw Drouet ascending the\r\nstairs with a key. Surely not Drouet! Then he thought, perhaps they had\r\nchanged their abode temporarily. He went straight up to the desk.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs Mr. Drouet stopping here?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked of the clerk.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think he is,\xe2\x80\x9d said the latter, consulting his private registry list.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs that so?\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Hurstwood, otherwise concealing his\r\nastonishment. \xe2\x80\x9cAlone?\xe2\x80\x9d he added.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said the clerk.\r\n\r\nHurstwood turned away and set his lips so as best to express and\r\nconceal his feelings.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow\xe2\x80\x99s that?\xe2\x80\x9d he thought. \xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99ve had a row.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe hastened to his room with rising spirits and changed his linen. As\r\nhe did so, he made up his mind that if Carrie was alone, or if she had\r\ngone to another place, it behooved him to find out. He decided to call\r\nat once.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know what I\xe2\x80\x99ll do,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll go to the door and ask if Mr.\r\nDrouet is at home. That will bring out whether he is there or not and\r\nwhere Carrie is.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe was almost moved to some muscular display as he thought of it. He\r\ndecided to go immediately after supper.\r\n\r\nOn coming down from his room at six, he looked carefully about to see\r\nif Drouet was present and then went out to lunch. He could scarcely\r\neat, however, he was so anxious to be about his errand. Before starting\r\nhe thought it well to discover where Drouet would be, and returned to\r\nhis hotel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHas Mr. Drouet gone out?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked of the clerk.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the latter, \xe2\x80\x9che\xe2\x80\x99s in his room. Do you wish to send up a\r\ncard?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I\xe2\x80\x99ll call around later,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Hurstwood, and strolled out.\r\n\r\nHe took a Madison car and went direct to Ogden Place this time walking\r\nboldly up to the door. The chambermaid answered his knock.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs Mr. Drouet in?\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood blandly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is out of the city,\xe2\x80\x9d said the girl, who had heard Carrie tell this\r\nto Mrs. Hale.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs Mrs. Drouet in?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, she has gone to the theatre.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs that so?\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood, considerably taken back; then, as if\r\nburdened with something important, \xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t know to which theatre?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe girl really had no idea where she had gone, but not liking\r\nHurstwood, and wishing to cause him trouble, answered: \xe2\x80\x9cYes, Hooley\xe2\x80\x99s.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the manager, and, tipping his hat slightly, went\r\naway.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll look in at Hooley\xe2\x80\x99s,\xe2\x80\x9d thought he, but as a matter of fact he did\r\nnot. Before he had reached the central portion of the city he thought\r\nthe whole matter over and decided it would be useless. As much as he\r\nlonged to see Carrie, he knew she would be with some one and did not\r\nwish to intrude with his plea there. A little later he might do so\xe2\x80\x94in\r\nthe morning. Only in the morning he had the lawyer question before him.\r\n\r\nThis little pilgrimage threw quite a wet blanket upon his rising\r\nspirits. He was soon down again to his old worry, and reached the\r\nresort anxious to find relief. Quite a company of gentlemen were making\r\nthe place lively with their conversation. A group of Cook County\r\npoliticians were conferring about a round cherry-wood table in the rear\r\nportion of the room. Several young merrymakers were chattering at the\r\nbar before making a belated visit to the theatre. A shabbily-genteel\r\nindividual, with a red nose and an old high hat, was sipping a quiet\r\nglass of ale alone at one end of the bar. Hurstwood nodded to the\r\npoliticians and went into his office.\r\n\r\nAbout ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock a friend of his, Mr. Frank L. Taintor, a local sport\r\nand racing man, dropped in, and seeing Hurstwood alone in his office\r\ncame to the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHello, George!\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow are you, Frank?\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood, somewhat relieved by the sight of\r\nhim. \xe2\x80\x9cSit down,\xe2\x80\x9d and he motioned him to one of the chairs in the little\r\nroom.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the matter, George?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Taintor. \xe2\x80\x9cYou look a little glum.\r\nHaven\xe2\x80\x99t lost at the track, have you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m not feeling very well to-night. I had a slight cold the other\r\nday.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake whiskey, George,\xe2\x80\x9d said Taintor. \xe2\x80\x9cYou ought to know that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHurstwood smiled.\r\n\r\nWhile they were still conferring there, several other of Hurstwood\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nfriends entered, and not long after eleven, the theatres being out,\r\nsome actors began to drop in\xe2\x80\x94among them some notabilities.\r\n\r\nThen began one of those pointless social conversations so common in\r\nAmerican resorts where the would-be _gilded_ attempt to rub off gilt\r\nfrom those who have it in abundance. If Hurstwood had one leaning, it\r\nwas toward notabilities. He considered that, if anywhere, he belonged\r\namong them. He was too proud to toady, too keen not to strictly observe\r\nthe plane he occupied when there were those present who did not\r\nappreciate him, but, in situations like the present, where he could\r\nshine as a gentleman and be received without equivocation as a friend\r\nand equal among men of known ability, he was most delighted. It was on\r\nsuch occasions, if ever, that he would \xe2\x80\x9ctake something.\xe2\x80\x9d When the\r\nsocial flavour was strong enough he would even unbend to the extent of\r\ndrinking glass for glass with his associates, punctiliously observing\r\nhis turn to pay as if he were an outsider like the others. If he ever\r\napproached intoxication\xe2\x80\x94or rather that ruddy warmth and comfortableness\r\nwhich precedes the more sloven state\xe2\x80\x94it was when individuals such as\r\nthese were gathered about him, when he was one of a circle of chatting\r\ncelebrities. To-night, disturbed as was his state, he was rather\r\nrelieved to find company, and now that notabilities were gathered, he\r\nlaid aside his troubles for the nonce, and joined in right heartily.\r\n\r\nIt was not long before the imbibing began to tell. Stories began to\r\ncrop up\xe2\x80\x94those ever-enduring, droll stories which form the major portion\r\nof the conversation among American men under such circumstances.\r\n\r\nTwelve o\xe2\x80\x99clock arrived, the hour for closing, and with it the company\r\ntook leave. Hurstwood shook hands with them most cordially. He was very\r\nroseate physically. He had arrived at that state where his mind, though\r\nclear, was, nevertheless, warm in its fancies. He felt as if his\r\ntroubles were not very serious. Going into his office, he began to turn\r\nover certain accounts, awaiting the departure of the bartenders and the\r\ncashier, who soon left.\r\n\r\nIt was the manager\xe2\x80\x99s duty, as well as his custom, after all were gone\r\nto see that everything was safely closed up for the night. As a rule,\r\nno money except the cash taken in after banking hours was kept about\r\nthe place, and that was locked in the safe by the cashier, who, with\r\nthe owners, was joint keeper of the secret combination, but,\r\nnevertheless, Hurstwood nightly took the precaution to try the cash\r\ndrawers and the safe in order to see that they were tightly closed.\r\nThen he would lock his own little office and set the proper light\r\nburning near the safe, after which he would take his departure.\r\n\r\nNever in his experience had he found anything out of order, but\r\nto-night, after shutting down his desk, he came out and tried the safe.\r\nHis way was to give a sharp pull. This time the door responded. He was\r\nslightly surprised at that, and looking in found the money cases as\r\nleft for the day, apparently unprotected. His first thought was, of\r\ncourse, to inspect the drawers and shut the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll speak to Mayhew about this to-morrow,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought.\r\n\r\nThe latter had certainly imagined upon going out a half-hour before\r\nthat he had turned the knob on the door so as to spring the lock. He\r\nhad never failed to do so before. But to-night Mayhew had other\r\nthoughts. He had been revolving the problem of a business of his own.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll look in here,\xe2\x80\x9d thought the manager, pulling out the money\r\ndrawers. He did not know why he wished to look in there. It was quite a\r\nsuperfluous action, which another time might not have happened at all.\r\n\r\nAs he did so, a layer of bills, in parcels of a thousand, such as banks\r\nissue, caught his eye. He could not tell how much they represented, but\r\npaused to view them. Then he pulled out the second of the cash drawers.\r\nIn that were the receipts of the day.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI didn\xe2\x80\x99t know Fitzgerald and Moy ever left any money this way,\xe2\x80\x9d his\r\nmind said to itself. \xe2\x80\x9cThey must have forgotten it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe looked at the other drawer and paused again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCount them,\xe2\x80\x9d said a voice in his ear.\r\n\r\nHe put his hand into the first of the boxes and lifted the stack,\r\nletting the separate parcels fall. They were bills of fifty and one\r\nhundred dollars done in packages of a thousand. He thought he counted\r\nten such.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy don\xe2\x80\x99t I shut the safe?\xe2\x80\x9d his mind said to itself, lingering. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat\r\nmakes me pause here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFor answer there came the strangest words:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you ever have ten thousand dollars in ready money?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLo, the manager remembered that he had never had so much. All his\r\nproperty had been slowly accumulated, and now his wife owned that. He\r\nwas worth more than forty thousand, all told\xe2\x80\x94but she would get that.\r\n\r\nHe puzzled as he thought of these things, then pushed in the drawers\r\nand closed the door, pausing with his hand upon the knob, which might\r\nso easily lock it all beyond temptation. Still he paused. Finally he\r\nwent to the windows and pulled down the curtains. Then he tried the\r\ndoor, which he had previously locked. What was this thing, making him\r\nsuspicious? Why did he wish to move about so quietly. He came back to\r\nthe end of the counter as if to rest his arm and think. Then he went\r\nand unlocked his little office door and turned on the light. He also\r\nopened his desk, sitting down before it, only to think strange\r\nthoughts.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe safe is open,\xe2\x80\x9d said a voice. \xe2\x80\x9cThere is just the least little crack\r\nin it. The lock has not been sprung.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe manager floundered among a jumble of thoughts. Now all the\r\nentanglement of the day came back. Also the thought that here was a\r\nsolution. That money would do it. If he had that and Carrie. He rose up\r\nand stood stock-still, looking at the floor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat about it?\xe2\x80\x9d his mind asked, and for answer he put his hand slowly\r\nup and scratched his head.\r\n\r\nThe manager was no fool to be led blindly away by such an errant\r\nproposition as this, but his situation was peculiar. Wine was in his\r\nveins. It had crept up into his head and given him a warm view of the\r\nsituation. It also coloured the possibilities of ten thousand for him.\r\nHe could see great opportunities with that. He could get Carrie. Oh,\r\nyes, he could! He could get rid of his wife. That letter, too, was\r\nwaiting discussion to-morrow morning. He would not need to answer that.\r\nHe went back to the safe and put his hand on the knob. Then he pulled\r\nthe door open and took the drawer with the money quite out.\r\n\r\nWith it once out and before him, it seemed a foolish thing to think\r\nabout leaving it. Certainly it would. Why, he could live quietly with\r\nCarrie for years.\r\n\r\nLord! what was that? For the first time he was tense, as if a stern\r\nhand had been laid upon his shoulder. He looked fearfully around. Not a\r\nsoul was present. Not a sound. Some one was shuffling by on the\r\nsidewalk. He took the box and the money and put it back in the safe.\r\nThen he partly closed the door again.\r\n\r\nTo those who have never wavered in conscience, the predicament of the\r\nindividual whose mind is less strongly constituted and who trembles in\r\nthe balance between duty and desire is scarcely appreciable, unless\r\ngraphically portrayed. Those who have never heard that solemn voice of\r\nthe ghostly clock which ticks with awful distinctness, \xe2\x80\x9cthou shalt,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthou shalt not,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cthou shalt,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cthou shalt not,\xe2\x80\x9d are in no position to\r\njudge. Not alone in sensitive, highly organised natures is such a\r\nmental conflict possible. The dullest specimen of humanity, when drawn\r\nby desire toward evil, is recalled by a sense of right, which is\r\nproportionate in power and strength to his evil tendency. We must\r\nremember that it may not be a knowledge of right, for no knowledge of\r\nright is predicated of the animal\xe2\x80\x99s instinctive recoil at evil. Men are\r\nstill led by instinct before they are regulated by knowledge. It is\r\ninstinct which recalls the criminal\xe2\x80\x94it is instinct (where highly\r\norganised reasoning is absent) which gives the criminal his feeling of\r\ndanger, his fear of wrong.\r\n\r\nAt every first adventure, then, into some untried evil, the mind\r\nwavers. The clock of thought ticks out its wish and its denial. To\r\nthose who have never experienced such a mental dilemma, the following\r\nwill appeal on the simple ground of revelation.\r\n\r\nWhen Hurstwood put the money back, his nature again resumed its ease\r\nand daring. No one had observed him. He was quite alone. No one could\r\ntell what he wished to do. He could work this thing out for himself.\r\n\r\nThe imbibation of the evening had not yet worn off. Moist as was his\r\nbrow, tremble as did his hand once after the nameless fright, he was\r\nstill flushed with the fumes of liquor. He scarcely noticed that the\r\ntime was passing. He went over his situation once again, his eye always\r\nseeing the money in a lump, his mind always seeing what it would do. He\r\nstrolled into his little room, then to the door, then to the safe\r\nagain. He put his hand on the knob and opened it. There was the money!\r\nSurely no harm could come from looking at it!\r\n\r\nHe took out the drawer again and lifted the bills. They were so smooth,\r\nso compact, so portable. How little they made, after all. He decided he\r\nwould take them. Yes, he would. He would put them in his pocket. Then\r\nhe looked at that and saw they would not go there. His hand satchel! To\r\nbe sure, his hand satchel. They would go in that\xe2\x80\x94all of it would. No\r\none would think anything of it either. He went into the little office\r\nand took it from the shelf in the corner. Now he set it upon his desk\r\nand went out toward the safe. For some reason he did not want to fill\r\nit out in the big room. First he brought the bills and then the loose\r\nreceipts of the day. He would take it all. He put the empty drawers\r\nback and pushed the iron door almost to, then stood beside it\r\nmeditating.\r\n\r\nThe wavering of a mind under such circumstances is an almost\r\ninexplicable thing, and yet it is absolutely true. Hurstwood could not\r\nbring himself to act definitely. He wanted to think about it\xe2\x80\x94to ponder\r\nover it, to decide whether it were best. He was drawn by such a keen\r\ndesire for Carrie, driven by such a state of turmoil in his own affairs\r\nthat he thought constantly it would be best, and yet he wavered. He did\r\nnot know what evil might result from it to him\xe2\x80\x94how soon he might come\r\nto grief. The true ethics of the situation never once occurred to him,\r\nand never would have, under any circumstances.\r\n\r\nAfter he had all the money in the handbag, a revulsion of feeling\r\nseized him. He would not do it\xe2\x80\x94no! Think of what a scandal it would\r\nmake. The police! They would be after him. He would have to fly, and\r\nwhere? Oh, the terror of being a fugitive from justice! He took out the\r\ntwo boxes and put all the money back. In his excitement he forgot what\r\nhe was doing, and put the sums in the wrong boxes. As he pushed the\r\ndoor to, he thought he remembered doing it wrong and opened the door\r\nagain. There were the two boxes mixed.\r\n\r\nHe took them out and straightened the matter, but now the terror had\r\ngone. Why be afraid?\r\n\r\nWhile the money was in his hand the lock clicked. It had sprung! Did he\r\ndo it? He grabbed at the knob and pulled vigorously. It had closed.\r\nHeavens! he was in for it now, sure enough.\r\n\r\nThe moment he realised that the safe was locked for a surety, the sweat\r\nburst out upon his brow and he trembled violently. He looked about him\r\nand decided instantly. There was no delaying now.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSupposing I do lay it on the top,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cand go away, they\xe2\x80\x99ll know\r\nwho took it. I\xe2\x80\x99m the last to close up. Besides, other things will\r\nhappen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt once he became the man of action.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI must get out of this,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought.\r\n\r\nHe hurried into his little room, took down his light overcoat and hat,\r\nlocked his desk, and grabbed the satchel. Then he turned out all but\r\none light and opened the door. He tried to put on his old assured air,\r\nbut it was almost gone. He was repenting rapidly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish I hadn\xe2\x80\x99t done that,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cThat was a mistake.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe walked steadily down the street, greeting a night watchman whom he\r\nknew who was trying doors. He must get out of the city, and that\r\nquickly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wonder how the trains run?\xe2\x80\x9d he thought.\r\n\r\nInstantly he pulled out his watch and looked. It was nearly half-past\r\none.\r\n\r\nAt the first drugstore he stopped, seeing a long-distance telephone\r\nbooth inside. It was a famous drugstore, and contained one of the first\r\nprivate telephone booths ever erected. \xe2\x80\x9cI want to use your \xe2\x80\x99phone a\r\nminute,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to the night clerk.\r\n\r\nThe latter nodded.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGive me 1643,\xe2\x80\x9d he called to Central, after looking up the Michigan\r\nCentral depot number. Soon he got the ticket agent.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow do the trains leave here for Detroit?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\nThe man explained the hours.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo more to-night?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing with a sleeper. Yes, there is, too,\xe2\x80\x9d he added. \xe2\x80\x9cThere is a\r\nmail train out of here at three o\xe2\x80\x99clock.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat time does that get to Detroit?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe was thinking if he could only get there and cross the river into\r\nCanada, he could take his time about getting to Montreal. He was\r\nrelieved to learn that it would reach there by noon.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMayhew won\xe2\x80\x99t open the safe till nine,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought. \xe2\x80\x9cThey can\xe2\x80\x99t get on\r\nmy track before noon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen he thought of Carrie. With what speed must he get her, if he got\r\nher at all. She would have to come along. He was very\r\nmuch disturbed over his own situation, and now that he had Carrie with\r\nhim, he only wanted to get safely out of reach of the law. As the train had only recently been made up and few\r\npassengers were expected, there were only one or two brakemen waiting.\r\nThey entered the rear day coach and sat down. Almost immediately, \xe2\x80\x9cAll\r\naboard,\xe2\x80\x9d resounded faintly from the outside, and the train started.\r\n\r\nCarrie began to think it was a little bit curious\xe2\x80\x94this going to a\r\ndepot\xe2\x80\x94but said nothing. The whole incident was so out of the natural\r\nthat she did not attach too much weight to anything she imagined.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow have you been?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Hurstwood gently, for he now breathed\r\neasier.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, who was so disturbed that she could not bring\r\na proper attitude to bear in the matter. She was still nervous to reach\r\nDrouet and see what could be the matter. Hurstwood contemplated her and\r\nfelt this. He was not disturbed that it should be so. They\r\nwere locking the vestibules and putting the cars in order for a long\r\nrun.\r\n\r\nPresently it began to gain speed, and Carrie saw the silent streets\r\nflashing by in rapid succession. He clutched her hand nervously and pressed\r\nit with all the force of an appeal.\r\n\r\nThe train was now all but stopped. It was running by some cars on a\r\nside track. Everything outside was dark and dreary. A few sprinkles on\r\nthe window began to indicate that it was raining. Carrie hung in a\r\nquandary, balancing between decision and helplessness. Now the train\r\nstopped, and she was listening to his plea. The engine backed a few\r\nfeet and all was still.\r\n\r\nShe wavered, totally unable to make a move. Minute after minute slipped\r\nby and still she hesitated, he pleading.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill you let me come back if I want to?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked, as if she now had\r\nthe upper hand and her companion was utterly subdued.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered, \xe2\x80\x9cyou know I will.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie only listened as one who has granted a temporary amnesty. She\r\nbegan to feel as if the matter were in her hands entirely.\r\n\r\nThe train was again in rapid motion. Hurstwood changed the subject.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAren\xe2\x80\x99t you very tired?\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWon\xe2\x80\x99t you let me get you a berth in the sleeper?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe shook her head, though for all her distress and his trickery she\r\nwas beginning to notice what she had always felt\xe2\x80\x94his thoughtfulness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cyou will feel so much better.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe shook her head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet me fix my coat for you, anyway,\xe2\x80\x9d and he arose and arranged his\r\nlight coat in a comfortable position to receive her head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere,\xe2\x80\x9d he said tenderly, \xe2\x80\x9cnow see if you can\xe2\x80\x99t rest a little.\xe2\x80\x9d He\r\ncould have kissed her for her compliance. He took his seat beside her\r\nand thought a moment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI believe we\xe2\x80\x99re in for a heavy rain,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo it looks,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, whose nerves were quieting under the sound\r\nof the rain drops, driven by a gusty wind, as the train swept on\r\nfrantically through the shadow to a newer world.\r\n\r\nThe fact that he had in a measure mollified Carrie was a source of\r\nsatisfaction to Hurstwood, but it furnished only the most temporary\r\nrelief. Now that her opposition was out of the way, he had all of his\r\ntime to devote to the consideration of his own error.\r\n\r\nHis condition was bitter in the extreme, for he did not want the\r\nmiserable sum he had stolen. He did not want to be a thief. That sum or\r\nany other could never compensate for the state which he had thus\r\nfoolishly doffed. It could not give him back his host of friends, his\r\nname, his house and family, nor Carrie, as he had meant to have her. He\r\nwas shut out from Chicago\xe2\x80\x94from his easy, comfortable state. He had\r\nrobbed himself of his dignity, his merry meetings, his pleasant\r\nevenings. And for what? The more he thought of it the more unbearable\r\nit became. He began to think that he would try and restore himself to\r\nhis old state. He would return the miserable thievings of the night and\r\nexplain. Perhaps Moy would understand. Perhaps they would forgive him\r\nand let him come back.\r\n\r\nBy noontime the train rolled into Detroit and he began to feel\r\nexceedingly nervous. The police must be on his track by now. They had\r\nprobably notified all the police of the big cities, and detectives\r\nwould be watching for him. He remembered instances in which defaulters\r\nhad been captured. Consequently, he breathed heavily and paled\r\nsomewhat. His hands felt as if they must have something to do. He\r\nsimulated interest in several scenes without which he did not feel. He\r\nrepeatedly beat his foot upon the floor.\r\n\r\nCarrie noticed his agitation, but said nothing. She had no idea what it\r\nmeant or that it was important.\r\n\r\nHe wondered now why he had not asked whether this train went on through\r\nto Montreal or some Canadian point. Perhaps he could have saved time.\r\nHe jumped up and sought the conductor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoes any part of this train go to Montreal?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, the next sleeper back does.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe would have asked more, but it did not seem wise, so he decided to\r\ninquire at the depot.\r\n\r\nThe train rolled into the yards, clanging and puffing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think we had better go right on through to Montreal,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to\r\nCarrie. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll see what the connections are when we get off.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe was exceedingly nervous, but did his best to put on a calm exterior.\r\nCarrie only looked at him with large, troubled eyes. She was drifting\r\nmentally, unable to say to herself what to do.\r\n\r\nThe train stopped and Hurstwood led the way out. He looked warily\r\naround him, pretending to look after Carrie. Seeing nothing that\r\nindicated studied observation, he made his way to the ticket office.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe next train for Montreal leaves when?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn twenty minutes,\xe2\x80\x9d said the man.\r\n\r\nHe bought two tickets and Pullman berths. Then he hastened back to\r\nCarrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe go right out again,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, scarcely noticing that Carrie looked\r\ntired and weary.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish I was out of all this,\xe2\x80\x9d she exclaimed gloomily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ll feel better when we reach Montreal,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI haven\xe2\x80\x99t an earthly thing with me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie; \xe2\x80\x9cnot even a\r\nhandkerchief.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou can buy all you want as soon as you get there, dearest,\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nexplained. \xe2\x80\x9cYou can call in a dressmaker.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNow the crier called the train ready and they got on. Hurstwood\r\nbreathed a sigh of relief as it started. There was a short run to the\r\nriver, and there they were ferried over. They had barely pulled the\r\ntrain off the ferry-boat when he settled back with a sigh.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt won\xe2\x80\x99t be so very long now,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, remembering her in his relief.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe get there the first thing in the morning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie scarcely deigned to reply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll see if there is a dining-car,\xe2\x80\x9d he added. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m hungry.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XXIX. THE SOLACE OF TRAVEL: THE BOATS OF THE SEA\r\n\r\nTo the untravelled, territory other than their own familiar heath is\r\ninvariably fascinating. Next to love, it is the one thing which solaces\r\nand delights. Things new are too important to be neglected, and mind,\r\nwhich is a mere reflection of sensory impressions, succumbs to the\r\nflood of objects. Thus lovers are forgotten, sorrows laid aside, death\r\nhidden from view. There is a world of accumulated feeling back of the\r\ntrite dramatic expression\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI am going away.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs Carrie looked out upon the flying scenery she almost forgot that she\r\nhad been tricked into this long journey against her will and that she\r\nwas without the necessary apparel for travelling. She quite forgot\r\nHurstwood\xe2\x80\x99s presence at times, and looked away to homely farmhouses and\r\ncosey cottages in villages with wondering eyes. It was an interesting\r\nworld to her.
