Her life had just begun. She did not feel herself\r\ndefeated at all. Neither was she blasted in hope. The great city held\r\nmuch. Possibly she would come out of bondage into freedom\xe2\x80\x94who knows?\r\nPerhaps she would be happy. These thoughts raised her above the level\r\nof erring. She was saved in that she was hopeful.\r\n\r\nThe following morning the train pulled safely into Montreal and they\r\nstepped down, Hurstwood glad to be out of danger, Carrie wondering at\r\nthe novel atmosphere of the northern city. Long before, Hurstwood had\r\nbeen here, and now he remembered the name of the hotel at which he had\r\nstopped. As they came out of the main entrance of the depot he heard it\r\ncalled anew by a busman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ll go right up and get rooms,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\nAt the clerk\xe2\x80\x99s office Hurstwood swung the register about while the\r\nclerk came forward. He was thinking what name he would put down. With\r\nthe latter before him he found no time for hesitation. A name he had\r\nseen out of the car window came swiftly to him. It was pleasing enough.\r\nWith an easy hand he wrote, \xe2\x80\x9cG. W. Murdock and wife.\xe2\x80\x9d It was the\r\nlargest concession to necessity he felt like making. His initials he\r\ncould not spare.\r\n\r\nWhen they were shown their room Carrie saw at once that he had secured\r\nher a lovely chamber.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have a bath there,\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cNow you can clean up when you get\r\nready.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie went over and looked out the window, while Hurstwood looked at\r\nhimself in the glass. He felt dusty and unclean. He had no trunk, no\r\nchange of linen, not even a hair-brush.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll ring for soap and towels,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cand send you up a\r\nhair-brush. Then you can bathe and get ready for breakfast. I\xe2\x80\x99ll go for\r\na shave and come back and get you, and then we\xe2\x80\x99ll go out and look for\r\nsome clothes for you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe smiled good-naturedly as he said this.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\nShe sat down in one of the rocking-chairs, while Hurstwood waited for\r\nthe boy, who soon knocked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSoap, towels, and a pitcher of ice-water.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll go now,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to Carrie, coming toward her and holding out his\r\nhands, but she did not move to take them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re not mad at me, are you?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked softly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no!\xe2\x80\x9d she answered, rather indifferently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t you care for me at all?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe made no answer, but looked steadily toward the window.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t you think you could love me a little?\xe2\x80\x9d he pleaded, taking one of\r\nher hands, which she endeavoured to draw away. \xe2\x80\x9cYou once said you did.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat made you deceive me so?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI couldn\xe2\x80\x99t help it,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cI wanted you too much.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou didn\xe2\x80\x99t have any right to want me,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered, striking cleanly\r\nhome.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, well, Carrie,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered, \xe2\x80\x9chere I am. It\xe2\x80\x99s too late now. Won\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nyou try and care for me a little?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe looked rather worsted in thought as he stood before her.\r\n\r\nShe shook her head negatively.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet me start all over again. Be my wife from to-day on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie rose up as if to step away, he holding her hand. Now he slipped\r\nhis arm about her and she struggled, but in vain. He held her quite\r\nclose. Instantly there flamed up in his body the all compelling desire.\r\nHis affection took an ardent form.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet me go,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, who was folded close to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWon\xe2\x80\x99t you love me?\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cWon\xe2\x80\x99t you be mine from now on?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie had never been ill-disposed toward him. Only a moment before she\r\nhad been listening with some complacency, remembering her old affection\r\nfor him. He was so handsome, so daring!\r\n\r\nNow, however, this feeling had changed to one of opposition, which rose\r\nfeebly. It mastered her for a moment, and then, held close as she was,\r\nbegan to wane. Something else in her spoke. This man, to whose bosom\r\nshe was being pressed, was strong; he was passionate, he loved her, and\r\nshe was alone. If she did not turn to him\xe2\x80\x94accept of his love\xe2\x80\x94where else\r\nmight she go? Her resistance half dissolved in the flood of his strong\r\nfeeling.\r\n\r\nShe found him lifting her head and looking into her eyes. What\r\nmagnetism there was she could never know. His many sins, however, were\r\nfor the moment all forgotten.\r\n\r\nHe pressed her closer and kissed her, and she felt that further\r\nopposition was useless.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill you marry me?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked, forgetting _how_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis very day,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, with all delight.\r\n\r\nNow the hall-boy pounded on the door and he released his hold upon her\r\nregretfully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou get ready now, will you,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cat once?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll be back in three-quarters of an hour.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie, flushed and excited, moved away as he admitted the boy.\r\n\r\nBelow stairs, he halted in the lobby to look for a barber shop. For the\r\nmoment, he was in fine feather. His recent victory over Carrie seemed\r\nto atone for much he had endured during the last few days. Life seemed\r\nworth fighting for. This eastward flight from all things customary and\r\nattached seemed as if it might have happiness in store. The storm\r\nshowed a rainbow at the end of which might be a pot of gold.\r\n\r\nHe was about to cross to a little red-and-white striped bar which was\r\nfastened up beside a door when a voice greeted him familiarly.\r\nInstantly his heart sank. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy, hello, George, old man!\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\nvoice. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat are you doing down here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHurstwood was already confronted, and recognised his friend Kenny, the\r\nstock-broker.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJust attending to a little private matter,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered, his mind\r\nworking like a key-board of a telephone station. This man evidently did\r\nnot know\xe2\x80\x94he had not read the papers.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, it seems strange to see you way up here,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Kenny\r\ngenially. \xe2\x80\x9cStopping here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood uneasily, thinking of his handwriting on the\r\nregister.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGoing to be in town long?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, only a day or so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs that so? Had your breakfast?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood, lying blandly. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m just going for a shave.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWon\xe2\x80\x99t you come have a drink?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot until afterwards,\xe2\x80\x9d said the ex-manager. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll see you later. Are\r\nyou stopping here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Kenny, and then, turning the word again added: \xe2\x80\x9cHow are\r\nthings out in Chicago?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAbout the same as usual,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood, smiling genially.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWife with you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I must see more of you to-day. I\xe2\x80\x99m just going in here for\r\nbreakfast. Come in when you\xe2\x80\x99re through.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood, moving away. The whole conversation was a\r\ntrial to him. It seemed to add complications with every word. This man\r\ncalled up a thousand memories. He represented everything he had left.\r\nChicago, his wife, the elegant resort\xe2\x80\x94all these were in his greeting\r\nand inquiries. And here he was in this same hotel expecting to confer\r\nwith him, unquestionably waiting to have a good time with him. All at\r\nonce the Chicago papers would arrive. The local papers would have\r\naccounts in them this very day. He forgot his triumph with Carrie in\r\nthe possibility of soon being known for what he was, in this man\xe2\x80\x99s\r\neyes, a safe-breaker. He could have groaned as he went into the barber\r\nshop. He decided to escape and seek a more secluded hotel.\r\n\r\nAccordingly, when he came out he was glad to see the lobby clear, and\r\nhastened toward the stairs. He would get Carrie and go out by the\r\nladies\xe2\x80\x99 entrance. They would have breakfast in some more inconspicuous\r\nplace.\r\n\r\nAcross the lobby, however, another individual was surveying him. He was\r\nof a commonplace Irish type, small of stature, cheaply dressed, and\r\nwith a head that seemed a smaller edition of some huge ward\r\npolitician\xe2\x80\x99s. This individual had been evidently talking with the\r\nclerk, but now he surveyed the ex-manager keenly.\r\n\r\nHurstwood felt the long-range examination and recognised the type.\r\nInstinctively he felt that the man was a detective\xe2\x80\x94that he was being\r\nwatched. He hurried across, pretending not to notice, but in his mind\r\nwas a world of thoughts. What would happen now? What could these people\r\ndo? He began to trouble concerning the extradition laws. He did not\r\nunderstand them absolutely. Perhaps he could be arrested. Oh, if Carrie\r\nshould find out! Montreal was too warm for him. He began to long to be\r\nout of it.\r\n\r\nCarrie had bathed and was waiting when he arrived. She looked\r\nrefreshed\xe2\x80\x94more delightful than ever, but reserved. Since he had gone\r\nshe had resumed somewhat of her cold attitude towards him. Love was not\r\nblazing in her heart. He felt it, and his troubles seemed increased. He\r\ncould not take her in his arms; he did not even try. Something about\r\nher forbade it. In part his opinion was the result of his own\r\nexperiences and reflections below stairs.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re ready, are you?\xe2\x80\x9d he said kindly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ll go out for breakfast. This place down here doesn\xe2\x80\x99t appeal to me\r\nvery much.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\nThey went out, and at the corner the commonplace Irish individual was\r\nstanding, eyeing him. Hurstwood could scarcely refrain from showing\r\nthat he knew of this chap\xe2\x80\x99s presence. The insolence in the fellow\xe2\x80\x99s eye\r\nwas galling. Still they passed, and he explained to Carrie concerning\r\nthe city. Another restaurant was not long in showing itself, and here\r\nthey entered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a queer town this is,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, who marvelled at it solely\r\nbecause it was not like Chicago.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt isn\xe2\x80\x99t as lively as Chicago,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t you like it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, whose feelings were already localised in the great\r\nWestern city.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, it isn\xe2\x80\x99t as interesting,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s here?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Carrie, wondering at his choosing to visit this\r\ntown.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing much,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Hurstwood. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s quite a resort. There\xe2\x80\x99s some\r\npretty scenery about here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie listened, but with a feeling of unrest. There was much about her\r\nsituation which destroyed the possibility of appreciation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe won\xe2\x80\x99t stay here long,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood, who was now really glad to\r\nnote her dissatisfaction. \xe2\x80\x9cYou pick out your clothes as soon as\r\nbreakfast is over and we\xe2\x80\x99ll run down to New York soon. You\xe2\x80\x99ll like\r\nthat. It\xe2\x80\x99s a lot more like a city than any place outside Chicago.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe was really planning to slip out and away. He would see what these\r\ndetectives would do\xe2\x80\x94what move his employers at Chicago would make\xe2\x80\x94then\r\nhe would slip away\xe2\x80\x94down to New York, where it was easy to hide. He knew\r\nenough about that city to know that its mysteries and possibilities of\r\nmystification were infinite.\r\n\r\nThe more he thought, however, the more wretched his situation became.\r\nHe saw that getting here did not exactly clear up the ground. The firm\r\nwould probably employ detectives to watch him\xe2\x80\x94Pinkerton men or agents\r\nof Mooney and Boland. They might arrest him the moment he tried to\r\nleave Canada. So he might be compelled to remain here months, and in\r\nwhat a state!\r\n\r\nBack at the hotel Hurstwood was anxious and yet fearful to see the\r\nmorning papers. He wanted to know how far the news of his criminal deed\r\nhad spread. So he told Carrie he would be up in a few moments, and went\r\nto secure and scan the dailies. No familiar or suspicious faces were\r\nabout, and yet he did not like reading in the lobby, so he sought the\r\nmain parlour on the floor above and, seated by a window there, looked\r\nthem over. Very little was given to his crime, but it was there,\r\nseveral \xe2\x80\x9csticks\xe2\x80\x9d in all, among all the riffraff of telegraphed murders,\r\naccidents, marriages, and other news. He wished, half sadly, that he\r\ncould undo it all. Every moment of his time in this far-off abode of\r\nsafety but added to his feeling that he had made a great mistake. There\r\ncould have been an easier way out if he had only known.\r\n\r\nHe left the papers before going to the room, thinking thus to keep them\r\nout of the hands of Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, how are you feeling?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked of her. She was engaged in\r\nlooking out of the window.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, all right,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered.\r\n\r\nHe came over, and was about to begin a conversation with her, when a\r\nknock came at their door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMaybe it\xe2\x80\x99s one of my parcels,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\nHurstwood opened the door, outside of which stood the individual whom\r\nhe had so thoroughly suspected.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re Mr. Hurstwood, are you?\xe2\x80\x9d said the latter, with a volume of\r\naffected shrewdness and assurance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood calmly. He knew the type so thoroughly that some\r\nof his old familiar indifference to it returned. Such men as these were\r\nof the lowest stratum welcomed at the resort. He stepped out and closed\r\nthe door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you know what I am here for, don\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x9d said the man\r\nconfidentially.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can guess,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood softly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, do you intend to try and keep the money?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s my affair,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood grimly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou can\xe2\x80\x99t do it, you know,\xe2\x80\x9d said the detective, eyeing him coolly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLook here, my man,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood authoritatively, \xe2\x80\x9cyou don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nunderstand anything about this case, and I can\xe2\x80\x99t explain to you.\r\nWhatever I intend to do I\xe2\x80\x99ll do without advice from the outside. You\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nhave to excuse me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, now, there\xe2\x80\x99s no use of your talking that way,\xe2\x80\x9d said the man,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cwhen you\xe2\x80\x99re in the hands of the police. We can make a lot of trouble\r\nfor you if we want to. You\xe2\x80\x99re not registered right in this house, you\r\nhaven\xe2\x80\x99t got your wife with you, and the newspapers don\xe2\x80\x99t know you\xe2\x80\x99re\r\nhere yet. You might as well be reasonable.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you want to know?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Hurstwood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhether you\xe2\x80\x99re going to send back that money or not.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHurstwood paused and studied the floor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s no use explaining to you about this,\xe2\x80\x9d he said at last.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s no use of your asking me. I\xe2\x80\x99m no fool, you know. I know just\r\nwhat you can do and what you can\xe2\x80\x99t. You can create a lot of trouble if\r\nyou want to. I know that all right, but it won\xe2\x80\x99t help you to get the\r\nmoney. Now, I\xe2\x80\x99ve made up my mind what to do. I\xe2\x80\x99ve already written\r\nFitzgerald and Moy, so there\xe2\x80\x99s nothing I can say. You wait until you\r\nhear more from them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAll the time he had been talking he had been moving away from the door,\r\ndown the corridor, out of the hearing of Carrie. They were now near the\r\nend where the corridor opened into the large general parlour.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou won\xe2\x80\x99t give it up?\xe2\x80\x9d said the man.\r\n\r\nThe words irritated Hurstwood greatly. Hot blood poured into his brain.\r\nMany thoughts formulated themselves. He was no thief. He didn\xe2\x80\x99t want\r\nthe money. If he could only explain to Fitzgerald and Moy, maybe it\r\nwould be all right again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSee here,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cthere\xe2\x80\x99s no use my talking about this at all. I\r\nrespect your power all right, but I\xe2\x80\x99ll have to deal with the people who\r\nknow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you can\xe2\x80\x99t get out of Canada with it,\xe2\x80\x9d said the man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t want to get out,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood. \xe2\x80\x9cWhen I get ready there\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nbe nothing to stop me for.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe turned back, and the detective watched him closely. It seemed an\r\nintolerable thing. Still he went on and into the room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho was it?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA friend of mine from Chicago.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe whole of this conversation was such a shock that, coming as it did\r\nafter all the other worry of the past week, it sufficed to induce a\r\ndeep gloom and moral revulsion in Hurstwood. What hurt him most was the\r\nfact that he was being pursued as a thief. He began to see the nature\r\nof that social injustice which sees but one side\xe2\x80\x94often but a single\r\npoint in a long tragedy. All the newspapers noted but one thing, his\r\ntaking the money. How and wherefore were but indifferently dealt with.\r\nAll the complications which led up to it were unknown. He was accused\r\nwithout being understood.\r\n\r\nSitting in his room with Carrie the same day, he decided to send the\r\nmoney back. He would write Fitzgerald and Moy, explain all, and then\r\nsend it by express. Maybe they would forgive him. Perhaps they would\r\nask him back. He would make good the false statement he had made about\r\nwriting them. Then he would leave this peculiar town.\r\n\r\nFor an hour he thought over this plausible statement of the tangle. He\r\nwanted to tell them about his wife, but couldn\xe2\x80\x99t. He finally narrowed\r\nit down to an assertion that he was light-headed from entertaining\r\nfriends, had found the safe open, and having gone so far as to take the\r\nmoney out, had accidentally closed it. This act he regretted very much.\r\nHe was sorry he had put them to so much trouble. He would undo what he\r\ncould by sending the money back\xe2\x80\x94the major portion of it. The remainder\r\nhe would pay up as soon as he could. Was there any possibility of his\r\nbeing restored? This he only hinted at.\r\n\r\nThe troubled state of the man\xe2\x80\x99s mind may be judged by the very\r\nconstruction of this letter. For the nonce he forgot what a painful\r\nthing it would be to resume his old place, even if it were given him.\r\nHe forgot that he had severed himself from the past as by a sword, and\r\nthat if he did manage to in some way reunite himself with it, the\r\njagged line of separation and reunion would always show. He was always\r\nforgetting something\xe2\x80\x94his wife, Carrie, his need of money, present\r\nsituation, or something\xe2\x80\x94and so did not reason clearly. Nevertheless, he\r\nsent the letter, waiting a reply before sending the money.\r\n\r\nMeanwhile, he accepted his present situation with Carrie, getting what\r\njoy out of it he could.\r\n\r\nOut came the sun by noon, and poured a golden flood through their open\r\nwindows. Sparrows were twittering. There were laughter and song in the\r\nair. Hurstwood could not keep his eyes from Carrie. She seemed the one\r\nray of sunshine in all his trouble. Oh, if she would only love him\r\nwholly\xe2\x80\x94only throw her arms around him in the blissful spirit in which\r\nhe had seen her in the little park in Chicago\xe2\x80\x94how happy he would be! It\r\nwould repay him; it would show him that he had not lost all. He would\r\nnot care.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCarrie,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, getting up once and coming over to her, \xe2\x80\x9care you\r\ngoing to stay with me from now on?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe looked at him quizzically, but melted with sympathy as the value of\r\nthe look upon his face forced itself upon her. It was love now, keen\r\nand strong\xe2\x80\x94love enhanced by difficulty and worry. She could not help\r\nsmiling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet me be everything to you from now on,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t make me\r\nworry any more. I\xe2\x80\x99ll be true to you. We\xe2\x80\x99ll go to New York and get a\r\nnice flat. I\xe2\x80\x99ll go into business again, and we\xe2\x80\x99ll be happy. Won\xe2\x80\x99t you\r\nbe mine?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie listened quite solemnly. There was no great passion in her, but\r\nthe drift of things and this man\xe2\x80\x99s proximity created a semblance of\r\naffection. She felt rather sorry for him\xe2\x80\x94a sorrow born of what had only\r\nrecently been a great admiration. True love she had never felt for him.\r\nShe would have known as much if she could have analysed her feelings,\r\nbut this thing which she now felt aroused by his great feeling broke\r\ndown the barriers between them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ll stay with me, won\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, nodding her head.\r\n\r\nHe gathered her to himself, imprinting kisses upon her lips and cheeks.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou must marry me, though,\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll get a license to-day,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUnder a new name,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll take a new name and live a new\r\nlife. From now on I\xe2\x80\x99m Murdock.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, don\xe2\x80\x99t take that name,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy not?\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t like it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, what shall I take?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, anything, only don\xe2\x80\x99t take that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe thought a while, still keeping his arms about her, and then said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow would Wheeler do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s all right,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, Wheeler,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll get the license this afternoon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey were married by a Baptist minister, the first divine they found\r\nconvenient.\r\n\r\nAt last the Chicago firm answered. It was by Mr. Moy\xe2\x80\x99s dictation. He\r\nwas astonished that Hurstwood had done this; very sorry that it had\r\ncome about as it had. If the money were returned, they would not\r\ntrouble to prosecute him, as they really bore him no ill-will. As for\r\nhis returning, or their restoring him to his former position, they had\r\nnot quite decided what the effect of it would be. They would think it\r\nover and correspond with him later, possibly, after a little time, and\r\nso on.\r\n\r\nThe sum and substance of it was that there was no hope, and they wanted\r\nthe money with the least trouble possible. Hurstwood read his doom. He\r\ndecided to pay $9,500 to the agent whom they said they would send,\r\nkeeping $1,300 for his own use. He telegraphed his acquiescence,\r\nexplained to the representative who called at the hotel the same day,\r\ntook a certificate of payment, and told Carrie to pack her trunk. He\r\nwas slightly depressed over this newest move at the time he began to\r\nmake it, but eventually restored himself. He feared that even yet he\r\nmight be seized and taken back, so he tried to conceal his movements,\r\nbut it was scarcely possible. He ordered Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s trunk sent to the\r\ndepot, where he had it sent by express to New York. No one seemed to be\r\nobserving him, but he left at night. He was greatly agitated lest at\r\nthe first station across the border or at the depot in New York there\r\nshould be waiting for him an officer of the law.\r\n\r\nCarrie, ignorant of his theft and his fears, enjoyed the entry into the\r\nlatter city in the morning. The round green hills sentinelling the\r\nbroad, expansive bosom of the Hudson held her attention by their beauty\r\nas the train followed the line of the stream. She had heard of the\r\nHudson River, the great city of New York, and now she looked out,\r\nfilling her mind with the wonder of it.\r\n\r\nAs the train turned east at Spuyten Duyvil and followed the east bank\r\nof the Harlem River, Hurstwood nervously called her attention to the\r\nfact that they were on the edge of the city. After her experience with\r\nChicago, she expected long lines of cars\xe2\x80\x94a great highway of tracks\xe2\x80\x94and\r\nnoted the difference. The sight of a few boats in the Harlem and more\r\nin the East River tickled her young heart. It was the first sign of the\r\ngreat sea. Next came a plain street with five-story brick flats, and\r\nthen the train plunged into the tunnel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGrand Central Station!\xe2\x80\x9d called the trainman, as, after a few minutes\r\nof darkness and smoke, daylight reappeared. Hurstwood arose and\r\ngathered up his small grip. He was screwed up to the highest tension.\r\nWith Carrie he waited at the door and then dismounted. No one\r\napproached him, but he glanced furtively to and fro as he made for the\r\nstreet entrance. So excited was he that he forgot all about Carrie, who\r\nfell behind, wondering at his self-absorption. As he passed through the\r\ndepot proper the strain reached its climax and began to wane. All at\r\nonce he was on the sidewalk, and none but cabmen hailed him. He heaved\r\na great breath and turned, remembering Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thought you were going to run off and leave me,\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was trying to remember which car takes us to the Gilsey,\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nanswered.\r\n\r\nCarrie hardly heard him, so interested was she in the busy scene.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow large is New York?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh a million or more,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood.\r\n\r\nHe looked around and hailed a cab, but he did so in a changed way.\r\n\r\nFor the first time in years the thought that he must count these little\r\nexpenses flashed through his mind. It was a disagreeable thing.\r\n\r\nHe decided he would lose no time living in hotels but would rent a\r\nflat. Accordingly he told Carrie, and she agreed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ll look to-day, if you want to,\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\r\n\r\nSuddenly he thought of his experience in Montreal. At the more\r\nimportant hotels he would be certain to meet Chicagoans whom he knew.\r\nHe stood up and spoke to the driver.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake me to the Belford,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, knowing it to be less frequented by\r\nthose whom he knew. Then he sat down.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere is the residence part?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Carrie, who did not take the tall\r\nfive-story walls on either hand to be the abodes of families.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEverywhere,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood, who knew the city fairly well. \xe2\x80\x9cThere are\r\nno lawns in New York. All these are houses.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, I don\xe2\x80\x99t like it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, who was coming to have a\r\nfew opinions of her own.\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XXX. THE KINGDOM OF GREATNESS: THE PILGRIM ADREAM\r\n\r\nWhatever a man like Hurstwood could be in Chicago, it is very evident\r\nthat he would be but an inconspicuous drop in an ocean like New York.\r\nIn Chicago, whose population still ranged about 500,000, millionaires\r\nwere not numerous. The rich had not become so conspicuously rich as to\r\ndrown all moderate incomes in obscurity. The attention of the\r\ninhabitants was not so distracted by local celebrities in the dramatic,\r\nartistic, social, and religious fields as to shut the well-positioned\r\nman from view. In Chicago the two roads to distinction were politics\r\nand trade. In New York the roads were any one of a half-hundred, and\r\neach had been diligently pursued by hundreds, so that celebrities were\r\nnumerous. The sea was already full of whales. A common fish must needs\r\ndisappear wholly from view\xe2\x80\x94remain unseen. In other words, Hurstwood was\r\nnothing.\r\n\r\nThere is a more subtle result of such a situation as this, which,\r\nthough not always taken into account, produces the tragedies of the\r\nworld. The great create an atmosphere which reacts badly upon the\r\nsmall. This atmosphere is easily and quickly felt. Walk among the\r\nmagnificent residences, the splendid equipages, the gilded shops,\r\nrestaurants, resorts of all kinds; scent the flowers, the silks, the\r\nwines; drink of the laughter springing from the soul of luxurious\r\ncontent, of the glances which gleam like light from defiant spears;\r\nfeel the quality of the smiles which cut like glistening swords and of\r\nstrides born of place, and you shall know of what is the atmosphere of\r\nthe high and mighty. Little use to argue that of such is not the\r\nkingdom of greatness, but so long as the world is attracted by this and\r\nthe human heart views this as the one desirable realm which it must\r\nattain, so long, to that heart, will this remain the realm of\r\ngreatness. So long, also, will the atmosphere of this realm work its\r\ndesperate results in the soul of man. It is like a chemical reagent.\r\nOne day of it, like one drop of the other, will so affect and discolour\r\nthe views, the aims, the desire of the mind, that it will thereafter\r\nremain forever dyed. A day of it to the untried mind is like opium to\r\nthe untried body. A craving is set up which, if gratified, shall\r\neternally result in dreams and death. Aye! dreams unfulfilled\xe2\x80\x94gnawing,\r\nluring, idle phantoms which beckon and lead, beckon and lead, until\r\ndeath and dissolution dissolve their power and restore us blind to\r\nnature\xe2\x80\x99s heart.\r\n\r\nA man of Hurstwood\xe2\x80\x99s age and temperament is not subject to the\r\nillusions and burning desires of youth, but neither has he the strength\r\nof hope which gushes as a fountain in the heart of youth. Such an\r\natmosphere could not incite in him the cravings of a boy of eighteen,\r\nbut in so far as they were excited, the lack of hope made them\r\nproportionately bitter. He could not fail to notice the signs of\r\naffluence and luxury on every hand. He had been to New York before and\r\nknew the resources of its folly. In part it was an awesome place to\r\nhim, for here gathered all that he most respected on this earth\xe2\x80\x94wealth,\r\nplace, and fame. The majority of the celebrities with whom he had\r\ntipped glasses in his day as manager hailed from this self-centred and\r\npopulous spot. The most inviting stories of pleasure and luxury had\r\nbeen told of places and individuals here. He knew it to be true that\r\nunconsciously he was brushing elbows with fortune the livelong day;\r\nthat a hundred or five hundred thousand gave no one the privilege of\r\nliving more than comfortably in so wealthy a place. Fashion and pomp\r\nrequired more ample sums, so that the poor man was nowhere. All this he\r\nrealised, now quite sharply, as he faced the city, cut off from his\r\nfriends, despoiled of his modest fortune, and even his name, and forced\r\nto begin the battle for place and comfort all over again. He was not\r\nold, but he was not so dull but that he could feel he soon would be. Of\r\na sudden, then, this show of fine clothes, place, and power took on\r\npeculiar significance. It was emphasised by contrast with his own\r\ndistressing state.\r\n\r\nAnd it was distressing. He soon found that freedom from fear of arrest\r\nwas not the _sine qua non_ of his existence. That danger dissolved, the\r\nnext necessity became the grievous thing. The paltry sum of thirteen\r\nhundred and some odd dollars set against the need of rent, clothing,\r\nfood, and pleasure for years to come was a spectacle little calculated\r\nto induce peace of mind in one who had been accustomed to spend five\r\ntimes that sum in the course of a year. He thought upon the subject\r\nrather actively the first few days he was in New York, and decided that\r\nhe must act quickly. As a consequence, he consulted the business\r\nopportunities advertised in the morning papers and began investigations\r\non his own account.\r\n\r\nThat was not before he had become settled, however. Carrie and he went\r\nlooking for a flat, as arranged, and found one in Seventy-eighth Street\r\nnear Amsterdam Avenue. It was a five-story building, and their flat was\r\non the third floor. Owing to the fact that the street was not yet built\r\nup solidly, it was possible to see east to the green tops of the trees\r\nin Central Park and west to the broad waters of the Hudson, a glimpse\r\nof which was to be had out of the west windows. For the privilege of\r\nsix rooms and a bath, running in a straight line, they were compelled\r\nto pay thirty-five dollars a month\xe2\x80\x94an average, and yet exorbitant, rent\r\nfor a home at the time. Carrie noticed the difference between the size\r\nof the rooms here and in Chicago and mentioned it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ll not find anything better, dear,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood, \xe2\x80\x9cunless you go\r\ninto one of the old-fashioned houses, and then you won\xe2\x80\x99t have any of\r\nthese conveniences.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie picked out the new abode because of its newness and bright\r\nwood-work. It was one of the very new ones supplied with steam heat,\r\nwhich was a great advantage. The stationary range, hot and cold water,\r\ndumb-waiter, speaking tubes, and call-bell for the janitor pleased her\r\nvery much. She had enough of the instincts of a housewife to take great\r\nsatisfaction in these things.\r\n\r\nHurstwood made arrangements with one of the instalment houses whereby\r\nthey furnished the flat complete and accepted fifty dollars down and\r\nten dollars a month. He then had a little plate, bearing the name G. W.\r\nWheeler, made, which he placed on his letter-box in the hall. It\r\nsounded exceedingly odd to Carrie to be called Mrs. Wheeler by the\r\njanitor, but in time she became used to it and looked upon the name as\r\nher own.\r\n\r\nThese house details settled, Hurstwood visited some of the advertised\r\nopportunities to purchase an interest in some flourishing down-town\r\nbar. After the palatial resort in Adams Street, he could not stomach\r\nthe commonplace saloons which he found advertised. He lost a number of\r\ndays looking up these and finding them disagreeable. He did, however,\r\ngain considerable knowledge by talking, for he discovered the influence\r\nof Tammany Hall and the value of standing in with the police. The most\r\nprofitable and flourishing places he found to be those which conducted\r\nanything but a legitimate business, such as that controlled by\r\nFitzgerald and Moy. Elegant back rooms and private drinking booths on\r\nthe second floor were usually adjuncts of very profitable places. He\r\nsaw by portly keepers, whose shirt fronts shone with large diamonds,\r\nand whose clothes were properly cut, that the liquor business here, as\r\nelsewhere, yielded the same golden profit. At last he found an\r\nindividual who had a resort in Warren Street, which seemed an excellent\r\nventure. It was fairly well-appearing and susceptible of improvement.\r\nThe owner claimed the business to be excellent, and it certainly looked\r\nso.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe deal with a very good class of people,\xe2\x80\x9d he told Hurstwood.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMerchants, salesmen, and professionals. It\xe2\x80\x99s a well-dressed class. No\r\nbums. We don\xe2\x80\x99t allow \xe2\x80\x99em in the place.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHurstwood listened to the cash-register ring, and watched the trade for\r\na while.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s profitable enough for two, is it?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou can see for yourself if you\xe2\x80\x99re any judge of the liquor trade,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid the owner. \xe2\x80\x9cThis is only one of the two places I have. The other\r\nis down in Nassau Street. I can\xe2\x80\x99t tend to them both alone. If I had\r\nsome one who knew the business thoroughly I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t mind sharing with\r\nhim in this one and letting him manage it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve had experience enough,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood blandly, but he felt a\r\nlittle diffident about referring to Fitzgerald and Moy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you can suit yourself, Mr. Wheeler,\xe2\x80\x9d said the proprietor.\r\n\r\nHe only offered a third interest in the stock, fixtures, and good-will,\r\nand this in return for a thousand dollars and managerial ability on the\r\npart of the one who should come in. There was no property involved,\r\nbecause the owner of the saloon merely rented from an estate.\r\n\r\nThe offer was genuine enough, but it was a question with Hurstwood\r\nwhether a third interest in that locality could be made to yield one\r\nhundred and fifty dollars a month, which he figured he must have in\r\norder to meet the ordinary family expenses and be comfortable. It was\r\nnot the time, however, after many failures to find what he wanted, to\r\nhesitate. It looked as though a third would pay a hundred a month now.\r\nBy judicious management and improvement, it might be made to pay more.\r\nAccordingly he agreed to enter into partnership, and made over his\r\nthousand dollars, preparing to enter the next day.\r\n\r\nHis first inclination was to be elated, and he confided to Carrie that\r\nhe thought he had made an excellent arrangement. Time, however,\r\nintroduced food for reflection. He found his partner to be very\r\ndisagreeable. Frequently he was the worse for liquor, which made him\r\nsurly. This was the last thing which Hurstwood was used to in business.\r\nBesides, the business varied. It was nothing like the class of\r\npatronage which he had enjoyed in Chicago. He found that it would take\r\na long time to make friends. These people hurried in and out without\r\nseeking the pleasures of friendship. It was no gathering or lounging\r\nplace. Whole days and weeks passed without one such hearty greeting as\r\nhe had been wont to enjoy every day in Chicago.\r\n\r\nFor another thing, Hurstwood missed the celebrities\xe2\x80\x94those well-dressed,\r\n_\xc3\xa9lite_ individuals who lend grace to the average bars and bring news\r\nfrom far-off and exclusive circles. He did not see one such in a month.\r\nEvenings, when still at his post, he would occasionally read in the\r\nevening papers incidents concerning celebrities whom he knew\xe2\x80\x94whom he\r\nhad drunk a glass with many a time. They would visit a bar like\r\nFitzgerald and Moy\xe2\x80\x99s in Chicago, or the Hoffman House, uptown, but he\r\nknew that he would never see them down here. Again, the business did\r\nnot pay as well as he thought. It increased a little, but he found he\r\nwould have to watch his household expenses, which was humiliating.\r\n\r\nIn the very beginning it was a delight to go home late at night, as he\r\ndid, and find Carrie. He managed to run up and take dinner with her\r\nbetween six and seven, and to remain home until nine o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the\r\nmorning, but the novelty of this waned after a time, and he began to\r\nfeel the drag of his duties.\r\n\r\nThe first month had scarcely passed before Carrie said in a very\r\nnatural way: \xe2\x80\x9cI think I\xe2\x80\x99ll go down this week and buy a dress.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat kind?\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, something for street wear.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered, smiling, although he noted mentally that it\r\nwould be more agreeable to his finances if she didn\xe2\x80\x99t. Nothing was said\r\nabout it the next day, but the following morning he asked:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you done anything about your dress?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot yet,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\nHe paused a few moments, as if in thought, and then said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWould you mind putting it off a few days?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Carrie, who did not catch the drift of his remarks. She\r\nhad never thought of him in connection with money troubles before.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood. \xe2\x80\x9cThis investment of mine is\r\ntaking a lot of money just now. I expect to get it all back shortly,\r\nbut just at present I am running close.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh!\xe2\x80\x9d answered Carrie. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy, certainly, dear. Why didn\xe2\x80\x99t you tell me\r\nbefore?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt wasn\xe2\x80\x99t necessary,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood.\r\n\r\nFor all her acquiescence, there was something about the way Hurstwood\r\nspoke which reminded Carrie of Drouet and his little deal which he was\r\nalways about to put through. It was only the thought of a second, but\r\nit was a beginning. It was something new in her thinking of Hurstwood.\r\n\r\nOther things followed from time to time, little things of the same\r\nsort, which in their cumulative effect were eventually equal to a full\r\nrevelation. Carrie was not dull by any means. Two persons cannot long\r\ndwell together without coming to an understanding of one another. The\r\nmental difficulties of an individual reveal themselves whether he\r\nvoluntarily confesses them or not. Trouble gets in the air and\r\ncontributes gloom, which speaks for itself. Hurstwood dressed as nicely\r\nas usual, but they were the same clothes he had in Canada. Carrie\r\nnoticed that he did not install a large wardrobe, though his own was\r\nanything but large. She noticed, also, that he did not suggest many\r\namusements, said nothing about the food, seemed concerned about his\r\nbusiness. This was not the easy Hurstwood of Chicago\xe2\x80\x94not the liberal,\r\nopulent Hurstwood she had known. The change was too obvious to escape\r\ndetection.\r\n\r\nIn time she began to feel that a change had come about, and that she\r\nwas not in his confidence. He was evidently secretive and kept his own\r\ncounsel. She found herself asking him questions about little things.\r\nThis is a disagreeable state to a woman. Great love makes it seem\r\nreasonable, sometimes plausible, but never satisfactory. Where great\r\nlove is not, a more definite and less satisfactory conclusion is\r\nreached.\r\n\r\nAs for Hurstwood, he was making a great fight against the difficulties\r\nof a changed condition. He was too shrewd not to realise the tremendous\r\nmistake he had made, and appreciate that he had done well in getting\r\nwhere he was, and yet he could not help contrasting his present state\r\nwith his former, hour after hour, and day after day.\r\n\r\nBesides, he had the disagreeable fear of meeting old-time friends, ever\r\nsince one such encounter which he made shortly after his arrival in the\r\ncity. It was in Broadway that he saw a man approaching him whom he\r\nknew. There was no time for simulating non-recognition. The exchange of\r\nglances had been too sharp, the knowledge of each other too apparent.\r\nSo the friend, a buyer for one of the Chicago wholesale houses, felt,\r\nperforce, the necessity of stopping.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow are you?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, extending his hand with an evident mixture of\r\nfeeling and a lack of plausible interest.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood, equally embarrassed. \xe2\x80\x9cHow is it with you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right; I\xe2\x80\x99m down here doing a little buying. Are you located here\r\nnow?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood, \xe2\x80\x9cI have a place down in Warren Street.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs that so?\xe2\x80\x9d said the friend. \xe2\x80\x9cGlad to hear it. I\xe2\x80\x99ll come down and see\r\nyou.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo long,\xe2\x80\x9d said the other, smiling affably and going on.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe never asked for my number,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Hurstwood; \xe2\x80\x9che wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t think\r\nof coming.\xe2\x80\x9d He wiped his forehead, which had grown damp, and hoped\r\nsincerely he would meet no one else.\r\n\r\nThese things told upon his good-nature, such as it was. His one hope\r\nwas that things would change for the better in a money way.\r\n\r\nHe had Carrie. His furniture was being paid for. He was maintaining his\r\nposition. As for Carrie, the amusements he could give her would have to\r\ndo for the present. He could probably keep up his pretensions\r\nsufficiently long without exposure to make good, and then all would be\r\nwell. He failed therein to take account of the frailties of human\r\nnature\xe2\x80\x94the difficulties of matrimonial life. Carrie was young. With him\r\nand with her varying mental states were common. At any moment the\r\nextremes of feeling might be anti-polarised at the dinner table. This\r\noften happens in the best regulated families. Little things brought out\r\non such occasions need great love to obliterate them afterward. Where\r\nthat is not, both parties count two and two and make a problem after a\r\nwhile.\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XXXI. A PET OF GOOD FORTUNE: BROADWAY FLAUNTS ITS JOYS\r\n\r\nThe effect of the city and his own situation on Hurstwood was\r\nparalleled in the case of Carrie, who accepted the things which fortune\r\nprovided with the most genial good-nature. New York, despite her first\r\nexpression of disapproval, soon interested her exceedingly. Its clear\r\natmosphere, more populous thoroughfares, and peculiar indifference\r\nstruck her forcibly. She had never seen such a little flat as hers, and\r\nyet it soon enlisted her affection. The new furniture made an excellent\r\nshowing, the sideboard which Hurstwood himself arranged gleamed\r\nbrightly. The furniture for each room was appropriate, and in the\r\nso-called parlour, or front room, was installed a piano, because Carrie\r\nsaid she would like to learn to play. She kept a servant and developed\r\nrapidly in household tactics and information. For the first time in her\r\nlife she felt settled, and somewhat justified in the eyes of society as\r\nshe conceived of it. Her thoughts were merry and innocent enough. For a\r\nlong while she concerned herself over the arrangement of New York\r\nflats, and wondered at ten families living in one building and all\r\nremaining strange and indifferent to each other. She also marvelled at\r\nthe whistles of the hundreds of vessels in the harbour\xe2\x80\x94the long, low\r\ncries of the Sound steamers and ferry-boats when fog was on. The mere\r\nfact that these things spoke from the sea made them wonderful. She\r\nlooked much at what she could see of the Hudson from her west windows\r\nand of the great city building up rapidly on either hand. It was much\r\nto ponder over, and sufficed to entertain her for more than a year\r\nwithout becoming stale.\r\n\r\nFor another thing, Hurstwood was exceedingly interesting in his\r\naffection for her. Troubled as he was, he never exposed his\r\ndifficulties to her. He carried himself with the same self-important\r\nair, took his new state with easy familiarity, and rejoiced in Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nproclivities and successes. Each evening he arrived promptly to dinner,\r\nand found the little dining-room a most inviting spectacle. In a way,\r\nthe smallness of the room added to its luxury. It looked full and\r\nreplete. The white-covered table was arrayed with pretty dishes and\r\nlighted with a four-armed candelabra, each light of which was topped\r\nwith a red shade. Between Carrie and the girl the steaks and chops came\r\nout all right, and canned goods did the rest for a while. Carrie\r\nstudied the art of making biscuit, and soon reached the stage where she\r\ncould show a plate of light, palatable morsels for her labour.\r\n\r\nIn this manner the second, third, and fourth months passed. Winter\r\ncame, and with it a feeling that indoors was best, so that the\r\nattending of theatres was not much talked of. Hurstwood made great\r\nefforts to meet all expenditures without a show of feeling one way or\r\nthe other. He pretended that he was reinvesting his money in\r\nstrengthening the business for greater ends in the future. He contented\r\nhimself with a very moderate allowance of personal apparel, and rarely\r\nsuggested anything for Carrie. Thus the first winter passed.\r\n\r\nIn the second year, the business which Hurstwood managed did increase\r\nsomewhat. He got out of it regularly the $150 per month which he had\r\nanticipated. Unfortunately, by this time Carrie had reached certain\r\nconclusions, and he had scraped up a few acquaintances.\r\n\r\nBeing of a passive and receptive rather than an active and aggressive\r\nnature, Carrie accepted the situation. Her state seemed satisfactory\r\nenough. Once in a while they would go to a theatre together,\r\noccasionally in season to the beaches and different points about the\r\ncity, but they picked up no acquaintances. Hurstwood naturally\r\nabandoned his show of fine manners with her and modified his attitude\r\nto one of easy familiarity. There were no misunderstandings, no\r\napparent differences of opinion. In fact, without money or visiting\r\nfriends, he led a life which could neither arouse jealousy nor comment.\r\nCarrie rather sympathised with his efforts and thought nothing upon her\r\nlack of entertainment such as she had enjoyed in Chicago. New York as a\r\ncorporate entity and her flat temporarily seemed sufficient.\r\n\r\nHowever, as Hurstwood\xe2\x80\x99s business increased, he, as stated, began to\r\npick up acquaintances. He also began to allow himself more clothes. He\r\nconvinced himself that his home life was very precious to him, but\r\nallowed that he could occasionally stay away from dinner. The first\r\ntime he did this he sent a message saying that he would be detained.\r\nCarrie ate alone, and wished that it might not happen again. The second\r\ntime, also, he sent word, but at the last moment. The third time he\r\nforgot entirely and explained afterwards. These events were months\r\napart, each.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere were you, George?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Carrie, after the first absence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTied up at the office,\xe2\x80\x9d he said genially. \xe2\x80\x9cThere were some accounts I\r\nhad to straighten.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m sorry you couldn\xe2\x80\x99t get home,\xe2\x80\x9d she said kindly. \xe2\x80\x9cI was fixing to\r\nhave such a nice dinner.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe second time he gave a similar excuse, but the third time the\r\nfeeling about it in Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s mind was a little bit out of the ordinary.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI couldn\xe2\x80\x99t get home,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, when he came in later in the evening,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was so busy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCouldn\xe2\x80\x99t you have sent me word?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI meant to,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cbut you know I forgot it until it was too late\r\nto do any good.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I had such a good dinner!\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\nNow, it so happened that from his observations of Carrie he began to\r\nimagine that she was of the thoroughly domestic type of mind. He really\r\nthought, after a year, that her chief expression in life was finding\r\nits natural channel in household duties. Notwithstanding the fact that\r\nhe had observed her act in Chicago, and that during the past year he\r\nhad only seen her limited in her relations to her flat and him by\r\nconditions which he made, and that she had not gained any friends or\r\nassociates, he drew this peculiar conclusion. With it came a feeling of\r\nsatisfaction in having a wife who could thus be content, and this\r\nsatisfaction worked its natural result. That is, since he imagined he\r\nsaw her satisfied, he felt called upon to give only that which\r\ncontributed to such satisfaction. He supplied the furniture, the\r\ndecorations, the food, and the necessary clothing. Thoughts of\r\nentertaining her, leading her out into the shine and show of life, grew\r\nless and less. He felt attracted to the outer world, but did not think\r\nshe would care to go along. Once he went to the theatre alone. Another\r\ntime he joined a couple of his new friends at an evening game of poker.\r\nSince his money-feathers were beginning to grow again he felt like\r\nsprucing about. All this, however, in a much less imposing way than had\r\nbeen his wont in Chicago. He avoided the gay places where he would be\r\napt to meet those who had known him. Now, Carrie began to feel this in\r\nvarious sensory ways. She was not the kind to be seriously disturbed by\r\nhis actions. Not loving him greatly, she could not be jealous in a\r\ndisturbing way. In fact, she was not jealous at all. Hurstwood was\r\npleased with her placid manner, when he should have duly considered it.\r\nWhen he did not come home it did not seem anything like a terrible\r\nthing to her. She gave him credit for having the usual allurements of\r\nmen\xe2\x80\x94people to talk to, places to stop, friends to consult with. She was\r\nperfectly willing that he should enjoy himself in his way, but she did\r\nnot care to be neglected herself. Her state still seemed fairly\r\nreasonable, however. All she did observe was that Hurstwood was\r\nsomewhat different.\r\n\r\nSome time in the second year of their residence in Seventy-eighth\r\nStreet the flat across the hall from Carrie became vacant, and into it\r\nmoved a very handsome young woman and her husband, with both of whom\r\nCarrie afterwards became acquainted. This was brought about solely by\r\nthe arrangement of the flats, which were united in one place, as it\r\nwere, by the dumb-waiter. This useful elevator, by which fuel,\r\ngroceries, and the like were sent up from the basement, and garbage and\r\nwaste sent down, was used by both residents of one floor; that is, a\r\nsmall door opened into it from each flat.\r\n\r\nIf the occupants of both flats answered to the whistle of the janitor\r\nat the same time, they would stand face to face when they opened the\r\ndumb-waiter doors. One morning, when Carrie went to remove her paper,\r\nthe newcomer, a handsome brunette of perhaps twenty-three years of age,\r\nwas there for a like purpose. She was in a night-robe and\r\ndressing-gown, with her hair very much tousled, but she looked so\r\npretty and good-natured that Carrie instantly conceived a liking for\r\nher. The newcomer did no more than smile shamefacedly, but it was\r\nsufficient. Carrie felt that she would like to know her, and a similar\r\nfeeling stirred in the mind of the other, who admired Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s innocent\r\nface.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s a real pretty woman who has moved in next door,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie to\r\nHurstwood at the breakfast table.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho are they?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Hurstwood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie. \xe2\x80\x9cThe name on the bell is Vance. Some one\r\nover there plays beautifully. I guess it must be she.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you never can tell what sort of people you\xe2\x80\x99re living next to in\r\nthis town, can you?\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood, expressing the customary New York\r\nopinion about neighbours.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJust think,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, \xe2\x80\x9cI have been in this house with nine other\r\nfamilies for over a year and I don\xe2\x80\x99t know a soul. These people have\r\nbeen here over a month and I haven\xe2\x80\x99t seen any one before this morning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s just as well,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood. \xe2\x80\x9cYou never know who you\xe2\x80\x99re going\r\nto get in with. Some of these people are pretty bad company.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI expect so,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, agreeably.\r\n\r\nThe conversation turned to other things, and Carrie thought no more\r\nupon the subject until a day or two later, when, going out to market,\r\nshe encountered Mrs. Vance coming in. The latter recognised her and\r\nnodded, for which Carrie returned a smile. This settled the probability\r\nof acquaintanceship. If there had been no faint recognition on this\r\noccasion, there would have been no future association.\r\n\r\nCarrie saw no more of Mrs. Vance for several weeks, but she heard her\r\nplay through the thin walls which divided the front rooms of the flats,\r\nand was pleased by the merry selection of pieces and the brilliance of\r\ntheir rendition. She could play only moderately herself, and such\r\nvariety as Mrs. Vance exercised bordered, for Carrie, upon the verge of\r\ngreat art. Everything she had seen and heard thus far\xe2\x80\x94the merest scraps\r\nand shadows\xe2\x80\x94indicated that these people were, in a measure, refined and\r\nin comfortable circumstances. So Carrie was ready for any extension of\r\nthe friendship which might follow.\r\n\r\nOne day Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s bell rang and the servant, who was in the kitchen,\r\npressed the button which caused the front door of the general entrance\r\non the ground floor to be electrically unlatched. When Carrie waited at\r\nher own door on the third floor to see who it might be coming up to\r\ncall on her, Mrs. Vance appeared.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hope you\xe2\x80\x99ll excuse me,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cI went out a while ago and forgot\r\nmy outside key, so I thought I\xe2\x80\x99d ring your bell.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis was a common trick of other residents of the building, whenever\r\nthey had forgotten their outside keys. They did not apologise for it,\r\nhowever.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m glad you did. I do the same thing\r\nsometimes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIsn\xe2\x80\x99t it just delightful weather?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Vance, pausing for a\r\nmoment.\r\n\r\nThus, after a few more preliminaries, this visiting acquaintance was\r\nwell launched, and in the young Mrs. Vance Carrie found an agreeable\r\ncompanion.\r\n\r\nOn several occasions Carrie visited her and was visited. Both flats\r\nwere good to look upon, though that of the Vances tended somewhat more\r\nto the luxurious.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI want you to come over this evening and meet my husband,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs.\r\nVance, not long after their intimacy began. \xe2\x80\x9cHe wants to meet you. You\r\nplay cards, don\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA little,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, we\xe2\x80\x99ll have a game of cards. If your husband comes home bring him\r\nover.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s not coming to dinner to-night,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, when he does come we\xe2\x80\x99ll call him in.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie acquiesced, and that evening met the portly Vance, an individual\r\na few years younger than Hurstwood, and who owed his seemingly\r\ncomfortable matrimonial state much more to his money than to his good\r\nlooks. He thought well of Carrie upon the first glance and laid himself\r\nout to be genial, teaching her a new game of cards and talking to her\r\nabout New York and its pleasures. Mrs. Vance played some upon the\r\npiano, and at last Hurstwood came.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am very glad to meet you,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to Mrs. Vance when Carrie\r\nintroduced him, showing much of the old grace which had captivated\r\nCarrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you think your wife had run away?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Vance, extending his\r\nhand upon introduction.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI didn\xe2\x80\x99t know but what she might have found a better husband,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nHurstwood.\r\n\r\nHe now turned his attention to Mrs. Vance, and in a flash Carrie saw\r\nagain what she for some time had subconsciously missed in Hurstwood\xe2\x80\x94the\r\nadroitness and flattery of which he was capable. She also saw that she\r\nwas not well dressed\xe2\x80\x94not nearly as well dressed\xe2\x80\x94as Mrs. Vance. These\r\nwere not vague ideas any longer. Her situation was cleared up for her.\r\nShe felt that her life was becoming stale, and therein she felt cause\r\nfor gloom. The old helpful, urging melancholy was restored. The\r\ndesirous Carrie was whispered to concerning her possibilities.\r\n\r\nThere were no immediate results to this awakening, for Carrie had\r\nlittle power of initiative; but, nevertheless, she seemed ever capable\r\nof getting herself into the tide of change where she would be easily\r\nborne along. Hurstwood noticed nothing. He had been unconscious of the\r\nmarked contrasts which Carrie had observed.\r\n\r\nHe did not even detect the shade of melancholy which settled in her\r\neyes. Worst of all, she now began to feel the loneliness of the flat\r\nand seek the company of Mrs. Vance, who liked her exceedingly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet\xe2\x80\x99s go to the matin\xc3\xa9e this afternoon,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Vance, who had\r\nstepped across into Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s flat one morning, still arrayed in a soft\r\npink dressing-gown, which she had donned upon rising. Hurstwood and\r\nVance had gone their separate ways nearly an hour before.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, noticing the air of the petted and\r\nwell-groomed woman in Mrs. Vance\xe2\x80\x99s general appearance. She looked as\r\nthough she was dearly loved and her every wish gratified. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat shall\r\nwe see?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I do want to see Nat Goodwin,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Vance. \xe2\x80\x9cI do think he is\r\nthe jolliest actor. The papers say this is such a good play.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat time will we have to start?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet\xe2\x80\x99s go at once and walk down Broadway from Thirty-fourth Street,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid Mrs. Vance. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s such an interesting walk. He\xe2\x80\x99s at the Madison\r\nSquare.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll be glad to go,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie. \xe2\x80\x9cHow much will we have to pay for\r\nseats?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot more than a dollar,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Vance.\r\n\r\nThe latter departed, and at one o\xe2\x80\x99clock reappeared, stunningly arrayed\r\nin a dark-blue walking dress, with a nobby hat to match. Carrie had\r\ngotten herself up charmingly enough, but this woman pained her by\r\ncontrast. She seemed to have so many dainty little things which Carrie\r\nhad not. There were trinkets of gold, an elegant green leather purse\r\nset with her initials, a fancy handkerchief, exceedingly rich in\r\ndesign, and the like. Carrie felt that she needed more and better\r\nclothes to compare with this woman, and that any one looking at the two\r\nwould pick Mrs. Vance for her raiment alone. It was a trying, though\r\nrather unjust thought, for Carrie had now developed an equally pleasing\r\nfigure, and had grown in comeliness until she was a thoroughly\r\nattractive type of her colour of beauty. There was some difference in\r\nthe clothing of the two, both of quality and age, but this difference\r\nwas not especially noticeable. It served, however, to augment Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndissatisfaction with her state.\r\n\r\nThe walk down Broadway, then as now, was one of the remarkable features\r\nof the city. There gathered, before the matin\xc3\xa9e and afterwards, not\r\nonly all the pretty women who love a showy parade, but the men who love\r\nto gaze upon and admire them. It was a very imposing procession of\r\npretty faces and fine clothes. Women appeared in their very best hats,\r\nshoes, and gloves, and walked arm in arm on their way to the fine shops\r\nor theatres strung along from Fourteenth to Thirty-fourth Streets.\r\nEqually the men paraded with the very latest they could afford. A\r\ntailor might have secured hints on suit measurements, a shoemaker on\r\nproper lasts and colours, a hatter on hats. It was literally true that\r\nif a lover of fine clothes secured a new suit, it was sure to have its\r\nfirst airing on Broadway. So true and well understood was this fact,\r\nthat several years later a popular song, detailing this and other facts\r\nconcerning the afternoon parade on matin\xc3\xa9e days, and entitled \xe2\x80\x9cWhat\r\nRight Has He on Broadway?\xe2\x80\x9d was published, and had quite a vogue about\r\nthe music-halls of the city.\r\n\r\nIn all her stay in the city, Carrie had never heard of this showy\r\nparade; had never even been on Broadway when it was taking place. On\r\nthe other hand, it was a familiar thing to Mrs. Vance, who not only\r\nknew of it as an entity, but had often been in it, going purposely to\r\nsee and be seen, to create a stir with her beauty and dispel any\r\ntendency to fall short in dressiness by contrasting herself with the\r\nbeauty and fashion of the town.\r\n\r\nCarrie stepped along easily enough after they got out of the car at\r\nThirty-fourth Street, but soon fixed her eyes upon the lovely company\r\nwhich swarmed by and with them as they proceeded. She noticed suddenly\r\nthat Mrs. Vance\xe2\x80\x99s manner had rather stiffened under the gaze of\r\nhandsome men and elegantly dressed ladies, whose glances were not\r\nmodified by any rules of propriety. To stare seemed the proper and\r\nnatural thing. Carrie found herself stared at and ogled. Men in\r\nflawless top-coats, high hats, and silver-headed walking sticks elbowed\r\nnear and looked too often into conscious eyes. Ladies rustled by in\r\ndresses of stiff cloth, shedding affected smiles and perfume. Carrie\r\nnoticed among them the sprinkling of goodness and the heavy percentage\r\nof vice. The rouged and powdered cheeks and lips, the scented hair, the\r\nlarge, misty, and languorous eye, were common enough. With a start she\r\nawoke to find that she was in fashion\xe2\x80\x99s crowd, on parade in a show\r\nplace\xe2\x80\x94and such a show place! Jewellers\xe2\x80\x99 windows gleamed along the path\r\nwith remarkable frequency. Florist shops, furriers, haberdashers,\r\nconfectioners\xe2\x80\x94all followed in rapid succession. The street was full of\r\ncoaches. Pompous doormen in immense coats, shiny brass belts and\r\nbuttons, waited in front of expensive salesrooms. Coachmen in tan\r\nboots, white tights, and blue jackets waited obsequiously for the\r\nmistresses of carriages who were shopping inside. The whole street bore\r\nthe flavour of riches and show, and Carrie felt that she was not of it.\r\nShe could not, for the life of her, assume the attitude and smartness\r\nof Mrs. Vance, who, in her beauty, was all assurance. She could only\r\nimagine that it must be evident to many that she was the less\r\nhandsomely dressed of the two. It cut her to the quick, and she\r\nresolved that she would not come here again until she looked better. At\r\nthe same time she longed to feel the delight of parading here as an\r\nequal. Ah, then she would be happy!\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XXXII. THE FEAST OF BELSHAZZAR: A SEER TO TRANSLATE\r\n\r\nSuch feelings as were generated in Carrie by this walk put her in an\r\nexceedingly receptive mood for the pathos which followed in the play.\r\nThe actor whom they had gone to see had achieved his popularity by\r\npresenting a mellow type of comedy, in which sufficient sorrow was\r\nintroduced to lend contrast and relief to humour. For Carrie, as we\r\nwell know, the stage had a great attraction. She had never forgotten\r\nher one histrionic achievement in Chicago. It dwelt in her mind and\r\noccupied her consciousness during many long afternoons in which her\r\nrocking-chair and her latest novel contributed the only pleasures of\r\nher state. Never could she witness a play without having her own\r\nability vividly brought to consciousness. Some scenes made her long to\r\nbe a part of them\xe2\x80\x94to give expression to the feelings which she, in the\r\nplace of the character represented, would feel. Almost invariably she\r\nwould carry the vivid imaginations away with her and brood over them\r\nthe next day alone. She lived as much in these things as in the\r\nrealities which made up her daily life.\r\n\r\nIt was not often that she came to the play stirred to her heart\xe2\x80\x99s core\r\nby actualities. To-day a low song of longing had been set singing in\r\nher heart by the finery, the merriment, the beauty she had seen. Oh,\r\nthese women who had passed her by, hundreds and hundreds strong, who\r\nwere they? Whence came the rich, elegant dresses, the astonishingly\r\ncoloured buttons, the knick-knacks of silver and gold? Where were these\r\nlovely creatures housed? Amid what elegancies of carved furniture,\r\ndecorated walls, elaborate tapestries did they move? Where were their\r\nrich apartments, loaded with all that money could provide? In what\r\nstables champed these sleek, nervous horses and rested the gorgeous\r\ncarriages? Where lounged the richly groomed footmen? Oh, the mansions,\r\nthe lights, the perfume, the loaded boudoirs and tables! New York must\r\nbe filled with such bowers, or the beautiful, insolent, supercilious\r\ncreatures could not be. Some hothouses held them. It ached her to know\r\nthat she was not one of them\xe2\x80\x94that, alas, she had dreamed a dream and it\r\nhad not come true. She wondered at her own solitude these two years\r\npast\xe2\x80\x94her indifference to the fact that she had never achieved what she\r\nhad expected.\r\n\r\nThe play was one of those drawing-room concoctions in which charmingly\r\noverdressed ladies and gentlemen suffer the pangs of love and jealousy\r\namid gilded surroundings. Such bon-mots are ever enticing to those who\r\nhave all their days longed for such material surroundings and have\r\nnever had them gratified. They have the charm of showing suffering\r\nunder ideal conditions. Who would not grieve upon a gilded chair? Who\r\nwould not suffer amid perfumed tapestries, cushioned furniture, and\r\nliveried servants? Grief under such circumstances becomes an enticing\r\nthing. Carrie longed to be of it. She wanted to take her sufferings,\r\nwhatever they were, in such a world, or failing that, at least to\r\nsimulate them under such charming conditions upon the stage. So\r\naffected was her mind by what she had seen, that the play now seemed an\r\nextraordinarily beautiful thing. She was soon lost in the world it\r\nrepresented, and wished that she might never return. Between the acts\r\nshe studied the galaxy of matin\xc3\xa9e attendants in front rows and boxes,\r\nand conceived a new idea of the possibilities of New York. She was sure\r\nshe had not seen it all\xe2\x80\x94that the city was one whirl of pleasure and\r\ndelight.\r\n\r\nGoing out, the same Broadway taught her a sharper lesson. The scene she\r\nhad witnessed coming down was now augmented and at its height. Such a\r\ncrush of finery and folly she had never seen. It clinched her\r\nconvictions concerning her state. She had not lived, could not lay\r\nclaim to having lived, until something of this had come into her own\r\nlife. Women were spending money like water; she could see that in every\r\nelegant shop she passed. Flowers, candy, jewelry, seemed the principal\r\nthings in which the elegant dames were interested. And she\xe2\x80\x94she had\r\nscarcely enough pin money to indulge in such outings as this a few\r\ntimes a month.\r\n\r\nThat night the pretty little flat seemed a commonplace thing. It was\r\nnot what the rest of the world was enjoying. She saw the servant\r\nworking at dinner with an indifferent eye. In her mind were running\r\nscenes of the play. Particularly she remembered one beautiful\r\nactress\xe2\x80\x94the sweetheart who had been wooed and won. The grace of this\r\nwoman had won Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s heart. Her dresses had been all that art could\r\nsuggest, her sufferings had been so real. The anguish which she had\r\nportrayed Carrie could feel. It was done as she was sure she could do\r\nit. There were places in which she could even do better. Hence she\r\nrepeated the lines to herself. Oh, if she could only have such a part,\r\nhow broad would be her life! She, too, could act appealingly.\r\n\r\nWhen Hurstwood came, Carrie was moody. She was sitting, rocking and\r\nthinking, and did not care to have her enticing imaginations broken in\r\nupon; so she said little or nothing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the matter, Carrie?\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood after a time, noticing her\r\nquiet, almost moody state.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie. \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t feel very well to-night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot sick, are you?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, approaching very close.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, almost pettishly, \xe2\x80\x9cI just don\xe2\x80\x99t feel very good.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s too bad,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, stepping away and adjusting his vest after\r\nhis slight bending over. \xe2\x80\x9cI was thinking we might go to a show\r\nto-night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t want to go,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, annoyed that her fine visions should\r\nhave thus been broken into and driven out of her mind. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve been to\r\nthe matin\xc3\xa9e this afternoon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, you have?\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat was it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA Gold Mine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow was it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPretty good,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you don\xe2\x80\x99t want to go again to-night?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t think I do,\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\r\n\r\nNevertheless, wakened out of her melancholia and called to the dinner\r\ntable, she changed her mind. A little food in the stomach does wonders.\r\nShe went again, and in so doing temporarily recovered her equanimity.\r\nThe great awakening blow had, however, been delivered. As often as she\r\nmight recover from these discontented thoughts now, they would occur\r\nagain. Time and repetition\xe2\x80\x94ah, the wonder of it! The dropping water and\r\nthe solid stone\xe2\x80\x94how utterly it yields at last!\r\n\r\nNot long after this matin\xc3\xa9e experience\xe2\x80\x94perhaps a month\xe2\x80\x94Mrs. Vance\r\ninvited Carrie to an evening at the theatre with them. She heard Carrie\r\nsay that Hurstwood was not coming home to dinner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy don\xe2\x80\x99t you come with us? Don\xe2\x80\x99t get dinner for yourself. We\xe2\x80\x99re going\r\ndown to Sherry\xe2\x80\x99s for dinner and then over to the Lyceum. Come along\r\nwith us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think I will,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Carrie.\r\n\r\nShe began to dress at three o\xe2\x80\x99clock for her departure at half-past five\r\nfor the noted dining-room which was then crowding Delmonico\xe2\x80\x99s for\r\nposition in society. In this dressing Carrie showed the influence of\r\nher association with the dashing Mrs. Vance. She had constantly had her\r\nattention called by the latter to novelties in everything which\r\npertains to a woman\xe2\x80\x99s apparel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you going to get such and such a hat?\xe2\x80\x9d or, \xe2\x80\x9cHave you seen the new\r\ngloves with the oval pearl buttons?\xe2\x80\x9d were but sample phrases out of a\r\nlarge selection.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe next time you get a pair of shoes, dearie,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Vance, \xe2\x80\x9cget\r\nbutton, with thick soles and patent-leather tips. They\xe2\x80\x99re all the rage\r\nthis fall.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, dear, have you seen the new shirtwaists at Altman\xe2\x80\x99s? They have\r\nsome of the loveliest patterns. I saw one there that I know would look\r\nstunning on you. I said so when I saw it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie listened to these things with considerable interest, for they\r\nwere suggested with more of friendliness than is usually common between\r\npretty women. Mrs. Vance liked Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s stable good-nature so well that\r\nshe really took pleasure in suggesting to her the latest things.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy don\xe2\x80\x99t you get yourself one of those nice serge skirts they\xe2\x80\x99re\r\nselling at Lord & Taylor\xe2\x80\x99s?\xe2\x80\x9d she said one day. \xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99re the circular\r\nstyle, and they\xe2\x80\x99re going to be worn from now on. A dark blue one would\r\nlook so nice on you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie listened with eager ears. These things never came up between her\r\nand Hurstwood. Nevertheless, she began to suggest one thing and\r\nanother, which Hurstwood agreed to without any expression of opinion.\r\nHe noticed the new tendency on Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s part, and finally, hearing much\r\nof Mrs. Vance and her delightful ways, suspected whence the change\r\ncame. He was not inclined to offer the slightest objection so soon, but\r\nhe felt that Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s wants were expanding. This did not appeal to him\r\nexactly, but he cared for her in his own way, and so the thing stood.\r\nStill, there was something in the details of the transactions which\r\ncaused Carrie to feel that her requests were not a delight to him. He\r\ndid not enthuse over the purchases. This led her to believe that\r\nneglect was creeping in, and so another small wedge was entered.\r\n\r\nNevertheless, one of the results of Mrs. Vance\xe2\x80\x99s suggestions was the\r\nfact that on this occasion Carrie was dressed somewhat to her own\r\nsatisfaction.
