She had on her best, but there was comfort in the thought\r\nthat if she must confine herself to a _best_, it was neat and fitting.\r\nShe looked the well-groomed woman of twenty-one, and Mrs. Vance praised\r\nher, which brought colour to her plump cheeks and a noticeable\r\nbrightness into her large eyes. It was threatening rain, and Mr. Vance,\r\nat his wife\xe2\x80\x99s request, had called a coach.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour husband isn\xe2\x80\x99t coming?\xe2\x80\x9d suggested Mr. Vance, as he met Carrie in\r\nhis little parlour.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; he said he wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be home for dinner.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBetter leave a little note for him, telling him where we are. He might\r\nturn up.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, who had not thought of it before.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell him we\xe2\x80\x99ll be at Sherry\xe2\x80\x99s until eight o\xe2\x80\x99clock. He knows, though I\r\nguess.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie crossed the hall with rustling skirts, and scrawled the note,\r\ngloves on. When she returned a newcomer was in the Vance flat.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMrs. Wheeler, let me introduce Mr. Ames, a cousin of mine,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs.\r\nVance. \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s going along with us, aren\xe2\x80\x99t you, Bob?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m very glad to meet you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ames, bowing politely to Carrie.\r\n\r\nThe latter caught in a glance the dimensions of a very stalwart figure.\r\nShe also noticed that he was smooth-shaven, good looking, and young,\r\nbut nothing more.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Ames is just down in New York for a few days,\xe2\x80\x9d put in Vance, \xe2\x80\x9cand\r\nwe\xe2\x80\x99re trying to show him around a little.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, are you?\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, taking another glance at the newcomer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; I am just on here from Indianapolis for a week or so,\xe2\x80\x9d said young\r\nAmes, seating himself on the edge of a chair to wait while Mrs. Vance\r\ncompleted the last touches of her toilet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI guess you find New York quite a thing to see, don\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nCarrie, venturing something to avoid a possible deadly silence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is rather large to get around in a week,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Ames,\r\npleasantly.\r\n\r\nHe was an exceedingly genial soul, this young man, and wholly free of\r\naffectation. It seemed to Carrie he was as yet only overcoming the last\r\ntraces of the bashfulness of youth. He did not seem apt at\r\nconversation, but he had the merit of being well dressed and wholly\r\ncourageous. Carrie felt as if it were not going to be hard to talk to\r\nhim.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I guess we\xe2\x80\x99re ready now. The coach is outside.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome on, people,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Vance, coming in smiling. \xe2\x80\x9cBob, you\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nhave to look after Mrs. Wheeler.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll try to,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bob smiling, and edging closer to Carrie. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\r\nwon\xe2\x80\x99t need much watching, will you?\xe2\x80\x9d he volunteered, in a sort of\r\ningratiating and help-me-out kind of way.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot very, I hope,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\nThey descended the stairs, Mrs. Vance offering suggestions, and climbed\r\ninto the open coach.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right,\xe2\x80\x9d said Vance, slamming the coach door, and the conveyance\r\nrolled away.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it we\xe2\x80\x99re going to see?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Ames.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSothern,\xe2\x80\x9d said Vance, \xe2\x80\x9cin \xe2\x80\x98Lord Chumley.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, he is so good!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Vance. \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s just the funniest man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI notice the papers praise it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ames.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI haven\xe2\x80\x99t any doubt,\xe2\x80\x9d put in Vance, \xe2\x80\x9cbut we\xe2\x80\x99ll all enjoy it very\r\nmuch.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAmes had taken a seat beside Carrie, and accordingly he felt it his\r\nbounden duty to pay her some attention. He was interested to find her\r\nso young a wife, and so pretty, though it was only a respectful\r\ninterest. There was nothing of the dashing lady\xe2\x80\x99s man about him. He had\r\nrespect for the married state, and thought only of some pretty\r\nmarriageable girls in Indianapolis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you a born New Yorker?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Ames of Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no; I\xe2\x80\x99ve only been here for two years.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, well, you\xe2\x80\x99ve had time to see a great deal of it, anyhow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t seem to have,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Carrie. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s about as strange to me\r\nas when I first came here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re not from the West, are you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. I\xe2\x80\x99m from Wisconsin,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, it does seem as if most people in this town haven\xe2\x80\x99t been here so\r\nvery long. I hear of lots of Indiana people in my line who are here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is your line?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m connected with an electrical company,\xe2\x80\x9d said the youth.\r\n\r\nCarrie followed up this desultory conversation with occasional\r\ninterruptions from the Vances. Several times it became general and\r\npartially humorous, and in that manner the restaurant was reached.\r\n\r\nCarrie had noticed the appearance of gayety and pleasure-seeking in the\r\nstreets which they were following. Coaches were numerous, pedestrians\r\nmany, and in Fifty-ninth Street the street cars were crowded. At\r\nFifty-ninth Street and Fifth Avenue a blaze of lights from several new\r\nhotels which bordered the Plaza Square gave a suggestion of sumptuous\r\nhotel life. Fifth Avenue, the home of the wealthy, was noticeably\r\ncrowded with carriages, and gentlemen in evening dress. At Sherry\xe2\x80\x99s an\r\nimposing doorman opened the coach door and helped them out. Young Ames\r\nheld Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s elbow as he helped her up the steps. They entered the\r\nlobby already swarming with patrons, and then, after divesting\r\nthemselves of their wraps, went into a sumptuous dining-room.\r\n\r\nIn all Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s experience she had never seen anything like this. In\r\nthe whole time she had been in New York Hurstwood\xe2\x80\x99s modified state had\r\nnot permitted his bringing her to such a place. There was an almost\r\nindescribable atmosphere about it which convinced the newcomer that\r\nthis was the proper thing. Here was the place where the matter of\r\nexpense limited the patrons to the moneyed or pleasure-loving class.\r\nCarrie had read of it often in the \xe2\x80\x9cMorning\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cEvening World.\xe2\x80\x9d She\r\nhad seen notices of dances, parties, balls, and suppers at Sherry\xe2\x80\x99s.\r\nThe Misses So-and-so would give a party on Wednesday evening at\r\nSherry\xe2\x80\x99s. Young Mr. So-and-so would entertain a party of friends at a\r\nprivate luncheon on the sixteenth, at Sherry\xe2\x80\x99s. The common run of\r\nconventional, perfunctory notices of the doings of society, which she\r\ncould scarcely refrain from scanning each day, had given her a distinct\r\nidea of the gorgeousness and luxury of this wonderful temple of\r\ngastronomy. Now, at last, she was really in it. She had come up the\r\nimposing steps, guarded by the large and portly doorman. She had seen\r\nthe lobby, guarded by another large and portly gentleman, and been\r\nwaited upon by uniformed youths who took care of canes, overcoats, and\r\nthe like. Here was the splendid dining-chamber, all decorated and\r\naglow, where the wealthy ate. Ah, how fortunate was Mrs. Vance; young,\r\nbeautiful, and well off\xe2\x80\x94at least, sufficiently so to come here in a\r\ncoach. What a wonderful thing it was to be rich.\r\n\r\nVance led the way through lanes of shining tables, at which were seated\r\nparties of two, three, four, five, or six. The air of assurance and\r\ndignity about it all was exceedingly noticeable to the novitiate.\r\nIncandescent lights, the reflection of their glow in polished glasses,\r\nand the shine of gilt upon the walls, combined into one tone of light\r\nwhich it requires minutes of complacent observation to separate and\r\ntake particular note of. The white shirt fronts of the gentlemen, the\r\nbright costumes of the ladies, diamonds, jewels, fine feathers\xe2\x80\x94all were\r\nexceedingly noticeable.\r\n\r\nCarrie walked with an air equal to that of Mrs. Vance, and accepted the\r\nseat which the head waiter provided for her. She was keenly aware of\r\nall the little things that were done\xe2\x80\x94the little genuflections and\r\nattentions of the waiters and head waiter which Americans pay for. The\r\nair with which the latter pulled out each chair, and the wave of the\r\nhand with which he motioned them to be seated, were worth several\r\ndollars in themselves.\r\n\r\nOnce seated, there began that exhibition of showy, wasteful, and\r\nunwholesome gastronomy as practised by wealthy Americans, which is the\r\nwonder and astonishment of true culture and dignity the world over. The\r\nlarge bill of fare held an array of dishes sufficient to feed an army,\r\nsidelined with prices which made reasonable expenditure a ridiculous\r\nimpossibility\xe2\x80\x94an order of soup at fifty cents or a dollar, with a dozen\r\nkinds to choose from; oysters in forty styles and at sixty cents the\r\nhalf-dozen; entr\xc3\xa9es, fish, and meats at prices which would house one\r\nover night in an average hotel. One dollar fifty and two dollars seemed\r\nto be the most common figures upon this most tastefully printed bill of\r\nfare.\r\n\r\nCarrie noticed this, and in scanning it the price of spring chicken\r\ncarried her back to that other bill of fare and far different occasion\r\nwhen, for the first time, she sat with Drouet in a good restaurant in\r\nChicago. It was only momentary\xe2\x80\x94a sad note as out of an old song\xe2\x80\x94and\r\nthen it was gone. But in that flash was seen the other Carrie\xe2\x80\x94poor,\r\nhungry, drifting at her wits\xe2\x80\x99 ends, and all Chicago a cold and closed\r\nworld, from which she only wandered because she could not find work.\r\n\r\nOn the walls were designs in colour, square spots of robin\xe2\x80\x99s-egg blue,\r\nset in ornate frames of gilt, whose corners were elaborate mouldings of\r\nfruit and flowers, with fat cupids hovering in angelic comfort. On the\r\nceilings were coloured traceries with more gilt, leading to a centre\r\nwhere spread a cluster of lights\xe2\x80\x94incandescent globes mingled with\r\nglittering prisms and stucco tendrils of gilt. The floor was of a\r\nreddish hue, waxed and polished, and in every direction were\r\nmirrors\xe2\x80\x94tall, brilliant, bevel-edged mirrors\xe2\x80\x94reflecting and\r\nre-reflecting forms, faces, and candelabra a score and a hundred times.\r\n\r\nThe tables were not so remarkable in themselves, and yet the imprint of\r\nSherry upon the napery, the name of Tiffany upon the silverware, the\r\nname of Haviland upon the china, and over all the glow of the small,\r\nred-shaded candelabra and the reflected tints of the walls on garments\r\nand faces, made them seem remarkable. Each waiter added an air of\r\nexclusiveness and elegance by the manner in which he bowed, scraped,\r\ntouched, and trifled with things. The exclusively personal attention\r\nwhich he devoted to each one, standing half bent, ear to one side,\r\nelbows akimbo, saying: \xe2\x80\x9cSoup\xe2\x80\x94green turtle, yes. One portion, yes.\r\nOysters\xe2\x80\x94certainly\xe2\x80\x94half-dozen\xe2\x80\x94yes. Asparagus. Olives\xe2\x80\x94yes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt would be the same with each one, only Vance essayed to order for\r\nall, inviting counsel and suggestions. Carrie studied the company with\r\nopen eyes. So this was high life in New York. It was so that the rich\r\nspent their days and evenings. Her poor little mind could not rise\r\nabove applying each scene to all society. Every fine lady must be in\r\nthe crowd on Broadway in the afternoon, in the theatre at the matin\xc3\xa9e,\r\nin the coaches and dining-halls at night. It must be glow and shine\r\neverywhere, with coaches waiting, and footmen attending, and she was\r\nout of it all. In two long years she had never even been in such a\r\nplace as this.\r\n\r\nVance was in his element here, as Hurstwood would have been in former\r\ndays. He ordered freely of soup, oysters, roast meats, and side dishes,\r\nand had several bottles of wine brought, which were set down beside the\r\ntable in a wicker basket.\r\n\r\nAmes was looking away rather abstractedly at the crowd and showed an\r\ninteresting profile to Carrie. His forehead was high, his nose rather\r\nlarge and strong, his chin moderately pleasing. He had a good, wide,\r\nwell-shaped mouth, and his dark-brown hair was parted slightly on one\r\nside. He seemed to have the least touch of boyishness to Carrie, and\r\nyet he was a man full grown.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, turning back to Carrie, after his reflection,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI sometimes think it is a shame for people to spend so much money this\r\nway.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie looked at him a moment with the faintest touch of surprise at\r\nhis seriousness. He seemed to be thinking about something over which\r\nshe had never pondered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you?\xe2\x80\x9d she answered, interestedly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cthey pay so much more than these things are worth.\r\nThey put on so much show.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know why people shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t spend when they have it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs.\r\nVance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt doesn\xe2\x80\x99t do any harm,\xe2\x80\x9d said Vance, who was still studying the bill\r\nof fare, though he had ordered.\r\n\r\nAmes was looking away again, and Carrie was again looking at his\r\nforehead. To her he seemed to be thinking about strange things. As he\r\nstudied the crowd his eye was mild.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLook at that woman\xe2\x80\x99s dress over there,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, again turning to\r\nCarrie, and nodding in a direction.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere?\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, following his eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOver there in the corner\xe2\x80\x94way over. Do you see that brooch?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIsn\xe2\x80\x99t it large?\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne of the largest clusters of jewels I have ever seen,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ames.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is, isn\xe2\x80\x99t it?\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie. She felt as if she would like to be\r\nagreeable to this young man, and also there came with it, or perhaps\r\npreceded it, the slightest shade of a feeling that he was better\r\neducated than she was\xe2\x80\x94that his mind was better. He seemed to look it,\r\nand the saving grace in Carrie was that she could understand that\r\npeople could be wiser. She had seen a number of people in her life who\r\nreminded her of what she had vaguely come to think of as scholars. This\r\nstrong young man beside her, with his clear, natural look, seemed to\r\nget a hold of things which she did not quite understand, but approved\r\nof. It was fine to be so, as a man, she thought.\r\n\r\nThe conversation changed to a book that was having its vogue at the\r\ntime\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cMoulding a Maiden,\xe2\x80\x9d by Albert Ross. Mrs. Vance had read it. Vance\r\nhad seen it discussed in some of the papers.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA man can make quite a strike writing a book,\xe2\x80\x9d said Vance. \xe2\x80\x9cI notice\r\nthis fellow Ross is very much talked about.\xe2\x80\x9d He was looking at Carrie\r\nas he spoke.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hadn\xe2\x80\x99t heard of him,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, honestly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I have,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Vance. \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s written lots of things. This last\r\nstory is pretty good.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe doesn\xe2\x80\x99t amount to much,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ames.\r\n\r\nCarrie turned her eyes toward him as to an oracle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHis stuff is nearly as bad as \xe2\x80\x98Dora Thorne,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d concluded Ames.\r\n\r\nCarrie felt this as a personal reproof. She read \xe2\x80\x9cDora Thorne,\xe2\x80\x9d or had\r\na great deal in the past. It seemed only fair to her, but she supposed\r\nthat people thought it very fine. Now this clear-eyed, fine-headed\r\nyouth, who looked something like a student to her, made fun of it. It\r\nwas poor to him, not worth reading. She looked down, and for the first\r\ntime felt the pain of not understanding.\r\n\r\nYet there was nothing sarcastic or supercilious in the way Ames spoke.\r\nHe had very little of that in him. Carrie felt that it was just kindly\r\nthought of a high order\xe2\x80\x94the right thing to think, and wondered what\r\nelse was right, according to him. He seemed to notice that she listened\r\nand rather sympathised with him, and from now on he talked mostly to\r\nher.\r\n\r\nAs the waiter bowed and scraped about, felt the dishes to see if they\r\nwere hot enough, brought spoons and forks, and did all those little\r\nattentive things calculated to impress the luxury of the situation upon\r\nthe diner, Ames also leaned slightly to one side and told her of\r\nIndianapolis in an intelligent way. He really had a very bright mind,\r\nwhich was finding its chief development in electrical knowledge. His\r\nsympathies for other forms of information, however, and for types of\r\npeople, were quick and warm. The red glow on his head gave it a sandy\r\ntinge and put a bright glint in his eye. Carrie noticed all these\r\nthings as he leaned toward her and felt exceedingly young. This man was\r\nfar ahead of her. He seemed wiser than Hurstwood, saner and brighter\r\nthan Drouet. He seemed innocent and clean, and she thought that he was\r\nexceedingly pleasant. She noticed, also, that his interest in her was a\r\nfar-off one. She was not in his life, nor any of the things that\r\ntouched his life, and yet now, as he spoke of these things, they\r\nappealed to her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t care to be rich,\xe2\x80\x9d he told her, as the dinner proceeded and\r\nthe supply of food warmed up his sympathies; \xe2\x80\x9cnot rich enough to spend\r\nmy money this way.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, the, to her, new attitude forcing\r\nitself distinctly upon her for the first time.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat good would it do? A man doesn\xe2\x80\x99t need this sort of\r\nthing to be happy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie thought of this doubtfully; but, coming from him, it had weight\r\nwith her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe probably could be happy,\xe2\x80\x9d she thought to herself, \xe2\x80\x9call alone. He\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nso strong.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. and Mrs. Vance kept up a running fire of interruptions, and these\r\nimpressive things by Ames came at odd moments. They were sufficient,\r\nhowever, for the atmosphere that went with this youth impressed itself\r\nupon Carrie without words. There was something in him, or the world he\r\nmoved in, which appealed to her. He reminded her of scenes she had seen\r\non the stage\xe2\x80\x94the sorrows and sacrifices that always went with she knew\r\nnot what. He had taken away some of the bitterness of the contrast\r\nbetween this life and her life, and all by a certain calm indifference\r\nwhich concerned only him.\r\n\r\nAs they went out, he took her arm and helped her into the coach, and\r\nthen they were off again, and so to the show.\r\n\r\nDuring the acts Carrie found herself listening to him very attentively.\r\nHe mentioned things in the play which she most approved of\xe2\x80\x94things which\r\nswayed her deeply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t you think it rather fine to be an actor?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked once.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I do,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cto be a good one. I think the theatre a great\r\nthing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nJust this little approval set Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s heart bounding. Ah, if she could\r\nonly be an actress\xe2\x80\x94a good one! This man was wise\xe2\x80\x94he knew\xe2\x80\x94and he\r\napproved of it. If she were a fine actress, such men as he would\r\napprove of her. She felt that he was good to speak as he had, although\r\nit did not concern her at all. She did not know why she felt this way.\r\n\r\nAt the close of the show it suddenly developed that he was not going\r\nback with them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, aren\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, with an unwarrantable feeling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no,\xe2\x80\x9d he said; \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m stopping right around here in Thirty-third\r\nStreet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie could not say anything else, but somehow this development\r\nshocked her. She had been regretting the wane of a pleasant evening,\r\nbut she had thought there was a half-hour more. Oh, the half-hours, the\r\nminutes of the world; what miseries and griefs are crowded into them!\r\n\r\nShe said good-bye with feigned indifference. What matter could it make?\r\nStill, the coach seemed lorn.\r\n\r\nWhen she went into her own flat she had this to think about. She did\r\nnot know whether she would ever see this man any more. What difference\r\ncould it make\xe2\x80\x94what difference could it make?\r\n\r\nHurstwood had returned, and was already in bed. His clothes were\r\nscattered loosely about. Carrie came to the door and saw him, then\r\nretreated. She did not want to go in yet a while. She wanted to think.\r\nIt was disagreeable to her.\r\n\r\nBack in the dining-room she sat in her chair and rocked. Her little\r\nhands were folded tightly as she thought. Through a fog of longing and\r\nconflicting desires she was beginning to see. Oh, ye legions of hope\r\nand pity\xe2\x80\x94of sorrow and pain! She was rocking, and beginning to see.\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XXXIII. WITHOUT THE WALLED CITY: THE SLOPE OF THE YEARS\r\n\r\nThe immediate result of this was nothing. Results from such things are\r\nusually long in growing. Morning brings a change of feeling. The\r\nexistent condition invariably pleads for itself. It is only at odd\r\nmoments that we get glimpses of the misery of things. The heart\r\nunderstands when it is confronted with contrasts. Take them away and\r\nthe ache subsides.\r\n\r\nCarrie went on, leading much this same life for six months thereafter\r\nor more. She did not see Ames any more. He called once upon the Vances,\r\nbut she only heard about it through the young wife. Then he went West,\r\nand there was a gradual subsidence of whatever personal attraction had\r\nexisted. The mental effect of the thing had not gone, however, and\r\nnever would entirely. She had an ideal to contrast men by\xe2\x80\x94particularly\r\nmen close to her.\r\n\r\nDuring all this time\xe2\x80\x94a period rapidly approaching three years\xe2\x80\x94Hurstwood\r\nhad been moving along in an even path. There was no apparent slope\r\ndownward, and distinctly none upward, so far as the casual observer\r\nmight have seen. But psychologically there was a change, which was\r\nmarked enough to suggest the future very distinctly indeed. This was in\r\nthe mere matter of the halt his career had received when he departed\r\nfrom Chicago. A man\xe2\x80\x99s fortune or material progress is very much the\r\nsame as his bodily growth. Either he is growing stronger, healthier,\r\nwiser, as the youth approaching manhood, or he is growing weaker,\r\nolder, less incisive mentally, as the man approaching old age. There\r\nare no other states. Frequently there is a period between the cessation\r\nof youthful accretion and the setting in, in the case of the\r\nmiddle-aged man, of the tendency toward decay when the two processes\r\nare almost perfectly balanced and there is little doing in either\r\ndirection. Given time enough, however, the balance becomes a sagging to\r\nthe grave side. Slowly at first, then with a modest momentum, and at\r\nlast the graveward process is in the full swing. So it is frequently\r\nwith man\xe2\x80\x99s fortune. If its process of accretion is never halted, if the\r\nbalancing stage is never reached, there will be no toppling. Rich men\r\nare, frequently, in these days, saved from this dissolution of their\r\nfortune by their ability to hire younger brains. These younger brains\r\nlook upon the interests of the fortune as their own, and so steady and\r\ndirect its progress. If each individual were left absolutely to the\r\ncare of his own interests, and were given time enough in which to grow\r\nexceedingly old, his fortune would pass as his strength and will. He\r\nand his would be utterly dissolved and scattered unto the four winds of\r\nthe heavens.\r\n\r\nBut now see wherein the parallel changes. A fortune, like a man, is an\r\norganism which draws to itself other minds and other strength than that\r\ninherent in the founder. Beside the young minds drawn to it by\r\nsalaries, it becomes allied with young forces, which make for its\r\nexistence even when the strength and wisdom of the founder are fading.\r\nIt may be conserved by the growth of a community or of a state. It may\r\nbe involved in providing something for which there is a growing demand.\r\nThis removes it at once beyond the special care of the founder. It\r\nneeds not so much foresight now as direction. The man wanes, the need\r\ncontinues or grows, and the fortune, fallen into whose hands it may,\r\ncontinues. Hence, some men never recognise the turning in the tide of\r\ntheir abilities. It is only in chance cases, where a fortune or a state\r\nof success is wrested from them, that the lack of ability to do as they\r\ndid formerly becomes apparent. Hurstwood, set down under new\r\nconditions, was in a position to see that he was no longer young. If he\r\ndid not, it was due wholly to the fact that his state was so well\r\nbalanced that an absolute change for the worse did not show.\r\n\r\nNot trained to reason or introspect himself, he could not analyse the\r\nchange that was taking place in his mind, and hence his body, but he\r\nfelt the depression of it. Constant comparison between his old state\r\nand his new showed a balance for the worse, which produced a constant\r\nstate of gloom or, at least, depression. Now, it has been shown\r\nexperimentally that a constantly subdued frame of mind produces certain\r\npoisons in the blood, called katastates, just as virtuous feelings of\r\npleasure and delight produce helpful chemicals called anastates. The\r\npoisons generated by remorse inveigh against the system, and eventually\r\nproduce marked physical deterioration. To these Hurstwood was subject.\r\n\r\nIn the course of time it told upon his temper. His eye no longer\r\npossessed that buoyant, searching shrewdness which had characterised it\r\nin Adams Street. His step was not as sharp and firm. He was given to\r\nthinking, thinking, thinking. The new friends he made were not\r\ncelebrities. They were of a cheaper, a slightly more sensual and\r\ncruder, grade. He could not possibly take the pleasure in this company\r\nthat he had in that of those fine frequenters of the Chicago resort. He\r\nwas left to brood.\r\n\r\nSlowly, exceedingly slowly, his desire to greet, conciliate, and make\r\nat home these people who visited the Warren Street place passed from\r\nhim. More and more slowly the significance of the realm he had left\r\nbegan to be clear. It did not seem so wonderful to be in it when he was\r\nin it. It had seemed very easy for any one to get up there and have\r\nample raiment and money to spend, but now that he was out of it, how\r\nfar off it became. He began to see as one sees a city with a wall about\r\nit. Men were posted at the gates. You could not get in. Those inside\r\ndid not care to come out to see who you were. They were so merry inside\r\nthere that all those outside were forgotten, and he was on the outside.\r\n\r\nEach day he could read in the evening papers of the doings within this\r\nwalled city. In the notices of passengers for Europe he read the names\r\nof eminent frequenters of his old resort. In the theatrical column\r\nappeared, from time to time, announcements of the latest successes of\r\nmen he had known. He knew that they were at their old gayeties.\r\nPullmans were hauling them to and fro about the land, papers were\r\ngreeting them with interesting mentions, the elegant lobbies of hotels\r\nand the glow of polished dining-rooms were keeping them close within\r\nthe walled city. Men whom he had known, men whom he had tipped glasses\r\nwith\xe2\x80\x94rich men, and he was forgotten! Who was Mr. Wheeler? What was the\r\nWarren Street resort? Bah!\r\n\r\nIf one thinks that such thoughts do not come to so common a type of\r\nmind\xe2\x80\x94that such feelings require a higher mental development\xe2\x80\x94I would\r\nurge for their consideration the fact that it is the higher mental\r\ndevelopment that does away with such thoughts. It is the higher mental\r\ndevelopment which induces philosophy and that fortitude which refuses\r\nto dwell upon such things\xe2\x80\x94refuses to be made to suffer by their\r\nconsideration. The common type of mind is exceedingly keen on all\r\nmatters which relate to its physical welfare\xe2\x80\x94exceedingly keen. It is\r\nthe unintellectual miser who sweats blood at the loss of a hundred\r\ndollars. It is the Epictetus who smiles when the last vestige of\r\nphysical welfare is removed.\r\n\r\nThe time came, in the third year, when this thinking began to produce\r\nresults in the Warren Street place. The tide of patronage dropped a\r\nlittle below what it had been at its best since he had been there. This\r\nirritated and worried him.\r\n\r\nThere came a night when he confessed to Carrie that the business was\r\nnot doing as well this month as it had the month before. This was in\r\nlieu of certain suggestions she had made concerning little things she\r\nwanted to buy. She had not failed to notice that he did not seem to\r\nconsult her about buying clothes for himself. For the first time, it\r\nstruck her as a ruse, or that he said it so that she would not think of\r\nasking for things. Her reply was mild enough, but her thoughts were\r\nrebellious. He was not looking after her at all. She was depending for\r\nher enjoyment upon the Vances.\r\n\r\nAnd now the latter announced that they were going away. It was\r\napproaching spring, and they were going North.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Vance to Carrie, \xe2\x80\x9cwe think we might as well give\r\nup the flat and store our things. We\xe2\x80\x99ll be gone for the summer, and it\r\nwould be a useless expense. I think we\xe2\x80\x99ll settle a little farther down\r\ntown when we come back.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie heard this with genuine sorrow. She had enjoyed Mrs. Vance\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncompanionship so much. There was no one else in the house whom she\r\nknew. Again she would be all alone.\r\n\r\nHurstwood\xe2\x80\x99s gloom over the slight decrease in profits and the departure\r\nof the Vances came together. So Carrie had loneliness and this mood of\r\nher husband to enjoy at the same time. It was a grievous thing. She\r\nbecame restless and dissatisfied, not exactly, as she thought, with\r\nHurstwood, but with life. What was it? A very dull round indeed. What\r\ndid she have? Nothing but this narrow, little flat. The Vances could\r\ntravel, they could do the things worth doing, and here she was. For\r\nwhat was she made, anyhow? More thought followed, and then tears\xe2\x80\x94tears\r\nseemed justified, and the only relief in the world.\r\n\r\nFor another period this state continued, the twain leading a rather\r\nmonotonous life, and then there was a slight change for the worse. One\r\nevening, Hurstwood, after thinking about a way to modify Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndesire for clothes and the general strain upon his ability to provide,\r\nsaid:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t think I\xe2\x80\x99ll ever be able to do much with Shaughnessy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the matter?\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, he\xe2\x80\x99s a slow, greedy \xe2\x80\x98mick\xe2\x80\x99! He won\xe2\x80\x99t agree to anything to improve\r\nthe place, and it won\xe2\x80\x99t ever pay without it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan\xe2\x80\x99t you make him?\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; I\xe2\x80\x99ve tried. The only thing I can see, if I want to improve, is to\r\nget hold of a place of my own.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy don\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, all I have is tied up in there just now. If I had a chance to\r\nsave a while I think I could open a place that would give us plenty of\r\nmoney.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan\xe2\x80\x99t we save?\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe might try it,\xe2\x80\x9d he suggested. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve been thinking that if we\xe2\x80\x99d take\r\na smaller flat down town and live economically for a year, I would have\r\nenough, with what I have invested, to open a good place. Then we could\r\narrange to live as you want to.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt would suit me all right,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, who, nevertheless, felt\r\nbadly to think it had come to this. Talk of a smaller flat sounded like\r\npoverty.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere are lots of nice little flats down around Sixth Avenue, below\r\nFourteenth Street. We might get one down there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll look at them if you say so,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think I could break away from this fellow inside of a year,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nHurstwood. \xe2\x80\x9cNothing will ever come of this arrangement as it\xe2\x80\x99s going on\r\nnow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll look around,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, observing that the proposed change\r\nseemed to be a serious thing with him.\r\n\r\nThe upshot of this was that the change was eventually effected; not\r\nwithout great gloom on the part of Carrie. It really affected her more\r\nseriously than anything that had yet happened. She began to look upon\r\nHurstwood wholly as a man, and not as a lover or husband. She felt\r\nthoroughly bound to him as a wife, and that her lot was cast with his,\r\nwhatever it might be; but she began to see that he was gloomy and\r\ntaciturn, not a young, strong, and buoyant man. He looked a little bit\r\nold to her about the eyes and mouth now, and there were other things\r\nwhich placed him in his true rank, so far as her estimation was\r\nconcerned. She began to feel that she had made a mistake. Incidentally,\r\nshe also began to recall the fact that he had practically forced her to\r\nflee with him.\r\n\r\nThe new flat was located in Thirteenth Street, a half block west of\r\nSixth Avenue, and contained only four rooms. The new neighbourhood did\r\nnot appeal to Carrie as much. There were no trees here, no west view of\r\nthe river. The street was solidly built up. There were twelve families\r\nhere, respectable enough, but nothing like the Vances. Richer people\r\nrequired more space.\r\n\r\nBeing left alone in this little place, Carrie did without a girl. She\r\nmade it charming enough, but could not make it delight her. Hurstwood\r\nwas not inwardly pleased to think that they should have to modify their\r\nstate, but he argued that he could do nothing. He must put the best\r\nface on it, and let it go at that.\r\n\r\nHe tried to show Carrie that there was no cause for financial alarm,\r\nbut only congratulation over the chance he would have at the end of the\r\nyear by taking her rather more frequently to the theatre and by\r\nproviding a liberal table. This was for the time only. He was getting\r\nin the frame of mind where he wanted principally to be alone and to be\r\nallowed to think. The disease of brooding was beginning to claim him as\r\na victim. Only the newspapers and his own thoughts were worth while.\r\nThe delight of love had again slipped away. It was a case of live, now,\r\nmaking the best you can out of a very commonplace station in life.\r\n\r\nThe road downward has but few landings and level places. The very state\r\nof his mind, superinduced by his condition, caused the breach to widen\r\nbetween him and his partner. At last that individual began to wish that\r\nHurstwood was out of it. It so happened, however, that a real estate\r\ndeal on the part of the owner of the land arranged things even more\r\neffectually than ill-will could have schemed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you see that?\xe2\x80\x9d said Shaughnessy one morning to Hurstwood, pointing\r\nto the real estate column in a copy of the \xe2\x80\x9cHerald,\xe2\x80\x9d which he held.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, what is it?\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood, looking down the items of news.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe man who owns this ground has sold it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t say so?\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood.\r\n\r\nHe looked, and there was the notice. Mr. August Viele had yesterday\r\nregistered the transfer of the lot, 25 x 75 feet, at the corner of\r\nWarren and Hudson Streets, to J. F. Slawson for the sum of $57,000.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOur lease expires when?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Hurstwood, thinking. \xe2\x80\x9cNext February,\r\nisn\xe2\x80\x99t it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s right,\xe2\x80\x9d said Shaughnessy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt doesn\xe2\x80\x99t say what the new man\xe2\x80\x99s going to do with it,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked\r\nHurstwood, looking back to the paper.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ll hear, I guess, soon enough,\xe2\x80\x9d said Shaughnessy.\r\n\r\nSure enough, it did develop. Mr. Slawson owned the property adjoining,\r\nand was going to put up a modern office building. The present one was\r\nto be torn down. It would take probably a year and a half to complete\r\nthe other one.\r\n\r\nAll these things developed by degrees, and Hurstwood began to ponder\r\nover what would become of the saloon. One day he spoke about it to his\r\npartner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you think it would be worth while to open up somewhere else in the\r\nneighbourhood?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat would be the use?\xe2\x80\x9d said Shaughnessy. \xe2\x80\x9cWe couldn\xe2\x80\x99t get another\r\ncorner around here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t pay anywhere else, do you think?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t try it,\xe2\x80\x9d said the other. The approaching change now took on\r\na most serious aspect to Hurstwood. Dissolution meant the loss of his\r\nthousand dollars, and he could not save another thousand in the time.\r\nHe understood that Shaughnessy was merely tired of the arrangement, and\r\nwould probably lease the new corner, when completed, alone. He began to\r\nworry about the necessity of a new connection and to see impending\r\nserious financial straits unless something turned up. This left him in\r\nno mood to enjoy his flat or Carrie, and consequently the depression\r\ninvaded that quarter.\r\n\r\nMeanwhile, he took such time as he could to look about, but\r\nopportunities were not numerous. More, he had not the same impressive\r\npersonality which he had when he first came to New York. Bad thoughts\r\nhad put a shade into his eyes which did not impress others favourably.\r\nNeither had he thirteen hundred dollars in hand to talk with. About a\r\nmonth later, finding that he had not made any progress, Shaughnessy\r\nreported definitely that Slawson would not extend the lease.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI guess this thing\xe2\x80\x99s got to come to an end,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, affecting an air\r\nof concern.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, if it has, it has,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Hurstwood, grimly. He would not\r\ngive the other a key to his opinions, whatever they were. He should not\r\nhave the satisfaction.\r\n\r\nA day or two later he saw that he must say something to Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cI think I\xe2\x80\x99m going to get the worst of my deal\r\ndown there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow is that?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Carrie in astonishment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, the man who owns the ground has sold it, and the new owner won\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nrelease it to us. The business may come to an end.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan\xe2\x80\x99t you start somewhere else?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere doesn\xe2\x80\x99t seem to be any place. Shaughnessy doesn\xe2\x80\x99t want to.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you lose what you put in?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood, whose face was a study.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, isn\xe2\x80\x99t that too bad?\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a trick,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood. \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s all. They\xe2\x80\x99ll start another\r\nplace there all right.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie looked at him, and gathered from his whole demeanour what it\r\nmeant. It was serious, very serious.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you think you can get something else?\xe2\x80\x9d she ventured, timidly.\r\n\r\nHurstwood thought a while. It was all up with the bluff about money and\r\ninvestment. She could see now that he was \xe2\x80\x9cbroke.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d he said solemnly; \xe2\x80\x9cI can try.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XXXIV. THE GRIND OF THE MILLSTONES: A SAMPLE OF CHAFF\r\n\r\nCarrie pondered over this situation as consistently as Hurstwood, once\r\nshe got the facts adjusted in her mind. It took several days for her to\r\nfully realise that the approach of the dissolution of her husband\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nbusiness meant commonplace struggle and privation. Her mind went back\r\nto her early venture in Chicago, the Hansons and their flat, and her\r\nheart revolted. That was terrible! Everything about poverty was\r\nterrible. She wished she knew a way out. Her recent experiences with\r\nthe Vances had wholly unfitted her to view her own state with\r\ncomplacence. The glamour of the high life of the city had, in the few\r\nexperiences afforded her by the former, seized her completely. She had\r\nbeen taught how to dress and where to go without having ample means to\r\ndo either. Now, these things\xe2\x80\x94ever-present realities as they were\xe2\x80\x94filled\r\nher eyes and mind. The more circumscribed became her state, the more\r\nentrancing seemed this other. And now poverty threatened to seize her\r\nentirely and to remove this other world far upward like a heaven to\r\nwhich any Lazarus might extend, appealingly, his hands.\r\n\r\nSo, too, the ideal brought into her life by Ames remained. He had gone,\r\nbut here was his word that riches were not everything; that there was a\r\ngreat deal more in the world than she knew; that the stage was good,\r\nand the literature she read poor. He was a strong man and clean\xe2\x80\x94how\r\nmuch stronger and better than Hurstwood and Drouet she only half\r\nformulated to herself, but the difference was painful. It was something\r\nto which she voluntarily closed her eyes.\r\n\r\nDuring the last three months of the Warren Street connection, Hurstwood\r\ntook parts of days off and hunted, tracking the business\r\nadvertisements. It was a more or less depressing business, wholly\r\nbecause of the thought that he must soon get something or he would\r\nbegin to live on the few hundred dollars he was saving, and then he\r\nwould have nothing to invest\xe2\x80\x94he would have to hire out as a clerk.\r\n\r\nEverything he discovered in his line advertised as an opportunity, was\r\neither too expensive or too wretched for him. Besides, winter was\r\ncoming, the papers were announcing hardships, and there was a general\r\nfeeling of hard times in the air, or, at least, he thought so. In his\r\nworry, other people\xe2\x80\x99s worries became apparent. No item about a firm\r\nfailing, a family starving, or a man dying upon the streets, supposedly\r\nof starvation, but arrested his eye as he scanned the morning papers.\r\nOnce the \xe2\x80\x9cWorld\xe2\x80\x9d came out with a flaring announcement about \xe2\x80\x9c80,000\r\npeople out of employment in New York this winter,\xe2\x80\x9d which struck as a\r\nknife at his heart.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEighty thousand!\xe2\x80\x9d he thought. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat an awful thing that is.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis was new reasoning for Hurstwood. In the old days the world had\r\nseemed to be getting along well enough. He had been wont to see similar\r\nthings in the \xe2\x80\x9cDaily News,\xe2\x80\x9d in Chicago, but they did not hold his\r\nattention. Now, these things were like grey clouds hovering along the\r\nhorizon of a clear day. They threatened to cover and obscure his life\r\nwith chilly greyness. He tried to shake them off, to forget and brace\r\nup. Sometimes he said to himself, mentally:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the use worrying? I\xe2\x80\x99m not out yet. I\xe2\x80\x99ve got six weeks more.\r\nEven if worst comes to worst, I\xe2\x80\x99ve got enough to live on for six\r\nmonths.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCuriously, as he troubled over his future, his thoughts occasionally\r\nreverted to his wife and family. He had avoided such thoughts for the\r\nfirst three years as much as possible. He hated her, and he could get\r\nalong without her. Let her go. He would do well enough. Now, however,\r\nwhen he was not doing well enough, he began to wonder what she was\r\ndoing, how his children were getting along. He could see them living as\r\nnicely as ever, occupying the comfortable house and using his property.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy George! it\xe2\x80\x99s a shame they should have it all,\xe2\x80\x9d he vaguely thought\r\nto himself on several occasions. \xe2\x80\x9cI didn\xe2\x80\x99t do anything.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs he looked back now and analysed the situation which led up to his\r\ntaking the money, he began mildly to justify himself. What had he\r\ndone\xe2\x80\x94what in the world\xe2\x80\x94that should bar him out this way and heap such\r\ndifficulties upon him? It seemed only yesterday to him since he was\r\ncomfortable and well-to-do. But now it was all wrested from him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe didn\xe2\x80\x99t deserve what she got out of me, that is sure. I didn\xe2\x80\x99t do\r\nso much, if everybody could just know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was no thought that the facts ought to be advertised. It was only\r\na mental justification he was seeking from himself\xe2\x80\x94something that would\r\nenable him to bear his state as a righteous man.\r\n\r\nOne afternoon, five weeks before the Warren Street place closed up, he\r\nleft the saloon to visit three or four places he saw advertised in the\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHerald.\xe2\x80\x9d One was down in Gold Street, and he visited that, but did not\r\nenter. It was such a cheap looking place he felt that he could not\r\nabide it. Another was on the Bowery, which he knew contained many showy\r\nresorts. It was near Grand Street, and turned out to be very handsomely\r\nfitted up. He talked around about investments for fully three-quarters\r\nof an hour with the proprietor, who maintained that his health was\r\npoor, and that was the reason he wished a partner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, now, just how much money would it take to buy a half interest\r\nhere?\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood, who saw seven hundred dollars as his limit.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThree thousand,\xe2\x80\x9d said the man.\r\n\r\nHurstwood\xe2\x80\x99s jaw fell.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCash?\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCash.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe tried to put on an air of deliberation, as one who might really buy;\r\nbut his eyes showed gloom. He wound up by saying he would think it\r\nover, and came away. The man he had been talking to sensed his\r\ncondition in a vague way.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t think he wants to buy,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to himself. \xe2\x80\x9cHe doesn\xe2\x80\x99t talk\r\nright.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe afternoon was as grey as lead and cold. It was blowing up a\r\ndisagreeable winter wind. He visited a place far up on the east side,\r\nnear Sixty-ninth Street, and it was five o\xe2\x80\x99clock, and growing dim, when\r\nhe reached there. A portly German kept this place.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow about this ad of yours?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Hurstwood, who rather objected to\r\nthe looks of the place.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, dat iss all over,\xe2\x80\x9d said the German. \xe2\x80\x9cI vill not sell now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, is that so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; dere is nothing to dat. It iss all over.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood, turning around.\r\n\r\nThe German paid no more attention to him, and it made him angry.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe crazy ass!\xe2\x80\x9d he said to himself. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat does he want to advertise\r\nfor?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWholly depressed, he started for Thirteenth Street. The flat had only a\r\nlight in the kitchen, where Carrie was working. He struck a match and,\r\nlighting the gas, sat down in the dining-room without even greeting\r\nher. She came to the door and looked in.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s you, is it?\xe2\x80\x9d she said, and went back.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, without even looking up from the evening paper he had\r\nbought.\r\n\r\nCarrie saw things were wrong with him. He was not so handsome when\r\ngloomy. The lines at the sides of the eyes were deepened. Naturally\r\ndark of skin, gloom made him look slightly sinister. He was quite a\r\ndisagreeable figure.\r\n\r\nCarrie set the table and brought in the meal.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDinner\xe2\x80\x99s ready,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, passing him for something.\r\n\r\nHe did not answer, reading on.\r\n\r\nShe came in and sat down at her place, feeling exceedingly wretched.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWon\xe2\x80\x99t you eat now?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked.\r\n\r\nHe folded his paper and drew near, silence holding for a time, except\r\nfor the \xe2\x80\x9cPass me\xe2\x80\x99s.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s been gloomy to-day, hasn\xe2\x80\x99t it?\xe2\x80\x9d ventured Carrie, after a time.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\nHe only picked at his food.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you still sure to close up?\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, venturing to take up the\r\nsubject which they had discussed often enough.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course we are,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, with the slightest modification of\r\nsharpness.\r\n\r\nThis retort angered Carrie. She had had a dreary day of it herself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou needn\xe2\x80\x99t talk like that,\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh!\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed, pushing back from the table, as if to say more, but\r\nletting it go at that. Then he picked up his paper. Carrie left her\r\nseat, containing herself with difficulty. He saw she was hurt.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t go \xe2\x80\x99way,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, as she started back into the kitchen. \xe2\x80\x9cEat\r\nyour dinner.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe passed, not answering.\r\n\r\nHe looked at the paper a few moments, and then rose up and put on his\r\ncoat.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m going downtown, Carrie,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, coming out. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m out of sorts\r\nto-night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe did not answer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t be angry,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cIt will be all right to-morrow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe looked at her, but she paid no attention to him, working at her\r\ndishes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood-bye!\xe2\x80\x9d he said finally, and went out.\r\n\r\nThis was the first strong result of the situation between them, but\r\nwith the nearing of the last day of the business the gloom became\r\nalmost a permanent thing. Hurstwood could not conceal his feelings\r\nabout the matter. Carrie could not help wondering where she was\r\ndrifting. It got so that they talked even less than usual, and yet it\r\nwas not Hurstwood who felt any objection to Carrie. It was Carrie who\r\nshied away from him. This he noticed. It aroused an objection to her\r\nbecoming indifferent to him. He made the possibility of friendly\r\nintercourse almost a giant task, and then noticed with discontent that\r\nCarrie added to it by her manner and made it more impossible.\r\n\r\nAt last the final day came. When it actually arrived, Hurstwood, who\r\nhad got his mind into such a state where a thunderclap and raging storm\r\nwould have seemed highly appropriate, was rather relieved to find that\r\nit was a plain, ordinary day. The sun shone, the temperature was\r\npleasant. He felt, as he came to the breakfast table, that it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t so\r\nterrible, after all.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to Carrie, \xe2\x80\x9cto-day\xe2\x80\x99s my last day on earth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie smiled in answer to his humour.\r\n\r\nHurstwood glanced over his paper rather gayly. He seemed to have lost a\r\nload.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll go down for a little while,\xe2\x80\x9d he said after breakfast, \xe2\x80\x9cand then\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ll look around. To-morrow I\xe2\x80\x99ll spend the whole day looking about. I\r\nthink I can get something, now this thing\xe2\x80\x99s off my hands.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe went out smiling and visited the place. Shaughnessy was there. They\r\nhad made all arrangements to share according to their interests. When,\r\nhowever, he had been there several hours, gone out three more, and\r\nreturned, his elation had departed. As much as he had objected to the\r\nplace, now that it was no longer to exist, he felt sorry. He wished\r\nthat things were different.\r\n\r\nShaughnessy was coolly businesslike.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d he said at five o\xe2\x80\x99clock, \xe2\x80\x9cwe might as well count the change and\r\ndivide.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey did so. The fixtures had already been sold and the sum divided.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood-night,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood at the final moment, in a last effort to\r\nbe genial.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo long,\xe2\x80\x9d said Shaughnessy, scarcely deigning a notice.\r\n\r\nThus the Warren Street arrangement was permanently concluded.\r\n\r\nCarrie had prepared a good dinner at the flat, but after his ride up,\r\nHurstwood was in a solemn and reflective mood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, inquisitively.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m out of that,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered, taking off his coat.\r\n\r\nAs she looked at him, she wondered what his financial state was now.\r\nThey ate and talked a little.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill you have enough to buy in anywhere else?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll have to get something else and save up.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt would be nice if you could get some place,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, prompted\r\nby anxiety and hope.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI guess I will,\xe2\x80\x9d he said reflectively.\r\n\r\nFor some days thereafter he put on his overcoat regularly in the\r\nmorning and sallied forth. On these ventures he first consoled himself\r\nwith the thought that with the seven hundred dollars he had he could\r\nstill make some advantageous arrangement. He thought about going to\r\nsome brewery, which, as he knew, frequently controlled saloons which\r\nthey leased, and get them to help him. Then he remembered that he would\r\nhave to pay out several hundred any way for fixtures and that he would\r\nhave nothing left for his monthly expenses. It was costing him nearly\r\neighty dollars a month to live.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, in his sanest moments, \xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t do it. I\xe2\x80\x99ll get\r\nsomething else and save up.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis getting-something proposition complicated itself the moment he\r\nbegan to think of what it was he wanted to do. Manage a place? Where\r\nshould he get such a position? The papers contained no requests for\r\nmanagers. Such positions, he knew well enough, were either secured by\r\nlong years of service or were bought with a half or third interest.\r\nInto a place important enough to need such a manager he had not money\r\nenough to buy.\r\n\r\nNevertheless, he started out. His clothes were very good and his\r\nappearance still excellent, but it involved the trouble of deluding.\r\nPeople, looking at him, imagined instantly that a man of his age, stout\r\nand well dressed, must be well off. He appeared a comfortable owner of\r\nsomething, a man from whom the common run of mortals could well expect\r\ngratuities. Being now forty-three years of age, and comfortably built,\r\nwalking was not easy. He had not been used to exercise for many years.\r\nHis legs tired, his shoulders ached, and his feet pained him at the\r\nclose of the day, even when he took street cars in almost every\r\ndirection. The mere getting up and down, if long continued, produced\r\nthis result.\r\n\r\nThe fact that people took him to be better off than he was, he well\r\nunderstood. It was so painfully clear to him that it retarded his\r\nsearch. Not that he wished to be less well-appearing, but that he was\r\nashamed to belie his appearance by incongruous appeals. So he\r\nhesitated, wondering what to do.\r\n\r\nHe thought of the hotels, but instantly he remembered that he had had\r\nno experience as a clerk, and, what was more important, no\r\nacquaintances or friends in that line to whom he could go. He did know\r\nsome hotel owners in several cities, including New York, but they knew\r\nof his dealings with Fitzgerald and Moy. He could not apply to them. He\r\nthought of other lines suggested by large buildings or businesses which\r\nhe knew of\xe2\x80\x94wholesale groceries, hardware, insurance concerns, and the\r\nlike\xe2\x80\x94but he had had no experience.\r\n\r\nHow to go about getting anything was a bitter thought. Would he have to\r\ngo personally and ask; wait outside an office door, and, then,\r\ndistinguished and affluent looking, announce that he was looking for\r\nsomething to do? He strained painfully at the thought. No, he could not\r\ndo that.\r\n\r\nHe really strolled about, thinking, and then, the weather being cold,\r\nstepped into a hotel. He knew hotels well enough to know that any\r\ndecent individual was welcome to a chair in the lobby. This was in the\r\nBroadway Central, which was then one of the most important hotels in\r\nthe city. Taking a chair here was a painful thing to him. To think he\r\nshould come to this! He had heard loungers about hotels called\r\nchairwarmers. He had called them that himself in his day. But here he\r\nwas, despite the possibility of meeting some one who knew him,\r\nshielding himself from cold and the weariness of the streets in a hotel\r\nlobby.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t do this way,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to himself. \xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s no use of my\r\nstarting out mornings without first thinking up some place to go. I\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nthink of some places and then look them up.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt occurred to him that the positions of bartenders were sometimes\r\nopen, but he put this out of his mind. Bartender\xe2\x80\x94he, the ex-manager!\r\n\r\nIt grew awfully dull sitting in the hotel lobby, and so at four he went\r\nhome. He tried to put on a business air as he went in, but it was a\r\nfeeble imitation. The rocking chair in the dining-room was comfortable.\r\nHe sank into it gladly, with several papers he had bought, and began to\r\nread.\r\n\r\nAs she was going through the room to begin preparing dinner, Carrie\r\nsaid:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe man was here for the rent to-day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, was he?\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood.\r\n\r\nThe least wrinkle crept into his brow as he remembered that this was\r\nFebruary 2d, the time the man always called. He fished down in his\r\npocket for his purse, getting the first taste of paying out when\r\nnothing is coming in. He looked at the fat, green roll as a sick man\r\nlooks at the one possible saving cure. Then he counted off twenty-eight\r\ndollars.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere you are,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to Carrie, when she came through again.\r\n\r\nHe buried himself in his papers and read. Oh, the rest of it\xe2\x80\x94the relief\r\nfrom walking and thinking! What Lethean waters were these floods of\r\ntelegraphed intelligence! He forgot his troubles, in part. Here was a\r\nyoung, handsome woman, if you might believe the newspaper drawing,\r\nsuing a rich, fat, candy-making husband in Brooklyn for divorce. Here\r\nwas another item detailing the wrecking of a vessel in ice and snow off\r\nPrince\xe2\x80\x99s Bay on Staten Island. A long, bright column told of the doings\r\nin the theatrical world\xe2\x80\x94the plays produced, the actors appearing, the\r\nmanagers making announcements. Fannie Davenport was just opening at the\r\nFifth Avenue. Daly was producing \xe2\x80\x9cKing Lear.\xe2\x80\x9d He read of the early\r\ndeparture for the season of a party composed of the Vanderbilts and\r\ntheir friends for Florida. An interesting shooting affray was on in the\r\nmountains of Kentucky. So he read, read, read, rocking in the warm room\r\nnear the radiator and waiting for dinner to be served.\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XXXV. THE PASSING OF EFFORT: THE VISAGE OF CARE\r\n\r\nThe next morning he looked over the papers and waded through a long\r\nlist of advertisements, making a few notes. Then he turned to the\r\nmale-help-wanted column, but with disagreeable feelings. The day was\r\nbefore him\xe2\x80\x94a long day in which to discover something\xe2\x80\x94and this was how\r\nhe must begin to discover. He scanned the long column, which mostly\r\nconcerned bakers, bushelmen, cooks, compositors, drivers, and the like,\r\nfinding two things only which arrested his eye. One was a cashier\r\nwanted in a wholesale furniture house, and the other a salesman for a\r\nwhiskey house. He had never thought of the latter. At once he decided\r\nto look that up.\r\n\r\nThe firm in question was Alsbery & Co., whiskey brokers.\r\n\r\nHe was admitted almost at once to the manager on his appearance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood-morning, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said the latter, thinking at first that he was\r\nencountering one of his out-of-town customers.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood-morning,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood. \xe2\x80\x9cYou advertised, I believe, for a\r\nsalesman?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh,\xe2\x80\x9d said the man, showing plainly the enlightenment which had come to\r\nhim. \xe2\x80\x9cYes. Yes, I did.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thought I\xe2\x80\x99d drop in,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood, with dignity. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve had some\r\nexperience in that line myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, have you?\xe2\x80\x9d said the man. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat experience have you had?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I\xe2\x80\x99ve managed several liquor houses in my time. Recently I owned\r\na third-interest in a saloon at Warren and Hudson streets.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI see,\xe2\x80\x9d said the man.\r\n\r\nHurstwood ceased, waiting for some suggestion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe did want a salesman,\xe2\x80\x9d said the man. \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know as it\xe2\x80\x99s anything\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x99d care to take hold of, though.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI see,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, I\xe2\x80\x99m in no position to choose, just at\r\npresent. If it were open, I should be glad to get it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe man did not take kindly at all to his \xe2\x80\x9cNo position to choose.\xe2\x80\x9d He\r\nwanted some one who wasn\xe2\x80\x99t thinking of a choice or something better.\r\nEspecially not an old man. He wanted some one young, active, and glad\r\nto work actively for a moderate sum. Hurstwood did not please him at\r\nall. He had more of an air than his employers.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d he said in answer, \xe2\x80\x9cwe\xe2\x80\x99d be glad to consider your application.\r\nWe shan\xe2\x80\x99t decide for a few days yet. Suppose you send us your\r\nreferences.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood.\r\n\r\nHe nodded good-morning and came away. At the corner he looked at the\r\nfurniture company\xe2\x80\x99s address, and saw that it was in West Twenty-third\r\nStreet. Accordingly, he went up there. The place was not large enough,\r\nhowever. It looked moderate, the men in it idle and small salaried. He\r\nwalked by, glancing in, and then decided not to go in there.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey want a girl, probably, at ten a week,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\nAt one o\xe2\x80\x99clock he thought of eating, and went to a restaurant in\r\nMadison Square. There he pondered over places which he might look up.\r\nHe was tired. It was blowing up grey again. Across the way, through\r\nMadison Square Park, stood the great hotels, looking down upon a busy\r\nscene. He decided to go over to the lobby of one and sit a while. It\r\nwas warm in there and bright. He had seen no one he knew at the\r\nBroadway Central. In all likelihood he would encounter no one here.\r\nFinding a seat on one of the red plush divans close to the great\r\nwindows which look out on Broadway\xe2\x80\x99s busy rout, he sat musing. His\r\nstate did not seem so bad in here. Sitting still and looking out, he\r\ncould take some slight consolation in the few hundred dollars he had in\r\nhis purse. He could forget, in a measure, the weariness of the street\r\nand his tiresome searches. Still, it was only escape from a severe to a\r\nless severe state. He was still gloomy and disheartened. There, minutes\r\nseemed to go very slowly. An hour was a long, long time in passing. It\r\nwas filled for him with observations and mental comments concerning the\r\nactual guests of the hotel, who passed in and out, and those more\r\nprosperous pedestrians whose good fortune showed in their clothes and\r\nspirits as they passed along Broadway, outside. It was nearly the first\r\ntime since he had arrived in the city that his leisure afforded him\r\nample opportunity to contemplate this spectacle. Now, being, perforce,\r\nidle himself, he wondered at the activity of others. How gay were the\r\nyouths he saw, how pretty the women. Such fine clothes they all wore.\r\nThey were so intent upon getting somewhere. He saw coquettish glances\r\ncast by magnificent girls. Ah, the money it required to train with\r\nsuch\xe2\x80\x94how well he knew! How long it had been since he had had the\r\nopportunity to do so!\r\n\r\nThe clock outside registered four. It was a little early, but he\r\nthought he would go back to the flat.\r\n\r\nThis going back to the flat was coupled with the thought that Carrie\r\nwould think he was sitting around too much if he came home early. He\r\nhoped he wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have to, but the day hung heavily on his hands. Over\r\nthere he was on his own ground. He could sit in his rocking-chair and\r\nread. This busy, distracting, suggestive scene was shut out. He could\r\nread his papers. Accordingly, he went home. Carrie was reading, quite\r\nalone. It was rather dark in the flat, shut in as it was.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ll hurt your eyes,\xe2\x80\x9d he said when he saw her.\r\n\r\nAfter taking off his coat, he felt it incumbent upon him to make some\r\nlittle report of his day.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve been talking with a wholesale liquor company,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cI may go\r\non the road.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWouldn\xe2\x80\x99t that be nice!\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be such a bad thing,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered.\r\n\r\nAlways from the man at the corner now he bought two papers\xe2\x80\x94the \xe2\x80\x9cEvening\r\nWorld\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cEvening Sun.\xe2\x80\x9d So now he merely picked his papers up, as he\r\ncame by, without stopping.\r\n\r\nHe drew up his chair near the radiator and lighted the gas. Then it was\r\nas the evening before. His difficulties vanished in the items he so\r\nwell loved to read.\r\n\r\nThe next day was even worse than the one before, because now he could\r\nnot think of where to go. Nothing he saw in the papers he studied\xe2\x80\x94till\r\nten o\xe2\x80\x99clock\xe2\x80\x94appealed to him. He felt that he ought to go out, and yet\r\nhe sickened at the thought. Where to, where to?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou mustn\xe2\x80\x99t forget to leave me my money for this week,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie,\r\nquietly.\r\n\r\nThey had an arrangement by which he placed twelve dollars a week in her\r\nhands, out of which to pay current expenses. He heaved a little sigh as\r\nshe said this, and drew out his purse. Again he felt the dread of the\r\nthing. Here he was taking off, taking off, and nothing coming in.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLord!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, in his own thoughts, \xe2\x80\x9cthis can\xe2\x80\x99t go on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTo Carrie he said nothing whatsoever. She could feel that her request\r\ndisturbed him. To pay her would soon become a distressing thing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYet, what have I got to do with it?\xe2\x80\x9d she thought. \xe2\x80\x9cOh, why should I be\r\nmade to worry?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHurstwood went out and made for Broadway. He wanted to think up some\r\nplace. Before long, though, he reached the Grand Hotel at Thirty-first\r\nStreet. He knew of its comfortable lobby. He was cold after his twenty\r\nblocks\xe2\x80\x99 walk.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll go in their barber shop and get a shave,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought.\r\n\r\nThus he justified himself in sitting down in here after his tonsorial\r\ntreatment.\r\n\r\nAgain, time hanging heavily on his hands, he went home early, and this\r\ncontinued for several days, each day the need to hunt paining him, and\r\neach day disgust, depression, shamefacedness driving him into lobby\r\nidleness.\r\n\r\nAt last three days came in which a storm prevailed, and he did not go\r\nout at all. The snow began to fall late one afternoon. It was a regular\r\nflurry of large, soft, white flakes. In the morning it was still coming\r\ndown with a high wind, and the papers announced a blizzard. From out\r\nthe front windows one could see a deep, soft bedding.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI guess I\xe2\x80\x99ll not try to go out to-day,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to Carrie at\r\nbreakfast. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s going to be awful bad, so the papers say.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe man hasn\xe2\x80\x99t brought my coal, either,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, who ordered by\r\nthe bushel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll go over and see about it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood. This was the first\r\ntime he had ever suggested doing an errand, but, somehow, the wish to\r\nsit about the house prompted it as a sort of compensation for the\r\nprivilege.\r\n\r\nAll day and all night it snowed, and the city began to suffer from a\r\ngeneral blockade of traffic. Great attention was given to the details\r\nof the storm by the newspapers, which played up the distress of the\r\npoor in large type.\r\n\r\nHurstwood sat and read by his radiator in the corner. He did not try to\r\nthink about his need of work. This storm being so terrific, and tying\r\nup all things, robbed him of the need. He made himself wholly\r\ncomfortable and toasted his feet.\r\n\r\nCarrie observed his ease with some misgiving. For all the fury of the\r\nstorm she doubted his comfort. He took his situation too\r\nphilosophically.\r\n\r\nHurstwood, however, read on and on. He did not pay much attention to\r\nCarrie. She fulfilled her household duties and said little to disturb\r\nhim.\r\n\r\nThe next day it was still snowing, and the next, bitter cold. Hurstwood\r\ntook the alarm of the paper and sat still. Now he volunteered to do a\r\nfew other little things. One was to go to the butcher, another to the\r\ngrocery. He really thought nothing of these little services in\r\nconnection with their true significance. He felt as if he were not\r\nwholly useless\xe2\x80\x94indeed, in such a stress of weather, quite worth while\r\nabout the house.\r\n\r\nOn the fourth day, however, it cleared, and he read that the storm was\r\nover. Now, however, he idled, thinking how sloppy the streets would be.\r\n\r\nIt was noon before he finally abandoned his papers and got under way.\r\nOwing to the slightly warmer temperature the streets were bad. He went\r\nacross Fourteenth Street on the car and got a transfer south on\r\nBroadway. One little advertisement he had, relating to a saloon down in\r\nPearl Street. When he reached the Broadway Central, however, he changed\r\nhis mind.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the use?\xe2\x80\x9d he thought, looking out upon the slop and snow. \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\ncouldn\xe2\x80\x99t buy into it. It\xe2\x80\x99s a thousand to one nothing comes of it. I\r\nguess I\xe2\x80\x99ll get off,\xe2\x80\x9d and off he got. In the lobby he took a seat and\r\nwaited again, wondering what he could do.\r\n\r\nWhile he was idly pondering, satisfied to be inside, a well-dressed man\r\npassed up the lobby, stopped, looked sharply, as if not sure of his\r\nmemory, and then approached. Hurstwood recognised Cargill, the owner of\r\nthe large stables in Chicago of the same name, whom he had last seen at\r\nAvery Hall, the night Carrie appeared there. The remembrance of how\r\nthis individual brought up his wife to shake hands on that occasion was\r\nalso on the instant clear.\r\n\r\nHurstwood was greatly abashed. His eyes expressed the difficulty he\r\nfelt.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, it\xe2\x80\x99s Hurstwood!\xe2\x80\x9d said Cargill, remembering now, and sorry that he\r\nhad not recognised him quickly enough in the beginning to have avoided\r\nthis meeting.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood. \xe2\x80\x9cHow are you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cargill, troubled for something to talk about.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStopping here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood, \xe2\x80\x9cjust keeping an appointment.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI knew you had left Chicago. I was wondering what had become of you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I\xe2\x80\x99m here now,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Hurstwood, anxious to get away.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoing well, I suppose?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExcellent.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGlad to hear it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey looked at one another, rather embarrassed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I have an engagement with a friend upstairs. I\xe2\x80\x99ll leave you. So\r\nlong.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHurstwood nodded his head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDamn it all,\xe2\x80\x9d he murmured, turning toward the door. \xe2\x80\x9cI knew that would\r\nhappen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe walked several blocks up the street. His watch only registered 1.30.\r\nHe tried to think of some place to go or something to do. The day was\r\nso bad he wanted only to be inside. Finally his feet began to feel wet\r\nand cold, and he boarded a car. This took him to Fifty-ninth Street,\r\nwhich was as good as anywhere else. Landed here, he turned to walk back\r\nalong Seventh Avenue, but the slush was too much. The misery of\r\nlounging about with nowhere to go became intolerable. He felt as if he\r\nwere catching cold.\r\n\r\nStopping at a corner, he waited for a car south bound. This was no day\r\nto be out; he would go home.\r\n\r\nCarrie was surprised to see him at a quarter of three.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a miserable day out,\xe2\x80\x9d was all he said. Then he took off his coat\r\nand changed his shoes.\r\n\r\nThat night he felt a cold coming on and took quinine. He was feverish\r\nuntil morning, and sat about the next day while Carrie waited on him.\r\nHe was a helpless creature in sickness, not very handsome in a\r\ndull-coloured bath gown and his hair uncombed. He looked haggard about\r\nthe eyes and quite old. Carrie noticed this, and it did not appeal to\r\nher. She wanted to be good-natured and sympathetic, but something about\r\nthe man held her aloof.\r\n\r\nToward evening he looked so badly in the weak light that she suggested\r\nhe go to bed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99d better sleep alone,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cyou\xe2\x80\x99ll feel better. I\xe2\x80\x99ll open\r\nyour bed for you now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\nAs she did all these things, she was in a most despondent state.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a life! What a life!\xe2\x80\x9d was her one thought.\r\n\r\nOnce during the day, when he sat near the radiator, hunched up and\r\nreading, she passed through, and seeing him, wrinkled her brows. In the\r\nfront room, where it was not so warm, she sat by the window and cried.\r\nThis was the life cut out for her, was it? To live cooped up in a small\r\nflat with some one who was out of work, idle, and indifferent to her.\r\nShe was merely a servant to him now, nothing more.\r\n\r\nThis crying made her eyes red, and when, in preparing his bed, she\r\nlighted the gas, and, having prepared it, called him in, he noticed the\r\nfact.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the matter with you?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, looking into her face. His\r\nvoice was hoarse and his unkempt head only added to its grewsome\r\nquality.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, weakly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ve been crying,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI haven\xe2\x80\x99t, either,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered.\r\n\r\nIt was not for love of him, that he knew.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou needn\xe2\x80\x99t cry,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, getting into bed. \xe2\x80\x9cThings will come out all\r\nright.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn a day or two he was up again, but rough weather holding, he stayed\r\nin. The Italian newsdealer now delivered the morning papers, and these\r\nhe read assiduously. A few times after that he ventured out, but\r\nmeeting another of his old-time friends, he began to feel uneasy\r\nsitting about hotel corridors.\r\n\r\nEvery day he came home early, and at last made no pretence of going\r\nanywhere. Winter was no time to look for anything.\r\n\r\nNaturally, being about the house, he noticed the way Carrie did things.\r\nShe was far from perfect in household methods and economy, and her\r\nlittle deviations on this score first caught his eye. Not, however,\r\nbefore her regular demand for her allowance became a grievous thing.\r\nSitting around as he did, the weeks seemed to pass very quickly. Every\r\nTuesday Carrie asked for her money.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you think we live as cheaply as we might?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked one Tuesday\r\nmorning.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do the best I can,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\nNothing was added to this at the moment, but the next day he said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you ever go to the Gansevoort Market over here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI didn\xe2\x80\x99t know there was such a market,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey say you can get things lots cheaper there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie was very indifferent to the suggestion.
