These were things which\r\nshe did not like at all.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow much do you pay for a pound of meat?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked one day.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, there are different prices,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie. \xe2\x80\x9cSirloin steak is\r\ntwenty-two cents.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s steep, isn\xe2\x80\x99t it?\xe2\x80\x9d he answered.\r\n\r\nSo he asked about other things, until finally, with the passing days,\r\nit seemed to become a mania with him. He learned the prices and\r\nremembered them. His errand-running capacity also improved. It began in\r\na small way, of course. Carrie, going to get her hat one morning, was\r\nstopped by him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere are you going, Carrie?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOver to the baker\xe2\x80\x99s,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d just as leave go for you,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\nShe acquiesced, and he went. Each afternoon he would go to the corner\r\nfor the papers.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs there anything you want?\xe2\x80\x9d he would say.\r\n\r\nBy degrees she began to use him. Doing this, however, she lost the\r\nweekly payment of twelve dollars.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou want to pay me to-day,\xe2\x80\x9d she said one Tuesday, about this time.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow much?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\nShe understood well enough what it meant.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, about five dollars,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered. \xe2\x80\x9cI owe the coal man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe same day he said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think this Italian up here on the corner sells coal at twenty-five\r\ncents a bushel. I\xe2\x80\x99ll trade with him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie heard this with indifference.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right,\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\r\n\r\nThen it came to be:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGeorge, I must have some coal to-day,\xe2\x80\x9d or, \xe2\x80\x9cYou must get some meat of\r\nsome kind for dinner.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe would find out what she needed and order.\r\n\r\nAccompanying this plan came skimpiness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI only got a half-pound of steak,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, coming in one afternoon\r\nwith his papers. \xe2\x80\x9cWe never seem to eat very much.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThese miserable details ate the heart out of Carrie. They blackened her\r\ndays and grieved her soul. Oh, how this man had changed! All day and\r\nall day, here he sat, reading his papers. The world seemed to have no\r\nattraction. Once in a while he would go out, in fine weather, it might\r\nbe four or five hours, between eleven and four. She could do nothing\r\nbut view him with gnawing contempt.\r\n\r\nIt was apathy with Hurstwood, resulting from his inability to see his\r\nway out. Each month drew from his small store. Now, he had only five\r\nhundred dollars left, and this he hugged, half feeling as if he could\r\nstave off absolute necessity for an indefinite period. Sitting around\r\nthe house, he decided to wear some old clothes he had. This came first\r\nwith the bad days. Only once he apologised in the very beginning:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s so bad to-day, I\xe2\x80\x99ll just wear these around.\xe2\x80\x9d Eventually these\r\nbecame the permanent thing.\r\n\r\nAlso, he had been wont to pay fifteen cents for a shave, and a tip of\r\nten cents. In his first distress, he cut down the tip to five, then to\r\nnothing. Later, he tried a ten-cent barber shop, and, finding that the\r\nshave was satisfactory, patronised regularly. Later still, he put off\r\nshaving to every other day, then to every third, and so on, until once\r\na week became the rule. On Saturday he was a sight to see.\r\n\r\nOf course, as his own self-respect vanished, it perished for him in\r\nCarrie. She could not understand what had gotten into the man. He had\r\nsome money, he had a decent suit remaining, he was not bad looking when\r\ndressed up. She did not forget her own difficult struggle in Chicago,\r\nbut she did not forget either that she had never ceased trying. He\r\nnever tried. He did not even consult the ads in the papers any more.\r\n\r\nFinally, a distinct impression escaped from her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat makes you put so much butter on the steak?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked her one\r\nevening, standing around in the kitchen.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo make it good, of course,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cButter is awful dear these days,\xe2\x80\x9d he suggested.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t mind it if you were working,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered.\r\n\r\nHe shut up after this, and went in to his paper, but the retort rankled\r\nin his mind. It was the first cutting remark that had come from her.\r\n\r\nThat same evening, Carrie, after reading, went off to the front room to\r\nbed. This was unusual. When Hurstwood decided to go, he retired, as\r\nusual, without a light. It was then that he discovered Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nabsence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s funny,\xe2\x80\x9d he said; \xe2\x80\x9cmaybe she\xe2\x80\x99s sitting up.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe gave the matter no more thought, but slept. In the morning she was\r\nnot beside him. Strange to say, this passed without comment.\r\n\r\nNight approaching, and a slightly more conversational feeling\r\nprevailing, Carrie said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think I\xe2\x80\x99ll sleep alone to-night. I have a headache.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood.\r\n\r\nThe third night she went to her front bed without apologies.\r\n\r\nThis was a grim blow to Hurstwood, but he never mentioned it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to himself, with an irrepressible frown, \xe2\x80\x9clet her\r\nsleep alone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XXXVI. A GRIM RETROGRESSION: THE PHANTOM OF CHANCE\r\n\r\nThe Vances, who had been back in the city ever since Christmas, had not\r\nforgotten Carrie; but they, or rather Mrs. Vance, had never called on\r\nher, for the very simple reason that Carrie had never sent her address.\r\nTrue to her nature, she corresponded with Mrs. Vance as long as she\r\nstill lived in Seventy-eighth Street, but when she was compelled to\r\nmove into Thirteenth, her fear that the latter would take it as an\r\nindication of reduced circumstances caused her to study some way of\r\navoiding the necessity of giving her address. Not finding any\r\nconvenient method, she sorrowfully resigned the privilege of writing to\r\nher friend entirely. The latter wondered at this strange silence,\r\nthought Carrie must have left the city, and in the end gave her up as\r\nlost. So she was thoroughly surprised to encounter her in Fourteenth\r\nStreet, where she had gone shopping. Carrie was there for the same\r\npurpose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, Mrs. Wheeler,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Vance, looking Carrie over in a glance,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cwhere have you been? Why haven\xe2\x80\x99t you been to see me? I\xe2\x80\x99ve been\r\nwondering all this time what had become of you. Really, I\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m so glad to see you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, pleased and yet nonplussed. Of\r\nall times, this was the worst to encounter Mrs. Vance. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy, I\xe2\x80\x99m living\r\ndown town here. I\xe2\x80\x99ve been intending to come and see you. Where are you\r\nliving now?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn Fifty-eighth Street,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Vance, \xe2\x80\x9cjust off Seventh\r\nAvenue\xe2\x80\x94218. Why don\xe2\x80\x99t you come and see me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie. \xe2\x80\x9cReally, I\xe2\x80\x99ve been wanting to come. I know I\r\nought to. It\xe2\x80\x99s a shame. But you know\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s your number?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Vance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThirteenth Street,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, reluctantly. \xe2\x80\x9c112 West.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Vance, \xe2\x80\x9cthat\xe2\x80\x99s right near here, isn\xe2\x80\x99t it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie. \xe2\x80\x9cYou must come down and see me some time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you\xe2\x80\x99re a fine one,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Vance, laughing, the while noting\r\nthat Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s appearance had modified somewhat. \xe2\x80\x9cThe address, too,\xe2\x80\x9d she\r\nadded to herself. \xe2\x80\x9cThey must be hard up.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nStill she liked Carrie well enough to take her in tow.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome with me in here a minute,\xe2\x80\x9d she exclaimed, turning into a store.\r\n\r\nWhen Carrie returned home, there was Hurstwood, reading as usual. He\r\nseemed to take his condition with the utmost nonchalance. His beard was\r\nat least four days old.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Carrie, \xe2\x80\x9cif she were to come here and see him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe shook her head in absolute misery. It looked as if her situation\r\nwas becoming unbearable.\r\n\r\nDriven to desperation, she asked at dinner:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you ever hear any more from that wholesale house?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cThey don\xe2\x80\x99t want an inexperienced man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie dropped the subject, feeling unable to say more.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI met Mrs. Vance this afternoon,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, after a time.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid, eh?\xe2\x80\x9d he answered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99re back in New York now,\xe2\x80\x9d Carrie went on. \xe2\x80\x9cShe did look so nice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, she can afford it as long as he puts up for it,\xe2\x80\x9d returned\r\nHurstwood. \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s got a soft job.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHurstwood was looking into the paper. You can\xe2\x80\x99t tell what\xe2\x80\x99ll happen.\r\nHe may get down like anybody else.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was something quite knavish in the man\xe2\x80\x99s attitude. His eye seemed\r\nto be cocked with a twinkle upon the fortunate, expecting their defeat.\r\nHis own state seemed a thing apart\xe2\x80\x94not considered.\r\n\r\nThis thing was the remains of his old-time cocksureness and\r\nindependence. Sitting in his flat, and reading of the doings of other\r\npeople, sometimes this independent, undefeated mood came upon him.\r\nForgetting the weariness of the streets and the degradation of search,\r\nhe would sometimes prick up his ears. It was as if he said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can do something. I\xe2\x80\x99m not down yet. There\xe2\x80\x99s a lot of things coming\r\nto me if I want to go after them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was in this mood that he would occasionally dress up, go for a\r\nshave, and, putting on his gloves, sally forth quite actively. He knew of several poker rooms\r\ndown town. A few acquaintances he had in downtown resorts and about the\r\nCity Hall. It was a change to see them and exchange a few friendly\r\ncommonplaces.\r\n\r\nHe had once been accustomed to hold a pretty fair hand at poker. Many a\r\nfriendly game had netted him a hundred dollars or more at the time when\r\nthat sum was merely sauce to the dish of the game\xe2\x80\x94not the all in all.\r\nNow, he thought of playing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI might win a couple of hundred. The poker room which he first invaded\r\nwas over a saloon in West Street, near one of the ferries. He had been\r\nthere before. Several games were going. These he watched for a time and\r\nnoticed that the pots were quite large for the ante involved.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDeal me a hand,\xe2\x80\x9d he said at the beginning of a new shuffle. He received a mixed collection\r\nwithout progression or pairs. The pot was opened.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI pass,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\nOn the strength of this, he was content to lose his ante. The deals did\r\nfairly by him in the long run, causing him to come away with a few\r\ndollars to the good.\r\n\r\nThe next afternoon he was back again, seeking amusement and profit.\r\nThis time he followed up three of a kind to his doom. Hurstwood was surprised at the persistence of this individual,\r\nwhose bets came with a _sang-froid_ which, if a bluff, was excellent\r\nart. Hurstwood began to doubt, but kept, or thought to keep, at least,\r\nthe cool demeanour with which, in olden times, he deceived those\r\npsychic students of the gaming table, who seem to read thoughts and\r\nmoods, rather than exterior evidences, however subtle. He could not\r\ndown the cowardly thought that this man had something better and would\r\nstay to the end, drawing his last dollar into the pot, should he choose\r\nto go so far. Still, he hoped to win much\xe2\x80\x94his hand was excellent. Why\r\nnot raise it five more?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI raise you three,\xe2\x80\x9d said the youth.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMake it five,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood, pushing out his chips.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome again,\xe2\x80\x9d said the youth, pushing out a small pile of reds.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet me have some more chips,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood to the keeper in charge,\r\ntaking out a bill.\r\n\r\nA cynical grin lit up the face of his youthful opponent. The other man\r\nreally became serious. Perhaps this individual (Hurstwood) really did\r\nhave a stiff hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI call,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\nHurstwood showed his hand. He was done. The bitter fact that he had\r\nlost seventy-five dollars made him desperate.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet\xe2\x80\x99s have another pot,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, grimly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right,\xe2\x80\x9d said the man.\r\n\r\nSome of the other players quit, but observant loungers took their\r\nplaces. Time passed, and it came to twelve o\xe2\x80\x99clock. Hurstwood held on,\r\nneither winning nor losing much. Then he grew weary, and on a last hand\r\nlost twenty more. He was sick at heart.\r\n\r\nAt a quarter after one in the morning he came out of the place. The\r\nchill, bare streets seemed a mockery of his state. He walked slowly\r\nwest, little thinking of his row with Carrie. He ascended the stairs\r\nand went into his room as if there had been no trouble. It was his loss\r\nthat occupied his mind. Sitting down on the bedside he counted his\r\nmoney. There was now but a hundred and ninety dollars and some change.\r\nHe put it up and began to undress.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wonder what\xe2\x80\x99s getting into me, anyhow?\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\nIn the morning Carrie scarcely spoke and he felt as if he must go out\r\nagain. He had treated her badly, but he could not afford to make up.\r\nNow desperation seized him, and for a day or two, going out thus, he\r\nlived like a gentleman\xe2\x80\x94or what he conceived to be a gentleman\xe2\x80\x94which\r\ntook money. For his escapades he was soon poorer in mind and body, to\r\nsay nothing of his purse, which had lost thirty by the process. Then he\r\ncame down to cold, bitter sense again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe rent man comes to-day,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, greeting him thus\r\nindifferently three mornings later.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe does?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; this is the second,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Carrie.\r\n\r\nHurstwood frowned. Then in despair he got out his purse.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt seems an awful lot to pay for rent,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\nHe was nearing his last hundred dollars.\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XXXVII. THE SPIRIT AWAKENS: NEW SEARCH FOR THE GATE\r\n\r\nIt would be useless to explain how in due time the last fifty dollars\r\nwas in sight. The seven hundred, by his process of handling, had only\r\ncarried them into June. Before the final hundred mark was reached he\r\nbegan to indicate that a calamity was approaching.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d he said one day, taking a trivial expenditure for meat\r\nas a text, \xe2\x80\x9cit seems to take an awful lot for us to live.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt doesn\xe2\x80\x99t seem to me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, \xe2\x80\x9cthat we spend very much.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy money is nearly gone,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cand I hardly know where it\xe2\x80\x99s gone\r\nto.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll that seven hundred dollars?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll but a hundred.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe looked so disconsolate that it scared her. She began to see that she\r\nherself had been drifting. She had felt it all the time.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, George,\xe2\x80\x9d she exclaimed, \xe2\x80\x9cwhy don\xe2\x80\x99t you get out and look for\r\nsomething? You could find something.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have looked,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cYou can\xe2\x80\x99t make people give you a place.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe gazed weakly at him and said: \xe2\x80\x9cWell, what do you think you will do?\r\nA hundred dollars won\xe2\x80\x99t last long.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t do any more than look.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie became frightened over this announcement. She thought\r\ndesperately upon the subject. Frequently she had considered the stage\r\nas a door through which she might enter that gilded state which she had\r\nso much craved. Now, as in Chicago, it came as a last resource in\r\ndistress. Something must be done if he did not get work soon. Perhaps\r\nshe would have to go out and battle again alone.\r\n\r\nShe began to wonder how one would go about getting a place. Her\r\nexperience in Chicago proved that she had not tried the right way.\r\nThere must be people who would listen to and try you\xe2\x80\x94men who would give\r\nyou an opportunity.\r\n\r\nThey were talking at the breakfast table, a morning or two later, when\r\nshe brought up the dramatic subject by saying that she saw that Sarah\r\nBernhardt was coming to this country. Hurstwood had seen it, too.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow do people get on the stage, George?\xe2\x80\x9d she finally asked,\r\ninnocently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cThere must be dramatic agents.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie was sipping coffee, and did not look up.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRegular people who get you a place?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I think so,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered.\r\n\r\nSuddenly the air with which she asked attracted his attention.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re not still thinking about being an actress, are you?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered, \xe2\x80\x9cI was just wondering.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWithout being clear, there was something in the thought which he\r\nobjected to. He did not believe any more, after three years of\r\nobservation, that Carrie would ever do anything great in that line. She\r\nseemed too simple, too yielding. His idea of the art was that it\r\ninvolved something more pompous. If she tried to get on the stage she\r\nwould fall into the hands of some cheap manager and become like the\r\nrest of them. He had a good idea of what he meant by _them_. Carrie was\r\npretty. She would get along all right, but where would he be?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d get that idea out of my head, if I were you. It\xe2\x80\x99s a lot more\r\ndifficult than you think.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie felt this to contain, in some way, an aspersion upon her\r\nability.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou said I did real well in Chicago,\xe2\x80\x9d she rejoined.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou did,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered, seeing that he was arousing opposition, \xe2\x80\x9cbut\r\nChicago isn\xe2\x80\x99t New York, by a big jump.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie did not answer this at all. It hurt her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe stage,\xe2\x80\x9d he went on, \xe2\x80\x9cis all right if you can be one of the big\r\nguns, but there\xe2\x80\x99s nothing to the rest of it. It takes a long while to\r\nget up.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, slightly aroused.\r\n\r\nIn a flash, he thought he foresaw the result of this thing. Now, when\r\nthe worst of his situation was approaching, she would get on the stage\r\nin some cheap way and forsake him. Strangely, he had not conceived well\r\nof her mental ability. That was because he did not understand the\r\nnature of emotional greatness. He had never learned that a person might\r\nbe emotionally\xe2\x80\x94instead of intellectually\xe2\x80\x94great. Avery Hall was too far\r\naway for him to look back and sharply remember. He had lived with this\r\nwoman too long.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I do,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered. \xe2\x80\x9cIf I were you I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t think of it. It\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nnot much of a profession for a woman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s better than going hungry,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie. \xe2\x80\x9cIf you don\xe2\x80\x99t want me to\r\ndo that, why don\xe2\x80\x99t you get work yourself?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was no answer ready for this. He had got used to the suggestion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, let up,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered.\r\n\r\nThe result of this was that she secretly resolved to try. It didn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nmatter about him. She was not going to be dragged into poverty and\r\nsomething worse to suit him. She could act. She could get something and\r\nthen work up. What would he say then? She pictured herself already\r\nappearing in some fine performance on Broadway; of going every evening\r\nto her dressing-room and making up. Then she would come out at eleven\r\no\xe2\x80\x99clock and see the carriages ranged about, waiting for the people. It\r\ndid not matter whether she was the star or not. If she were only once\r\nin, getting a decent salary, wearing the kind of clothes she liked,\r\nhaving the money to do with, going here and there as she pleased, how\r\ndelightful it would all be. Her mind ran over this picture all the day\r\nlong. Hurstwood\xe2\x80\x99s dreary state made its beauty become more and more\r\nvivid.\r\n\r\nCuriously this idea soon took hold of Hurstwood. His vanishing sum\r\nsuggested that he would need sustenance. Why could not Carrie assist\r\nhim a little until he could get something?\r\n\r\nHe came in one day with something of this idea in his mind.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI met John B. Drake to-day,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s going to open a hotel here\r\nin the fall. He says that he can make a place for me then.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho is he?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s the man that runs the Grand Pacific in Chicago.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d get about fourteen hundred a year out of that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat would be good, wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t it?\xe2\x80\x9d she said, sympathetically.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I can only get over this summer,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, \xe2\x80\x9cI think I\xe2\x80\x99ll be all\r\nright. I\xe2\x80\x99m hearing from some of my friends again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie swallowed this story in all its pristine beauty. She sincerely\r\nwished he could get through the summer. He looked so hopeless.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow much money have you left?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnly fifty dollars.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, mercy,\xe2\x80\x9d she exclaimed, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat will we do? It\xe2\x80\x99s only twenty days\r\nuntil the rent will be due again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHurstwood rested his head on his hands and looked blankly at the floor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMaybe you could get something in the stage line?\xe2\x80\x9d he blandly\r\nsuggested.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMaybe I could,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, glad that some one approved of the idea.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll lay my hand to whatever I can get,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, now that he saw her\r\nbrighten up. \xe2\x80\x9cI can get something.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe cleaned up the things one morning after he had gone, dressed as\r\nneatly as her wardrobe permitted, and set out for Broadway. She did not\r\nknow that thoroughfare very well. To her it was a wonderful\r\nconglomeration of everything great and mighty. The theatres were\r\nthere\xe2\x80\x94these agencies must be somewhere about.\r\n\r\nShe decided to stop in at the Madison Square Theatre and ask how to\r\nfind the theatrical agents. This seemed the sensible way. Accordingly,\r\nwhen she reached that theatre she applied to the clerk at the box\r\noffice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEh?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, looking out. \xe2\x80\x9cDramatic agents? I don\xe2\x80\x99t know. You\xe2\x80\x99ll find\r\nthem in the \xe2\x80\x98Clipper,\xe2\x80\x99 though. They all advertise in that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs that a paper?\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said the clerk, marvelling at such ignorance of a common fact.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou can get it at the news-stands,\xe2\x80\x9d he added politely, seeing how\r\npretty the inquirer was.\r\n\r\nCarrie proceeded to get the \xe2\x80\x9cClipper,\xe2\x80\x9d and tried to find the agents by\r\nlooking over it as she stood beside the stand. This could not be done\r\nso easily. Thirteenth Street was a number of blocks off, but she went\r\nback, carrying the precious paper and regretting the waste of time.\r\n\r\nHurstwood was already there, sitting in his place.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere were you?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve been trying to find some dramatic agents.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe felt a little diffident about asking concerning her success. The\r\npaper she began to scan attracted his attention.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat have you got there?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe \xe2\x80\x98Clipper.\xe2\x80\x99 The man said I\xe2\x80\x99d find their addresses in here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you been all the way over to Broadway to find that out? I could\r\nhave told you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy didn\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked, without looking up.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou never asked me,\xe2\x80\x9d he returned.\r\n\r\nShe went hunting aimlessly through the crowded columns. Her mind was\r\ndistracted by this man\xe2\x80\x99s indifference. The difficulty of the situation\r\nshe was facing was only added to by all he did. Self-commiseration\r\nbrewed in her heart. Tears trembled along her eyelids but did not fall.\r\nHurstwood noticed something.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet me look.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTo recover herself she went into the front room while he searched.\r\nPresently she returned. He had a pencil, and was writing upon an\r\nenvelope.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere\xe2\x80\x99re three,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\nCarrie took it and found that one was Mrs. Bermudez, another Marcus\r\nJenks, a third Percy Weil. He got up and put on his hat.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI guess I\xe2\x80\x99ll go out,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to himself, and went, strolling nowhere\r\nin particular, but feeling somehow that he must go.\r\n\r\nCarrie\xe2\x80\x99s first call was upon Mrs. Bermudez, whose address was quite the\r\nnearest. It was an old-fashioned residence turned into offices. Mrs.\r\nBermudez\xe2\x80\x99s offices consisted of what formerly had been a back chamber\r\nand a hall bedroom, marked \xe2\x80\x9cPrivate.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs Carrie entered she noticed several persons lounging about\xe2\x80\x94men, who\r\nsaid nothing and did nothing.\r\n\r\nWhile she was waiting to be noticed, the door of the hall bedroom\r\nopened and from it issued two very mannish-looking women, very tightly\r\ndressed, and wearing white collars and cuffs. After them came a portly\r\nlady of about forty-five, light-haired, sharp-eyed, and evidently\r\ngood-natured. At least she was smiling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, don\xe2\x80\x99t forget about that,\xe2\x80\x9d said one of the mannish women.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI won\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d said the portly \xe2\x80\x9cIt was just a show gotten\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I see,\xe2\x80\x9d said the woman, interrupting her. \xe2\x80\x9cNo, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know She hardly knew how to continue the\r\ninquiry.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCould you get me a part if I paid?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf we didn\xe2\x80\x99t you\xe2\x80\x99d get your money back.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh,\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\r\n\r\nThe agent saw he was dealing with an inexperienced soul, and continued\r\naccordingly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99d want to deposit fifty dollars, anyway. No agent would trouble\r\nabout you for less than that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie saw a light.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll think about it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe started to go, and then bethought herself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow soon would I get a place?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, that\xe2\x80\x99s hard to say,\xe2\x80\x9d said the man. \xe2\x80\x9cYou might get one in a week,\r\nor it might be a month. You\xe2\x80\x99d get the first thing that we thought you\r\ncould do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI see,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, and then, half-smiling to be agreeable, she\r\nwalked out.\r\n\r\nThe agent studied a moment, and then said to himself:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s funny how anxious these women are to get on the stage.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie found ample food for reflection in the fifty-dollar proposition.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMaybe they\xe2\x80\x99d take my money and not give me anything,\xe2\x80\x9d she thought. She\r\nhad some jewelry\xe2\x80\x94a diamond ring and pin and several other pieces. She\r\ncould get fifty dollars for those if she went to a pawnbroker.\r\n\r\nHurstwood was home before her. He had not thought she would be so long\r\nseeking.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, not venturing to ask what news.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI didn\xe2\x80\x99t find out anything to-day,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, taking off her\r\ngloves. \xe2\x80\x9cThey all want money to get you a place.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow much?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Hurstwood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFifty dollars.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey don\xe2\x80\x99t want anything, do they?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, they\xe2\x80\x99re like everybody else. You can\xe2\x80\x99t tell whether they\xe2\x80\x99d ever\r\nget you anything after you did pay them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t put up fifty on that basis,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood, as if he\r\nwere deciding, money in hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie. \xe2\x80\x9cI think I\xe2\x80\x99ll try some of the managers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHurstwood heard this, dead to the horror of it. He rocked a little to\r\nand fro, and chewed at his finger. It seemed all very natural in such\r\nextreme states. He would do better later on.\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XXXVIII. IN ELF LAND DISPORTING: THE GRIM WORLD WITHOUT\r\n\r\nWhen Carrie renewed her search, as she did the next day, going to the\r\nCasino, she found that in the opera chorus, as in other fields,\r\nemployment is difficult to secure. Girls who can stand in a line and\r\nlook pretty are as numerous as labourers who can swing a pick. She\r\nfound there was no discrimination between one and the other of\r\napplicants, save as regards a conventional standard of prettiness and\r\nform. Their own opinion or knowledge of their ability went for nothing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere shall I find Mr. Gray?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked of a sulky doorman at the\r\nstage entrance of the Casino.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou can\xe2\x80\x99t see him now; he\xe2\x80\x99s busy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know when I can see him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGot an appointment with him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you\xe2\x80\x99ll have to call at his office.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, dear!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Carrie. \xe2\x80\x9cWhere is his office?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe gave her the number.\r\n\r\nShe knew there was no need of calling there now. He would not be in.\r\nNothing remained but to employ the intermediate hours in search.\r\n\r\nThe dismal story of ventures in other places is quickly told. Mr. Daly\r\nsaw no one save by appointment. Carrie waited an hour in a dingy\r\noffice, quite in spite of obstacles, to learn this fact of the placid,\r\nindifferent Mr. Dorney.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will have to write and ask him to see you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo she went away.\r\n\r\nAt the Empire Theatre she found a hive of peculiarly listless and\r\nindifferent individuals. Everything ornately upholstered, everything\r\ncarefully finished, everything remarkably reserved.\r\n\r\nAt the Lyceum she entered one of those secluded, under-stairway\r\nclosets, berugged and bepaneled, which causes one to feel the greatness\r\nof all positions of authority. Here was reserve itself done into a\r\nbox-office clerk, a doorman, and an assistant, glorying in their fine\r\npositions.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, be very humble now\xe2\x80\x94very humble indeed. Tell us what it is you\r\nrequire. Tell it quickly, nervously, and without a vestige of\r\nself-respect. If no trouble to us in any way, we may see what we can\r\ndo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis was the atmosphere of the Lyceum\xe2\x80\x94the attitude, for that matter, of\r\nevery managerial office in the city. These little proprietors of\r\nbusinesses are lords indeed on their own ground.\r\n\r\nCarrie came away wearily, somewhat more abashed for her pains.\r\n\r\nHurstwood heard the details of the weary and unavailing search that\r\nevening.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI didn\xe2\x80\x99t get to see any one,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie. \xe2\x80\x9cI just walked, and walked,\r\nand waited around.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHurstwood only looked at her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI suppose you have to have some friends before you can get in,\xe2\x80\x9d she\r\nadded, disconsolately.\r\n\r\nHurstwood saw the difficulty of this thing, and yet it did not seem so\r\nterrible. Carrie was tired and dispirited, but now she could rest.\r\nViewing the world from his rocking-chair, its bitterness did not seem\r\nto approach so rapidly. To-morrow was another day.\r\n\r\nTo-morrow came, and the next, and the next.\r\n\r\nCarrie saw the manager at the Casino once.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome around,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cthe first of next week. I may make some\r\nchanges then.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe was a large and corpulent individual, surfeited with good clothes\r\nand good eating, who judged women as another would horseflesh. Carrie\r\nwas pretty and graceful. She might be put in even if she did not have\r\nany experience. One of the proprietors had suggested that the chorus\r\nwas a little weak on looks.\r\n\r\nThe first of next week was some days off yet. The first of the month\r\nwas drawing near. Carrie began to worry as she had never worried\r\nbefore.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you really look for anything when you go out?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked Hurstwood\r\none morning as a climax to some painful thoughts of her own.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course I do,\xe2\x80\x9d he said pettishly, troubling only a little over the\r\ndisgrace of the insinuation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d take anything,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cfor the present. It will soon be the\r\nfirst of the month again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe looked the picture of despair.\r\n\r\nHurstwood quit reading his paper and changed his clothes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe would look for something,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought. \xe2\x80\x9cHe would go and see if some\r\nbrewery couldn\xe2\x80\x99t get him in somewhere. Yes, he would take a position as\r\nbartender, if he could get it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was the same sort of pilgrimage he had made before. One or two\r\nslight rebuffs, and the bravado disappeared.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo use,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought. \xe2\x80\x9cI might as well go on back home.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNow that his money was so low, he began to observe his clothes and feel\r\nthat even his best ones were beginning to look commonplace. This was a\r\nbitter thought.\r\n\r\nCarrie came in after he did.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI went to see some of the variety managers,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, aimlessly. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\r\nhave to have an act. They don\xe2\x80\x99t want anybody that hasn\xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI saw some of the brewery people to-day,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood. \xe2\x80\x9cOne man\r\ntold me he\xe2\x80\x99d try to make a place for me in two or three weeks.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn the face of so much distress on Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s part, he had to make some\r\nshowing, and it was thus he did so. It was lassitude\xe2\x80\x99s apology to\r\nenergy.\r\n\r\nMonday Carrie went again to the Casino.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid I tell you to come around to-day?\xe2\x80\x9d said the manager, looking her\r\nover as she stood before him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou said the first of the week,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, greatly abashed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEver had any experience?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked again, almost severely.\r\n\r\nCarrie owned to ignorance.\r\n\r\nHe looked her over again as he stirred among some papers. He was\r\nsecretly pleased with this pretty, disturbed-looking young woman. \xe2\x80\x9cCome\r\naround to the theatre to-morrow morning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie\xe2\x80\x99s heart bounded to her throat.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will,\xe2\x80\x9d she said with difficulty. She could see he wanted her, and\r\nturned to go.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWould he really put her to work? Oh, blessed fortune, could it be?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlready the hard rumble of the city through the open windows became\r\npleasant.\r\n\r\nA sharp voice answered her mental interrogation, driving away all\r\nimmediate fears on that score.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe sure you\xe2\x80\x99re there promptly,\xe2\x80\x9d the manager said roughly. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ll be\r\ndropped if you\xe2\x80\x99re not.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie hastened away. She did not quarrel now with Hurstwood\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nidleness. She had a place\xe2\x80\x94she had a place! This sang in her ears.\r\n\r\nIn her delight she was almost anxious to tell Hurstwood. But, as she\r\nwalked homeward, and her survey of the facts of the case became larger,\r\nshe began to think of the anomaly of her finding work in several weeks\r\nand his lounging in idleness for a number of months.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy don\xe2\x80\x99t he get something?\xe2\x80\x9d she openly said to herself. \xe2\x80\x9cIf I can he\r\nsurely ought to. It wasn\xe2\x80\x99t very hard for me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe forgot her youth and her beauty. The handicap of age she did not,\r\nin her enthusiasm, perceive.\r\n\r\nThus, ever, the voice of success. Still, she could not keep her secret.\r\nShe tried to be calm and indifferent, but it was a palpable sham.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, seeing her relieved face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have a place.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, breathing a better breath.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat sort of a place is it?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, feeling in his veins as if now\r\nhe might get something good also.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the chorus,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it the Casino show you told me about?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered. \xe2\x80\x9cI begin rehearsing to-morrow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was more explanation volunteered by Carrie, because she was\r\nhappy. At last Hurstwood said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know how much you\xe2\x80\x99ll get?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I didn\xe2\x80\x99t want to ask,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie. \xe2\x80\x9cI guess they pay twelve or\r\nfourteen dollars a week.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAbout that, I guess,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood.\r\n\r\nThere was a good dinner in the flat that evening, owing to the mere\r\nlifting of the terrible strain. Hurstwood went out for a shave, and\r\nreturned with a fair-sized sirloin steak.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, to-morrow,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll look around myself,\xe2\x80\x9d and with\r\nrenewed hope he lifted his eyes from the ground.\r\n\r\nOn the morrow Carrie reported promptly and was given a place in the\r\nline. She saw a large, empty, shadowy play-house, still redolent of the\r\nperfumes and blazonry of the night, and notable for its rich, oriental\r\nappearance. The wonder of it awed and delighted her. Blessed be its\r\nwondrous reality. How hard she would try to be worthy of it. It was\r\nabove the common mass, above idleness, above want, above\r\ninsignificance. People came to it in finery and carriages to see. It\r\nwas ever a centre of light and mirth. And here she was of it. Oh, if\r\nshe could only remain, how happy would be her days!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is your name?\xe2\x80\x9d said the manager, who was conducting the drill.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadenda,\xe2\x80\x9d she replied, instantly mindful of the name Drouet had\r\nselected in Chicago. \xe2\x80\x9cCarrie Madenda.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, now, Miss Madenda,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, very affably, as Carrie thought,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cyou go over there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen he called to a young woman who was already of the company:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMiss Clark, you pair with Miss Madenda.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis young lady stepped forward, so that Carrie saw where to go, and\r\nthe rehearsal began.\r\n\r\nCarrie soon found that while this drilling had some slight resemblance\r\nto the rehearsals as conducted at Avery Hall, the attitude of the\r\nmanager was much more pronounced. She had marvelled at the insistence\r\nand superior airs of Mr. Millice, but the individual conducting here\r\nhad the same insistence, coupled with almost brutal roughness. As the\r\ndrilling proceeded, he seemed to wax exceedingly wroth over trifles,\r\nand to increase his lung power in proportion. It was very evident that\r\nhe had a great contempt for any assumption of dignity or innocence on\r\nthe part of these young women.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cClark,\xe2\x80\x9d he would call\xe2\x80\x94meaning, of course, Miss Clark\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cwhy don\xe2\x80\x99t you\r\ncatch step there?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy fours, right! Right, I said, right! For heaven\xe2\x80\x99s sake, get on to\r\nyourself! Right!\xe2\x80\x9d and in saying this he would lift the last sounds into\r\na vehement roar.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMaitland! Carrie trembled for\r\nher out of the fulness of her own sympathies and fear.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Maitland.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs there anything the matter with your ears?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know what \xe2\x80\x98column left\xe2\x80\x99 means?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, what are you stumbling around the right for? Want to break up\r\nthe line?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was just\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever mind what you were just. Keep your ears open.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie pitied, and trembled for her turn.\r\n\r\nYet another suffered the pain of personal rebuke.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHold on a minute,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the manager, throwing up his hands, as if in\r\ndespair. His demeanour was fierce.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cElvers,\xe2\x80\x9d he shouted, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat have you got in your mouth?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Elvers, while some smiled and stood nervously by.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, are you talking?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, keep your mouth still then. Now, all together again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt last Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s turn came. It was because of her extreme anxiety to do\r\nall that was required that brought on the trouble.\r\n\r\nShe heard some one called.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMason,\xe2\x80\x9d said the voice. \xe2\x80\x9cMiss Mason.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe looked around to see who it could be. A girl behind shoved her a\r\nlittle, but she did not understand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou, you!\xe2\x80\x9d said the manager. \xe2\x80\x9cCan\xe2\x80\x99t you hear?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, collapsing, and blushing fiercely.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIsn\xe2\x80\x99t your name Mason?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the manager.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, \xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99s Madenda.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, what\xe2\x80\x99s the matter with your feet? Carrie came away worn enough in body, but too excited\r\nin mind to notice it. She meant to go home and practise her evolutions\r\nas prescribed. She would not err in any way, if she could help it.\r\n\r\nWhen she reached the flat Hurstwood was not there. For a wonder he was\r\nout looking for work, as she supposed. She took only a mouthful to eat\r\nand then practised on, sustained by visions of freedom from financial\r\ndistress\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cThe sound of glory ringing in her ears.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhen Hurstwood returned he was not so elated as when he went away, and\r\nnow she was obliged to drop practice and get dinner. Here was an early\r\nirritation. She would have her work and this. Was she going to act and\r\nkeep house?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll not do it,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cafter I get started. He can take his meals\r\nout.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEach day thereafter brought its cares. She found it was not such a\r\nwonderful thing to be in the chorus, and she also learned that her\r\nsalary would be twelve dollars a week. After a few days she had her\r\nfirst sight of those high and mighties\xe2\x80\x94the leading ladies and\r\ngentlemen. She saw that they were privileged and deferred to. She was\r\nnothing\xe2\x80\x94absolutely nothing at all.\r\n\r\nAt home was Hurstwood, daily giving her cause for thought. He seemed to\r\nget nothing to do, and yet he made bold to inquire how she was getting\r\nalong. The regularity with which he did this smacked of some one who\r\nwas waiting to live upon her labour. Now that she had a visible means\r\nof support, this irritated her. He seemed to be depending upon her\r\nlittle twelve dollars.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow are you getting along?\xe2\x80\x9d he would blandly inquire.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, all right,\xe2\x80\x9d she would reply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFind it easy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt will be all right when I get used to it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHis paper would then engross his thoughts.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI got some lard,\xe2\x80\x9d he would add, as an afterthought. \xe2\x80\x9cI thought maybe\r\nyou might want to make some biscuit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe calm suggestion of the man astonished her a little, especially in\r\nthe light of recent developments. Her dawning independence gave her\r\nmore courage to observe, and she felt as if she wanted to say things.\r\nStill she could not talk to him as she had to Drouet. There was\r\nsomething in the man\xe2\x80\x99s manner of which she had always stood in awe. He\r\nseemed to have some invisible strength in reserve.\r\n\r\nOne day, after her first week\xe2\x80\x99s rehearsal, what she expected came\r\nopenly to the surface.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ll have to be rather saving,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, laying down some meat he had\r\npurchased. \xe2\x80\x9cYou won\xe2\x80\x99t get any money for a week or so yet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, who was stirring a pan at the stove.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve only got the rent and thirteen dollars more,\xe2\x80\x9d he added.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s it,\xe2\x80\x9d she said to herself. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m to use my money now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nInstantly she remembered that she had hoped to buy a few things for\r\nherself. She needed clothes. Her hat was not nice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat will twelve dollars do towards keeping up this flat?\xe2\x80\x9d she\r\nthought. \xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t do it. Why doesn\xe2\x80\x99t he get something to do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe important night of the first real performance came. She did not\r\nsuggest to Hurstwood that he come and see. He did not think of going.\r\nIt would only be money wasted. She had such a small part.\r\n\r\nThe advertisements were already in the papers; the posters upon the\r\nbill-boards. The leading lady and many members were cited. Carrie was\r\nnothing.\r\n\r\nAs in Chicago, she was seized with stage fright as the very first\r\nentrance of the ballet approached, but later she recovered. The\r\napparent and painful insignificance of the part took fear away from\r\nher. She felt that she was so obscure it did not matter. Fortunately,\r\nshe did not have to wear tights. A group of twelve were assigned pretty\r\ngolden-hued skirts which came only to a line about an inch above the\r\nknee. Carrie happened to be one of the twelve.\r\n\r\nIn standing about the stage, marching, and occasionally lifting up her\r\nvoice in the general chorus, she had a chance to observe the audience\r\nand to see the inauguration of a great hit. There was plenty of\r\napplause, but she could not help noting how poorly some of the women of\r\nalleged ability did.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI could do better than that,\xe2\x80\x9d Carrie ventured to herself, in several\r\ninstances. To do her justice, she was right.\r\n\r\nAfter it was over she dressed quickly, and as the manager had scolded\r\nsome others and passed her, she imagined she must have proved\r\nsatisfactory. She wanted to get out quickly, because she knew but few,\r\nand the stars were gossiping. Outside were carriages and some correct\r\nyouths in attractive clothing, waiting. Carrie saw that she was scanned\r\nclosely. The flutter of an eyelash would have brought her a companion.\r\nThat she did not give.\r\n\r\nOne experienced youth volunteered, anyhow.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot going home alone, are you?\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\nCarrie merely hastened her steps and took the Sixth Avenue car. Her\r\nhead was so full of the wonder of it that she had time for nothing\r\nelse.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you hear any more from the brewery?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked at the end of the\r\nweek, hoping by the question to stir him on to action.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered, \xe2\x80\x9cthey\xe2\x80\x99re not quite ready yet. I think something will\r\ncome of that, though.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe said nothing more then, objecting to giving up her own money, and\r\nyet feeling that such would have to be the case. Hurstwood felt the\r\ncrisis, and artfully decided to appeal to Carrie. He had long since\r\nrealised how good-natured she was, how much she would stand. There was\r\nsome little shame in him at the thought of doing so, but he justified\r\nhimself with the thought that he really would get something. Rent day\r\ngave him his opportunity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, as he counted it out, \xe2\x80\x9cthat\xe2\x80\x99s about the last of my\r\nmoney. I\xe2\x80\x99ll have to get something pretty soon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie looked at him askance, half-suspicious of an appeal.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I could only hold out a little longer I think I could get\r\nsomething. Drake is sure to open a hotel here in September.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs he?\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, thinking of the short month that still remained\r\nuntil that time.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWould you mind helping me out until then?\xe2\x80\x9d he said appealingly. \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nthink I\xe2\x80\x99ll be all right after that time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, feeling sadly handicapped by fate.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe can get along if we economise. I\xe2\x80\x99ll pay you back all right.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I\xe2\x80\x99ll help you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, feeling quite hardhearted at thus\r\nforcing him to humbly appeal, and yet her desire for the benefit of her\r\nearnings wrung a faint protest from her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy don\xe2\x80\x99t you take anything, George, temporarily?\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat\r\ndifference does it make? Maybe, after a while, you\xe2\x80\x99ll get something\r\nbetter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will take anything,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, relieved, and wincing under reproof.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d just as leave dig on the streets. Nobody knows me here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, you needn\xe2\x80\x99t do that,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, hurt by the pity of it. \xe2\x80\x9cBut\r\nthere must be other things.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll get something!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, assuming determination.\r\n\r\nThen he went back to his paper.\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XXXIX. OF LIGHTS AND OF SHADOWS: THE PARTING OF WORLDS\r\n\r\nWhat Hurstwood got as the result of this determination was more\r\nself-assurance that each particular day was not the day. At the same\r\ntime, Carrie passed through thirty days of mental distress.\r\n\r\nHer need of clothes\xe2\x80\x94to say nothing of her desire for ornaments\xe2\x80\x94grew\r\nrapidly as the fact developed that for all her work she was not to have\r\nthem. The sympathy she felt for Hurstwood, at the time he asked her to\r\ntide him over, vanished with these newer urgings of decency. He was not\r\nalways renewing his request, but this love of good appearance was. It\r\ninsisted, and Carrie wished to satisfy it, wished more and more that\r\nHurstwood was not in the way.\r\n\r\nHurstwood reasoned, when he neared the last ten dollars, that he had\r\nbetter keep a little pocket change and not become wholly dependent for\r\ncar-fare, shaves, and the like; so when this sum was still in his hand\r\nhe announced himself as penniless.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m clear out,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to Carrie one afternoon. \xe2\x80\x9cI paid for some coal\r\nthis morning, and that took all but ten or fifteen cents.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve got some money there in my purse.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHurstwood went to get it, starting for a can of tomatoes. Carrie\r\nscarcely noticed that this was the beginning of the new order. He took\r\nout fifteen cents and bought the can with it. Thereafter it was dribs\r\nand drabs of this sort, until one morning Carrie suddenly remembered\r\nthat she would not be back until close to dinner time.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re all out of flour,\xe2\x80\x9d she said; \xe2\x80\x9cyou\xe2\x80\x99d better get some this\r\nafternoon. We haven\xe2\x80\x99t any meat, either. How would it do if we had liver\r\nand bacon?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSuits me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBetter get a half or three-quarters of a pound of that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHalf \xe2\x80\x99ll be enough,\xe2\x80\x9d volunteered Hurstwood.\r\n\r\nShe opened her purse and laid down a half dollar. He pretended not to\r\nnotice it.\r\n\r\nHurstwood bought the flour\xe2\x80\x94which all grocers sold in 3\xc2\xbd-pound\r\npackages\xe2\x80\x94for thirteen cents and paid fifteen cents for a half-pound of\r\nliver and bacon. He left the packages, together with the balance of\r\ntwenty-two cents, upon the kitchen table, where Carrie found it. It did\r\nnot escape her that the change was accurate. There was something sad in\r\nrealising that, after all, all that he wanted of her was something to\r\neat. She felt as if hard thoughts were unjust. Maybe he would get\r\nsomething yet. He had no vices.\r\n\r\nThat very evening, however, on going into the theatre, one of the\r\nchorus girls passed her all newly arrayed in a pretty mottled tweed\r\nsuit, which took Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s eye. The young woman wore a fine bunch of\r\nviolets and seemed in high spirits. She smiled at Carrie good-naturedly\r\nas she passed, showing pretty, even teeth, and Carrie smiled back.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe can afford to dress well,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Carrie, \xe2\x80\x9cand so could I, if I\r\ncould only keep my money. I haven\xe2\x80\x99t a decent tie of any kind to wear.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe put out her foot and looked at her shoe reflectively. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll get a\r\npair of shoes Saturday, anyhow; I don\xe2\x80\x99t care what happens.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOne of the sweetest and most sympathetic little chorus girls in the\r\ncompany made friends with her because in Carrie she found nothing to\r\nfrighten her away. She was a gay little Manon, unwitting of society\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nfierce conception of morality, but, nevertheless, good to her neighbour\r\nand charitable. Little license was allowed the chorus in the matter of\r\nconversation, but, nevertheless, some was indulged in.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s warm to-night, isn\xe2\x80\x99t it?\xe2\x80\x9d said this girl, arrayed in pink\r\nfleshings and an imitation golden helmet. She also carried a shining\r\nshield.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; it is,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, pleased that some one should talk to her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m almost roasting,\xe2\x80\x9d said the girl.\r\n\r\nCarrie looked into her pretty face, with its large blue eyes, and saw\r\nlittle beads of moisture.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s more marching in this opera than ever I did before,\xe2\x80\x9d added the\r\ngirl.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you been in others?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Carrie, surprised at her experience.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLots of them,\xe2\x80\x9d said the girl; \xe2\x80\x9chaven\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is my first experience.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, is it? I thought I saw you the time they ran \xe2\x80\x98The Queen\xe2\x80\x99s Mate\xe2\x80\x99\r\nhere.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, shaking her head; \xe2\x80\x9cnot me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis conversation was interrupted by the blare of the orchestra and the\r\nsputtering of the calcium lights in the wings as the line was called to\r\nform for a new entrance. No further opportunity for conversation\r\noccurred, but the next evening, when they were getting ready for the\r\nstage, this girl appeared anew at her side.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey say this show is going on the road next month.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it?\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; do you think you\xe2\x80\x99ll go?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know; I guess so, if they\xe2\x80\x99ll take me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, they\xe2\x80\x99ll take you. I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t go. They won\xe2\x80\x99t give you any more, and\r\nit will cost you everything you make to live. I never leave New York.\r\nThere are too many shows going on here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan you always get in another show?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI always have. There\xe2\x80\x99s one going on up at the Broadway this month. I\xe2\x80\x99m\r\ngoing to try and get in that if this one really goes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie heard this with aroused intelligence. Evidently it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t so\r\nvery difficult to get on. Maybe she also could get a place if this show\r\nwent away. \xe2\x80\x9cDo they all pay about the same?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. Sometimes you get a little more. This show doesn\xe2\x80\x99t pay very\r\nmuch.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI get twelve,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you?\xe2\x80\x9d said the girl. \xe2\x80\x9cThey pay me fifteen, and you do more work\r\nthan I do. I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t stand it if I were you. They\xe2\x80\x99re just giving you\r\nless because they think you don\xe2\x80\x99t know. You ought to be making\r\nfifteen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I\xe2\x80\x99m not,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you\xe2\x80\x99ll get more at the next place if you want it,\xe2\x80\x9d went on the\r\ngirl, who admired Carrie very much. \xe2\x80\x9cYou do fine, and the manager knows\r\nit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTo say the truth, Carrie did unconsciously move about with an air\r\npleasing and somewhat distinctive. It was due wholly to her natural\r\nmanner and total lack of self-consciousness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you suppose I could get more up at the Broadway?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course you can,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the girl. \xe2\x80\x9cYou come with me when I go.\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ll do the talking.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie heard this, flushing with thankfulness. She liked this little\r\ngaslight soldier. She seemed so experienced and self-reliant in her\r\ntinsel helmet and military accoutrements.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy future must be assured if I can always get work this way,\xe2\x80\x9d thought\r\nCarrie.\r\n\r\nStill, in the morning, when her household duties would infringe upon\r\nher and Hurstwood sat there, a perfect load to contemplate, her fate\r\nseemed dismal and unrelieved. It did not take so very much to feed them\r\nunder Hurstwood\xe2\x80\x99s close-measured buying, and there would possibly be\r\nenough for rent, but it left nothing else. Carrie bought the shoes and\r\nsome other things, which complicated the rent problem very seriously.\r\nSuddenly, a week from the fatal day, Carrie realised that they were\r\ngoing to run short.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t believe,\xe2\x80\x9d she exclaimed, looking into her purse at breakfast,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthat I\xe2\x80\x99ll have enough to pay the rent.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow much have you?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Hurstwood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I\xe2\x80\x99ve got twenty-two dollars, but there\xe2\x80\x99s everything to be paid\r\nfor this week yet, and if I use all I get Saturday to pay this, there\r\nwon\xe2\x80\x99t be any left for next week. Do you think your hotel man will open\r\nhis hotel this month?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think so,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Hurstwood. \xe2\x80\x9cHe said he would.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAfter a while, Hurstwood said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t worry about it. Maybe the grocer will wait. He can do that.\r\nWe\xe2\x80\x99ve traded there long enough to make him trust us for a week or two.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you think he will?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think so.\xe2\x80\x9d On this account, Hurstwood, this very day, looked grocer\r\nOeslogge clearly in the eye as he ordered a pound of coffee, and said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you mind carrying my account until the end of every week?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no, Mr. Wheeler,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Oeslogge. \xe2\x80\x9cDat iss all right.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHurstwood, still tactful in distress, added nothing to this. It seemed\r\nan easy thing. He looked out of the door, and then gathered up his\r\ncoffee when ready and came away. The game of a desperate man had begun.\r\n\r\nRent was paid, and now came the grocer. Hurstwood managed by paying out\r\nof his own ten and collecting from Carrie at the end of the week. Then\r\nhe delayed a day next time settling with the grocer, and so soon had\r\nhis ten back, with Oeslogge getting his pay on this Thursday or Friday\r\nfor last Saturday\xe2\x80\x99s bill.\r\n\r\nThis entanglement made Carrie anxious for a change of some sort.\r\nHurstwood did not seem to realise that she had a right to anything. He\r\nschemed to make what she earned cover all expenses, but seemed not to\r\ntrouble over adding anything himself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe talks about worrying,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Carrie. \xe2\x80\x9cIf he worried enough he\r\ncouldn\xe2\x80\x99t sit there and wait for me. He\xe2\x80\x99d get something to do. No man\r\ncould go seven months without finding something if he tried.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe sight of him always around in his untidy clothes and gloomy\r\nappearance drove Carrie to seek relief in other places. Twice a week\r\nthere were matin\xc3\xa9es, and then Hurstwood ate a cold snack, which he\r\nprepared himself. Two other days there were rehearsals beginning at ten\r\nin the morning and lasting usually until one. Now, to this Carrie added\r\na few visits to one or two chorus girls, including the blue-eyed\r\nsoldier of the golden helmet. She did it because it was pleasant and a\r\nrelief from dulness of the home over which her husband brooded.\r\n\r\nThe blue-eyed soldier\xe2\x80\x99s name was Osborne\xe2\x80\x94Lola Osborne. Her room was in\r\nNineteenth Street near Fourth Avenue, a block now given up wholly to\r\noffice buildings. Here she had a comfortable back room, looking over a\r\ncollection of back yards in which grew a number of shade trees pleasant\r\nto see.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIsn\xe2\x80\x99t your home in New York?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked of Lola one day.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; but I can\xe2\x80\x99t get along with my people. They always want me to do\r\nwhat they want. Do you live here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith your family?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie was ashamed to say that she was married. She had talked so much\r\nabout getting more salary and confessed to so much anxiety about her\r\nfuture, that now, when the direct question of fact was waiting, she\r\ncould not tell this girl.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith some relatives,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered.\r\n\r\nMiss Osborne took it for granted that, like herself, Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s time was\r\nher own. She invariably asked her to stay, proposing little outings and\r\nother things of that sort until Carrie began neglecting her dinner\r\nhours. Hurstwood noticed it, but felt in no position to quarrel with\r\nher. Several times she came so late as scarcely to have an hour in\r\nwhich to patch up a meal and start for the theatre.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you rehearse in the afternoons?\xe2\x80\x9d Hurstwood once asked, concealing\r\nalmost completely the cynical protest and regret which prompted it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; I was looking around for another place,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\nAs a matter of fact she was, but only in such a way as furnished the\r\nleast straw of an excuse. Miss Osborne and she had gone to the office\r\nof the manager who was to produce the new opera at the Broadway and\r\nreturned straight to the former\xe2\x80\x99s room, where they had been since three\r\no\xe2\x80\x99clock.\r\n\r\nCarrie felt this question to be an infringement on her liberty. She did\r\nnot take into account how much liberty she was securing. Only the\r\nlatest step, the newest freedom, must not be questioned.\r\n\r\nHurstwood saw it all clearly enough. He was shrewd after his kind, and\r\nyet there was enough decency in the man to stop him from making any\r\neffectual protest. In his almost inexplicable apathy he was content to\r\ndroop supinely while Carrie drifted out of his life, just as he was\r\nwilling supinely to see opportunity pass beyond his control. He could\r\nnot help clinging and protesting in a mild, irritating, and ineffectual\r\nway, however\xe2\x80\x94a way that simply widened the breach by slow degrees.\r\n\r\nA further enlargement of this chasm between them came when the manager,\r\nlooking between the wings upon the brightly lighted stage where the\r\nchorus was going through some of its glittering evolutions, said to the\r\nmaster of the ballet:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho is that fourth girl there on the right\xe2\x80\x94the one coming round at the\r\nend now?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh,\xe2\x80\x9d said the ballet-master, \xe2\x80\x9cthat\xe2\x80\x99s Miss Madenda.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe\xe2\x80\x99s good looking. Why don\xe2\x80\x99t you let her head that line?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will,\xe2\x80\x9d said the man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJust do that. She\xe2\x80\x99ll look better there than the woman you\xe2\x80\x99ve got.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right. I will do that,\xe2\x80\x9d said the master.\r\n\r\nThe next evening Carrie was called out, much as if for an error.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou lead your company to-night,\xe2\x80\x9d said the master.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPut snap into it,\xe2\x80\x9d he added. \xe2\x80\x9cWe must have snap.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Carrie.\r\n\r\nAstonished at this change, she thought that the heretofore leader must\r\nbe ill; but when she saw her in the line, with a distinct expression of\r\nsomething unfavourable in her eye, she began to think that perhaps it\r\nwas merit.\r\n\r\nShe had a chic way of tossing her head to one side, and holding her\r\narms as if for action\xe2\x80\x94not listlessly. In front of the line this showed\r\nup even more effectually.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat girl knows how to carry herself,\xe2\x80\x9d said the manager, another\r\nevening. He began to think that he should like to talk with her. If he\r\nhadn\xe2\x80\x99t made it a rule to have nothing to do with the members of the\r\nchorus, he would have approached her most unbendingly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPut that girl at the head of the white column,\xe2\x80\x9d he suggested to the\r\nman in charge of the ballet.\r\n\r\nThis white column consisted of some twenty girls, all in snow-white\r\nflannel trimmed with silver and blue. Its leader was most stunningly\r\narrayed in the same colours, elaborated, however, with epaulets and a\r\nbelt of silver, with a short sword dangling at one side. Carrie was\r\nfitted for this costume, and a few days later appeared, proud of her\r\nnew laurels. She was especially gratified to find that her salary was\r\nnow eighteen instead of twelve.\r\n\r\nHurstwood heard nothing about this.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll not give him the rest of my money,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie. \xe2\x80\x9cI do enough. I\r\nam going to get me something to wear.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs a matter of fact, during this second month she had been buying for\r\nherself as recklessly as she dared, regardless of the consequences.\r\nThere were impending more complications rent day, and more extension of\r\nthe credit system in the neighbourhood. Now, however, she proposed to\r\ndo better by herself.\r\n\r\nHer first move was to buy a shirt waist, and in studying these she\r\nfound how little her money would buy\xe2\x80\x94how much, if she could only use\r\nall. She forgot that if she were alone she would have to pay for a room\r\nand board, and imagined that every cent of her eighteen could be spent\r\nfor clothes and things that she liked.\r\n\r\nAt last she picked upon something, which not only used up all her\r\nsurplus above twelve, but invaded that sum. She knew she was going too\r\nfar, but her feminine love of finery prevailed. The next day Hurstwood\r\nsaid:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe owe the grocer five dollars and forty cents this week.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo we?\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, frowning a little.\r\n\r\nShe looked in her purse to leave it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve only got eight dollars and twenty cents altogether.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe owe the milkman sixty cents,\xe2\x80\x9d added Hurstwood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, and there\xe2\x80\x99s the coal man,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\nHurstwood said nothing. He had seen the new things she was buying; the\r\nway she was neglecting household duties; the readiness with which she\r\nwas slipping out afternoons and staying. He felt that something was\r\ngoing to happen. All at once she spoke:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d she said; \xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t do it all. I don\xe2\x80\x99t earn enough.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis was a direct challenge. Hurstwood had to take it up. He tried to\r\nbe calm.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t want you to do it all,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cI only want a little help\r\nuntil I can get something to do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Carrie. \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s always the way. It takes more than\r\nI can earn to pay for things. I don\xe2\x80\x99t see what I\xe2\x80\x99m going to do.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I\xe2\x80\x99ve tried to get something,\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed. What do you want me\r\nto do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou couldn\xe2\x80\x99t have tried so very hard,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie. \xe2\x80\x9cI got something.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I did,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, angered almost to harsh words. \xe2\x80\x9cYou needn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nthrow up your success to me. All I asked was a little help until I\r\ncould get something. I\xe2\x80\x99m not down yet. I\xe2\x80\x99ll come up all right.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe tried to speak steadily, but his voice trembled a little.\r\n\r\nCarrie\xe2\x80\x99s anger melted on the instant. She felt ashamed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9chere\xe2\x80\x99s the money,\xe2\x80\x9d and emptied it out on the table.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI haven\xe2\x80\x99t got quite enough to pay it all. If they can wait until\r\nSaturday, though, I\xe2\x80\x99ll have some more.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou keep it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood sadly. \xe2\x80\x9cI only want enough to pay the\r\ngrocer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe put it back, and proceeded to get dinner early and in good time.\r\nHer little bravado made her feel as if she ought to make amends.\r\n\r\nIn a little while their old thoughts returned to both.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe\xe2\x80\x99s making more than she says,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Hurstwood. \xe2\x80\x9cShe says she\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nmaking twelve, but that wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t buy all those things. I don\xe2\x80\x99t care.\r\nLet her keep her money. I\xe2\x80\x99ll get something again one of these days.\r\nThen she can go to the deuce.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe only said this in his anger, but it prefigured a possible course of\r\naction and attitude well enough.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t care,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Carrie. \xe2\x80\x9cHe ought to be told to get out and do\r\nsomething. It isn\xe2\x80\x99t right that I should support him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn these days Carrie was introduced to several youths, friends of Miss\r\nOsborne, who were of the kind most aptly described as gay and festive.\r\nThey called once to get Miss Osborne for an afternoon drive. Carrie was\r\nwith her at the time.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome and go along,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lola.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I can\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes, come and go. What have you got to do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have to be home by five,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat for?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, dinner.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99ll take us to dinner,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lola.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie. \xe2\x80\x9cI won\xe2\x80\x99t go. I can\xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, do come. They\xe2\x80\x99re awful nice boys. We\xe2\x80\x99ll get you back in time.\r\nWe\xe2\x80\x99re only going for a drive in Central Park.\xe2\x80\x9d Carrie thought a while,\r\nand at last yielded.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, I must be back by half-past four,\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\r\n\r\nThe information went in one ear of Lola and out the other.\r\n\r\nAfter Drouet and Hurstwood, there was the least touch of cynicism in\r\nher attitude toward young men\xe2\x80\x94especially of the gay and frivolous sort.\r\nShe felt a little older than they. Some of their pretty compliments\r\nseemed silly. Still, she was young in heart and body and youth appealed\r\nto her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, we\xe2\x80\x99ll be right back, Miss Madenda,\xe2\x80\x9d said one of the chaps, bowing.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t think we\xe2\x80\x99d keep you over time, now, would you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, smiling.\r\n\r\nThey were off for a drive\xe2\x80\x94she, looking about and noticing fine\r\nclothing, the young men voicing those silly pleasantries and weak quips\r\nwhich pass for humour in coy circles. Carrie saw the great park parade\r\nof carriages, beginning at the Fifty-ninth Street entrance and winding\r\npast the Museum of Art to the exit at One Hundred and Tenth Street and\r\nSeventh Avenue. Her eye was once more taken by the show of wealth\xe2\x80\x94the\r\nelaborate costumes, elegant harnesses, spirited horses, and, above all,\r\nthe beauty. Once more the plague of poverty galled her, but now she\r\nforgot in a measure her own troubles so far as to forget Hurstwood. He\r\nwaited until four, five, and even six. It was getting dark when he got\r\nup out of his chair.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI guess she isn\xe2\x80\x99t coming home,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, grimly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s the way,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought. \xe2\x80\x9cShe\xe2\x80\x99s getting a start now. I\xe2\x80\x99m out of\r\nit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie had really discovered her neglect, but only at a quarter after\r\nfive, and the open carriage was now far up Seventh Avenue, near the\r\nHarlem River.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat time is it?\xe2\x80\x9d she inquired. \xe2\x80\x9cI must be getting back.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA quarter after five,\xe2\x80\x9d said her companion, consulting an elegant,\r\nopen-faced watch.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, dear me!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Carrie. Then she settled back with a sigh.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s no use crying over spilt milk,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s too late.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course it is,\xe2\x80\x9d said the youth, who saw visions of a fine dinner\r\nnow, and such invigorating talk as would result in a reunion after the\r\nshow. He was greatly taken with Carrie. \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ll drive down to\r\nDelmonico\xe2\x80\x99s now and have something there, won\xe2\x80\x99t we, Orrin?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo be sure,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Orrin, gaily.\r\n\r\nCarrie thought of Hurstwood. Never before had she neglected dinner\r\nwithout an excuse.\r\n\r\nThey drove back, and at 6.15 sat down to dine. It was the Sherry\r\nincident over again, the remembrance of which came painfully back to\r\nCarrie. She remembered Mrs. Vance, who had never called again after\r\nHurstwood\xe2\x80\x99s reception, and Ames.\r\n\r\nAt this figure her mind halted. It was a strong, clean vision. He liked\r\nbetter books than she read, better people than she associated with. His\r\nideals burned in her heart.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s fine to be a good actress,\xe2\x80\x9d came distinctly back.\r\n\r\nWhat sort of an actress was she?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat are you thinking about, Miss Madenda?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired her merry\r\ncompanion. \xe2\x80\x9cCome, now, let\xe2\x80\x99s see if I can guess.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t try.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe shook it off and ate. She forgot, in part, and was merry. When it\r\ncame to the after-theatre proposition, however, she shook her head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t. I have a previous engagement.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, now, Miss Madenda,\xe2\x80\x9d pleaded the youth.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, \xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t. You\xe2\x80\x99ve been so kind, but you\xe2\x80\x99ll have to\r\nexcuse me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe youth looked exceedingly crestfallen.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCheer up, old man,\xe2\x80\x9d whispered his companion. \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ll go around, anyhow.\r\nShe may change her mind.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XL.
