A PUBLIC DISSENSION: A FINAL APPEAL\r\n\r\nThere was no after-theatre lark, however, so far as Carrie was\r\nconcerned. She made her way homeward, thinking about her absence.\r\nHurstwood was asleep, but roused up to look as she passed through to\r\nher own bed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs that you?\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered.\r\n\r\nThe next morning at breakfast she felt like apologising.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI couldn\xe2\x80\x99t get home last evening,\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, Carrie,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat\xe2\x80\x99s the use saying that? I don\xe2\x80\x99t care.\r\nYou needn\xe2\x80\x99t tell me that, though.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI couldn\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, her colour rising. Then, seeing that he\r\nlooked as if he said \xe2\x80\x9cI know,\xe2\x80\x9d she exclaimed: \xe2\x80\x9cOh, all right. I don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ncare.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFrom now on, her indifference to the flat was even greater. There\r\nseemed no common ground on which they could talk to one another. She\r\nlet herself be asked for expenses. It became so with him that he hated\r\nto do it. He preferred standing off the butcher and baker. He ran up a\r\ngrocery bill of sixteen dollars with Oeslogge, laying in a supply of\r\nstaple articles, so that they would not have to buy any of those things\r\nfor some time to come. Then he changed his grocery. It was the same\r\nwith the butcher and several others. Carrie never heard anything of\r\nthis directly from him. He asked for such as he could expect, drifting\r\nfarther and farther into a situation which could have but one ending.\r\n\r\nIn this fashion, September went by.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIsn\xe2\x80\x99t Mr. Drake going to open his hotel?\xe2\x80\x9d Carrie asked several times.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. He won\xe2\x80\x99t do it before October, though, now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie became disgusted. \xe2\x80\x9cSuch a man,\xe2\x80\x9d she said to herself frequently.\r\nMore and more she visited. She put most of her spare money in clothes,\r\nwhich, after all, was not an astonishing amount. At last the opera she\r\nwas with announced its departure within four weeks. \xe2\x80\x9cLast two weeks of\r\nthe Great Comic Opera success\xe2\x80\x94The \xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94,\xe2\x80\x9d etc., was upon all billboards\r\nand in the newspapers, before she acted.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m not going out on the road,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Osborne.\r\n\r\nCarrie went with her to apply to another manager.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEver had any experience?\xe2\x80\x9d was one of his questions.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m with the company at the Casino now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, you are?\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\nThe end of this was another engagement at twenty per week.\r\n\r\nCarrie was delighted. She began to feel that she had a place in the\r\nworld. People recognised ability.\r\n\r\nSo changed was her state that the home atmosphere became intolerable.\r\nIt was all poverty and trouble there, or seemed to be, because it was a\r\nload to bear. It became a place to keep away from. Still she slept\r\nthere, and did a fair amount of work, keeping it in order. It was a\r\nsitting place for Hurstwood. He sat and rocked, rocked and read,\r\nenveloped in the gloom of his own fate. October went by, and November.\r\nIt was the dead of winter almost before he knew it, and there he sat.\r\n\r\nCarrie was doing better, that he knew. Her clothes were improved now,\r\neven fine. He saw her coming and going, sometimes picturing to himself\r\nher rise. Little eating had thinned him somewhat. He had no appetite.\r\nHis clothes, too, were a poor man\xe2\x80\x99s clothes. Talk about getting\r\nsomething had become even too threadbare and ridiculous for him. So he\r\nfolded his hands and waited\xe2\x80\x94for what, he could not anticipate.\r\n\r\nAt last, however, troubles became too thick. The hounding of creditors,\r\nthe indifference of Carrie, the silence of the flat, and presence of\r\nwinter, all joined to produce a climax. It was effected by the arrival\r\nof Oeslogge, personally, when Carrie was there.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI call about my bill,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Oeslogge.\r\n\r\nCarrie was only faintly surprised.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow much is it?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSixteen dollars,\xe2\x80\x9d he replied.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, that much?\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie. \xe2\x80\x9cIs this right?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked, turning to\r\nHurstwood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I never heard anything about it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe looked as if she thought he had been contracting some needless\r\nexpense.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, we had it all right,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered. Then he went to the door. \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\ncan\xe2\x80\x99t pay you anything on that to-day,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, mildly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, when can you?\xe2\x80\x9d said the grocer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot before Saturday, anyhow,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHuh!\xe2\x80\x9d returned the grocer. \xe2\x80\x9cThis is fine. I must have that. I need the\r\nmoney.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie was standing farther back in the room, hearing it all. She was\r\ngreatly distressed. It was so bad and commonplace. Hurstwood was\r\nannoyed also.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cthere\xe2\x80\x99s no use talking about it now. If you\xe2\x80\x99ll come\r\nin Saturday, I\xe2\x80\x99ll pay you something on it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe grocery man went away.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow are we going to pay it?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Carrie, astonished by the bill. \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\ncan\xe2\x80\x99t do it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you don\xe2\x80\x99t have to,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cHe can\xe2\x80\x99t get what he can\xe2\x80\x99t get.\r\nHe\xe2\x80\x99ll have to wait.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t see how we ran up such a bill as that,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, we ate it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s funny,\xe2\x80\x9d she replied, still doubting.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the use of your standing there and talking like that, now?\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nasked. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you think I\xe2\x80\x99ve had it alone? You talk as if I\xe2\x80\x99d taken\r\nsomething.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, it\xe2\x80\x99s too much, anyhow,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie. \xe2\x80\x9cI oughtn\xe2\x80\x99t to be made to\r\npay for it. I\xe2\x80\x99ve got more than I can pay for now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Hurstwood, sitting down in silence. He was sick of\r\nthe grind of this thing.\r\n\r\nCarrie went out and there he sat, determining to do something.\r\n\r\nThere had been appearing in the papers about this time rumours and\r\nnotices of an approaching strike on the trolley lines in Brooklyn.\r\nThere was general dissatisfaction as to the hours of labour required\r\nand the wages paid. As usual\xe2\x80\x94and for some inexplicable reason\xe2\x80\x94the men\r\nchose the winter for the forcing of the hand of their employers and the\r\nsettlement of their difficulties.\r\n\r\nHurstwood had been reading of this thing, and wondering concerning the\r\nhuge tie-up which would follow. A day or two before this trouble with\r\nCarrie, it came. On a cold afternoon, when everything was grey and it\r\nthreatened to snow, the papers announced that the men had been called\r\nout on all the lines. Being so utterly idle, and his mind filled with\r\nthe numerous predictions which had been made concerning the scarcity of\r\nlabour this winter and the panicky state of the financial market,\r\nHurstwood read this with interest. He noted the claims of the striking\r\nmotormen and conductors, who said that they had been wont to receive\r\ntwo dollars a day in times past, but that for a year or more \xe2\x80\x9ctrippers\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nhad been introduced, which cut down their chance of livelihood\r\none-half, and increased their hours of servitude from ten to twelve,\r\nand even fourteen. These \xe2\x80\x9ctrippers\xe2\x80\x9d were men put on during the busy and\r\n_rush_ hours, to take a car out for one trip. The compensation paid for\r\nsuch a trip was only twenty-five cents. When the rush or busy hours\r\nwere over, they were laid off. Worst of all, no man might know when he\r\nwas going to get a car. He must come to the barns in the morning and\r\nwait around in fair and foul weather until such time as he was needed.\r\nTwo trips were an average reward for so much waiting\xe2\x80\x94a little over\r\nthree hours\xe2\x80\x99 work for fifty cents. The work of waiting was not counted.\r\n\r\nThe men complained that this system was extending, and that the time\r\nwas not far off when but a few out of 7,000 employees would have\r\nregular two-dollar-a-day work at all. They demanded that the system be\r\nabolished, and that ten hours be considered a day\xe2\x80\x99s work, barring\r\nunavoidable delays, with $2.25 pay. They demanded immediate acceptance\r\nof these terms, which the various trolley companies refused.\r\n\r\nHurstwood at first sympathised with the demands of these men\xe2\x80\x94indeed, it\r\nis a question whether he did not always sympathise with them to the\r\nend, belie him as his actions might. Reading nearly all the news, he\r\nwas attracted first by the scare-heads with which the trouble was noted\r\nin the \xe2\x80\x9cWorld.\xe2\x80\x9d He read it fully\xe2\x80\x94the names of the seven companies\r\ninvolved, the number of men.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99re foolish to strike in this sort of weather,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought to\r\nhimself. \xe2\x80\x9cLet \xe2\x80\x99em win if they can, though.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe next day there was even a larger notice of it. \xe2\x80\x9cBrooklynites Walk,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid the \xe2\x80\x9cWorld.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cKnights of Labour Tie up the Trolley Lines Across\r\nthe Bridge.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cAbout Seven Thousand Men Out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHurstwood read this, formulating to himself his own idea of what would\r\nbe the outcome. He was a great believer in the strength of\r\ncorporations.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey can\xe2\x80\x99t win,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, concerning the men. \xe2\x80\x9cThey haven\xe2\x80\x99t any money.\r\nThe police will protect the companies. They\xe2\x80\x99ve got to. The public has\r\nto have its cars.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe didn\xe2\x80\x99t sympathise with the corporations, but strength was with them.\r\nSo was property and public utility.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThose fellows can\xe2\x80\x99t win,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought.\r\n\r\nAmong other things, he noticed a circular issued by one of the\r\ncompanies, which read:\r\n\r\n     ATLANTIC AVENUE RAILROAD\r\n\r\n     SPECIAL NOTICE\r\n\r\n\r\n     The motormen and conductors and other employees of this company\r\n     having abruptly left its service, an opportunity is now given to\r\n     all loyal men who have struck against their will to be reinstated,\r\n     providing they will make their applications by twelve o\xe2\x80\x99clock noon\r\n     on Wednesday, January 16th. Such men will be given employment\r\n     (with guaranteed protection) in the order in which such\r\n     applications are received, and runs and positions assigned them\r\n     accordingly.  Otherwise, they will be considered discharged, and\r\n     every vacancy will be filled by a new man as soon as his services\r\n     can be secured.\r\n\r\n     (Signed)\r\n     Benjamin Norton,\r\n     _President._\r\n\r\n\r\nHe also noted among the want ads. one which read:\r\n\r\n     WANTED.\xe2\x80\x9450 skilled motormen, accustomed to Westinghouse system, to\r\n     run U.S. mail cars only, in the City of Brooklyn; protection\r\n     guaranteed.\r\n\r\n\r\nHe noted particularly in each the \xe2\x80\x9cprotection guaranteed.\xe2\x80\x9d It signified\r\nto him the unassailable power of the companies.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99ve got the militia on their side,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought. \xe2\x80\x9cThere isn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nanything those men can do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhile this was still in his mind, the incident with Oeslogge and Carrie\r\noccurred. There had been a good deal to irritate him, but this seemed\r\nmuch the worst. Never before had she accused him of stealing\xe2\x80\x94or very\r\nnear that. She doubted the naturalness of so large a bill. And he had\r\nworked so hard to make expenses seem light. He had been \xe2\x80\x9cdoing\xe2\x80\x9d butcher\r\nand baker in order not to call on her. He had eaten very little\xe2\x80\x94almost\r\nnothing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDamn it all!\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cI can get something. I\xe2\x80\x99m not down yet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe thought that he really must do something now. It was too cheap to\r\nsit around after such an insinuation as this. Why, after a little, he\r\nwould be standing anything.\r\n\r\nHe got up and looked out the window into the chilly street. It came\r\ngradually into his mind, as he stood there, to go to Brooklyn.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy not?\xe2\x80\x9d his mind said. \xe2\x80\x9cAny one can get work over there. You\xe2\x80\x99ll get\r\ntwo a day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow about accidents?\xe2\x80\x9d said a voice. \xe2\x80\x9cYou might get hurt.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, there won\xe2\x80\x99t be much of that,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered. \xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99ve called out the\r\npolice. Any one who wants to run a car will be protected all right.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t know how to run a car,\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined the voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI won\xe2\x80\x99t apply as a motorman,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered. \xe2\x80\x9cI can ring up fares all\r\nright.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99ll want motormen, mostly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99ll take anybody; that I know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFor several hours he argued pro and con with this mental counsellor,\r\nfeeling no need to act at once in a matter so sure of profit.\r\n\r\nIn the morning he put on his best clothes, which were poor enough, and\r\nbegan stirring about, putting some bread and meat into a page of a\r\nnewspaper. Carrie watched him, interested in this new move.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere are you going?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOver to Brooklyn,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered. Then, seeing her still inquisitive, he\r\nadded: \xe2\x80\x9cI think I can get on over there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn the trolley lines?\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, astonished.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d he rejoined.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAren\xe2\x80\x99t you afraid?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat of?\xe2\x80\x9d he answered. \xe2\x80\x9cThe police are protecting them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe paper said four men were hurt yesterday.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d he returned; \xe2\x80\x9cbut you can\xe2\x80\x99t go by what the papers say. They\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nrun the cars all right.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe looked rather determined now, in a desolate sort of way, and Carrie\r\nfelt very sorry. Something of the old Hurstwood was here\xe2\x80\x94the least\r\nshadow of what was once shrewd and pleasant strength. Outside, it was\r\ncloudy and blowing a few flakes of snow.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a day to go over there,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Carrie.\r\n\r\nNow he left before she did, which was a remarkable thing, and tramped\r\neastward to Fourteenth Street and Sixth Avenue, where he took the car.\r\nHe had read that scores of applicants were applying at the office of\r\nthe Brooklyn City Railroad building and were being received. He made\r\nhis way there by horse-car and ferry\xe2\x80\x94a dark, silent man\xe2\x80\x94to the offices\r\nin question. It was a long way, for no cars were running, and the day\r\nwas cold; but he trudged along grimly. Once in Brooklyn, he could\r\nclearly see and feel that a strike was on. People showed it in their\r\nmanner. Along the routes of certain tracks not a car was running. About\r\ncertain corners and nearby saloons small groups of men were lounging.\r\nSeveral spring wagons passed him, equipped with plain wooden chairs,\r\nand labelled \xe2\x80\x9cFlatbush\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cProspect Park. Fare, Ten Cents.\xe2\x80\x9d He noticed\r\ncold and even gloomy faces. Labour was having its little war.\r\n\r\nWhen he came near the office in question, he saw a few men standing\r\nabout, and some policemen. On the far corners were other men\xe2\x80\x94whom he\r\ntook to be strikers\xe2\x80\x94watching. All the houses were small and wooden, the\r\nstreets poorly paved. After New York, Brooklyn looked actually poor and\r\nhard-up.\r\n\r\nHe made his way into the heart of the small group, eyed by policemen\r\nand the men already there. One of the officers addressed him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat are you looking for?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI want to see if I can get a place.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe offices are up those steps,\xe2\x80\x9d said the bluecoat. His face was a\r\nvery neutral thing to contemplate. In his heart of hearts, he\r\nsympathised with the strikers and hated this \xe2\x80\x9cscab.\xe2\x80\x9d In his heart of\r\nhearts, also, he felt the dignity and use of the police force, which\r\ncommanded order. Of its true social significance, he never once\r\ndreamed. His was not the mind for that. The two feelings blended in\r\nhim\xe2\x80\x94neutralised one another and him. He would have fought for this man\r\nas determinedly as for himself, and yet only so far as commanded. Strip\r\nhim of his uniform, and he would have soon picked his side.\r\n\r\nHurstwood ascended a dusty flight of steps and entered a small,\r\ndust-coloured office, in which were a railing, a long desk, and several\r\nclerks.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d said a middle-aged man, looking up at him from the long\r\ndesk.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you want to hire any men?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Hurstwood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat are you\xe2\x80\x94a motorman?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; I\xe2\x80\x99m not anything,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood.\r\n\r\nHe was not at all abashed by his position. He knew these people needed\r\nmen. If one didn\xe2\x80\x99t take him, another would. This man could take him or\r\nleave him, just as he chose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, we prefer experienced men, of course,\xe2\x80\x9d said the man. He paused,\r\nwhile Hurstwood smiled indifferently. Then he added: \xe2\x80\x9cStill, I guess\r\nyou can learn. What is your name?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWheeler,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood.\r\n\r\nThe man wrote an order on a small card. \xe2\x80\x9cTake that to our barns,\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nsaid, \xe2\x80\x9cand give it to the foreman. He\xe2\x80\x99ll show you what to do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHurstwood went down and out. He walked straight away in the direction\r\nindicated, while the policemen looked after.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s another wants to try it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Officer Kiely to Officer Macey.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have my mind he\xe2\x80\x99ll get his fill,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the latter, quietly.\r\n\r\nThey had been in strikes before.\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XLI. THE STRIKE\r\n\r\nThe barn at which Hurstwood applied was exceedingly short-handed, and\r\nwas being operated practically by three men as directors. There were a\r\nlot of green hands around\xe2\x80\x94queer, hungry-looking men, who looked as if\r\nwant had driven them to desperate means. They tried to be lively and\r\nwilling, but there was an air of hang-dog diffidence about the place.\r\n\r\nHurstwood went back through the barns and out into a large, enclosed\r\nlot, where were a series of tracks and loops. A half-dozen cars were\r\nthere, manned by instructors, each with a pupil at the lever. More\r\npupils were waiting at one of the rear doors of the barn.\r\n\r\nIn silence Hurstwood viewed this scene, and waited. His companions took\r\nhis eye for a while, though they did not interest him much more than\r\nthe cars. They were an uncomfortable-looking gang, however. One or two\r\nwere very thin and lean. Several were quite stout. Several others were\r\nrawboned and sallow, as if they had been beaten upon by all sorts of\r\nrough weather.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you see by the paper they are going to call out the militia?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nHurstwood heard one of them remark.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, they\xe2\x80\x99ll do that,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the other. \xe2\x80\x9cThey always do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThink we\xe2\x80\x99re liable to have much trouble?\xe2\x80\x9d said another, whom Hurstwood\r\ndid not see.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot very.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat Scotchman that went out on the last car,\xe2\x80\x9d put in a voice, \xe2\x80\x9ctold\r\nme that they hit him in the ear with a cinder.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA small, nervous laugh accompanied this.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne of those fellows on the Fifth Avenue line must have had a hell of\r\na time, according to the papers,\xe2\x80\x9d drawled another. \xe2\x80\x9cThey broke his car\r\nwindows and pulled him off into the street \xe2\x80\x99fore the police could stop\r\n\xe2\x80\x99em.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; but there are more police around to-day,\xe2\x80\x9d was added by another.\r\n\r\nHurstwood hearkened without much mental comment. These talkers seemed\r\nscared to him. Their gabbling was feverish\xe2\x80\x94things said to quiet their\r\nown minds. He looked out into the yard and waited.\r\n\r\nTwo of the men got around quite near him, but behind his back. They\r\nwere rather social, and he listened to what they said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you a railroad man?\xe2\x80\x9d said one.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMe? No. I\xe2\x80\x99ve always worked in a paper factory.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI had a job in Newark until last October,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the other, with\r\nreciprocal feeling.\r\n\r\nThere were some words which passed too low to hear. Then the\r\nconversation became strong again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t blame these fellers for striking,\xe2\x80\x9d said one. \xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99ve got the\r\nright of it, all right, but I had to get something to do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSame here,\xe2\x80\x9d said the other. \xe2\x80\x9cIf I had any job in Newark I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be\r\nover here takin\xe2\x80\x99 chances like these.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s hell these days, ain\xe2\x80\x99t it?\xe2\x80\x9d said the man. \xe2\x80\x9cA poor man ain\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nnowhere. You could starve, by God, right in the streets, and there\r\nain\xe2\x80\x99t most no one would help you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRight you are,\xe2\x80\x9d said the other. \xe2\x80\x9cThe job I had I lost \xe2\x80\x99cause they shut\r\ndown. They run all summer and lay up a big stock, and then shut down.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHurstwood paid some little attention to this. Somehow, he felt a little\r\nsuperior to these two\xe2\x80\x94a little better off. To him these were ignorant\r\nand commonplace, poor sheep in a driver\xe2\x80\x99s hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor devils,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought, speaking out of the thoughts and feelings of\r\na bygone period of success.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNext,\xe2\x80\x9d said one of the instructors.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re next,\xe2\x80\x9d said a neighbour, touching him.\r\n\r\nHe went out and climbed on the platform. The instructor took it for\r\ngranted that no preliminaries were needed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see this handle,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, reaching up to an electric cut-off,\r\nwhich was fastened to the roof. \xe2\x80\x9cThis throws the current off or on. If\r\nyou want to reverse the car you turn it over here. If you want to send\r\nit forward, you put it over here. If you want to cut off the power, you\r\nkeep it in the middle.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHurstwood smiled at the simple information.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, this handle here regulates your speed. To here,\xe2\x80\x9d he said,\r\npointing with his finger, \xe2\x80\x9cgives you about four miles an hour. This is\r\neight. When it\xe2\x80\x99s full on, you make about fourteen miles an hour.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHurstwood watched him calmly. He had seen motormen work before. He knew\r\njust about how they did it, and was sure he could do as well, with a\r\nvery little practice.\r\n\r\nThe instructor explained a few more details, and then said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, we\xe2\x80\x99ll back her up.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHurstwood stood placidly by, while the car rolled back into the yard.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne thing you want to be careful about, and that is to start easy.\r\nGive one degree time to act before you start another. The one fault of\r\nmost men is that they always want to throw her wide open. That\xe2\x80\x99s bad.\r\nIt\xe2\x80\x99s dangerous, too. Wears out the motor. You don\xe2\x80\x99t want to do that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI see,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood.\r\n\r\nHe waited and waited, while the man talked on.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow you take it,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, finally.\r\n\r\nThe ex-manager laid hand to the lever and pushed it gently, as he\r\nthought. It worked much easier than he imagined, however, with the\r\nresult that the car jerked quickly forward, throwing him back against\r\nthe door. He straightened up sheepishly, while the instructor stopped\r\nthe car with the brake.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou want to be careful about that,\xe2\x80\x9d was all he said.\r\n\r\nHurstwood found, however, that handling a brake and regulating speed\r\nwere not so instantly mastered as he had imagined. Once or twice he\r\nwould have ploughed through the rear fence if it had not been for the\r\nhand and word of his companion. The latter was rather patient with him,\r\nbut he never smiled.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ve got to get the knack of working both arms at once,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt takes a little practice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOne o\xe2\x80\x99clock came while he was still on the car practising, and he began\r\nto feel hungry. The day set in snowing, and he was cold. He grew weary\r\nof running to and fro on the short track.\r\n\r\nThey ran the car to the end and both got off. Hurstwood went into the\r\nbarn and sought a car step, pulling out his paper-wrapped lunch from\r\nhis pocket. There was no water and the bread was dry, but he enjoyed\r\nit. There was no ceremony about dining. He swallowed and looked about,\r\ncontemplating the dull, homely labour of the thing. It was\r\ndisagreeable\xe2\x80\x94miserably disagreeable\xe2\x80\x94in all its phases. Not because it\r\nwas bitter, but because it was hard. It would be hard to any one, he\r\nthought.\r\n\r\nAfter eating, he stood about as before, waiting until his turn came.\r\n\r\nThe intention was to give him an afternoon of practice, but the greater\r\npart of the time was spent in waiting about.\r\n\r\nAt last evening came, and with it hunger and a debate with himself as\r\nto how he should spend the night. It was half-past five. He must soon\r\neat. If he tried to go home, it would take him two hours and a half of\r\ncold walking and riding. Besides he had orders to report at seven the\r\nnext morning, and going home would necessitate his rising at an unholy\r\nand disagreeable hour. He had only something like a dollar and fifteen\r\ncents of Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s money, with which he had intended to pay the two\r\nweeks\xe2\x80\x99 coal bill before the present idea struck him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey must have some place around here,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought. \xe2\x80\x9cWhere does that\r\nfellow from Newark stay?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFinally he decided to ask. There was a young fellow standing near one\r\nof the doors in the cold, waiting a last turn. He was a mere boy in\r\nyears\xe2\x80\x94twenty-one about\xe2\x80\x94but with a body lank and long, because of\r\nprivation. A little good living would have made this youth plump and\r\nswaggering.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow do they arrange this, if a man hasn\xe2\x80\x99t any money?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired\r\nHurstwood, discreetly.\r\n\r\nThe fellow turned a keen, watchful face on the inquirer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou mean eat?\xe2\x80\x9d he replied.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, and sleep. I can\xe2\x80\x99t go back to New York to-night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe foreman \xe2\x80\x99ll fix that if you ask him, I guess. He did me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. I just told him I didn\xe2\x80\x99t have anything. Gee, I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t go home.\r\nI live way over in Hoboken.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHurstwood only cleared his throat by way of acknowledgment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99ve got a place upstairs here, I understand. I don\xe2\x80\x99t know what\r\nsort of a thing it is. Purty tough, I guess. He gave me a meal ticket\r\nthis noon. I know that wasn\xe2\x80\x99t much.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHurstwood smiled grimly, and the boy laughed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt ain\xe2\x80\x99t no fun, is it?\xe2\x80\x9d he inquired, wishing vainly for a cheery\r\nreply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot much,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Hurstwood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d tackle him now,\xe2\x80\x9d volunteered the youth. \xe2\x80\x9cHe may go \xe2\x80\x99way.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHurstwood did so.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIsn\xe2\x80\x99t there some place I can stay around here to-night?\xe2\x80\x9d he inquired.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I have to go back to New York, I\xe2\x80\x99m afraid I won\xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99re some cots upstairs,\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted the man, \xe2\x80\x9cif you want one of\r\nthem.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99ll do,\xe2\x80\x9d he assented.\r\n\r\nHe meant to ask for a meal ticket, but the seemingly proper moment\r\nnever came, and he decided to pay himself that night.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll ask him in the morning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe ate in a cheap restaurant in the vicinity, and, being cold and\r\nlonely, went straight off to seek the loft in question. The company was\r\nnot attempting to run cars after nightfall. It was so advised by the\r\npolice.\r\n\r\nThe room seemed to have been a lounging place for night workers. There\r\nwere some nine cots in the place, two or three wooden chairs, a soap\r\nbox, and a small, round-bellied stove, in which a fire was blazing.\r\nEarly as he was, another man was there before him. The latter was\r\nsitting beside the stove warming his hands.\r\n\r\nHurstwood approached and held out his own toward the fire. He was sick\r\nof the bareness and privation of all things connected with his venture,\r\nbut was steeling himself to hold out. He fancied he could for a while.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCold, isn\xe2\x80\x99t it?\xe2\x80\x9d said the early guest.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRather.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA long silence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot much of a place to sleep in, is it?\xe2\x80\x9d said the man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBetter than nothing,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Hurstwood.\r\n\r\nAnother silence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI believe I\xe2\x80\x99ll turn in,\xe2\x80\x9d said the man.\r\n\r\nRising, he went to one of the cots and stretched himself, removing only\r\nhis shoes, and pulling the one blanket and dirty old comforter over him\r\nin a sort of bundle. The sight disgusted Hurstwood, but he did not\r\ndwell on it, choosing to gaze into the stove and think of something\r\nelse. Presently he decided to retire, and picked a cot, also removing\r\nhis shoes.\r\n\r\nWhile he was doing so, the youth who had advised him to come here\r\nentered, and, seeing Hurstwood, tried to be genial.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBetter\xe2\x80\x99n nothin\xe2\x80\x99,\xe2\x80\x9d he observed, looking around.\r\n\r\nHurstwood did not take this to himself. He thought it to be an\r\nexpression of individual satisfaction, and so did not answer. The youth\r\nimagined he was out of sorts, and set to whistling softly. Seeing\r\nanother man asleep, he quit that and lapsed into silence.\r\n\r\nHurstwood made the best of a bad lot by keeping on his clothes and\r\npushing away the dirty covering from his head, but at last he dozed in\r\nsheer weariness. The covering became more and more comfortable, its\r\ncharacter was forgotten, and he pulled it about his neck and slept. In\r\nthe morning he was aroused out of a pleasant dream by several men\r\nstirring about in the cold, cheerless room. He had been back in Chicago\r\nin fancy, in his own comfortable home. Jessica had been arranging to go\r\nsomewhere, and he had been talking with her about it. This was so clear\r\nin his mind, that he was startled now by the contrast of this room. He\r\nraised his head, and the cold, bitter reality jarred him into\r\nwakefulness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGuess I\xe2\x80\x99d better get up,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\nThere was no water on this floor. He put on his shoes in the cold and\r\nstood up, shaking himself in his stiffness. His clothes felt\r\ndisagreeable, his hair bad.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHell!\xe2\x80\x9d he muttered, as he put on his hat.\r\n\r\nDownstairs things were stirring again.\r\n\r\nHe found a hydrant, with a trough which had once been used for horses,\r\nbut there was no towel here, and his handkerchief was soiled from\r\nyesterday. He contented himself with wetting his eyes with the ice-cold\r\nwater. Then he sought the foreman, who was already on the ground.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHad your breakfast yet?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired that worthy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBetter get it, then; your car won\xe2\x80\x99t be ready for a little while.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHurstwood hesitated.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCould you let me have a meal ticket?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked with an effort.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere you are,\xe2\x80\x9d said the man, handing him one.\r\n\r\nHe breakfasted as poorly as the night before on some fried steak and\r\nbad coffee. Then he went back.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere,\xe2\x80\x9d said the foreman, motioning him, when he came in. \xe2\x80\x9cYou take\r\nthis car out in a few minutes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHurstwood climbed up on the platform in the gloomy barn and waited for\r\na signal. He was nervous, and yet the thing was a relief. Anything was\r\nbetter than the barn.\r\n\r\nOn this the fourth day of the strike, the situation had taken a turn\r\nfor the worse. The strikers, following the counsel of their leaders and\r\nthe newspapers, had struggled peaceably enough. There had been no great\r\nviolence done. Cars had been stopped, it is true, and the men argued\r\nwith. Some crews had been won over and led away, some windows broken,\r\nsome jeering and yelling done; but in no more than five or six\r\ninstances had men been seriously injured. These by crowds whose acts\r\nthe leaders disclaimed.\r\n\r\nIdleness, however, and the sight of the company, backed by the police,\r\ntriumphing, angered the men. They saw that each day more cars were\r\ngoing on, each day more declarations were being made by the company\r\nofficials that the effective opposition of the strikers was broken.\r\nThis put desperate thoughts in the minds of the men. Peaceful methods\r\nmeant, they saw, that the companies would soon run all their cars and\r\nthose who had complained would be forgotten. There was nothing so\r\nhelpful to the companies as peaceful methods. All at once they blazed\r\nforth, and for a week there was storm and stress. Cars were assailed,\r\nmen attacked, policemen struggled with, tracks torn up, and shots\r\nfired, until at last street fights and mob movements became frequent,\r\nand the city was invested with militia.\r\n\r\nHurstwood knew nothing of the change of temper.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRun your car out,\xe2\x80\x9d called the foreman, waving a vigorous hand at him.\r\nA green conductor jumped up behind and rang the bell twice as a signal\r\nto start. Hurstwood turned the lever and ran the car out through the\r\ndoor into the street in front of the barn. Here two brawny policemen\r\ngot up beside him on the platform\xe2\x80\x94one on either hand.\r\n\r\nAt the sound of a gong near the barn door, two bells were given by the\r\nconductor and Hurstwood opened his lever.\r\n\r\nThe two policemen looked about them calmly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x99Tis cold, all right, this morning,\xe2\x80\x9d said the one on the left, who\r\npossessed a rich brogue.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI had enough of it yesterday,\xe2\x80\x9d said the other. \xe2\x80\x9cI wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t want a\r\nsteady job of this.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNor I.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNeither paid the slightest attention to Hurstwood, who stood facing the\r\ncold wind, which was chilling him completely, and thinking of his\r\norders.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cKeep a steady gait,\xe2\x80\x9d the foreman had said. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t stop for any one who\r\ndoesn\xe2\x80\x99t look like a real passenger. Whatever you do, don\xe2\x80\x99t stop for a\r\ncrowd.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe two officers kept silent for a few moments.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe last man must have gone through all right,\xe2\x80\x9d said the officer on\r\nthe left. \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t see his car anywhere.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho\xe2\x80\x99s on there?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the second officer, referring, of course, to\r\nits complement of policemen.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSchaeffer and Ryan.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was another silence, in which the car ran smoothly along. There\r\nwere not so many houses along this part of the way. Hurstwood did not\r\nsee many people either. The situation was not wholly disagreeable to\r\nhim. If he were not so cold, he thought he would do well enough.\r\n\r\nHe was brought out of this feeling by the sudden appearance of a curve\r\nahead, which he had not expected. He shut off the current and did an\r\nenergetic turn at the brake, but not in time to avoid an unnaturally\r\nquick turn. It shook him up and made him feel like making some\r\napologetic remarks, but he refrained.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou want to look out for them things,\xe2\x80\x9d said the officer on the left,\r\ncondescendingly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s right,\xe2\x80\x9d agreed Hurstwood, shamefacedly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s lots of them on this line,\xe2\x80\x9d said the officer on the right.\r\nAround the corner a more populated way appeared. One or two pedestrians\r\nwere in view ahead. A boy coming out of a gate with a tin milk bucket\r\ngave Hurstwood his first objectionable greeting.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cScab!\xe2\x80\x9d he yelled. \xe2\x80\x9cScab!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHurstwood heard it, but tried to make no comment, even to himself. He\r\nknew he would get that, and much more of the same sort, probably.\r\n\r\nAt a corner farther up a man stood by the track and signalled the car\r\nto stop.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever mind him,\xe2\x80\x9d said one of the officers. \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s up to some game.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHurstwood obeyed. At the corner he saw the wisdom of it. No sooner did\r\nthe man perceive the intention to ignore him, than he shook his fist.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, you bloody coward!\xe2\x80\x9d he yelled.\r\n\r\nSome half dozen men, standing on the corner, flung taunts and jeers\r\nafter the speeding car.\r\n\r\nHurstwood winced the least bit. The real thing was slightly worse than\r\nthe thoughts of it had been.\r\n\r\nNow came in sight, three or four blocks farther on, a heap of something\r\non the track.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99ve been at work, here, all right,\xe2\x80\x9d said one of the policemen.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ll have an argument, maybe,\xe2\x80\x9d said the other.\r\n\r\nHurstwood ran the car close and stopped. He had not done so wholly,\r\nhowever, before a crowd gathered about. It was composed of ex-motormen\r\nand conductors in part, with a sprinkling of friends and sympathisers.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome off the car, pardner,\xe2\x80\x9d said one of the men in a voice meant to be\r\nconciliatory. \xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t want to take the bread out of another man\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nmouth, do you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHurstwood held to his brake and lever, pale and very uncertain what to\r\ndo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStand back,\xe2\x80\x9d yelled one of the officers, leaning over the platform\r\nrailing. \xe2\x80\x9cClear out of this, now. Give the man a chance to do his\r\nwork.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen, pardner,\xe2\x80\x9d said the leader, ignoring the policeman and\r\naddressing Hurstwood. \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re all working men, like yourself. If you\r\nwere a regular motorman, and had been treated as we\xe2\x80\x99ve been, you\r\nwouldn\xe2\x80\x99t want any one to come in and take your place, would you? You\r\nwouldn\xe2\x80\x99t want any one to do you out of your chance to get your rights,\r\nwould you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShut her off! shut her off!\xe2\x80\x9d urged the other of the policemen,\r\nroughly. \xe2\x80\x9cGet out of this, now,\xe2\x80\x9d and he jumped the railing and landed\r\nbefore the crowd and began shoving. Instantly the other officer was\r\ndown beside him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStand back, now,\xe2\x80\x9d they yelled. \xe2\x80\x9cGet out of this. What the hell do you\r\nmean? Out, now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was like a small swarm of bees.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t shove me,\xe2\x80\x9d said one of the strikers, determinedly. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m not\r\ndoing anything.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGet out of this!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the officer, swinging his club. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll give ye\r\na bat on the sconce. Back, now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat the hell!\xe2\x80\x9d cried another of the strikers, pushing the other way,\r\nadding at the same time some lusty oaths.\r\n\r\nCrack came an officer\xe2\x80\x99s club on his forehead. He blinked his eyes\r\nblindly a few times, wabbled on his legs, threw up his hands, and\r\nstaggered back. In return, a swift fist landed on the officer\xe2\x80\x99s neck.\r\n\r\nInfuriated by this, the latter plunged left and right, laying about\r\nmadly with his club. He was ably assisted by his brother of the blue,\r\nwho poured ponderous oaths upon the troubled waters. No severe damage\r\nwas done, owing to the agility of the strikers in keeping out of reach.\r\nThey stood about the sidewalk now and jeered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere is the conductor?\xe2\x80\x9d yelled one of the officers, getting his eye\r\non that individual, who had come nervously forward to stand by\r\nHurstwood. The latter had stood gazing upon the scene with more\r\nastonishment than fear.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy don\xe2\x80\x99t you come down here and get these stones off the track?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\ninquired the officer. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat you standing there for? Do you want to stay\r\nhere all day? Get down.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHurstwood breathed heavily in excitement and jumped down with the\r\nnervous conductor as if he had been called.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHurry up, now,\xe2\x80\x9d said the other policeman.\r\n\r\nCold as it was, these officers were hot and mad. Hurstwood worked with\r\nthe conductor, lifting stone after stone and warming himself by the\r\nwork.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, you scab, you!\xe2\x80\x9d yelled the crowd. \xe2\x80\x9cYou coward! Steal a man\xe2\x80\x99s job,\r\nwill you? Rob the poor, will you, you thief? We\xe2\x80\x99ll get you yet, now.\r\nWait.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNot all of this was delivered by one man. It came from here and there,\r\nincorporated with much more of the same sort and curses.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWork, you blackguards,\xe2\x80\x9d yelled a voice. \xe2\x80\x9cDo the dirty work. You\xe2\x80\x99re the\r\nsuckers that keep the poor people down!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMay God starve ye yet,\xe2\x80\x9d yelled an old Irish woman, who now threw open\r\na nearby window and stuck out her head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, and you,\xe2\x80\x9d she added, catching the eye of one of the policemen.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou bloody, murtherin\xe2\x80\x99 thafe! Crack my son over the head, will you,\r\nyou hardhearted, murtherin\xe2\x80\x99 divil? Ah, ye\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut the officer turned a deaf ear.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo to the devil, you old hag,\xe2\x80\x9d he half muttered as he stared round\r\nupon the scattered company.\r\n\r\nNow the stones were off, and Hurstwood took his place again amid a\r\ncontinued chorus of epithets. Both officers got up beside him and the\r\nconductor rang the bell, when, bang! bang! through window and door came\r\nrocks and stones. One narrowly grazed Hurstwood\xe2\x80\x99s head. Another\r\nshattered the window behind.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThrow open your lever,\xe2\x80\x9d yelled one of the officers, grabbing at the\r\nhandle himself.\r\n\r\nHurstwood complied and the car shot away, followed by a rattle of\r\nstones and a rain of curses.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94 hit me in the neck,\xe2\x80\x9d said one of the officers. \xe2\x80\x9cI gave\r\nhim a good crack for it, though.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think I must have left spots on some of them,\xe2\x80\x9d said the other.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know that big guy that called us a \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d said the first. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nget him yet for that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thought we were in for it sure, once there,\xe2\x80\x9d said the second.\r\n\r\nHurstwood, warmed and excited, gazed steadily ahead. It was an\r\nastonishing experience for him. He had read of these things, but the\r\nreality seemed something altogether new. He was no coward in spirit.\r\nThe fact that he had suffered this much now rather operated to arouse a\r\nstolid determination to stick it out. He did not recur in thought to\r\nNew York or the flat. This one trip seemed a consuming thing.\r\n\r\nThey now ran into the business heart of Brooklyn uninterrupted. People\r\ngazed at the broken windows of the car and at Hurstwood in his plain\r\nclothes. Voices called \xe2\x80\x9cscab\xe2\x80\x9d now and then, as well as other epithets,\r\nbut no crowd attacked the car. At the downtown end of the line, one of\r\nthe officers went to call up his station and report the trouble.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s a gang out there,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9claying for us yet. Better send\r\nsome one over there and clean them out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe car ran back more quietly\xe2\x80\x94hooted, watched, flung at, but not\r\nattacked. Hurstwood breathed freely when he saw the barns.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d he observed to himself, \xe2\x80\x9cI came out of that all right.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe car was turned in and he was allowed to loaf a while, but later he\r\nwas again called. This time a new team of officers was aboard. Slightly\r\nmore confident, he sped the car along the commonplace streets and felt\r\nsomewhat less fearful. On one side, however, he suffered intensely. The\r\nday was raw, with a sprinkling of snow and a gusty wind, made all the\r\nmore intolerable by the speed of the car. His clothing was not intended\r\nfor this sort of work. He shivered, stamped his feet, and beat his arms\r\nas he had seen other motormen do in the past, but said nothing. The\r\nnovelty and danger of the situation modified in a way his disgust and\r\ndistress at being compelled to be here, but not enough to prevent him\r\nfrom feeling grim and sour. This was a dog\xe2\x80\x99s life, he thought. It was a\r\ntough thing to have to come to.\r\n\r\nThe one thought that strengthened him was the insult offered by Carrie.\r\nHe was not down so low as to take all that, he thought. He could do\r\nsomething\xe2\x80\x94this, even\xe2\x80\x94for a while. It would get better. He would save a\r\nlittle.\r\n\r\nA boy threw a clod of mud while he was thus reflecting and hit him upon\r\nthe arm. It hurt sharply and angered him more than he had been any time\r\nsince morning.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe little cur!\xe2\x80\x9d he muttered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHurt you?\xe2\x80\x9d asked one of the policemen.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered.\r\n\r\nAt one of the corners, where the car slowed up because of a turn, an\r\nex-motorman, standing on the sidewalk, called to him:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWon\xe2\x80\x99t you come out, pardner, and be a man? Remember we\xe2\x80\x99re fighting for\r\ndecent day\xe2\x80\x99s wages, that\xe2\x80\x99s all. We\xe2\x80\x99ve got families to support.\xe2\x80\x9d The man\r\nseemed most peaceably inclined.\r\n\r\nHurstwood pretended not to see him. He kept his eyes straight on before\r\nand opened the lever wide. The voice had something appealing in it.\r\n\r\nAll morning this went on and long into the afternoon. He made three\r\nsuch trips. The dinner he had was no stay for such work and the cold\r\nwas telling on him. At each end of the line he stopped to thaw out, but\r\nhe could have groaned at the anguish of it. One of the barnmen, out of\r\npity, loaned him a heavy cap and a pair of sheepskin gloves, and for\r\nonce he was extremely thankful.\r\n\r\nOn the second trip of the afternoon he ran into a crowd about half way\r\nalong the line, that had blocked the car\xe2\x80\x99s progress with an old\r\ntelegraph pole.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGet that thing off the track,\xe2\x80\x9d shouted the two policemen.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYah, yah, yah!\xe2\x80\x9d yelled the crowd. \xe2\x80\x9cGet it off yourself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe two policemen got down and Hurstwood started to follow.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou stay there,\xe2\x80\x9d one called. \xe2\x80\x9cSome one will run away with your car.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAmid the babel of voices, Hurstwood heard one close beside him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome down, pardner, and be a man. Don\xe2\x80\x99t fight the poor. Leave that to\r\nthe corporations.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe saw the same fellow who had called to him from the corner. Now, as\r\nbefore, he pretended not to hear him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome down,\xe2\x80\x9d the man repeated gently. \xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t want to fight poor\r\nmen. Don\xe2\x80\x99t fight at all.\xe2\x80\x9d It was a most philosophic and jesuitical\r\nmotorman.\r\n\r\nA third policeman joined the other two from somewhere and some one ran\r\nto telephone for more officers. Hurstwood gazed about, determined but\r\nfearful.\r\n\r\nA man grabbed him by the coat.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome off of that,\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed, jerking at him and trying to pull him\r\nover the railing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet go,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood, savagely.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll show you\xe2\x80\x94you scab!\xe2\x80\x9d cried a young Irishman, jumping up on the car\r\nand aiming a blow at Hurstwood. The latter ducked and caught it on the\r\nshoulder instead of the jaw.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAway from here,\xe2\x80\x9d shouted an officer, hastening to the rescue, and\r\nadding, of course, the usual oaths.\r\n\r\nHurstwood recovered himself, pale and trembling. It was becoming\r\nserious with him now. People were looking up and jeering at him. One\r\ngirl was making faces.\r\n\r\nHe began to waver in his resolution, when a patrol wagon rolled up and\r\nmore officers dismounted. Now the track was quickly cleared and the\r\nrelease effected.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet her go now, quick,\xe2\x80\x9d said the officer, and again he was off.\r\n\r\nThe end came with a real mob, which met the car on its return trip a\r\nmile or two from the barns. It was an exceedingly poor-looking\r\nneighbourhood. He wanted to run fast through it, but again the track\r\nwas blocked. He saw men carrying something out to it when he was yet a\r\nhalf-dozen blocks away.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere they are again!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed one policeman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll give them something this time,\xe2\x80\x9d said the second officer, whose\r\npatience was becoming worn. Hurstwood suffered a qualm of body as the\r\ncar rolled up. As before, the crowd began hooting, but now, rather than\r\ncome near, they threw things. One or two windows were smashed and\r\nHurstwood dodged a stone.\r\n\r\nBoth policemen ran out toward the crowd, but the latter replied by\r\nrunning toward the car. A woman\xe2\x80\x94a mere girl in appearance\xe2\x80\x94was among\r\nthese, bearing a rough stick. She was exceedingly wrathful and struck\r\nat Hurstwood, who dodged. Thereupon, her companions, duly encouraged,\r\njumped on the car and pulled Hurstwood over. He had hardly time to\r\nspeak or shout before he fell.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet go of me,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, falling on his side.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, you sucker,\xe2\x80\x9d he heard some one say. Kicks and blows rained on him.\r\nHe seemed to be suffocating. Then two men seemed to be dragging him off\r\nand he wrestled for freedom.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet up,\xe2\x80\x9d said a voice, \xe2\x80\x9cyou\xe2\x80\x99re all right. Stand up.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe was let loose and recovered himself. Now he recognised two officers.\r\nHe felt as if he would faint from exhaustion. Something was wet on his\r\nchin. He put up his hand and felt, then looked. It was red.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey cut me,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, foolishly, fishing for his handkerchief.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, now,\xe2\x80\x9d said one of the officers. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s only a scratch.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHis senses became cleared now and he looked around. He was standing in\r\na little store, where they left him for the moment. Outside, he could\r\nsee, as he stood wiping his chin, the car and the excited crowd. A\r\npatrol wagon was there, and another.\r\n\r\nHe walked over and looked out. It was an ambulance, backing in.\r\n\r\nHe saw some energetic charging by the police and arrests being made.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome on, now, if you want to take your car,\xe2\x80\x9d said an officer, opening\r\nthe door and looking in. He walked out, feeling rather uncertain of\r\nhimself. He was very cold and frightened.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere\xe2\x80\x99s the conductor?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, he\xe2\x80\x99s not here now,\xe2\x80\x9d said the policeman.\r\n\r\nHurstwood went toward the car and stepped nervously on. As he did so\r\nthere was a pistol shot. Something stung his shoulder.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho fired that?\xe2\x80\x9d he heard an officer exclaim. \xe2\x80\x9cBy God! who did that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nBoth left him, running toward a certain building. He paused a moment\r\nand then got down.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGeorge!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Hurstwood, weakly, \xe2\x80\x9cthis is too much for me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe walked nervously to the corner and hurried down a side street.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhew!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, drawing in his breath.\r\n\r\nA half block away, a small girl gazed at him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99d better sneak,\xe2\x80\x9d she called.\r\n\r\nHe walked homeward in a blinding snowstorm, reaching the ferry by dusk.\r\nThe cabins were filled with comfortable souls, who studied him\r\ncuriously. His head was still in such a whirl that he felt confused.\r\nAll the wonder of the twinkling lights of the river in a white storm\r\npassed for nothing. He trudged doggedly on until he reached the flat.\r\nThere he entered and found the room warm. Carrie was gone. A couple of\r\nevening papers were lying on the table where she left them. He lit the\r\ngas and sat down. Then he got up and stripped to examine his shoulder.\r\nIt was a mere scratch. He washed his hands and face, still in a brown\r\nstudy, apparently, and combed his hair. Then he looked for something to\r\neat, and finally, his hunger gone, sat down in his comfortable\r\nrocking-chair. It was a wonderful relief.\r\n\r\nHe put his hand to his chin, forgetting, for the moment, the papers.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, after a time, his nature recovering itself, \xe2\x80\x9cthat\xe2\x80\x99s a\r\npretty tough game over there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen he turned and saw the papers. With half a sigh he picked up the\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWorld.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStrike Spreading in Brooklyn,\xe2\x80\x9d he read. \xe2\x80\x9cRioting Breaks Out in all\r\nParts of the City.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe adjusted his paper very comfortably and continued. It was the one\r\nthing he read with absorbing interest.\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XLII. A TOUCH OF SPRING: THE EMPTY SHELL\r\n\r\nThose who look upon Hurstwood\xe2\x80\x99s Brooklyn venture as an error of\r\njudgment will none the less realise the negative influence on him of\r\nthe fact that he had tried and failed. Carrie got a wrong idea of it.\r\nHe said so little that she imagined he had encountered nothing worse\r\nthan the ordinary roughness\xe2\x80\x94quitting so soon in the face of this seemed\r\ntrifling. He did not want to work.\r\n\r\nShe was now one of a group of oriental beauties who, in the second act\r\nof the comic opera, were paraded by the vizier before the new potentate\r\nas the treasures of his harem. There was no word assigned to any of\r\nthem, but on the evening when Hurstwood was housing himself in the loft\r\nof the street-car barn, the leading comedian and star, feeling\r\nexceedingly facetious, said in a profound voice, which created a ripple\r\nof laughter:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, who are you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt merely happened to be Carrie who was courtesying before him. It\r\nmight as well have been any of the others, so far as he was concerned.\r\nHe expected no answer and a dull one would have been reproved. But\r\nCarrie, whose experience and belief in herself gave her daring,\r\ncourtesied sweetly again and answered:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am yours truly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was a trivial thing to say, and yet something in the way she did it\r\ncaught the audience, which laughed heartily at the mock-fierce\r\npotentate towering before the young woman. The comedian also liked it,\r\nhearing the laughter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thought your name was Smith,\xe2\x80\x9d he returned, endeavouring to get the\r\nlast laugh.\r\n\r\nCarrie almost trembled for her daring after she had said this. All\r\nmembers of the company had been warned that to interpolate lines or\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cbusiness\xe2\x80\x9d meant a fine or worse. She did not know what to think.\r\n\r\nAs she was standing in her proper position in the wings, awaiting\r\nanother entry, the great comedian made his exit past her and paused in\r\nrecognition.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou can just leave that in hereafter,\xe2\x80\x9d he remarked, seeing how\r\nintelligent she appeared. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t add any more, though.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, humbly. When he went on she found herself\r\ntrembling violently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you\xe2\x80\x99re in luck,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked another member of the chorus. \xe2\x80\x9cThere\r\nisn\xe2\x80\x99t another one of us has got a line.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was no gainsaying the value of this. Everybody in the company\r\nrealised that she had got a start. Carrie hugged herself when next\r\nevening the lines got the same applause. She went home rejoicing,\r\nknowing that soon something must come of it. It was Hurstwood who, by\r\nhis presence, caused her merry thoughts to flee and replaced them with\r\nsharp longings for an end of distress.\r\n\r\nThe next day she asked him about his venture.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99re not trying to run any cars except with police. They don\xe2\x80\x99t want\r\nanybody just now\xe2\x80\x94not before next week.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNext week came, but Carrie saw no change. Hurstwood seemed more\r\napathetic than ever. He saw her off mornings to rehearsals and the like\r\nwith the utmost calm. He read and read. Several times he found himself\r\nstaring at an item, but thinking of something else. The first of these\r\nlapses that he sharply noticed concerned a hilarious party he had once\r\nattended at a driving club, of which he had been a member. He sat,\r\ngazing downward, and gradually thought he heard the old voices and the\r\nclink of glasses.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re a dandy, Hurstwood,\xe2\x80\x9d his friend Walker said. He was standing\r\nagain well dressed, smiling, good-natured, the recipient of encores for\r\na good story.\r\n\r\nAll at once he looked up. The room was so still it seemed ghostlike. He\r\nheard the clock ticking audibly and half suspected that he had been\r\ndozing. The paper was so straight in his hands, however, and the items\r\nhe had been reading so directly before him, that he rid himself of the\r\ndoze idea. Still, it seemed peculiar. When it occurred a second time,\r\nhowever, it did not seem quite so strange.\r\n\r\nButcher and grocery man, baker and coal man\xe2\x80\x94not the group with whom he\r\nwas then dealing, but those who had trusted him to the limit\xe2\x80\x94called. He\r\nmet them all blandly, becoming deft in excuse. At last he became bold,\r\npretended to be out, or waved them off.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey can\xe2\x80\x99t get blood out of a turnip,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cif I had it I\xe2\x80\x99d pay\r\nthem.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie\xe2\x80\x99s little soldier friend, Miss Osborne, seeing her succeeding,\r\nhad become a sort of satellite. Little Osborne could never of herself\r\namount to anything. She seemed to realise it in a sort of pussy-like\r\nway and instinctively concluded to cling with her soft little claws to\r\nCarrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, you\xe2\x80\x99ll get up,\xe2\x80\x9d she kept telling Carrie with admiration. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re\r\nso good.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTimid as Carrie was, she was strong in capability. The reliance of\r\nothers made her feel as if she must, and when she must she dared.\r\nExperience of the world and of necessity was in her favour. No longer\r\nthe lightest word of a man made her head dizzy. She had learned that\r\nmen could change and fail. Flattery in its most palpable form had lost\r\nits force with her. It required superiority\xe2\x80\x94kindly superiority\xe2\x80\x94to move\r\nher\xe2\x80\x94the superiority of a genius like Ames.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t like the actors in our company,\xe2\x80\x9d she told Lola one day.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99re all so struck on themselves.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t you think Mr. Barclay\xe2\x80\x99s pretty nice?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Lola, who had\r\nreceived a condescending smile or two from that quarter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, he\xe2\x80\x99s nice enough,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Carrie; \xe2\x80\x9cbut he isn\xe2\x80\x99t sincere. He\r\nassumes such an air.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLola felt for her first hold upon Carrie in the following manner:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you paying room-rent where you are?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Carrie. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know where I could get the loveliest room and bath, cheap. It\xe2\x80\x99s too\r\nbig for me, but it would be just right for two, and the rent is only\r\nsix dollars a week for both.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere?\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn Seventeenth Street.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know as I\xe2\x80\x99d care to change,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, who was\r\nalready turning over the three-dollar rate in her mind. She was\r\nthinking if she had only herself to support this would leave her\r\nseventeen for herself.\r\n\r\nNothing came of this until after the Brooklyn adventure of Hurstwood\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nand her success with the speaking part. Then she began to feel as if\r\nshe must be free. She thought of leaving Hurstwood and thus making him\r\nact for himself, but he had developed such peculiar traits she feared\r\nhe might resist any effort to throw him off. He might hunt her out at\r\nthe show and hound her in that way. She did not wholly believe that he\r\nwould, but he might. This, she knew, would be an embarrassing thing if\r\nhe made himself conspicuous in any way. It troubled her greatly.\r\n\r\nThings were precipitated by the offer of a better part. One of the\r\nactresses playing the part of a modest sweetheart gave notice of\r\nleaving and Carrie was selected.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow much are you going to get?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Miss Osborne, on hearing the\r\ngood news.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI didn\xe2\x80\x99t ask him,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, find out. Goodness, you\xe2\x80\x99ll never get anything if you don\xe2\x80\x99t ask.\r\nTell them you must have forty dollars, anyhow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Lola. \xe2\x80\x9cAsk \xe2\x80\x99em, anyway.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie succumbed to this prompting, waiting, however, until the manager\r\ngave her notice of what clothing she must have to fit the part.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow much do I get?\xe2\x80\x9d she inquired.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThirty-five dollars,\xe2\x80\x9d he replied.\r\n\r\nCarrie was too much astonished and delighted to think of mentioning\r\nforty. She was nearly beside herself, and almost hugged Lola, who clung\r\nto her at the news.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt isn\xe2\x80\x99t as much as you ought to get,\xe2\x80\x9d said the latter, \xe2\x80\x9cespecially\r\nwhen you\xe2\x80\x99ve got to buy clothes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie remembered this with a start. Where to get the money? She had\r\nnone laid up for such an emergency. Rent day was drawing near.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll not do it,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, remembering her necessity. \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t use the\r\nflat. I\xe2\x80\x99m not going to give up my money this time. I\xe2\x80\x99ll move.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFitting into this came another appeal from Miss Osborne, more urgent\r\nthan ever.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome live with me, won\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x9d she pleaded. \xe2\x80\x9cWe can have the loveliest\r\nroom.
