It was fostered by the\r\ndemands of creditors and the impossibility of holding up many more.\r\nTwenty-eight dollars was too much for rent. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s hard on her,\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nthought. \xe2\x80\x9cWe could get a cheaper place.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nStirred with this idea, he spoke at the breakfast table.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t you think we pay too much rent here?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed I do,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, not catching his drift.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI should think we could get a smaller place,\xe2\x80\x9d he suggested. \xe2\x80\x9cWe don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nneed four rooms.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHer countenance, had he been scrutinising her, would have exhibited the\r\ndisturbance she felt at this evidence of his determination to stay by\r\nher. He saw nothing remarkable in asking her to come down lower.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered, growing wary.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere must be places around here where we could get a couple of rooms,\r\nwhich would do just as well.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHer heart revolted. \xe2\x80\x9cNever!\xe2\x80\x9d she thought. Who would furnish the money\r\nto move? To think of being in two rooms with him! She resolved to spend\r\nher money for clothes quickly, before something terrible happened. That\r\nvery day she did it. Having done so, there was but one other thing to\r\ndo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLola,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, visiting her friend, \xe2\x80\x9cI think I\xe2\x80\x99ll come.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, jolly!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the latter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan we get it right away?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked, meaning the room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Lola.\r\n\r\nThey went to look at it. Carrie had saved ten dollars from her\r\nexpenditures\xe2\x80\x94enough for this and her board beside. Her enlarged salary\r\nwould not begin for ten days yet\xe2\x80\x94would not reach her for seventeen. She\r\npaid half of the six dollars with her friend.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, I\xe2\x80\x99ve just enough to get on to the end of the week,\xe2\x80\x9d she confided.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I\xe2\x80\x99ve got some,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lola. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve got twenty-five dollars, if you\r\nneed it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie. \xe2\x80\x9cI guess I\xe2\x80\x99ll get along.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey decided to move Friday, which was two days away. Now that the\r\nthing was settled, Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s heart misgave her. She felt very much like\r\na criminal in the matter. Each day looking at Hurstwood, she had\r\nrealised that, along with the disagreeableness of his attitude, there\r\nwas something pathetic.\r\n\r\nShe looked at him the same evening she had made up her mind to go, and\r\nnow he seemed not so shiftless and worthless, but run down and beaten\r\nupon by chance. His eyes were not keen, his face marked, his hands\r\nflabby. She thought his hair had a touch of grey. All unconscious of\r\nhis doom, he rocked and read his paper, while she glanced at him.\r\n\r\nKnowing that the end was so near, she became rather solicitous.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill you go over and get some canned peaches?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked Hurstwood,\r\nlaying down a two-dollar bill.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, looking in wonder at the money.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSee if you can get some nice asparagus,\xe2\x80\x9d she added. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll cook it for\r\ndinner.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHurstwood rose and took the money, slipping on his overcoat and getting\r\nhis hat. Carrie noticed that both of these articles of apparel were old\r\nand poor looking in appearance. It was plain enough before, but now it\r\ncame home with peculiar force. Perhaps he couldn\xe2\x80\x99t help it, after all.\r\nHe had done well in Chicago. She remembered his fine appearance the\r\ndays he had met her in the park. Then he was so sprightly, so clean.\r\nHad it been all his fault?\r\n\r\nHe came back and laid the change down with the food.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99d better keep it,\xe2\x80\x9d she observed. \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ll need other things.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, with a sort of pride; \xe2\x80\x9cyou keep it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, go on and keep it,\xe2\x80\x9d she replied, rather unnerved. \xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99ll be\r\nother things.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe wondered at this, not knowing the pathetic figure he had become in\r\nher eyes. She restrained herself with difficulty from showing a quaver\r\nin her voice.\r\n\r\nTo say truly, this would have been Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s attitude in any case. She\r\nhad looked back at times upon her parting from Drouet and had regretted\r\nthat she had served him so badly. She hoped she would never meet him\r\nagain, but she was ashamed of her conduct. Not that she had any choice\r\nin the final separation. She had gone willingly to seek him, with\r\nsympathy in her heart, when Hurstwood had reported him ill. There was\r\nsomething cruel somewhere, and not being able to track it mentally to\r\nits logical lair, she concluded with feeling that he would never\r\nunderstand what Hurstwood had done and would see hard-hearted decision\r\nin her deed; hence her shame. Not that she cared for him. She did not\r\nwant to make any one who had been good to her feel badly.\r\n\r\nShe did not realise what she was doing by allowing these feelings to\r\npossess her. Hurstwood, noticing the kindness, conceived better of her.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCarrie\xe2\x80\x99s good-natured, anyhow,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought.\r\n\r\nGoing to Miss Osborne\xe2\x80\x99s that afternoon, she found that little lady\r\npacking and singing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy don\xe2\x80\x99t you come over with me to-day?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I can\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll be there Friday. Would you mind\r\nlending me the twenty-five dollars you spoke of?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, no,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lola, going for her purse.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI want to get some other things,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, that\xe2\x80\x99s all right,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the little girl, good-naturedly, glad\r\nto be of service. It had been days since Hurstwood had done more than\r\ngo to the grocery or to the news-stand. Now the weariness of indoors\r\nwas upon him\xe2\x80\x94had been for two days\xe2\x80\x94but chill, grey weather had held him\r\nback. Friday broke fair and warm. It was one of those lovely harbingers\r\nof spring, given as a sign in dreary winter that earth is not forsaken\r\nof warmth and beauty. The blue heaven, holding its one golden orb,\r\npoured down a crystal wash of warm light. It was plain, from the voice\r\nof the sparrows, that all was halcyon outside. Carrie raised the front\r\nwindows, and felt the south wind blowing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s lovely out to-day,\xe2\x80\x9d she remarked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it?\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood.\r\n\r\nAfter breakfast, he immediately got his other clothes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill you be back for lunch?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Carrie nervously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\nHe went out into the streets and tramped north, along Seventh Avenue,\r\nidly fixing upon the Harlem River as an objective point. He had seen\r\nsome ships up there, the time he had called upon the brewers. He\r\nwondered how the territory thereabouts was growing.\r\n\r\nPassing Fifty-ninth Street, he took the west side of Central Park,\r\nwhich he followed to Seventy-eighth Street. Then he remembered the\r\nneighbourhood and turned over to look at the mass of buildings erected.\r\nIt was very much improved. The great open spaces were filling up.\r\nComing back, he kept to the Park until 110th Street, and then turned\r\ninto Seventh Avenue again, reaching the pretty river by one o\xe2\x80\x99clock.\r\n\r\nThere it ran winding before his gaze, shining brightly in the clear\r\nlight, between the undulating banks on the right and the tall,\r\ntree-covered heights on the left. The spring-like atmosphere woke him\r\nto a sense of its loveliness, and for a few moments he stood looking at\r\nit, folding his hands behind his back. Then he turned and followed it\r\ntoward the east side, idly seeking the ships he had seen. It was four\r\no\xe2\x80\x99clock before the waning day, with its suggestion of a cooler evening,\r\ncaused him to return. He was hungry and would enjoy eating in the warm\r\nroom.\r\n\r\nWhen he reached the flat by half-past five, it was still dark. He knew\r\nthat Carrie was not there, not only because there was no light showing\r\nthrough the transom, but because the evening papers were stuck between\r\nthe outside knob and the door. He opened with his key and went in.\r\nEverything was still dark. Lighting the gas, he sat down, preparing to\r\nwait a little while. Even if Carrie did come now, dinner would be late.\r\nHe read until six, then got up to fix something for himself.\r\n\r\nAs he did so, he noticed that the room seemed a little queer. What was\r\nit? He looked around, as if he missed something, and then saw an\r\nenvelope near where he had been sitting. It spoke for itself, almost\r\nwithout further action on his part.\r\n\r\nReaching over, he took it, a sort of chill settling upon him even while\r\nhe reached. The crackle of the envelope in his hands was loud. Green\r\npaper money lay soft within the note.\r\n\r\n     \xe2\x80\x9cDear George,\xe2\x80\x9d he read, crunching the money in one hand, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m\r\n     going away. I\xe2\x80\x99m not coming back any more. It\xe2\x80\x99s no use trying to\r\n     keep up the flat; I can\xe2\x80\x99t do it. I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t mind helping you, if I\r\n     could, but I can\xe2\x80\x99t support us both, and pay the rent. I need what\r\n     little I make to pay for my clothes. I\xe2\x80\x99m leaving twenty dollars.\r\n     It\xe2\x80\x99s all I have just now. You can do whatever you like with the\r\n     furniture. I won\xe2\x80\x99t want it.\xe2\x80\x94CARRIE.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nHe dropped the note and looked quietly round. Now he knew what he\r\nmissed. It was the little ornamental clock, which was hers. It had gone\r\nfrom the mantelpiece. He went into the front room, his bedroom, the\r\nparlour, lighting the gas as he went. From the chiffonier had gone the\r\nknick-knacks of silver and plate. From the table-top, the lace\r\ncoverings. He opened the wardrobe\xe2\x80\x94no clothes of hers. He opened the\r\ndrawers\xe2\x80\x94nothing of hers. Her trunk was gone from its accustomed place.\r\nBack in his own room hung his old clothes, just as he had left them.\r\nNothing else was gone.\r\n\r\nHe stepped into the parlour and stood for a few moments looking\r\nvacantly at the floor. The silence grew oppressive. The little flat\r\nseemed wonderfully deserted. He wholly forgot that he was hungry, that\r\nit was only dinner-time. It seemed later in the night.\r\n\r\nSuddenly, he found that the money was still in his hands. There were\r\ntwenty dollars in all, as she had said. Now he walked back, leaving the\r\nlights ablaze, and feeling as if the flat were empty.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll get out of this,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to himself.\r\n\r\nThen the sheer loneliness of his situation rushed upon him in full.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLeft me!\xe2\x80\x9d he muttered, and repeated, \xe2\x80\x9cleft me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe place that had been so comfortable, where he had spent so many days\r\nof warmth, was now a memory. Something colder and chillier confronted\r\nhim. He sank down in his chair, resting his chin in his hand\xe2\x80\x94mere\r\nsensation, without thought, holding him.\r\n\r\nThen something like a bereaved affection and self-pity swept over him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe needn\xe2\x80\x99t have gone away,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d have got something.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe sat a long while without rocking, and added quite clearly, out loud:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI tried, didn\xe2\x80\x99t I?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt midnight he was still rocking, staring at the floor.\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XLIII. THE WORLD TURNS FLATTERER: AN EYE IN THE DARK\r\n\r\nInstalled in her comfortable room, Carrie wondered how Hurstwood had\r\ntaken her departure. She arranged a few things hastily and then left\r\nfor the theatre, half expecting to encounter him at the door. Not\r\nfinding him, her dread lifted, and she felt more kindly toward him. She\r\nquite forgot him until about to come out, after the show, when the\r\nchance of his being there frightened her. As day after day passed and\r\nshe heard nothing at all, the thought of being bothered by him passed.\r\nIn a little while she was, except for occasional thoughts, wholly free\r\nof the gloom with which her life had been weighed in the flat.\r\n\r\nIt is curious to note how quickly a profession absorbs one. Carrie\r\nbecame wise in theatrical lore, hearing the gossip of little Lola. She\r\nlearned what the theatrical papers were, which ones published items\r\nabout actresses and the like. She began to read the newspaper notices,\r\nnot only of the opera in which she had so small a part, but of others.\r\nGradually the desire for notice took hold of her. She longed to be\r\nrenowned like others, and read with avidity all the complimentary or\r\ncritical comments made concerning others high in her profession. The\r\nshowy world in which her interest lay completely absorbed her.\r\n\r\nIt was about this time that the newspapers and magazines were beginning\r\nto pay that illustrative attention to the beauties of the stage which\r\nhas since become fervid. The newspapers, and particularly the Sunday\r\nnewspapers, indulged in large decorative theatrical pages, in which the\r\nfaces and forms of well-known theatrical celebrities appeared, enclosed\r\nwith artistic scrolls. The magazines also or at least one or two of the\r\nnewer ones\xe2\x80\x94published occasional portraits of pretty stars, and now and\r\nagain photos of scenes from various plays. Carrie watched these with\r\ngrowing interest. When would a scene from her opera appear? When would\r\nsome paper think her photo worth while?\r\n\r\nThe Sunday before taking her new part she scanned the theatrical pages\r\nfor some little notice. It would have accorded with her expectations if\r\nnothing had been said, but there in the squibs, tailing off several\r\nmore substantial items, was a wee notice. Carrie read it with a\r\ntingling body:\r\n\r\n     \xe2\x80\x9cThe part of Katisha, the country maid, in \xe2\x80\x98The Wives of Abdul\xe2\x80\x99 at\r\n     the Broadway, heretofore played by Inez Carew, will be hereafter\r\n     filled by Carrie Madenda, one of the cleverest members of the\r\n     chorus.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nCarrie hugged herself with delight. Oh, wasn\xe2\x80\x99t it just fine! At last!\r\nThe first, the long-hoped for, the delightful notice! And they called\r\nher clever. She could hardly restrain herself from laughing loudly. Had\r\nLola seen it?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99ve got a notice here of the part I\xe2\x80\x99m going to play to-morrow\r\nnight,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie to her friend.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, jolly! Have they?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Lola, running to her. \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s all right,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nshe said, looking. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ll get more now, if you do well. I had my\r\npicture in the \xe2\x80\x98World\xe2\x80\x99 once.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid I? Well, I should say,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the little girl. \xe2\x80\x9cThey had a\r\nframe around it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie laughed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99ve never published my picture.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut they will,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lola. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ll see. You do better than most that\r\nget theirs in now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie felt deeply grateful for this. She almost loved Lola for the\r\nsympathy and praise she extended. It was so helpful to her\xe2\x80\x94so almost\r\nnecessary.\r\n\r\nFulfilling her part capably brought another notice in the papers that\r\nshe was doing her work acceptably. This pleased her immensely. She\r\nbegan to think the world was taking note of her.\r\n\r\nThe first week she got her thirty-five dollars, it seemed an enormous\r\nsum. Paying only three dollars for room rent seemed ridiculous. After\r\ngiving Lola her twenty-five, she still had seven dollars left. With\r\nfour left over from previous earnings, she had eleven. Five of this\r\nwent to pay the regular installment on the clothes she had to buy. The\r\nnext week she was even in greater feather. Now, only three dollars need\r\nbe paid for room rent and five on her clothes. The rest she had for\r\nfood and her own whims.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99d better save a little for summer,\xe2\x80\x9d cautioned Lola. \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nprobably close in May.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI intend to,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\nThe regular entrance of thirty-five dollars a week to one who has\r\nendured scant allowances for several years is a demoralising thing.\r\nCarrie found her purse bursting with good green bills of comfortable\r\ndenominations. Having no one dependent upon her, she began to buy\r\npretty clothes and pleasing trinkets, to eat well, and to ornament her\r\nroom. Friends were not long in gathering about. She met a few young men\r\nwho belonged to Lola\xe2\x80\x99s staff. The members of the opera company made her\r\nacquaintance without the formality of introduction. One of these\r\ndiscovered a fancy for her. On several occasions he strolled home with\r\nher.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet\xe2\x80\x99s stop in and have a rarebit,\xe2\x80\x9d he suggested one midnight.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\nIn the rosy restaurant, filled with the merry lovers of late hours, she\r\nfound herself criticising this man. He was too stilted, too\r\nself-opinionated. He did not talk of anything that lifted her above the\r\ncommon run of clothes and material success. When it was all over, he\r\nsmiled most graciously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGot to go straight home, have you?\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered, with an air of quiet understanding.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe\xe2\x80\x99s not so inexperienced as she looks,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought, and thereafter\r\nhis respect and ardour were increased.\r\n\r\nShe could not help sharing in Lola\xe2\x80\x99s love for a good time. There were\r\ndays when they went carriage riding, nights when after the show they\r\ndined, afternoons when they strolled along Broadway, tastefully\r\ndressed. She was getting in the metropolitan whirl of pleasure.\r\n\r\nAt last her picture appeared in one of the weeklies. She had not known\r\nof it, and it took her breath. \xe2\x80\x9cMiss Carrie Madenda,\xe2\x80\x9d it was labelled.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne of the favourites of \xe2\x80\x98The Wives of Abdul\xe2\x80\x99 company.\xe2\x80\x9d At Lola\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nadvice she had had some pictures taken by Sarony. They had got one\r\nthere. She thought of going down and buying a few copies of the paper,\r\nbut remembered that there was no one she knew well enough to send them\r\nto. Only Lola, apparently, in all the world was interested.\r\n\r\nThe metropolis is a cold place socially, and Carrie soon found that a\r\nlittle money brought her nothing. The world of wealth and distinction\r\nwas quite as far away as ever. She could feel that there was no warm,\r\nsympathetic friendship back of the easy merriment with which many\r\napproached her. All seemed to be seeking their own amusement,\r\nregardless of the possible sad consequence to others. So much for the\r\nlessons of Hurstwood and Drouet.\r\n\r\nIn April she learned that the opera would probably last until the\r\nmiddle or the end of May, according to the size of the audiences. Next\r\nseason it would go on the road. She wondered if she would be with it.\r\nAs usual, Miss Osborne, owing to her moderate salary, was for securing\r\na home engagement.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99re putting on a summer play at the Casino,\xe2\x80\x9d she announced, after\r\nfiguratively putting her ear to the ground. \xe2\x80\x9cLet\xe2\x80\x99s try and get in\r\nthat.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m willing,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\nThey tried in time and were apprised of the proper date to apply again.\r\nThat was May 16th. Meanwhile their own show closed May 5th.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThose that want to go with the show next season,\xe2\x80\x9d said the manager,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cwill have to sign this week.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t you sign,\xe2\x80\x9d advised Lola. \xe2\x80\x9cI wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t go.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, \xe2\x80\x9cbut maybe I can\xe2\x80\x99t get anything else.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I won\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d said the little girl, who had a resource in her\r\nadmirers. \xe2\x80\x9cI went once and I didn\xe2\x80\x99t have anything at the end of the\r\nseason.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie thought this over. She had never been on the road.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe can get along,\xe2\x80\x9d added Lola. \xe2\x80\x9cI always have.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie did not sign.\r\n\r\nThe manager who was putting on the summer skit at the Casino had never\r\nheard of Carrie, but the several notices she had received, her\r\npublished picture, and the programme bearing her name had some little\r\nweight with him. He gave her a silent part at thirty dollars a week.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDidn\xe2\x80\x99t I tell you?\xe2\x80\x9d said Lola. \xe2\x80\x9cIt doesn\xe2\x80\x99t do you any good to go away\r\nfrom New York. They forget all about you if you do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNow, because Carrie was pretty, the gentlemen who made up the advance\r\nillustrations of shows about to appear for the Sunday papers selected\r\nCarrie\xe2\x80\x99s photo along with others to illustrate the announcement.\r\nBecause she was very pretty, they gave it excellent space and drew\r\nscrolls about it. Carrie was delighted. Still, the management did not\r\nseem to have seen anything of it. At least, no more attention was paid\r\nto her than before. At the same time there seemed very little in her\r\npart. It consisted of standing around in all sorts of scenes, a silent\r\nlittle Quakeress. The author of the skit had fancied that a great deal\r\ncould be made of such a part, given to the right actress, but now,\r\nsince it had been doled out to Carrie, he would as leave have had it\r\ncut out.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t kick, old man,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked the manager. \xe2\x80\x9cIf it don\xe2\x80\x99t go the first\r\nweek we will cut it out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie had no warning of this halcyon intention. She practised her part\r\nruefully, feeling that she was effectually shelved. At the dress\r\nrehearsal she was disconsolate.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat isn\xe2\x80\x99t so bad,\xe2\x80\x9d said the author, the manager noting the curious\r\neffect which Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s blues had upon the part. \xe2\x80\x9cTell her to frown a\r\nlittle more when Sparks dances.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie did not know it, but there was the least show of wrinkles\r\nbetween her eyes and her mouth was puckered quaintly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrown a little more, Miss Madenda,\xe2\x80\x9d said the stage manager.\r\n\r\nCarrie instantly brightened up, thinking he had meant it as a rebuke.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; frown,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cFrown as you did before.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie looked at him in astonishment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI mean it,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cFrown hard when Mr. Sparks dances. I want to see\r\nhow it looks.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was easy enough to do. Carrie scowled. The effect was something so\r\nquaint and droll it caught even the manager.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is good,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cIf she\xe2\x80\x99ll do that all through, I think it\r\nwill take.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGoing over to Carrie, he said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSuppose you try frowning all through. Do it hard. Look mad. It\xe2\x80\x99ll make\r\nthe part really funny.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOn the opening night it looked to Carrie as if there were nothing to\r\nher part, after all. The happy, sweltering audience did not seem to see\r\nher in the first act. She frowned and frowned, but to no effect. Eyes\r\nwere riveted upon the more elaborate efforts of the stars.\r\n\r\nIn the second act, the crowd, wearied by a dull conversation, roved\r\nwith its eyes about the stage and sighted her. There she was,\r\ngrey-suited, sweet-faced, demure, but scowling. At first the general\r\nidea was that she was temporarily irritated, that the look was genuine\r\nand not fun at all. As she went on frowning, looking now at one\r\nprincipal and now at the other, the audience began to smile. The portly\r\ngentlemen in the front rows began to feel that she was a delicious\r\nlittle morsel. It was the kind of frown they would have loved to force\r\naway with kisses. All the gentlemen yearned toward her. She was\r\ncapital.\r\n\r\nAt last, the chief comedian, singing in the centre of the stage,\r\nnoticed a giggle where it was not expected. Then another and another.\r\nWhen the place came for loud applause it was only moderate. What could\r\nbe the trouble? He realised that something was up.\r\n\r\nAll at once, after an exit, he caught sight of Carrie. She was frowning\r\nalone on the stage and the audience was giggling and laughing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy George, I won\xe2\x80\x99t stand that!\xe2\x80\x9d thought the thespian. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m not going\r\nto have my work cut up by some one else. Either she quits that when I\r\ndo my turn or I quit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, that\xe2\x80\x99s all right,\xe2\x80\x9d said the manager, when the kick came. \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nwhat she\xe2\x80\x99s supposed to do. You needn\xe2\x80\x99t pay any attention to that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut she ruins my work.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, she don\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the former, soothingly. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s only a little\r\nfun on the side.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is, eh?\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the big comedian. \xe2\x80\x9cShe killed my hand all right.\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99m not going to stand that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, wait until after the show. Wait until to-morrow. We\xe2\x80\x99ll see what\r\nwe can do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe next act, however, settled what was to be done. Carrie was the\r\nchief feature of the play. The audience, the more it studied her, the\r\nmore it indicated its delight. Every other feature paled beside the\r\nquaint, teasing, delightful atmosphere which Carrie contributed while\r\non the stage. Manager and company realised she had made a hit.\r\n\r\nThe critics of the daily papers completed her triumph. There were long\r\nnotices in praise of the quality of the burlesque, touched with\r\nrecurrent references to Carrie. The contagious mirth of the thing was\r\nrepeatedly emphasised.\r\n\r\n     \xe2\x80\x9cMiss Madenda presents one of the most delightful bits of\r\n     character work ever seen on the Casino stage,\xe2\x80\x9d observed the stage\r\n     critic of the \xe2\x80\x9cSun.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cIt is a bit of quiet, unassuming drollery\r\n     which warms like good wine. Evidently the part was not intended to\r\n     take precedence, as Miss Madenda is not often on the stage, but\r\n     the audience, with the characteristic perversity of such bodies,\r\n     selected for itself. The little Quakeress was marked for a\r\n     favourite the moment she appeared, and thereafter easily held\r\n     attention and applause. The vagaries of fortune are indeed\r\n     curious.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nThe critic of the \xe2\x80\x9cEvening World,\xe2\x80\x9d seeking as usual to establish a\r\ncatch phrase which should \xe2\x80\x9cgo\xe2\x80\x9d with the town, wound up by advising: \xe2\x80\x9cIf\r\nyou wish to be merry, see Carrie frown.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe result was miraculous so far as Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s fortune was concerned.\r\nEven during the morning she received a congratulatory message from the\r\nmanager.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou seem to have taken the town by storm,\xe2\x80\x9d he wrote. \xe2\x80\x9cThis is\r\ndelightful. I am as glad for your sake as for my own.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe author also sent word.\r\n\r\nThat evening when she entered the theatre the manager had a most\r\npleasant greeting for her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Stevens,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, referring to the author, \xe2\x80\x9cis preparing a little\r\nsong, which he would like you to sing next week.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I can\xe2\x80\x99t sing,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt isn\xe2\x80\x99t anything difficult. \xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s something that is very simple,\xe2\x80\x99 he\r\nsays, \xe2\x80\x98and would suit you exactly.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course, I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t mind trying,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, archly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWould you mind coming to the box-office a few moments before you\r\ndress?\xe2\x80\x9d observed the manager, in addition. \xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s a little matter I\r\nwant to speak to you about.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Carrie.\r\n\r\nIn that latter place the manager produced a paper.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, of course,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cwe want to be fair with you in the matter\r\nof salary. Your contract here only calls for thirty dollars a week for\r\nthe next three months. How would it do to make it, say, one hundred and\r\nfifty a week and extend it for twelve months?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, very well,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, scarcely believing her ears.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSupposing, then, you just sign this.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie looked and beheld a new contract made out like the other one,\r\nwith the exception of the new figures of salary and time. With a hand\r\ntrembling from excitement she affixed her name.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne hundred and fifty a week!\xe2\x80\x9d she murmured, when she was again alone.\r\nShe found, after all\xe2\x80\x94as what millionaire has not?\xe2\x80\x94that there was no\r\nrealising, in consciousness, the meaning of large sums. It was only a\r\nshimmering, glittering phrase in which lay a world of possibilities.\r\n\r\nDown in a third-rate Bleecker Street hotel, the brooding Hurstwood read\r\nthe dramatic item covering Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s success, without at first realising\r\nwho was meant. Then suddenly it came to him and he read the whole thing\r\nover again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s her, all right, I guess,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\nThen he looked about upon a dingy, moth-eaten hotel lobby.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI guess she\xe2\x80\x99s struck it,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought, a picture of the old shiny,\r\nplush-covered world coming back, with its lights, its ornaments, its\r\ncarriages, and flowers. Ah, she was in the walled city now! Its\r\nsplendid gates had opened, admitting her from a cold, dreary outside.\r\nShe seemed a creature afar off\xe2\x80\x94like every other celebrity he had known.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, let her have it,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cI won\xe2\x80\x99t bother her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was the grim resolution of a bent, bedraggled, but unbroken pride.\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XLIV. AND THIS IS NOT ELF LAND: WHAT GOLD WILL NOT BUY\r\n\r\nWhen Carrie got back on the stage, she found that over night her\r\ndressing-room had been changed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are to use this room, Miss Madenda,\xe2\x80\x9d said one of the stage\r\nlackeys.\r\n\r\nNo longer any need of climbing several flights of steps to a small coop\r\nshared with another. Instead, a comparatively large and commodious\r\nchamber with conveniences not enjoyed by the small fry overhead. She\r\nbreathed deeply and with delight. Her sensations were more physical\r\nthan mental. In fact, she was scarcely thinking at all. Heart and body\r\nwere having their say.\r\n\r\nGradually the deference and congratulation gave her a mental\r\nappreciation of her state. She was no longer ordered, but requested,\r\nand that politely. The other members of the cast looked at her\r\nenviously as she came out arrayed in her simple habit, which she wore\r\nall through the play. All those who had supposedly been her equals and\r\nsuperiors now smiled the smile of sociability, as much as to say: \xe2\x80\x9cHow\r\nfriendly we have always been.\xe2\x80\x9d Only the star comedian whose part had\r\nbeen so deeply injured stalked by himself. Figuratively, he could not\r\nkiss the hand that smote him.\r\n\r\nDoing her simple part, Carrie gradually realised the meaning of the\r\napplause which was for her, and it was sweet. She felt mildly guilty of\r\nsomething\xe2\x80\x94perhaps unworthiness. When her associates addressed her in\r\nthe wings she only smiled weakly. The pride and daring of place were\r\nnot for her. It never once crossed her mind to be reserved or\r\nhaughty\xe2\x80\x94to be other than she had been. After the performances she rode\r\nto her room with Lola, in a carriage provided.\r\n\r\nThen came a week in which the first fruits of success were offered to\r\nher lips\xe2\x80\x94bowl after bowl. It did not matter that her splendid salary\r\nhad not begun. The world seemed satisfied with the promise. She began\r\nto get letters and cards. A Mr. Withers\xe2\x80\x94whom she did not know from\r\nAdam\xe2\x80\x94having learned by some hook or crook where she resided, bowed\r\nhimself politely in.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will excuse me for intruding,\xe2\x80\x9d he said; \xe2\x80\x9cbut have you been\r\nthinking of changing your apartments?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hadn\xe2\x80\x99t thought of it,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I am connected with the Wellington\xe2\x80\x94the new hotel on Broadway.\r\nYou have probably seen notices of it in the papers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie recognised the name as standing for one of the newest and most\r\nimposing hostelries. She had heard it spoken of as having a splendid\r\nrestaurant.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJust so,\xe2\x80\x9d went on Mr. Withers, accepting her acknowledgment of\r\nfamiliarity. \xe2\x80\x9cWe have some very elegant rooms at present which we would\r\nlike to have you look at, if you have not made up your mind where you\r\nintend to reside for the summer. Our apartments are perfect in every\r\ndetail\xe2\x80\x94hot and cold water, private baths, special hall service for\r\nevery floor, elevators, and all that. You know what our restaurant is.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie looked at him quietly. She was wondering whether he took her to\r\nbe a millionaire.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat are your rates?\xe2\x80\x9d she inquired.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, now, that is what I came to talk with you privately about. Our\r\nregular rates are anywhere from three to fifty dollars a day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMercy!\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted Carrie. \xe2\x80\x9cI couldn\xe2\x80\x99t pay any such rate as that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know how you feel about it,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Mr. Withers, halting. \xe2\x80\x9cBut\r\njust let me explain. I said those are our regular rates. Like every\r\nother hotel we make special ones however. Possibly you have not thought\r\nabout it, but your name is worth something to us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh!\xe2\x80\x9d ejaculated Carrie, seeing at a glance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course. Every hotel depends upon the repute of its patrons. A\r\nwell-known actress like yourself,\xe2\x80\x9d and he bowed politely, while Carrie\r\nflushed, \xe2\x80\x9cdraws attention to the hotel, and\xe2\x80\x94although you may not\r\nbelieve it\xe2\x80\x94patrons.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Carrie, vacantly, trying to arrange this curious\r\nproposition in her mind.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Mr. Withers, swaying his derby hat softly and beating\r\none of his polished shoes upon the floor, \xe2\x80\x9cI want to arrange, if\r\npossible, to have you come and stop at the Wellington. You need not\r\ntrouble about terms. In fact, we need hardly discuss them. Anything\r\nwill do for the summer\xe2\x80\x94a mere figure\xe2\x80\x94anything that you think you could\r\nafford to pay.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie was about to interrupt, but he gave her no chance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou can come to-day or to-morrow\xe2\x80\x94the earlier the better\xe2\x80\x94and we will\r\ngive you your choice of nice, light, outside rooms\xe2\x80\x94the very best we\r\nhave.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re very kind,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, touched by the agent\xe2\x80\x99s extreme\r\naffability. \xe2\x80\x9cI should like to come very much. I would want to pay what\r\nis right, however. I shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t want to\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou need not trouble about that at all,\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted Mr. Withers. \xe2\x80\x9cWe\r\ncan arrange that to your entire satisfaction at any time. If three\r\ndollars a day is satisfactory to you, it will be so to us. All you have\r\nto do is to pay that sum to the clerk at the end of the week or month,\r\njust as you wish, and he will give you a receipt for what the rooms\r\nwould cost if charged for at our regular rates.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe speaker paused.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSuppose you come and look at the rooms,\xe2\x80\x9d he added.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d be glad to,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I have a rehearsal this morning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI did not mean at once,\xe2\x80\x9d he returned. \xe2\x80\x9cAny time will do. Would this\r\nafternoon be inconvenient?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot at all,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\nSuddenly she remembered Lola, who was out at the time.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have a room-mate,\xe2\x80\x9d she added, \xe2\x80\x9cwho will have to go wherever I do. I\r\nforgot about that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, very well,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Withers, blandly. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is for you to say whom\r\nyou want with you. As I say, all that can be arranged to suit\r\nyourself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe bowed and backed toward the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt four, then, we may expect you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will be there to show you,\xe2\x80\x9d and so Mr. Withers withdrew.\r\n\r\nAfter rehearsal Carrie informed Lola.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid they really?\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the latter, thinking of the Wellington as\r\na group of managers. \xe2\x80\x9cIsn\xe2\x80\x99t that fine? Oh, jolly! It\xe2\x80\x99s so swell. That\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nwhere we dined that night we went with those two Cushing boys. Don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nyou know?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI remember,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, it\xe2\x80\x99s as fine as it can be.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99d better be going up there,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Carrie later in the\r\nafternoon.\r\n\r\nThe rooms which Mr. Withers displayed to Carrie and Lola were three and\r\nbath\xe2\x80\x94a suite on the parlour floor. They were done in chocolate and dark\r\nred, with rugs and hangings to match. Three windows looked down into\r\nbusy Broadway on the east, three into a side street which crossed\r\nthere. There were two lovely bedrooms, set with brass and white enamel\r\nbeds, white ribbon-trimmed chairs and chiffoniers to match. In the\r\nthird room, or parlour, was a piano, a heavy piano lamp, with a shade\r\nof gorgeous pattern, a library table, several huge easy rockers, some\r\ndado book shelves, and a gilt curio case, filled with oddities.\r\nPictures were upon the walls, soft Turkish pillows upon the divan\r\nfootstools of brown plush upon the floor. Such accommodations would\r\nordinarily cost a hundred dollars a week.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, lovely!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Lola, walking about.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is comfortable,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, who was lifting a lace curtain and\r\nlooking down into crowded Broadway.\r\n\r\nThe bath was a handsome affair, done in white enamel, with a large,\r\nblue-bordered stone tub and nickel trimmings. It was bright and\r\ncommodious, with a bevelled mirror set in the wall at one end and\r\nincandescent lights arranged in three places.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you find these satisfactory?\xe2\x80\x9d observed Mr. Withers.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, very,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, any time you find it convenient to move in, they are\r\nready. The boy will bring you the keys at the door.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie noted the elegantly carpeted and decorated hall, the marbled\r\nlobby, and showy waiting-room. It was such a place as she had often\r\ndreamed of occupying.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI guess we\xe2\x80\x99d better move right away, don\xe2\x80\x99t you think so?\xe2\x80\x9d she observed\r\nto Lola, thinking of the commonplace chamber in Seventeenth Street.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, by all means,\xe2\x80\x9d said the latter.\r\n\r\nThe next day her trunks left for the new abode.\r\n\r\nDressing, after the matin\xc3\xa9e on Wednesday, a knock came at her\r\ndressing-room door.\r\n\r\nCarrie looked at the card handed by the boy and suffered a shock of\r\nsurprise.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell her I\xe2\x80\x99ll be right out,\xe2\x80\x9d she said softly. Then, looking at the\r\ncard, added: \xe2\x80\x9cMrs. Vance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, you little sinner,\xe2\x80\x9d the latter exclaimed, as she saw Carrie\r\ncoming toward her across the now vacant stage. \xe2\x80\x9cHow in the world did\r\nthis happen?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie laughed merrily. You would have thought that the long separation had\r\ncome about accidentally.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Carrie, warming, in spite of her first\r\ntroubled feelings, toward this handsome, good-natured young matron.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you know, I saw your picture in the Sunday paper, but your name\r\nthrew me off. I was\r\nalmost afraid to come back here this afternoon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, nonsense,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, blushing. \xe2\x80\x9cYou know I\xe2\x80\x99d be glad to see\r\nyou.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, anyhow, here you are. Can\xe2\x80\x99t you come up and take dinner with me\r\nnow? Where are you stopping?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt the Wellington,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, who permitted herself a touch of\r\npride in the acknowledgment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, are you?\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the other, upon whom the name was not without\r\nits proper effect.\r\n\r\nTactfully, Mrs. Vance avoided the subject of Hurstwood, of whom she\r\ncould not help thinking. No doubt Carrie had left him. That much she\r\nsurmised.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I don\xe2\x80\x99t think I can,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, \xe2\x80\x9cto-night. I have so little\r\ntime. I must be back here by 7.30. Won\xe2\x80\x99t you come and dine with me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d be delighted, but I can\xe2\x80\x99t to-night,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Vance studying\r\nCarrie\xe2\x80\x99s fine appearance. The latter\xe2\x80\x99s good fortune made her seem more\r\nthan ever worthy and delightful in the other\xe2\x80\x99s eyes. \xe2\x80\x9cI promised\r\nfaithfully to be home at six.\xe2\x80\x9d Glancing at the small gold watch pinned\r\nto her bosom, she added: \xe2\x80\x9cI must be going, too.
