I\xe2\x80\x99m living at the Chelsea now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMoved again?\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Carrie, laughing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. You know I can\xe2\x80\x99t stay six months in one place. I just have to\r\nmove. Remember now\xe2\x80\x94half-past five.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI won\xe2\x80\x99t forget,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, casting a glance at her as she went\r\naway. Then it came to her that she was as good as this woman\r\nnow\xe2\x80\x94perhaps better. Something in the other\xe2\x80\x99s solicitude and interest\r\nmade her feel as if she were the one to condescend.\r\n\r\nNow, as on each preceding day, letters were handed her by the doorman\r\nat the Casino. This was a feature which had rapidly developed since\r\nMonday. What they contained she well knew. _Mash notes_ were old\r\naffairs in their mildest form. She remembered having received her first\r\none far back in Columbia City. Since then, as a chorus girl, she had\r\nreceived others\xe2\x80\x94gentlemen who prayed for an engagement. They were\r\ncommon sport between her and Lola, who received some also. They both\r\nfrequently made light of them.\r\n\r\nNow, however, they came thick and fast. Gentlemen with fortunes did not\r\nhesitate to note, as an addition to their own amiable collection of\r\nvirtues, that they had their horses and carriages. Thus one:\r\n\r\n     \xe2\x80\x9cI have a million in my own right. I could give you every luxury.\r\n     There isn\xe2\x80\x99t anything you could ask for that you couldn\xe2\x80\x99t have. I\r\n     say this, not because I want to speak of my money, but because I\r\n     love you and wish to gratify your every desire. It is love that\r\n     prompts me to write. Will you not give me one half-hour in which\r\n     to plead my cause?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nSuch of these letters as came while Carrie was still in the Seventeenth\r\nStreet place were read with more interest\xe2\x80\x94though never delight\xe2\x80\x94than\r\nthose which arrived after she was installed in her luxurious quarters\r\nat the Wellington. Even there her vanity\xe2\x80\x94or that self-appreciation\r\nwhich, in its more rabid form, is called vanity\xe2\x80\x94was not sufficiently\r\ncloyed to make these things wearisome. Adulation, being new in any\r\nform, pleased her. Only she was sufficiently wise to distinguish\r\nbetween her old condition and her new one. She had not had fame or\r\nmoney before. Now they had come. She had not had adulation and\r\naffectionate propositions before. Now they had come. Wherefore? She\r\nsmiled to think that men should suddenly find her so much more\r\nattractive. In the least way it incited her to coolness and\r\nindifference.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo look here,\xe2\x80\x9d she remarked to Lola. \xe2\x80\x9cSee what this man says: \xe2\x80\x98If you\r\nwill only deign to grant me one half-hour,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d she repeated, with an\r\nimitation of languor. \xe2\x80\x9cThe idea. Aren\xe2\x80\x99t men silly?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe must have lots of money, the way he talks,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Lola. \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nwhat they all say,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, innocently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy don\xe2\x80\x99t you see him,\xe2\x80\x9d suggested Lola, \xe2\x80\x9cand hear what he has to say?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed I won\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie. \xe2\x80\x9cI know what he\xe2\x80\x99d say. I don\xe2\x80\x99t want to\r\nmeet anybody that way.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLola looked at her with big, merry eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe couldn\xe2\x80\x99t hurt you,\xe2\x80\x9d she returned. \xe2\x80\x9cYou might have some fun with\r\nhim.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie shook her head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re awfully queer,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the little, blue-eyed soldier.\r\n\r\nThus crowded fortune. For this whole week, though her large salary had\r\nnot yet arrived, it was as if the world understood and trusted her.\r\nWithout money\xe2\x80\x94or the requisite sum, at least\xe2\x80\x94she enjoyed the luxuries\r\nwhich money could buy. For her the doors of fine places seemed to open\r\nquite without the asking. These palatial chambers, how marvellously\r\nthey came to her. The elegant apartments of Mrs. Vance in the\r\nChelsea\xe2\x80\x94these were hers. Men sent flowers, love notes, offers of\r\nfortune. And still her dreams ran riot. The one hundred and fifty! the\r\none hundred and fifty! What a door to an Aladdin\xe2\x80\x99s cave it seemed to\r\nbe. Each day, her head almost turned by developments, her fancies of\r\nwhat her fortune must be, with ample money, grew and multiplied. She\r\nconceived of delights which were not\xe2\x80\x94saw lights of joy that never were\r\non land or sea. Then, at last, after a world of anticipation, came her\r\nfirst installment of one hundred and fifty dollars.\r\n\r\nIt was paid to her in greenbacks\xe2\x80\x94three twenties, six tens, and six\r\nfives. Thus collected it made a very convenient roll. It was\r\naccompanied by a smile and a salutation from the cashier who paid it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d said the latter, when she applied; \xe2\x80\x9cMiss Madenda\xe2\x80\x94one hundred\r\nand fifty dollars. Quite a success the show seems to have made.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, indeed,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Carrie.\r\n\r\nRight after came one of the insignificant members of the company, and\r\nshe heard the changed tone of address.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow much?\xe2\x80\x9d said the same cashier, sharply. One, such as she had only\r\nrecently been, was waiting for her modest salary. It took her back to\r\nthe few weeks in which she had collected\xe2\x80\x94or rather had received\xe2\x80\x94almost\r\nwith the air of a domestic, four-fifty per week from a lordly foreman\r\nin a shoe factory\xe2\x80\x94a man who, in distributing the envelopes, had the\r\nmanner of a prince doling out favours to a servile group of\r\npetitioners. She knew that out in Chicago this very day the same\r\nfactory chamber was full of poor homely-clad girls working in long\r\nlines at clattering machines; that at noon they would eat a miserable\r\nlunch in a half-hour; that Saturday they would gather, as they had when\r\nshe was one of them, and accept the small pay for work a hundred times\r\nharder than she was now doing. Oh, it was so easy now! The world was so\r\nrosy and bright. She felt so thrilled that she must needs walk back to\r\nthe hotel to think, wondering what she should do.\r\n\r\nIt does not take money long to make plain its impotence, providing the\r\ndesires are in the realm of affection. With her one hundred and fifty\r\nin hand, Carrie could think of nothing particularly to do. In itself,\r\nas a tangible, apparent thing which she could touch and look upon, it\r\nwas a diverting thing for a few days, but this soon passed. Her hotel\r\nbill did not require its use. Her clothes had for some time been wholly\r\nsatisfactory. Another day or two and she would receive another hundred\r\nand fifty. It began to appear as if this were not so startlingly\r\nnecessary to maintain her present state. If she wanted to do anything\r\nbetter or move higher she must have more\xe2\x80\x94a great deal more.\r\n\r\nNow a critic called to get up one of those tinsel interviews which\r\nshine with clever observations, show up the wit of critics, display the\r\nfolly of celebrities, and divert the public. He liked Carrie, and said\r\nso, publicly\xe2\x80\x94adding, however, that she was merely pretty, good-natured,\r\nand lucky. This cut like a knife. The \xe2\x80\x9cHerald,\xe2\x80\x9d getting up an\r\nentertainment for the benefit of its free ice fund, did her the honour\r\nto beg her to appear along with celebrities for nothing. She was\r\nvisited by a young author, who had a play which he thought she could\r\nproduce. Alas, she could not judge. It hurt her to think it. Then she\r\nfound she must put her money in the bank for safety, and so moving,\r\nfinally reached the place where it struck her that the door to life\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nperfect enjoyment was not open.\r\n\r\nGradually she began to think it was because it was summer. Nothing was\r\ngoing on much save such entertainments as the one in which she was the\r\nstar. Fifth Avenue was boarded up where the rich had deserted their\r\nmansions. Madison Avenue was little better. Broadway was full of\r\nloafing thespians in search of next season\xe2\x80\x99s engagements. The whole\r\ncity was quiet and her nights were taken up with her work. Hence the\r\nfeeling that there was little to do.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d she said to Lola one day, sitting at one of the windows\r\nwhich looked down into Broadway, \xe2\x80\x9cI get lonely; don\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lola, \xe2\x80\x9cnot very often. You won\xe2\x80\x99t go anywhere. That\xe2\x80\x99s what\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nthe matter with you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere can I go?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, there\xe2\x80\x99re lots of places,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Lola, who was thinking of her\r\nown lightsome tourneys with the gay youths. \xe2\x80\x9cYou won\xe2\x80\x99t go with\r\nanybody.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t want to go with these people who write to me. I know what kind\r\nthey are.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou oughtn\xe2\x80\x99t to be lonely,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lola, thinking of Carrie\xe2\x80\x99s success.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99re lots would give their ears to be in your shoes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie looked out again at the passing crowd.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\r\n\r\nUnconsciously her idle hands were beginning to weary.\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XLV. CURIOUS SHIFTS OF THE POOR\r\n\r\nThe gloomy Hurstwood, sitting in his cheap hotel, where he had taken\r\nrefuge with seventy dollars\xe2\x80\x94the price of his furniture\xe2\x80\x94between him and\r\nnothing, saw a hot summer out and a cool fall in, reading. He was not\r\nwholly indifferent to the fact that his money was slipping away. As\r\nfifty cents after fifty cents were paid out for a day\xe2\x80\x99s lodging he\r\nbecame uneasy, and finally took a cheaper room\xe2\x80\x94thirty-five cents a\r\nday\xe2\x80\x94to make his money last longer. Frequently he saw notices of Carrie.\r\nHer picture was in the \xe2\x80\x9cWorld\xe2\x80\x9d once or twice, and an old \xe2\x80\x9cHerald\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nfound in a chair informed him that she had recently appeared with some\r\nothers at a benefit for something or other. He read these things with\r\nmingled feelings. Each one seemed to put her farther and farther away\r\ninto a realm which became more imposing as it receded from him. On the\r\nbillboards, too, he saw a pretty poster, showing her as the Quaker\r\nMaid, demure and dainty. More than once he stopped and looked at these,\r\ngazing at the pretty face in a sullen sort of way. His clothes were\r\nshabby, and he presented a marked contrast to all that she now seemed\r\nto be.\r\n\r\nSomehow, so long as he knew she was at the Casino, though he had never\r\nany intention of going near her, there was a subconscious comfort for\r\nhim\xe2\x80\x94he was not quite alone. The show seemed such a fixture that, after\r\na month or two, he began to take it for granted that it was still\r\nrunning. In September it went on the road and he did not notice it.\r\nWhen all but twenty dollars of his money was gone, he moved to a\r\nfifteen-cent lodging-house in the Bowery, where there was a bare\r\nlounging-room filled with tables and benches as well as some chairs.\r\nHere his preference was to close his eyes and dream of other days, a\r\nhabit which grew upon him. It was not sleep at first, but a mental\r\nhearkening back to scenes and incidents in his Chicago life. As the\r\npresent became darker, the past grew brighter, and all that concerned\r\nit stood in relief.\r\n\r\nHe was unconscious of just how much this habit had hold of him until\r\none day he found his lips repeating an old answer he had made to one of\r\nhis friends. They were in Fitzgerald and Moy\xe2\x80\x99s. It was as if he stood\r\nin the door of his elegant little office, comfortably dressed, talking\r\nto Sagar Morrison about the value of South Chicago real estate in which\r\nthe latter was about to invest.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow would you like to come in on that with me?\xe2\x80\x9d he heard Morrison say.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot me,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered, just as he had years before. \xe2\x80\x9cI have my hands\r\nfull now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe movement of his lips aroused him. He wondered whether he had really\r\nspoken. The next time he noticed anything of the sort he really did\r\ntalk.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy don\xe2\x80\x99t you jump, you bloody fool?\xe2\x80\x9d he was saying. \xe2\x80\x9cJump!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was a funny English story he was telling to a company of actors.\r\nEven as his voice recalled him, he was smiling. A crusty old codger,\r\nsitting near by, seemed disturbed; at least, he stared in a most\r\npointed way. Hurstwood straightened up. The humour of the memory fled\r\nin an instant and he felt ashamed. For relief, he left his chair and\r\nstrolled out into the streets.\r\n\r\nOne day, looking down the ad. columns of the \xe2\x80\x9cEvening World,\xe2\x80\x9d he saw\r\nwhere a new play was at the Casino. Instantly, he came to a mental\r\nhalt. Carrie had gone! He remembered seeing a poster of her only\r\nyesterday, but no doubt it was one left uncovered by the new signs.\r\nCuriously, this fact shook him up. He had almost to admit that somehow\r\nhe was depending upon her being in the city. Now she was gone. He\r\nwondered how this important fact had skipped him. Goodness knows when\r\nshe would be back now. Impelled by a nervous fear, he rose and went\r\ninto the dingy hall, where he counted his remaining money, unseen.\r\nThere were but ten dollars in all.\r\n\r\nHe wondered how all these other lodging-house people around him got\r\nalong. They didn\xe2\x80\x99t seem to do anything. Perhaps they\r\nbegged\xe2\x80\x94unquestionably they did. Many was the dime he had given to such\r\nas they in his day. He had seen other men asking for money on the\r\nstreets. Maybe he could get some that way. There was horror in this\r\nthought.\r\n\r\nSitting in the lodging-house room, he came to his last fifty cents. He\r\nhad saved and counted until his health was affected. His stoutness had\r\ngone. With it, even the semblance of a fit in his clothes. Now he\r\ndecided he must do something, and, walking about, saw another day go\r\nby, bringing him down to his last twenty cents\xe2\x80\x94not enough to eat for\r\nthe morrow.\r\n\r\nSummoning all his courage, he crossed to Broadway and up to the\r\nBroadway Central hotel. Within a block he halted, undecided. A big,\r\nheavy-faced porter was standing at one of the side entrances, looking\r\nout. Hurstwood purposed to appeal to him. Walking straight up, he was\r\nupon him before he could turn away.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy friend,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, recognising even in his plight the man\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ninferiority, \xe2\x80\x9cis there anything about this hotel that I could get to\r\ndo?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe porter stared at him the while he continued to talk.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m out of work and out of money and I\xe2\x80\x99ve got to get something,\xe2\x80\x94it\r\ndoesn\xe2\x80\x99t matter what. I don\xe2\x80\x99t care to talk about what I\xe2\x80\x99ve been, but if\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x99d tell me how to get something to do, I\xe2\x80\x99d be much obliged to you.\r\nIt wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t matter if it only lasted a few days just now. I\xe2\x80\x99ve got to\r\nhave something.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe porter still gazed, trying to look indifferent. Then, seeing that\r\nHurstwood was about to go on, he said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve nothing to do with it. You\xe2\x80\x99ll have to ask inside.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCuriously, this stirred Hurstwood to further effort.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thought you might tell me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe fellow shook his head irritably.\r\n\r\nInside went the ex-manager and straight to an office off the clerk\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndesk. One of the managers of the hotel happened to be there. Hurstwood\r\nlooked him straight in the eye.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCould you give me something to do for a few days?\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m in a\r\nposition where I have to get something at once.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe comfortable manager looked at him, as much as to say: \xe2\x80\x9cWell, I\r\nshould judge so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI came here,\xe2\x80\x9d explained Hurstwood, nervously, \xe2\x80\x9cbecause I\xe2\x80\x99ve been a\r\nmanager myself in my day. I\xe2\x80\x99ve had bad luck in a way but I\xe2\x80\x99m not here\r\nto tell you that. I want something to do, if only for a week.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe man imagined he saw a feverish gleam in the applicant\xe2\x80\x99s eye.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat hotel did you manage?\xe2\x80\x9d he inquired.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt wasn\xe2\x80\x99t a hotel,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood. \xe2\x80\x9cI was manager of Fitzgerald and\r\nMoy\xe2\x80\x99s place in Chicago for fifteen years.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs that so?\xe2\x80\x9d said the hotel man. \xe2\x80\x9cHow did you come to get out of\r\nthat?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe figure of Hurstwood was rather surprising in contrast to the fact.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, by foolishness of my own. It isn\xe2\x80\x99t anything to talk about now.\r\nYou could find out if you wanted to. I\xe2\x80\x99m \xe2\x80\x98broke\xe2\x80\x99 now and, if you will\r\nbelieve me, I haven\xe2\x80\x99t eaten anything to-day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe hotel man was slightly interested in this story. He could hardly\r\ntell what to do with such a figure, and yet Hurstwood\xe2\x80\x99s earnestness\r\nmade him wish to do something.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCall Olsen,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, turning to the clerk.\r\n\r\nIn reply to a bell and a disappearing hall-boy, Olsen, the head porter,\r\nappeared.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOlsen,\xe2\x80\x9d said the manager, \xe2\x80\x9cis there anything downstairs you could find\r\nfor this man to do? I\xe2\x80\x99d like to give him something.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Olsen. \xe2\x80\x9cWe have about all the help we need. I\r\nthink I could find something, sir, though, if you like.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo. Take him to the kitchen and tell Wilson to give him something to\r\neat.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Olsen.\r\n\r\nHurstwood followed. Out of the manager\xe2\x80\x99s sight, the head porter\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nmanner changed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know what the devil there is to do,\xe2\x80\x9d he observed.\r\n\r\nHurstwood said nothing. To him the big trunk hustler was a subject for\r\nprivate contempt.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re to give this man something to eat,\xe2\x80\x9d he observed to the cook.\r\n\r\nThe latter looked Hurstwood over, and seeing something keen and\r\nintellectual in his eyes, said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, sit down over there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThus was Hurstwood installed in the Broadway Central, but not for long.\r\nHe was in no shape or mood to do the scrub work that exists about the\r\nfoundation of every hotel. Nothing better offering, he was set to aid\r\nthe fireman, to work about the basement, to do anything and everything\r\nthat might offer. Porters, cooks, firemen, clerks\xe2\x80\x94all were over him.\r\nMoreover his appearance did not please these individuals\xe2\x80\x94his temper was\r\ntoo lonely\xe2\x80\x94and they made it disagreeable for him.\r\n\r\nWith the stolidity and indifference of despair, however, he endured it\r\nall, sleeping in an attic at the roof of the house, eating what the\r\ncook gave him, accepting a few dollars a week, which he tried to save.\r\nHis constitution was in no shape to endure.\r\n\r\nOne day the following February he was sent on an errand to a large coal\r\ncompany\xe2\x80\x99s office. It had been snowing and thawing and the streets were\r\nsloppy. He soaked his shoes in his progress and came back feeling dull\r\nand weary. All the next day he felt unusually depressed and sat about\r\nas much as possible, to the irritation of those who admired energy in\r\nothers.\r\n\r\nIn the afternoon some boxes were to be moved to make room for new\r\nculinary supplies. He was ordered to handle a truck. Encountering a big\r\nbox, he could not lift it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the matter there?\xe2\x80\x9d said the head porter. \xe2\x80\x9cCan\xe2\x80\x99t you handle it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe was straining to lift it, but now he quit.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, weakly.\r\n\r\nThe man looked at him and saw that he was deathly pale.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot sick, are you?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think I am,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Hurstwood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you\xe2\x80\x99d better go sit down, then.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis he did, but soon grew rapidly worse. It seemed all he could do to\r\ncrawl to his room, where he remained for a day.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat man Wheeler\xe2\x80\x99s sick,\xe2\x80\x9d reported one of the lackeys to the night\r\nclerk.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the matter with him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know. He\xe2\x80\x99s got a high fever.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe hotel physician looked at him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBetter send him to Bellevue,\xe2\x80\x9d he recommended. \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s got pneumonia.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAccordingly, he was carted away.\r\n\r\nIn three weeks the worst was over, but it was nearly the first of May\r\nbefore his strength permitted him to be turned out. Then he was\r\ndischarged.\r\n\r\nNo more weakly looking object ever strolled out into the spring\r\nsunshine than the once hale, lusty manager. All his corpulency had\r\nfled. His face was thin and pale, his hands white, his body flabby.\r\nClothes and all, he weighed but one hundred and thirty-five pounds.\r\nSome old garments had been given him\xe2\x80\x94a cheap brown coat and misfit pair\r\nof trousers. Also some change and advice. He was told to apply to the\r\ncharities.\r\n\r\nAgain he resorted to the Bowery lodging-house, brooding over where to\r\nlook. From this it was but a step to beggary.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat can a man do?\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t starve.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHis first application was in sunny Second Avenue. A well-dressed man\r\ncame leisurely strolling toward him out of Stuyvesant Park. Hurstwood\r\nnerved himself and sidled near.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWould you mind giving me ten cents?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, directly. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m in a\r\nposition where I must ask some one.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe man scarcely looked at him, fished in his vest pocket and took out\r\na dime.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere you are,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMuch obliged,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood, softly, but the other paid no more\r\nattention to him.\r\n\r\nSatisfied with his success and yet ashamed of his situation, he decided\r\nthat he would only ask for twenty-five cents more, since that would be\r\nsufficient. He strolled about sizing up people, but it was long before\r\njust the right face and situation arrived. When he asked, he was\r\nrefused. Shocked by this result, he took an hour to recover and then\r\nasked again. This time a nickel was given him. By the most watchful\r\neffort he did get twenty cents more, but it was painful.\r\n\r\nThe next day he resorted to the same effort, experiencing a variety of\r\nrebuffs and one or two generous receptions. At last it crossed his mind\r\nthat there was a science of faces, and that a man could pick the\r\nliberal countenance if he tried.\r\n\r\nIt was no pleasure to him, however, this stopping of passers-by. He saw\r\none man taken up for it and now troubled lest he should be arrested.\r\nNevertheless, he went on, vaguely anticipating that indefinite\r\nsomething which is always better.\r\n\r\nIt was with a sense of satisfaction, then, that he saw announced one\r\nmorning the return of the Casino Company, \xe2\x80\x9cwith Miss Carrie Madenda.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nHe had thought of her often enough in days past. How successful she\r\nwas\xe2\x80\x94how much money she must have! Even now, however, it took a severe\r\nrun of ill luck to decide him to appeal to her. He was truly hungry\r\nbefore he said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll ask her. She won\xe2\x80\x99t refuse me a few dollars.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAccordingly, he headed for the Casino one afternoon, passing it several\r\ntimes in an effort to locate the stage entrance. Then he sat in Bryant\r\nPark, a block away, waiting. \xe2\x80\x9cShe can\xe2\x80\x99t refuse to help me a little,\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nkept saying to himself.\r\n\r\nBeginning with half-past six, he hovered like a shadow about the\r\nThirty-ninth Street entrance, pretending always to be a hurrying\r\npedestrian and yet fearful lest he should miss his object. He was\r\nslightly nervous, too, now that the eventful hour had arrived; but\r\nbeing weak and hungry, his ability to suffer was modified. At last he\r\nsaw that the actors were beginning to arrive, and his nervous tension\r\nincreased, until it seemed as if he could not stand much more.\r\n\r\nOnce he thought he saw Carrie coming and moved forward, only to see\r\nthat he was mistaken.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe can\xe2\x80\x99t be long, now,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to himself, half fearing to encounter\r\nher and equally depressed at the thought that she might have gone in by\r\nanother way. His stomach was so empty that it ached.\r\n\r\nIndividual after individual passed him, nearly all well dressed, almost\r\nall indifferent. He saw coaches rolling by, gentlemen passing with\r\nladies\xe2\x80\x94the evening\xe2\x80\x99s merriment was beginning in this region of theatres\r\nand hotels.\r\n\r\nSuddenly a coach rolled up and the driver jumped down to open the door.\r\nBefore Hurstwood could act, two ladies flounced across the broad walk\r\nand disappeared in the stage door. He thought he saw Carrie, but it was\r\nso unexpected, so elegant and far away, he could hardly tell. He waited\r\na while longer, growing feverish with want, and then seeing that the\r\nstage door no longer opened, and that a merry audience was arriving, he\r\nconcluded it must have been Carrie and turned away.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLord,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, hastening out of the street into which the more\r\nfortunate were pouring, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve got to get something.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt that hour, when Broadway is wont to assume its most interesting\r\naspect, a peculiar individual invariably took his stand at the corner\r\nof Twenty-sixth Street and Broadway\xe2\x80\x94a spot which is also intersected by\r\nFifth Avenue. This was the hour when the theatres were just beginning\r\nto receive their patrons. Fire signs announcing the night\xe2\x80\x99s amusements\r\nblazed on every hand. Cabs and carriages, their lamps gleaming like\r\nyellow eyes, pattered by. Couples and parties of three and four freely\r\nmingled in the common crowd, which poured by in a thick stream,\r\nlaughing and jesting. On Fifth Avenue were loungers\xe2\x80\x94a few wealthy\r\nstrollers, a gentleman in evening dress with his lady on his arm, some\r\nclub-men passing from one smoking-room to another. Across the way the\r\ngreat hotels showed a hundred gleaming windows, their caf\xc3\xa9s and\r\nbilliard-rooms filled with a comfortable, well-dressed, and\r\npleasure-loving throng. All about was the night, pulsating with the\r\nthoughts of pleasure and exhilaration\xe2\x80\x94the curious enthusiasm of a great\r\ncity bent upon finding joy in a thousand different ways.\r\n\r\nThis unique individual was no less than an ex-soldier turned\r\nreligionist, who, having suffered the whips and privations of our\r\npeculiar social system, had concluded that his duty to the God which he\r\nconceived lay in aiding his fellow-man. The form of aid which he chose\r\nto administer was entirely original with himself. It consisted of\r\nsecuring a bed for all such homeless wayfarers as should apply to him\r\nat this particular spot, though he had scarcely the wherewithal to\r\nprovide a comfortable habitation for himself. Taking his place amid\r\nthis lightsome atmosphere, he would stand, his stocky figure cloaked in\r\na great cape overcoat, his head protected by a broad slouch hat,\r\nawaiting the applicants who had in various ways learned the nature of\r\nhis charity. For a while he would stand alone, gazing like any idler\r\nupon an ever-fascinating scene. On the evening in question, a policeman\r\npassing saluted him as \xe2\x80\x9ccaptain,\xe2\x80\x9d in a friendly way. An urchin who had\r\nfrequently seen him before, stopped to gaze. All others took him for\r\nnothing out of the ordinary, save in the matter of dress, and conceived\r\nof him as a stranger whistling and idling for his own amusement.\r\n\r\nAs the first half-hour waned, certain characters appeared. Here and\r\nthere in the passing crowds one might see, now and then, a loiterer\r\nedging interestedly near. A slouchy figure crossed the opposite corner\r\nand glanced furtively in his direction. Another came down Fifth Avenue\r\nto the corner of Twenty-sixth Street, took a general survey, and\r\nhobbled off again. Two or three noticeable Bowery types edged along the\r\nFifth Avenue side of Madison Square, but did not venture over. The\r\nsoldier, in his cape overcoat, walked a short line of ten feet at his\r\ncorner, to and fro, indifferently whistling.\r\n\r\nAs nine o\xe2\x80\x99clock approached, some of the hubbub of the earlier hour\r\npassed. The atmosphere of the hotels was not so youthful. The air, too,\r\nwas colder. On every hand curious figures were moving\xe2\x80\x94watchers and\r\npeepers, without an imaginary circle, which they seemed afraid to\r\nenter\xe2\x80\x94a dozen in all. Presently, with the arrival of a keener sense of\r\ncold, one figure came forward. It crossed Broadway from out the shadow\r\nof Twenty-sixth Street, and, in a halting, circuitous way, arrived\r\nclose to the waiting figure. There was something shamefaced or\r\ndiffident about the movement, as if the intention were to conceal any\r\nidea of stopping until the very last moment. Then suddenly, close to\r\nthe soldier, came the halt.\r\n\r\nThe captain looked in recognition, but there was no especial greeting.\r\nThe newcomer nodded slightly and murmured something like one who waits\r\nfor gifts. The other simply motioned toward the edge of the walk.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStand over there,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\nBy this the spell was broken. Even while the soldier resumed his short,\r\nsolemn walk, other figures shuffled forward. They did not so much as\r\ngreet the leader, but joined the one, sniffling and hitching and\r\nscraping their feet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCold, ain\xe2\x80\x99t it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m glad winter\xe2\x80\x99s over.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLooks as though it might rain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe motley company had increased to ten. One or two knew each other and\r\nconversed. Others stood off a few feet, not wishing to be in the crowd\r\nand yet not counted out. They were peevish, crusty, silent, eying\r\nnothing in particular and moving their feet.\r\n\r\nThere would have been talking soon, but the soldier gave them no\r\nchance. Counting sufficient to begin, he came forward.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBeds, eh, all of you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was a general shuffle and murmur of approval.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, line up here. I\xe2\x80\x99ll see what I can do. I haven\xe2\x80\x99t a cent myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey fell into a sort of broken, ragged line. One might see, now, some\r\nof the chief characteristics by contrast. There was a wooden leg in the\r\nline. Hats were all drooping, a group that would ill become a\r\nsecond-hand Hester Street basement collection. Trousers were all warped\r\nand frayed at the bottom and coats worn and faded. In the glare of the\r\nstore lights, some of the faces looked dry and chalky; others were red\r\nwith blotches and puffed in the cheeks and under the eyes; one or two\r\nwere rawboned and reminded one of railroad hands. A few spectators came\r\nnear, drawn by the seemingly conferring group, then more and more, and\r\nquickly there was a pushing, gaping crowd. Some one in the line began\r\nto talk.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSilence!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the captain. \xe2\x80\x9cNow, then, gentlemen, these men are\r\nwithout beds. They have to have some place to sleep to-night. They\r\ncan\xe2\x80\x99t lie out in the streets. I need twelve cents to put one of them to\r\nbed. Who will give it to me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNo reply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, we\xe2\x80\x99ll have to wait here, boys, until some one does. Twelve cents\r\nisn\xe2\x80\x99t so very much for one man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere\xe2\x80\x99s fifteen,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed a young man, peering forward with strained\r\neyes. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s all I can afford.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right. Now I have fifteen. Step out of the line,\xe2\x80\x9d and seizing one\r\nby the shoulder, the captain marched him off a little way and stood him\r\nup alone.\r\n\r\nComing back, he resumed his place and began again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have three cents left. These men must be put to bed somehow. There\r\nare\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94counting\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cone, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine,\r\nten, eleven, twelve men. Nine cents more will put the next man to bed;\r\ngive him a good, comfortable bed for the night. I go right along and\r\nlook after that myself. Who will give me nine cents?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOne of the watchers, this time a middle-aged man, handed him a\r\nfive-cent piece.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, I have eight cents. Four more will give this man a bed. Come,\r\ngentlemen. We are going very slow this evening. You all have good beds.\r\nHow about these?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere you are,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked a bystander, putting a coin into his hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat,\xe2\x80\x9d said the captain, looking at the coin, \xe2\x80\x9cpays for two beds for\r\ntwo men and gives me five on the next one. Who will give me seven cents\r\nmore?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will,\xe2\x80\x9d said a voice.\r\n\r\nComing down Sixth Avenue this evening, Hurstwood chanced to cross east\r\nthrough Twenty-sixth Street toward Third Avenue. He was wholly\r\ndisconsolate in spirit, hungry to what he deemed an almost mortal\r\nextent, weary, and defeated. How should he get at Carrie now? It would\r\nbe eleven before the show was over. If she came in a coach, she would\r\ngo away in one. He would need to interrupt under most trying\r\ncircumstances. Worst of all, he was hungry and weary, and at best a\r\nwhole day must intervene, for he had not heart to try again to-night.\r\nHe had no food and no bed.\r\n\r\nWhen he neared Broadway, he noticed the captain\xe2\x80\x99s gathering of\r\nwanderers, but thinking it to be the result of a street preacher or\r\nsome patent medicine fakir, was about to pass on. However, in crossing\r\nthe street toward Madison Square Park, he noticed the line of men whose\r\nbeds were already secured, stretching out from the main body of the\r\ncrowd. In the glare of the neighbouring electric light he recognised a\r\ntype of his own kind\xe2\x80\x94the figures whom he saw about the streets and in\r\nthe lodging-houses, drifting in mind and body like himself. He wondered\r\nwhat it could be and turned back.\r\n\r\nThere was the captain curtly pleading as before. He heard with\r\nastonishment and a sense of relief the oft-repeated words: \xe2\x80\x9cThese men\r\nmust have a bed.\xe2\x80\x9d Before him was the line of unfortunates whose beds\r\nwere yet to be had, and seeing a newcomer quietly edge up and take a\r\nposition at the end of the line, he decided to do likewise. What use to\r\ncontend? He was weary to-night. It was a simple way out of one\r\ndifficulty, at least. To-morrow, maybe, he would do better.\r\n\r\nBack of him, where some of those were whose beds were safe, a relaxed\r\nair was apparent. The strain of uncertainty being removed, he heard\r\nthem talking with moderate freedom and some leaning toward sociability.\r\nPolitics, religion, the state of the government, some newspaper\r\nsensations, and the more notorious facts the world over, found\r\nmouthpieces and auditors there. Cracked and husky voices pronounced\r\nforcibly upon odd matters. Vague and rambling observations were made in\r\nreply.\r\n\r\nThere were squints, and leers, and some dull, ox-like stares from those\r\nwho were too dull or too weary to converse.\r\n\r\nStanding tells. Hurstwood became more weary waiting. He thought he\r\nshould drop soon and shifted restlessly from one foot to the other. At\r\nlast his turn came. The man ahead had been paid for and gone to the\r\nblessed line of success. He was now first, and already the captain was\r\ntalking for him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTwelve cents, gentlemen\xe2\x80\x94twelve cents puts this man to bed. He wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nstand here in the cold if he had any place to go.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHurstwood swallowed something that rose to his throat. Hunger and\r\nweakness had made a coward of him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere you are,\xe2\x80\x9d said a stranger, handing money to the captain.\r\n\r\nNow the latter put a kindly hand on the ex-manager\xe2\x80\x99s shoulder. \xe2\x80\x9cLine up\r\nover there,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\nOnce there, Hurstwood breathed easier. He felt as if the world were not\r\nquite so bad with such a good man in it. Others seemed to feel like\r\nhimself about this.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCaptain\xe2\x80\x99s a great feller, ain\xe2\x80\x99t he?\xe2\x80\x9d said the man ahead\xe2\x80\x94a little,\r\nwoebegone, helpless-looking sort of individual, who looked as though he\r\nhad ever been the sport and care of fortune.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood, indifferently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHuh! there\xe2\x80\x99s a lot back there yet,\xe2\x80\x9d said a man farther up, leaning out\r\nand looking back at the applicants for whom the captain was pleading.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. Must be over a hundred to-night,\xe2\x80\x9d said another.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLook at the guy in the cab,\xe2\x80\x9d observed a third.\r\n\r\nA cab had stopped. Some gentleman in evening dress reached out a bill\r\nto the captain, who took it with simple thanks and turned away to his\r\nline. There was a general craning of necks as the jewel in the white\r\nshirt front sparkled and the cab moved off. Even the crowd gaped in\r\nawe.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat fixes up nine men for the night,\xe2\x80\x9d said the captain, counting out\r\nas many of the line near him. \xe2\x80\x9cLine up over there. Now, then, there are\r\nonly seven. I need twelve cents.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMoney came slowly. In the course of time the crowd thinned out to a\r\nmeagre handful. Fifth Avenue, save for an occasional cab or foot\r\npassenger, was bare. Broadway was thinly peopled with pedestrians. Only\r\nnow and then a stranger passing noticed the small group, handed out a\r\ncoin, and went away, unheeding.\r\n\r\nThe captain remained stolid and determined. He talked on, very slowly,\r\nuttering the fewest words and with a certain assurance, as though he\r\ncould not fail.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome; I can\xe2\x80\x99t stay out here all night. These men are getting tired and\r\ncold. Some one give me four cents.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere came a time when he said nothing at all. Money was handed him,\r\nand for each twelve cents he singled out a man and put him in the other\r\nline. Then he walked up and down as before, looking at the ground.\r\n\r\nThe theatres let out. Fire signs disappeared. A clock struck eleven.\r\nAnother half-hour and he was down to the last two men.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, now,\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed to several curious observers; \xe2\x80\x9ceighteen cents\r\nwill fix us all up for the night. Eighteen cents. I have six. Somebody\r\ngive me the money. Remember, I have to go over to Brooklyn yet\r\nto-night. Before that I have to take these men down and put them to\r\nbed. Eighteen cents.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNo one responded. He walked to and fro, looking down for several\r\nminutes, occasionally saying softly: \xe2\x80\x9cEighteen cents.\xe2\x80\x9d It seemed as if\r\nthis paltry sum would delay the desired culmination longer than all the\r\nrest had. Hurstwood, buoyed up slightly by the long line of which he\r\nwas a part, refrained with an effort from groaning, he was so weak.\r\n\r\nAt last a lady in opera cape and rustling skirts came down Fifth\r\nAvenue, accompanied by her escort. Hurstwood gazed wearily, reminded by\r\nher both of Carrie in her new world and of the time when he had\r\nescorted his own wife in like manner.\r\n\r\nWhile he was gazing, she turned and, looking at the remarkable company,\r\nsent her escort over. He came, holding a bill in his fingers, all\r\nelegant and graceful.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere you are,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThanks,\xe2\x80\x9d said the captain, turning to the two remaining applicants.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow we have some for to-morrow night,\xe2\x80\x9d he added.\r\n\r\nTherewith he lined up the last two and proceeded to the head, counting\r\nas he went.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne hundred and thirty-seven,\xe2\x80\x9d he announced. \xe2\x80\x9cNow, boys, line up.\r\nRight dress there. We won\xe2\x80\x99t be much longer about this. Steady, now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe placed himself at the head and called out \xe2\x80\x9cForward.\xe2\x80\x9d Hurstwood moved\r\nwith the line. Across Fifth Avenue, through Madison Square by the\r\nwinding paths, east on Twenty-third Street, and down Third Avenue wound\r\nthe long, serpentine company. Midnight pedestrians and loiterers\r\nstopped and stared as the company passed. Chatting policemen, at\r\nvarious corners, stared indifferently or nodded to the leader, whom\r\nthey had seen before. On Third Avenue they marched, a seemingly weary\r\nway, to Eighth Street, where there was a lodging-house, closed,\r\napparently, for the night. They were expected, however.\r\n\r\nOutside in the gloom they stood, while the leader parleyed within. Then\r\ndoors swung open and they were invited in with a \xe2\x80\x9cSteady, now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSome one was at the head showing rooms, so that there was no delay for\r\nkeys. Toiling up the creaky stairs, Hurstwood looked back and saw the\r\ncaptain, watching; the last one of the line being included in his broad\r\nsolicitude. Then he gathered his cloak about him and strolled out into\r\nthe night.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t stand much of this,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hurstwood, whose legs ached him\r\npainfully, as he sat down upon the miserable bunk in the small,\r\nlightless chamber allotted to him. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve got to eat, or I\xe2\x80\x99ll die.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XLVI. STIRRING TROUBLED WATERS\r\n\r\nPlaying in New York one evening on this her return, Carrie was putting\r\nthe finishing touches to her toilet before leaving for the night, when\r\na commotion near the stage door caught her ear. The\r\nsame fine clothes, the same stocky body, the same rosy countenance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat fellow at the door there didn\xe2\x80\x99t want to let me in, until I paid\r\nhim. I always said you could act\xe2\x80\x94didn\xe2\x80\x99t I?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie smiled.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, you did,\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you do look great,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cI never saw anybody improve so.\r\nYou\xe2\x80\x99re taller, aren\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMe? Poor fellow! What a thing to have had hanging over\r\nhis head all the time.\r\n\r\nAt dinner Drouet, warmed up by eating and drinking and softened in\r\nmood, fancied he was winning Carrie to her old-time good-natured regard\r\nfor him.
