Drouet called again, but now he was not even seen by\r\nher. His attentions seemed out of place.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m out,\xe2\x80\x9d was her reply to the boy.\r\n\r\nSo peculiar, indeed, was her lonely, self-withdrawing temper, that she\r\nwas becoming an interesting figure in the public eye\xe2\x80\x94she was so quiet\r\nand reserved.\r\n\r\nNot long after the management decided to transfer the show to London. A\r\nsecond summer season did not seem to promise well here.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow would you like to try subduing London?\xe2\x80\x9d asked her manager, one\r\nafternoon.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt might be just the other way,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think we\xe2\x80\x99ll go in June,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered.\r\n\r\nIn the hurry of departure, Hurstwood was forgotten. Both he and Drouet\r\nwere left to discover that she was gone. The latter called once, and\r\nexclaimed at the news. Then he stood in the lobby, chewing the ends of\r\nhis moustache. At last he reached a conclusion\xe2\x80\x94the old days had gone\r\nfor good.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe isn\xe2\x80\x99t so much,\xe2\x80\x9d he said; but in his heart of hearts he did not\r\nbelieve this.\r\n\r\nHurstwood shifted by curious means through a long summer and fall. A\r\nsmall job as janitor of a dance hall helped him for a month. Begging,\r\nsometimes going hungry, sometimes sleeping in the park, carried him\r\nover more days. Resorting to those peculiar charities, several of\r\nwhich, in the press of hungry search, he accidentally stumbled upon,\r\ndid the rest. Toward the dead of winter, Carrie came back, appearing on\r\nBroadway in a new play; but he was not aware of it. For weeks he\r\nwandered about the city, begging, while the fire sign, announcing her\r\nengagement, blazed nightly upon the crowded street of amusements.\r\nDrouet saw it, but did not venture in.\r\n\r\nAbout this time Ames returned to New York. He had made a little success\r\nin the West, and now opened a laboratory in Wooster Street. Of course,\r\nhe encountered Carrie through Mrs. Vance; but there was nothing\r\nresponsive between them. He thought she was still united to Hurstwood,\r\nuntil otherwise informed. Not knowing the facts then, he did not\r\nprofess to understand, and refrained from comment.\r\n\r\nWith Mrs. Vance, he saw the new play, and expressed himself\r\naccordingly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe ought not to be in comedy,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cI think she could do better\r\nthan that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOne afternoon they met at the Vances\xe2\x80\x99 accidentally, and began a very\r\nfriendly conversation. She could hardly tell why the one-time keen\r\ninterest in him was no longer with her. Unquestionably, it was because\r\nat that time he had represented something which she did not have; but\r\nthis she did not understand. Success had given her the momentary\r\nfeeling that she was now blessed with much of which he would approve.\r\nAs a matter of fact, her little newspaper fame was nothing at all to\r\nhim. He thought she could have done better, by far.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou didn\xe2\x80\x99t go into comedy-drama, after all?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, remembering her\r\ninterest in that form of art.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered; \xe2\x80\x9cI haven\xe2\x80\x99t, so far.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe looked at her in such a peculiar way that she realised she had\r\nfailed. It moved her to add: \xe2\x80\x9cI want to, though.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI should think you would,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cYou have the sort of disposition\r\nthat would do well in comedy-drama.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt surprised her that he should speak of disposition. Was she, then, so\r\nclearly in his mind?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cI should judge you were rather sympathetic in your\r\nnature.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie smiled and coloured slightly. He was so innocently frank with\r\nher that she drew nearer in friendship. The old call of the ideal was\r\nsounding.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered, pleased, nevertheless, beyond all\r\nconcealment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI saw your play,\xe2\x80\x9d he remarked. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s very good.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m glad you liked it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery good, indeed,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cfor a comedy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis is all that was said at the time, owing to an interruption, but\r\nlater they met again. He was sitting in a corner after dinner, staring\r\nat the floor, when Carrie came up with another of the guests. Hard work\r\nhad given his face the look of one who is weary. It was not for Carrie\r\nto know the thing in it which appealed to her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll alone?\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was listening to the music.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll be back in a moment,\xe2\x80\x9d said her companion, who saw nothing in the\r\ninventor.\r\n\r\nNow he looked up in her face, for she was standing a moment, while he\r\nsat.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIsn\xe2\x80\x99t that a pathetic strain?\xe2\x80\x9d he inquired, listening.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, very,\xe2\x80\x9d she returned, also catching it, now that her attention was\r\ncalled.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSit down,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, offering her the chair beside him.\r\n\r\nThey listened a few moments in silence, touched by the same feeling,\r\nonly hers reached her through the heart. Music still charmed her as in\r\nthe old days.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know what it is about music,\xe2\x80\x9d she started to say, moved by the\r\ninexplicable longings which surged within her; \xe2\x80\x9cbut it always makes me\r\nfeel as if I wanted something\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d he replied; \xe2\x80\x9cI know how you feel.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSuddenly he turned to considering the peculiarity of her disposition,\r\nexpressing her feelings so frankly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou ought not to be melancholy,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\nHe thought a while, and then went off into a seemingly alien\r\nobservation which, however, accorded with their feelings.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe world is full of desirable situations, but, unfortunately, we can\r\noccupy but one at a time. It doesn\xe2\x80\x99t do us any good to wring our hands\r\nover the far-off things.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe music ceased and he arose, taking a standing position before her,\r\nas if to rest himself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy don\xe2\x80\x99t you get into some good, strong comedy-drama?\xe2\x80\x9d he said. He\r\nwas looking directly at her now, studying her face. Her large,\r\nsympathetic eyes and pain-touched mouth appealed to him as proofs of\r\nhis judgment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps I shall,\xe2\x80\x9d she returned.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s your field,\xe2\x80\x9d he added.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you think so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d he said; \xe2\x80\x9cI do. I don\xe2\x80\x99t suppose you\xe2\x80\x99re aware of it, but there is\r\nsomething about your eyes and mouth which fits you for that sort of\r\nwork.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie thrilled to be taken so seriously. For the moment, loneliness\r\ndeserted her. Here was praise which was keen and analytical.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s in your eyes and mouth,\xe2\x80\x9d he went on abstractedly. \xe2\x80\x9cI remember\r\nthinking, the first time I saw you, that there was something peculiar\r\nabout your mouth. I thought you were about to cry.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow odd,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, warm with delight. This was what her heart\r\ncraved.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen I noticed that that was your natural look, and to-night I saw it\r\nagain. There\xe2\x80\x99s a shadow about your eyes, too, which gives your face\r\nmuch this same character. It\xe2\x80\x99s in the depth of them, I think.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie looked straight into his face, wholly aroused.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou probably are not aware of it,\xe2\x80\x9d he added.\r\n\r\nShe looked away, pleased that he should speak thus, longing to be equal\r\nto this feeling written upon her countenance. It unlocked the door to a\r\nnew desire. She had cause to ponder over this until they met\r\nagain\xe2\x80\x94several weeks or more. It showed her she was drifting away from\r\nthe old ideal which had filled her in the dressing-rooms of the Avery\r\nstage and thereafter, for a long time. Why had she lost it?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know why you should be a success,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, another time, \xe2\x80\x9cif you\r\nhad a more dramatic part. I\xe2\x80\x99ve studied it out\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it?\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, as one pleased with a puzzle, \xe2\x80\x9cthe expression in your\r\nface is one that comes out in different things. You get the same thing\r\nin a pathetic song, or any picture which moves you deeply. It\xe2\x80\x99s a thing\r\nthe world likes to see, because it\xe2\x80\x99s a natural expression of its\r\nlonging.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie gazed without exactly getting the import of what he meant.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe world is always struggling to express itself,\xe2\x80\x9d he went on. \xe2\x80\x9cMost\r\npeople are not capable of voicing their feelings. They depend upon\r\nothers. That is what genius is for. One man expresses their desires for\r\nthem in music; another one in poetry; another one in a play. Sometimes\r\nnature does it in a face\xe2\x80\x94it makes the face representative of all\r\ndesire. That\xe2\x80\x99s what has happened in your case.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe looked at her with so much of the import of the thing in his eyes\r\nthat she caught it. At least, she got the idea that her look was\r\nsomething which represented the world\xe2\x80\x99s longing. She took it to heart\r\nas a creditable thing, until he added:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat puts a burden of duty on you. It so happens that you have this\r\nthing. It is no credit to you\xe2\x80\x94that is, I mean, you might not have had\r\nit. You paid nothing to get it. But now that you have it, you must do\r\nsomething with it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Carrie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI should say, turn to the dramatic field. You have so much sympathy\r\nand such a melodious voice. Make them valuable to others. It will make\r\nyour powers endure.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie did not understand this last. All the rest showed her that her\r\ncomedy success was little or nothing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you mean?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, just this. You have this quality in your eyes and mouth and in\r\nyour nature. You can lose it, you know. If you turn away from it and\r\nlive to satisfy yourself alone, it will go fast enough. The look will\r\nleave your eyes. Your mouth will change. Your power to act will\r\ndisappear. You may think they won\xe2\x80\x99t, but they will. Nature takes care\r\nof that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe was so interested in forwarding all good causes that he sometimes\r\nbecame enthusiastic, giving vent to these preachments. Something in\r\nCarrie appealed to him. He wanted to stir her up.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, absently, feeling slightly guilty of neglect.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I were you,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d change.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe effect of this was like roiling helpless waters. Carrie troubled\r\nover it in her rocking-chair for days.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t believe I\xe2\x80\x99ll stay in comedy so very much longer,\xe2\x80\x9d she\r\neventually remarked to Lola.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, why not?\xe2\x80\x9d said the latter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cI can do better in a serious play.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat put that idea in your head?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, nothing,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered; \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve always thought so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nStill, she did nothing\xe2\x80\x94grieving. It was a long way to this better\r\nthing\xe2\x80\x94or seemed so\xe2\x80\x94and comfort was about her; hence the inactivity and\r\nlonging.\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XLVII. THE WAY OF THE BEATEN: A HARP IN THE WIND\r\n\r\nIn the city, at that time, there were a number of charities similar in\r\nnature to that of the captain\xe2\x80\x99s, which Hurstwood now patronised in a\r\nlike unfortunate way. One was a convent mission-house of the Sisters of\r\nMercy in Fifteenth Street\xe2\x80\x94a row of red brick family dwellings, before\r\nthe door of which hung a plain wooden contribution box, on which was\r\npainted the statement that every noon a meal was given free to all\r\nthose who might apply and ask for aid. This simple announcement was\r\nmodest in the extreme, covering, as it did, a charity so broad.\r\nInstitutions and charities are so large and so numerous in New York\r\nthat such things as this are not often noticed by the more comfortably\r\nsituated. But to one whose mind is upon the matter, they grow\r\nexceedingly under inspection. Unless one were looking up this matter in\r\nparticular, he could have stood at Sixth Avenue and Fifteenth Street\r\nfor days around the noon hour and never have noticed that out of the\r\nvast crowd that surged along that busy thoroughfare there turned out,\r\nevery few seconds, some weather-beaten, heavy-footed specimen of\r\nhumanity, gaunt in countenance and dilapidated in the matter of\r\nclothes. The fact is none the less true, however, and the colder the\r\nday the more apparent it became. Space and a lack of culinary room in\r\nthe mission-house, compelled an arrangement which permitted of only\r\ntwenty-five or thirty eating at one time, so that a line had to be\r\nformed outside and an orderly entrance effected. This caused a daily\r\nspectacle which, however, had become so common by repetition during a\r\nnumber of years that now nothing was thought of it. The men waited\r\npatiently, like cattle, in the coldest weather\xe2\x80\x94waited for several hours\r\nbefore they could be admitted. No questions were asked and no service\r\nrendered. They ate and went away again, some of them returning\r\nregularly day after day the winter through.\r\n\r\nA big, motherly looking woman invariably stood guard at the door during\r\nthe entire operation and counted the admissible number. The men moved\r\nup in solemn order. There was no haste and no eagerness displayed. It\r\nwas almost a dumb procession. In the bitterest weather this line was to\r\nbe found here. Under an icy wind there was a prodigious slapping of\r\nhands and a dancing of feet. Fingers and the features of the face\r\nlooked as if severely nipped by the cold. A study of these men in broad\r\nlight proved them to be nearly all of a type. They belonged to the\r\nclass that sit on the park benches during the endurable days and sleep\r\nupon them during the summer nights. They frequent the Bowery and those\r\ndown-at-the-heels East Side streets where poor clothes and shrunken\r\nfeatures are not singled out as curious. They are the men who are in\r\nthe lodging-house sitting-rooms during bleak and bitter weather and who\r\nswarm about the cheaper shelters which only open at six in a number of\r\nthe lower East Side streets. Miserable food, ill-timed and greedily\r\neaten, had played havoc with bone and muscle. They were all pale,\r\nflabby, sunken-eyed, hollow-chested, with eyes that glinted and shone\r\nand lips that were a sickly red by contrast. Their hair was but half\r\nattended to, their ears an\xc3\xa6mic in hue, and their shoes broken in\r\nleather and run down at heel and toe. They were of the class which\r\nsimply floats and drifts, every wave of people washing up one, as\r\nbreakers do driftwood upon a stormy shore.\r\n\r\nFor nearly a quarter of a century, in another section of the city,\r\nFleischmann, the baker, had given a loaf of bread to any one who would\r\ncome for it to the side door of his restaurant at the corner of\r\nBroadway and Tenth Street, at midnight. Every night during twenty years\r\nabout three hundred men had formed in line and at the appointed time\r\nmarched past the doorway, picked their loaf from a great box placed\r\njust outside, and vanished again into the night. From the beginning to\r\nthe present time there had been little change in the character or\r\nnumber of these men. There were two or three figures that had grown\r\nfamiliar to those who had seen this little procession pass year after\r\nyear. Two of them had missed scarcely a night in fifteen years. There\r\nwere about forty, more or less, regular callers. The remainder of the\r\nline was formed of strangers. In times of panic and unusual hardships\r\nthere were seldom more than three hundred. In times of prosperity, when\r\nlittle is heard of the unemployed, there were seldom less. The same\r\nnumber, winter and summer, in storm or calm, in good times and bad,\r\nheld this melancholy midnight rendezvous at Fleischmann\xe2\x80\x99s bread box.\r\n\r\nAt both of these two charities, during the severe winter which was now\r\non, Hurstwood was a frequent visitor. On one occasion it was peculiarly\r\ncold, and finding no comfort in begging about the streets, he waited\r\nuntil noon before seeking this free offering to the poor. Already, at\r\neleven o\xe2\x80\x99clock of this morning, several such as he had shambled forward\r\nout of Sixth Avenue, their thin clothes flapping and fluttering in the\r\nwind. They leaned against the iron railing which protects the walls of\r\nthe Ninth Regiment Armory, which fronts upon that section of Fifteenth\r\nStreet, having come early in order to be first in. Having an hour to\r\nwait, they at first lingered at a respectful distance; but others\r\ncoming up, they moved closer in order to protect their right of\r\nprecedence. To this collection Hurstwood came up from the west out of\r\nSeventh Avenue and stopped close to the door, nearer than all the\r\nothers. Those who had been waiting before him, but farther away, now\r\ndrew near, and by a certain stolidity of demeanour, no words being\r\nspoken, indicated that they were first.\r\n\r\nSeeing the opposition to his action, he looked sullenly along the line,\r\nthen moved out, taking his place at the foot. When order had been\r\nrestored, the animal feeling of opposition relaxed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMust be pretty near noon,\xe2\x80\x9d ventured one.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is,\xe2\x80\x9d said another. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve been waiting nearly an hour.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGee, but it\xe2\x80\x99s cold!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey peered eagerly at the door, where all must enter. A grocery man\r\ndrove up and carried in several baskets of eatables. This started some\r\nwords upon grocery men and the cost of food in general.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI see meat\xe2\x80\x99s gone up,\xe2\x80\x9d said one.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf there wuz war, it would help this country a lot.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe line was growing rapidly. Already there were fifty or more, and\r\nthose at the head, by their demeanour, evidently congratulated\r\nthemselves upon not having so long to wait as those at the foot. There\r\nwas much jerking of heads, and looking down the line.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt don\xe2\x80\x99t matter how near you get to the front, so long as you\xe2\x80\x99re in\r\nthe first twenty-five,\xe2\x80\x9d commented one of the first twenty-five. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\r\nall go in together.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHumph!\xe2\x80\x9d ejaculated Hurstwood, who had been so sturdily displaced.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis here Single Tax is the thing,\xe2\x80\x9d said another. \xe2\x80\x9cThere ain\xe2\x80\x99t going\r\nto be no order till it comes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFor the most part there was silence; gaunt men shuffling, glancing, and\r\nbeating their arms.\r\n\r\nAt last the door opened and the motherly-looking sister appeared. She\r\nonly looked an order. Slowly the line moved up and, one by one, passed\r\nin, until twenty-five were counted. Then she interposed a stout arm,\r\nand the line halted, with six men on the steps. Of these the ex-manager\r\nwas one. Waiting thus, some talked, some ejaculated concerning the\r\nmisery of it; some brooded, as did Hurstwood. At last he was admitted,\r\nand, having eaten, came away, almost angered because of his pains in\r\ngetting it.\r\n\r\nAt eleven o\xe2\x80\x99clock of another evening, perhaps two weeks later, he was\r\nat the midnight offering of a loaf\xe2\x80\x94waiting patiently. It had been an\r\nunfortunate day with him, but now he took his fate with a touch of\r\nphilosophy. If he could secure no supper, or was hungry late in the\r\nevening, here was a place he could come. A few minutes before twelve, a\r\ngreat box of bread was pushed out, and exactly on the hour a portly,\r\nround-faced German took position by it, calling \xe2\x80\x9cReady.\xe2\x80\x9d The whole line\r\nat once moved forward each taking his loaf in turn and going his\r\nseparate way. On this occasion, the ex-manager ate his as he went\r\nplodding the dark streets in silence to his bed.\r\n\r\nBy January he had about concluded that the game was up with him. Life\r\nhad always seemed a precious thing, but now constant want and weakened\r\nvitality had made the charms of earth rather dull and inconspicuous.\r\nSeveral times, when fortune pressed most harshly, he thought he would\r\nend his troubles; but with a change of weather, or the arrival of a\r\nquarter or a dime, his mood would change, and he would wait. Each day\r\nhe would find some old paper lying about and look into it, to see if\r\nthere was any trace of Carrie, but all summer and fall he had looked in\r\nvain. Then he noticed that his eyes were beginning to hurt him, and\r\nthis ailment rapidly increased until, in the dark chambers of the\r\nlodgings he frequented, he did not attempt to read. Bad and irregular\r\neating was weakening every function of his body. The one recourse left\r\nhim was to doze when a place offered and he could get the money to\r\noccupy it.\r\n\r\nHe was beginning to find, in his wretched clothing and meagre state of\r\nbody, that people took him for a chronic type of bum and beggar. Police\r\nhustled him along, restaurant and lodging-house keepers turned him out\r\npromptly the moment he had his due; pedestrians waved him off. He found\r\nit more and more difficult to get anything from anybody.\r\n\r\nAt last he admitted to himself that the game was up. It was after a\r\nlong series of appeals to pedestrians, in which he had been refused and\r\nrefused\xe2\x80\x94every one hastening from contact.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGive me a little something, will you, mister?\xe2\x80\x9d he said to the last\r\none. \xe2\x80\x9cFor God\xe2\x80\x99s sake, do; I\xe2\x80\x99m starving.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAw, get out,\xe2\x80\x9d said the man, who happened to be a common type himself.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re no good. I\xe2\x80\x99ll give you nawthin\xe2\x80\x99.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHurstwood put his hands, red from cold, down in his pockets. Tears came\r\ninto his eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s right,\xe2\x80\x9d he said; \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m no good now. I was all right. I had\r\nmoney. I\xe2\x80\x99m going to quit this,\xe2\x80\x9d and, with death in his heart, he\r\nstarted down toward the Bowery. People had turned on the gas before and\r\ndied; why shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t he? He remembered a lodging-house where there were\r\nlittle, close rooms, with gas-jets in them, almost pre-arranged, he\r\nthought, for what he wanted to do, which rented for fifteen cents. Then\r\nhe remembered that he had no fifteen cents.\r\n\r\nOn the way he met a comfortable-looking gentleman, coming,\r\nclean-shaven, out of a fine barber shop.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWould you mind giving me a little something?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked this man\r\nboldly.\r\n\r\nThe gentleman looked him over and fished for a dime. Nothing but\r\nquarters were in his pocket.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, handing him one, to be rid of him. \xe2\x80\x9cBe off, now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHurstwood moved on, wondering. The sight of the large, bright coin\r\npleased him a little. He remembered that he was hungry and that he\r\ncould get a bed for ten cents. With this, the idea of death passed, for\r\nthe time being, out of his mind. It was only when he could get nothing\r\nbut insults that death seemed worth while.\r\n\r\nOne day, in the middle of the winter, the sharpest spell of the season\r\nset in. It broke grey and cold in the first day, and on the second\r\nsnowed. Poor luck pursuing him, he had secured but ten cents by\r\nnightfall, and this he had spent for food. At evening he found himself\r\nat the Boulevard and Sixty-seventh Street, where he finally turned his\r\nface Bowery-ward. Especially fatigued because of the wandering\r\npropensity which had seized him in the morning, he now half dragged his\r\nwet feet, shuffling the soles upon the sidewalk. An old, thin coat was\r\nturned up about his red ears\xe2\x80\x94his cracked derby hat was pulled down\r\nuntil it turned them outward. His hands were in his pockets.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll just go down Broadway,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to himself.\r\n\r\nWhen he reached Forty-second Street, the fire signs were already\r\nblazing brightly. Crowds were hastening to dine. Through bright\r\nwindows, at every corner, might be seen gay companies in luxuriant\r\nrestaurants. There were coaches and crowded cable cars.\r\n\r\nIn his weary and hungry state, he should never have come here. The\r\ncontrast was too sharp. Even he was recalled keenly to better things.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the use?\xe2\x80\x9d he thought. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s all up with me. I\xe2\x80\x99ll quit this.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPeople turned to look after him, so uncouth was his shambling figure.\r\nSeveral officers followed him with their eyes, to see that he did not\r\nbeg of anybody.\r\n\r\nOnce he paused in an aimless, incoherent sort of way and looked through\r\nthe windows of an imposing restaurant, before which blazed a fire sign,\r\nand through the large, plate windows of which could be seen the red and\r\ngold decorations, the palms, the white napery, and shining glassware,\r\nand, above all, the comfortable crowd. Weak as his mind had become, his\r\nhunger was sharp enough to show the importance of this. He stopped\r\nstock still, his frayed trousers soaking in the slush, and peered\r\nfoolishly in.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEat,\xe2\x80\x9d he mumbled. \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s right, eat. Nobody else wants any.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen his voice dropped even lower, and his mind half lost the fancy it\r\nhad.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s mighty cold,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cAwful cold.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt Broadway and Thirty-ninth Street was blazing, in incandescent fire,\r\nCarrie\xe2\x80\x99s name. \xe2\x80\x9cCarrie Madenda,\xe2\x80\x9d it read, \xe2\x80\x9cand the Casino Company.\xe2\x80\x9d All\r\nthe wet, snowy sidewalk was bright with this radiated fire. It was so\r\nbright that it attracted Hurstwood\xe2\x80\x99s gaze. He looked up, and then at a\r\nlarge, gilt-framed posterboard, on which was a fine lithograph of\r\nCarrie, lifesize.\r\n\r\nHurstwood gazed at it a moment, snuffling and hunching one shoulder, as\r\nif something were scratching him. He was so run down, however, that his\r\nmind was not exactly clear.\r\n\r\nHe approached that entrance and went in.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d said the attendant, staring at him. Seeing him pause, he went\r\nover and shoved him. \xe2\x80\x9cGet out of here,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI want to see Miss Madenda,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou do, eh?\xe2\x80\x9d the other said, almost tickled at the spectacle. \xe2\x80\x9cGet out\r\nof here,\xe2\x80\x9d and he shoved him again. Hurstwood had no strength to resist.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI want to see Miss Madenda,\xe2\x80\x9d he tried to explain, even as he was being\r\nhustled away. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m all right. I\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe man gave him a last push and closed the door. As he did so,\r\nHurstwood slipped and fell in the snow. It hurt him, and some vague\r\nsense of shame returned. He began to cry and swear foolishly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGod damned dog!\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cDamned old cur,\xe2\x80\x9d wiping the slush from his\r\nworthless coat. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x94I hired such people as you once.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNow a fierce feeling against Carrie welled up\xe2\x80\x94just one fierce, angry\r\nthought before the whole thing slipped out of his mind.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe owes me something to eat,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cShe owes it to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHopelessly he turned back into Broadway again and slopped onward and\r\naway, begging, crying, losing track of his thoughts, one after another,\r\nas a mind decayed and disjointed is wont to do.\r\n\r\nIt was truly a wintry evening, a few days later, when his one distinct\r\nmental decision was reached. Already, at four o\xe2\x80\x99clock, the sombre hue\r\nof night was thickening the air. A heavy snow was falling\xe2\x80\x94a fine\r\npicking, whipping snow, borne forward by a swift wind in long, thin\r\nlines. The streets were bedded with it\xe2\x80\x94six inches of cold, soft carpet,\r\nchurned to a dirty brown by the crush of teams and the feet of men.\r\nAlong Broadway men picked their way in ulsters and umbrellas. Along the\r\nBowery, men slouched through it with collars and hats pulled over their\r\nears. In the former thoroughfare businessmen and travellers were making\r\nfor comfortable hotels. In the latter, crowds on cold errands shifted\r\npast dingy stores, in the deep recesses of which lights were already\r\ngleaming. There were early lights in the cable cars, whose usual\r\nclatter was reduced by the mantle about the wheels. The whole city was\r\nmuffled by this fast-thickening mantle.\r\n\r\nIn her comfortable chambers at the Waldorf, Carrie was reading at this\r\ntime \xe2\x80\x9cP\xc3\xa8re Goriot,\xe2\x80\x9d which Ames had recommended to her. It was so\r\nstrong, and Ames\xe2\x80\x99s mere recommendation had so aroused her interest,\r\nthat she caught nearly the full sympathetic significance of it. For the\r\nfirst time, it was being borne in upon her how silly and worthless had\r\nbeen her earlier reading, as a whole. Becoming wearied, however, she\r\nyawned and came to the window, looking out upon the old winding\r\nprocession of carriages rolling up Fifth Avenue.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIsn\xe2\x80\x99t it bad?\xe2\x80\x9d she observed to Lola.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTerrible!\xe2\x80\x9d said that little lady, joining her. \xe2\x80\x9cI hope it snows enough\r\nto go sleigh riding.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, dear,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, with whom the sufferings of Father Goriot were\r\nstill keen. \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s all you think of. Aren\xe2\x80\x99t you sorry for the people\r\nwho haven\xe2\x80\x99t anything to-night?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course I am,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lola; \xe2\x80\x9cbut what can I do? I haven\xe2\x80\x99t anything.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCarrie smiled.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t care, if you had,\xe2\x80\x9d she returned.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI would, too,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lola. \xe2\x80\x9cBut people never gave me anything when I\r\nwas hard up.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIsn\xe2\x80\x99t it just awful?\xe2\x80\x9d said Carrie, studying the winter\xe2\x80\x99s storm.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLook at that man over there,\xe2\x80\x9d laughed Lola, who had caught sight of\r\nsome one falling down. \xe2\x80\x9cHow sheepish men look when they fall, don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nthey?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ll have to take a coach to-night,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Carrie absently.\r\n\r\n\r\nIn the lobby of the Imperial, Mr. Charles Drouet was just arriving,\r\nshaking the snow from a very handsome ulster. Bad weather had driven\r\nhim home early and stirred his desire for those pleasures which shut\r\nout the snow and gloom of life. A good dinner, the company of a young\r\nwoman, and an evening at the theatre were the chief things for him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, hello, Harry!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, addressing a lounger in one of the\r\ncomfortable lobby chairs. \xe2\x80\x9cHow are you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, about six and six,\xe2\x80\x9d said the other. \xe2\x80\x9cRotten weather, isn\xe2\x80\x99t it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I should say,\xe2\x80\x9d said the other. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve been just sitting here\r\nthinking where I\xe2\x80\x99d go to-night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome along with me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet. \xe2\x80\x9cI can introduce you to something\r\ndead swell.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho is it?\xe2\x80\x9d said the other.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, a couple of girls over here in Fortieth Street. We could have a\r\ndandy time. I was just looking for you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSupposing you get \xe2\x80\x99em and take \xe2\x80\x99em out to dinner?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSure,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet. \xe2\x80\x9cWait\xe2\x80\x99ll I go upstairs and change my clothes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I\xe2\x80\x99ll be in the barber shop,\xe2\x80\x9d said the other. \xe2\x80\x9cI want to get a\r\nshave.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right,\xe2\x80\x9d said Drouet, creaking off in his good shoes toward the\r\nelevator. The old butterfly was as light on the wing as ever.\r\n\r\n\r\nOn an incoming vestibuled Pullman, speeding at forty miles an hour\r\nthrough the snow of the evening, were three others, all related.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFirst call for dinner in the dining-car,\xe2\x80\x9d a Pullman servitor was\r\nannouncing, as he hastened through the aisle in snow-white apron and\r\njacket.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t believe I want to play any more,\xe2\x80\x9d said the youngest, a\r\nblack-haired beauty, turned supercilious by fortune, as she pushed a\r\neuchre hand away from her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall we go into dinner?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired her husband, who was all that fine\r\nraiment can make.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, not yet,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered. \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t want to play any more, though.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJessica,\xe2\x80\x9d said her mother, who was also a study in what good clothing\r\ncan do for age, \xe2\x80\x9cpush that pin down in your tie\xe2\x80\x94it\xe2\x80\x99s coming up.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nJessica obeyed, incidentally touching at her lovely hair and looking at\r\na little jewel-faced watch. Her husband studied her, for beauty, even\r\ncold, is fascinating from one point of view.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, we won\xe2\x80\x99t have much more of this weather,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cIt only\r\ntakes two weeks to get to Rome.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Hurstwood nestled comfortably in her corner and smiled. It was so\r\nnice to be the mother-in-law of a rich young man\xe2\x80\x94one whose financial\r\nstate had borne her personal inspection.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you suppose the boat will sail promptly?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Jessica, \xe2\x80\x9cif it\r\nkeeps up like this?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d answered her husband. \xe2\x80\x9cThis won\xe2\x80\x99t make any difference.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPassing down the aisle came a very fair-haired banker\xe2\x80\x99s son, also of\r\nChicago, who had long eyed this supercilious beauty. Even now he did\r\nnot hesitate to glance at her, and she was conscious of it. With a\r\nspecially conjured show of indifference, she turned her pretty face\r\nwholly away. It was not wifely modesty at all. By so much was her pride\r\nsatisfied.\r\n\r\n\r\nAt this moment Hurstwood stood before a dirty four story building in a\r\nside street quite near the Bowery, whose one-time coat of buff had been\r\nchanged by soot and rain. He mingled with a crowd of men\xe2\x80\x94a crowd which\r\nhad been, and was still, gathering by degrees.\r\n\r\nIt began with the approach of two or three, who hung about the closed\r\nwooden doors and beat their feet to keep them warm. They had on faded\r\nderby hats with dents in them. Their misfit coats were heavy with\r\nmelted snow and turned up at the collars. Their trousers were mere\r\nbags, frayed at the bottom and wobbling over big, soppy shoes, torn at\r\nthe sides and worn almost to shreds. They made no effort to go in, but\r\nshifted ruefully about, digging their hands deep in their pockets and\r\nleering at the crowd and the increasing lamps. With the minutes,\r\nincreased the number. There were old men with grizzled beards and\r\nsunken eyes, men who were comparatively young but shrunken by diseases,\r\nmen who were middle-aged. None were fat. There was a face in the thick\r\nof the collection which was as white as drained veal. There was another\r\nred as brick. Some came with thin, rounded shoulders, others with\r\nwooden legs, still others with frames so lean that clothes only flapped\r\nabout them. There were great ears, swollen noses, thick lips, and,\r\nabove all, red, blood-shot eyes. Not a normal, healthy face in the\r\nwhole mass; not a straight figure; not a straightforward, steady\r\nglance.\r\n\r\nIn the drive of the wind and sleet they pushed in on one another. There\r\nwere wrists, unprotected by coat or pocket, which were red with cold.\r\nThere were ears, half covered by every conceivable semblance of a hat,\r\nwhich still looked stiff and bitten. In the snow they shifted, now one\r\nfoot, now another, almost rocking in unison.\r\n\r\nWith the growth of the crowd about the door came a murmur. It was not\r\nconversation, but a running comment directed at any one in general. It\r\ncontained oaths and slang phrases.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy damn, I wish they\xe2\x80\x99d hurry up.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLook at the copper watchin\xe2\x80\x99.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMaybe it ain\xe2\x80\x99t winter, nuther!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wisht I was in Sing Sing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNow a sharper lash of wind cut down and they huddled closer. It was an\r\nedging, shifting, pushing throng. There was no anger, no pleading, no\r\nthreatening words. It was all sullen endurance, unlightened by either\r\nwit or good fellowship.\r\n\r\nA carriage went jingling by with some reclining figure in it. One of\r\nthe men nearest the door saw it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLook at the bloke ridin\xe2\x80\x99.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe ain\xe2\x80\x99t so cold.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEh, eh, eh!\xe2\x80\x9d yelled another, the carriage having long since passed out\r\nof hearing.\r\n\r\nLittle by little the night crept on. Along the walk a crowd turned out\r\non its way home. Men and shop-girls went by with quick steps. The\r\ncross-town cars began to be crowded. The gas lamps were blazing, and\r\nevery window bloomed ruddy with a steady flame. Still the crowd hung\r\nabout the door, unwavering.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAin\xe2\x80\x99t they ever goin\xe2\x80\x99 to open up?\xe2\x80\x9d queried a hoarse voice,\r\nsuggestively.\r\n\r\nThis seemed to renew the general interest in the closed door, and many\r\ngazed in that direction. They looked at it as dumb brutes look, as dogs\r\npaw and whine and study the knob. They shifted and blinked and\r\nmuttered, now a curse, now a comment. Still they waited and still the\r\nsnow whirled and cut them with biting flakes. On the old hats and\r\npeaked shoulders it was piling. It gathered in little heaps and curves\r\nand no one brushed it off. In the centre of the crowd the warmth and\r\nsteam melted it, and water trickled off hat rims and down noses, which\r\nthe owners could not reach to scratch. On the outer rim the piles\r\nremained unmelted. Hurstwood, who could not get in the centre, stood\r\nwith head lowered to the weather and bent his form.\r\n\r\nA light appeared through the transom overhead. It sent a thrill of\r\npossibility through the watchers. There was a murmur of recognition. At\r\nlast the bars grated inside and the crowd pricked up its ears.\r\nFootsteps shuffled within and it murmured again. Some one called: \xe2\x80\x9cSlow\r\nup there, now,\xe2\x80\x9d and then the door opened. It was push and jam for a\r\nminute, with grim, beast silence to prove its quality, and then it\r\nmelted inward, like logs floating, and disappeared. There were wet hats\r\nand wet shoulders, a cold, shrunken, disgruntled mass, pouring in\r\nbetween bleak walls. It was just six o\xe2\x80\x99clock and there was supper in\r\nevery hurrying pedestrian\xe2\x80\x99s face. And yet no supper was provided\r\nhere\xe2\x80\x94nothing but beds.\r\n\r\nHurstwood laid down his fifteen cents and crept off with weary steps to\r\nhis allotted room. It was a dingy affair\xe2\x80\x94wooden, dusty, hard. A small\r\ngas-jet furnished sufficient light for so rueful a corner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHm!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, clearing his throat and locking the door.\r\n\r\nNow he began leisurely to take off his clothes, but stopped first with\r\nhis coat, and tucked it along the crack under the door. His vest he\r\narranged in the same place. His old wet, cracked hat he laid softly\r\nupon the table. Then he pulled off his shoes and lay down.\r\n\r\nIt seemed as if he thought a while, for now he arose and turned the gas\r\nout, standing calmly in the blackness, hidden from view. After a few\r\nmoments, in which he reviewed nothing, but merely hesitated, he turned\r\nthe gas on again, but applied no match. Even then he stood there,\r\nhidden wholly in that kindness which is night, while the uprising fumes\r\nfilled the room. When the odour reached his nostrils, he quit his\r\nattitude and fumbled for the bed. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the use?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, weakly, as\r\nhe stretched himself to rest.\r\n\r\n\r\nAnd now Carrie had attained that which in the beginning seemed life\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nobject, or, at least, such fraction of it as human beings ever attain\r\nof their original desires. She could look about on her gowns and\r\ncarriage, her furniture and bank account. Friends there were, as the\r\nworld takes it\xe2\x80\x94those who would bow and smile in acknowledgment of her\r\nsuccess. For these she had once craved. Applause there was, and\r\npublicity\xe2\x80\x94once far off, essential things, but now grown trivial and\r\nindifferent. Beauty also\xe2\x80\x94her type of loveliness\xe2\x80\x94and yet she was lonely.\r\nIn her rocking-chair she sat, when not otherwise engaged\xe2\x80\x94singing and\r\ndreaming.\r\n\r\nThus in life there is ever the intellectual and the emotional\r\nnature\xe2\x80\x94the mind that reasons, and the mind that feels. Of one come the\r\nmen of action\xe2\x80\x94generals and statesmen; of the other, the poets and\r\ndreamers\xe2\x80\x94artists all.\r\n\r\nAs harps in the wind, the latter respond to every breath of fancy,\r\nvoicing in their moods all the ebb and flow of the ideal.\r\n\r\nMan has not yet comprehended the dreamer any more than he has the\r\nideal. For him the laws and morals of the world are unduly severe. Ever\r\nhearkening to the sound of beauty, straining for the flash of its\r\ndistant wings, he watches to follow, wearying his feet in travelling.\r\nSo watched Carrie, so followed, rocking and singing.\r\n\r\nAnd it must be remembered that reason had little part in this. Chicago\r\ndawning, she saw the city offering more of loveliness than she had ever\r\nknown, and instinctively, by force of her moods alone, clung to it. In\r\nfine raiment and elegant surroundings, men seemed to be contented.\r\nHence, she drew near these things. Chicago, New York; Drouet,\r\nHurstwood; the world of fashion and the world of stage\xe2\x80\x94these were but\r\nincidents. Not them, but that which they represented, she longed for.\r\nTime proved the representation false.\r\n\r\nOh, the tangle of human life! How dimly as yet we see. Here was Carrie,\r\nin the beginning poor, unsophisticated, emotional; responding with\r\ndesire to everything most lovely in life, yet finding herself turned as\r\nby a wall. Laws to say: \xe2\x80\x9cBe allured, if you will, by everything lovely,\r\nbut draw not nigh unless by righteousness.\xe2\x80\x9d Convention to say: \xe2\x80\x9cYou\r\nshall not better your situation save by honest labour.\xe2\x80\x9d If honest\r\nlabour be unremunerative and difficult to endure; if it be the long,\r\nlong road which never reaches beauty, but wearies the feet and the\r\nheart; if the drag to follow beauty be such that one abandons the\r\nadmired way, taking rather the despised path leading to her dreams\r\nquickly, who shall cast the first stone? Not evil, but longing for that\r\nwhich is better, more often directs the steps of the erring. Not evil,\r\nbut goodness more often allures the feeling mind unused to reason.\r\n\r\nAmid the tinsel and shine of her state walked Carrie, unhappy. As when\r\nDrouet took her, she had thought: \xe2\x80\x9cNow I am lifted into that which is\r\nbest\xe2\x80\x9d; as when Hurstwood seemingly offered her the better way: \xe2\x80\x9cNow am\r\nI happy.\xe2\x80\x9d But since the world goes its way past all who will not\r\npartake of its folly, she now found herself alone. Her purse was open\r\nto him whose need was greatest. In her walks on Broadway, she no longer\r\nthought of the elegance of the creatures who passed her. Had they more\r\nof that peace and beauty which glimmered afar off, then were they to be\r\nenvied.\r\n\r\nDrouet abandoned his claim and was seen no more. Of Hurstwood\xe2\x80\x99s death\r\nshe was not even aware. A slow, black boat setting out from the pier at\r\nTwenty-seventh Street upon its weekly errand bore, with many others,\r\nhis nameless body to the Potter\xe2\x80\x99s Field.\r\n\r\nThus passed all that was of interest concerning these twain in their\r\nrelation to her. Their influence upon her life is explicable alone by\r\nthe nature of her longings. Time was when both represented for her all\r\nthat was most potent in earthly success. They were the personal\r\nrepresentatives of a state most blessed to attain\xe2\x80\x94the titled\r\nambassadors of comfort and peace, aglow with their credentials. It is\r\nbut natural that when the world which they represented no longer\r\nallured her, its ambassadors should be discredited. Even had Hurstwood\r\nreturned in his original beauty and glory, he could not now have\r\nallured her. She had learned that in his world, as in her own present\r\nstate, was not happiness.\r\n\r\nSitting alone, she was now an illustration of the devious ways by which\r\none who feels, rather than reasons, may be led in the pursuit of\r\nbeauty. Though often disillusioned, she was still waiting for that\r\nhalcyon day when she would be led forth among dreams become real. Ames\r\nhad pointed out a farther step, but on and on beyond that, if\r\naccomplished, would lie others for her. It was forever to be the\r\npursuit of that radiance of delight which tints the distant hilltops of\r\nthe world.\r\n\r\nOh, Carrie, Carrie! Oh, blind strivings of the human heart! Onward\r\nonward, it saith, and where beauty leads, there it follows. Whether it\r\nbe the tinkle of a lone sheep bell o\xe2\x80\x99er some quiet landscape, or the\r\nglimmer of beauty in sylvan places, or the show of soul in some passing\r\neye, the heart knows and makes answer, following. It is when the feet\r\nweary and hope seems vain that the heartaches and the longings arise.\r\nKnow, then, that for you is neither surfeit nor content. In your\r\nrocking-chair, by your window dreaming, shall you long, alone. In your\r\nrocking-chair, by your window, shall you dream such happiness as you\r\nmay never feel.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n*** END OF THE PROJECT GUTENBERG EBOOK SISTER CARRIE ***\r\n\r\nUpdated editions will replace the previous one--the old editions will\r\nbe renamed.\r\n\r\nCreating the works from print editions not protected by U.S. copyright\r\nlaw means that no one owns a United States copyright in these works,\r\nso the Foundation (and you!) can copy and distribute it in the\r\nUnited States without permission and without paying copyright\r\nroyalties.
